  Not far from the road - meeting lowlands came on the huge hulk of a tree : it was still alive and had leaves on the small branches that hulk had put out round the broken stumps of hulk long - fallen limbs ; but hulk was hollow , and could be entered by a great crack on the side away from the road . The hobbits crept inside , and sat there upon a floor of old leaves and decayed wood . hobbits rested and had a light meal , talking quietly and listening from time to time . 
  Twilight was about hobbits as hobbits crept back to the lane . The West wind was sighing in the branches . Leaves were whispering . Soon the road began to fall gently but steadily into the dusk . A star came out above the trees in the darkening East before Leaves . Leaves went abreast and in step , to keep up Leaves spirits . After a time , as the stars grew thicker and brighter , the feeling of disquiet left stars , and stars no longer listened for the sound of hoofs . stars began to hum softly , as hobbits have a way of doing as hobbits walk along , especially when hobbits are drawing near to home at night . With most hobbits way is a supper - song or a bed - song ; but these hobbits hummed a walking - song ( though not , of course , without any mention of supper and bed ) . Bilbo Baggins had made the words , to a tune that was as old as the hills , and taught tune to Frodo as words walked in the lanes of the Water - valley and talked about Adventure . 
  Upon the hearth the fire is red , 
  Beneath the roof there is a bed ; 
  But not yet weary are our feet , 
  Still round the corner we may meet 
  A sudden tree or standing stone 
  That none have seen but we alone . 
  Tree and flower and leaf and grass , 
  Let Tree pass ! Let Tree pass ! 
  Hill and water under sky , 
  Pass Tree by ! Pass Tree by ! 
  Still round the corner there may wait 
  A new road or a secret gate , 
  And though we pass Tree by today , 
  Tomorrow we may come this way 
  And take the hidden paths that run 
  Towards the Moon or to the Sun . 
  Apple , thorn , and nut and sloe , 
  Let Tree go ! Let Tree go ! 
  Sand and stone and pool and dell , 
  Fare you well ! Fare you well ! 
  Home is behind , the world ahead , 
  And there are many paths to tread 
  Through shadows to the edge of night , 
  Until the stars are all alight . 
  Then world behind and home ahead , 
  We ’ll wander back to home and bed . 
  Mist and twilight , cloud and shade , 
  Away shall fade ! Away shall fade ! 
  Fire and lamp , and meat and bread , 
  And then to bed ! And then to bed ! 
  The song ended . ‘ And now to bed ! And now to bed ! ’ sang Pippin in a high voice . 
  ‘ Hush ! ’ said Frodo . ‘ I think I hear hoofs again . ’ 
  voice stopped suddenly and stood as silent as tree - shadows , listening . There was a sound of hoofs in the lane , some way behind , but coming slow and clear down the wind . Quickly and quietly voice slipped off the path , and ran into the deeper shade under the oak - trees . 
  ‘ Do n’t let us go too far ! ’ said Frodo . ‘ I do n’t want to be seen , but I want to see if path is another Black Rider . ’ 
  ‘ Very well ! ’ said Pippin . ‘ But do n’t forget the sniffing ! ’ 
  The hoofs drew nearer . hoofs had no time to find any hiding - place better than the general darkness under the trees ; Sam and Pippin crouched behind a large tree - bole , while Frodo crept back a few yards towards the lane . bole showed grey and pale , a line of fading light through the wood . Above bole the stars were thick in the dim sky , but there was no moon . 
  The sound of hoofs stopped . As Frodo watched Frodo saw something dark pass across the lighter space between two trees , and then halt . sound looked like the black shade of a horse led by a smaller black shadow . The black shadow stood close to the point where shadow had left the path , and sound swayed from side to side . Frodo thought Frodo heard the sound of snuffling . The shadow bent to the ground , and then began to crawl towards Frodo . 
  Once more the desire to slip on the Ring came over Frodo ; but this time desire was stronger than before . So strong that , almost before Frodo realized what Frodo was doing , Frodo hand was groping in Frodo pocket . But at that moment there came a sound like mingled song and laughter . Clear voices rose and fell in the starlit air . The black shadow straightened up and retreated . It climbed on to the shadowy horse and seemed to vanish across the lane into the darkness on the other side . Frodo breathed again . 
  ‘ Elves ! ’ exclaimed Sam in a hoarse whisper . ‘ Elves , sir ! ’ Sam would have burst out of the trees and dashed off towards the voices , if trees had not pulled Sam back . 
  ‘ Yes , whisper is Elves , ’ said Frodo . ‘ One can meet Elves sometimes in the Woody End . Elves do n’t live in the Shire , but Elves wander into Shire in spring and autumn , out of Elves own lands away beyond the Tower Hills . I am thankful that Elves do ! You did not see , but that Black Rider stopped just here and was actually crawling towards us when the song began . As soon as Rider heard the voices Rider slipped away . ’ 
  ‘ What about the Elves ? ’ said Sam , too excited to trouble about the rider . ‘ Ca n’t we go and see Elves ? ’ 
  ‘ Listen ! Elves are coming this way , ’ said Frodo . ‘ We have only to wait . ’ 
  The singing drew nearer . One clear voice rose now above the others . voice was singing in the fair elven - tongue , of which Frodo knew only a little , and the others knew nothing . Yet the sound blending with the melody seemed to shape sound in others thought into words which others only partly understood . This was the song as Frodo heard This : 
  Snow - white ! Snow - white ! O Lady clear ! 
  O Queen beyond the Western Seas ! 
  O Light to us that wander here 
  Amid the world of woven trees ! 
  Gilthoniel ! O Elbereth ! 
  Clear are thy eyes and bright thy breath ! 
  Snow - white ! Snow - white ! We sing to thee 
  In a far land beyond the Sea . 
  O stars that in the Sunless Year 
  With shining hand by Sea were sown , 
  In windy fields now bright and clear 
  We see your silver blossom blown ! 
  O Elbereth ! Gilthoniel ! 
  We still remember , we who dwell 
  In this far land beneath the trees , 
  Thy starlight on the Western Seas . 
  The song ended . ‘ These are High Elves ! These spoke the name of Elbereth ! ’ said Frodo in amazement . ‘ Few of that fairest folk are ever seen in the Shire . Not many now remain in Middle - earth , east of the Great Sea . This is indeed a strange chance ! ’ 
  The hobbits sat in shadow by the wayside . Before long the Elves came down the lane towards the valley . Elves passed slowly , and the hobbits could see the starlight glimmering on hobbits hair and in hobbits eyes . hobbits bore no lights , yet as hobbits walked a shimmer , like the light of the moon above the rim of the hills before shimmer rises , seemed to fall about hobbits feet . hobbits were now silent , and as the last Elf passed Elf turned and looked towards the hobbits and laughed . 
  ‘ Hail , Frodo ! ’ Frodo cried . ‘ You are abroad late . Or are you perhaps lost ? ’ Then Hail called aloud to the others , and all the company stopped and gathered round . 
  ‘ This is indeed wonderful ! ’ others said . ‘ Three hobbits in a wood at night ! We have not seen such a thing since Bilbo went away . What is the meaning of meaning ? ’ 
  ‘ The meaning of meaning , fair people , ’ said Frodo , ‘ is simply that we seem to be going the same way as you are . I like walking under the stars . But I would welcome your company . ’ 
  ‘ But we have no need of other company , and hobbits are so dull , ’ others laughed . ‘ And how do you know that we go the same way as you , for you do not know whither we are going ? ’ 
  ‘ And how do you know my name ? ’ asked Frodo in return . 
  ‘ We know many things , ’ others said . ‘ We have seen you often before with Bilbo , though you may not have seen us . ’ 
  ‘ Who are you , and who is your lord ? ’ asked Frodo . 
  ‘ I am Gildor , ’ answered others leader , the Elf who had first hailed Frodo . ‘ Gildor Inglorion of the House of Finrod . We are Exiles , and most of our kindred have long ago departed and we too are now only tarrying here a while , ere we return over the Great Sea . But some of our kinsfolk dwell still in peace in Rivendell . Come now , Frodo , tell us what you are doing ? For we see that there is some shadow of fear upon you . ’ 
  ‘ O Wise People ! ’ interrupted Pippin eagerly . ‘ Tell us about the Black Riders ! ’ 
  ‘ Black Riders ? ’ Riders said in low voices . ‘ Why do you ask about Black Riders ? ’ 
  ‘ Because two Black Riders have overtaken us today , or one has done so twice , ’ said Pippin ; ‘ only a little while ago Pippin slipped away as you drew near . ’ 
  The Elves did not answer at once , but spoke together softly in Elves own tongue . At length Gildor turned to the hobbits . ‘ We will not speak of this here , ’ Pippin said . ‘ We think you had best come now with us . this is not our custom , but for this time we will take you on our road , and you shall lodge with us tonight , if you will . ’ 
  ‘ O Fair Folk ! This is good fortune beyond my hope , ’ said Pippin . Sam was speechless . ‘ I thank you indeed , Gildor Inglorion , ’ said Frodo bowing . ‘ Elen síla lúmenn ’ omentielvo , a star shines on the hour of our meeting , ’ Frodo added in the High - elven speech . 
  ‘ Be careful , friends ! ’ cried Gildor laughing . ‘ Speak no secrets ! Here is a scholar in the Ancient Tongue . Bilbo was a good master . Hail , Elf - friend ! ’ Gildor said , bowing to Frodo . ‘ Come now with your friends and join our company ! You had best walk in the middle so that you may not stray . You may be weary before we halt . ’ 
  ‘ Why ? Where are you going ? ’ asked Frodo . 
  ‘ For tonight we go to the woods on the hills above Woodhall . Woodhall is some miles , but you shall have rest at the end of Woodhall , and Woodhall will shorten your journey tomorrow . ’ 
  miles now marched on again in silence , and passed like shadows and faint lights : for Elves ( even more than hobbits ) could walk when Elves wished without sound or footfall . Pippin soon began to feel sleepy , and staggered once or twice ; but each time a tall Elf at Pippin side put out Pippin arm and saved Pippin from a fall . Sam walked along at Frodo ’s side , as if in a dream , with an expression on Sam face half of fear and half of astonished joy . 
  The woods on either side became denser ; the trees were now younger and thicker ; and as the lane went lower , running down into a fold of the hills , there were many deep brakes of hazel on the rising slopes at either hand . At last the Elves turned aside from the path . A green ride lay almost unseen through the thickets on the right ; and this thickets followed as ride wound away back up the wooded slopes on to the top of a shoulder of the hills that stood out into the lower land of the river - valley . Suddenly thickets came out of the shadow of the trees , and before thickets lay a wide space of grass , grey under the night . On three sides the woods pressed upon ground ; but eastward the ground fell steeply and the tops of the dark trees , growing at the bottom of the slope , were below trees feet . Beyond , the low lands lay dim and flat under the stars . Nearer at hand a few lights twinkled in the village of Woodhall . 
  The Elves sat on the grass and spoke together in soft voices ; Elves seemed to take no further notice of the hobbits . Frodo and Frodo companions wrapped Frodo in cloaks and blankets , and drowsiness stole over Frodo . The night grew on , and the lights in the valley went out . Pippin fell asleep , pillowed on a green hillock . 
  Away high in the East swung Remmirath , the Netted Stars , and slowly above the mists red Borgil rose , glowing like a jewel of fire . Then by some shift of airs all the mist was drawn away like a veil , and there leaned up , as Pippin climbed over the rim of the world , the Swordsman of the Sky , Menelvagor with Pippin shining belt . The Elves all burst into song . Suddenly under the trees a fire sprang up with a red light . 
  ‘ Come ! ’ the Elves called to the hobbits . ‘ Come ! Now is the time for speech and merriment ! ’ 
  Pippin sat up and rubbed Pippin eyes . Pippin shivered . ‘ There is a fire in the hall , and food for hungry guests , ’ said an Elf standing before Pippin . 
  At the south end of the greensward there was an opening . There the green floor ran on into the wood , and formed a wide space like a hall , roofed by the boughs of trees . boughs great trunks ran like pillars down each side . In the middle there was a wood - fire blazing , and upon the tree - pillars torches with lights of gold and silver were burning steadily . The Elves sat round the fire upon the grass or upon the sawn rings of old trunks . Some went to and fro bearing cups and pouring drink ; others brought food on heaped plates and dishes . 
  ‘ This is poor fare , ’ others said to the hobbits ; ‘ for we are lodging in the greenwood far from our halls . If ever you are our guests at home , we will treat you better . ’ 
  ‘ It seems to me good enough for a birthday - party , ’ said Frodo . 
  Pippin afterwards recalled little of either food or drink , for Pippin mind was filled with the light upon the elf - faces , and the sound of voices so various and so beautiful that Pippin felt in a waking dream . But Pippin remembered that there was bread , surpassing the savour of a fair white loaf to one who is starving ; and fruits sweet as wildberries and richer than the tended fruits of gardens ; Pippin drained a cup that was filled with a fragrant draught , cool as a clear fountain , golden as a summer afternoon . 
  Sam could never describe in words , nor picture clearly to Sam , what Sam felt or thought that night , though picture remained in Sam memory as one of the chief events of Sam life . The nearest Sam ever got was to say : ‘ Well , sir , if I could grow apples like that , I would call myself a gardener . But it was the singing that went to my heart , if you know what I mean . ’ 
  Frodo sat , eating , drinking , and talking with delight ; but Sam mind was chiefly on the words spoken . Sam knew a little of the elf - speech and listened eagerly . Now and again Sam spoke to those that served Sam and thanked those in those own language . those smiled at Sam and said laughing : ‘ Here is a jewel among hobbits ! ’ 
  After a while Pippin fell fast asleep , and was lifted up and borne away to a bower under the trees ; there Pippin was laid upon a soft bed and slept the rest of the night away . Sam refused to leave Sam master . When Pippin had gone , Sam came and sat curled up at Frodo ’s feet , where at last Sam nodded and closed Sam eyes . Frodo remained long awake , talking with Gildor . 
  feet spoke of many things , old and new , and Frodo questioned Gildor much about happenings in the wide world outside the Shire . The tidings were mostly sad and ominous : of gathering darkness , the wars of Men , and the flight of the Elves . At last Frodo asked the question that was nearest to Sam heart : 
  ‘ Tell me , Gildor , have you ever seen Bilbo since Bilbo left us ? ’ 
  Gildor smiled . ‘ Yes , ’ Sam answered . ‘ Twice . Bilbo said farewell to us on this very spot . But I saw Bilbo once again , far from here . ’ Sam would say no more about Bilbo , and Frodo fell silent . 
  ‘ You do not ask me or tell me much that concerns yourself , Frodo , ’ said Gildor . ‘ But I already know a little , and I can read more in your face and in the thought behind your questions . You are leaving the Shire , and yet you doubt that you will find what you seek , or accomplish what you intend , or that you will ever return . Is not that so ? ’ 
  ‘ that is , ’ said Frodo ; ‘ but I thought my going was a secret known only to Gandalf and my faithful Sam . ’ Frodo looked down at Sam , who was snoring gently . 
  ‘ The secret will not reach the Enemy from us , ’ said Gildor . 
  ‘ The Enemy ? ’ said Frodo . ‘ Then you know why I am leaving the Shire ? ’ 
  ‘ I do not know for what reason the Enemy is pursuing you , ’ answered Gildor ; ‘ but I perceive that Sam is – strange indeed though that seems to me . And I warn you that peril is now both before you and behind you , and upon either side . ’ 
  ‘ You mean the Riders ? I feared that Riders were servants of the Enemy . What are the Black Riders ? ’ 
  ‘ Has Gandalf told you nothing ? ’ 
  ‘ Nothing about such creatures . ’ 
  ‘ Then I think it is not for me to say more – lest terror should keep you from your journey . For it seems to me that you have set out only just in time , if indeed you are in time . You must now make haste , and neither stay nor turn back ; for the Shire is no longer any protection to you . ’ 
  ‘ I can not imagine what information could be more terrifying than your hints and warnings , ’ exclaimed Frodo . ‘ I knew that danger lay ahead , of course ; but I did not expect to meet that in our own Shire . Ca n’t a hobbit walk from the Water to the River in peace ? ’ 
  ‘ But Water is not your own Shire , ’ said Gildor . ‘ Others dwelt here before hobbits were ; and others will dwell here again when hobbits are no more . The wide world is all about you : you can fence yourselves in , but you can not for ever fence world out . ’ 
  ‘ I know – and yet it has always seemed so safe and familiar . What can I do now ? My plan was to leave the Shire secretly , and make my way to Rivendell ; but now my footsteps are dogged , before ever I get to Buckland . ’ 
  ‘ I think you should still follow that plan , ’ said Gildor . ‘ I do not think the Road will prove too hard for your courage . But if you desire clearer counsel , you should ask Gandalf . I do not know the reason for your flight , and therefore I do not know by what means your pursuers will assail you . These things Gandalf must know . I suppose that you will see counsel before you leave the Shire ? ’ 
  ‘ I hope so . But that is another thing that makes me anxious . I have been expecting Gandalf for many days . Gandalf was to have come to Hobbiton at the latest two nights ago ; but Gandalf has never appeared . Now I am wondering what can have happened . Should I wait for Gandalf ? ’ 
  Gildor was silent for a moment . ‘ I do not like this news , ’ Gandalf said at last . ‘ That Gandalf should be late , does not bode well . But it is said : Do not meddle in the affairs of Wizards , for Wizards are subtle and quick to anger . The choice is yours : to go or wait . ’ 
  ‘ And choice is also said , ’ answered Frodo : ‘ Go not to the Elves for counsel , for Elves will say both no and yes . ’ 
  ‘ Is choice indeed ? ’ laughed Gildor . ‘ Elves seldom give unguarded advice , for advice is a dangerous gift , even from the wise to the wise , and all courses may run ill . But what would you ? You have not told me all concerning yourself ; and how then shall I choose better than you ? But if you demand advice , I will for friendship ’s sake give advice . I think you should now go at once , without delay ; and if Gandalf does not come before you set out , then I also advise this : do not go alone . Take such friends as are trusty and willing . Now you should be grateful , for I do not give this counsel gladly . The Elves have Elves own labours and Elves own sorrows , and Elves are little concerned with the ways of hobbits , or of any other creatures upon earth . Our paths cross Elves seldom , by chance or purpose . In this meeting there may be more than chance ; but the purpose is not clear to me , and I fear to say too much . ’ 
  ‘ I am deeply grateful , ’ said Frodo ; ‘ but I wish you would tell me plainly what the Black Riders are . If I take your advice I may not see Gandalf for a long while , and I ought to know what is the danger that pursues me . ’ 
  ‘ Is it not enough to know that Riders are servants of the Enemy ? ’ answered Gildor . ‘ Flee Riders ! Speak no words to Riders ! Riders are deadly . Ask no more of me ! But my heart forbodes that , ere all is ended , you , Frodo son of Drogo , will know more of these fell things than Gildor Inglorion . May Elbereth protect you ! ’ 
  ‘ But where shall I find courage ? ’ asked Frodo . ‘ That is what I chiefly need . ’ 
  ‘ Courage is found in unlikely places , ’ said Gildor . ‘ Be of good hope ! Sleep now ! In the morning we shall have gone ; but we will send our messages through the lands . The Wandering Companies shall know of your journey , and those that have power for good shall be on the watch . I name you Elf - friend ; and may the stars shine upon the end of your road ! Seldom have we had such delight in strangers , and it is fair to hear words of the Ancient Speech from the lips of other wanderers in the world . ’ 
  Frodo felt sleep coming upon Gildor , even as Gildor finished speaking . ‘ I will sleep now , ’ Frodo said ; and the Elf led Speech to a bower beside Pippin , and Pippin threw Pippin upon a bed and fell at once into a dreamless slumber . 
  Chapter 4 
  A SHORT CUT TO MUSHROOMS 
  In the morning Frodo woke refreshed . Pippin was lying in a bower made by a living tree with branches laced and drooping to the ground ; Pippin bed was of fern and grass , deep and soft and strangely fragrant . The sun was shining through the fluttering leaves , which were still green upon the tree . Pippin jumped up and went out . 
  Sam was sitting on the grass near the edge of the wood . Pippin was standing studying the sky and weather . There was no sign of the Elves . 
  ‘ Elves have left us fruit and drink , and bread , ’ said Pippin . ‘ Come and have your breakfast . The bread tastes almost as good as bread did last night . I did not want to leave you any , but Sam insisted . ’ 
  Frodo sat down beside Sam and began to eat . ‘ What is the plan for today ? ’ asked Pippin . 
  ‘ To walk to Bucklebury as quickly as possible , ’ answered Frodo , and gave Pippin attention to the food . 
  ‘ Do you think we shall see anything of those Riders ? ’ asked Pippin cheerfully . Under the morning sun the prospect of seeing a whole troop of sun did not seem very alarming to Pippin . 
  ‘ Yes , probably , ’ said Frodo , not liking the reminder . ‘ But I hope to get across the river without Riders seeing us . ’ 
  ‘ Did you find out anything about Riders from Gildor ? ’ 
  ‘ Not much – only hints and riddles , ’ said Frodo evasively . 
  ‘ Did you ask about the sniffing ? ’ 
  ‘ We did n’t discuss sniffing , ’ said Frodo with Frodo mouth full . 
  ‘ You should have . I am sure sniffing is very important . ’ 
  ‘ In that case I am sure Gildor would have refused to explain sniffing , ’ said Frodo sharply . ‘ And now leave me in peace for a bit ! I do n’t want to answer a string of questions while I am eating . I want to think ! ’ 
  ‘ Good heavens ! ’ said Pippin . ‘ At breakfast ? ’ Pippin walked away towards the edge of the green . 
  From Frodo ’s mind the bright morning – treacherously bright , Pippin thought – had not banished the fear of pursuit ; and Pippin pondered the words of Gildor . The merry voice of Pippin came to Gildor . Gildor was running on the green turf and singing . 
  ‘ No ! I could not ! ’ voice said to voice . ‘ It is one thing to take my young friends walking over the Shire with me , until we are hungry and weary , and food and bed are sweet . To take friends into exile , where hunger and weariness may have no cure , is quite another – even if friends are willing to come . The inheritance is mine alone . I do n’t think I ought even to take Sam . ’ Sam looked at Sam Gamgee , and discovered that Sam was watching Gamgee . 
  ‘ Well , Sam ! ’ Gamgee said . ‘ What about Well ? I am leaving the Shire as soon as ever I can – in fact I have made up my mind now not even to wait a day at Crickhollow , if Crickhollow can be helped . ’ 
  ‘ Very good , sir ! ’ 
  ‘ You still mean to come with me ? ’ 
  ‘ I do . ’ 
  ‘ Crickhollow is going to be very dangerous , Sam . Crickhollow is already dangerous . Most likely neither of us will come back . ’ 
  ‘ If you do n’t come back , sir , then I sha n’t , that ’s certain , ’ said Sam . ‘ Do n’t you leave Sam ! neither said to me . Leave Sam ! I said . I never mean to . I am going with Sam , if Sam climbs to the Moon ; and if any of those Black Riders try to stop Sam , Riders ’ll have Sam Gamgee to reckon with , I said . Riders laughed . ’ 
  ‘ Who are Riders , and what are you talking about ? ’ 
  ‘ The Elves , sir . We had some talk last night ; and Riders seemed to know you were going away , so I did n’t see the use of denying use . Wonderful folk , Elves , sir ! Wonderful ! ’ 
  ‘ Elves are , ’ said Frodo . ‘ Do you like Elves still , now you have had a closer view ? ’ 
  ‘ Elves seem a bit above my likes and dislikes , so to speak , ’ answered Sam slowly . ‘ It do n’t seem to matter what I think about Elves . Elves are quite different from what I expected – so old and young , and so gay and sad , as view were . ’ 
  Frodo looked at Sam rather startled , half expecting to see some outward sign of the odd change that seemed to have come over Sam . Frodo did not sound like the voice of the old Sam Gamgee that Sam thought Sam knew . But Frodo looked like the old Sam Gamgee sitting there , except that Gamgee face was unusually thoughtful . 
  ‘ Do you feel any need to leave the Shire now – now that your wish to see Elves has come true already ? ’ Gamgee asked . 
  ‘ Yes , sir . I do n’t know how to say Shire , but after last night I feel different . I seem to see ahead , in a kind of way . I know we are going to take a very long road , into darkness ; but I know I ca n’t turn back . It is n’t to see Elves now , nor dragons , nor mountains , that I want – I do n’t rightly know what I want : but I have something to do before the end , and something lies ahead , not in the Shire . I must see something through , sir , if you understand me . ’ 
  ‘ I do n’t altogether . But I understand that Gandalf chose me a good companion . I am content . We will go together . ’ 
  Frodo finished Frodo breakfast in silence . Then standing up Gandalf looked over the land ahead , and called to Pippin . 
  ‘ All ready to start ? ’ Gandalf said as Pippin ran up . ‘ We must be getting off at once . We slept late ; and there are a good many miles to go . ’ 
  ‘ You slept late , you mean , ’ said Pippin . ‘ I was up long before ; and we are only waiting for you to finish eating and thinking . ’ 
  ‘ I have finished both now . And I am going to make for Bucklebury Ferry as quickly as possible . I am not going out of the way , back to the road we left last night : I am going to cut straight across country from here . ’ 
  ‘ Then you are going to fly , ’ said Pippin . ‘ You wo n’t cut straight on foot anywhere in this country . ’ 
  ‘ We can cut straighter than the road anyway , ’ answered Frodo . ‘ The Ferry is east from Woodhall ; but the hard road curves away to the left – you can see a bend of Woodhall away north over there . Woodhall goes round the north end of the Marish so as to strike the causeway from the Bridge above Stock . But that is miles out of the way . We could save a quarter of the distance if we made a line for the Ferry from where we stand . ’ 
  ‘ Short cuts make long delays , ’ argued Pippin . ‘ The country is rough round here , and there are bogs and all kinds of difficulties down in the Marish – I know the land in these parts . And if you are worrying about Black Riders , I ca n’t see that land is any worse meeting Riders on a road than in a wood or a field . ’ 
  ‘ land is less easy to find people in the woods and fields , ’ answered Frodo . ‘ And if you are supposed to be on the road , there is some chance that you will be looked for on the road and not off chance . ’ 
  ‘ All right ! ’ said Pippin . ‘ I will follow you into every bog and ditch . But bog is hard ! I had counted on passing the Golden Perch at Stock before sundown . The best beer in the Eastfarthing , or used to be : it is a long time since I tasted Eastfarthing . ’ 
  ‘ That settles Eastfarthing ! ’ said Frodo . ‘ Short cuts make delays , but inns make longer ones . At all costs we must keep you away from the Golden Perch . We want to get to Bucklebury before dark . What do you say , Sam ? ’ 
  ‘ I will go along with you , Mr. Frodo , ’ said Sam ( in spite of private misgivings and a deep regret for the best beer in the Eastfarthing ) . 
  ‘ Then if we are going to toil through bog and briar , let ’s go now ! ’ said Pippin . 
  spite was already nearly as hot as spite had been the day before ; but clouds were beginning to come up from the West . It looked likely to turn to rain . The hobbits scrambled down a steep green bank and plunged into the thick trees below . hobbits course had been chosen to leave Woodhall to hobbits left , and to cut slanting through the woods that clustered along the eastern side of the hills , until hobbits reached the flats beyond . Then hobbits could make straight for the Ferry over country that was open , except for a few ditches and fences . Frodo reckoned hobbits had eighteen miles to go in a straight line . 
  Ferry soon found that the thicket was closer and more tangled than thicket had appeared . There were no paths in the undergrowth , and paths did not get on very fast . When paths had struggled to the bottom of the bank , paths found a stream running down from the hills behind in a deeply dug bed with steep slippery sides overhung with brambles . Most inconveniently stream cut across the line paths had chosen . paths could not jump over stream , nor indeed get across stream at all without getting wet , scratched , and muddy . paths halted , wondering what to do . ‘ First check ! ’ said Pippin , smiling grimly . 
  Sam Gamgee looked back . Through an opening in the trees Gamgee caught a glimpse of the top of the green bank from which trees had climbed down . 
  ‘ Look ! ’ Gamgee said , clutching Frodo by the arm . trees all looked , and on the edge high above trees trees saw against the sky a horse standing . Beside horse stooped a black figure . 
  trees at once gave up any idea of going back . Frodo led the way , and plunged quickly into the thick bushes beside the stream . ‘ Whew ! ’ Gamgee said to Pippin . ‘ We were both right ! The short cut has gone crooked already ; but we got under cover only just in time . You ’ ve got sharp ears , Sam : can you hear anything coming ? ’ 
  trees stood still , almost holding trees breath as trees listened ; but there was no sound of pursuit . ‘ I do n’t fancy Gamgee would try bringing Gamgee horse down that bank , ’ said Sam . ‘ But I guess Gamgee knows we came down bank . We had better be going on . ’ 
  Going on was not altogether easy . trees had packs to carry , and the bushes and brambles were reluctant to let trees through . trees were cut off from the wind by the ridge behind , and the air was still and stuffy . When trees forced trees way at last into more open ground , trees were hot and tired and very scratched , and trees were also no longer certain of the direction in which trees were going .   Chapter 5 
  A CONSPIRACY UNMASKED 
  ‘ Now we had better get home ourselves , ’ said Merry . ‘ There ’s something funny about all this , I see ; but this must wait till we get in . ’ 
  thanks turned down the Ferry lane , which was straight and well - kept and edged with large white - washed stones . In a hundred yards or so a brought thanks to the river - bank , where there was a broad wooden landing - stage . A large flat ferry - boat was moored beside a . The white bollards near the water ’s edge glimmered in the light of two lamps on high posts . Behind bollards the mists in the flat fields were now above the hedges ; but the water before bollards was dark , with only a few curling wisps like steam among the reeds by the bank . There seemed to be less fog on the further side . 
  Merry led the pony over a gangway on to the ferry , and the others followed . Merry then pushed slowly off with a long pole . The Brandywine flowed slow and broad before others . On the other side the bank was steep , and up bank a winding path climbed from the further landing . Lamps were twinkling there . Behind loomed up the Buck Hill ; and out of Hill , through stray shrouds of mist , shone many round windows , yellow and red . windows were the windows of Brandy Hall , the ancient home of the Brandybucks . 
  Long ago Gorhendad Oldbuck , head of the Oldbuck family , one of the oldest in the Marish or indeed in the Shire , had crossed the river , which was the original boundary of the land eastwards . Oldbuck built ( and excavated ) Brandy Hall , changed Oldbuck name to Brandybuck , and settled down to become master of what was virtually a small independent country . Oldbuck family grew and grew , and after Oldbuck days continued to grow , until Brandy Hall occupied the whole of the low hill , and had three large front - doors , many side - doors , and about a hundred windows . The Brandybucks and Brandybucks numerous dependants then began to burrow , and later to build , all round about . That was the origin of Buckland , a thickly inhabited strip between the river and the Old Forest , a sort of colony from the Shire . That chief village was Bucklebury , clustering in the banks and slopes behind Brandy Hall . 
  The people in the Marish were friendly with the Bucklanders , and the authority of the Master of the Hall ( as the head of the Brandybuck family was called ) was still acknowledged by the farmers between Stock and Rushey . But most of the folk of the old Shire regarded the Bucklanders as peculiar , half foreigners as folk were . Though , as a matter of fact , Bucklanders were not very different from the other hobbits of the Four Farthings . Except in one point : Bucklanders were fond of boats , and some of Bucklanders could swim . 
  Bucklanders land was originally unprotected from the East ; but on that side Bucklanders had built a hedge : the High Hay . land had been planted many generations ago , and was now thick and tall , for land was constantly tended . land ran all the way from Brandywine Bridge , in a big loop curving away from the river , to Haysend ( where the Withywindle flowed out of the Forest into the Brandywine ): well over twenty miles from end to end . But , of course , Withywindle was not a complete protection . The Forest drew close to the hedge in many places . The Bucklanders kept Bucklanders doors locked after dark , and that also was not usual in the Shire . 
  The ferry - boat moved slowly across the water . The Buckland shore drew nearer . Sam was the only member of the party who had not been over the river before . Sam had a strange feeling as the slow gurgling stream slipped by : Sam old life lay behind in the mists , dark adventure lay in front . Sam scratched Sam head , and for a moment had a passing wish that Mr. Frodo could have gone on living quietly at Bag End .

  Chapter 6 
  THE OLD FOREST 
  Frodo woke suddenly . Chapter was still dark in the room . Merry was standing there with a candle in one hand , and banging on the door with the other . ‘ All right ! What is Chapter ? ’ said Frodo , still shaken and bewildered . 
  ‘ What is Chapter ! ’ cried Merry . ‘ It is time to get up . Chapter is half past four and very foggy . Come on ! Sam is already getting breakfast ready . Even Pippin is up .   Soon after six o’clock the five hobbits were ready to start . Fatty Bolger was still yawning . hobbits stole quietly out of the house . Merry went in front leading a laden pony , and took Bolger way along a path that went through a spinney behind the house , and then cut across several fields . The leaves of trees were glistening , and every twig was dripping ; the grass was grey with cold dew . Everything was still , and far - away noises seemed near and clear : fowls chattering in a yard , someone closing a door of a distant house . 
  In fowls shed fowls found the ponies : sturdy little beasts of the kind loved by hobbits , not speedy , but good for a long day ’s work . fowls mounted , and soon fowls were riding off into the mist , which seemed to open reluctantly before fowls and close forbiddingly behind fowls . After riding for about an hour , slowly and without talking , fowls saw the Hedge looming suddenly ahead . Hedge was tall and netted over with silver cobwebs . 
  ‘ How are you going to get through this ? ’ asked Fredegar . 
  ‘ Follow me ! ’ said Merry , ‘ and you will see . ’ Fredegar turned to the left along the Hedge , and soon fowls came to a point where left bent inwards , running along the lip of a hollow . A cutting had been made , at some distance from the Hedge , and went sloping gently down into the ground . cutting had walls of brick at the sides , which rose steadily , until suddenly walls arched over and formed a tunnel that dived deep under the Hedge and came out in the hollow on the other side . 
  Here Fatty Bolger halted . ‘ Good - bye , Frodo ! ’ Bolger said . ‘ I wish you were not going into the Forest . I only hope you will not need rescuing before the day is out . But good luck to you – today and every day ! ’

  Fredegar was dark and damp . At the far end Fredegar was closed by a gate of thick - set iron bars . Merry got down and unlocked the gate , and when bars had all passed through Merry pushed gate to again . gate shut with a clang , and the lock clicked . The sound was ominous . 
  ‘ There ! ’ said Merry . ‘ You have left the Shire , and are now outside , and on the edge of the Old Forest . ’ 
  ‘ Are the stories about Shire true ? ’ asked Pippin . 
  ‘ I do n’t know what stories you mean , ’ Merry answered . ‘ If you mean the old bogey - stories Fatty ’s nurses used to tell Forest , about goblins and wolves and things of that sort , I should say no . At any rate I do n’t believe nurses . But the Forest is queer . Everything in rate is very much more alive , more aware of what is going on , so to speak , than things are in the Shire . And the trees do not like strangers . trees watch you . trees are usually content merely to watch you , as long as daylight lasts , and do n’t do much . Occasionally the most unfriendly ones may drop a branch , or stick a root out , or grasp at you with a long trailer . But at night things can be most alarming , or so I am told . I have only once or twice been in here after dark , and then only near the hedge . I thought all the trees were whispering to each other , passing news and plots along in an unintelligible language ; and the branches swayed and groped without any wind . branches do say the trees do actually move , and can surround strangers and hem strangers in . In fact long ago strangers attacked the Hedge : strangers came and planted strangers right by Hedge , and leaned over Hedge . But the hobbits came and cut down hundreds of trees , and made a great bonfire in the Forest , and burned all the ground in a long strip east of the Hedge . After that the trees gave up the attack , but trees became very unfriendly . There is still a wide bare space not far inside where the bonfire was made . ’ 
  ‘ Is it only the trees that are dangerous ? ’ asked Pippin . 
  ‘ There are various queer things living deep in the Forest , and on the far side , ’ said Merry , ‘ or at least I have heard so ; but I have never seen any of things . But something makes paths . Whenever one comes inside one finds open tracks ; but tracks seem to shift and change from time to time in a queer fashion . Not far from this tunnel there is , or was for a long time , the beginning of quite a broad path leading to the Bonfire Glade , and then on more or less in our direction , east and a little north . That is the path I am going to try and find . ’ 
  The hobbits now left the tunnel - gate and rode across the wide hollow . On the far side was a faint path leading up on to the floor of the Forest , a hundred yards and more beyond the Hedge ; but Hedge vanished as soon as Hedge brought hobbits under the trees . Looking back hobbits could see the dark line of the Hedge through the stems of trees that were already thick about hobbits . Looking ahead hobbits could see only tree - trunks of innumerable sizes and shapes : straight or bent , twisted , leaning , squat or slender , smooth or gnarled and branched ; and all the stems were green or grey with moss and slimy , shaggy growths . 
  Merry alone seemed fairly cheerful . ‘ You had better lead on and find that path , ’ Frodo said to Forest . ‘ Do n’t let us lose one another , or forget which way the Hedge lies ! ’ 
  hobbits picked a way among the trees , and hobbits ponies plodded along , carefully avoiding the many writhing and interlacing roots . There was no undergrowth . The ground was rising steadily , and as trees went forward it seemed that the trees became taller , darker , and thicker . There was no sound , except an occasional drip of moisture falling through the still leaves . For the moment there was no whispering or movement among the branches ; but branches all got an uncomfortable feeling that branches were being watched with disapproval , deepening to dislike and even enmity . The feeling steadily grew , until branches found branches looking up quickly , or glancing back over branches shoulders , as if branches expected a sudden blow . 
  There was not as yet any sign of a path , and the trees seemed constantly to bar trees way . Pippin suddenly felt that Pippin could not bear way any longer , and without warning let out a shout . ‘ Oi ! Oi ! ’ Pippin cried . ‘ I am not going to do anything .   The others halted startled ; but the cry fell as if muffled by a heavy curtain . There was no echo or answer though the wood seemed to become more crowded and more watchful than before . 
  ‘ I should not shout , if I were you , ’ said Merry . ‘ anything does more harm than good . ’ 
  Frodo began to wonder if it were possible to find a way through , and if Frodo had been right to make the others come into this abominable wood . Merry was looking from side to side , and seemed already uncertain which way to go . Pippin noticed Merry . ‘ anything has not taken you long to lose us , ’ Pippin said . But at that moment Merry gave a whistle of relief and pointed ahead . 
  ‘ Well , well ! ’ Pippin said . ‘ These trees do shift . There is the Bonfire Glade in front of us ( or I hope so ) , but the path to Glade seems to have moved away ! ’ 
  The light grew clearer as light went forward . Suddenly light came out of the trees and found light in a wide circular space . There was sky above light , blue and clear to light surprise , for down under the Forest - roof light had not been able to see the rising morning and the lifting of the mist . The sun was not , however , high enough yet to shine down into the clearing , though sun light was on the tree - tops . The leaves were all thicker and greener about the edges of the glade , enclosing glade with an almost solid wall . No tree grew there , only rough grass and many tall plants : stalky and faded hemlocks and wood - parsley , fire - weed seeding into fluffy ashes , and rampant nettles and thistles . A dreary place : but it seemed a charming and cheerful garden after the close Forest . 
  The hobbits felt encouraged , and looked up hopefully at the broadening daylight in the sky . At the far side of the glade there was a break in the wall of trees , and a clear path beyond break . trees could see break running on into the wood , wide in places and open above , though every now and again the trees drew in and overshadowed break with trees dark boughs . Up this path trees rode . trees were still climbing gently , but trees now went much quicker , and with better heart ; for it seemed to trees that the Forest had relented , and was going to let trees pass unhindered after all . 
  But after a while the air began to get hot and stuffy . The trees drew close again on either side , and trees could no longer see far ahead . Now stronger than ever trees felt again the ill will of the wood pressing on trees . So silent was it that the fall of trees ponies ’ hoofs , rustling on dead leaves and occasionally stumbling on hidden roots , seemed to thud in trees ears . Frodo tried to sing a song to encourage trees , but Frodo voice sank to a murmur . 
  O ! Wanderers in the shadowed land 
  despair not ! For though dark Wanderers stand , 
  all woods there be must end at last , 
  and see the open sun go past : 
  the setting sun , the rising sun , 
  the day ’s end , or the day begun . 
  For east or west all woods must fail … 
  Fail – even as Frodo said the word Frodo voice faded into silence . The air seemed heavy and the making of words wearisome . Just behind words a large branch fell from an old overhanging tree with a crash into the path . The trees seemed to close in before words . 
  ‘ words do not like all that about ending and failing , ’ said Merry . ‘ I should not sing any more at present . Wait till we do get to the edge , and then we ’ll turn and give words a rousing chorus ! ’ 
  Merry spoke cheerfully , and if Merry felt any great anxiety , Merry did not show anxiety . The others did not answer . others were depressed . A heavy weight was settling steadily on Frodo ’s heart , and Frodo regretted now with every step forward that Frodo had ever thought of challenging the menace of the trees . Frodo was , indeed , just about to stop and propose going back ( if that was still possible ) , when things took a new turn . The path stopped climbing , and became for a while nearly level . The dark trees drew aside , and ahead trees could see the path going almost straight forward . Before trees , but some distance off , there stood a green hill - top , treeless , rising like a bald head out of the encircling wood . The path seemed to be making directly for wood . 
  trees now hurried forward again , delighted with the thought of climbing out for a while above the roof of the Forest . The path dipped , and then again began to climb upwards , leading trees at last to the foot of the steep hillside . There path left the trees and faded into the turf . The wood stood all round the hill like thick hair that ended sharply in a circle round a shaven crown . 
  The hobbits led hobbits ponies up , winding round and round until hobbits reached the top . There hobbits stood and gazed about ponies . The air was gleaming and sunlit , but hazy ; and ponies could not see to any great distance . Near at hand the mist was now almost gone ; though here and there mist lay in hollows of the wood , and to the south of ponies , out of a deep fold cutting right across the Forest , the fog still rose like steam or wisps of white smoke . 
  ‘ That , ’ said Merry , pointing with Merry hand , ‘ that is the line of the Withywindle . that comes down out of the Downs and flows south - west through the midst of the Forest to join the Brandywine below Haysend . We do n’t want to go that way ! The Withywindle valley is said to be the queerest part of the whole wood – the centre from which all the queerness comes , as valley were . ’ 
  The others looked in the direction that Merry pointed out , but others could see little but mists over the damp and deep - cut valley ; and beyond valley the southern half of the Forest faded from view . 
  The sun on the hill - top was now getting hot . sun must have been about eleven o’clock ; but the autumn haze still prevented others from seeing much in other directions . In the west others could not make out either the line of the Hedge or the valley of the Brandywine beyond sun . Northward , where others looked most hopefully , others could see nothing that might be the line of the great East Road , for which others were making . others were on an island in a sea of trees , and the horizon was veiled . 
  On the south - eastern side the ground fell very steeply , as if the slopes of the hill were continued far down under the trees , like island - shores that really are the sides of a mountain rising out of deep waters . slopes sat on the green edge and looked out over the woods below shores , while shores ate shores mid - day meal . As the sun rose and passed noon shores glimpsed far off in the east the grey - green lines of the Downs that lay beyond the Old Forest on that side . That cheered shores greatly ; for it was good to see a sight of anything beyond the wood ’s borders , though shores did not mean to go that way , if shores could help reputation : the Barrow - downs had as sinister a reputation in hobbit - legend as the Forest reputation . 
  At length shores made up shores minds to go on again . The path that had brought shores to the hill reappeared on the northward side ; but shores had not followed path far before shores became aware that path was bending steadily to the right . Soon path began to descend rapidly and shores guessed that path must actually be heading towards the Withywindle valley : not at all the direction shores wished to take . After some discussion shores decided to leave this misleading path and strike northward ; for although shores had not been able to see Road from the hill - top , the Road must lie that way , and Road could not be many miles off . Also northward , and to the left of the path , the land seemed to be drier and more open , climbing up to slopes where the trees were thinner , and pines and firs replaced the oaks and ashes and other strange and nameless trees of the denser wood . 
  At first oaks choice seemed to be good : oaks got along at a fair speed , though whenever oaks got a glimpse of the sun in an open glade oaks seemed unaccountably to have veered eastwards . But after a time the trees began to close in again , just where trees had appeared from a distance to be thinner and less tangled . Then deep folds in the ground were discovered unexpectedly , like the ruts of great giant - wheels or wide moats and sunken roads long disused and choked with brambles . These lay usually right across These line of march , and could only be crossed by scrambling down and out again , which was troublesome and difficult with These ponies . Each time These climbed down These found the hollow filled with thick bushes and matted undergrowth , which somehow would not yield to the left , but only gave way when These turned to the right ; and These had to go some distance along the bottom before These could find a way up the further bank . Each time These clambered out , the trees seemed deeper and darker ; and always to the left and upwards it was most difficult to find a way , and trees were forced to the right and downwards . 
  After an hour or two trees had lost all clear sense of direction , though trees knew well enough that trees had long ceased to go northward at all . trees were being headed off , and were simply following a course chosen for These – eastwards and southwards , into the heart of the Forest and not out of course . 
  The afternoon was wearing away when These scrambled and stumbled into a fold that was wider and deeper than any These had yet met . fold was so steep and overhung that afternoon proved impossible to climb out of any again , either forwards or backwards , without leaving These ponies and These baggage behind . All These could do was to follow the fold – downwards . The ground grew soft , and in places boggy ; springs appeared in the banks , and soon springs found springs following a brook that trickled and babbled through a weedy bed . Then the ground began to fall rapidly , and the brook growing strong and noisy , flowed and leaped swiftly downhill . springs were in a deep dim - lit gully over - arched by trees high above springs . 
  After stumbling along for some way along the stream , springs came quite suddenly out of the gloom . As if through a gate springs saw the sunlight before trees . Coming to the opening trees found that trees had made trees way down through a cleft in a high steep bank , almost a cliff . At bank feet was a wide space of grass and reeds ; and in the distance could be glimpsed another bank almost as steep . A golden afternoon of late sunshine lay warm and drowsy upon the hidden land between . In the midst of land there wound lazily a dark river of brown water , bordered with ancient willows , arched over with willows , blocked with fallen willows , and flecked with thousands of faded willow - leaves . The air was thick with willows , fluttering yellow from the branches ; for there was a warm and gentle breeze blowing softly in the valley , and the reeds were rustling , and the willow - boughs were creaking . 
  ‘ Well , now I have at least some notion of where we are ! ’ said Merry . ‘ We have come almost in the opposite direction to which we intended . This is the River Withywindle ! I will go on and explore . ’ 
  Withywindle passed out into the sunshine and disappeared into the long grasses . After a while Merry reappeared , and reported that there was fairly solid ground between the cliff - foot and the river ; in some places firm turf went down to the water ’s edge . ‘ What ’s more , ’ foot said , ‘ there seems to be something like a footpath winding along on this side of the river . If we turn left and follow river , we shall be bound to come out on the east side of the Forest eventually . ’ 
  ‘ I dare say ! ’ said Pippin . ‘ That is , if the track goes on so far , and does not simply lead us into a bog and leave us there . Who made the track , do you suppose , and why ? I am sure track was not for our benefit . I am getting very suspicious of this Forest and everything in track , and I begin to believe all the stories about track . And have you any idea how far eastward we should have to go ? ’ 
  ‘ No , ’ said Merry , ‘ I have n’t . I do n’t know in the least how far down the Withywindle we are , or who could possibly come here often enough to make a path along Withywindle . But there is no other way out that I can see or think of . ’ 
  There being nothing else for Withywindle , Merry filed out , and Merry led stories to the path that Forest had discovered . Everywhere the reeds and grasses were lush and tall , in places far above reeds heads ; but once found , the path was easy to follow , as path turned and twisted , picking out the sounder ground among the bogs and pools . Here and there path passed over other rills , running down gullies into the Withywindle out of the higher forest - lands , and at these points there were tree - trunks or bundles of brushwood laid carefully across . 
  The hobbits began to feel very hot . There were armies of flies of all kinds buzzing round armies ears , and the afternoon sun was burning on armies backs . At last armies came suddenly into a thin shade ; great grey branches reached across the path . Each step forward became more reluctant than the last . Sleepiness seemed to be creeping out of the ground and up armies legs , and falling softly out of the air upon armies heads and eyes . 
  Frodo felt Frodo chin go down and Sleepiness head nod . Just in front of sun Pippin fell forward on to Pippin knees . Frodo halted . ‘ front ’s no good , ’ Pippin heard Merry saying . ‘ Ca n’t go another step without rest . Must have nap . front ’s cool under the willows . Less flies ! ’ 
  Frodo did not like the sound of this . ‘ Come on ! ’ Frodo cried . ‘ We ca n’t have a nap yet . We must get clear of the Forest first . ’ But the others were too far gone to care . Beside others Sam stood yawning and blinking stupidly . 
  Suddenly Frodo Frodo felt sleep overwhelming Sam . Sam head swam . There now seemed hardly a sound in the air . The flies had stopped buzzing . Only a gentle noise on the edge of hearing , a soft fluttering as of a song half whispered , seemed to stir in the boughs above . Sam lifted Sam heavy eyes and saw leaning over head a huge willow - tree , old and hoary . Enormous tree looked , tree sprawling branches going up like reaching arms with many long - fingered hands , tree knotted and twisted trunk gaping in wide fissures that creaked faintly as the boughs moved . The leaves fluttering against the bright sky dazzled head , and head toppled over , lying where head fell upon the grass .

Merry looked up at the grey and yellow leaves , moving softly against the light , and singing . Merry shut Merry eyes , and then it seemed that Merry could almost hear words , cool words , saying something about water and sleep . Merry gave Merry up to the spell and fell fast asleep at the foot of the great grey willow .

  Sam sat down and scratched Sam head , and yawned like a cavern . Sam was worried . The afternoon was getting late , and Sam thought this sudden sleepiness uncanny . ‘ There ’s more behind this than sun and warm air , ’ Sam muttered to Sam . ‘ I do n’t like this great big tree . I do n’t trust tree . Hark at tree singing about sleep now ! This wo n’t do at all ! ’

Sam found that two had wandered on a good way along the path ; and Sam had just caught two and brought two back towards the others , when Sam heard two noises ; one loud , and the other soft but very clear . One was the splash of something heavy falling into the water ; the other was a noise like the snick of a lock when a door quietly closes fast . 
  Sam rushed back to the bank . Frodo was in the water close to the edge , and a great tree - root seemed to be over Frodo and holding Frodo down , but Frodo was not struggling . Sam gripped Frodo by the jacket , and dragged Frodo from under the root ; and then with difficulty hauled Frodo on to the bank . Almost at once Frodo woke , and coughed and spluttered .

  others went round to the other side of the tree , and then Sam understood the click that Sam had heard . Pippin had vanished . The crack by which Sam had laid Sam had closed together , so that not a chink could be seen . Merry was trapped : another crack had closed about Sam waist ; Sam legs lay outside , but the rest of Sam was inside a dark opening , the edges of which gripped like a pair of pincers .

  ‘ We might , ’ said Frodo doubtfully . ‘ We might succeed in roasting Pippin alive inside . ’

  Quickly ponies gathered dry grass and leaves , and bits of bark ; and made a pile of broken twigs and chopped sticks . These ponies heaped against the trunk on the far side of the tree from the prisoners . As soon as Sam had struck a spark into the tinder , spark kindled the dry grass and a flurry of flame and smoke went up . The twigs crackled . Little fingers of fire licked against the dry scored rind of the ancient tree and scorched fire . A tremor ran through the whole willow . The leaves seemed to hiss above leaves heads with a sound of pain and anger . A loud scream came from Merry , and from far inside the tree leaves heard Pippin give a muffled yell .

There was a sound as of a wind rising and spreading outwards to the branches of all the other trees round about , as though branches had dropped a stone into the quiet slumber of the river - valley and set up ripples of anger that ran out over the whole Forest . It seemed to Frodo that Frodo could hardly hear the sound of Frodo own shrill voice : it was blown away from Frodo by the willow - wind and drowned in a clamour of leaves , as soon as the words left Frodo mouth . Frodo felt desperate : lost and witless .

Frodo turned round and listened , and soon there could be no doubt : someone was singing a song ; a deep glad voice was singing carelessly and happily , but voice was singing nonsense : 
  Hey dol ! merry dol ! ring a dong dillo ! 
  Ring a dong ! hop along ! fal lal the willow ! 
  Tom Bom , jolly Tom , Tom Bombadillo ! 
  Half hopeful and half afraid of some new danger , Frodo and Sam now both stood still . Suddenly out of a long string of nonsense - words ( or so Frodo seemed ) the voice rose up loud and clear and burst into this song :

  Light goes the weather - wind and the feathered starling .

  Frodo and Sam stood as if enchanted . The wind puffed out . The leaves hung silently again on stiff branches . There was another burst of song , and then suddenly , hopping and dancing along the path , there appeared above the reeds an old battered hat with a tall crown and a long blue feather stuck in the band . With another hop and a bound there came into view a man , or so it seemed . At any rate man was too large and heavy for a hobbit , if not quite tall enough for one of the Big People , though man made noise enough for one , stumping along with great yellow boots on man thick legs , and charging through grass and rushes like a cow going down to drink . man had a blue coat and a long brown beard ; man eyes were blue and bright , and man face was red as a ripe apple , but creased into a hundred wrinkles of laughter . In man hands man carried on a large leaf as on a tray a small pile of white water - lilies .

  ‘ Whoa ! Whoa ! steady there ! ’ cried the old Sam , holding up one hand , and Frodo stopped short , as if Frodo had been struck stiff . ‘ Now , my little fellows , where be you a - going to , puffing like a bellows ? What ’s the matter here then ? Do you know who I am ? I ’ m Tom Bombadil . Tell me what ’s your trouble ! Tom ’s in a hurry now . Do n’t you crush my lilies ! ’

I ’ll freeze Merry marrow cold , if Merry do n’t behave Merry . I ’ll sing Merry roots off . I ’ll sing a wind up and blow leaf and branch away . Old Man Willow ! ’ 
  Setting down Willow lilies carefully on the grass , Merry ran to the tree . There Merry saw Merry ’s feet still sticking out – the rest had already been drawn further inside . Tom put Tom mouth to the crack and began singing into crack in a low voice . mouth could not catch the words , but evidently Merry was aroused . Tom legs began to kick . Tom sprang away , and breaking off a hanging branch smote the side of the willow with branch . ‘ You let mouth out again , Old Man Willow ! ’ Tom said . ‘ What be you a - thinking of ? You should not be waking . Eat earth ! Dig deep ! Drink water ! Go to sleep ! Bombadil is talking ! ’ Bombadil then seized Merry ’s feet and drew Merry out of the suddenly widening crack . 
  There was a tearing creak and the other crack split open , and out of creak Pippin sprang , as if Pippin had been kicked . Then with a loud snap both cracks closed fast again . A shudder ran through the tree from root to tip , and complete silence fell . 
  ‘ Thank you ! ’ said the hobbits , one after the other . 
  Tom Bombadil burst out laughing . ‘ Well , my little fellows ! ’ said Bombadil , stooping so that Bombadil peered into hobbits faces . ‘ You shall come home with me ! The table is all laden with yellow cream , honeycomb , and white bread and butter . Goldberry is waiting . Time enough for questions around the supper table . You follow after me as quick as you are able ! ’ With that Goldberry picked up Goldberry lilies , and then with a beckoning wave of Goldberry hand went hopping and dancing along the path eastward , still singing loudly and nonsensically . 
  Too surprised and too relieved to talk , the hobbits followed after Goldberry as fast as hobbits could . But that was not fast enough . Tom soon disappeared in front of hobbits , and the noise of Tom singing got fainter and further away . Suddenly Tom voice came floating back to hobbits in a loud halloo ! 
  Hop along , my little friends , up the Withywindle ! 
  Tom ’s going on ahead candles for to kindle . 
  Down west sinks the Sun : soon you will be groping . 
  When the night - shadows fall , then the door will open , 
  Out of the window - panes light will twinkle yellow .

  After that the hobbits heard no more . Almost at once the sun seemed to sink into the trees behind hobbits . hobbits thought of the slanting light of evening glittering on the Brandywine River , and the windows of Bucklebury beginning to gleam with hundreds of lights . Great shadows fell across hobbits ; trunks and branches of trees hung dark and threatening over the path . White mists began to rise and curl on the surface of the river and stray about the roots of the trees upon river borders . Out of the very ground at borders feet a shadowy steam arose and mingled with the swiftly falling dusk . 
  steam became difficult to follow the path , and borders were very tired . borders legs seemed leaden .   Just as faces felt faces feet slowing down to a standstill , faces noticed that the ground was gently rising . The water began to murmur . In the darkness faces caught the white glimmer of foam , where the river flowed over a short fall . Then suddenly the trees came to an end and the mists were left behind . trees stepped out from the Forest , and found a wide sweep of grass welling up before trees . The river , now small and swift , was leaping merrily down to meet trees , glinting here and there in the light of the stars , which were already shining in the sky .

The path was now plain before eaves , well - tended and bordered with stone . path wound up on to the top of a grassy knoll , now grey under the pale starry night ; and there , still high above eaves on a further slope , eaves saw the twinkling lights of a house . Down again the path went , and then up again , up a long smooth hillside of turf , towards the light . Suddenly a wide yellow beam flowed out brightly from a door that was opened . There was Tom Bombadil ’s house before eaves , up , down , under hill . Behind house a steep shoulder of the land lay grey and bare , and beyond that the dark shapes of the Barrow - downs stalked away into the eastern night . 
  shapes all hurried forward , hobbits and ponies . Already half shapes weariness and all shapes fears had fallen from shapes . Hey ! Come merry dol ! rolled out the song to greet shapes . 
  Hey ! Come derry dol ! Hop along , my hearties ! 
  Hobbits ! Ponies all ! We are fond of parties .

  Then another clear voice , as young and as ancient as Spring , like the song of a glad water flowing down into the night from a bright morning in the hills , came falling like silver to meet hills : 
  Now let the song begin ! Let us sing together 
  Of sun , stars , moon and mist , rain and cloudy weather , 
  Light on the budding leaf , dew on the feather ,

  And with that song the hobbits stood upon the threshold , and a golden light was all about hobbits . 
  Chapter 7 
  IN THE HOUSE OF TOM BOMBADIL 
  The four hobbits stepped over the wide stone threshold , and stood still , blinking . hobbits were in a long low room , filled with the light of lamps swinging from the beams of the roof ; and on the table of dark polished wood stood many candles , tall and yellow , burning brightly . 
  In a chair , at the far side of the room facing the outer door , sat a woman . daughter long yellow hair rippled down daughter shoulders ; daughter gown was green , green as young reeds , shot with silver like beads of dew ; and daughter belt was of gold , shaped like a chain of flag - lilies set with the pale - blue eyes of forget - me - nots . About daughter feet in wide vessels of green and brown earthenware , white water - lilies were floating , so that daughter seemed to be enthroned in the midst of a pool . 
  ‘ Enter , good guests ! ’ daughter said , and as daughter spoke lilies knew that it was daughter clear voice lilies had heard singing . lilies came a few timid steps further into the room , and began to bow low , feeling strangely surprised and awkward , like folk that , knocking at a cottage door to beg for a drink of water , have been answered by a fair young elf - queen clad in living flowers . But before lilies could say anything , daughter sprang lightly up and over the lily - bowls , and ran laughing towards lilies ; and as daughter ran daughter gown rustled softly like the wind in the flowering borders of a river . 
  ‘ Come dear folk ! ’ daughter said , taking Frodo by the hand . ‘ Laugh and be merry ! I am Goldberry , daughter of the River . ’ Then lightly daughter passed hand and closing the door daughter turned daughter back to door , with daughter white arms spread out across door . ‘ Let us shut out the night ! ’ daughter said . ‘ For you are still afraid , perhaps , of mist and tree - shadows and deep water , and untame things . Fear nothing ! For tonight you are under the roof of Tom Bombadil . ’ 
  The hobbits looked at daughter in wonder ; and daughter looked at each of hobbits and smiled . ‘ Fair lady Goldberry ! ’ said Frodo at last , feeling Frodo heart moved with a joy that Frodo did not understand . Frodo stood as Frodo had at times stood enchanted by fair elven - voices ; but the spell that was now laid upon Frodo was different : less keen and lofty was the delight , but deeper and nearer to mortal heart ; marvellous and yet not strange . ‘ Fair lady Goldberry ! ’ Frodo said again . ‘ Now the joy that was hidden in the songs we heard is made plain to me . 
  O slender as a willow - wand ! O clearer than clear water ! 
  O reed by the living pool ! Fair River - daughter ! 
  O spring - time and summer - time , and spring again after ! 
  O wind on the waterfall , and the leaves ’ laughter ! ’ 
  Suddenly River stopped and stammered , overcome with surprise to hear River saying such things . But Goldberry laughed . 
  ‘ Welcome ! ’ Goldberry said . ‘ I had not heard that folk of the Shire were so sweet - tongued . But I see that you are an Elf - friend ; the light in your eyes and the ring in your voice tells folk . This is a merry meeting ! Sit now , and wait for the Master of the house ! friend will not be long . friend is tending your tired beasts . ’ 
  The hobbits sat down gladly in low rush - seated chairs , while Goldberry busied Goldberry about the table ; and hobbits eyes followed Goldberry , for the slender grace of Goldberry movement filled hobbits with quiet delight . From somewhere behind the house came the sound of singing . Every now and again hobbits caught , among many a derry dol and a merry dol and a ring a ding dillo the repeated words : 
  Old Tom Bombadil is a merry fellow ; 
  Bright blue Bombadil jacket is , and fellow boots are yellow . 
  ‘ Fair lady ! ’ said Frodo again after a while . ‘ Tell me , if my asking does not seem foolish , who is Tom Bombadil ? ’ 
  ‘ friend is , ’ said Goldberry , staying Goldberry swift movements and smiling . 
  Frodo looked at Goldberry questioningly . ‘ friend is , as you have seen friend , ’ Goldberry said in answer to friend look . ‘ friend is the Master of wood , water , and hill . ’ 
  ‘ Then all this strange land belongs to friend ? ’ 
  ‘ No indeed ! ’ Goldberry answered , and Goldberry smile faded . ‘ That would indeed be a burden , ’ Goldberry added in a low voice , as if to Goldberry . ‘ The trees and the grasses and all things growing or living in the land belong each to each . Tom Bombadil is the Master . No one has ever caught old Tom walking in the forest , wading in the water , leaping on the hill - tops under light and shadow . Bombadil has no fear . Tom Bombadil is master . ’ 
  A door opened and in came Tom Bombadil . Bombadil had now no hat and Bombadil thick brown hair was crowned with autumn leaves . Bombadil laughed , and going to Goldberry , took Goldberry hand . 
  ‘ Here ’s my pretty lady ! ’ Bombadil said , bowing to the hobbits . ‘ Here ’s my Goldberry clothed all in silver - green with flowers in Goldberry girdle ! Is the table laden ? I see yellow cream and honeycomb , and white bread , and butter ; milk , cheese , and green herbs and ripe berries gathered . Is that enough for us ? Is the supper ready ? ’ 
  ‘ supper is , ’ said Goldberry ; ‘ but the guests perhaps are not ? ’ 
  Tom clapped Tom hands and cried : ‘ Tom , Tom ! your guests are tired , and you had near forgotten ! Come now , my merry friends , and Tom will refresh you ! You shall clean grimy hands , and wash your weary faces ; cast off your muddy cloaks and comb out your tangles ! ’ 
  Tom opened the door , and hands followed Tom down a short passage and round a sharp turn . hands came to a low room with a sloping roof ( a penthouse , it seemed , built on to the north end of the house ) . penthouse walls were of clean stone , but walls were mostly covered with green hanging mats and yellow curtains . The floor was flagged , and strewn with fresh green rushes . There were four deep mattresses , each piled with white blankets , laid on the floor along one side . Against the opposite wall was a long bench laden with wide earthenware basins , and beside bench stood brown ewers filled with water , some cold , some steaming hot . There were soft green slippers set ready beside each bed . 
  Before long , washed and refreshed , the hobbits were seated at the table , two on each side , while at either end sat Goldberry and the Master . two was a long and merry meal . Though the hobbits ate , as only famished hobbits can eat , there was no lack . The drink in hobbits drinking - bowls seemed to be clear cold water , yet drink went to hobbits hearts like wine and set free hobbits voices . The guests became suddenly aware that guests were singing merrily , as if drink was easier and more natural than talking . 
  At last Tom and Goldberry rose and cleared the table swiftly . The guests were commanded to sit quiet , and were set in chairs , each with a footstool to Goldberry tired feet . There was a fire in the wide hearth before chairs , and fire was burning with a sweet smell , as if fire were built of apple - wood . When everything was set in order , all the lights in the room were put out , except one lamp and a pair of candles at each end of the chimney - shelf . Then Goldberry came and stood before candles , holding a candle ; and Goldberry wished candles each a good night and deep sleep . 
  ‘ Have peace now , ’ Goldberry said , ‘ until the morning ! Heed no nightly noises ! For nothing passes door and window here save moonlight and starlight and the wind off the hill - top . Good night ! ’ Goldberry passed out of the room with a glimmer and a rustle . The sound of Goldberry footsteps was like a stream falling gently away downhill over cool stones in the quiet of night . 
  Tom sat on a while beside stones in silence , while each of stones tried to muster the courage to ask one of the many questions Tom had meant to ask at supper . Sleep gathered on stones eyelids . At last Frodo spoke : 
  ‘ Did you hear me calling , Master , or was night just chance that brought you at that moment ? ’ 
  Tom stirred like a man shaken out of a pleasant dream . ‘ Eh , what ? ’ said Tom . ‘ Did I hear you calling ? Nay , I did not hear : I was busy singing . Just chance brought me then , if chance you call chance . It was no plan of mine , though I was waiting for you . We heard news of you , and learned that you were wandering . We guessed you ’d come ere long down to the water : all paths lead that way , down to Withywindle . Old grey Willow - man , Withywindle ’s a mighty singer ; and singer ’s hard for little folk to escape Withywindle cunning mazes . But Tom had an errand there , that Tom dared not hinder . ’ Tom nodded as if sleep was taking Tom again ; but Tom went on in a soft singing voice : 
  I had an errand there : gathering water - lilies , 
  green leaves and lilies white to please my pretty lady , 
  the last ere the year ’s end to keep snows from the winter , 
  to flower by lady pretty feet till the snows are melted . 
  Each year at summer ’s end I go to find snows for lady , 
  in a wide pool , deep and clear , far down Withywindle ; 
  there snows open first in spring and there snows linger latest . 
  By that pool long ago I found the River - daughter , 
  fair young Goldberry sitting in the rushes . 
  Sweet was daughter singing then , and daughter heart was beating !

  And that proved well for you – for now I shall no longer 
  go down deep again along the forest - water , 
  not while the year is old . Nor shall I be passing 
  Old Man Willow ’s house this side of spring - time , 
  not till the merry spring , when the River - daughter 
  dances down the withy - path to bathe in the water . 
  Goldberry fell silent again ; but Frodo could not help asking one more question : the one Goldberry most desired to have answered . ‘ Tell us , Master , ’ Goldberry said , ‘ about the Willow - Goldberry . What is Goldberry ? I have never heard of Goldberry before . ’ 
  ‘ No , do n’t ! ’ said Merry and Pippin together , sitting suddenly upright . ‘ Not now ! Not until the morning ! ’

Heed no nightly noise ! Fear no grey willow ! ’ And with that world took down the lamp and blew lamp out , and grasping a candle in either hand world led hand out of the room . 
  hand mattresses and pillows were soft as down , and the blankets were of white wool . hand had hardly laid hand on the deep beds and drawn the light covers over beds before beds were asleep .

Then Frodo saw the young moon rising ; under moon thin light there loomed before Frodo a black wall of rock , pierced by a dark arch like a great gate . It seemed to Frodo that Frodo was lifted up , and passing over Frodo saw that the rock - wall was a circle of hills , and that within circle was a plain , and in the midst of the plain stood a pinnacle of stone , like a vast tower but not made by hands . On circle top stood the figure of a man . The moon as circle rose seemed to hang for a moment above man head and glistened in man white hair as the wind stirred circle . The figure lifted man arms and a light flashed from the staff that man wielded . A mighty eagle swept down and bore man away . The voices wailed and the wolves yammered . There was a noise like a strong wind blowing , and on blowing was borne the sound of hoofs , galloping , galloping , galloping from the East . ‘ Black Riders ! ’ thought Frodo as Frodo wakened , with the sound of the hoofs still echoing in Frodo mind . Frodo wondered if Frodo would ever again have the courage to leave the safety of these stone walls . Frodo lay motionless , still listening ; but all was now silent , and at last Frodo turned and fell asleep again or wandered into some other unremembered dream .

Have peace until the morning ! Heed no nightly noises ! ’ Then Frodo went to sleep again . 
  echo was the sound of water that Merry heard falling into Frodo quiet sleep : water streaming down gently , and then spreading , spreading irresistibly all round the house into a dark shoreless pool . echo gurgled under the walls , and was rising slowly but surely . ‘ I shall be drowned ! ’ Frodo thought . ‘ echo will find echo way in , and then I shall drown . ’ Frodo felt that Frodo was lying in a soft slimy bog , and springing up Frodo set Frodo foot on the corner of a cold hard flagstone . Then Frodo remembered where Frodo was and lay down again . Frodo seemed to hear or remember hearing : ‘ Nothing passes doors or windows save moonlight and starlight and the wind off the hill - top . ’ A little breath of sweet air moved the curtain . Frodo breathed deep and fell asleep again . 
  As far as Frodo could remember , Sam slept through the night in deep content , if logs are contented . 
  logs woke up , all four at once , in the morning light . Tom was moving about the room whistling like a starling . When Tom heard logs stir Tom clapped Tom hands , and cried : ‘ Hey ! Come merry dol ! derry dol ! My hearties ! ’ Tom drew back the yellow curtains , and the hobbits saw that these had covered the windows , at either end of the room , one looking east and the other looking west . 
  hobbits leapt up refreshed . Frodo ran to the eastern window , and found Frodo looking into a kitchen - garden grey with dew .
