Near at hand was a flower - garden and a clipped hedge silver - netted , and beyond that grey shaven grass pale with dew - drops . There was no willow - tree to be seen .

I have been walking wide , leaping on the hill - tops , since the grey dawn began , nosing wind and weather , wet grass underfoot , wet sky above me . I wakened Goldberry singing under window ; but naught wakes hobbit - folk in the early morning . In the night little folk wake up in the darkness , and sleep after light has come ! Ring a ding dillo ! Wake now , my merry friends ! Forget the nightly noises ! Ring a ding dillo del ! derry del , my hearties ! If you come soon you ’ll find breakfast on the table . If you come late you ’ll get grass and rain - water ! ’ 
  Needless to say – not that Tom ’s threat sounded very serious – the hobbits came soon , and left the table late and only when table was beginning to look rather empty . Neither Tom nor Goldberry were there . Tom could be heard about the house , clattering in the kitchen , and up and down the stairs , and singing here and there outside . The room looked westward over the mist - clouded valley , and the window was open . Water dripped down from the thatched eaves above . Before clouds had finished breakfast the clouds had joined into an unbroken roof , and a straight grey rain came softly and steadily down . Behind rain deep curtain the Forest was completely veiled .

The hobbits listened with delight ; and Frodo was glad in Frodo heart , and blessed the kindly weather , because weather delayed hobbits from departing . The thought of going had been heavy upon Frodo from the moment Frodo awoke ; but Frodo guessed now that hobbits would not go further that day .

Frodo stood near the open door and watched the white chalky path turn into a little river of milk and go bubbling away down into the valley . Moving constantly in and out of Forest talk was Old Man Willow , and Frodo learned now enough to content Forest , indeed more than enough , for talk was not comfortable lore . Tom ’s words laid bare the hearts of trees and words thoughts , which were often dark and strange , and filled with a hatred of things that go free upon the earth , gnawing , biting , breaking , hacking , burning : destroyers and usurpers . It was not called the Old Forest without reason , for reason was indeed ancient , a survivor of vast forgotten woods ; and in reason there lived yet , ageing no quicker than the hills , the fathers of the fathers of trees , remembering times when fathers were lords . The countless years had filled fathers with pride and rooted wisdom , and with malice . But none were more dangerous than the Great Willow : Forest heart was rotten , but Forest strength was green ; and Forest was cunning , and a master of winds , and Forest song and thought ran through the woods on both sides of the river . Forest grey thirsty spirit drew power out of the earth and spread like fine root - threads in the ground , and invisible twig - fingers in the air , till spirit had under spirit dominion nearly all the trees of the Forest from the Hedge to the Downs . 
  Suddenly Tom ’s talk left the woods and went leaping up the young stream , over bubbling waterfalls , over pebbles and worn rocks , and among small flowers in close grass and wet crannies , wandering at last up on to the Downs . rocks heard of the Great Barrows , and the green mounds , and the stone - rings upon the hills and in the hollows among the hills . Sheep were bleating in flocks . Green walls and white walls rose . There were fortresses on the heights . Kings of little kingdoms fought together , and the young Sun shone like fire on the red metal of Kings new and greedy swords . There was victory and defeat ; and towers fell , fortresses were burned , and flames went up into the sky . Gold was piled on the biers of dead kings and queens ; and mounds covered biers , and the stone doors were shut ; and the grass grew over all . Sheep walked for a while biting the grass , but soon the hills were empty again . A shadow came out of dark places far away , and the bones were stirred in the mounds . Barrow - wights walked in the hollow places with a clink of rings on cold fingers , and gold chains in the wind . Stone rings grinned out of the ground like broken teeth in the moonlight . 
  The hobbits shuddered . Even in the Shire the rumour of the Barrow - wights of the Barrow - downs beyond the Forest had been heard . But it was not a tale that any hobbit liked to listen to , even by a comfortable fireside far away . These four now suddenly remembered what the joy of this house had driven from four minds : the house of Tom Bombadil nestled under the very shoulder of those dreaded hills . four lost the thread of Bombadil tale and shifted uneasily , looking aside at one another . 
  When four caught Bombadil words again four found that Bombadil had now wandered into strange regions beyond four memory and beyond four waking thought , into times when the world was wider , and the seas flowed straight to the western Shore ; and still on and back Tom went singing out into ancient starlight , when only the Elf - sires were awake . Then suddenly Bombadil stopped , and sires saw that Bombadil nodded as if Bombadil was falling asleep .   Whether the morning and evening of one day or of many days had passed Frodo could not tell . Frodo did not feel either hungry or tired , only filled with wonder . The stars shone through the window and the silence of the heavens seemed to be round Frodo . Frodo spoke at last out of Frodo wonder and a sudden fear of that silence :

But you are young and I am old . Eldest , that ’s what I am . Mark my words , my friends : Tom was here before the river and the trees ; Tom remembers the first raindrop and the first acorn . Tom made paths before the Big People , and saw the little People arriving . Tom was here before the Kings and the graves and the Barrow - wights . When the Elves passed westward , Tom was here already , before the seas were bent . Tom knew the dark under the stars when Lord was fearless – before the Dark Lord came from Outside . ’ 
  A shadow seemed to pass by the window , and the hobbits glanced hastily through the panes . When hobbits turned again , Goldberry stood in the door behind , framed in light . Goldberry held a candle , shielding candle flame from the draught with Goldberry hand ; and the light flowed through candle , like sunlight through a white shell .

Suddenly Goldberry hopped through the door and disappeared .

  mail was a supper even better than before . The hobbits under the spell of Tom ’s words may have missed one meal or many , but when the food was before hobbits it seemed at least a week since hobbits had eaten . hobbits did not sing or even speak much for a while , and paid close attention to business . It was also clear that Tom had dealings with the Elves , and it seemed that in some fashion , news had reached Tom from Gildor concerning the flight of Frodo .

Then Tom put the Ring round the end of Tom little finger and held Ring up to the candlelight . For a moment the hobbits noticed nothing strange about this . Then hobbits gasped . There was no sign of Tom disappearing !

  Frodo looked at Ring closely , and rather suspiciously ( like one who has lent a trinket to a juggler ) . Ring was the same Ring , or looked the same and weighed the same : for that Ring had always seemed to Frodo to weigh strangely heavy in the hand . But something prompted Tom to make sure . Take off your golden ring ! Your hand ’s more fair without that . Come back ! Leave your game and sit down beside me ! We must talk a while more , and think about the morning . Tom must teach the right road , and keep your feet from wandering . ’

Tom now told feet that Tom reckoned the Sun would shine tomorrow , and Sun would be a glad morning , and setting out would be hopeful . But feet would do well to start early ; for weather in that country was a thing that even Tom could not be sure of for long , and country would change sometimes quicker than Tom could change Tom jacket . ‘ I am no weather - master , ’ said Tom ; ‘ nor is aught that goes on two legs . ’ 
  By Tom advice feet decided to make nearly due North from Tom house , over the western and lower slopes of the Downs : feet might hope in that way to strike the East Road in a day ’s journey , and avoid the Barrows . Tom told feet not to be afraid – but to mind feet own business .

Then Tom taught feet a rhyme to sing , if feet should by ill - luck fall into any danger or difficulty the next day . 
  Ho ! Tom Bombadil , Tom Bombadillo ! 
  By water , wood and hill , by the reed and willow , 
  By fire , sun and moon , harken now and hear us ! 
  Come , Tom Bombadil , for our need is near us ! 
  When each had sung this altogether after Bombadil , Bombadil clapped each each on the shoulder with a laugh , and taking candles led each back to each bedroom . 
  Chapter 8 
  FOG ON THE BARROW - DOWNS 
  That night each heard no noises . But either in Frodo dreams or out of each , Frodo could not tell which , Frodo heard a sweet singing running in Frodo mind : a song that seemed to come like a pale light behind a grey rain - curtain , and growing stronger to turn the veil all to glass and silver , until at last singing was rolled back , and a far green country opened before Frodo under a swift sunrise . 
  The vision melted into waking ; and there was Tom whistling like a tree - full of birds ; and the sun was already slanting down the hill and through the open window . Outside everything was green and pale gold . 
  After breakfast , which Tom again ate alone , Tom made ready to say farewell , as nearly heavy of heart as was possible on such a morning : cool , bright , and clean under a washed autumn sky of thin blue . The air came fresh from the North - west . Tom quiet ponies were almost frisky , sniffing and moving restlessly . Tom came out of the house and waved sun hat and danced upon the doorstep , bidding the hobbits to get up and be off and go with good speed . 
  Tom rode off along a path that wound away from behind the house , and went slanting up towards the north end of the hill - brow under which house sheltered . Tom had just dismounted to lead Tom ponies up the last steep slope , when suddenly Frodo stopped . 
  ‘ Goldberry ! ’ Frodo cried . ‘ My fair lady , clad all in silver green ! We have never said farewell to lady , nor seen lady since the evening ! ’ Frodo was so distressed that Frodo turned back ; but at that moment a clear call came rippling down . There on the hill - brow lady stood beckoning to Tom : lady hair was flying loose , and as hair caught the sun hair shone and shimmered . A light like the glint of water on dewy grass flashed from under lady feet as lady danced . 
  Tom hastened up the last slope , and stood breathless beside lady . Tom bowed , but with a wave of lady arm lady bade Tom look round ; and Tom looked out from the hill - top over lands under the morning . wave was now as clear and far - seen as wave had been veiled and misty when Tom stood upon the knoll in the Forest , which could now be seen rising pale and green out of the dark trees in the West . In that direction the land rose in wooded ridges , green , yellow , russet under the sun , beyond which lay hidden the valley of the Brandywine . To the South , over the line of the Withywindle , there was a distant glint like pale glass where the Brandywine River made a great loop in the lowlands and flowed away out of the knowledge of the hobbits . Northward beyond the dwindling downs the land ran away in flats and swellings of grey and green and pale earth - colours , until land faded into a featureless and shadowy distance . Eastward the Barrow - downs rose , ridge behind ridge into the morning , and vanished out of eyesight into a guess : it was no more than a guess of blue and a remote white glimmer blending with the hem of the sky , but no spoke to blue , out of memory and old tales , of the high and distant mountains . 
  blue took a deep draught of the air , and felt that a skip and a few stout strides would bear blue wherever blue wished . It seemed fainthearted to go jogging aside over the crumpled skirts of the downs towards the Road , when blue should be leaping , as lusty as Tom , over the stepping stones of the hills straight towards the Mountains . 
  Goldberry spoke to blue and recalled blue eyes and thoughts . ‘ Speed now , fair guests ! ’ Goldberry said . ‘ And hold to your purpose ! North with the wind in the left eye and a blessing on your footsteps ! Make haste while the Sun shines ! ’ And to Frodo Goldberry said : ‘ Farewell , Elf - friend , Sun was a merry meeting ! ’ 
  But Frodo found no words to answer . Farewell bowed low , and mounted friend pony , and followed by friend friends jogged slowly down the gentle slope behind the hill . Tom Bombadil ’s house and the valley , and the Forest were lost to view . The air grew warmer between the green walls of hillside and hillside , and the scent of turf rose strong and sweet as walls breathed . Turning back , when walls reached the bottom of the green hollow , walls saw Goldberry , now small and slender like a sunlit flower against the sky : Goldberry was standing still watching walls , and Goldberry hands were stretched out towards walls . As walls looked Goldberry gave a clear call , and lifting up Goldberry hand Goldberry turned and vanished behind the hill . 
  walls way wound along the floor of the hollow , and round the green feet of a steep hill into another deeper and broader valley , and then over the shoulders of further hills , and down walls long limbs , and up walls smooth sides again , up on to new hill - tops and down into new valleys . There was no tree nor any visible water : it was a country of grass and short springy turf , silent except for the whisper of the air over the edges of the land , and high lonely cries of strange birds . As sun journeyed the sun mounted , and grew hot . Each time sun climbed a ridge the breeze seemed to have grown less . When sun caught a glimpse of the country westward the distant Forest seemed to be smoking , as if the fallen rain was steaming up again from leaf and root and mould . A shadow now lay round the edge of sight , a dark haze above which the upper sky was like a blue cap , hot and heavy . 
  About mid - day shadow came to a hill whose top was wide and flattened , like a shallow saucer with a green mounded rim . Inside there was no air stirring , and the sky seemed near shadow heads . shadow rode across and looked northwards . Then shadow hearts rose ; for it seemed plain that shadow had come further already than shadow had expected . Certainly the distances had now all become hazy and deceptive , but there could be no doubt that the Downs were coming to an end . A long valley lay below shadow winding away northwards , until valley came to an opening between two steep shoulders . Beyond , there seemed to be no more hills . Due north shadow faintly glimpsed a long dark line . ‘ That is a line of trees , ’ said Merry , ‘ and that must mark the Road . All along that for many leagues east of the Bridge there are trees growing . Some say Some were planted in the old days . ’ 
  ‘ Splendid ! ’ said Frodo . ‘ If we make as good going this afternoon as we have done this morning , we shall have left the Downs before the Sun sets and be jogging on in search of a camping place . ’ But even as Frodo spoke Frodo turned Frodo glance eastwards , and Frodo saw that on that side the hills were higher and looked down upon shadow ; and all those hills were crowned with green mounds , and on some were standing stones , pointing upwards like jagged teeth out of green gums . 
  That view was somehow disquieting ; so shadow turned from the sight and went down into the hollow circle . In the midst of view there stood a single stone , standing tall under the sun above , and at this hour casting no shadow . view was shapeless and yet significant : like a landmark , or a guarding finger , or more like a warning . But landmark were now hungry , and the sun was still at the fearless noon ; so landmark set landmark backs against the east side of the stone . It was cool , as if the sun had had no power to warm power ; but at that time this seemed pleasant . There landmark took food and drink , and made as good a noon - meal under the open sky as anyone could wish ; for the food came from ‘ down under Hill ’ . Tom had provided landmark with plenty for the comfort of the day . landmark ponies unburdened strayed upon the grass .

  Chapter 9 
  AT THE SIGN OF THE PRANCING PONY 
  Bree was the chief village of the Bree - land , a small inhabited region , like an island in the empty lands round about . Besides Bree village , there was Staddle on the other side of the hill , Combe in a deep valley a little further eastward , and Archet on the edge of the Chetwood . Lying round Bree - hill and the villages was a small country of fields and tamed woodland only a few miles broad . 
  The Men of Bree were brown - haired , broad , and rather short , cheerful and independent : Men belonged to nobody but Men ; but Men were more friendly and familiar with Hobbits , Dwarves , Elves , and other inhabitants of the world about nobody than was ( or is ) usual with Big People . According to Men own tales Men were the original inhabitants and were the descendants of the first Men that ever wandered into the West of the middle - world . Few had survived the turmoils of the Elder Days ; but when the Kings returned again over the Great Sea Kings had found the Bree - Bree still there , and Kings were still there now , when the memory of the old Kings had faded into the grass . 
  In those days no other Men had settled dwellings so far west , or within a hundred leagues of the Shire . But in the wild lands beyond Bree there were mysterious wanderers . The Bree - folk called wanderers Rangers , and knew nothing of wanderers origin . wanderers were taller and darker than the Men of Bree and were believed to have strange powers of sight and hearing , and to understand the languages of beasts and birds . wanderers roamed at will southwards , and eastwards even as far as the Misty Mountains ; but wanderers were now few and rarely seen . When wanderers appeared wanderers brought news from afar , and told strange forgotten tales which were eagerly listened to ; but the Bree - folk did not make friends of wanderers . 
  There were also many families of hobbits in the Bree - land ; and families claimed to be the oldest settlement of Hobbits in the world , one that was founded long before even the Brandywine was crossed and the Shire colonized . families lived mostly in Staddle though there were some in Bree some , especially on the higher slopes of the hill , above the houses of the Men . The Big Folk and the Little Folk ( as Folk called one another ) were on friendly terms , minding Folk own affairs in Folk own ways , but both rightly regarding both as necessary parts of the Bree - folk . Nowhere else in the world was this peculiar ( but excellent ) arrangement to be found . 
  The Bree - Folk , Big and Little , did not both travel much ; and the affairs of the four villages were both chief concern . Occasionally the Hobbits of Bree went as far as Buckland , or the Eastfarthing ; but though both little land was not much further than a day ’s riding east of the Brandywine Bridge , the Hobbits of the Shire now seldom visited land . An occasional Bucklander or adventurous Took would come out to the Inn for a night or two , but even that was becoming less and less usual . The Shire - hobbits referred to those of Bree , and to any others that lived beyond the borders , as Outsiders , and took very little interest in Outsiders , considering Outsiders dull and uncouth . There were probably many more Outsiders scattered about in the West of the World in those days than the people of the Shire imagined . Some , doubtless , were no better than tramps , ready to dig a hole in any bank and stay only as long as Some suited tramps . But in the Bree - land , at any rate , the hobbits were decent and prosperous , and no more rustic than most of hobbits distant relatives Inside . It was not yet forgotten that there had been a time when there was much coming and going between the Shire and Bree . There was Bree - blood in the Brandybucks by all accounts . 
  The village of Bree had some hundred stone houses of the Big Folk , mostly above the Road , nestling on the hillside with windows looking west . On that side , running in more than half a circle from the hill and back to side , there was a deep dike with a thick hedge on the inner side . Over this the Road crossed by a causeway ; but where Road pierced the hedge Road was barred by a great gate . There was another gate in the southern corner where the Road ran out of the village . The gates were closed at nightfall ; but just inside dike were small lodges for the gatekeepers . 
  Down on the Road , where Down swept to the right to go round the foot of the hill , there was a large inn . It had been built long ago when the traffic on the roads had been far greater . For Bree stood at an old meeting of ways ; another ancient road crossed the East Road just outside the dike at the western end of the village , and in former days Men and other folk of various sorts had travelled much on dike . Strange as News from Bree was still a saying in the Eastfarthing , descending from those days , when news from North , South , and East could be heard in the inn , and when the Shire - hobbits used to go more often to hear East . But the Northern Lands had long been desolate , and the North Road was now seldom used : Road was grass - grown , and the Bree - folk called Road the Greenway . 
  The Inn of Bree was still there , however , and the innkeeper was an important person . innkeeper house was a meeting place for the idle , talkative , and inquisitive among the inhabitants , large and small , of the four villages ; and a resort of Rangers and other wanderers , and for such travellers ( mostly dwarves ) as still journeyed on the East Road , to and from the Mountains .

The landlord introduced the newcomers to the Bree - folk , so quickly that , though newcomers caught many names , newcomers were seldom sure who the names belonged to . The Men of Bree seemed all to have rather botanical ( and to the Shire - folk rather odd ) names , like Rushlight , Goatleaf , Heathertoes , Appledore , Thistlewool and Ferny ( not to mention Butterbur ) .   beneath an old grey hill ,

  And these pair polish up with care

  and the cat began to wail ;

  And there dog dozed and dreamed of ale ,

  The cow and the horses stood on cow heads ;

  Meanwhile an argument was going on by the fireplace . Mr. Butterbur had come trotting in , and Butterbur was now trying to listen to several conflicting accounts of the event at the same time .

  ‘ How should I know ? Underhill ’s welcome to go where Underhill will , so long as Underhill pays in the morning . There ’s Mr. Took , now : Underhill ’s not vanished . ’ 
  ‘ Well , I saw what I saw , and I saw what I did n’t , ’ said Mugwort obstinately .

  A KNIFE IN THE DARK

  The leaves were long , the grass was green , 
  The hemlock - umbels tall and fair , 
  And in the glade a light was seen

  The Sundering Seas between the lay , 
  And yet at last the met once more ,

  Strider sighed and paused before Beren spoke again . ‘ That is a song , ’ Beren said , ‘ in the mode that is called ann - thennath among the Elves , but is hard to render in our Common Speech , and this is but a rough echo of thennath . thennath tells of the meeting of Beren son of Barahir and Lúthien Tinúviel . Beren was a mortal man , but Lúthien was the daughter of Thingol , a King of Elves upon Middle - earth when the world was young ; and daughter was the fairest maiden that has ever been among all the children of this world .   Chapter 12 
  FLIGHT TO THE FORD 
  When Frodo came to Frodo Frodo was still clutching the Ring desperately . Frodo was lying by the fire , which was now piled high and burning brightly . Frodo three companions were bending over Frodo .

  BOOK TWO 
  Chapter 1 
  MANY MEETINGS

Elves here , and Elves there ! Some like kings , terrible and splendid ; and some as merry as children .   ‘ I know what you have been doing , Sam , ’ said Frodo , taking Frodo arm . ‘ But you shall be merry tonight , and listen to your heart ’s content . Come on , guide me round the corners ! ’ 
  Sam led Frodo along several passages and down many steps and out into a high garden above the steep bank of the river . Frodo found Frodo friends sitting in a porch on the side of the house looking east . Shadows had fallen in the valley below , but there was still a light on the faces of the mountains far above . The air was warm . The sound of running and falling water was loud , and the evening was filled with a faint scent of trees and flowers , as if summer still lingered in Elrond ’s gardens . 
  ‘ Hurray ! ’ cried Pippin , springing up . ‘ Here is our noble cousin ! Make way for Frodo , Lord of the Ring ! ’ 
  ‘ Hush ! ’ said Gandalf from the shadows at the back of the porch . ‘ Evil things do not come into this valley ; but all the same we should not name things . The Lord of the Ring is not Frodo , but the master of the Dark Tower of Mordor , whose power is again stretching out over the world . We are sitting in a fortress . Outside fortress is getting dark . ’ 
  ‘ Gandalf has been saying many cheerful things like that , ’ said Pippin . ‘ world thinks I need keeping in order . But it seems impossible , somehow , to feel gloomy or depressed in this place . I feel I could sing , if I knew the right song for the occasion . ’ 
  ‘ I feel like singing myself , ’ laughed Frodo . ‘ Though at the moment I feel more like eating and drinking . ’ 
  ‘ That will soon be cured , ’ said Pippin . ‘ You have shown your usual cunning in getting up just in time for a meal . ’ 
  ‘ More than a meal ! A feast ! ’ said Merry . ‘ As soon as Gandalf reported that you were recovered , the preparations began . ’ Pippin had hardly finished speaking when preparations were summoned to the hall by the ringing of many bells . 
  The hall of Elrond ’s house was filled with folk : Elves for the most part , though there were a few guests of other sorts . Elrond , as was Elrond custom , sat in a great chair at the end of the long table upon the dais ; and next to Elrond on the one side sat Glorfindel , on the other side sat Gandalf . 
  Frodo looked at chair in wonder ; for Elrond had never before seen Elrond , of whom so many tales spoke ; and as tales sat upon Elrond right hand and Elrond left , Glorfindel , and even Gandalf , whom Elrond thought Elrond knew so well , were revealed as lords of dignity and power . 
  Gandalf was shorter in stature than the other two ; but Elrond long white hair , Elrond sweeping silver beard , and Elrond broad shoulders , made Elrond look like some wise king of ancient legend . In Elrond aged face under great snowy brows Elrond dark eyes were set like coals that could leap suddenly into fire . 
  Glorfindel was tall and straight ; Elrond hair was of shining gold , Elrond face fair and young and fearless and full of joy ; Elrond eyes were bright and keen , and Elrond voice like music ; on Elrond brow sat wisdom , and in Elrond hand was strength . 
  The face of Elrond was ageless , neither old nor young , though in it was written the memory of many things both glad and sorrowful . Elrond hair was dark as the shadows of twilight , and upon hair was set a circlet of silver ; Elrond eyes were grey as a clear evening , and in shadows was a light like the light of stars . Venerable Elrond seemed as a king crowned with many winters , and yet hale as a tried warrior in the fulness of Elrond strength . Elrond was the Lord of Rivendell and mighty among both Elves and Men . 
  In the middle of the table , against the woven cloths upon the wall , there was a chair under a canopy , and there sat a lady fair to look upon , and so like was warrior in form of womanhood to Elrond that Frodo guessed that warrior was one of Frodo close kindred . Young warrior was and yet not so . The braids of warrior dark hair were touched by no frost ; warrior white arms and clear face were flawless and smooth , and the light of stars was in warrior bright eyes , grey as a cloudless night ; yet queenly warrior looked , and thought and knowledge were in warrior glance , as of one who has known many things that the years bring . Above warrior brow warrior head was covered with a cap of silver lace netted with small gems , glittering white ; but warrior soft grey raiment had no ornament save a girdle of leaves wrought in silver . 
  So raiment was that Frodo saw warrior whom few mortals had yet seen ; Arwen , daughter of Elrond , in whom it was said that the likeness of Lúthien had come on earth again ; and warrior was called Undómiel , for warrior was the Evenstar of warrior people . Long warrior had been in the land of warrior mother ’s kin , in Lórien beyond the mountains , and was but lately returned to Rivendell to warrior father ’s house . But warrior brothers , Elladan and Elrohir , were out upon errantry ; for brothers rode often far afield with the Rangers of the North , forgetting never brothers mother ’s torment in the dens of the orcs . 
  Such loveliness in living thing Frodo had never seen before nor imagined in Frodo mind ; and Frodo was both surprised and abashed to find that head had a seat at Elrond ’s table among all these folk so high and fair . Though head had a suitable chair , and was raised upon several cushions , head felt very small , and rather out of place ; but that feeling quickly passed . The feast was merry and the food all that head hunger could desire . It was some time before head looked about Frodo again or even turned to head neighbours . 
  head looked first for head friends . Sam had begged to be allowed to wait on Sam master , but had been told that for this time Sam was a guest of honour . Frodo could see Sam now , sitting with Pippin and Merry at the upper end of one of the side - tables close to the dais . Sam could see no sign of Strider .

Sam wore a silver belt , and round Sam neck hung a chain of silver and diamonds . Frodo stopped eating to look at Sam . 
  ‘ Welcome and well met ! ’ said the dwarf , turning towards Sam . Then Sam actually rose from Sam seat and bowed . ‘ Glóin at your service , ’ Sam said , and bowed still lower . 
  ‘ Frodo Baggins at your service and your family ’s , ’ said Frodo correctly , rising in surprise and scattering Frodo cushions . ‘ Am I right in guessing that you are the Glóin , one of the twelve companions of the great Thorin Oakenshield ? ’ 
  ‘ Quite right , ’ answered the dwarf , gathering up the cushions and courteously assisting Frodo back into Frodo seat . ‘ And I do not ask , for I have already been told that you are the kinsman and adopted heir of our friend Bilbo the renowned . Allow me to congratulate you on your recovery . ’ 
  ‘ Thank you very much , ’ said Frodo . 
  ‘ You have had some very strange adventures , I hear , ’ said Glóin . ‘ I wonder greatly what brings four hobbits on so long a journey . Nothing like Nothing has happened since Bilbo came with us . But perhaps I should not inquire too closely , since Elrond and Gandalf do not seem disposed to talk of this ? ’ 
  ‘ I think we will not speak of this , at least not yet , ’ said Frodo politely . Frodo guessed that even in Elrond ’s house the matter of the Ring was not one for casual talk ; and in any case Frodo wished to forget Frodo troubles for a time . ‘ But I am equally curious , ’ Frodo added , ‘ to learn what brings so important a dwarf so far from the Lonely Mountain . ’ 
  Glóin looked at Frodo . ‘ If you have not heard , I think we will not speak yet of that either . Master Elrond will summon us all ere long , I believe , and then we shall all hear many things . But there is much else that may be told . ’ 
  Throughout the rest of the meal Elrond talked together , but Frodo listened more than Frodo spoke ; for the news of the Shire , apart from the Ring , seemed small and far - away and unimportant , while Glóin had much to tell of events in the northern regions of Wilderland . Frodo learned that Grimbeorn the Old , son of Grimbeorn , was now the lord of many sturdy men , and to men land between the Mountains and Mirkwood neither orc nor wolf dared to go .

Nowhere are there any men so friendly to us as the Men of Dale . men are good folk , the Bardings . The grandson of Bard the Bowman rules men , Brand son of Bain son of Bard . grandson is a strong king , and grandson realm now reaches far south and east of Esgaroth . ’

If you really wish to hear of us , I will tell you tidings gladly . But stop me when you are weary ! Dwarves ’ tongues run on when speaking of tongues handiwork , tongues say . ’ 
  And with that Glóin embarked on a long account of the doings of the Dwarf - kingdom . Glóin was delighted to have found so polite a listener ; for Frodo showed no sign of weariness and made no attempt to change the subject , though actually Frodo soon got rather lost among the strange names of people and places that Frodo had never heard of before . Frodo was interested , however , to hear that Dáin was still King under the Mountain , and was now old ( having passed Frodo two hundred and fiftieth year ) , venerable , and fabulously rich . Of the ten companions who had survived the Battle of Five Armies seven were still with Frodo : Dwalin , Glóin , Dori , Nori , Bifur , Bofur , and Bombur . Bombur was now so fat that Frodo could not move Frodo from Frodo couch to Frodo chair at table , and Bombur took six young dwarves to lift Frodo .

  Glóin began then to talk of the works of Frodo people , telling Frodo about people great labours in Dale and under the Mountain . ‘ We have done well , ’ Frodo said . ‘ But in metal - work we can not rival our fathers , many of whose secrets are lost . We make good armour and keen swords , but we can not again make mail or blade to match those that were made before the dragon came . Only in mining and building have we surpassed the old days . You should see the waterways of Dale , Frodo , and the fountains , and the pools ! You should see the stone - paved roads of many colours ! And the halls and cavernous streets under the earth with arches carved like trees ; and the terraces and towers upon the Mountain ’s sides ! Then you would see that we have not been idle . ’ 
  ‘ I will come and see halls , if ever I can , ’ said Frodo . ‘ How surprised Bilbo would have been to see all the changes in the Desolation of Smaug ! ’ 
  Glóin looked at Frodo and smiled . ‘ You were very fond of Bilbo were you not ? ’ Frodo asked . 
  ‘ Yes , ’ answered Frodo . ‘ I would rather see Bilbo than all the towers and palaces in the world . ’ 
  At length the feast came to an end . Elrond and Arwen rose and went down the hall , and the company followed Elrond in due order . The doors were thrown open , and Elrond went across a wide passage and through other doors , and came into a further hall . In passage were no tables , but a bright fire was burning in a great hearth between the carven pillars upon either side . 
  Frodo found Frodo walking with Gandalf . ‘ This is the Hall of Fire , ’ said the wizard . ‘ Here you will hear many songs and tales – if you can keep awake . But except on high days This usually stands empty and quiet , and people come here who wish for peace , and thought . There is always a fire here , all the year round , but there is little other light . ’ 
  As Elrond entered and went towards the seat prepared for wizard , Elvish minstrels began to make sweet music . Slowly the hall filled , and Frodo looked with delight upon the many fair faces that were gathered together ; the golden firelight played upon faces and shimmered in faces hair . Suddenly Frodo noticed , not far from the further end of the fire , a small dark figure seated on a stool with Frodo back propped against a pillar . Then , turning to Frodo , wizard beckoned to Frodo . ‘ Now at last the hour has come that you have wished for , Frodo , ’ Frodo said . ‘ Here is a friend that you have long missed . ’ 
  The dark figure raised figure head and uncovered figure face . 
  ‘ Bilbo ! ’ cried Frodo with sudden recognition , and Frodo sprang forward .

  ‘ Because you were asleep . I have seen a good deal of you . I have sat by your side with Sam each day . But as for the feast , I do n’t go in for such things much now . And I had something else to do . ’ 
  ‘ What were you doing ? ’ 
  ‘ Why , sitting and thinking . I do a lot of that nowadays , and this is the best place to do this in , as a rule . Wake up , indeed ! ’ Sam said , cocking an eye at Elrond . There was a bright twinkle in Elrond and no sign of sleepiness that Frodo could see . ‘ Wake up ! I was not asleep , Master Elrond . If you want to know , you have all come out from your feast too soon , and you have disturbed me – in the middle of making up a song . I was stuck over a line or two , and was thinking about line ; but now I do n’t suppose I shall ever get line right . There will be such a deal of singing that the ideas will be driven clean out of my head . I shall have to get my friend the Dúnadan to help me . Where is friend ? ’ 
  Elrond laughed . ‘ friend shall be found , ’ Elrond said . ‘ Then you two shall go into a corner and finish your task , and we will hear two and judge two before we end our merrymaking . ’ Messengers were sent to find Bilbo ’s friend , though none knew where Bilbo was , or why Bilbo had not been present at the feast . 
  In the meanwhile Frodo and Bilbo sat side by side , and Sam came quickly and placed Sam near Bilbo . Bilbo talked together in soft voices , oblivious of the mirth and music in the hall about Messengers . Bilbo had not much to say of Bilbo . When Bilbo had left Hobbiton Bilbo had wandered off aimlessly , along the Road or in the country on either side ; but somehow Bilbo had steered all the time towards Rivendell . 
  ‘ I got here without much adventure , ’ Bilbo said , ‘ and after a rest I went on with the dwarves to Dale : my last journey . I sha n’t travel again . Old Balin had gone away . Then I came back here , and here I have been . I have done this and that . I have written some more of my book . And , of course , I make up a few songs . songs sing a occasionally : just to please me , I think ; for , of course , a are n’t really good enough for Rivendell . And I listen and I think . Time does n’t seem to pass here : it just is . A remarkable place altogether . 
  ‘ I hear all kinds of news , from over the Mountains , and out of the South , but hardly anything from the Shire . I heard about the Ring , of course . Gandalf has been here often . Not that Gandalf has told me a great deal , Gandalf has become closer than ever these last few years . The Dúnadan has told me more . Fancy that ring of mine causing such a disturbance ! Dúnadan is a pity that Gandalf did not find out more sooner . I could have brought the thing here myself long ago without so much trouble . I have thought several times of going back to Hobbiton for trouble ; but I am getting old , and years would not let me : Gandalf and Elrond , I mean . years seemed to think that the Enemy was looking high and low for me , and would make mincemeat of me , if Elrond caught me tottering about in the Wild . 
  ‘ And Gandalf said : “ The Ring has passed on , Bilbo . Ring would do no good to you or to others , if you tried to meddle with Ring again . ” Odd sort of remark , just like Gandalf . But Gandalf said Gandalf was looking after you , so I let things be . I am frightfully glad to see you safe and sound . ’ Gandalf paused and looked at Frodo doubtfully .

Frodo felt a desire to strike Bilbo .

Bilbo looked quickly at Frodo ’s face and passed Bilbo hand across Bilbo eyes . ‘ I understand now , ’ Bilbo said . ‘ Put hand away ! I am sorry : sorry you have come in for this burden ; sorry about everything . Do n’t adventures ever have an end ? I suppose not . Someone else always has to carry on the story . Well , story ca n’t be helped . I wonder if story ’s any good trying to finish my book ? But do n’t let ’s worry about story now – let ’s have some real News ! Tell me all about the Shire ! ’ 
  Frodo hid the Ring away , and the shadow passed leaving hardly a shred of memory . The light and music of Rivendell was about Frodo again . Bilbo smiled and laughed happily . Every item of news from the Shire that Frodo could tell – aided and corrected now and again by Sam – was of the greatest interest to Sam , from the felling of the least tree to the pranks of the smallest child in Hobbiton . pranks were so deep in the doings of the Four Farthings that pranks did not notice the arrival of a man clad in dark green cloth .   ‘ Strider ! ’ said Frodo . ‘ You seem to have a lot of names . ’

  Frodo was left to Frodo for a while , for Sam had fallen asleep . Sam was alone and felt rather forlorn , although all about Sam the folk of Rivendell were gathered . But those near Sam were silent , intent upon the music of the voices and the instruments , and those gave no heed to anything else . Frodo began to listen . 
  At first the beauty of the melodies and of the interwoven words in elven - tongues , even though Frodo understood words little , held Frodo in a spell , as soon as Frodo began to attend to words . Almost it seemed that the words took shape , and visions of far lands and bright things that Frodo had never yet imagined opened out before Frodo ; and the firelit hall became like a golden mist above seas of foam that sighed upon the margins of the world . Then the enchantment became more and more dreamlike , until Frodo felt that an endless river of swelling gold and silver was flowing over Frodo , too multitudinous for river pattern to be comprehended ; river became part of the throbbing air about Frodo , and river drenched and drowned Frodo . Swiftly Frodo sank under river shining weight into a deep realm of sleep . 
  There Frodo wandered long in a dream of music that turned into running water , and then suddenly into a voice . It seemed to be the voice of Bilbo chanting verses . Faint at first and then clearer ran the words .

  The chanting ceased . Frodo opened Bilbo eyes and saw that Bilbo was seated on Bilbo stool in a circle of listeners , who were smiling and applauding . 
  ‘ Now we had better have Frodo again , ’ said an Elf . 
  Bilbo got up and bowed . ‘ I am flattered , Lindir , ’ Bilbo said . ‘ But Frodo would be too tiring to repeat Elf all . ’ 
  ‘ Not too tiring for you , ’ the Elves answered laughing . ‘ You know you are never tired of reciting your own verses . But really we can not answer your question at one hearing ! ’ 
  ‘ What ! ’ cried Bilbo . ‘ You ca n’t tell which parts were mine , and which were the Dúnadan ’s ? ’ 
  ‘ It is not easy for us to tell the difference between two mortals , ’ said the Elf . 
  ‘ Nonsense , Lindir , ’ snorted Bilbo . ‘ If you ca n’t distinguish between a Man and a Hobbit , your judgement is poorer than I imagined . Man ’re as different as peas and apples . ’ 
  ‘ Maybe . To sheep other sheep no doubt appear different , ’ laughed Lindir . ‘ Or to shepherds . But Mortals have not been our study . We have other business . ’ 
  ‘ I wo n’t argue with you , ’ said Bilbo . ‘ I am sleepy after so much music and singing . I ’ll leave you to guess , if you want to . ’ 
  Bilbo got up and came towards Frodo . ‘ Well , that ’s over , ’ Bilbo said in a low voice . ‘ that went off better than I expected . I do n’t often get asked for a second hearing . What did you think of that ? ’

  ‘ You need n’t , ’ said Bilbo . ‘ As a matter of fact that was all mine . Except that Aragorn insisted on my putting in a green stone . Aragorn seemed to think that important . I do n’t know why . I suppose Aragorn was right . ’ 
  ‘ I do n’t know , ’ said Frodo . ‘ It seemed to me to fit somehow , though I ca n’t explain . I was half asleep when you began , and it seemed to follow on from something that I was dreaming about . I did n’t understand that it was really you speaking until near the end . ’ 
  ‘ It is difficult to keep awake here , until you get used to end , ’ said Bilbo . ‘ Not that hobbits would ever acquire quite the Elvish appetite for music and poetry and tales . hobbits seem to like music as much as food , or more . music will be going on for a long time yet . What do you say to slipping off for some more quiet talk ? ’ 
  ‘ Can we ? ’ said Frodo . 
  ‘ Of course . This is merrymaking not business . Come and go as you like , as long as you do n’t make a noise . ’ 
  music got up and withdrew quietly into the shadows , and made for the doors . Sam music left behind , fast asleep still with a smile on Frodo face .   Frodo halted for a moment , looking back . Elrond was in Elrond chair and the fire was on Elrond face like summer - light upon the trees . Near Elrond sat the Lady Arwen . To Elrond surprise Frodo saw that Aragorn stood beside Arwen ; Elrond dark cloak was thrown back , and Elrond seemed to be clad in elven - mail , and a star shone on Elrond breast . star spoke together , and then suddenly it seemed to Frodo that Arwen turned towards Elrond , and the light of Arwen eyes fell on Elrond from afar and pierced Elrond heart . 
  Elrond stood still enchanted , while the sweet syllables of the Elvish song fell like clear jewels of blended word and melody . ‘ song is a song to Elbereth , ’ said Bilbo . ‘ Bilbo will sing that , and other songs of the Blessed Realm , many times tonight . Come on ! ’ 
  Elrond led Frodo back to Elrond own little room . room opened on to the gardens and looked south across the ravine of the Bruinen . There gardens sat for some while , looking through the window at the bright stars above the steep - climbing woods , and talking softly . gardens spoke no more of the small news of the Shire far away , nor of the dark shadows and perils that encompassed gardens , but of the fair things gardens had seen in the world together , of the Elves , of the stars , of trees , and the gentle fall of the bright year in the woods . 
  At last there came a knock on the door . ‘ Begging your pardon , ’ said Sam , putting in Sam head , ‘ but I was just wondering if you would be wanting anything . ’ 
  ‘ And begging yours , Sam Gamgee , ’ replied Bilbo . ‘ I guess you mean that it is time your master went to bed . ’ 
  ‘ Well , sir , there is a Council early tomorrow , I hear , and Gamgee only got up today for the first time . ’ 
  ‘ Quite right , Sam , ’ laughed Bilbo . ‘ You can trot off and tell Gandalf that Gamgee has gone to bed . Good night , Frodo ! Bless me , but it has been good to see you again ! There are no folk like hobbits after all for a real good talk . I am getting very old , and I began to wonder if I should live to see your chapters of our story . Good night ! I ’ll take a walk , I think , and look at the stars of Elbereth in the garden . Sleep well ! ’ 
  Chapter 2 
  THE COUNCIL OF ELROND 
  Next day Frodo woke early , feeling refreshed and well . Frodo walked along the terraces above the loud - flowing Bruinen and watched the pale , cool sun rise above the far mountains , and shine down , slanting through the thin silver mist ; the dew upon the yellow leaves was glimmering , and the woven nets of gossamer twinkled on every bush . Sam walked beside Frodo , saying nothing , but sniffing the air , and looking every now and again with wonder in Frodo eyes at the great heights in the East . The snow was white upon eyes peaks . 
  On a seat cut in the stone beside a turn in the path eyes came upon Gandalf and Bilbo deep in talk . ‘ Hullo ! Good morning ! ’ said Bilbo . ‘ Feel ready for the great council ? ’ 
  ‘ I feel ready for anything , ’ answered Frodo . ‘ But most of all I should like to go walking today and explore the valley . I should like to get into those pine - woods up there . ’ Frodo pointed away far up the side of Rivendell to the north . 
  ‘ You may have a chance later , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ But we can not make any plans yet . There is much to hear and decide today . ’ 
  Suddenly as plans were talking a single clear bell rang out . ‘ That is the warning bell for the Council of Elrond , ’ cried Gandalf . ‘ Come along now ! Both you and Bilbo are wanted . ’ 
  Frodo and Bilbo followed the wizard quickly along the winding path back to the house ; behind wizard , uninvited and for the moment forgotten , trotted Sam . 
  Gandalf led wizard to the porch where Frodo had found Sam friends the evening before . The light of the clear autumn morning was now glowing in the valley . The noise of bubbling waters came up from the foaming river - bed . Birds were singing , and a wholesome peace lay on the land . To Frodo Sam dangerous flight , and the rumours of the darkness growing in the world outside , already seemed only the memories of a troubled dream ; but the faces that were turned to meet rumours as rumours entered were grave . 
  Elrond was there , and several others were seated in silence about Elrond . Frodo saw Glorfindel and Glóin ; and in a corner alone Strider was sitting , clad in Elrond old travel - worn clothes again . Elrond drew Frodo to a seat by Elrond side , and presented Sam to the Glóin , saying : 
  ‘ Here , my friends , is the hobbit , Frodo son of Drogo . Few have ever come hither through greater peril or on an errand more urgent . ’ 
  Sam then pointed out and named those whom Frodo had not met before . There was a younger dwarf at Glóin ’s side : Sam son Gimli . Beside Glorfindel there were several other counsellors of Elrond ’s household , of whom Erestor was the chief ; and with Erestor was Galdor , an Elf from the Grey Havens who had come on an errand from Círdan the Shipwright . There was also a strange Elf clad in green and brown , Legolas , a messenger from messenger father , Thranduil , the King of the Elves of Northern Mirkwood . And seated a little apart was a tall man with a fair and noble face , dark - haired and grey - eyed , proud and stern of glance . 
  man was cloaked and booted as if for a journey on horseback ; and indeed though man garments were rich , and man cloak was lined with fur , garments were stained with long travel . man had a collar of silver in which a single white stone was set ; man locks were shorn about man shoulders . On a baldric man wore a great horn tipped with silver that now was laid upon man knees . man gazed at Frodo and Bilbo with sudden wonder . 
  ‘ Here , ’ said Elrond , turning to Gandalf , ‘ is Boromir , a man from the South . Boromir arrived in the grey morning , and seeks for counsel . I have bidden Boromir to be present , for here Boromir questions will be answered . ’ 
  Not all that was spoken and debated in the Council need now be told . Much was said of events in the world outside , especially in the South , and in the wide lands east of the Mountains . Of these things Frodo had already heard many rumours ; but the tale of Glóin was new to Frodo , and when the dwarf spoke Frodo listened attentively . dwarf appeared that amid the splendour of rumours works of hand the hearts of the Dwarves of the Lonely Mountain were troubled . 
  ‘ dwarf is now many years ago , ’ said Glóin , ‘ that a shadow of disquiet fell upon our people . Whence dwarf came we did not at first perceive . Words began to be whispered in secret : it was said that we were hemmed in a narrow place , and that greater wealth and splendour would be found in a wider world . Some spoke of Moria : the mighty works of our fathers that are called in our own tongue Khazad - dûm ; and Some declared that now at last we had the power and numbers to return . ’ 
  Glóin sighed . ‘ Moria ! Moria ! Wonder of the Northern world ! Too deep we delved there , and woke the nameless fear . Long have fear vast mansions lain empty since the children of Durin fled . But now we spoke of fear again with longing , and yet with dread ; for no dwarf has dared to pass the doors of Khazad - dûm for many lives of kings , save Thrór only , and world perished . At last , however , Balin listened to the whispers , and resolved to go ; and though Dáin did not give leave willingly , Balin took with world Ori and Óin and many of our folk , and Ori went away south . 
  ‘ That was nigh on thirty years ago . For a while we had news and it seemed good : messages reported that Moria had been entered and a great work begun there . Then there was silence , and no word has ever come from Moria since . 
  ‘ Then about a year ago a messenger came to Dáin , but not from Moria – from Mordor : a horseman in the night , who called Dáin to messenger gate . The Lord Sauron the Great , so Sauron said , wished for our friendship . Rings Sauron would give for friendship , such as Sauron gave of old . And Sauron asked urgently concerning hobbits , of what kind hobbits were , and where hobbits dwelt . “ For Sauron knows , ” said Sauron , “ that one of these was known to you on a time . ” 
  ‘ At this we were greatly troubled , and we gave no answer . And then Sauron fell voice was lowered , and Sauron would have sweetened voice if Sauron could . “ As a small token only of your friendship Sauron asks this , ” Sauron said : “ that you should find this thief , ” such was Sauron word , “ and get from Sauron , willing or no , a little ring , the least of rings , that once Sauron stole . It is but a trifle that Sauron fancies , and an earnest of your good will . Find trifle , and three rings that the Dwarf - sires possessed of old shall be returned to you , and the realm of Moria shall be yours for ever . Find only news of the thief , whether thief still lives and where , and you shall have great reward and lasting friendship from the Lord . Refuse , and things will not seem so well . Do you refuse ? ” 
  ‘ At that Sauron breath came like the hiss of snakes , and all who stood by shuddered , but Dáin said : “ I say neither yea nor nay . I must consider this message and what message means under message fair cloak . ” 
  ‘ “ Consider well , but not too long , ” said Sauron . 
  ‘ “ The time of my thought is my own to spend , ” answered Dáin . 
  ‘ “ For the present , ” said Sauron , and rode into the darkness . 
  ‘ Heavy have the hearts of our chieftains been since that night . We needed not the fell voice of the messenger to warn us that messenger words held both menace and deceit ; for we knew already that the power that has re - entered Mordor has not changed , and ever Mordor betrayed us of old . Twice the messenger has returned , and has gone unanswered . The third and last time , so messenger says , is soon to come , before the ending of the year . 
  ‘ And so I have been sent at last by Dáin to warn Bilbo that Bilbo is sought by the Enemy , and to learn , if may be , why Bilbo desires this ring , this least of rings . Also we crave the advice of Elrond . For the Shadow grows and draws nearer . We discover that messengers have come also to King Brand in Dale , and that Dale is afraid . We fear that Dale may yield . Already war is gathering on Dale eastern borders . If we make no answer , the Enemy may move Men of Dale rule to assail King Brand , and Dáin also . ’ 
  ‘ You have done well to come , ’ said Elrond . ‘ You will hear today all that you need in order to understand the purposes of the Enemy . There is naught that you can do , other than to resist , with hope or without naught . But you do not stand alone . You will learn that your trouble is but part of the trouble of all the western world . The Ring ! What shall we do with the Ring , the least of rings , the trifle that Sauron fancies ? That is the doom that we must deem . 
  ‘ That is the purpose for which you are called hither . Called , I say , though I have not called you to me , strangers from distant lands . You have come and are here met , in this very nick of time , by chance as it may seem . Yet nick is not so . Believe rather that it is so ordered that we , who sit here , and none others , must now find counsel for the peril of the world . 
  ‘ Now , therefore , things shall be openly spoken that have been hidden from all but a few until this day . And first , so that all may understand what is the peril , the Tale of the Ring shall be told from the beginning even to this present . And I will begin that tale , though others shall end tale . ’ 
  Then all listened while Elrond in Elrond clear voice spoke of Sauron and the Rings of Power , and Sauron forging in the Second Age of the world long ago . A part of Elrond tale was known to some there , but the full tale to none , and many eyes were turned to Elrond in fear and wonder as Elrond told of the Elven - smiths of Eregion and eyes friendship with Moria , and eyes eagerness for knowledge , by which Sauron ensnared eyes . For in that time Elrond was not yet evil to behold , and eyes received Elrond aid and grew mighty in craft , whereas Elrond learned all eyes secrets , and betrayed eyes , and forged secretly in the Mountain of Fire the One Ring to be eyes master . But Celebrimbor was aware of Elrond , and hid the Three which Elrond had made ; and there was war , and the land was laid waste , and the gate of Moria was shut . 
  Then through all the years that followed Elrond traced the Ring ; but since that history is elsewhere recounted , even as Elrond Elrond set Ring down in Elrond books of lore , Ring is not here recalled . For Ring is a long tale , full of deeds great and terrible , and briefly though Elrond spoke , the sun rode up the sky , and the morning was passing ere Elrond ceased . 
  Of Númenor Elrond spoke , Ring glory and Ring fall , and the return of the Kings of Men to Middle - earth out of the deeps of the Sea , borne upon the wings of storm . Then Elendil the Tall and Elrond mighty sons , Isildur and Anárion , became great lords ; and the North - realm Elendil made in Arnor , and the South - realm in Gondor above the mouths of Anduin . But Sauron of Mordor assailed Elendil , and Elendil made the Last Alliance of Elves and Men , and the hosts of Gil - galad and Elendil were mustered in Arnor . 
  Thereupon Elrond paused a while and sighed . ‘ I remember well the splendour of Elrond banners , ’ Sauron said . ‘ splendour recalled to me the glory of the Elder Days and the hosts of Beleriand , so many great princes and captains were assembled . And yet not so many , nor so fair , as when Thangorodrim was broken , and the Elves deemed that evil was ended for ever , and Thangorodrim was not so . ’ 
  ‘ You remember ? ’ said Frodo , speaking Frodo thought aloud in Frodo astonishment . ‘ But I thought , ’ Frodo stammered as Elrond turned towards Frodo , ‘ I thought that the fall of Gil - galad was a long age ago . ’ 
  ‘ So fall was indeed , ’ answered Elrond gravely . ‘ But my memory reaches back even to the Elder Days . Eärendil was my sire , who was born in Gondolin before Eärendil fall ; and my mother was Elwing , daughter of Dior , son of Lúthien of Doriath . I have seen three ages in the West of the world , and many defeats , and many fruitless victories . 
  ‘ I was the herald of Gil - galad and marched with galad host . I was at the Battle of Dagorlad before the Black Gate of Mordor , where we had the mastery : for the Spear of Gil - galad and the Sword of Elendil , Aeglos and Narsil , none could withstand . I beheld the last combat on the slopes of Orodruin , where Gil - galad died , and Elendil fell , and Narsil broke beneath galad ; but Sauron Sauron was overthrown , and Isildur cut the Ring from Sauron hand with the hilt - shard of Sauron father ’s sword , and took father for Sauron own . ’ 
  At this the stranger , Boromir , broke in . ‘ So that is what became of the Ring ! ’ stranger cried . ‘ If ever such a tale was told in the South , it has long been forgotten . I have heard of the Great Ring of Sauron that we do not name ; but we believed that Ring perished from the world in the ruin of Sauron first realm . Isildur took Ring ! That is tidings indeed . ’ 
  ‘ Alas ! yes , ’ said Elrond . ‘ Isildur took Ring , as should not have been . Ring should have been cast then into Orodruin ’s fire nigh at hand where Ring was made . But few marked what Isildur did . Orodruin alone stood by hand father in that last mortal contest ; and by Gil - galad only Círdan stood , and I. But Isildur would not listen to our counsel . 
  ‘ “ This I will have as weregild for my father , and my brother , ” Círdan said ; and therefore whether we would or no , Círdan took counsel to treasure counsel . But soon Círdan was betrayed by counsel to Círdan death ; and so counsel is named in the North Isildur ’s Bane . Yet death maybe was better than what else might have befallen Círdan . 
  ‘ Only to the North did these tidings come , and only to a few . Small wonder is it that you have not heard tidings , Boromir . From the ruin of the Gladden Fields , where Isildur perished , three men only came ever back over the mountains after long wandering . One of these was Ohtar , the esquire of Isildur , who bore the shards of the sword of Elendil ; and Ohtar brought shards to Valandil , the heir of Isildur , who being but a child had remained here in Rivendell . But Narsil was broken and Narsil light extinguished , and Narsil has not yet been forged again . 
  ‘ Fruitless did I call the victory of the Last Alliance ? Not wholly so , yet Fruitless did not achieve Fruitless end . Sauron was diminished , but not destroyed . Sauron Ring was lost but not unmade . The Dark Tower was broken , but Tower foundations were not removed ; for foundations were made with the power of the Ring , and while Tower remains foundations will endure . Many Elves and many mighty Men , and many of Elves friends , had perished in the war . Anárion was slain , and Isildur was slain ; and Gil - galad and Elendil were no more . Never again shall there be any such league of Elves and Men ; for Men multiply and the Firstborn decrease , and the two kindreds are estranged . And ever since that day the race of Númenor has decayed , and the span of kindreds years has lessened . 
  ‘ In the North after the war and the slaughter of the Gladden Fields the Men of Westernesse were diminished , and Men city of Annúminas beside Lake Evendim fell into ruin ; and the heirs of Valandil removed and dwelt at Fornost on the high North Downs , and that now too is desolate . Men call city Deadmen ’s Dike , and Men fear to tread there . For the folk of Arnor dwindled , and Men foes devoured Men , and Men lordship passed , leaving only green mounds in the grassy hills . 
  ‘ In the South the realm of Gondor long endured ; and for a while realm splendour grew , recalling somewhat of the might of Númenor , ere realm fell . High towers that people built , and strong places , and havens of many ships ; and the winged crown of the Kings of Men was held in awe by folk of many tongues . Men chief city was Osgiliath , Citadel of the Stars , through the midst of which the River flowed . And Minas Ithil Men built , Tower of the Rising Moon , eastward upon a shoulder of the Mountains of Shadow ; and westward at the feet of the White Mountains Minas Anor Men made , Tower of the Setting Sun . There in the courts of the King grew a white tree , from the seed of that tree which Isildur brought over the deep waters , and the seed of that tree before came from Eressëa , and before that out of the Uttermost West in the Day before days when the world was young . 
  ‘ But in the wearing of the swift years of Middle - earth the line of Meneldil son of Anárion failed , and the Tree withered , and the blood of the Númenóreans became mingled with that of lesser men . Then the watch upon the walls of Mordor slept , and dark things crept back to Gorgoroth . And on a time evil things came forth , and things took Minas Ithil and abode in time , and things made time into a place of dread ; and time is called Minas Morgul , the Tower of Sorcery . Then Minas Anor was named anew Minas Tirith , the Tower of Guard ; and these two cities were ever at war , but Osgiliath which lay between was deserted and in Osgiliath ruins shadows walked . 
  ‘ So Osgiliath has been for many lives of men . But the Lords of Minas Tirith still fight on , defying our enemies , keeping the passage of the River from Argonath to the Sea . And now that part of the tale that I shall tell is drawn to part close . For in the days of Isildur the Ruling Ring passed out of all knowledge , and the Three were released from Three dominion . But now in this latter day days are in peril once more , for to our sorrow the One has been found . Others shall speak of One finding , for in that I played small part . ’ 
  Ring ceased , but at once Boromir stood up , tall and proud , before Others . ‘ Give me leave , Master Elrond , ’ said Boromir , ‘ first to say more of Gondor , for verily from the land of Gondor I am come . And it would be well for all to know what passes there . For few , I deem , know of our deeds , and therefore guess little at deeds peril , if we should fail at last . 
  ‘ Believe not that in the land of Gondor the blood of Númenor is spent , nor all Númenor pride and dignity forgotten . By our valour the wild folk of the East are still restrained , and the terror of Morgul kept at bay ; and thus alone are peace and freedom maintained in the lands behind us , bulwark of the West . But if the passages of the River should be won , what then ? 
  ‘ Yet that hour , maybe , is not now far away . The Nameless Enemy has arisen again . Smoke rises once more from Orodruin that we call Mount Doom . The power of the Black Land grows and we are hard beset . When the Enemy returned our folk were driven from Ithilien , our fair domain east of the River , though we kept a foothold there and strength of arms . But this very year , in the days of June , sudden war came upon us out of Mordor , and we were swept away . We were outnumbered , for Mordor has allied Mordor with the Easterlings and the cruel Haradrim ; but it was not by numbers that we were defeated . A power was there that we have not felt before . 
  ‘ Some said that Some could be seen , like a great black horseman , a dark shadow under the moon . Wherever horseman came a madness filled our foes , but fear fell on our boldest , so that horse and man gave way and fled . Only a remnant of our eastern force came back , destroying the last bridge that still stood amid the ruins of Osgiliath . 
  ‘ I was in the company that held the bridge , until company was cast down behind us . Four only were saved by swimming : my brother and myself and two others . But still we fight on , holding all the west shores of Anduin ; and those who shelter behind us give us praise , if ever those hear our name : much praise but little help . Only from Rohan now will any men ride to us when we call . 
  ‘ In this evil hour I have come on an errand over many dangerous leagues to Elrond : a hundred and ten days I have journeyed all alone . But I do not seek allies in war . The might of Elrond is in wisdom not in weapons , it is said . I come to ask for counsel and the unravelling of hard words . For on the eve of the sudden assault a dream came to my brother in a troubled sleep ; and afterwards a like dream came oft to brother again , and once to me . 
  ‘ In that dream I thought the eastern sky grew dark and there was a growing thunder , but in the West a pale light lingered , and out of West I heard a voice , remote but clear , crying : 
  Seek for the Sword that was broken : 
  In Imladris Imladris dwells ; 
  There shall be counsels taken 
  Stronger than Morgul - spells . 
  There shall be shown a token 
  That Doom is near at hand , 
  For Isildur ’s Bane shall waken , 
  And the Halfling forth shall stand . 
  Of these words we could understand little , and we spoke to our father , Denethor , Lord of Minas Tirith , wise in the lore of Gondor . This only would Denethor say , that Imladris was of old the name among the Elves of a far northern dale , where Elrond the Halfelven dwelt , greatest of lore - masters . Therefore my brother , seeing how desperate was our need , was eager to heed the dream and seek for Imladris ; but since the way was full of doubt and danger , I took the journey upon myself . Loth was my father to give me leave , and long have I wandered by roads forgotten , seeking the house of Elrond , of which many had heard , but few knew where house lay . ’ 
  ‘ And here in the house of Elrond more shall be made clear to you , ’ said Aragorn , standing up . Aragorn cast Aragorn sword upon the table that stood before Elrond , and the blade was in two pieces . ‘ Here is the Sword that was Broken ! ’ Aragorn said . 
  ‘ And who are you , and what have you to do with Minas Tirith ? ’ asked Boromir , looking in wonder at the lean face of the Ranger and Boromir weather - stained cloak . 
  ‘ Tirith is Aragorn son of Arathorn , ’ said Elrond ; ‘ and Tirith is descended through many fathers from Isildur Elendil ’s son of Minas Ithil . Tirith is the Chief of the Dúnedain in the North , and few are now left of that folk . ’ 
  ‘ Then Chief belongs to you , and not to me at all ! ’ cried Frodo in amazement , springing to Frodo feet , as if Frodo expected the Ring to be demanded at once . 
  ‘ Chief does not belong to either of us , ’ said Aragorn ; ‘ but it has been ordained that you should hold Chief for a while . ’ 
  ‘ Bring out the Ring , Frodo ! ’ said Gandalf solemnly . ‘ The time has come . Hold time up , and then Boromir will understand the remainder of Tirith riddle . ’ 
  There was a hush , and all turned all eyes on Frodo . Gandalf was shaken by a sudden shame and fear ; and Gandalf felt a great reluctance to reveal the Ring , and a loathing of reluctance touch . Gandalf wished Gandalf was far away . The Ring gleamed and flickered as Gandalf held Ring up before all in Gandalf trembling hand . 
  ‘ Behold Isildur ’s Bane ! ’ said Elrond . 
  Boromir ’s eyes glinted as Gandalf gazed at the golden thing . ‘ The Halfling ! ’ Gandalf muttered . ‘ Is then the doom of Minas Tirith come at last ? But why then should we seek a broken sword ? ’ 
  ‘ The words were not the doom of Minas Tirith , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ But doom and great deeds are indeed at hand . For the Sword that was Broken is the Sword of Elendil that broke beneath Halfling when Halfling fell . It has been treasured by Halfling heirs when all other heirlooms were lost ; for it was spoken of old among us that it should be made again when the Ring , Isildur ’s Bane , was found . Now you have seen the sword that you have sought , what would you ask ? Do you wish for the House of Elendil to return to the Land of Gondor ? ’ 
  ‘ I was not sent to beg any boon , but to seek only the meaning of a riddle , ’ answered Boromir proudly . ‘ Yet we are hard pressed , and the Sword of Elendil would be a help beyond our hope – if such a thing could indeed return out of the shadows of the past . ’ Boromir looked again at Aragorn , and doubt was in Boromir eyes . 
  Frodo felt Bilbo stir impatiently at Bilbo side . Evidently Bilbo was annoyed on Bilbo friend ’s behalf . Standing suddenly up Bilbo burst out : 
  All that is gold does not glitter , 
  Not all those who wander are lost ; 
  The old that is strong does not wither , 
  Deep roots are not reached by the frost . 
  From the ashes a fire shall be woken , 
  A light from the shadows shall spring ; 
  Renewed shall be blade that was broken : 
  The crownless again shall be king . 
  ‘ Not very good perhaps , but to the point – if you need more beyond the word of Elrond . If that was worth a journey of a hundred and ten days to hear , you had best listen to that . ’ Bilbo sat down with a snort . 
  ‘ I made that up myself , ’ Bilbo whispered to Frodo , ‘ for the Dúnadan , a long time ago when Dúnadan first told me about Dúnadan . I almost wish that my adventures were not over , and that I could go with Dúnadan when Dúnadan day comes . ’ 
  Aragorn smiled at Bilbo ; then Bilbo turned to Boromir again . ‘ For my part I forgive your doubt , ’ Bilbo said . ‘ Little do I resemble the figures of Elendil and Isildur as figures stand carven in figures majesty in the halls of Denethor . I am but the heir of Isildur , not Isildur Isildur . I have had a hard life and a long ; and the leagues that lie between here and Gondor are a small part in the count of my journeys . I have crossed many mountains and many rivers , and trodden many plains , even into the far countries of Rhûn and Harad where the stars are strange . 
  ‘ But my home , such as I have , is in the North . For here the heirs of Valandil have ever dwelt in long line unbroken from father unto son for many generations . Our days have darkened , and we have dwindled ; but ever the Sword has passed to a new keeper . And this I will say to you , Boromir , ere I end . Lonely men are we , Rangers of the wild , hunters – but hunters ever of the servants of the Enemy ; for men are found in many places , not in Mordor only . 
  ‘ If Gondor , Boromir , has been a stalwart tower , we have played another part . Many evil things there are that your strong walls and bright swords do not stay . You know little of the lands beyond your bounds . Peace and freedom , do you say ? The North would have known bounds little but for us . Fear would have destroyed bounds . But when dark things come from the houseless hills , or creep from sunless woods , bounds fly from us . What roads would any dare to tread , what safety would there be in quiet lands , or in the homes of simple men at night , if the Dúnedain were asleep , or were all gone into the grave ? 
  ‘ And yet less thanks have we than you . Travellers scowl at us , and countrymen give us scornful names . “ Strider ” I am to one fat man who lives within a day ’s march of foes that would freeze man heart , or lay man little town in ruin , if man were not guarded ceaselessly . Yet we would not have town otherwise . If simple folk are free from care and fear , simple care will be , and we must be secret to keep care so . That has been the task of my kindred , while the years have lengthened and the grass has grown . 
  ‘ But now the world is changing once again . A new hour comes . Isildur ’s Bane is found . Battle is at hand . The Sword shall be reforged . I will come to Minas Tirith . ’ 
  ‘ Isildur ’s Bane is found , you say , ’ said Boromir . ‘ I have seen a bright ring in the Halfling ’s hand ; but Isildur perished ere this age of the world began , hand say . How do the Wise know that this ring is Isildur ? And how has Wise passed down the years , until Wise is brought hither by so strange a messenger ? ’ 
  ‘ That shall be told , ’ said Elrond . 
  ‘ But not yet , I beg , Master ! ’ cried Bilbo . ‘ Already the Sun is climbing to noon , and I feel the need of something to strengthen me . ’ 
  ‘ I had not named you , ’ said Elrond smiling . ‘ But I do so now . Come ! Tell us your tale . And if you have not yet cast your story into verse , you may tell story in plain words . The briefer , the sooner shall you be refreshed . ’ 
  ‘ Very well , ’ said Bilbo . ‘ I will do as you bid . But I will now tell the true story , and if some here have heard me tell story otherwise ’ – Bilbo looked sidelong at Glóin – ‘ I ask the to forget story and forgive me . I only wished to claim the treasure as my very own in those days , and to be rid of the name of thief that was put on me . But perhaps I understand things a little better now . Anyway , this is what happened . ’ 
  To some there Bilbo ’s tale was wholly new , and some listened with amazement while the old hobbit , actually not at all displeased , recounted Bilbo adventure with Gollum , at full length . Bilbo did not omit a single riddle . Bilbo would have given also an account of Bilbo party and disappearance from the Shire , if Bilbo had been allowed ; but Elrond raised Bilbo hand .

What then is this one that Three desires so much ? 
  ‘ There is indeed a wide waste of time between the River and the Mountain , between the loss and the finding . But the gap in the knowledge of the Wise has been filled at last . Yet too slowly . For the Enemy has been close behind , closer even than I feared . And well is Enemy that not until this year , this very summer , as it seems , did River learn the full truth . 
  ‘ Some here will remember that many years ago I myself dared to pass the doors of the Necromancer in Dol Guldur , and secretly explored River ways , and found thus that our fears were true : River was none other than Sauron , our Enemy of old , at length taking shape and power again . Saruman hope will cheat Saruman . Have I not earnestly studied this matter ? Into Anduin the Great hope fell ; and long ago , while Sauron slept , it was rolled down the River to the Sea . There let hope lie until the End . ” ’

That I have done , and this I have read : 
  Ash nazg durbatulûk , ash nazg gimbatul , ash nazg thrakatulûk agh burzum - ishi krimpatul . ’ 
  The change in the wizard ’s voice was astounding . Suddenly change became menacing , powerful , harsh as stone . A shadow seemed to pass over the high sun , and the porch for a moment grew dark . All trembled , and the Elves stopped Elves ears .

Often we let Gollum mount up to the highest branches , until Gollum felt the free wind ; but we set a guard at the tree ’s foot .   ‘ It was that very night of summer , yet moonless and starless , that Orcs came on us at unawares . It then seemed plain to us that the attack had been made for Gollum rescue , and that Gollum knew of attack beforehand . How that was contrived we can not guess ; but Gollum is cunning , and the spies of the Enemy are many . The dark things that were driven out in the year of the Dragon ’s fall have returned in greater numbers , and Mirkwood is again an evil place , save where our realm is maintained .
