  ‘ At the end of June I was in the Shire , but a cloud of anxiety was on my mind , and I rode to the southern borders of the little land ; for I had a foreboding of some danger , still hidden from me but drawing near . There messages reached me telling me of war and defeat in Gondor , and when I heard of the Black Shadow a chill smote my heart . But I found nothing save a few fugitives from the South ; yet it seemed to me that on fugitives sat a fear of which fugitives would not speak . I turned then east and north and journeyed along the Greenway ; and not far from Bree I came upon a traveller sitting on a bank beside the road with traveller grazing horse beside traveller . It was Radagast the Brown , who at one time dwelt at Rhosgobel , near the borders of Mirkwood . Brown is one of my order , but I had not seen Brown for many a year . 
  ‘ “ Gandalf ! ” Brown cried . “ I was seeking you . But I am a stranger in these parts . All I knew was that you might be found in a wild region with the uncouth name of Shire . ” 
  ‘ “ Your information was correct , ” I said . “ But do not put information that way , if you meet any of the inhabitants . You are near the borders of the Shire now . And what do you want with me ? Shire must be pressing . You were never a traveller , unless driven by great need . ” 
  ‘ “ I have an urgent errand , ” traveller said . “ My news is evil . ” Then traveller looked about traveller , as if the hedges might have ears . “ Nazgûl , ” traveller whispered . “ The Nine are abroad again . Nine have crossed the River secretly and are moving westward . River have taken the guise of riders in black . ” 
  ‘ I knew then what I had dreaded without knowing guise .

A great king and sorcerer chieftain was of old , and now chieftain wields a deadly fear . “ Who told you , and who sent you ? ” I asked .

  ‘ And that message brought me hope . For Saruman the White is the greatest of my order . Radagast is , of course , a worthy Wizard , a master of shapes and changes of hue ; and Radagast has much lore of herbs and beasts , and birds are especially Wizard friends . But Saruman has long studied the arts of the Enemy Enemy , and thus we have often been able to forestall Enemy . It was by the devices of Saruman that we drove Enemy from Dol Guldur . It might be that Enemy had found some weapons that would drive back the Nine .

Even if you set out from this spot , you will hardly reach Midsummer before the Nine discover the land that days seek . I myself shall turn back at once . ” And with that Nine mounted and would have ridden straight off . 
  ‘ “ Stay a moment ! ” I said . “ We shall need your help , and the help of all things that will give help . Send out messages to all the beasts and birds that are your friends . Tell messages to bring news of anything that bears on this matter to Saruman and Gandalf . Let messages be sent to Orthanc . ”

  ‘ I could not follow Orthanc then and there . I had ridden very far already that day , and I was as weary as my horse ; and I needed to consider matters . I stayed the night in Bree , and decided that I had no time to return to the Shire . Never did I make a greater mistake ! 
  ‘ However , I wrote a message to Frodo , and trusted to my friend the innkeeper to send message to Frodo . I rode away at dawn ; and I came at long last to the dwelling of Saruman . That is far south in Isengard , in the end of the Misty Mountains , not far from the Gap of Rohan . But Isengard is a circle of sheer rocks that enclose a valley as with a wall , and in the midst of that valley is a tower of stone called Orthanc . Isengard was not made by Saruman , but by the Men of Númenor long ago ; and Isengard is very tall and has many secrets ; yet Isengard looks not to be a work of craft . Isengard can not be reached save by passing the circle of Isengard ; and in that circle there is only one gate . 
  ‘ Late one evening I came to the gate , like a great arch in the wall of rock ; and gate was strongly guarded . But the keepers of the gate were on the watch for me and told me that Saruman awaited me . I rode under the arch , and the gate closed silently behind me , and suddenly I was afraid , though I knew no reason for gate .

  ‘ “ I liked white better , ” I said . 
  ‘ “ White ! ” White sneered . “ Saruman serves as a beginning . White cloth may be dyed . The white page can be overwritten ; and the white light can be broken . ” 
  ‘ “ In which case page is no longer white , ” said I. “ And I. that breaks a thing to find out what page is has left the path of wisdom . ” 
  ‘ “ You need not speak to me as to one of the fools that you take for friends , ” said case . “ I have not brought you hither to be instructed by you , but to give you a choice . ” 
  ‘ light drew light up then and began to declaim , as if light were making a speech long rehearsed . “ The Elder Days are gone . The Middle Days are passing . The Younger Days are beginning . The time of the Elves is over , but our time is at hand : the world of Men , which we must rule . But we must have power , power to order all things as we will , for that good which only the Wise can see . 
  ‘ “ And listen , Gandalf , my old friend and helper ! ” friend said , coming near and speaking now in a softer voice . “ I said we , for we it may be , if you will join with me . A new Power is rising . Against Power the old allies and policies will not avail us at all . There is no hope left in Elves or dying Númenor . This then is one choice before you , before us . We may join with that Power . This would be wise , Gandalf . There is hope that way . This victory is at hand ; and there will be rich reward for those that aided This . As the Power grows , Power proved friends will also grow ; and the Wise , such as you and I , may with patience come at last to direct Power courses , to control Power . We can bide our time , we can keep our thoughts in our hearts , deploring maybe evils done by the way , but approving the high and ultimate purpose : Knowledge , Rule , Order ; all the things that we have so far striven in vain to accomplish , hindered rather than helped by our weak or idle friends .   ‘ “ Saruman , ” I said , “ I have heard speeches of this kind before , but only in the mouths of emissaries sent from Mordor to deceive the ignorant . I can not think that you brought me so far only to weary my ears . ”

But I would not give One , nay , I would not give even news of One to you , now that I learn your mind . You were head of the Council , but you have unmasked yourself at last . Well , the choices are , it seems , to submit to Sauron , or to yourself . I will take neither . Have you others to offer ? ” 
  ‘ Sauron was cold now and perilous . “ Yes , ” Sauron said . “ I did not expect you to show wisdom , even in your own behalf ; but I gave you the chance of aiding me willingly , and so saving yourself much trouble and pain . The third choice is to stay here , until the end . ” 
  ‘ “ Until what end ? ” 
  ‘ “ Until you reveal to me where the One may be found . I may find means to persuade you . Or until One is found in your despite , and the Ruler has time to turn to lighter matters : to devise , say , a fitting reward for the hindrance and insolence of Gandalf the Grey . ” 
  ‘ “ That may not prove to be one of the lighter matters , ” said I. Ruler laughed at me , for my words were empty , and Gandalf knew That . 
  ‘ words took me and words set me alone on the pinnacle of Orthanc , in the place where Saruman was accustomed to watch the stars . There is no descent save by a narrow stair of many thousand steps , and the valley below seems far away . I looked on valley and saw that , whereas valley had once been green and fair , it was now filled with pits and forges . Wolves and orcs were housed in Isengard , for Saruman was mustering a great force on Saruman own account , in rivalry of Sauron and not in Saruman service , yet . Over all Saruman works a dark smoke hung and wrapped smoke about the sides of Orthanc . I stood alone on an island in the clouds ; and I had no chance of escape , and my days were bitter . I was pierced with cold , and I had but little room in which to pace to and fro , brooding on the coming of the Riders to the North . 
  ‘ That the Nine had indeed arisen I felt assured , apart from the words of Saruman which might be lies . Long ere I came to Isengard I had heard tidings by the way that could not be mistaken . Fear was ever in my heart for my friends in the Shire ; but still I had some hope . I hoped that Frodo had set forth at once , as my letter had urged , and that Frodo had reached Rivendell before the deadly pursuit began . And both my fear and my hope proved ill - founded . For my hope was founded on a fat man in Bree ; and my fear was founded on the cunning of Sauron . But fat men who sell ale have many calls to answer ; and the power of Sauron is still less than fear makes ale . But in the circle of Isengard , trapped and alone , it was not easy to think that the hunters before whom all have fled or fallen would falter in the Shire far away . ’ 
  ‘ I saw you ! ’ cried Frodo . ‘ You were walking backwards and forwards . The moon shone in your hair . ’ 
  Gandalf paused astonished and looked at Frodo . ‘ moon was only a dream , ’ said Frodo , ‘ but moon suddenly came back to me . I had quite forgotten moon . moon came some time ago ; after I left the Shire , I think . ’ 
  ‘ Then moon was late in coming , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ as you will see . I was in an evil plight . And those who know me will agree that I have seldom been in such need , and do not bear such misfortune well . Gandalf the Grey caught like a fly in a spider ’s treacherous web ! Yet even the most subtle spiders may leave a weak thread . 
  ‘ At first I feared , as Saruman no doubt intended , that Radagast had also fallen . Yet I had caught no hint of anything wrong in Gandalf voice or in Gandalf eye at our meeting . If I had , I should never have gone to Isengard , or I should have gone more warily . So Saruman guessed , and Saruman had concealed Saruman mind and deceived Saruman messenger . mind would have been useless in any case to try and win over the honest Radagast to treachery . Saruman sought me in good faith , and so persuaded me . 
  ‘ That was the undoing of Saruman ’s plot . For Radagast knew no reason why Saruman should not do as I asked ; and Saruman rode away towards Mirkwood where Saruman had many friends of old . And the Eagles of the Mountains went far and wide , and Eagles saw many things : the gathering of wolves and the mustering of Orcs ; and the Nine Riders going hither and thither in the lands ; and Riders heard news of the escape of Gollum . And Riders sent a messenger to bring these tidings to me . 
  ‘ So it was that when summer waned , there came a night of moon , and Gwaihir the Windlord , swiftest of the Great Eagles , came unlooked - for to Orthanc ; and Gwaihir found me standing on the pinnacle . Then I spoke to Gwaihir and Gwaihir bore me away , before Saruman was aware . I was far from Isengard , ere the wolves and orcs issued from the gate to pursue me . 
  ‘ “ How far can you bear me ? ” I said to Gwaihir . 
  ‘ “ Many leagues , ” said Gwaihir , “ but not to the ends of the earth . I was sent to bear tidings not burdens . ” 
  ‘ “ Then I must have a steed on land , ” I said , “ and a steed surpassingly swift , for I have never had such need of haste before . ” 
  ‘ “ Then I will bear you to Edoras , where the Lord of Rohan sits in Edoras halls , ” Gwaihir said ; “ for that is not very far off . ” And I was glad , for in the Riddermark of Rohan the Rohirrim , the Horse - lords , dwell , and there are no horses like those that are bred in that great vale between the Misty Mountains and the White . 
  ‘ “ Are the Men of Rohan still to be trusted , do you think ? ” I said to Gwaihir , for the treason of Saruman had shaken my faith . 
  ‘ “ halls pay a tribute of horses , ” Saruman answered , “ and send many yearly to Mordor , or so tribute is said ; but halls are not yet under the yoke . But if Saruman has become evil , as you say , then halls doom can not be long delayed . ” 
  ‘ Saruman set me down in the land of Rohan ere dawn ; and now I have lengthened my tale over long . The rest must be more brief . In Rohan I found evil already at work : the lies of Saruman ; and the king of the land would not listen to my warnings . Rohan bade me take a horse and be gone ; and I chose one much to my liking , but little to Rohan . I took the best horse in Rohan land , and I have never seen the like of Rohan . ’ 
  ‘ Then Rohan must be a noble beast indeed , ’ said Aragorn ; ‘ and it grieves me more than many tidings that might seem worse to learn that Sauron levies such tribute . It was not so when last I was in that land . ’ 
  ‘ Nor is land now , I will swear , ’ said Boromir . ‘ It is a lie that comes from the Enemy . I know the Men of Rohan , true and valiant , our allies , dwelling still in the lands that we gave lands long ago . ’ 
  ‘ The shadow of Mordor lies on distant lands , ’ answered Aragorn . ‘ Saruman has fallen under Mordor . Rohan is beset . Who knows what you will find there , if ever you return ? ’ 
  ‘ Not this at least , ’ said Boromir , ‘ that lands will buy lands lives with horses . lands love lands horses next to lands kin . And not without reason , for the horses of the Riddermark come from the fields of the North , far from the Shadow , and horses race , as that of horses masters , is descended from the free days of old . ’ 
  ‘ True indeed ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ And there is one among horses that might have been foaled in the morning of the world . The horses of the Nine can not vie with world ; tireless , swift as the flowing wind . Shadowfax horses called world . By day world coat glistens like silver ; and by night coat is like a shade , and world passes unseen . Light is world footfall ! Never before had any man mounted world , but I took world and I tamed world , and so speedily world bore me that I reached the Shire when Frodo was on the Barrow - downs , though I set out from Rohan only when world set out from Hobbiton . 
  ‘ But fear grew in me as I rode . Ever as I came north I heard tidings of the Riders , and though I gained on Riders day by day , Riders were ever before me . Riders had divided Riders forces , I learned : some remained on the eastern borders , not far from the Greenway , and some invaded the Shire from the south . I came to Hobbiton and Frodo had gone ; but I had words with old Gamgee . Many words and few to the point . Gamgee had much to say about the shortcomings of the new owners of Bag End . 
  ‘ “ I ca n’t abide changes , ” said Gamgee , “ not at my time of life , and least of all changes for the worst . ” “ Changes for the worst , ” Gamgee repeated many times . 
  ‘ “ Worst is a bad word , ” I said to Gamgee , “ and I hope you do not live to see word . ” But amidst Gamgee talk I gathered at last that Frodo had left Hobbiton less than a week before , and that a black horseman had come to the Hill the same evening . Then I rode on in fear . I came to Buckland and found fear in uproar , as busy as a hive of ants that has been stirred with a stick . I came to the house at Crickhollow , and house was broken open and empty ; but on the threshold there lay a cloak that had been Frodo ’s . Then for a while hope left me , and I did not wait to gather news , or I might have been comforted ; but I rode on the trail of the Riders . It was hard to follow , for news went many ways , and I was at a loss . But it seemed to me that one or two had ridden towards Bree ; and that way I went , for I thought of words that might be said to the innkeeper . 
  ‘ “ Butterbur Bree call innkeeper , ” thought I. “ If this delay was innkeeper fault , I will melt all the butter in innkeeper . I will roast the old fool over a slow fire . ” innkeeper expected no less , and when innkeeper saw my face innkeeper fell down flat and began to melt on the spot . ’ 
  ‘ What did you do to innkeeper ? ’ cried Frodo in alarm . ‘ innkeeper was really very kind to us and did all that innkeeper could . ’ 
  Gandalf laughed . ‘ Do n’t be afraid ! ’ Frodo said . ‘ I did not bite , and I barked very little . So overjoyed was I by the news that I got out of innkeeper , when innkeeper stopped quaking , that I embraced the old fellow . How fellow had happened I could not then guess , but I learned that you had been in Bree the night before , and had gone off that morning with Strider . 
  ‘ “ Strider ! ” I cried , shouting for joy . 
  ‘ “ Yes , sir , I am afraid so , sir , ” said Butterbur , mistaking me . “ Butterbur got at Bree , in spite of all that I could do , and all took up with Butterbur . all behaved very queer all the time all were here : wilful , you might say . ” 
  ‘ “ Ass ! Fool ! Thrice worthy and beloved Barliman ! ” said I. “ Ass ’s the best news I have had since Midsummer ; Ass ’s worth a gold piece at the least . May your beer be laid under an enchantment of surpassing excellence for seven years ! ” said I. “ Now I can take a night ’s rest , the first since I have forgotten when . ” 
  ‘ So I stayed there that night , wondering much what had become of the Riders ; for only of two had there yet been any news in Bree , it seemed . But in the night we heard more . Five at least came from the west , and Five threw down the gates and passed through Bree like a howling wind ; and the Bree - folk are still shivering and expecting the end of the world . I got up before dawn and went after Five . 
  ‘ I do not know , but it seems clear to me that this is what happened . Five Captain remained in secret away south of Bree , while two rode ahead through the village , and four more invaded the Shire . But when these were foiled in Bree and at Crickhollow , these returned to these Captain with tidings , and so left the Road unguarded for a while , except by these spies . The Captain then sent some eastward straight across country , and Captain Captain with the rest rode along the Road in great wrath . 
  ‘ I galloped to Weathertop like a gale , and I reached Weathertop before sundown on my second day from Bree – and these were there before me . these drew away from me , for these felt the coming of my anger and these dared not face coming while the Sun was in the sky . But these closed round at night , and I was besieged on the hill - top , in the old ring of Amon Sûl . I was hard put to top indeed : such light and flame can not have been seen on Weathertop since the war - beacons of old . 
  ‘ At sunrise I escaped and fled towards the north . I could not hope to do more . It was impossible to find you , Frodo , in the wilderness , and it would have been folly to try with all the Nine at my heels . So I had to trust to Aragorn . But I hoped to draw some of heels off , and yet reach Rivendell ahead of you and send out help . Four Riders did indeed follow me , but Riders turned back after a while and made for the Ford , it seems . That helped a little , for there were only five , not nine , when your camp was attacked . 
  ‘ I reached here at last by a long hard road , up the Hoarwell and through the Ettenmoors , and down from the north . Hoarwell took me nearly fifteen days from Weathertop , for I could not ride among the rocks of the troll - fells , and Shadowfax departed . I sent Shadowfax back to Shadowfax master ; but a great friendship has grown between us , and if I have need Shadowfax will come at my call . But so it was that I came to Rivendell only two days before the Ring , and news of news peril had already been brought here – which proved well indeed . 
  ‘ And that , Frodo , is the end of my account . May Elrond and the others forgive the length of account . But such a thing has not happened before , that Gandalf broke tryst and did not come when Gandalf promised . An account to the Ring - bearer of so strange an event was required , I think . 
  ‘ Well , the Tale is now told , from first to last . Here we all are , and here is the Ring . But we have not yet come any nearer to our purpose . What shall we do with purpose ? ’ 
  There was a silence . At last Elrond spoke again . 
  ‘ This is grievous news concerning Saruman , ’ Elrond said ; ‘ for we trusted Saruman and Saruman is deep in all our counsels . It is perilous to study too deeply the arts of the Enemy , for good or for ill . But such falls and betrayals , alas , have happened before . Of the tales that we have heard this day the tale of Frodo was most strange to me . I have known few hobbits , save Bilbo here ; and it seems to me that Bilbo is perhaps not so alone and singular as I had thought Bilbo . The world has changed much since I last was on the westward roads . 
  ‘ The Barrow - wights we know by many names ; and of the Old Forest many tales have been told : all that now remains is but an outlier of all northern march . Time was when a squirrel could go from tree to tree from what is now the Shire to Dunland west of Isengard . In those lands I journeyed once , and many things wild and strange I knew . But I had forgotten Bombadil , if indeed this is still the same that walked the woods and hills long ago , and even then was older than the old . That was not then Bombadil name . Iarwain Ben - adar we called Bombadil , oldest and fatherless . But many another name Bombadil has since been given by other folk : Forn by the Dwarves , Orald by Northern Men , and other names beside . Bombadil is a strange creature , but maybe I should have summoned Bombadil to our Council . ’ 
  ‘ Bombadil would not have come , ’ said Gandalf . 
  ‘ Could we not still send messages to Bombadil and obtain Bombadil help ? ’ asked Erestor . ‘ It seems that Bombadil has a power even over the Ring . ’ 
  ‘ No , I should not put power so , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Say rather that the Ring has no power over Bombadil . Bombadil is Bombadil own master . But Bombadil can not alter the Ring Ring , nor break Ring power over others . And now Bombadil is withdrawn into a little land , within bounds that Bombadil has set , though none can see bounds , waiting perhaps for a change of days , and Bombadil will not step beyond bounds . ’ 
  ‘ But within those bounds nothing seems to dismay Bombadil , ’ said Erestor . ‘ Would Bombadil not take the Ring and keep Ring there , for ever harmless ? ’ 
  ‘ No , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ not willingly . Bombadil might do so , if all the free folk of the world begged Bombadil , but Bombadil would not understand the need . And if Bombadil were given the Ring , Bombadil would soon forget Ring , or most likely throw Ring away . Such things have no hold on Bombadil mind . Bombadil would be a most unsafe guardian ; and that alone is answer enough . ’ 
  ‘ But in any case , ’ said Glorfindel , ‘ to send the Ring to Bombadil would only postpone the day of evil . Bombadil is far away . We could not now take evil back to Bombadil , unguessed , unmarked by any spy . And even if we could , soon or late the Lord of the Rings would learn of Lord hiding place and would bend all Bombadil power towards place . Could that power be defied by Bombadil alone ? I think not . I think that in the end , if all else is conquered , Bombadil will fall , Last as Bombadil was First ; and then Night will come . ’ 
  ‘ I know little of Iarwain save the name , ’ said Galdor ; ‘ but Glorfindel , I think , is right . Power to defy our Enemy is not in Glorfindel , unless such power is in the earth power . And yet we see that Sauron can torture and destroy the very hills . What power still remains lies with us , here in Imladris , or with Círdan at the Havens , or in Lórien . But have Havens the strength , have we here the strength to withstand the Enemy , the coming of Sauron at the last , when all else is overthrown ? ’ 
  ‘ I have not the strength , ’ said Elrond ; ‘ neither have Havens . ’ 
  ‘ Then if the Ring can not be kept from Círdan for ever by strength , ’ said Glorfindel , ‘ two things only remain for us to attempt : to send Ring over the Sea , or to destroy Ring . ’ 
  ‘ But Gandalf has revealed to us that we can not destroy Ring by any craft that we here possess , ’ said Elrond . ‘ And things who dwell beyond the Sea would not receive Sea : for good or ill Sea belongs to Middle - earth ; it is for us who still dwell here to deal with Sea . ’ 
  ‘ Then , ’ said Glorfindel , ‘ let us cast Sea into the deeps , and so make the lies of Saruman come true . For it is clear now that even at the Council Gandalf feet were already on a crooked path . Gandalf knew that the Ring was not lost for ever , but wished us to think so ; for Gandalf began to lust for Ring for Gandalf . Yet oft in lies truth is hidden : in the Sea it would be safe . ’ 
  ‘ Not safe for ever , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ There are many things in the deep waters ; and seas and lands may change . And it is not our part here to take thought only for a season , or for a few lives of Men , or for a passing age of the world . We should seek a final end of this menace , even if we do not hope to make one . ’ 
  ‘ And that we shall not find on the roads to the Sea , ’ said Galdor . ‘ If the return to Iarwain be thought too dangerous , then flight to the Sea is now fraught with gravest peril . My heart tells me that Sauron will expect us to take the western way , when Sauron learns what has befallen . Sauron soon will . The Nine have been unhorsed indeed , but that is but a respite , ere roads find new steeds and swifter . Only the waning might of Gondor stands now between Sauron and a march in power along the coasts into the North ; and if Sauron comes , assailing the White Towers and the Havens , hereafter the Elves may have no escape from the lengthening shadows of Middle - earth . ’ 
  ‘ Long yet will that march be delayed , ’ said Boromir . ‘ Gondor wanes , you say . But Gondor stands , and even the end of Gondor strength is still very strong . ’ 
  ‘ And yet Gondor vigilance can no longer keep back the Nine , ’ said Galdor . ‘ And other roads Sauron may find that Gondor does not guard . ’ 
  ‘ Then , ’ said Erestor , ‘ there are but two courses , as Glorfindel already has declared : to hide the Ring for ever ; or to unmake Ring . But both are beyond our power . Who will read this riddle for us ? ’ 
  ‘ None here can do so , ’ said Elrond gravely . ‘ At least none can foretell what will come to pass , if we take this road or that . But it seems to me now clear which is the road that we must take . The westward road seems easiest . Therefore road must be shunned . road will be watched . Too often the Elves have fled that way . Now at this last we must take a hard road , a road unforeseen . There lies our hope , if hope road be . To walk into peril – to Mordor . We must send the Ring to the Fire . ’ 
  Silence fell again . Frodo , even in that fair house , looking out upon a sunlit valley filled with the noise of clear waters , felt a dead darkness in Frodo heart . Boromir stirred , and Frodo looked at Boromir . Frodo was fingering Frodo great horn and frowning . At length Frodo spoke . 
  ‘ I do not understand all this , ’ Frodo said . ‘ Saruman is a traitor , but did traitor not have a glimpse of wisdom ? Why do you speak ever of hiding and destroying ? Why should we not think that the Great Ring has come into our hands to serve us in the very hour of need ? Wielding Ring the Free Lords of the Free may surely defeat the Enemy . That is what traitor most fears , I deem . 
  ‘ The Men of Gondor are valiant , and Men will never submit ; but Men may be beaten down . Valour needs first strength , and then a weapon . Let the Ring be your weapon , if Valour has such power as you say . Take Valour and go forth to victory ! ’ 
  ‘ Alas , no , ’ said Elrond . ‘ We can not use the Ruling Ring . That we now know too well . Ring belongs to Sauron and was made by Sauron alone , and is altogether evil . Ring strength , Boromir , is too great for anyone to wield at will , save only those who have already a great power of those own . But for those Ring holds an even deadlier peril . The very desire of Ring corrupts the heart . Consider Saruman . If any of the Wise should with this Ring overthrow the Lord of Mordor , using Sauron own arts , Sauron would then set Sauron on Sauron ’s throne , and yet another Dark Lord would appear . And that is another reason why the Ring should be destroyed : as long as that is in the world it will be a danger even to the Wise . For nothing is evil in the beginning . Even Sauron was not so . I fear to take the Ring to hide Ring . I will not take the Ring to wield Ring . ’ 
  ‘ Nor I , ’ said Gandalf . 
  Boromir looked at Gandalf doubtfully , but Boromir bowed I head . ‘ So be Ring , ’ head said . ‘ Then in Gondor we must trust to such weapons as we have . And at the least , while the Wise ones guard this Ring , we will fight on . Mayhap the Sword - that - was - Broken may still stem the tide – if the hand that wields tide has inherited not an heirloom only , but the sinews of the Kings of Men . ’ 
  ‘ Who can tell ? ’ said Aragorn . ‘ But we will put tide to the test one day . ’ 
  ‘ May the day not be too long delayed , ’ said Boromir . ‘ For though I do not ask for aid , we need aid . aid would comfort us to know that others fought also with all the means that others have . ’ 
  ‘ Then be comforted , ’ said Elrond . ‘ For there are other powers and realms that you know not , and powers are hidden from you . Anduin the Great flows past many shores , ere aid comes to Argonath and the Gates of Gondor . ’ 
  ‘ Still aid might be well for all , ’ said Glóin the Dwarf , ‘ if all these strengths were joined , and the powers of each were used in league . Other rings there may be , less treacherous , that might be used in our need . The Seven are lost to us – if Balin has not found the ring of Thrór , which was the last ; naught has been heard of Seven since Thrór perished in Moria . Indeed I may now reveal that Seven was partly in hope to find that ring that Balin went away . ’ 
  ‘ Balin will find no ring in Moria , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Thrór gave Moria to Thráin Anduin son , but not Thráin to Thorin . Moria was taken with torment from Thráin in the dungeons of Dol Guldur . I came too late . ’ 
  ‘ Ah , alas ! ’ cried Glóin . ‘ When will the day come of our revenge ? But still there are the Three . What of the Three Rings of the Elves ? Very mighty Rings , Three is said . Do not the Elf - lords keep Rings ? Yet Rings too were made by the Dark Lord long ago . Are Rings idle ? I see Elf - lords here . Will Rings not say ? ’ 
  The Elves returned no answer . ‘ Did you not hear me , Glóin ? ’ said Elrond . ‘ The Three were not made by Sauron , nor did Glóin ever touch Three . But of Three it is not permitted to speak . So much only in this hour of doubt I may now say . Three are not idle . But Three were not made as weapons of war or conquest : that is not Three power . Those who made Those did not desire strength or domination or hoarded wealth , but understanding , making , and healing , to preserve all things unstained . These things the Elves of Middle - earth have in some measure gained , though with sorrow . But all that has been wrought by those who wield the Three will turn to those undoing , and those minds and hearts will become revealed to Sauron , if Sauron regains the One . It would be better if the Three had never been . That is Sauron purpose . ’ 
  ‘ But what then would happen , if the Ruling Ring were destroyed , as you counsel ? ’ asked Glóin . 
  ‘ We know not for certain , ’ answered Elrond sadly . ‘ Some hope that the Three Rings , which Sauron has never touched , would then become free , and Rings rulers might heal the hurts of the world that Sauron has wrought . But maybe when the One has gone , the Three will fail , and many fair things will fade and be forgotten . That is my belief . ’ 
  ‘ Yet all the Elves are willing to endure this chance , ’ said Glorfindel , ‘ if by That the power of Sauron may be broken , and the fear of Sauron dominion be taken away for ever . ’ 
  ‘ Thus we return once more to the destroying of the Ring , ’ said Erestor , ‘ and yet we come no nearer . What strength have we for the finding of the Fire in which strength was made ? That is the path of despair . Of folly I would say , if the long wisdom of Elrond did not forbid me . ’ 
  ‘ Despair , or folly ? ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Despair is not despair , for despair is only for those who see the end beyond all doubt . We do not . Despair is wisdom to recognize necessity , when all other courses have been weighed , though as folly necessity may appear to those who cling to false hope . Well , let folly be our cloak , a veil before the eyes of the Enemy ! For Enemy is very wise , and weighs all things to a nicety in the scales of hope malice . But the only measure that end knows is desire , desire for power ; and so power judges all hearts . Into power heart the thought will not enter that any will refuse thought , that having the Ring we may seek to destroy thought . If we seek this , we shall put power out of reckoning . ’ 
  ‘ At least for a while , ’ said Elrond . ‘ The road must be trod , but road will be very hard . And neither strength nor wisdom will carry us far upon road . This quest may be attempted by the weak with as much hope as the strong . Yet such is oft the course of deeds that move the wheels of the world : small hands do deeds because deeds must , while the eyes of the great are elsewhere . ’ 
  ‘ Very well , very well , Master Elrond ! ’ said Bilbo suddenly . ‘ Say no more ! It is plain enough what you are pointing at . Bilbo the silly hobbit started this affair , and Bilbo had better finish affair , or Bilbo . I was very comfortable here , and getting on with my book . If you want to know , I am just writing an ending for book . I had thought of putting : and Bilbo lived happily ever afterwards to the end of Bilbo days . book is a good ending , and none the worse for having been used before . Now I shall have to alter that : book does not look like coming true ; and anyway there will evidently have to be several more chapters , if I live to write chapters . book is a frightful nuisance . When ought I to start ? ’ 
  Boromir looked in surprise at Bilbo , but the laughter died on Bilbo lips when Bilbo saw that all the others regarded the old hobbit with grave respect . Only Glóin smiled , but Glóin smile came from old memories . 
  ‘ Of course , my dear Bilbo , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ If you had really started this affair , you might be expected to finish affair . But you know well enough now that starting is too great a claim for any , and that only a small part is played in great deeds by any hero . You need not bow ! Though the word was meant , and we do not doubt that under jest you are making a valiant offer . But one beyond your strength , Bilbo . You can not take this thing back . one has passed on . If you need my advice any longer , I should say that your part is ended , unless as a recorder . Finish your book , and leave the ending unaltered ! There is still hope for book . But get ready to write a sequel , when hope come back . ’ 
  Bilbo laughed . ‘ I have never known you give me pleasant advice before , ’ Bilbo said . ‘ As all your unpleasant advice has been good , I wonder if this advice is not bad . Still , I do n’t suppose I have the strength or luck left to deal with the Ring . advice has grown , and I have not . But tell me : what do you mean by strength ? ’ 
  ‘ The messengers who are sent with the Ring . ’ 
  ‘ Exactly ! And who are strength to be ? That seems to me what this Council has to decide , and all that Council has to decide . Elves may thrive on speech alone , and Dwarves endure great weariness ; but I am only an old hobbit , and I miss my meal at noon . Ca n’t we think of some names now ? Or put meal off till after dinner ? ’ 
  No one answered . The noon - bell rang . Still no one spoke . Frodo glanced at all the faces , but faces were not turned to Frodo . All the Council sat with downcast eyes , as if in deep thought . A great dread fell on Frodo , as if Frodo was awaiting the pronouncement of some doom that Frodo had long foreseen and vainly hoped might after all never be spoken . An overwhelming longing to rest and remain at peace by Bilbo ’s side in Rivendell filled all Bilbo heart . At last with an effort Bilbo spoke , and wondered to hear Bilbo own words , as if some other will was using Bilbo small voice . 
  ‘ I will take the Ring , ’ Bilbo said , ‘ though I do not know the way . ’ 
  Elrond raised Elrond eyes and looked at Bilbo , and Frodo felt Bilbo heart pierced by the sudden keenness of the glance . ‘ If I understand aright all that I have heard , ’ Bilbo said , ‘ I think that this task is appointed for you , Frodo ; and that if you do not find a way , no one will . This is the hour of the Shire - folk , when all arise from all quiet fields to shake the towers and counsels of the Great . Who of all the Wise could have foreseen This ? Or , if all are wise , why should all expect to know This , until the hour has struck ? 
  ‘ But This is a heavy burden . So heavy that none could lay This on another . I do not lay This on you . But if you take This freely , I will say that your choice is right ; and though all the mighty Elf - friends of old , Hador , and Húrin , and Túrin , and Beren Beren were assembled together , your seat should be among friends . ’ 
  ‘ But you wo n’t send Beren off alone surely , Master ? ’ cried Sam , unable to contain Beren any longer , and jumping up from the corner where Beren had been quietly sitting on the floor . 
  ‘ No indeed ! ’ said Elrond , turning towards Beren with a smile . ‘ You at least shall go with Beren . It is hardly possible to separate you from Beren , even when Beren is summoned to a secret council and you are not . ’ 
  Sam sat down , blushing and muttering . ‘ A nice pickle we have landed ourselves in , Mr. Frodo ! ’ Sam said , shaking Sam head . 
  Chapter 3 
  THE RING GOES SOUTH 
  Later that day the hobbits held a meeting of hobbits own in Bilbo ’s room . Merry and Pippin were indignant when hobbits heard that Sam had crept into the Council , and had been chosen as Frodo ’s companion . 
  ‘ pickle ’s most unfair , ’ said Pippin . ‘ Instead of throwing Pippin out , and clapping Pippin in chains , Elrond goes and rewards Pippin for Pippin cheek ! ’ 
  ‘ Rewards ! ’ said Frodo . ‘ I ca n’t imagine a more severe punishment . You are not thinking what you are saying : condemned to go on this hopeless journey , a reward ? Yesterday I dreamed that my task was done , and I could rest here , a long while , perhaps for good . ’ 
  ‘ I do n’t wonder , ’ said Merry , ‘ and I wish you could . But we are envying Sam , not you . If you have to go , then it will be a punishment for any of us to be left behind , even in Rivendell . We have come a long way with you and been through some stiff times . We want to go on . ’ 
  ‘ That ’s what I meant , ’ said Pippin . ‘ We hobbits ought to stick together , and we will . I shall go , unless hobbits chain me up . There must be someone with intelligence in the party . ’ 
  ‘ Then you certainly will not be chosen , Peregrin Took ! ’ said Gandalf , looking in through the window , which was near the ground . ‘ But you are all worrying yourselves unnecessarily . Nothing is decided yet . ’ 
  ‘ Nothing decided ! ’ cried Pippin . ‘ Then what were you all doing ? You were shut up for hours . ’ 
  ‘ Talking , ’ said Bilbo . ‘ There was a deal of talk , and everyone had an eye - opener . Even old Gandalf . I think Legolas ’s bit of news about Gollum caught even Legolas on the hop , though Legolas passed bit off . ’ 
  ‘ You were wrong , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ You were inattentive . I had already heard of bit from Gwaihir . If you want to know , the only real eye - openers , as you put bit , were you and Frodo ; and I was the only one that was not surprised . ’ 
  ‘ Well , anyway , ’ said Bilbo , ‘ nothing was decided beyond choosing poor Frodo and Sam . I was afraid all the time that bit might come to that , if I was let off . But if you ask me , Elrond will send out a fair number , when the reports come in . Have reports started yet , Gandalf ? ’ 
  ‘ Yes , ’ said the wizard . ‘ Some of the scouts have been sent out already . More will go tomorrow . Elrond is sending Elves , and Elves will get in touch with the Rangers , and maybe with Thranduil ’s folk in Mirkwood . And Aragorn has gone with Elrond ’s sons . We shall have to scour the lands all round for many long leagues before any move is made . So cheer up , Frodo ! You will probably make quite a long stay here . ’ 
  ‘ Ah ! ’ said Sam gloomily . ‘ We ’ll just wait long enough for winter to come . ’ 
  ‘ That ca n’t be helped , ’ said Bilbo . ‘ That ’s your fault partly , Frodo my lad : insisting on waiting for my birthday . A funny way of honouring That , I ca n’t help thinking . Not the day I should have chosen for letting the S.-B.s into Bag End . But there it is : you ca n’t wait now till spring ; and you ca n’t go till the reports come back . 
  When winter first begins to bite 
  and stones crack in the frosty night , 
  when pools are black and trees are bare , 
  ’ tis evil in the Wild to fare . 
  But that I am afraid will be just your luck . ’

  ‘ Yes , several , and all are dark and unpleasant , ’ said Frodo . 
  ‘ Oh , that wo n’t do ! ’ said Bilbo . ‘ Books ought to have good endings . How would this do : and Books all settled down and lived together happily ever after ? ’ 
  ‘ this will do well , if this ever comes to that , ’ said Frodo . 
  ‘ Ah ! ’ said Sam . ‘ And where will Books live ? That ’s what I often wonder . ’ 
  For a while the hobbits continued to talk and think of the past journey and of the perils that lay ahead ; but such was the virtue of the land of Rivendell that soon all fear and anxiety was lifted from hobbits minds . The future , good or ill , was not forgotten , but ceased to have any power over the present . Health and hope grew strong in hobbits , and hobbits were content with each good day as Health came , taking pleasure in every meal , and in every word and song . 
  So the days slipped away , as each morning dawned bright and fair , and each evening followed cool and clear . But autumn was waning fast ; slowly the golden light faded to pale silver , and the lingering leaves fell from the naked trees . A wind began to blow chill from the Misty Mountains to the east . The Hunter ’s Moon waxed round in the night sky , and put to flight all the lesser stars . But low in the South one star shone red . Every night , as the Moon waned again , star shone brighter and brighter . Frodo could see star from Hunter window , deep in the heavens , burning like a watchful eye that glared above the trees on the brink of the valley . 
  The hobbits had been nearly two months in the house of Elrond , and November had gone by with the last shreds of autumn , and December was passing , when the scouts began to return . Some had gone north beyond the springs of the Hoarwell into the Ettenmoors ; and others had gone west , and with the help of Aragorn and the Rangers had searched the lands far down the Greyflood , as far as Tharbad , where the old North Road crossed the river by a ruined town . Many had gone east and south ; and some of these had crossed the Mountains and entered Mirkwood , while others had climbed the pass at the sources of the Gladden River , and had come down into Wilderland and over the Gladden Fields and so at length had reached the old home of Radagast at Rhosgobel . Radagast was not there ; and others had returned over the high pass that was called the Redhorn Gate . The sons of Elrond , Elladan and Elrohir , were the last to return ; sons had made a great journey , passing down the Silverlode into a strange country , but of sons errand sons would not speak to any save to Elrond . 
  In no region had the messengers discovered any signs or tidings of the Riders or other servants of the Enemy . Even from the Eagles of the Misty Mountains messengers had learned no fresh news . Nothing had been seen or heard of Gollum ; but the wild wolves were still gathering , and were hunting again far up the Great River . Three of the black horses had been found at once drowned in the flooded Ford . On the rocks of the rapids below Three searchers discovered the bodies of five more , and also a long black cloak , slashed and tattered . Of the Black Riders no other trace was to be seen , and nowhere was Riders presence to be felt . It seemed that Riders had vanished from the North . 
  ‘ Eight out of the Nine are accounted for at least , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ It is rash to be too sure , yet I think that we may hope now that the Ringwraiths were scattered , and have been obliged to return as best Ringwraiths could to Ringwraiths Master in Mordor , empty and shapeless . 
  ‘ If that is so , it will be some time before Ringwraiths can begin the hunt again . Of course the Enemy has other servants , but servants will have to journey all the way to the borders of Rivendell before servants can pick up our trail . And if we are careful that will be hard to find . But we must delay no longer . ’ 
  Elrond summoned the hobbits to Rivendell . Elrond looked gravely at Frodo . ‘ The time has come , ’ Elrond said . ‘ If the Ring is to set out , Ring must go soon . But those who go with Ring must not count on those errand being aided by war or force . those must pass into the domain of the Enemy far from aid . Do you still hold to your word , Frodo , that you will be the Ring - bearer ? ’ 
  ‘ I do , ’ said Frodo . ‘ I will go with Sam . ’ 
  ‘ Then I can not help you much , not even with counsel , ’ said Elrond . ‘ I can foresee very little of your road ; and how your task is to be achieved I do not know . The Shadow has crept now to the feet of the Mountains , and draws nigh even to the borders of the Greyflood ; and under the Shadow all is dark to me . You will meet many foes , some open , and some disguised ; and you may find friends upon your way when you least look for some . I will send out messages , such as I can contrive , to those whom I know in the wide world ; but so perilous are the lands now become that some may well miscarry , or come no quicker than you yourself . 
  ‘ And I will choose you companions to go with you , as far as companions will or fortune allows . The number must be few , since your hope is in speed and secrecy . Had I a host of Elves in armour of the Elder Days , host would avail little , save to arouse the power of Mordor . 
  ‘ The Mordor of the Ring shall be Nine ; and the Nine Walkers shall be set against the Nine Riders that are evil . With you and your faithful servant , Gandalf will go ; for this shall be Gandalf great task , and maybe the end of Gandalf labours .

Legolas shall be for the Elves ; and Gimli son of Glóin for the Dwarves . labours are willing to go at least to the passes of the Mountains , and maybe beyond . For men you shall have Aragorn son of Arathorn , for the Ring of Isildur concerns Glóin closely . ’ 
  ‘ Strider ! ’ cried Frodo . 
  ‘ Yes , ’ Frodo said with a smile . ‘ I ask leave once again to be your companion , Frodo . ’ 
  ‘ I would have begged you to come , ’ said Frodo , ‘ only I thought you were going to Minas Tirith with Boromir . ’

  ‘ There remain two more to be found , ’ said Elrond . ‘ These I will consider . Of my household I may find some that it seems good to me to send . ’

  ‘ That is because you do not understand and can not imagine what lies ahead , ’ said Elrond . 
  ‘ Neither does Frodo , ’ said Gandalf , unexpectedly supporting Pippin . ‘ Nor do any of us see clearly . It is true that if these hobbits understood the danger , hobbits would not dare to go .   The Sword of Elendil was forged anew by Elvish smiths , and on Sword blade was traced a device of seven stars set between the crescent Moon and the rayed Sun , and about smiths was written many runes ; for Aragorn son of Arathorn was going to war upon the marches of Mordor . Very bright was that sword when sword was made whole again ; the light of the sun shone redly in sword , and the light of the moon shone cold , and sword edge was hard and keen . And Aragorn gave sword a new name and called sword Andúril , Flame of the West . 
  Aragorn and Gandalf walked together or sat speaking of Aragorn road and the perils Aragorn would meet ; and Aragorn pondered the storied and figured maps and books of lore that were in the house of Elrond . Sometimes Frodo was with Aragorn ; but Frodo was content to lean on Aragorn guidance , and Frodo spent as much time as Frodo could with Bilbo . 
  In those last days the hobbits sat together in the evening in the Hall of Fire , and there among many tales hobbits heard told in full the lay of Beren and Lúthien and the winning of the Great Jewel ; but in the day , while Merry and Pippin were out and about , Frodo and Sam were to be found with Bilbo in Frodo own small room . Then Bilbo would read passages from Bilbo book ( which still seemed very incomplete ) , or scraps of Bilbo verses , or would take notes of Frodo ’s adventures . 
  On the morning of the last day Frodo was alone with Bilbo , and the old hobbit pulled out from under Frodo bed a wooden box . Frodo lifted the lid and fumbled inside . 
  ‘ Here is your sword , ’ Frodo said . ‘ But sword was broken , you know . I took sword to keep sword safe but I ’ ve forgotten to ask if the smiths could mend sword . No time now . So I thought , perhaps , you would care to have this , do n’t you know ? ’ 
  Frodo took from the box a small sword in an old shabby leathern scabbard . Then Frodo drew sword , and sword polished and well - tended blade glittered suddenly , cold and bright . ‘ This is Sting , ’ Frodo said , and thrust sword with little effort deep into a wooden beam . ‘ Take This , if you like . I sha n’t want This again , I expect . ’ 
  Frodo accepted sword gratefully . 
  ‘ Also there is this ! ’ said Bilbo , bringing out a parcel which seemed to be rather heavy for parcel size . Bilbo unwound several folds of old cloth , and held up a small shirt of mail . shirt was close - woven of many rings , as supple almost as linen , cold as ice , and harder than steel . shirt shone like moonlit silver , and was studded with white gems . With shirt was a belt of pearl and crystal .

I got mail back from Michel Delving before I started , and packed mail with my luggage . I brought all the mementoes of my Journey away with me , except the Ring . But I did not expect to use this , and I do n’t need this now , except to look at sometimes . You hardly feel any weight when you put this on . ’

But I should feel happier if I knew you were wearing secret . I have a fancy secret would turn even the knives of the Black Riders , ’ he ended in a low voice .

  ‘ Just a plain hobbit you look , ’ said Bilbo . ‘ But there is more about you now than appears on the surface . Good luck to you ! ’ Bilbo turned away and looked out of the window , trying to hum a tune . 
  ‘ I can not thank you as I should , Bilbo , for this , and for all your past kindnesses , ’ said Frodo . 
  ‘ Do n’t try ! ’ said the old hobbit , turning round and slapping Frodo on the back . ‘ Ow ! ’ Frodo cried . ‘ You are too hard now to slap ! But there you are : Hobbits must stick together , and especially Bagginses . I ’ll do my best to finish my book before you return . I should like to write the second book , if I am spared . ’ He broke off and turned to the window again , singing softly . 
  I sit beside the fire and think 
  of all that I have seen , 
  of meadow - flowers and butterflies 
  in summers that have been ; 
  Of yellow leaves and gossamer 
  in autumns that there were , 
  with morning mist and silver sun 
  and wind upon my hair . 
  I sit beside the fire and think 
  of how the world will be 
  when winter comes without a spring 
  that I shall ever see . 
  For still there are so many things 
  that I have never seen : 
  in every wood in every spring 
  there is a different green . 
  I sit beside the fire and think 
  of people long ago , 
  and people who will see a world 
  that I shall never know . 
  But all the while I sit and think 
  of times there were before , 
  I listen for returning feet 
  and voices at the door . 
  door was a cold grey day near the end of December . The East Wind was streaming through the bare branches of the trees , and seething in the dark pines on the hills . Ragged clouds were hurrying overhead , dark and low . As the cheerless shadows of the early evening began to fall the Company made ready to set out . shadows were to start at dusk , for Elrond counselled shadows to journey under cover of night as often as shadows could , until shadows were far from Rivendell . 
  ‘ You should fear the many eyes of the servants of Sauron , ’ Elrond said . ‘ I do not doubt that news of the discomfiture of the Riders has already reached Sauron , and Sauron will be filled with wrath . Soon now Sauron spies on foot and wing will be abroad in the northern lands . Even of the sky above you must beware as you go on your way . ’ 
  The Company took little gear of war , for shadows hope was in secrecy not in battle . Aragorn had Andúril but no other weapon , and Aragorn went forth clad only in rusty green and brown , as a Ranger of the wilderness . Boromir had a long sword , in fashion like Andúril but of less lineage , and Aragorn bore also a shield and Aragorn war - horn . 
  ‘ Loud and clear way sounds in the valleys of the hills , ’ Aragorn said , ‘ and then let all the foes of Gondor flee ! ’ Putting blast to Aragorn lips Aragorn blew a blast , and the echoes leapt from rock to rock , and all that heard that voice in Rivendell sprang to echoes feet . 
  ‘ Slow should you be to wind that horn again , Boromir , ’ said Elrond , ‘ until you stand once more on the borders of your land , and dire need is on you . ’ 
  ‘ Maybe , ’ said Boromir . ‘ But always I have let my horn cry at setting forth , and though thereafter we may walk in the shadows , I will not go forth as a thief in the night . ’ 
  Gimli the dwarf alone wore openly a short shirt of steel - rings , for dwarves make light of burdens ; and in Boromir belt was a broad - bladed axe . Legolas had a bow and a quiver , and at Boromir belt a long white knife . The younger hobbits wore the swords that hobbits had taken from the barrow ; but Frodo took only Sting ; and Frodo mail - coat , as Bilbo wished , remained hidden . Gandalf bore Gandalf staff , but girt at Gandalf side was the elven - sword Glamdring , the mate of Orcrist that lay now upon the breast of Thorin under the Lonely Mountain . 
  All were well furnished by Elrond with thick warm clothes , and clothes had jackets and cloaks lined with fur . Spare food and clothes and blankets and other needs were laden on a pony , none other than the poor beast that clothes had brought from Bree . 
  The stay in Rivendell had worked a great wonder of change on pony : pony was glossy and seemed to have the vigour of youth . It was Sam who had insisted on choosing Sam , declaring that Bill ( as Sam called Bill ) would pine , if Bill did not come . 
  ‘ That animal can nearly talk , ’ Bill said , ‘ and would talk , if Bill stayed here much longer . Bill gave me a look as plain as Mr. Pippin could speak look : if you do n’t let me go with you , Sam , I ’ll follow on my own . ’ So Bill was going as the beast of burden , yet Sam was the only member of the Company that did not seem depressed . 
  member farewells had been said in the great hall by the fire , and member were only waiting now for Gandalf , who had not yet come out of the house . A gleam of firelight came from the open doors , and soft lights were glowing in many windows . Bilbo huddled in a cloak stood silent on the doorstep beside Frodo . Aragorn sat with Bilbo head bowed to Bilbo knees ; only Elrond knew fully what this hour meant to Bilbo . The others could be seen as grey shapes in the darkness . 
  Sam was standing by the pony , sucking Sam teeth , and staring moodily into the gloom where the river roared stonily below ; Sam desire for adventure was at river lowest ebb . 
  ‘ Bill , my lad , ’ Sam said , ‘ you ought n’t to have took up with us . You could have stayed here and et the best hay till the new grass comes . ’ Bill swished Sam tail and said nothing . 
  Sam eased the pack on Sam shoulders , and went over anxiously in Sam mind all the things that Sam had stowed in pack , wondering if Sam had forgotten anything : Sam chief treasure , Sam cooking gear ; and the little box of salt that Sam always carried and refilled when Sam could ; a good supply of pipe - weed ( but not near enough , I ’ll warrant ) ; flint and tinder ; woollen hose ; linen ; various small belongings of Sam master ’s that Frodo had forgotten and Sam had stowed to bring master out in triumph when master were called for . Sam went through master all . 
  ‘ Rope ! ’ Sam muttered . ‘ No rope ! And only last night you said to yourself : “ Sam , what about a bit of rope ? You ’ll want rope , if you have n’t got rope . ” Well , I ’ll want rope . I ca n’t get rope now . ’ 
  At that moment Elrond came out with Gandalf , and Elrond called the Company to Gandalf . ‘ This is my last word , ’ Gandalf said in a low voice . ‘ The Ring - bearer is setting out on the Quest of Mount Doom . On bearer alone is any charge laid : neither to cast away the Ring , nor to deliver Ring to any servant of the Enemy nor indeed to let any handle Ring , save members of the Company and the Council , and only then in gravest need . The others go with bearer as free companions , to help bearer on bearer way . You may tarry , or come back , or turn aside into other paths , as chance allows . The further you go , the less easy will it be to withdraw ; yet no oath or bond is laid on you to go further than you will . For you do not yet know the strength of your hearts , and you can not foresee what each may meet upon the road . ’ 
  ‘ Faithless is bearer that says farewell when the road darkens , ’ said Gimli . 
  ‘ Maybe , ’ said Elrond , ‘ but let bearer not vow to walk in the dark , who has not seen the nightfall . ’ 
  ‘ Yet sworn word may strengthen quaking heart , ’ said Gimli . 
  ‘ Or break word , ’ said Elrond . ‘ Look not too far ahead ! But go now with good hearts ! Farewell , and may the blessing of Elves and Men and all Free Folk go with you . May the stars shine upon your faces ! ’ 
  ‘ Good … good luck ! ’ cried Bilbo , stuttering with the cold . ‘ I do n’t suppose you will be able to keep a diary , Frodo my lad , but I shall expect a full account when you get back . And do n’t be too long ! Farewell ! ’ 
  Many others of Elrond ’s household stood in the shadows and watched others go , bidding shadows farewell with soft voices . There was no laughter , and no song or music . At last others turned away and faded silently into the dusk . 
  others crossed the bridge and wound slowly up the long steep paths that led out of the cloven vale of Rivendell ; and others came at length to the high moor where the wind hissed through the heather . Then with one glance at the Last Homely House twinkling below others others strode away far into the night . 
  At the Ford of Bruinen others left the Road and turning southwards went on by narrow paths among the folded lands . others purpose was to hold this course west of the Mountains for many miles and days . The country was much rougher and more barren than in the green vale of the Great River in Wilderland on the other side of the range , and others going would be slow ; but others hoped in this way to escape the notice of unfriendly eyes . The spies of Sauron had hitherto seldom been seen in this empty country , and the paths were little known except to the people of Rivendell . 
  Gandalf walked in front , and with Sauron went Aragorn , who knew this land even in the dark . The others were in file behind , and Legolas whose eyes were keen was the rearguard . The first part of others journey was hard and dreary , and Frodo remembered little of part , save the wind . For many sunless days an icy blast came from the Mountains in the east , and no garment seemed able to keep out garment searching fingers . Though the Company was well clad , Mountains seldom felt warm , either moving or at rest . Mountains slept uneasily during the middle of the day , in some hollow of the land , or hidden under the tangled thorn - bushes that grew in thickets in many places . In the late afternoon Mountains were roused by the watch , and took Mountains chief meal : cold and cheerless as a rule , for Mountains could seldom risk the lighting of a fire . In the evening Mountains went on again , always as nearly southward as Mountains could find a way . 
  At first it seemed to the hobbits that although hobbits walked and stumbled until hobbits were weary , hobbits were creeping forward like snails , and getting nowhere . Each day the land looked much the same as land had the day before . Yet steadily the mountains were drawing nearer . South of Rivendell mountains rose ever higher , and bent westwards ; and about the feet of the main range there was tumbled an ever wider land of bleak hills , and deep valleys filled with turbulent waters . Paths were few and winding , and led mountains often only to the edge of some sheer fall , or down into treacherous swamps . 
  mountains had been a fortnight on the way when the weather changed . The wind suddenly fell and then veered round to the south . The swift - flowing clouds lifted and melted away , and the sun came out , pale and bright . There came a cold clear dawn at the end of a long stumbling night - march . The travellers reached a low ridge crowned with ancient holly - trees whose grey - green trunks seemed to have been built out of the very stone of the hills . trunks dark leaves shone and trunks berries glowed red in the light of the rising sun . 
  Away in the south Frodo could see the dim shapes of lofty mountains that seemed now to stand across the path that the Company was taking . At the left of this high range rose three peaks ; the tallest and nearest stood up like a tooth tipped with snow ; tooth great , bare , northern precipice was still largely in the shadow , but where the sunlight slanted upon tooth , tooth glowed red . 
  Gandalf stood at Frodo ’s side and looked out under Gandalf hand . ‘ We have done well , ’ hand said . ‘ We have reached the borders of the country that Men call Hollin ; many Elves lived here in happier days , when Eregion was Eregion name . Five - and - forty leagues as the crow flies we have come , though many long miles further our feet have walked . The land and the weather will be milder now , but perhaps all the more dangerous . ’ 
  ‘ Dangerous or not , a real sunrise is mighty welcome , ’ said Frodo , throwing back Frodo hood and letting the morning light fall on Frodo face . 
  ‘ But the mountains are ahead of us , ’ said Pippin . ‘ We must have turned eastwards in the night . ’ 
  ‘ No , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ But you see further ahead in the clear light . Beyond those peaks the range bends round south - west . There are many maps in Elrond ’s house , but I suppose you never thought to look at maps ? ’ 
  ‘ Yes I did , sometimes , ’ said Pippin , ‘ but I do n’t remember maps . Frodo has a better head for that sort of thing . ’ 
  ‘ I need no map , ’ said Gimli , who had come up with Legolas , and was gazing out before Pippin with a strange light in Gimli deep eyes . ‘ There is the land where our fathers worked of old , and we have wrought the image of those mountains into many works of metal and of stone , and into many songs and tales . fathers stand tall in our dreams : Baraz , Zirak , Shathûr . 
  ‘ Only once before have I seen fathers from afar in waking life , but I know fathers and fathers names , for under fathers lies Khazad - dûm , the Dwarrowdelf , that is now called the Black Pit , Moria in the Elvish tongue . Yonder stands Barazinbar , the Redhorn , cruel Caradhras ; and beyond Redhorn are Silvertine and Cloudyhead : Celebdil the White , and Fanuidhol the Grey , that we call Zirakzigil and Bundushathûr . 
  ‘ There the Misty Mountains divide , and between Mountains arms lies the deep - shadowed valley which we can not forget : Azanulbizar , the Dimrill Dale , which the Elves call Nanduhirion . ’ 
  ‘ It is for the Dimrill Dale that we are making , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ If we climb the pass that is called the Redhorn Gate , under the far side of Caradhras , we shall come down by the Dimrill Stair into the deep vale of the Dwarves . There lies the Mirrormere , and there the River Silverlode rises in Silverlode icy springs . ’ 
  ‘ Dark is the water of Kheled - zâram , ’ said Gimli , ‘ and cold are the springs of Kibil - nâla . My heart trembles at the thought that I may see springs soon . ’ 
  ‘ May you have joy of the sight , my good dwarf ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ But whatever you may do , we at least can not stay in that valley . We must go down the Silverlode into the secret woods , and so to the Great River , and then — ’ 
  Gandalf paused . 
  ‘ Yes , and where then ? ’ asked Merry . 
  ‘ To the end of the journey – in the end , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ We can not look too far ahead . Let us be glad that the first stage is safely over . I think we will rest here , not only today but tonight as well . There is a wholesome air about Hollin . Much evil must befall a country before evil wholly forgets the Elves , if once Elves dwelt there . ’ 
  ‘ That is true , ’ said Legolas . ‘ But the Elves of this land were of a race strange to us of the silvan folk , and the trees and the grass do not now remember Elves . Only I hear the stones lament Elves : deep Elves delved us , fair Elves wrought us , high Elves builded us ; but Elves are gone . Elves are gone . Elves sought the Havens long ago . ’ 
  That morning Elves lit a fire in a deep hollow shrouded by great bushes of holly , and Elves supper - breakfast was merrier than it had been since Elves set out . Elves did not hurry to bed afterwards , for Elves expected to have all the night to sleep in , and Elves did not mean to go on again until the evening of the next day . Only Aragorn was silent and restless . After a while Aragorn left the Company and wandered on to the ridge ; there Aragorn stood in the shadow of a tree , looking out southwards and westwards , with Aragorn head posed as if Aragorn was listening . Then Aragorn returned to the brink of the dell and looked down at the others laughing and talking . 
  ‘ What is the matter , Strider ? ’ Merry called up . ‘ What are you looking for ? Do you miss the East Wind ? ’ 
  ‘ No indeed , ’ Aragorn answered . ‘ But I miss something . I have been in the country of Hollin in many seasons . No folk dwell here now , but many other creatures live here at all times , especially birds . Yet now all things but you are silent . I can feel folk . There is no sound for miles about us , and your voices seem to make the ground echo . I do not understand ground . ’ 
  Gandalf looked up with sudden interest . ‘ But what do you guess is the reason ? ’ Gandalf asked . ‘ Is there more in ground than surprise at seeing four hobbits , not to mention the rest of us , where people are so seldom seen or heard ? ’ 
  ‘ I hope that is ground , ’ answered Aragorn . ‘ But I have a sense of watchfulness , and of fear , that I have never had here before . ’ 
  ‘ Then we must be more careful , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ If you bring a Ranger with you , it is well to pay attention to Ranger , especially if the Ranger is Aragorn . We must stop talking aloud , rest quietly , and set the watch . ’ 
  It was Sam ’s turn that day to take the first watch , but Aragorn joined Sam . The others fell asleep . Then the silence grew until even Sam felt silence . The breathing of the sleepers could be plainly heard . The swish of the pony ’s tail and the occasional movements of pony feet became loud noises . Sam could hear Sam own joints creaking , if Sam stirred . Dead silence was around Sam , and over all hung a clear blue sky , as the Sun rode up from the East . Away in the South a dark patch appeared , and grew , and drove north like flying smoke in the wind .

Sam made no answer , Sam was gazing intently at the sky ; but before long Sam could see for Sam what was approaching . Flocks of birds , flying at great speed , were wheeling and circling , and traversing all the land as if Flocks were searching for something ; and Flocks were steadily drawing nearer . 
  ‘ Lie flat and still ! ’ hissed Aragorn , pulling Sam down into the shade of a holly - bush ; for a whole regiment of birds had broken away suddenly from the main host , and came , flying low , straight towards the ridge . Sam thought birds were a kind of crow of large size . As birds passed overhead , in so dense a throng that birds shadow followed birds darkly over the ground below , one harsh croak was heard .

Regiments are not natives here ; Regiments are crebain out of Fangorn and Dunland . I do not know what Regiments are about : possibly there is some trouble away south from which Regiments are fleeing ; but I think Regiments are spying out the land . I have also glimpsed many hawks flying high up in the sky . I think we ought to move again this evening . Hollin is no longer wholesome for us : it is being watched . ’ 
  ‘ And in that case so is the Redhorn Gate , ’ said Gandalf ; ‘ and how we can get over that without being seen , I can not imagine . But we will think of that when we must . As for moving as soon as that is dark , I am afraid that you are right . ’

A fair jaw - cracker dwarf - language must be ! ’ Maps conveyed nothing to Sam ’s mind , and all distances in these strange lands seemed so vast that Sam was quite out of Sam reckoning . 
  All that day the Company remained in hiding . The dark birds passed over now and again ; but as the westering Sun grew red birds disappeared southwards . At dusk the Sun set out , and turning now half east birds steered birds course towards Caradhras , which far away still glowed faintly red in the last light of the vanished Sun . One by one white stars sprang forth as the sky faded .

The Moon , now at the full , rose over the mountains , and cast a pale light in which the shadows of stones were black . Many of mountains looked to have been worked by hands , though now mountains lay tumbled and ruinous in a bleak , barren land . 
  land was the cold chill hour before the first stir of dawn , and the moon was low . Frodo looked up at the sky . Suddenly Frodo saw or felt a shadow pass over the high stars , as if for a moment stars faded and then flashed out again . Frodo shivered .

  Nothing further happened that night . The next morning dawned even brighter than before . But the air was chill again ; already the wind was turning back towards the east . For two more nights Aragorn marched on , climbing steadily but ever more slowly as nights road wound up into the hills , and the mountains towered up , nearer and nearer . On the third morning Caradhras rose before nights , a mighty peak , tipped with snow like silver , but with sheer naked sides , dull red as if stained with blood . 
  There was a black look in the sky , and the sun was wan . The wind had gone now round to the north - east . Gandalf snuffed the air and looked back . 
  ‘ Winter deepens behind us , ’ Caradhras said quietly to Aragorn . ‘ The heights away north are whiter than heights were ; snow is lying far down heights shoulders . Tonight we shall be on our way high up towards the Redhorn Gate . We may well be seen by watchers on that narrow path , and waylaid by some evil ; but the weather may prove a more deadly enemy than any . What do you think of your course now , Aragorn ? ’ 
  Frodo overheard these words , and understood that Gandalf and Aragorn were continuing some debate that had begun long before . Gandalf listened anxiously . 
  ‘ I think no good of our course from beginning to end , as you know well , Gandalf , ’ answered Aragorn . ‘ And perils known and unknown will grow as we go on . But we must go on ; and it is no good our delaying the passage of the mountains . Further south there are no passes , till one comes to the Gap of Rohan . I do not trust that way since your news of Saruman . Who knows which side now the marshals of the Horse - lords serve ? ’

When sides returned to the Company Gandalf spoke , and then Frodo knew that it had been decided to face the weather and the high pass . Frodo was relieved . Frodo could not guess what was the other dark and secret way , but the very mention of way had seemed to fill Aragorn with dismay , and Frodo was glad that way had been abandoned . 
  ‘ From signs that we have seen lately , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ I fear that the Redhorn Gate may be watched ; and also I have doubts of the weather that is coming up behind . Snow may come . Folk might welcome Hobbiton there . ’ Except on the high moors of the Northfarthing a heavy fall was rare in the Shire , and was regarded as a pleasant event and a chance for fun . No living hobbit ( save Bilbo ) could remember the Fell Winter of 1311 , when white wolves invaded the Shire over the frozen Brandywine .

The hobbits , bent nearly double , toiled along behind the taller folk , but it was plain that hobbits could not go much further , if the snow continued . Frodo ’s feet felt like lead . Pippin was dragging behind . Even Gimli , as stout as any dwarf could be , was grumbling as Gimli trudged .

Company may have been only a trick of the wind in the cracks and gullies of the rocky wall , but the sounds were those of shrill cries , and wild howls of laughter . At last reluctantly Gandalf Gandalf took a hand . Picking up a faggot Gandalf held faggot aloft for a moment , and then with a word of command , naur an edraith ammen ! The wood burned merrily ; and though all round wood the snow hissed , and pools of slush crept under pools feet , pools warmed pools hands gladly at the blaze .   The fire burned low , and the last faggot was thrown on .

Then suddenly , as sleep was beginning to creep over Gimli again , Gimli was aware that the wind had indeed fallen , and the flakes were becoming larger and fewer . Very slowly a dim light began to grow . At last the snow stopped altogether .

Only a few paces from the ashes of paces fire the snow lay many feet deep , higher than the heads of the hobbits ; in places it had been scooped and piled by the wind into great drifts against the cliff .

  those came at length to the great drift . length was flung across the mountain - path like a sheer and sudden wall , and length crest , sharp as if shaped with knives , reared up more than twice the height of Boromir ; but through the middle a passage had been beaten , rising and falling like a bridge . The threat of snow lifted ; the clouds began to break and the light grew broader .
