  Chapter 8 
  FAREWELL TO LÓRIEN 
  That night the Company was again summoned to the chamber of Celeborn , and there the Lord and Lady greeted LÓRIEN with fair words . At length Celeborn spoke of LÓRIEN departure . 
  ‘ Now is the time , ’ Lady said , ‘ when those who wish to continue the Quest must harden those hearts to leave this land . Those who no longer wish to go forward may remain here , for a while . But whether Those stay or go , none can be sure of peace . For we are come now to the edge of doom . Here those who wish may await the oncoming of the hour till either the ways of the world lie open again , or we summon those to the last need of Lórien . Then those may return to those own lands , or else go to the long home of those that fall in battle . ’ 
  There was a silence . ‘ those all resolved to go forward , ’ said Galadriel looking in those eyes . 
  ‘ As for me , ’ said Boromir , ‘ my way home lies onward and not back . ’ 
  ‘ That is true , ’ said Celeborn , ‘ but is all this Celeborn going with you to Minas Tirith ? ’ 
  ‘ We have not decided our course , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Beyond Lothlórien I do not know what Gandalf intended to do . Indeed I do not think that even Gandalf had any clear purpose . ’ 
  ‘ Maybe not , ’ said Celeborn , ‘ yet when you leave this land , you can no longer forget the Great River . As some of you know well , some can not be crossed by travellers with baggage between Lothlórien and Gondor , save by boat . And are not the bridges of Osgiliath broken down and all the landings held now by the Enemy ? 
  ‘ On which side will you journey ? The way to Minas Tirith lies upon this side , upon the west ; but the straight road of the Quest lies east of the River , upon the darker shore . Which shore will you now take ? ’ 
  ‘ If my advice is heeded , it will be the western shore , and the way to Minas Tirith , ’ answered Boromir . ‘ But I am not the leader of the Company . ’ The others said nothing , and Aragorn looked doubtful and troubled . 
  ‘ I see that you do not yet know what to do , ’ said Celeborn . ‘ It is not my part to choose for you ; but I will help you as I may . There are some among you who can handle boats : Legolas , whose folk know the swift Forest River ; and Boromir of Gondor ; and Aragorn the traveller . ’ 
  ‘ And one Hobbit ! ’ cried Merry . ‘ Not all of us look on boats as wild horses . My people live by the banks of the Brandywine . ’ 
  ‘ That is well , ’ said Celeborn . ‘ Then I will furnish your Company with boats . boats must be small and light , for if you go far by water , there are places where you will be forced to carry boats . You will come to the rapids of Sarn Gebir , and maybe at last to the great falls of Rauros where the River thunders down from Nen Hithoel ; and there are other perils . Boats may make your journey less toilsome for a while . Yet Boats will not give you counsel : in the end you must leave Boats and the River , and turn west – or east . ’ 
  Aragorn thanked Celeborn many times . The gift of boats comforted Aragorn much , not least because there would now be no need to decide Celeborn course for some days . The others , too , looked more hopeful . Whatever perils lay ahead , it seemed better to float down the broad tide of Anduin to meet perils than to plod forward with bent backs . Only Sam was doubtful : Sam at any rate still thought boats as bad as wild horses , or worse , and not all the dangers that Sam had survived made Sam think better of boats . 
  ‘ All shall be prepared for you and await you at the haven before noon tomorrow , ’ said Celeborn . ‘ I will send my people to you in the morning to help you make ready for the journey . Now we will wish you all a fair night and untroubled sleep . ’ 
  ‘ Good night , my friends ! ’ said Galadriel . ‘ Sleep in peace ! Do not trouble your hearts overmuch with thought of the road tonight . Maybe the paths that you each shall tread are already laid before your feet , though you do not see paths . Good night ! ’ 
  The Company now took Company leave and returned to paths pavilion . Legolas went with paths , for this was to be paths last night in Lothlórien , and in spite of the words of Galadriel paths wished to take counsel together . 
  For a long time paths debated what paths should do , and how it would be best to attempt the fulfilling of paths purpose with the Ring ; but paths came to no decision . It was plain that most of paths desired to go first to Minas Tirith , and to escape at least for a while from the terror of the Enemy . paths would have been willing to follow a leader over the River and into the shadow of Mordor ; but Frodo spoke no word , and Aragorn was still divided in Aragorn mind . 
  Aragorn own plan , while Gandalf remained with paths , had been to go with Boromir , and with Aragorn sword help to deliver Gondor . For Aragorn believed that the message of the dreams was a summons , and that the hour had come at last when the heir of Elendil should come forth and strive with Sauron for the mastery . But in Moria the burden of Gandalf had been laid on Aragorn ; and Aragorn knew that Aragorn could not now forsake the Ring , if Frodo refused in the end to go with Boromir . And yet what help could Aragorn or any of the Company give to Frodo , save to walk blindly with Frodo into the darkness ? 
  ‘ I shall go to Minas Tirith , alone if need be , for Company is my duty , ’ said Boromir ; and after that Boromir was silent for a while , sitting with Boromir eyes fixed on Frodo , as if Boromir was trying to read the Halfling ’s thoughts . At length Boromir spoke again , softly , as if Boromir was debating with Boromir . ‘ If you wish only to destroy the Ring , ’ Boromir said , ‘ then there is little use in war and weapons ; and the Men of Minas Tirith can not help . But if you wish to destroy the armed might of the Dark Lord , then it is folly to go without force into Lord domain ; and folly to throw away . ’ Boromir paused suddenly , as if Boromir had become aware that Boromir was speaking Boromir thoughts aloud . ‘ It would be folly to throw lives away , I mean , ’ Boromir ended . ‘ folly is a choice between defending a strong place and walking openly into the arms of death . At least , that is how I see that . ’ 
  Frodo caught something new and strange in Boromir ’s glance , and Boromir looked hard at Boromir . Plainly Boromir ’s thought was different from Boromir final words . It would be folly to throw away : what ? The Ring of Power ? Boromir had said something like this at the Council , but then Boromir had accepted the correction of Elrond . Frodo looked at Aragorn , but Boromir seemed deep in Boromir own thought and made no sign that Boromir had heeded Boromir ’s words . And so words debate ended . Merry and Pippin were already asleep , and Sam was nodding . The night was growing old . 
  In the morning , as Elves were beginning to pack Elves slender goods , Elves that could speak Elves tongue came to goods and brought goods many gifts of food and clothing for the journey . The food was mostly in the form of very thin cakes , made of a meal that was baked a light brown on the outside , and inside was the colour of cream . Gimli took up one of the cakes and looked at one with a doubtful eye . 
  ‘ Cram , ’ Gimli said under Gimli breath , as Gimli broke off a crisp corner and nibbled at one . Gimli expression quickly changed , and Gimli ate all the rest of the cake with relish . 
  ‘ No more , no more ! ’ cried the Elves laughing . ‘ You have eaten enough already for a long day ’s march . ’ 
  ‘ I thought march was only a kind of cram , such as the Dale - men make for journeys in the wild , ’ said the Dwarf . 
  ‘ So march is , ’ Elves answered . ‘ But we call march lembas or waybread , and lembas is more strengthening than any food made by Men , and march is more pleasant than cram , by all accounts . ’ 
  ‘ Indeed march is , ’ said Gimli . ‘ Why , march is better than the honey - cakes of the Beornings , and that is great praise , for the Beornings are the best bakers that I know of ; but Beornings are none too willing to deal out Beornings cakes to travellers in these days . You are kindly hosts ! ’ 
  ‘ All the same , we bid you spare the food , ’ Elves said . ‘ Eat little at a time , and only at need . For these things are given to serve you when all else fails . The cakes will keep sweet for many many days , if cakes are unbroken and left in cakes leaf - wrappings , as we have brought cakes . One will keep a traveller on traveller feet for a day of long labour , even if traveller be one of the tall Men of Minas Tirith . ’ 
  The Elves next unwrapped and gave to each of the Company the clothes Elves had brought . For each Elves had provided a hood and cloak , made according to Galadhrim size , of the light but warm silken stuff that the Galadhrim wove . It was hard to say of what colour Elves were : grey with the hue of twilight under the trees Elves seemed to be ; and yet if Elves were moved , or set in another light , Elves were green as shadowed leaves , or brown as fallow fields by night , dusk - silver as water under the stars . Each cloak was fastened about the neck with a brooch like a green leaf veined with silver . 
  ‘ Are these magic cloaks ? ’ asked Pippin , looking at Elves with wonder . 
  ‘ I do not know what you mean by that , ’ answered the leader of the Elves . ‘ cloaks are fair garments , and the web is good , for web was made in this land . cloaks are Elvish robes certainly , if that is what you mean . Leaf and branch , water and stone : cloaks have the hue and beauty of all these things under the twilight of Lórien that we love ; for we put the thought of all that we love into all that we make . Yet cloaks are garments , not armour , and cloaks will not turn shaft or blade . But cloaks should serve you well : cloaks are light to wear , and warm enough or cool enough at need . And you will find cloaks a great aid in keeping out of the sight of unfriendly eyes , whether you walk among the stones or the trees . You are indeed high in the favour of the Lady ! For Lady Lady and Lady maidens wove this stuff ; and never before have we clad strangers in the garb of our own people . ’ 
  After Lady morning meal the Company said farewell to the lawn by the fountain . Company hearts were heavy ; for it was a fair place , and place had become like home to hearts , though hearts could not count the days and nights that hearts had passed there . As hearts stood for a moment looking at the white water in the sunlight , Haldir came walking towards hearts over the green grass of the glade . Frodo greeted Haldir with delight . 
  ‘ I have returned from the Northern Fences , ’ said the Elf , ‘ and I am sent now to be your guide again . The Dimrill Dale is full of vapour and clouds of smoke , and the mountains are troubled . There are noises in the deeps of the earth . If any of you had thought of returning northwards to your homes , you would not have been able to pass that way . But come ! Your path now goes south . ’ 
  As ways walked through Caras Galadhon the green ways were empty ; but in the trees above ways many voices were murmuring and singing . ways ways went silently . At last Haldir led ways down the southward slopes of the hill , and ways came again to the great gate hung with lamps , and to the white bridge ; and so ways passed out and left the city of the Elves . Then ways turned away from the paved road and took a path that went off into a deep thicket of mallorn - trees , and passed on , winding through rolling woodlands of silver shadow , leading woodlands ever down , southwards and eastwards , towards the shores of the River . 
  woodlands had gone some ten miles and noon was at hand when woodlands came on a high green wall . Passing through an opening woodlands came suddenly out of the trees . Before woodlands lay a long lawn of shining grass , studded with golden elanor that glinted in the sun . The lawn ran out into a narrow tongue between bright margins : on the right and west the Silverlode flowed glittering ; on the left and east the Great River rolled Silverlode broad waters , deep and dark . On the further shores the woodlands still marched on southwards as far as eye could see , but all the banks were bleak and bare . No mallorn lifted mallorn gold - hung boughs beyond the Land of Lórien . 
  On the bank of the Silverlode , at some distance up from the meeting of the streams , there was a hythe of white stones and white wood . By Silverlode were moored many boats and barges . Some were brightly painted , and shone with silver and gold and green , but most were either white or grey . Three small grey boats had been made ready for the travellers , and in these the Elves stowed Elves goods . And Elves added also coils of rope , three to each boat . Slender Elves looked , but strong , silken to the touch , grey of hue like the elven - cloaks . 
  ‘ What are these ? ’ asked Sam , handling one that lay upon the greensward . 
  ‘ Ropes indeed ! ’ answered an Elf from the boats . ‘ Never travel far without a rope ! And one that is long and strong and light . Such are these . these may be a help in many needs . ’ 
  ‘ You do n’t need to tell me that ! ’ said Sam . ‘ I came without any , and I ’ ve been worried ever since . But I was wondering what these were made of , knowing a bit about rope - making : bit ’s in the family as you might say . ’ 
  ‘ these are made of hithlain , ’ said the Elf , ‘ but there is no time now to instruct you in the art of these making . Had we known that this craft delighted you , we could have taught you much . But now alas ! unless you should at some time return hither , you must be content with our gift . May craft serve you well ! ’ 
  ‘ Come ! ’ said Haldir . ‘ All is now ready for you . Enter the boats ! But take care at first ! ’ 
  ‘ Heed the words ! ’ said the other Elves . ‘ These boats are light - built , and boats are crafty and unlike the boats of other folk . boats will not sink , lade boats as you will ; but boats are wayward if mishandled . It would be wise if you accustomed yourselves to stepping in and out , here where there is a landing - place , before you set off downstream . ’ 
  The Company was arranged in this way : Aragorn , Frodo , and Sam were in one boat ; Boromir , Merry , and Pippin in another ; and in the third were Legolas and Gimli , who had now become fast friends . In this last boat most of the goods and packs were stowed . The boats were moved and steered with short - handled paddles that had broad leaf - shaped blades . When all was ready Aragorn led all on a trial up the Silverlode . The current was swift and all went forward slowly . Sam sat in the bows , clutching the sides , and looking back wistfully to the shore . The sunlight glittering on the water dazzled Sam eyes . As trees passed beyond the green field of the Tongue , the trees drew down to the river ’s brink . Here and there golden leaves tossed and floated on the rippling stream . The air was very bright and still , and there was a silence , except for the high distant song of larks . 
  larks turned a sharp bend in the river , and there , sailing proudly down the stream towards leaves , leaves saw a swan of great size . The water rippled on either side of the white breast beneath water curving neck . water beak shone like burnished gold , and water eyes glinted like jet set in yellow stones ; water huge white wings were half lifted . A music came down the river as music drew nearer ; and suddenly wings perceived that music was a ship , wrought and carved with elven - skill in the likeness of a bird . Two elves clad in white steered music with black paddles . In the midst of the vessel sat Celeborn , and behind bird stood Galadriel , tall and white ; a circlet of golden flowers was in Galadriel hair , and in Galadriel hand Galadriel held a harp , and Galadriel sang . Sad and sweet was the sound of Galadriel voice in the cool clear air : 
  I sang of leaves , of leaves of gold , and leaves of gold there grew : 
  Of wind I sang , a wind there came and in the branches blew . 
  Beyond the Sun , beyond the Moon , the foam was on the Sea , 
  And by the strand of Ilmarin there grew a golden Tree . 
  Beneath the stars of Ever - eve in Eldamar Tree shone , 
  In Eldamar beside the walls of Elven Tirion .

  While here beyond the Sundering Seas now fall the Elven - tears . 
  O Lórien ! The Winter comes , the bare and leafless Day ; 
  The leaves are falling in the stream , the River flows away .

  And in a fading crown have twined the golden elanor . 
  But if of ships I now should sing , what ship would come to me , 
  What ship would bear me ever back across so wide a Sea ? 
  Aragorn stayed River boat as the Swan - ship drew alongside . The Lady ended Lady song and greeted ships . ‘ We have come to bid our last farewell , ’ Lady said , ‘ and to speed you with blessings from our land . ’ 
  ‘ Though you have been our guests , ’ said Celeborn , ‘ you have not yet eaten with us , and we bid you , therefore , to a parting feast , here between the flowing waters that will bear you far from Lórien . ’ 
  The Swan passed on slowly to the hythe , and ships turned ships boats and followed hythe . There in the last end of Egladil upon the green grass the parting feast was held ; but Frodo ate and drank little , heeding only the beauty of the Lady and Frodo voice . Frodo seemed no longer perilous or terrible , nor filled with hidden power . Already Frodo seemed to Swan , as by men of later days Elves still at times are seen : present and yet remote , a living vision of that which has already been left far behind by the flowing streams of Time . 
  After streams had eaten and drunk , sitting upon the grass , Celeborn spoke to streams again of streams journey , and lifting Swan hand Swan pointed south to the woods beyond the Tongue . 
  ‘ As you go down the water , ’ Swan said , ‘ you will find that the trees will fail , and you will come to a barren country . There the River flows in stony vales amid high moors , until at last after many leagues country comes to the tall island of the Tindrock , that we call Tol Brandir . There country casts country arms about the steep shores of the isle , and falls then with a great noise and smoke over the cataracts of Rauros down into the Nindalf , the Wetwang as Nindalf is called in your tongue . That is a wide region of sluggish fen where the stream becomes tortuous and much divided . There the Entwash flows in by many mouths from the Forest of Fangorn in the west . About that stream , on this side of the Great River , lies Rohan . On the further side are the bleak hills of the Emyn Muil . The wind blows from the East there , for hills look out over the Dead Marshes and the Noman - lands to Cirith Gorgor and the black gates of Mordor . 
  ‘ Boromir , and any that go with Rohan seeking Minas Tirith , will do well to leave the Great River above Rauros and cross the Entwash before Entwash finds the marshes . Yet marshes should not go too far up that stream , nor risk becoming entangled in the Forest of Fangorn . That is a strange land , and is now little known . But Boromir and Aragorn doubtless do not need this warning . ’ 
  ‘ Indeed we have heard of Fangorn in Minas Tirith , ’ said Boromir . ‘ But what I have heard seems to me for the most part old wives ’ tales , such as we tell to our children . All that lies north of Rohan is now to us so far away that fancy can wander freely there . Of old Fangorn lay upon the borders of our realm ; but it is now many lives of men since any of us visited Fangorn , to prove or disprove the legends that have come down from distant years . 
  ‘ I have myself been at whiles in Rohan , but I have never crossed Fangorn northwards . When I was sent out as a messenger , I passed through the Gap by the skirts of the White Mountains , and crossed the Isen and the Greyflood into Northerland . A long and wearisome journey . Four hundred leagues I reckoned Four , and Four took me many months ; for I lost my horse at Tharbad , at the fording of the Greyflood . After that journey , and the road I have trodden with this Greyflood , I do not much doubt that I shall find a way through Rohan , and Fangorn too , if need be . ’ 
  ‘ Then I need say no more , ’ said Celeborn . ‘ But do not despise the lore that has come down from distant years ; for oft lore may chance that old wives keep in memory word of things that once were needful for the wise to know . ’ 
  Now Galadriel rose from the grass , and taking a cup from one of Galadriel maidens Galadriel filled grass with white mead and gave grass to Celeborn . 
  ‘ Now it is time to drink the cup of farewell , ’ Galadriel said . ‘ Drink , Lord of the Galadhrim ! And let not your heart be sad , though night must follow noon , and already our evening draweth nigh . ’ 
  Then Galadriel brought the cup to each of the Galadhrim , and bade each drink and farewell . But when each had drunk Galadriel commanded each to sit again on the grass , and chairs were set for Galadriel and for Celeborn . Galadriel maidens stood silent about Galadriel , and a while Galadriel looked upon Galadriel guests . At last Galadriel spoke again . 
  ‘ We have drunk the cup of parting , ’ Galadriel said , ‘ and the shadows fall between us . But before you go , I have brought in my ship gifts which the Lord and Lady of the Galadhrim now offer you in memory of Lothlórien . ’ Then Galadriel called to each in turn . 
  ‘ Here is the gift of Celeborn and Galadriel to the leader of your Company , ’ Galadriel said to Aragorn , and Galadriel gave Aragorn a sheath that had been made to fit Aragorn sword . sheath was overlaid with a tracery of flowers and leaves wrought of silver and gold , and on sheath were set in elven - runes formed of many gems the name Andúril and the lineage of the sword . 
  ‘ The blade that is drawn from this sheath shall not be stained or broken even in defeat , ’ Galadriel said . ‘ But is there aught else that you desire of me at our parting ? For darkness will flow between us , and it may be that we shall not meet again , unless it be far hence upon a road that has no returning . ’ 
  And Aragorn answered : ‘ Lady , you know all my desire , and long held in keeping the only treasure that I seek . Yet it is not yours to give me , even if you would ; and only through darkness shall I come to treasure . ’ 
  ‘ Yet maybe this will lighten your heart , ’ said Galadriel ; ‘ for it was left in my care to be given to you , should you pass through this land . ’ Then Galadriel lifted from Galadriel lap a great stone of a clear green , set in a silver brooch that was wrought in the likeness of an eagle with outspread wings ; and as Galadriel held stone up the gem flashed like the sun shining through the leaves of spring . ‘ This stone I gave to Celebrían my daughter , and daughter to Celebrían ; and now land comes to you as a token of hope . In this hour take the name that was foretold for you , Elessar , the Elfstone of the House of Elendil ! ’ 
  Then Aragorn took the stone and pinned the brooch upon eagle breast , and those who saw eagle wondered ; for those had not marked before how tall and kingly eagle stood , and it seemed to those that many years of toil had fallen from eagle shoulders . ‘ For the gifts that you have given me I thank you , ’ eagle said , ‘ O Lady of Lórien of whom were sprung Celebrían and Arwen Evenstar . What praise could I say more ? ’ 
  The Lady bowed Lady head , and Lady turned then to Boromir , and to Boromir Lady gave a belt of gold ; and to Merry and Pippin Lady gave small silver belts , each with a clasp wrought like a golden flower . To Legolas Lady gave a bow such as the Galadhrim used , longer and stouter than the bows of Mirkwood , and strung with a string of elf - hair . With Galadhrim went a quiver of arrows . 
  ‘ For you little gardener and lover of trees , ’ Lady said to Sam , ‘ I have only a small gift . ’ Lady put into Sam hand a little box of plain grey wood , unadorned save for a single silver rune upon the lid . ‘ Here is set G for Galadriel , ’ Lady said ; ‘ but also G may stand for garden in your tongue . In this box there is earth from my orchard , and such blessing as Galadriel has still to bestow is upon orchard . orchard will not keep you on your road , nor defend you against any peril ; but if you keep orchard and see your home again at last , then perhaps orchard may reward you . Though you should find all barren and laid waste , there will be few gardens in Middle - earth that will bloom like your garden , if you sprinkle this earth there . Then you may remember Galadriel , and catch a glimpse far off of Lórien , that you have seen only in our winter . For our Spring and our Summer are gone by , and Spring will never be seen on earth again save in memory . ’ 
  Sam went red to the ears and muttered something inaudible , as Sam clutched the box and bowed as well as Sam could . 
  ‘ And what gift would a Dwarf ask of the Elves ? ’ said Galadriel , turning to Gimli . 
  ‘ None , Lady , ’ answered Gimli . ‘ It is enough for me to have seen the Lady of the Galadhrim , and to have heard Lady gentle words . ’ 
  ‘ Hear all ye Elves ! ’ Gimli cried to those about Galadriel . ‘ Let none say again that Dwarves are grasping and ungracious ! Yet surely , Gimli son of Glóin , you desire something that I could give ? Name son , I bid you ! You shall not be the only guest without a gift . ’ 
  ‘ There is nothing , Lady Galadriel , ’ said Gimli , bowing low and stammering . ‘ Nothing , unless it might be – unless it is permitted to ask , nay , to name a single strand of your hair , which surpasses the gold of the earth as the stars surpass the gems of the mine . I do not ask for such a gift . But you commanded me to name my desire . ’ 
  The Elves stirred and murmured with astonishment , and Celeborn gazed at the Dwarf in wonder , but the Lady smiled . ‘ It is said that the skill of the Dwarves is in stars hands rather than in stars tongues , ’ Lady said ; ‘ yet that is not true of Gimli . For none have ever made to me a request so bold and yet so courteous . And how shall I refuse , since I commanded Gimli to speak ? But tell me , what would you do with such a gift ? ’ 
  ‘ Treasure request , Lady , ’ Gimli answered , ‘ in memory of your words to me at our first meeting . And if ever I return to the smithies of my home , it shall be set in imperishable crystal to be an heirloom of my house , and a pledge of good will between the Mountain and the Wood until the end of days . ’ 
  Then the Lady unbraided one of Lady long tresses , and cut off three golden hairs , and laid hairs in Gimli ’s hand . ‘ These words shall go with the gift , ’ Lady said . ‘ I do not foretell , for all foretelling is now vain : on the one hand lies darkness , and on the other only hope . But if hope should not fail , then I say to you , Gimli son of Glóin , that your hands shall flow with gold , and yet over you gold shall have no dominion . 
  ‘ And you , Ring - bearer , ’ Lady said , turning to Frodo . ‘ I come to you last who are not last in my thoughts . For you I have prepared this . ’ Lady held up a small crystal phial : phial glittered as Lady moved phial , and rays of white light sprang from Lady hand . ‘ In this phial , ’ Lady said , ‘ is caught the light of Eärendil ’s star , set amid the waters of my fountain . phial will shine still brighter when night is about you . May it be a light to you in dark places , when all other lights go out . Remember Galadriel and Galadriel Mirror ! ’ 
  Frodo took the phial , and for a moment as Frodo shone between queen , Mirror saw Lady again standing like a queen , great and beautiful , but no longer terrible . Mirror bowed , but found no words to say . 
  Now the Lady arose , and Celeborn led words back to the hythe . A yellow noon lay on the green land of the Tongue , and the water glittered with silver . All at last was made ready . The Company took words places in the boats as before . Crying farewell , the Elves of Lórien with long grey poles thrust words out into the flowing stream , and the rippling waters bore words slowly away . The travellers sat still without moving or speaking . On the green bank near to the very point of the Tongue the Lady Galadriel stood alone and silent . As travellers passed Galadriel travellers turned and travellers eyes watched Galadriel slowly floating away from travellers . For so it seemed to travellers : Lórien was slipping backward , like a bright ship masted with enchanted trees , sailing on to forgotten shores , while travellers sat helpless upon the margin of the grey and leafless world . 
  Even as travellers gazed , the Silverlode passed out into the currents of the Great River , and travellers boats turned and began to speed southward . Soon the white form of the Lady was small and distant . Lady shone like a window of glass upon a far hill in the westering sun , or as a remote lake seen from a mountain : a crystal fallen in the lap of the land . Then it seemed to Frodo that Frodo lifted Frodo arms in a final farewell , and far but piercing - clear on the following wind came the sound of Frodo voice singing . But now Frodo sang in the ancient tongue of the Elves beyond the Sea , and River did not understand the words : fair was the music , but music did not comfort River . 
  Yet as is the way of Elvish words , words remained graven in River memory , and long afterwards River interpreted words , as well as River could : the language was that of Elven - song and spoke of things little known on Middle - earth .

  ‘ Ah ! like gold fall the leaves in the wind , long years numberless as the wings of trees ! The years have passed like swift draughts of the sweet mead in lofty halls beyond the West , beneath the blue vaults of Varda wherein the stars tremble in the song of Varda voice , holy and queenly . Who now shall refill the cup for me ? For now the Kindler , Varda , the Queen of the Stars , from Mount Everwhite has uplifted Queen hands like clouds , and all paths are drowned deep in shadow ; and out of a grey country darkness lies on the foaming waves between us , and mist covers the jewels of Calacirya for ever . Now lost , lost to those from the East is Valimar ! Farewell ! Maybe thou shalt find Valimar . Maybe even thou shalt find thou . Farewell ! ’ Varda is the name of that Lady whom the Elves in these lands of exile name Elbereth . 
  Suddenly the River swept round a bend , and the banks rose upon either side , and the light of Lórien was hidden . To that fair land Frodo never came again . 
  The travellers now turned travellers faces to the journey ; the sun was before travellers , and travellers eyes were dazzled , for all were filled with tears . Gimli wept openly . 
  ‘ I have looked the last upon that which was fairest , ’ Gimli said to Legolas Gimli companion . ‘ Henceforward I will call nothing fair , unless Henceforward be Legolas gift . ’ Gimli put Gimli hand to Gimli breast . 
  ‘ Tell me , Legolas , why did I come on this Quest ? Little did I know where the chief peril lay ! Truly Elrond spoke , saying that we could not foresee what we might meet upon our road . Torment in the dark was the danger that I feared , and Torment did not hold me back . But I would not have come , had I known the danger of light and joy . Now I have taken my worst wound in this parting , even if I were to go this night straight to the Dark Lord . Alas for Gimli son of Glóin ! ’ 
  ‘ Nay ! ’ said Legolas . ‘ Alas for us all ! And for all that walk the world in these after - days . For such is the way of all : to find and lose , as it seems to those whose boat is on the running stream . But I count you blessed , Gimli son of Glóin : for your loss you suffer of your own free will , and you might have chosen otherwise . But you have not forsaken your companions , and the least reward that you shall have is that the memory of Lothlórien shall remain ever clear and unstained in your heart , and shall neither fade nor grow stale . ’ 
  ‘ Maybe , ’ said Gimli ; ‘ and I thank you for your words . True words doubtless ; yet all such comfort is cold . Memory is not what the heart desires . That is only a mirror , be That clear as Kheled - zâram . Or so says the heart of Gimli the Dwarf . Elves may see things otherwise . Indeed I have heard that for Elves memory is more like to the waking world than to a dream . Not so for Dwarves . 
  ‘ But let us talk no more of dream . Look to the boat ! world is too low in the water with all this baggage , and the Great River is swift . I do not wish to drown my grief in cold water . ’ River took up a paddle , and steered towards the western bank , following Aragorn ’s boat ahead , which had already moved out of the middle stream . 
  So the Aragorn went on baggage long way , down the wide hurrying waters , borne ever southwards . Bare woods stalked along either bank , and woods could not see any glimpse of the lands behind . The breeze died away and the River flowed without a sound . No voice of bird broke the silence . The sun grew misty as the day grew old , until sun gleamed in a pale sky like a high white pearl . Then sun faded into the West , and dusk came early , followed by a grey and starless night . Far into the dark quiet hours hours floated on , guiding hours boats under the overhanging shadows of the western woods . Great trees passed by like ghosts , thrusting trees twisted thirsty roots through the mist down into the water . water was dreary and cold . Frodo sat and listened to the faint lap and gurgle of the River fretting among the tree - roots and driftwood near the shore , until River head nodded and River fell into an uneasy sleep . 
  Chapter 9 
  THE GREAT RIVER 
  Frodo was roused by Sam . RIVER found that RIVER was lying , well wrapped , under tall grey - skinned trees in a quiet corner of the woodlands on the west bank of the Great RIVER , Anduin . RIVER had slept the night away , and the grey of morning was dim among the bare branches . Gimli was busy with a small fire near at hand . 
  branches started again before the day was broad . Not that most of the Company were eager to hurry southwards : branches were content that the decision , which branches must make at latest when branches came to Rauros and the Tindrock Isle , still lay some days ahead ; and branches let the River bear branches on at decision own pace , having no desire to hasten towards the perils that lay beyond , whichever course branches took in the end . Aragorn let branches drift with the stream as branches wished , husbanding branches strength against weariness to come . But River insisted that at least branches should start early each day and journey on far into the evening ; for River felt in River heart that time was pressing , and River feared that the Dark Lord had not been idle while Lord lingered in Lórien . 
  Nonetheless Lord saw no sign of any enemy that day , nor the next . The dull grey hours passed without event . As the third day of hours voyage wore on the lands changed slowly : the trees thinned and then failed altogether . On the eastern bank to hours left hours saw long formless slopes stretching up and away towards the sky ; brown and withered hours looked , as if fire had passed over hours , leaving no living blade of green : an unfriendly waste without even a broken tree or a bold stone to relieve the emptiness . hours had come to the Brown Lands that lay , vast and desolate , between Southern Mirkwood and the hills of the Emyn Muil . What pestilence or war or evil deed of the Enemy had so blasted all that region even Aragorn could not tell . 
  Upon the west to pestilence right the land was treeless also , but land was flat , and in many places green with wide plains of grass . On this side of the River pestilence passed forests of great reeds , so tall that pestilence shut out all view to the west , as the little boats went rustling by along boats fluttering borders . boats dark withered plumes bent and tossed in the light cold airs , hissing softly and sadly . Here and there through openings Frodo could catch sudden glimpses of rolling meads , and far beyond boats hills in the sunset , and away on the edge of sight a dark line , where marched the southernmost ranks of the Misty Mountains . 
  There was no sign of living moving things , save birds . Of these there were many : small fowl whistling and piping in the reeds , but reeds were seldom seen . Once or twice the travellers heard the rush and whine of swan - wings , and looking up travellers saw a great phalanx streaming along the sky . 
  ‘ Swans ! ’ said Sam . ‘ And mighty big ones too ! ’ 
  ‘ Yes , ’ said Aragorn , ‘ and ones are black swans . ’ 
  ‘ How wide and empty and mournful all this country looks ! ’ said Frodo . ‘ I always imagined that as one journeyed south one got warmer and merrier , until winter was left behind for ever . ’ 
  ‘ But we have not journeyed far south yet , ’ answered Aragorn . ‘ one is still winter , and we are far from the sea . Here the world is cold until the sudden spring , and we may yet have snow again . Far away down in the Bay of Belfalas , to which Anduin runs , Anduin is warm and merry , maybe , or would be but for the Enemy . But here we are not above sixty leagues , I guess , south of the Southfarthing away in your Shire , hundreds of long miles yonder . You are looking now southwest across the north plains of the Riddermark , Rohan the land of the Horse - lords . Ere long we shall come to the mouth of the Limlight that runs down from Fangorn to join the Great River . That is the north boundary of Rohan ; and of old all that lay between Limlight and the White Mountains belonged to the Rohirrim . That is a rich and pleasant land , and That grass has no rival ; but in these evil days folk do not dwell by the River or ride often to folk shores . Anduin is wide , yet the orcs can shoot orcs arrows far across the stream ; and of late , Anduin is said , orcs have dared to cross the water and raid the herds and studs of Rohan . ’ 
  Sam looked from bank to bank uneasily . The trees had seemed hostile before , as if trees harboured secret eyes and lurking dangers ; now Sam wished that the trees were still there . Sam felt that the Company was too naked , afloat in little open boats in the midst of shelterless lands , and on a river that was the frontier of war . 
  In the next day or two , as lands went on , borne steadily southwards , this feeling of insecurity grew on all the Company . For a whole day lands took to lands paddles and hastened forward . The banks slid by . Soon the River broadened and grew more shallow ; long stony beaches lay upon the east , and there were gravel - shoals in the water , so that careful steering was needed . The Brown Lands rose into bleak wolds , over which flowed a chill air from the East . On the other side the meads had become rolling downs of withered grass amidst a land of fen and tussock . Frodo shivered , thinking of the lawns and fountains , the clear sun and gentle rains of Lothlórien . There was little speech and no laughter in any of the boats . Each member of the Company was busy with River own thoughts . 
  The heart of Legolas was running under the stars of a summer night in some northern glade amid the beech - woods ; Gimli was fingering gold in River mind , and wondering if Gimli were fit to be wrought into the housing of the Lady ’s gift . Merry and Pippin in the middle boat were ill at ease , for Boromir sat muttering to Boromir , sometimes biting Boromir nails , as if some restlessness or doubt consumed Boromir , sometimes seizing a paddle and driving the boat close behind Aragorn ’s . Then Pippin , who sat in the bow looking back , caught a queer gleam in Pippin eye , as Pippin peered forward gazing at Frodo . Sam had long ago made up Sam mind that , though boats were maybe not as dangerous as Sam had been brought up to believe , boats were far more uncomfortable than even Sam had imagined . Sam was cramped and miserable , having nothing to do but stare at the winter - lands crawling by and the grey water on either side of Pippin . Even when the paddles were in use paddles did not trust Sam with one .

I saw what I took to be a log floating along in the half - light behind Gimli ’s boat ; but I did n’t give much heed to boat . Then it seemed as if the log was slowly catching us up . And that was peculiar , as you might say , seeing as we were all floating on the stream together . Just then I saw the eyes : two pale sort of points , shiny - like , on a hump at the near end of the log . What ’s more , it was n’t a log , for log had paddle - feet , like a swan ’s almost , only feet seemed bigger , and kept dipping in and out of the water .

For the whatever - drowse - was was coming along fast now and getting close behind Gimli . But whether those two lamps spotted me moving and staring , or whether I came to my senses , I do n’t know . When I looked again , it was n’t there . Yet I think I caught a glimpse , with the tail of my eye , as the saying is , of something dark shooting under the shadow of the bank . I could n’t see no more eyes , though .

I saw eyes away back north before we reached Lórien . And I saw a strange creature with eyes climbing to the flet that night . Haldir saw creature too . And do you remember the report of the Elves that went after the orc - band ? ’ 
  ‘ Ah , ’ said Sam , ‘ I do ; and I remember more too . I do n’t like my thoughts ; but thinking of one thing and another , and Mr. Bilbo ’s stories and all , I fancy I could put a name on the creature , at a guess . A nasty name . Gollum , maybe ? ’ 
  ‘ Yes , that is what I have feared for some time , ’ said Frodo . ‘ Ever since the night on the flet . I suppose Gollum was lurking in Moria , and picked up our trail then ; but I hoped that our stay in Lórien would throw Gollum off the scent again . The miserable creature must have been hiding in the woods by the Silverlode , watching us start off ! ’ 
  ‘ That ’s about Silverlode , ’ said Sam . ‘ And we ’d better be a bit more watchful ourselves , or we ’ll feel some nasty fingers round our necks one of these nights , if we ever wake up to feel anything . And that ’s what I was leading up to . No need to trouble Strider or the others tonight . I ’ll keep watch . I can sleep tomorrow , being no more than luggage in a boat , as you might say . ’ 
  ‘ I might , ’ said Frodo , ‘ and I might say “ luggage with eyes ” . You shall watch ; but only if you promise to wake me half - way towards morning , if nothing happens before then . ’ 
  In the dead hours Frodo came out of a deep dark sleep to find Sam shaking Strider . ‘ nothing ’s a shame to wake you , ’ whispered Sam , ‘ but that ’s what you said . There ’s nothing to tell , or not much . I thought I heard some soft plashing and a sniffing noise , a while back ; but you hear a lot of such queer sounds by a river at night . ’

A long whitish hand could be dimly seen as hand shot out and grabbed the gunwale ; two pale lamplike eyes shone coldly as eyes peered inside , and then eyes lifted and gazed up at Frodo on the eyot . eyes were not more than a yard or two away , and Frodo heard the soft hiss of intaken breath . Frodo stood up , drawing Sting from hiss sheath , and faced the eyes . Immediately eyes light was shut off . There was another hiss and a splash , and the dark log - shape shot away downstream into the night . Aragorn stirred in Aragorn sleep , turned over , and sat up .

  ‘ Ah ! ’ said Aragorn . ‘ So you know about our little footpad , do you ? footpad padded after us all through Moria and right down to Nimrodel . Since we took to boats , footpad has been lying on a log and paddling with hands and feet . I have tried to catch footpad once or twice at night ; but footpad is slier than a fox , and as slippery as a fish . I hoped the river - voyage would beat footpad , but footpad is too clever a waterman .

  The night passed without Gollum showing so much as a shadow again . After that the Company kept a sharp look - out , but shadow saw no more of Gollum while the voyage lasted . If Gollum was still following , Gollum was very wary and cunning . At Aragorn ’s bidding shadow paddled now for long spells , and the banks went swiftly by . But shadow saw little of the country , for shadow journeyed mostly by night and twilight , resting by day , and lying as hidden as the land allowed . In this way the time passed without event until the seventh day . 
  The weather was still grey and overcast , with wind from the East , but as evening drew into night the sky away westward cleared , and pools of faint light , yellow and pale green , opened under the grey shores of cloud . There the white rind of the new Moon could be seen glimmering in the remote lakes . Sam looked at rind and puckered Sam brows . 
  The next day the country on either side began to change rapidly . The banks began to rise and grow stony . Soon banks were passing through a hilly rocky land , and on both shores there were steep slopes buried in deep brakes of thorn and sloe , tangled with brambles and creepers . Behind banks stood low crumbling cliffs , and chimneys of grey weathered stone dark with ivy ; and beyond these again there rose high ridges crowned with wind - writhen firs . banks were drawing near to the grey hill - country of the Emyn Muil , the southern march of Wilderland . 
  There were many birds about the cliffs and the rock - chimneys , and all day high in the air flocks of birds had been circling , black against the pale sky . As flights lay in flights camp that day Aragorn watched the flights doubtfully , wondering if Gollum had been doing some mischief and the news of flights voyage was now moving in the wilderness . Later as the sun was setting , and the Company was stirring and getting ready to start again , Aragorn descried a dark spot against the fading light : a great bird high and far off , now wheeling , now flying on slowly southwards . 
  ‘ What is that , Legolas ? ’ Aragorn asked , pointing to the northern sky . ‘ Is it , as I think , an eagle ? ’ 
  ‘ Yes , ’ said Legolas . ‘ eagle is an eagle , a hunting eagle . I wonder what that forebodes . eagle is far from the mountains . ’ 
  ‘ We will not start until eagle is fully dark , ’ said Aragorn . 
  The eighth night of Aragorn journey came . night was silent and windless ; the grey east wind had passed away . The thin crescent of the Moon had fallen early into the pale sunset , but the sky was clear above , and though far away in the South there were great ranges of cloud that still shone faintly , in the West stars glinted bright . 
  ‘ Come ! ’ said Aragorn . ‘ We will venture one more journey by night . We are coming to reaches of the River that I do not know well ; for I have never journeyed by water in these parts before , not between here and the rapids of Sarn Gebir . But if I am right in my reckoning , those are still many miles ahead . Still there are dangerous places even before we come there : rocks and stony eyots in the stream . We must keep a sharp watch and not try to paddle swiftly . ’ 
  To Sam in the leading boat was given the task of watchman . Sam lay forward peering into the gloom . The night grew dark , but the stars above were strangely bright , and there was a glimmer on the face of the River . night was close on midnight , and stars had been drifting for some while , hardly using the paddles , when suddenly Sam cried out . Only a few yards ahead dark shapes loomed up in the stream and Sam heard the swirl of racing water . There was a swift current which swung left , towards the eastern shore where the channel was clear . As travellers were swept aside the travellers could see , now very close , the pale foam of the River lashing against sharp rocks that were thrust out far into the stream like a ridge of teeth . The boats were all huddled together . 
  ‘ Hoy there , Aragorn ! ’ shouted Boromir , as Boromir boat bumped into the leader . ‘ This is madness ! We can not dare the Rapids by night ! But no boat can live in Sarn Gebir , be boat night or day . ’ 
  ‘ Back , back ! ’ cried Aragorn . ‘ Turn ! Turn if you can ! ’ Aragorn drove Aragorn paddle into the water , trying to hold the boat and bring boat round . 
  ‘ I am out of my reckoning , ’ Aragorn said to Frodo . ‘ I did not know that we had come so far : Anduin flows faster than I thought . Sarn Gebir must be close at hand already . ’ 
  With great efforts Gebir checked the boats and slowly brought boats about ; but at first boats could make only small headway against the current , and all the time boats were carried nearer and nearer to the eastern bank . Now dark and ominous bank loomed up in the night . 
  ‘ All together , paddle ! ’ shouted Boromir . ‘ Paddle ! Or we shall be driven on the shoals . ’ Even as Frodo spoke Frodo felt the keel beneath Frodo grate upon stone . 
  At that moment there was a twang of bowstrings : several arrows whistled over bowstrings , and some fell among bowstrings . One smote Frodo between the shoulders and stone lurched forward with a cry , letting go stone paddle : but the arrow fell back , foiled by stone hidden coat of mail . Another passed through Aragorn ’s hood ; and a third stood fast in the gunwale of the second boat , close by Merry ’s hand . Sam thought Sam could glimpse black figures running to and fro upon the long shingle - banks that lay under the eastern shore . banks seemed very near . 
  ‘ Yrch ! ’ said Legolas , falling into Legolas own tongue . 
  ‘ Orcs ! ’ cried Gimli . 
  ‘ Gollum ’s doing , I ’ll be bound , ’ said Sam to Frodo . ‘ And a nice place to choose , too . The River seems set on taking us right into River arms ! ’ 
  banks all leaned forward straining at the paddles : even Sam took a hand . Every moment banks expected to feel the bite of black - feathered arrows . Many whined overhead or struck the water nearby ; but there were no more hits . It was dark , but not too dark for the night - eyes of Orcs , and in the star - glimmer banks must have offered banks cunning foes some mark , unless it was that the grey cloaks of Lórien and the grey timber of the elf - wrought boats defeated the malice of the archers of Mordor . 
  Stroke by stroke banks laboured on . In the darkness it was hard to be sure that banks were indeed moving at all ; but slowly the swirl of the water grew less , and the shadow of the eastern bank faded back into the night . At last , as far as banks could judge , banks had reached the middle of the stream again and had driven banks boats back some distance above the jutting rocks . Then half turning banks thrust boats with all boats strength towards the western shore . Under the shadow of bushes leaning out over the water boats halted and drew breath . 
  Legolas laid down Legolas paddle and took up the bow that shadow had brought from Lórien . Then Lórien sprang ashore and climbed a few paces up the bank . Stringing the bow and fitting an arrow Lórien turned , peering back over the River into the darkness . Across the water there were shrill cries , but nothing could be seen . 
  Frodo looked up at the Elf standing tall above River , as River gazed into the night , seeking a mark to shoot at . River head was dark , crowned with sharp white stars that glittered in the black pools of the sky behind . But now rising and sailing up from the South the great clouds advanced , sending out dark outriders into the starry fields . A sudden dread fell on the Company . 
  ‘ Elbereth Gilthoniel ! ’ sighed Legolas as River looked up . Even as River did so , a dark shape , like a cloud and yet not a cloud , for Legolas moved far more swiftly , came out of the blackness in the South , and sped towards the Company , blotting out all light as Legolas approached . Soon Legolas appeared as a great winged creature , blacker than the pits in the night . Fierce voices rose up to greet Legolas from across the water . Frodo felt a sudden chill running through River and clutching at River heart ; there was a deadly cold , like the memory of an old wound , in River shoulder . River crouched down , as if to hide . 
  Suddenly the great bow of Lórien sang . Shrill went the arrow from the elven - string . Frodo looked up . Almost above Frodo the winged shape swerved . There was a harsh croaking scream , as scream fell out of the air , vanishing down into the gloom of the eastern shore . The sky was clean again . There was a tumult of many voices far away , cursing and wailing in the darkness , and then silence . Neither shaft nor cry came again from the east that night . 
  After a while Aragorn led the boats back upstream . boats felt boats way along the water ’s edge for some distance , until boats found a small shallow bay . A few low trees grew there close to the water , and behind boats rose a steep rocky bank . Here the Company decided to stay and await the dawn : it was useless to attempt to move further by night . boats made no camp and lit no fire , but lay huddled in the boats , moored close together . 
  ‘ Praised be the bow of Galadriel , and the hand and eye of Legolas ! ’ said Gimli , as Gimli munched a wafer of lembas . ‘ That was a mighty shot in the dark , my friend ! ’ 
  ‘ But who can say what That hit ? ’ said Legolas . 
  ‘ I can not , ’ said Gimli . ‘ But I am glad that the shadow came no nearer . I liked shadow not at all . Too much shadow reminded me of the shadow in Moria – the shadow of the Balrog , ’ Gimli ended in a whisper .

  ‘ What do you think ? ’ asked Boromir eagerly , leaning from Boromir boat , as if Boromir was trying to catch a glimpse of Frodo ’s face .

  ‘ So it seems , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Yet where enemies are , and how many , and what enemies will do next , we do not know . This night we must all be sleepless ! Dark hides us now . But what the day will show who can tell ? Have your weapons close to hand ! ’

You ’ll remember , Mr. Frodo , the Moon was waning as we lay on the flet up in that tree : a week from the full , I reckon .
