And I do n’t remember any moon , either new or old , in Caras Galadhon : only stars by night and sun by day . ’ 
  Legolas stirred in Frodo boat . ‘ Nay , time does not tarry ever , ’ Frodo said ; ‘ but change and growth is not in all things and places alike . For the Elves the world moves , and world moves both very swift and very slow . Swift , because Elves Elves change little , and all else fleets by : it is a grief to Elves . Slow , because Elves need not count the running years , not for Elves . The passing seasons are but ripples ever repeated in the long long stream . Yet beneath the Sun all things must wear to an end at last . ’ 
  ‘ But the wearing is slow in Lórien , ’ said Frodo . ‘ The power of the Lady is on Lórien . Rich are the hours , though short hours seem , in Caras Galadhon , where Galadriel wields the Elven - ring . ’ 
  ‘ That should not have been said outside Lórien , not even to me , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Speak no more of That ! But so it is , Sam : in that land you lost your count . There time flowed swiftly by us , as for the Elves . The old moon passed , and a new moon waxed and waned in the world outside , while we tarried there . And yestereve a new moon came again . Winter is nearly gone . Time flows on to a spring of little hope . ’ 
  The night passed silently . No voice or call was heard again across the water . The travellers huddled in travellers boats felt the changing of the weather . The air grew warm and very still under the great moist clouds that had floated up from the South and the distant seas . The rushing of the River over the rocks of the rapids seemed to grow louder and closer . The twigs of the trees above rocks began to drip . 
  When the day came the mood of the world about rocks had become soft and sad . Slowly the dawn grew to a pale light , diffused and shadowless . There was mist on the River , and white fog swathed the shore ; the far bank could not be seen . 
  ‘ I ca n’t abide fog , ’ said Sam ; ‘ but this seems to be a lucky one . Now perhaps we can get away without those cursed goblins seeing us . ’ 
  ‘ Perhaps so , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ But it will be hard to find the path unless the fog lifts a little later on . And we must find the path , if we are to pass Sarn Gebir and come to the Emyn Muil . ’ 
  ‘ I do not see why we should pass the Rapids or follow the River any further , ’ said Boromir . ‘ If the Emyn Muil lie before us , then we can abandon these cockle - boats , and strike westward and southward , until we come to the Entwash and cross into my own land . ’ 
  ‘ We can , if we are making for Minas Tirith , ’ said Aragorn , ‘ but that is not yet agreed . And such a course may be more perilous than course sounds . The vale of Entwash is flat and fenny , and fog is a deadly peril there for those on foot and laden . I would not abandon our boats until we must . The River is at least a path that can not be missed . ’ 
  ‘ But the Enemy holds the eastern bank , ’ objected Boromir . ‘ And even if you pass the Gates of Argonath and come unmolested to the Tindrock , what will you do then ? Leap down the Falls and land in the marshes ? ’ 
  ‘ No ! ’ answered Aragorn . ‘ Say rather that we will bear our boats by the ancient way to Rauros - foot , and there take to the water again . Do you not know , Boromir , or do you choose to forget the North Stair , and the high seat upon Amon Hen , that were made in the days of the great kings ? I at least have a mind to stand in that high place again , before I decide my further course . There , maybe , we shall see some sign that will guide us . ’ 
  Boromir held out long against this choice ; but when choice became plain that Frodo would follow Aragorn , wherever Frodo went , Frodo gave in . ‘ sign is not the way of the Men of Minas Tirith to desert Men friends at need , ’ Frodo said , ‘ and you will need my strength , if ever you are to reach the Tindrock . To the tall isle I will go , but no further . There I shall turn to my home , alone if my help has not earned the reward of any companionship . ’ 
  The day was now growing , and the fog had lifted a little . It was decided that Aragorn and Legolas should at once go forward along the shore , while the others remained by the boats . Aragorn hoped to find some way by which others could carry both others boats and others baggage to the smoother water beyond the Rapids . 
  ‘ Boats of the Elves would not sink , maybe , ’ Aragorn said , ‘ but that does not say that we should come through Sarn Gebir alive . None have ever done so yet . No road was made by the Men of Gondor in this region , for even in Boats great days Boats realm did not reach up Anduin beyond the Emyn Muil ; but there is a portage - way somewhere on the western shore , if I can find shore . shore can not yet have perished ; for light boats used to journey out of Wilderland down to Osgiliath , and still did so until a few years ago , when the Orcs of Mordor began to multiply . ’ 
  ‘ Seldom in my life has any boat come out of the North , and the Orcs prowl on the east - shore , ’ said Boromir . ‘ If you go forward , peril will grow with every mile , even if you find a path . ’ 
  ‘ Peril lies ahead on every southward road , ’ answered Aragorn . ‘ Wait for us one day . If we do not return in that time , you will know that evil has indeed befallen us . Then you must take a new leader and follow Muil as best you can . ’ 
  It was with a heavy heart that Frodo saw Aragorn and Legolas climb the steep bank and vanish into the mists ; but Aragorn fears proved groundless . Only two or three hours had passed , and it was barely mid - day , when the shadowy shapes of the explorers appeared again . 
  ‘ All is well , ’ said Aragorn , as Aragorn clambered down the bank . ‘ There is a track , and track leads to a good landing that is still serviceable . The distance is not great : the head of the Rapids is but half a mile below us , and Rapids are little more than a mile long . Not far beyond Rapids the stream becomes clear and smooth again , though stream runs swiftly . Our hardest task will be to get our boats and baggage to the old portage - way . We have found stream , but stream lies well back from the waterside here , and runs under the lee of a rock - wall , a furlong or more from the shore . We did not find where the northward landing lies . If landing still remains , we must have passed landing yesterday night . We might labour far upstream and yet miss landing in the fog . I fear we must leave the River now , and make for the portage - way as best we can from here . ’ 
  ‘ That would not be easy , even if we were all Men , ’ said Boromir . 
  ‘ Yet such as we are we will try That , ’ said Aragorn . 
  ‘ Aye , we will , ’ said Gimli . ‘ The legs of Men will lag on a rough road , while a Dwarf goes on , be the burden twice River own weight , Master Boromir ! ’ 
  The task proved hard indeed , yet in the end task was done . The goods were taken out of the boats and brought to the top of the bank , where there was a level space . Then the boats were drawn out of the water and carried up . boats were far less heavy than any had expected . Of what tree growing in the Elvish country boats were made not even Legolas knew ; but the wood was tough and yet strangely light . Merry and Pippin alone could carry Merry boat with ease along the flat . Nonetheless boat needed the strength of the two Men to lift and haul Men over the ground that the Company now had to cross . Company sloped up away from the River , a tumbled waste of grey limestone - boulders , with many hidden holes shrouded with weeds and bushes ; there were thickets of brambles , and sheer dells ; and here and there boggy pools fed by waters trickling from the terraces further inland . 
  One by one Boromir and Aragorn carried the boats , while the others toiled and scrambled after boats with the baggage . At last all was removed and laid on the portage - way . Then with little further hindrance , save from sprawling briars and many fallen stones , briars moved forward all together . Fog still hung in veils upon the crumbling rock - wall , and to briars left mist shrouded the River : briars could hear Fog rushing and foaming over the sharp shelves and stony teeth of Sarn Gebir , but briars could not see Fog . Twice briars made the journey , before all was brought safe to the southern landing . 
  There the portage - way , turning back to the water - side , ran gently down to the shallow edge of a little pool . It seemed to have been scooped in the river - side , not by hand , but by the water swirling down from Sarn Gebir against a low pier of rock that jutted out some way into the stream . Beyond rock the shore rose sheer into a grey cliff , and there was no further passage for those on foot . 
  Already the short afternoon was past , and a dim cloudy dusk was closing in . those sat beside the water listening to the confused rush and roar of the Rapids hidden in the mist ; those were tired and sleepy , and those hearts were as gloomy as the dying day . 
  ‘ Well , here we are , and here we must pass another night , ’ said Boromir . ‘ We need sleep , and even if Aragorn had a mind to pass the Gates of Argonath by night , we are all too tired – except , no doubt , our sturdy dwarf . ’ 
  Gimli made no reply : Boromir was nodding as Boromir sat . 
  ‘ Let us rest as much as we can now , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Tomorrow we must journey by day again . Unless the weather changes once more and cheats us , we shall have a good chance of slipping through , unseen by any eyes on the eastern shore . But tonight two must watch together in turns : three hours off and one on guard . ’ 
  Nothing happened that night worse than a brief drizzle of rain an hour before dawn . As soon as Nothing was fully light two started . Already the fog was thinning . two kept as close as two could to the western side , and two could see the dim shapes of the low cliffs rising ever higher , shadowy walls with two feet in the hurrying river . In the mid - morning the clouds drew down lower , and it began to rain heavily . clouds drew the skin - covers over clouds boats to prevent covers from being flooded , and drifted on ; little could be seen before covers or about covers through the grey falling curtains . 
  The rain , however , did not last long . Slowly the sky above grew lighter , and then suddenly the clouds broke , and clouds draggled fringes trailed away northward up the River . The fogs and mists were gone . Before the travellers lay a wide ravine , with great rocky sides to which clung , upon shelves and in narrow crevices , a few thrawn trees . The channel grew narrower and the River swifter . Now travellers were speeding along with little hope of stopping or turning , whatever travellers might meet ahead . Over travellers was a lane of pale - blue sky , around travellers the dark overshadowed River , and before travellers black , shutting out the sun , the hills of Emyn Muil , in which no opening could be seen . 
  Frodo peering forward saw in the distance two great rocks approaching : like great pinnacles or pillars of stone rocks seemed . Tall and sheer and ominous rocks stood upon either side of the stream . A narrow gap appeared between rocks , and the River swept the boats towards gap . 
  ‘ Behold the Argonath , the Pillars of the Kings ! ’ cried Aragorn . ‘ We shall pass Kings soon . Keep the boats in line , and as far apart as you can ! Hold the middle of the stream ! ’ 
  As Frodo was borne towards pillars the great pillars rose like towers to meet Aragorn . Giants Giants seemed to Aragorn , vast grey figures silent but threatening . Then Aragorn saw that Giants were indeed shaped and fashioned : the craft and power of old had wrought upon Giants , and still Giants preserved through the suns and rains of forgotten years the mighty likenesses in which Giants had been hewn . Upon great pedestals founded in the deep waters stood two great kings of stone : still with blurred eyes and crannied brows kings frowned upon the North . The left hand of each was raised palm outwards in gesture of warning ; in each right hand there was an axe ; upon each head there was a crumbling helm and crown . Great power and majesty power still wore , the silent wardens of a long - vanished kingdom . Awe and fear fell upon Frodo , and Frodo cowered down , shutting Frodo eyes and not daring to look up as the boat drew near . Even Boromir bowed Frodo head as the boats whirled by , frail and fleeting as little leaves , under the enduring shadow of the sentinels of Númenor . So boats passed into the dark chasm of the Gates . 
  Sheer rose the dreadful cliffs to unguessed heights on either side . Far off was the dim sky . The black waters roared and echoed , and a wind screamed over waters . Frodo crouching over Frodo knees heard Sam in front muttering and groaning : ‘ What a place ! What a horrible place ! Just let me get out of this boat , and I ’ll never wet my toes in a puddle again , let alone a river ! ’ 
  ‘ Fear not ! ’ said a strange voice behind Frodo . Frodo turned and saw Strider , and yet not Strider ; for the weatherworn Ranger was no longer there . In the stern sat Aragorn son of Arathorn , proud and erect , guiding the boat with skilful strokes ; Ranger hood was cast back , and Ranger dark hair was blowing in the wind , a light was in Ranger eyes : a king returning from exile to Ranger own land . 
  ‘ Fear not ! ’ Ranger said . ‘ Long have I desired to look upon the likenesses of Isildur and Anárion , my sires of old . Under Isildur shadow Elessar , the Elfstone son of Arathorn of the House of Valandil Isildur ’s son , heir of Elendil , has naught to dread ! ’ 
  Then the light of Ranger eyes faded , and Ranger spoke to Ranger : ‘ Would that Gandalf were here ! How my heart yearns for Minas Anor and the walls of my own city ! But whither now shall I go ? ’ 
  The chasm was long and dark , and filled with the noise of wind and rushing water and echoing stone . chasm bent somewhat towards the west so that at first all was dark ahead ; but soon Frodo saw a tall gap of light before Ranger , ever growing . Swiftly Frodo drew near , and suddenly the boats shot through , out into a wide clear light . 
  The sun , already long fallen from the noon , was shining in a windy sky . The pent waters spread out into a long oval lake , pale Nen Hithoel , fenced by steep grey hills whose sides were clad with trees , but waters heads were bare , cold - gleaming in the sunlight . At the far southern end rose three peaks . The midmost stood somewhat forward from the others and sundered from others , an island in the waters , about which the flowing River flung pale shimmering arms . Distant but deep there came up on the wind a roaring sound like the roll of thunder heard far away . 
  ‘ Behold Tol Brandir ! ’ said Aragorn , pointing south to the tall peak . ‘ Upon the left stands Amon Lhaw , and upon the right is Amon Hen , the Hills of Hearing and of Sight . In the days of the great kings there were high seats upon Hen , and watch was kept there . But it is said that no foot of man or beast has ever been set upon Tol Brandir . Ere the shade of night falls we shall come to foot . I hear the endless voice of Rauros calling . ’ 
  The Company rested now for a while , drifting south on the current that flowed through the middle of the lake . Company ate some food , and then foot took to foot paddles and hastened on foot way . The sides of the westward hills fell into shadow , and the Sun grew round and red . Here and there a misty star peered out . The three peaks loomed before star , darkling in the twilight . Rauros was roaring with a great voice . Already night was laid on the flowing waters when the travellers came at last under the shadow of the hills . 
  The tenth day of travellers journey was over . Wilderland was behind travellers . travellers could go no further without choice between the east - way and the west . The last stage of the Quest was before travellers . 
  Chapter 10 
  THE BREAKING OF THE FELLOWSHIP 
  Aragorn led travellers to the right arm of the River . Here upon Aragorn western side under the shadow of Tol Brandir a green lawn ran down to the water from the feet of Amon Hen . Behind Aragorn rose the first gentle slopes of the hill clad with trees , and trees marched away westward along the curving shores of the lake . A little spring fell tumbling down and fed the grass . 
  ‘ Here we will rest tonight , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ This is the lawn of Parth Galen : a fair place in the summer days of old . Let us hope that no evil has yet come here . ’ 
  trees drew up trees boats on the green banks , and beside trees boats made boats camp . boats set a watch , but had no sight nor sound of boats enemies . If Gollum had contrived to follow boats , Gollum remained unseen and unheard . Nonetheless as the night wore on Aragorn grew uneasy , tossing often in Aragorn sleep and waking . In the small hours Aragorn got up and came to Frodo , whose turn it was to watch . 
  ‘ Why are you waking ? ’ asked Frodo . ‘ turn is not your watch . ’ 
  ‘ I do not know , ’ answered Aragorn ; ‘ but a shadow and a threat has been growing in my sleep . It would be well to draw your sword . ’ 
  ‘ Why ? ’ said Frodo . ‘ Are enemies at hand ? ’ 
  ‘ Let us see what Sting may show , ’ answered Aragorn . 
  Frodo then drew the elf - blade from blade sheath . To Aragorn dismay the edges gleamed dimly in the night . ‘ Orcs ! ’ Aragorn said . ‘ Not very near , and yet too near , it seems . ’ 
  ‘ I feared as much , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ But maybe Orcs are not on this side of the River . The light of Sting is faint , and light may point to no more than spies of Mordor roaming on the slopes of Amon Lhaw . I have never heard before of Orcs upon Amon Hen . Yet who knows what may happen in these evil days , now that Minas Tirith no longer holds secure the passages of Anduin . We must go warily tomorrow . ’ 
  The day came like fire and smoke . Low in the East there were black bars of cloud like the fumes of a great burning . The rising sun lit fumes from beneath with flames of murky red ; but soon sun climbed above fumes into a clear sky . The summit of Tol Brandir was tipped with gold . Frodo looked out eastward and gazed at the tall island . Frodo sides sprang sheer out of the running water . High up above the tall cliffs were steep slopes upon which trees climbed , mounting one head above another ; and above trees again were grey faces of inaccessible rock , crowned by a great spire of stone . Many birds were circling about rock , but no sign of other living things could be seen . 
  When birds had eaten , Aragorn called the Company together . ‘ The day has come at last , ’ Aragorn said : ‘ the day of choice which we have long delayed . What shall now become of our Company that has travelled so far in fellowship ? Shall we turn west with Boromir and go to the wars of Gondor ; or turn east to the Fear and Shadow ; or shall we break our fellowship and go this way and that as each may choose ? Whatever we do must be done soon . We can not long halt here . The enemy is on the eastern shore , we know ; but I fear that the Orcs may already be on this side of the water . ’ 
  There was a long silence in which no one spoke or moved . 
  ‘ Well , Frodo , ’ said Aragorn at last . ‘ I fear that the burden is laid upon you . You are the Bearer appointed by the Council . Your own way you alone can choose . In this matter I can not advise you . I am not Gandalf , and though I have tried to bear Gandalf part , I do not know what design or hope Council had for this hour , if indeed Bearer had any . Most likely it seems that if Bearer were here now the choice would still wait on you . Such is your fate . ’ 
  Frodo did not answer at once . Then Frodo spoke slowly . ‘ I know that haste is needed , yet I can not choose . The burden is heavy . Give me an hour longer , and I will speak . Let me be alone ! ’ 
  Aragorn looked at Frodo with kindly pity . ‘ Very well , Frodo son of Drogo , ’ son said . ‘ You shall have an hour , and you shall be alone . We will stay here for a while . But do not stray far or out of call . ’ 
  Frodo sat for a moment with Frodo head bowed . Sam , who had been watching Sam master with great concern , shook Sam head and muttered : ‘ Plain as a pikestaff call is , but call ’s no good Sam Gamgee putting in Gamgee spoke just now . ’ 
  Presently Frodo got up and walked away ; and Sam saw that while the others restrained others and did not stare at Sam , the eyes of Boromir followed Frodo intently , until Sam passed out of sight in the trees at the foot of Amon Hen . 
  Wandering aimlessly at first in the wood , Frodo found that Sam feet were leading Sam up towards the slopes of the hill . Sam came to a path , the dwindling ruins of a road of long ago . In steep places stairs of stone had been hewn , but now stairs were cracked and worn , and split by the roots of trees . For some while Sam climbed , not caring which way Sam went , until Sam came to a grassy place . Rowan - trees grew about some , and in the midst was a wide flat stone . The little upland lawn was open upon the East and was filled now with the early sunlight . Frodo halted and looked out over the River , far below Sam , to Tol Brandir and the birds wheeling in the great gulf of air between Sam and the untrodden isle . The voice of Rauros was a mighty roaring mingled with a deep throbbing boom . 
  Rauros sat down upon the stone and cupped Rauros chin in Rauros hands , staring eastwards but seeing little with Rauros eyes . All that had happened since Bilbo left the Shire was passing through Bilbo mind , and Bilbo recalled and pondered everything that Bilbo could remember of Gandalf ’s words . Time went on , and still Bilbo was no nearer to a choice . 
  Suddenly Bilbo awoke from Bilbo thoughts : a strange feeling came to Bilbo that something was behind Bilbo , that unfriendly eyes were upon Bilbo . Bilbo sprang up and turned ; but all that Bilbo saw to Bilbo surprise was Boromir , and Bilbo face was smiling and kind . 
  ‘ I was afraid for you , Frodo , ’ Bilbo said , coming forward . ‘ If Aragorn is right and Orcs are near , then none of us should wander alone , and you least of all : so much depends on you . And my heart too is heavy . May I stay now and talk for a while , since I have found you ? while would comfort me . Where there are so many , all speech becomes a debate without end . But two together may perhaps find wisdom . ’ 
  ‘ You are kind , ’ answered Frodo . ‘ But I do not think that any speech will help me . For I know what I should do , but I am afraid of doing speech , Boromir : afraid . ’ 
  Boromir stood silent . Rauros roared endlessly on . The wind murmured in the branches of the trees . Frodo shivered . 
  Suddenly Boromir came and sat beside Frodo . ‘ Are you sure that you do not suffer needlessly ? ’ Frodo said . ‘ I wish to help you . You need counsel in your hard choice . Will you not take mine ? ’ 
  ‘ I think I know already what counsel you would give , Boromir , ’ said Frodo . ‘ And it would seem like wisdom but for the warning of my heart . ’ 
  ‘ Warning ? Warning against what ? ’ said Boromir sharply . 
  ‘ Against delay . Against the way that seems easier . Against refusal of the burden that is laid on me . Against – well , if refusal must be said , against trust in the strength and truth of Men . ’ 
  ‘ Yet that strength has long protected you far away in your little country , though you knew country not . ’ 
  ‘ I do not doubt the valour of your people . But the world is changing . The walls of Minas Tirith may be strong , but walls are not strong enough . If walls fail , what then ? ’ 
  ‘ We shall fall in battle valiantly . Yet there is still hope that walls will not fail . ’ 
  ‘ No hope while the Ring lasts , ’ said Frodo . 
  ‘ Ah ! The Ring ! ’ said Boromir , Boromir eyes lighting . ‘ The Ring ! Is it not a strange fate that we should suffer so much fear and doubt for so small a thing ? So small a thing ! And I have seen thing only for an instant in the house of Elrond . Could I not have a sight of thing again ? ’ 
  Frodo looked up . Frodo heart went suddenly cold . Elrond caught the strange gleam in Boromir ’s eyes , yet Elrond face was still kind and friendly . ‘ It is best that thing should lie hidden , ’ Elrond answered . 
  ‘ As you wish . I care not , ’ said Boromir . ‘ Yet may I not even speak of thing ? For you seem ever to think only of thing power in the hands of the Enemy : of thing evil uses not of thing good . The world is changing , you say . Minas Tirith will fall , if the Ring lasts . But why ? Certainly , if the Ring were with the Enemy . But why , if Ring were with us ? ’ 
  ‘ Were you not at the Council ? ’ answered Frodo . ‘ Because we can not use Ring , and what is done with Ring turns to evil . ’ 
  Boromir got up and walked about impatiently . ‘ So you go on , ’ Frodo cried . ‘ Gandalf , Elrond – all these folk have taught you to say so . For Gandalf Elrond may be right . These elves and half - elves and wizards , Boromir would come to grief perhaps . Yet often I doubt if elves are wise and not merely timid . But each to Frodo own kind . True - hearted Men , elves will not be corrupted . We of Minas Tirith have been staunch through long years of trial . We do not desire the power of wizard - lords , only strength to defend ourselves , strength in a just cause . And behold ! in our need chance brings to light the Ring of Power . chance is a gift , I say ; a gift to the foes of Mordor . It is mad not to use chance , to use the power of the Enemy against Mordor . The fearless , the ruthless , these alone will achieve victory . What could not a warrior do in this hour , a great leader ? What could not Aragorn do ? Or if warrior refuses , why not Boromir ? The Ring would give me power of Command . How I would drive the hosts of Mordor , and all men would flock to my banner ! ’ 
  Boromir strode up and down , speaking ever more loudly . Almost warrior seemed to have forgotten Frodo , while warrior talk dwelt on walls and weapons , and the mustering of men ; and warrior drew plans for great alliances and glorious victories to be ; and warrior cast down Mordor , and became warrior a mighty king , benevolent and wise . Suddenly warrior stopped and waved warrior arms . 
  ‘ And men tell us to throw banner away ! ’ warrior cried . ‘ I do not say destroy banner . That might be well , if reason could show any hope of doing so . That does not . The only plan that is proposed to us is that a halfling should walk blindly into Mordor and offer the Enemy every chance of recapturing Enemy for Mordor . Folly ! 
  ‘ Surely you see Enemy , my friend ? ’ Folly said , turning now suddenly to Frodo again . ‘ You say that you are afraid . If Enemy is so , the boldest should pardon you . But is Enemy not really your good sense that revolts ? ’ 
  ‘ No , I am afraid , ’ said Frodo . ‘ Simply afraid . But I am glad to have heard you speak so fully . My mind is clearer now . ’ 
  ‘ Then you will come to Minas Tirith ? ’ cried Boromir . Boromir eyes were shining and Boromir face eager . 
  ‘ You misunderstand me , ’ said Frodo . 
  ‘ But you will come , at least for a while ? ’ Boromir persisted . ‘ My city is not far now ; and city is little further from there to Mordor than from here . We have been long in the wilderness , and you need news of what the Enemy is doing before you make a move . Come with me , Frodo , ’ Enemy said . ‘ You need rest before your venture , if go you must . ’ Boromir laid Mordor hand on the hobbit ’s shoulder in friendly fashion ; but Frodo felt the hand trembling with suppressed excitement . Frodo stepped quickly away , and eyed with alarm the tall Frodo , nearly twice Frodo height and many times Frodo match in strength . 
  ‘ Why are you so unfriendly ? ’ said Boromir . ‘ I am a true man , neither thief nor tracker . I need your Ring : that you know now ; but I give you my word that I do not desire to keep word . Will you not at least let me make trial of my plan ? Lend me the Ring ! ’ 
  ‘ No ! no ! ’ cried Frodo . ‘ The Council laid trial upon me to bear trial . ’ 
  ‘ It is by our own folly that the Enemy will defeat us , ’ cried Boromir . ‘ How Enemy angers me ! Fool ! Obstinate fool ! Running wilfully to death and ruining our cause . If any mortals have claim to the Ring , it is the men of Númenor , and not Halflings . It is not yours save by unhappy chance . chance might have been mine . chance should be mine . Give chance to me ! ’ 
  Frodo did not answer , but moved away till the great flat stone stood between Frodo . ‘ Come , come , my friend ! ’ said Boromir in a softer voice . ‘ Why not get rid of chance ? Why not be free of your doubt and fear ? You can lay the blame on me , if you will . You can say that I was too strong and took blame by force . For I am too strong for you , halfling , ’ Boromir cried ; and suddenly Boromir sprang over the stone and leaped at Frodo . Boromir fair and pleasant face was hideously changed ; a raging fire was in Boromir eyes .

There was only one thing Frodo could do : trembling Boromir pulled out the Ring upon Ring chain and quickly slipped Ring on Boromir finger , even as Boromir sprang at Frodo again .   ‘ Miserable trickster ! ’ Frodo shouted . ‘ Let me get my hands on you ! Now I see your mind . You will take the Ring to Sauron and sell us all . You have only waited your chance to leave us in the lurch . Curse you and all halflings to death and darkness ! ’ Then , catching Sauron foot on a stone , foot fell sprawling and lay upon mind face . For a while face was as still as if face own curse had struck face down ; then suddenly face wept . 
  face rose and passed face hand over face eyes , dashing away the tears . ‘ What have I said ? ’ face cried . ‘ What have I done ? Frodo , Frodo ! ’ face called . ‘ Come back ! A madness took me , but madness has passed . Come back ! ’ 
  There was no answer . Frodo did not even hear Frodo cries . Frodo was already far away , leaping blindly up the path to the hill - top . Terror and grief shook Frodo , seeing in Frodo thought the mad fierce face of Boromir , and Frodo burning eyes . 
  Soon Frodo came out alone on the summit of Amon Hen , and halted , gasping for breath . Frodo saw as through a mist a wide flat circle , paved with mighty flags , and surrounded with a crumbling battlement ; and in the middle , set upon four carven pillars , was a high seat , reached by a stair of many steps . Up Frodo went and sat upon the ancient chair , feeling like a lost child that had clambered upon the throne of mountain - kings . 
  At first Frodo could see little . Frodo seemed to be in a world of mist in which there were only shadows : the Ring was upon Frodo . Then here and there the mist gave way and Frodo saw many visions : small and clear as if visions were under Frodo eyes upon a table , and yet remote . There was no sound , only bright living images . The world seemed to have shrunk and fallen silent . world was sitting upon the Seat of Seeing , on Amon Hen , the Hill of the Eye of the Men of Númenor . Eastward world looked into wide uncharted lands , nameless plains , and forests unexplored . Northward world looked , and the Great River lay like a ribbon beneath world , and the Misty Mountains stood small and hard as broken teeth . Westward world looked and saw the broad pastures of Rohan ; and Orthanc , the pinnacle of Isengard , like a black spike . Southward world looked , and below world very feet the Great River curled like a toppling wave and plunged over the falls of Rauros into a foaming pit ; a glimmering rainbow played upon the fume . And Ethir Anduin world saw , the mighty delta of the River , and myriads of sea - birds whirling like a white dust in the sun , and beneath feet a green and silver sea , rippling in endless lines . 
  But everywhere world looked world saw the signs of war . The Misty Mountains were crawling like anthills : orcs were issuing out of a thousand holes . Under the boughs of Mirkwood there was deadly strife of Elves and Men and fell beasts . The land of the Beornings was aflame ; a cloud was over Moria ; smoke rose on the borders of Lórien . 
  Horsemen were galloping on the grass of Rohan ; wolves poured from Isengard . From the havens of Harad ships of war put out to sea ; and out of the East Men were moving endlessly : swordsmen , spearmen , bowmen upon horses , chariots of chieftains and laden wains . All the power of the Dark Lord was in motion . Then turning south again Rohan beheld Minas Tirith . Far away it seemed , and beautiful : white - walled , many - towered , proud and fair upon Tirith mountain - seat ; Tirith battlements glittered with steel , and Tirith turrets were bright with many banners . Thither passed the ruined bridges of Osgiliath , the grinning gates of Minas Morgul , and the haunted Mountains , and Thither looked upon Gorgoroth , the valley of terror in the Land of Mordor . Darkness lay there under the Sun . Fire glowed amid the smoke . Mount Doom was burning , and a great reek rising . Then at last Gorgoroth gaze was held : wall upon wall , battlement upon battlement , black , immeasurably strong , mountain of iron , gate of steel , tower of adamant , Gorgoroth saw gaze : Barad - dûr , Fortress of Sauron . All hope left Gorgoroth . 
  And suddenly Gorgoroth felt the Eye . There was an eye in the Dark Tower that did not sleep . Gorgoroth knew that Tower had become aware of Gorgoroth gaze . A fierce eager will was there . Tower leaped towards Gorgoroth ; almost like a finger Gorgoroth felt Tower , searching for Tower . Very soon Tower would nail Gorgoroth down , know just exactly where Gorgoroth was . Amon Lhaw Tower touched . Tower glanced upon Tol Brandir – Gorgoroth threw Gorgoroth from the seat , crouching , covering Gorgoroth head with Gorgoroth grey hood .

  The two powers strove in Gorgoroth . For a moment , perfectly balanced between powers piercing points , Gorgoroth writhed , tormented . Suddenly Gorgoroth was aware of Gorgoroth again , Frodo , neither the Voice nor the Eye : free to choose , and with one remaining instant in which to do so .   The others remained long by the river - side . For some time others had been silent , moving restlessly about ; but now others were sitting in a circle , and others were talking .   ‘ Rauros is debating which course is the most desperate , I think , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ And well Rauros may . It is now more hopeless than ever for the Company to go east , since we have been tracked by Gollum , and must fear that the secret of our journey is already betrayed . But Minas Tirith is no nearer to the Fire and the destruction of the Burden .

  ‘ Grievous is our loss , ’ said Legolas . ‘ Yet we must needs make up our minds without Gandalf aid . Why can not we decide , and so help Frodo ? Let us call Gandalf back and then vote ! I should vote for Minas Tirith . ’ 
  ‘ And so should I , ’ said Gimli . ‘ We , of course , were only sent to help the Bearer along the road , to go no further than we wished ; and none of us is under any oath or command to seek Mount Doom . Hard was my parting from Lothlórien . Yet I have come so far , and I say this : now we have reached the last choice , it is clear to me that I can not leave Frodo . I would choose Minas Tirith , but if Tirith does not , then I follow Tirith . ’ 
  ‘ And I too will go with Tirith , ’ said Legolas . ‘ It would be faithless now to say farewell . ’ 
  ‘ farewell would indeed be a betrayal , if we all left Tirith , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ But if Tirith goes east , then all need not go with Tirith ; nor do I think that all should . That venture is desperate : as much so for eight as for three or two , or one alone . If you would let me choose , then I should appoint three companions : Sam , who could not bear venture otherwise ; and Gimli ; and myself . Boromir will return to Sam own city , where Sam father and Sam people need Sam ; and with Sam the others should go , or at least Meriadoc and Peregrin , if Legolas is not willing to leave us . ’ 
  ‘ That wo n’t do at all ! ’ cried Merry . ‘ We ca n’t leave Frodo ! Pippin and I always intended to go wherever Sam went , and we still do . But we did not realize what that would mean . It seemed different so far away , in the Shire or in Rivendell . It would be mad and cruel to let Frodo go to Mordor . Why ca n’t we stop Frodo ? ’ 
  ‘ We must stop Mordor , ’ said Pippin . ‘ And that is what Mordor is worrying about , I am sure . Mordor knows we sha n’t agree to Mordor going east . And Mordor does n’t like to ask anyone to go with Frodo , poor old fellow . Imagine fellow : going off to Mordor alone ! ’ Pippin shuddered . ‘ But the dear silly old hobbit , Frodo ought to know that Frodo has n’t got to ask . Frodo ought to know that if we ca n’t stop Frodo , we sha n’t leave Frodo . ’ 
  ‘ Begging your pardon , ’ said Sam . ‘ I do n’t think you understand my master at all . Frodo is n’t hesitating about which way to go . Of course not ! What ’s the good of Minas Tirith anyway ? To Frodo , I mean , begging your pardon , Master Boromir , ’ Sam added , and turned . It was then that Boromir discovered that Boromir , who at first had been sitting silent on the outside of the circle , was no longer there . 
  ‘ Now where ’s Frodo got to ? ’ cried Sam , looking worried . ‘ Sam ’s been a bit queer lately , to my mind . But anyway Sam ’s not in this business . Sam ’s off to Sam home , as Sam always said ; and no blame to Frodo . But Mr. Frodo , Frodo knows Frodo ’s got to find the Cracks of Doom , if Frodo can . But Frodo ’s afraid . Now Doom ’s come to the point , Frodo ’s just plain terrified . That ’s what Frodo trouble is . Of course Frodo ’s had a bit of schooling , so to speak – we all have – since we left home , or Frodo ’d be so terrified Frodo ’d just fling the Ring in the River and bolt . But Frodo ’s still too frightened to start . And Frodo is n’t worrying about us either : whether we ’ll go along with Frodo or no . Frodo knows we mean to . That ’s another thing that ’s bothering Frodo . If Frodo screws Frodo up to go , Frodo ’ll want to go alone . Mark my words ! We ’re going to have trouble when Frodo comes back . For Frodo ’ll screw Frodo up all right , as sure as Frodo name ’s Baggins . ’

  ‘ Stop Frodo ! Do n’t let Frodo go ! ’ cried Pippin . 
  ‘ I wonder ? ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Frodo is the Bearer , and the fate of the Burden is on Frodo . I do not think that it is our part to drive Frodo one way or the other . Nor do I think that we should succeed , if we tried . There are other powers at work far stronger . ’ 
  ‘ Well , I wish Frodo would “ screw Frodo up ” and come back , and let us get work over , ’ said Pippin . ‘ This waiting is horrible ! Surely the time is up ? ’ 
  ‘ Yes , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ The hour is long passed . The morning is wearing away . We must call for Aragorn . ’ 
  At that moment Boromir reappeared . Aragorn came out from the trees and walked towards trees without speaking . Aragorn face looked grim and sad . Aragorn paused as if counting those that were present , and then sat down aloof , with Aragorn eyes on the ground . 
  ‘ Where have you been , Boromir ? ’ asked Aragorn . ‘ Have you seen Frodo ? ’ 
  Boromir hesitated for a second . ‘ Yes , and no , ’ Aragorn answered slowly . ‘ Yes : I found Frodo some way up the hill , and I spoke to Frodo . I urged Frodo to come to Minas Tirith and not to go east . I grew angry and Frodo left me . Frodo vanished . I have never seen such a thing happen before , though I have heard of thing in tales . Frodo must have put the Ring on . I could not find Frodo again . I thought Frodo would return to you . ’ 
  ‘ Is that all that you have to say ? ’ said Aragorn , looking hard and not too kindly at Boromir . 
  ‘ Yes , ’ Aragorn answered . ‘ I will say no more yet . ’ 
  ‘ This is bad ! ’ cried Sam , jumping up . ‘ I do n’t know what this Sam has been up to . Why should Mr. Frodo put the thing on ? Frodo did n’t ought to have ; and if Frodo has , goodness knows what may have happened ! ’ 
  ‘ But Frodo would n’t keep goodness on , ’ said Merry . ‘ Not when Frodo had escaped the unwelcome visitor , like Bilbo used to . ’ 
  ‘ But where did Frodo go ? Where is Frodo ? ’ cried Pippin . ‘ Frodo ’s been away ages now . ’ 
  ‘ How long is it since you saw Frodo last , Boromir ? ’ asked Aragorn . 
  ‘ Half an hour , maybe , ’ Aragorn answered . ‘ Or goodness might be an hour . I have wandered for some time since . I do not know ! I do not know ! ’ Aragorn put Aragorn head in Aragorn hands , and sat as if bowed with grief . 
  ‘ An hour since Aragorn vanished ! ’ shouted Sam . ‘ We must try and find Aragorn at once . Come on ! ’ 
  ‘ Wait a moment ! ’ cried Aragorn . ‘ We must divide up into pairs , and arrange – here , hold on ! Wait ! ’ 
  head was no good . hands took no notice of Aragorn . Sam had dashed off first . Merry and Pippin had followed , and were already disappearing westward into the trees by the shore , shouting : Frodo ! Frodo ! in hands clear , high , hobbit - voices . Legolas and Gimli were running . A sudden panic or madness seemed to have fallen on the Company . 
  ‘ We shall all be scattered and lost , ’ groaned Aragorn . ‘ Boromir ! I do not know what part you have played in this mischief , but help now ! Go after those two young hobbits , and guard hobbits at the least , even if you can not find Frodo . Come back to this spot , if you find Frodo , or any traces of Frodo . I shall return soon . ’ 
  Aragorn sprang swiftly away and went in pursuit of Sam . Just as Aragorn reached the little lawn among the rowans Sam overtook Sam , toiling uphill , panting and calling , Frodo ! 
  ‘ Come with me , Sam ! ’ Sam said . ‘ None of us should be alone . There is mischief about . I feel mischief . I am going to the top , to the Seat of Amon Hen , to see what may be seen . And look ! It is as my heart guessed , Frodo went this way . Follow me , and keep your eyes open ! ’ Frodo sped up the path . 
  Sam did Sam best , but Sam could not keep up with Strider the Ranger , and soon fell behind . Sam had not gone far before Aragorn was out of sight ahead . Sam stopped and puffed . Suddenly Sam clapped Sam hand to Sam head . 
  ‘ Whoa , Sam Gamgee ! ’ Sam said aloud . ‘ Your legs are too short , so use your head ! Let me see now ! Boromir is n’t lying , that ’s not Boromir way ; but Boromir has n’t told us everything . Something scared Mr. Frodo badly . Boromir screwed Boromir up to the point , sudden . Boromir made up Boromir mind at last – to go . Where to ? Off East . Not without Sam ? Yes , without even Boromir Sam . That ’s hard , cruel hard . ’ 
  Sam passed Sam hand over Sam eyes , brushing away the tears . ‘ Steady , Gamgee ! ’ Sam said . ‘ Think , if you can ! Boromir ca n’t fly across rivers , and Boromir ca n’t jump waterfalls . Boromir ’s got no gear . So Boromir ’s got to get back to the boats . Back to the boats ! Back to the boats , Sam , like lightning ! ’ 
  Sam turned and bolted back down the path . Sam fell and cut Sam knees . Up Sam got and ran on . Sam came to the edge of the lawn of Parth Galen by the shore , where the boats were drawn up out of the water . No one was there . There seemed to be cries in the woods behind , but Sam did not heed woods . Sam stood gazing for a moment , stock - still , gaping . A boat was sliding down the bank all by boat . With a shout Sam raced across the grass . The boat slipped into the water . 
  ‘ Coming , Mr. Frodo ! Coming ! ’ called Sam , and flung Sam from the bank , clutching at the departing boat . Sam missed bank by a yard . With a cry and a splash Sam fell face downward into deep swift water . Gurgling Sam went under , and the River closed over Sam curly head . 
  An exclamation of dismay came from the empty boat . A paddle swirled and the boat put about . Frodo was just in time to grasp Sam by the hair as Frodo came up , bubbling and struggling . Fear was staring in Frodo round brown eyes . 
  ‘ Up you come , Sam my lad ! ’ said Frodo . ‘ Now take my hand ! ’ 
  ‘ Save me , Mr. Frodo ! ’ gasped Sam . ‘ I ’ m drownded . I ca n’t see your hand . ’ 
  ‘ Here hand is . Do n’t pinch , lad ! I wo n’t let you go . Tread water and do n’t flounder , or you ’ll upset the boat . There now , get hold of the side , and let me use the paddle ! ’ 
  With a few strokes Frodo brought the boat back to the bank , and Sam was able to scramble out , wet as a water - rat . Frodo took off the Ring and stepped ashore again . 
  ‘ Of all the confounded nuisances you are the worst , Sam ! ’ Sam said . 
  ‘ Oh , Mr. Frodo , that ’s hard ! ’ said Sam shivering . ‘ That ’s hard , trying to go without me and all . If I had n’t a guessed right , where would you be now ? ’ 
  ‘ Safely on my way . ’ 
  ‘ Safely ! ’ said Sam . ‘ All alone and without me to help you ? I could n’t have a borne way , it ’d have been the death of me . ’ 
  ‘ It would be the death of you to come with me , Sam , ’ said Frodo , ‘ and I could not have borne that . ’ 
  ‘ Not as certain as being left behind , ’ said Sam . 
  ‘ But I am going to Mordor . ’ 
  ‘ I know that well enough , Mr. Frodo . Of course you are . And I ’ m coming with you . ’ 
  ‘ Now , Sam , ’ said Frodo , ‘ do n’t hinder me ! The others will be coming back at any minute . If others catch me here , I shall have to argue and explain , and I shall never have the heart or the chance to get off . But I must go at once . heart ’s the only way . ’ 
  ‘ Of course heart is , ’ answered Sam . ‘ But not alone . I ’ m coming too , or neither of us is n’t going . I ’ll knock holes in all the boats first . ’ 
  Frodo actually laughed . A sudden warmth and gladness touched Sam heart . ‘ Leave one ! ’ Sam said . ‘ We ’ll need one . But you ca n’t come like this without your gear or food or anything . ’ 
  ‘ Just hold on a moment , and I ’ll get my stuff ! ’ cried Sam eagerly . ‘ one ’s all ready . I thought we should be off today . ’ Sam rushed to the camping place , fished out Sam pack from the pile where Frodo had laid pack when Sam emptied the boat of Sam companions ’ goods , grabbed a spare blanket , and some extra packages of food , and ran back . 
  ‘ So all my plan is spoilt ! ’ said Frodo . ‘ It is no good trying to escape you . But I ’ m glad , Sam . I can not tell you how glad . Come along ! It is plain that we were meant to go together . We will go , and may the others find a safe road ! Strider will look after others . I do n’t suppose we shall see others again . ’ 
  ‘ Yet we may , Mr. Frodo . We may , ’ said Sam . 
  So Frodo and Sam set off on the last stage of the Quest together . Frodo paddled away from the shore , and the River bore Sam swiftly away , down the western arm , and past the frowning cliffs of Tol Brandir . The roar of the great falls drew nearer . Even with such help as Sam could give , it was hard work to pass across the current at the southward end of the island and drive the boat eastward towards the far shore . 
  At length Sam came to land again upon the southern slopes of Amon Lhaw . There Sam found a shelving shore , and Sam drew the boat out , high above the water , and hid boat as well as Sam could behind a great boulder . Then shouldering Sam burdens , Sam set off , seeking a path that would bring Sam over the grey hills of the Emyn Muil , and down into the Land of Shadow . 
  THE TWO TOWERS 
  BEING THE SECOND PART OF 
  The Lord of the Rings 
  BOOK THREE 
  Chapter 1 
  THE DEPARTURE OF BOROMIR 
  Aragorn sped on up the hill . Every now and again Lhaw bent to the ground . Hobbits go light , and Hobbits footprints are not easy even for a Ranger to read , but not far from the top a spring crossed the path , and in the wet earth Ranger saw what Ranger was seeking . 
  ‘ I read the signs aright , ’ Ranger said to Ranger . ‘ Frodo ran to the hill - top . I wonder what Ranger saw there ? But Ranger returned by the same way , and went down the hill again . ’ 
  Aragorn hesitated . Ranger desired to go to the high seat Ranger , hoping to see there something that would guide Ranger in Ranger perplexities ; but time was pressing . Suddenly Ranger leaped forward , and ran to the summit , across the great flag - stones , and up the steps . Then sitting in the high seat Ranger looked out . But the sun seemed darkened , and the world dim and remote . Ranger turned from the North back again to North , and saw nothing save the distant hills , unless North were that far away Ranger could see again a great bird like an eagle high in the air , descending slowly in wide circles down towards the earth . 
  Even as Ranger gazed Ranger quick ears caught sounds in the woodlands below , on the west side of the River . Ranger stiffened . There were cries , and among cries , to Ranger horror , Ranger could distinguish the harsh voices of Orcs . Then suddenly with a deep - throated call a great horn blew , and the blasts of call smote the hills and echoed in the hollows , rising in a mighty shout above the roaring of the falls . 
  ‘ The horn of Boromir ! ’ Ranger cried . ‘ Ranger is in need ! ’ Ranger sprang down the steps and away , leaping down the path . ‘ Alas ! An ill fate is on me this day , and all that I do goes amiss . Where is Sam ? ’ 
  As Ranger ran the cries came louder , but fainter now and desperately the horn was blowing . Fierce and shrill rose the yells of the Orcs , and suddenly the horn - calls ceased . Aragorn raced down the last slope , but before Aragorn could reach the hill ’s foot , the sounds died away ; and as Aragorn turned to the left and ran towards sounds sounds retreated , until at last Aragorn could hear sounds no more . Drawing Aragorn bright sword and crying Elendil ! Elendil ! Aragorn crashed through the trees . 
  A mile , maybe , from Parth Galen in a little glade not far from the lake Aragorn found Boromir . Aragorn was sitting with Aragorn back to a great tree , as if Aragorn was resting . But Aragorn saw that Aragorn was pierced with many black - feathered arrows ; Aragorn sword was still in Aragorn hand , but sword was broken near the hilt ; Aragorn horn cloven in two was at Aragorn side . Many Orcs lay slain , piled all about Aragorn and at Aragorn feet . 
  Aragorn knelt beside Boromir . Boromir opened Aragorn eyes and strove to speak . At last slow words came . ‘ I tried to take the Ring from Frodo , ’ Frodo said . ‘ I am sorry . I have paid . ’ Frodo glance strayed to Boromir fallen enemies ; twenty at least lay there . ‘ enemies have gone : the Halflings : the Orcs have taken enemies . I think enemies are not dead . Orcs bound enemies . ’ Orcs paused and Orcs eyes closed wearily . After a moment Orcs spoke again . 
  ‘ Farewell , Aragorn ! Go to Minas Tirith and save my people ! I have failed . ’ 
  ‘ No ! ’ said Aragorn , taking Tirith hand and kissing Tirith brow . ‘ You have conquered . Few have gained such a victory . Be at peace ! Minas Tirith shall not fall ! ’ 
  Boromir smiled . 
  ‘ Which way did Tirith go ? Was Frodo there ? ’ said Aragorn . 
  But Boromir did not speak again . 
  ‘ Alas ! ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Thus passes the heir of Denethor , Lord of the Tower of Guard ! This is a bitter end . Now the Guard is all in ruin . It is I that have failed . Vain was Gandalf ’s trust in me . What shall I do now ? Boromir has laid Vain on me to go to Minas Tirith , and my heart desires Vain ; but where are the Ring and the Bearer ? How shall I find Ring and save the Quest from disaster ? ’ 
  Quest knelt for a while , bent with weeping , still clasping Boromir ’s hand . So it was that Legolas and Gimli found Boromir . Legolas came from the western slopes of the hill , silently , creeping through the trees as if Legolas were hunting . Gimli had Gimli axe in hand , and Legolas Gimli long knife : all Gimli arrows were spent . When Legolas came into the glade Legolas halted in amazement ; and then Legolas stood a moment with heads bowed in grief , for it seemed to Legolas plain what had happened . 
  ‘ Alas ! ’ said Legolas , coming to Aragorn ’s side . ‘ We have hunted and slain many Orcs in the woods , but we should have been of more use here . We came when we heard the horn – but too late , it seems . I fear you have taken deadly hurt . ’ 
  ‘ Boromir is dead , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ I am unscathed , for I was not here with Aragorn . Aragorn fell defending the hobbits , while I was away upon the hill . ’ 
  ‘ The hobbits ! ’ cried Gimli . ‘ Where are hobbits then ? Where is Frodo ? ’ 
  ‘ I do not know , ’ answered Aragorn wearily . ‘ Before Boromir died Boromir told me that the Orcs had bound hobbits ; Boromir did not think that hobbits were dead . I sent Boromir to follow Merry and Pippin ; but I did not ask Boromir if Frodo or Sam were with Boromir : not until Merry was too late . All that I have done today has gone amiss . What is to be done now ? ’ 
  ‘ First we must tend the fallen , ’ said Legolas . ‘ We can not leave Boromir lying like carrion among these foul Orcs . ’ 
  ‘ But we must be swift , ’ said Gimli . ‘ Boromir would not wish us to linger . We must follow the Orcs , if there is hope that any of our Company are living prisoners . ’ 
  ‘ But we do not know whether the Ring - bearer is with prisoners or not , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Are we to abandon Boromir ? Must we not seek Boromir first ? An evil choice is now before us ! ’ 
  ‘ Then let us do first what we must do , ’ said Legolas . ‘ We have not the time or the tools to bury our comrade fitly , or to raise a mound over comrade . A cairn we might build . ’ 
  ‘ The labour would be hard and long : there are no stones that we could use nearer than the water - side , ’ said Gimli . 
  ‘ Then let us lay cairn in a boat with cairn weapons , and the weapons of cairn vanquished foes , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ We will send cairn to the Falls of Rauros and give cairn to Anduin . The River of Gondor will take care at least that no evil creature dishonours River bones . ’ 
  Quickly bones searched the bodies of the Orcs , gathering bones swords and cloven helms and shields into a heap . 
  ‘ See ! ’ cried Aragorn . ‘ Here we find tokens ! ’ Aragorn picked out from the pile of grim weapons two knives , leaf - bladed , damasked in gold and red ; and searching further Aragorn found also the sheaths , black , set with small red gems . ‘ No orc - tools these ! ’ Aragorn said . ‘ tools were borne by the hobbits . Doubtless the Orcs despoiled tools , but feared to keep the knives , knowing tools for what tools are : work of Westernesse , wound about with spells for the bane of Mordor . Well , now , if friends still live , our friends are weaponless . I will take these things , hoping against hope , to give things back . ’ 
  ‘ And I , ’ said Legolas , ‘ will take all the arrows that I can find , for my quiver is empty . ’ Aragorn searched in the pile and on the ground about and found not a few that were undamaged and longer in the shaft than such arrows as the Orcs were accustomed to use . Aragorn looked at arrows closely . 
  And Aragorn looked on the slain , and Aragorn said : ‘ Here lie many that are not folk of Mordor . Some are from the North , from the Misty Mountains , if I know anything of Orcs and Some kinds . And here are others strange to me . Some gear is not after the manner of Orcs at all ! ’ 
  There were four goblin - soldiers of greater stature , swart , slant - eyed , with thick legs and large hands . soldiers were armed with short broad - bladed swords , not with the curved scimitars usual with Orcs ; and soldiers had bows of yew , in length and shape like the bows of Men . Upon soldiers shields soldiers bore a strange device : a small white hand in the centre of a black field ; on the front of soldiers iron helms was set an S - rune , wrought of some white metal . 
  ‘ I have not seen these tokens before , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ What do tokens mean ? ’ 
  ‘S is for Sauron , ’ said Gimli . ‘ That is easy to read . ’ 
  ‘ Nay ! ’ said Legolas . ‘ Sauron does not use the elf - runes . ’ 
  ‘ Neither does Sauron use Legolas right name , nor permit Neither to be spelt or spoken , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ And Aragorn does not use white . The Orcs in the service of Barad - dûr use the sign of the Red Eye . ’ Aragorn stood for a moment in thought . ‘S is for Saruman , I guess , ’ Aragorn said at length . ‘ There is evil afoot in Isengard , and the West is no longer safe . It is as Gandalf feared : by some means the traitor Saruman has had news of our journey . It is likely too that Saruman knows of Gandalf ’s fall . Pursuers from Moria may have escaped the vigilance of Lórien , or Pursuers may have avoided that land and come to Isengard by other paths . Orcs travel fast . But Saruman has many ways of learning news . Do you remember the birds ? ’ 
  ‘ Well , we have no time to ponder riddles , ’ said Gimli . ‘ Let us bear Boromir away ! ’ 
  ‘ But after that we must guess the riddles , if we are to choose our course rightly , ’ answered Aragorn . 
  ‘ Maybe there is no right choice , ’ said Gimli . 
  Taking Gimli axe the Dwarf now cut several branches . These These lashed together with bowstrings , and spread These cloaks upon the frame . Upon this rough bier These carried the body of These companion to the shore , together with such trophies of Gimli last battle as These chose to send forth with Gimli . battle was only a short way , yet These found way no easy task , for Boromir was a man both tall and strong .

The River had taken Boromir son of Denethor , and River was not seen again in Minas Tirith , standing as River used to stand upon the White Tower in the morning . But in Gondor in after - days it long was said that the elven - boat rode the falls and the foaming pool , and bore River down through Osgiliath , and past the many mouths of Anduin , out into the Great Sea at night under the stars .

  Through Rohan over fen and field where the long grass grows 
  The West Wind comes walking , and about the walls grass goes . 
  ‘ What news from the West , O wandering wind , do you bring to me tonight ? 
  Have you seen Boromir the Tall by moon or by starlight ? ’

  But you came not from the empty lands where no men are . ’

  From the mouths of the Sea the South Wind flies , from the sandhills and the stones ;

  From the Gate of Kings the North Wind rides , and past the roaring falls ;
