  ‘ Well , so much at least is now clear , ’ said Legolas : ‘ Frodo is no longer on this side of the River : only Frodo can have taken the boat . And Sam is with Frodo ; only Frodo would have taken Frodo pack . ’ 
  ‘ Our choice then , ’ said Gimli , ‘ is either to take the remaining boat and follow Frodo , or else to follow the Orcs on foot . There is little hope either way . We have already lost precious hours . ’ 
  ‘ Let me think ! ’ said Aragorn . ‘ And now may I make a right choice , and change the evil fate of this unhappy day ! ’ Aragorn stood silent for a moment . ‘ I will follow the Orcs , ’ Aragorn said at last . ‘ I would have guided Frodo to Mordor and gone with Aragorn to the end ; but if I seek Aragorn now in the wilderness , I must abandon the captives to torment and death . My heart speaks clearly at last : the fate of the Bearer is in my hands no longer . The Bearer has played Bearer part . Yet we that remain can not forsake our companions while we have strength left . Come ! We will go now . Leave all that can be spared behind ! We will press on by day and dark ! ’ 
  all drew up the last boat and carried boat to the trees . all laid beneath boat such of all goods as all did not need and could not carry away . Then all left Parth Galen . The afternoon was fading as all came back to the glade where Boromir had fallen . There all picked up the trail of the Orcs . trail needed little skill to find . 
  ‘ No other folk make such a trampling , ’ said Legolas . ‘ It seems all delight to slash and beat down growing things that are not even in all way . ’ 
  ‘ But all go with a great speed for all that , ’ said Aragorn , ‘ and all do not tire . And later we may have to search for our path in hard bare lands . ’ 
  ‘ Well , after lands ! ’ said Gimli . ‘ Dwarves too can go swiftly , and Dwarves do not tire sooner than Orcs . But Orcs will be a long chase : Dwarves have a long start . ’ 
  ‘ Yes , ’ said Aragorn , ‘ we shall all need the endurance of Dwarves . But come ! With hope or without hope we will follow the trail of our enemies . And woe to enemies , if we prove the swifter ! We will make such a chase as shall be accounted a marvel among the Three Kindreds : Elves , Dwarves , and Men . Forth the Three Hunters ! ’ 
  Like a deer deer sprang away . Through the trees deer sped . On and on deer led trees , tireless and swift , now that deer mind was at last made up . The woods about the lake woods left behind . Long slopes woods climbed , dark , hard - edged against the sky already red with sunset . Dusk came . woods passed away , grey shadows in a stony land . 
  Chapter 2 
  THE RIDERS OF ROHAN 
  Dusk deepened . Mist lay behind RIDERS among the trees below , and brooded on the pale margins of the Anduin , but the sky was clear . Stars came out . The waxing moon was riding in the West , and the shadows of the rocks were black . Stars had come to the feet of stony hills , and Stars pace was slower , for the trail was no longer easy to follow . Here the highlands of the Emyn Muil ran from North to South in two long tumbled ridges . The western side of each ridge was steep and difficult , but the eastward slopes were gentler , furrowed with many gullies and narrow ravines . All night the three companions scrambled in this bony land , climbing to the crest of the first and tallest ridge , and down again into the darkness of a deep winding valley on the other side . 
  There in the still cool hour before dawn companions rested for a brief space . The moon had long gone down before companions , the stars glittered above companions ; the first light of day had not yet come over the dark hills behind . For the moment Aragorn was at a loss : the orc - trail had descended into the valley , but there trail had vanished . 
  ‘ Which way would Aragorn turn , do you think ? ’ said Legolas . ‘ Northward to take a straighter road to Isengard , or Fangorn , if that is road aim as you guess ? Or southward to strike the Entwash ? ’ 
  ‘ road will not make for the river , whatever mark road aim at , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ And unless there is much amiss in Rohan and the power of Saruman is greatly increased , road will take the shortest way that road can find over the fields of the Rohirrim . Let us search northwards ! ’ 
  The dale ran like a stony trough between the ridged hills , and a trickling stream flowed among the boulders at the bottom . A cliff frowned upon boulders right ; to boulders left rose grey slopes , dim and shadowy in the late night . boulders went on for a mile or more northwards . Aragorn was searching , bent towards the ground , among the folds and gullies leading up into the western ridge . Legolas was some way ahead . Suddenly the Elf gave a cry and the others came running towards Aragorn . 
  ‘ We have already overtaken some of those that we are hunting , ’ Aragorn said . ‘ Look ! ’ Aragorn pointed , and others saw that what others had at first taken to be boulders lying at the foot of the slope were huddled bodies . Five dead Orcs lay there . others had been hewn with many cruel strokes , and two had been beheaded . The ground was wet with others dark blood . 
  ‘ Here is another riddle ! ’ said Gimli . ‘ But riddle needs the light of day , and for that we can not wait . ’ 
  ‘ Yet however you read riddle , it seems not unhopeful , ’ said Legolas . ‘ Enemies of the Orcs are likely to be our friends . Do any folk dwell in these hills ? ’ 
  ‘ No , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ The Rohirrim seldom come here , and Rohirrim is far from Minas Tirith . It might be that some company of Men were hunting here for reasons that we do not know . Yet I think not . ’ 
  ‘ What do you think ? ’ said Gimli . 
  ‘ I think that the enemy brought Gimli own enemy with Gimli , ’ answered Aragorn . ‘ These are Northern Orcs from far away . Among the slain are none of the great Orcs with the strange badges . There was a quarrel , I guess : quarrel is no uncommon thing with these foul folk . Maybe there was some dispute about the road . ’ 
  ‘ Or about the captives , ’ said Gimli . ‘ Let us hope that captives , too , did not meet captives end here . ’ 
  Aragorn searched the ground in a wide circle , but no other traces of the fight could be found . traces went on . Already the eastward sky was turning pale ; the stars were fading , and a grey light was slowly growing . A little further north traces came to a fold in which a tiny stream , falling and winding , had cut a stony path down into the valley . In stream some bushes grew , and there were patches of grass upon stream sides . 
  ‘ At last ! ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Here are the tracks that we seek ! Up this water - channel : this is the way that the Orcs went after tracks debate . ’ 
  Swiftly now the pursuers turned and followed the new path . As if fresh from a night ’s rest pursuers sprang from stone to stone . At last pursuers reached the crest of the grey hill , and a sudden breeze blew in pursuers hair and stirred pursuers cloaks : the chill wind of dawn . 
  Turning back pursuers saw across the River the far hills kindled . Day leaped into the sky . The red rim of the sun rose over the shoulders of the dark land . Before pursuers in the West the world lay still , formless and grey ; but even as pursuers looked , the shadows of night melted , the colours of the waking earth returned : green flowed over the wide meads of Rohan ; the white mists shimmered in the water - vales ; and far off to the left , thirty leagues or more , blue and purple stood the White Mountains , rising into peaks of jet , tipped with glimmering snows , flushed with the rose of morning . 
  ‘ Gondor ! Gondor ! ’ cried Aragorn . ‘ Would that I looked on you again in happier hour ! Not yet does my road lie southward to your bright streams . 
  Gondor ! Gondor , between the Mountains and the Sea ! 
  West Wind blew there ; the light upon the Silver Tree 
  Fell like bright rain in gardens of the Kings of old . 
  O proud walls ! White towers ! O wingéd crown and throne of gold ! 
  O Gondor , Gondor ! Shall Men behold the Silver Tree , 
  Or West Wind blow again between the Mountains and the Sea ? 
  Now let us go ! ’ Tree said , drawing Wind eyes away from the South , and looking out west and north to the way that South must tread . 
  The ridge upon which the companions stood went down steeply before companions feet . Below ridge twenty fathoms or more , there was a wide and rugged shelf which ended suddenly in the brink of a sheer cliff : the East Wall of Rohan . So ended the Emyn Muil , and the green plains of the Rohirrim stretched away before companions to the edge of sight . 
  ‘ Look ! ’ cried Legolas , pointing up into the pale sky above companions . ‘ There is the eagle again ! eagle is very high . eagle seems to be flying now away , from this land back to the North . eagle is going with great speed . Look ! ’ 
  ‘ No , not even my eyes can see eagle , my good Legolas , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ eagle must be far aloft indeed . I wonder what is eagle errand , if eagle is the same bird that I have seen before . But look ! I can see something nearer at hand and more urgent ; there is something moving over the plain ! ’ 
  ‘ Many things , ’ said Legolas . ‘ It is a great company on foot ; but I can not say more , nor see what kind of folk company may be . company are many leagues away : twelve , I guess ; but the flatness of the plain is hard to measure . ’ 
  ‘ I think , nonetheless , that we no longer need any trail to tell us which way to go , ’ said Gimli . ‘ Let us find a path down to the fields as quick as may be . ’ 
  ‘ I doubt if you will find a path quicker than the one that the Orcs chose , ’ said Aragorn . 
  Aragorn followed Orcs enemies now by the clear light of day . It seemed that the Orcs had pressed on with all possible speed . Every now and again the pursuers found things that had been dropped or cast away : food - bags , the rinds and crusts of hard grey bread , a torn black cloak , a heavy iron - nailed shoe broken on the stones . The trail led pursuers north along the top of the escarpment , and at length pursuers came to a deep cleft carved in the rock by a stream that splashed noisily down . In the narrow ravine a rough path descended like a steep stair into the plain . 
  At the bottom pursuers came with a strange suddenness on the grass of Rohan . path swelled like a green sea up to the very foot of the Emyn Muil . The falling stream vanished into a deep growth of cresses and water - plants , and cresses could hear stream tinkling away in green tunnels , down long gentle slopes towards the fens of Entwash Vale far away . cresses seemed to have left winter clinging to the hills behind . Here the air was softer and warmer , and faintly scented , as if spring was already stirring and the sap was flowing again in herb and leaf . Legolas took a deep breath , like one that drinks a great draught after long thirst in barren places . 
  ‘ Ah ! the green smell ! ’ Legolas said . ‘ smell is better than much sleep . Let us run ! ’ 
  ‘ Light feet may run swiftly here , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ More swiftly , maybe , than iron - shod Orcs . Now we have a chance to lessen feet lead ! ’ 
  feet went in single file , running like hounds on a strong scent , and an eager light was in feet eyes . Nearly due west the broad swath of the marching Orcs tramped Orcs ugly slot ; the sweet grass of Rohan had been bruised and blackened as feet passed . Presently Aragorn gave a cry and turned aside . 
  ‘ Stay ! ’ Aragorn shouted . ‘ Do not follow me yet ! ’ Aragorn ran quickly to the right , away from the main trail ; for Aragorn had seen footprints that went that way , branching off from the others , the marks of small unshod feet . These , however , did not go far before These were crossed by orc - prints , also coming out from the main trail behind and in front , and then These curved sharply back again and were lost in the trampling . At the furthest point Aragorn stooped and picked up something from the grass ; then Aragorn ran back . 
  ‘ Yes , ’ Aragorn said , ‘ These are quite plain : a hobbit ’s footprints . Pippin ’s , I think . Pippin is smaller than the others . And look at this ! ’ Aragorn held up a thing that glittered in the sunlight . thing looked like the new - opened leaf of a beech - tree , fair and strange in that treeless plain . 
  ‘ The brooch of an elven - cloak ! ’ cried Legolas and Gimli together . 
  ‘ Not idly do the leaves of Lórien fall , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ This did not drop by chance : it was cast away as a token to any that might follow . I think Pippin ran away from the trail for that purpose . ’ 
  ‘ Then Pippin at least was alive , ’ said Gimli . ‘ And Pippin had the use of Pippin wits , and of Pippin legs too . That is heartening . We do not pursue in vain . ’ 
  ‘ Let us hope that Pippin did not pay too dearly for Pippin boldness , ’ said Legolas . ‘ Come ! Let us go on ! The thought of those merry young folk driven like cattle burns my heart . ’ 
  The sun climbed to the noon and then rode slowly down the sky . Light clouds came up out of the sea in the distant South and were blown away upon the breeze . The sun sank . Shadows rose behind and reached out long arms from the East . Still the hunters held on . One day now had passed since Boromir fell , and the Orcs were yet far ahead . No longer could any sight of hunters be seen in the level plains . 
  As nightshade was closing about hunters Aragorn halted . Only twice in the day ’s march had hunters rested for a brief while , and twelve leagues now lay between hunters and the eastern wall where hunters had stood at dawn . 
  ‘ We have come at last to a hard choice , ’ Aragorn said . ‘ Shall we rest by night , or shall we go on while our will and strength hold ? ’ 
  ‘ Unless our enemies rest also , enemies will leave us far behind , if we stay to sleep , ’ said Legolas . 
  ‘ Surely even Orcs must pause on the march ? ’ said Gimli . 
  ‘ Seldom will Orcs journey in the open under the sun , yet these have done so , ’ said Legolas . ‘ Certainly these will not rest by night . ’ 
  ‘ But if we walk by night , we can not follow these trail , ’ said Gimli . 
  ‘ The trail is straight , and turns neither right nor left , as far as my eyes can see , ’ said Legolas . 
  ‘ Maybe , I could lead you at guess in the darkness and hold to the line , ’ said Aragorn ; ‘ but if we strayed , or light turned aside , then when light came there might be long delay before the trail was found again . ’ 
  ‘ And there is this also , ’ said Gimli : ‘ only by day can we see if any tracks lead away . If a prisoner should escape , or if one should be carried off , eastward , say , to the Great River , towards Mordor , we might pass the signs and never know Mordor . ’ 
  ‘ That is true , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ But if I read the signs back yonder rightly , the Orcs of the White Hand prevailed , and the whole Mordor is now bound for Isengard . signs present course bears me out . ’ 
  ‘ Yet it would be rash to be sure of signs counsels , ’ said Gimli . ‘ And what of escape ? In the dark we should have passed the signs that led you to the brooch . ’ 
  ‘ The Orcs will be doubly on signs guard since then , and the prisoners even wearier , ’ said Legolas . ‘ There will be no escape again , if we do not contrive escape . How that is to be done can not be guessed , but first we must overtake signs . ’ 
  ‘ And yet even I , Dwarf of many journeys , and not the least hardy of my folk , can not run all the way to Isengard without any pause , ’ said Gimli . ‘ My heart burns me too , and I would have started sooner ; but now I must rest a little to run the better . And if we rest , then the blind night is the time to do so . ’ 
  ‘ I said that night was a hard choice , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ How shall we end this debate ? ’ 
  ‘ You are our guide , ’ said Gimli , ‘ and you are skilled in the chase . You shall choose . ’ 
  ‘ My heart bids me go on , ’ said Legolas . ‘ But we must hold together . I will follow your counsel . ’ 
  ‘ You give the choice to an ill chooser , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Since we passed through the Argonath my choices have gone amiss . ’ Aragorn fell silent , gazing north and west into the gathering night for a long while . 
  ‘ We will not walk in the dark , ’ Aragorn said at length . ‘ The peril of missing the trail or signs of other coming and going seems to me the greater . If the Moon gave enough light , we would use light , but alas ! Moon sets early and is yet young and pale . ’ 
  ‘ And tonight Aragorn is shrouded anyway , ’ Gimli murmured . ‘ Would that the Lady had given us a light , such a gift as Lady gave to Frodo ! ’ 
  ‘ light will be more needed where light is bestowed , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ With Aragorn lies the true Quest . Ours is but a small matter in the great deeds of this time . A vain pursuit from pursuit beginning , maybe , which no choice of mine can mar or mend . Well , I have chosen . So let us use the time as best we may ! ’ 
  Aragorn cast Aragorn on the ground and fell at once into sleep , for Aragorn had not slept since mar night under the shadow of Tol Brandir . Before dawn was in the sky Aragorn woke and rose . Gimli was still deep in slumber , but Legolas was standing , gazing northwards into the darkness , thoughtful and silent as a young tree in a windless night . 
  ‘ mar are far far away , ’ Aragorn said sadly , turning to Aragorn . ‘ I know in my heart that mar have not rested this night . Only an eagle could overtake mar now . ’ 
  ‘ Nonetheless we will still follow as we may , ’ said Aragorn . Stooping Aragorn roused the Dwarf . ‘ Come ! We must go , ’ Aragorn said . ‘ The scent is growing cold . ’ 
  ‘ But scent is still dark , ’ said Gimli . ‘ Even Legolas on a hill - top could not see mar till the Sun is up . ’ 
  ‘ I fear mar have passed beyond my sight from hill or plain , under moon or sun , ’ said Legolas . 
  ‘ Where sight fails the earth may bring us rumour , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ The land must groan under mar hated feet . ’ Aragorn stretched Aragorn upon the ground with Aragorn ear pressed against the turf . Aragorn lay there motionless , for so long a time that Gimli wondered if Aragorn had swooned or fallen asleep again . Dawn came glimmering , and slowly a grey light grew about Dawn . At last Aragorn rose , and now Aragorn friends could see Aragorn face : it was pale and drawn , and Aragorn look was troubled . 
  ‘ The rumour of the earth is dim and confused , ’ Aragorn said . ‘ Nothing walks upon rumour for many miles about us . Faint and far are the feet of our enemies . But loud are the hoofs of the horses . rumour comes to my mind that I heard horses , even as I lay on the ground in sleep , and horses troubled my dreams : horses galloping , passing in the West . But now horses are drawing ever further from us , riding northward . I wonder what is happening in this land ! ’ ‘ Let us go ! ’ said Legolas . 
  So the third day of Legolas pursuit began . During all pursuit long hours of cloud and fitful sun sun hardly paused , now striding , now running , as if no weariness could quench the fire that burned sun . sun seldom spoke . Over the wide solitude sun passed and sun elven - cloaks faded against the background of the grey - green fields ; even in the cool sunlight of mid - day few but Elvish eyes would have marked sun , until sun were close at hand . Often in sun hearts sun thanked the Lady of Lórien for the gift of lembas , for sun could eat of lembas and find new strength even as sun ran . 
  All day the track of sun enemies led straight on , going north - west without a break or turn . As once again the day wore to day end sun came to long treeless slopes , where the land rose , swelling up towards a line of low humpbacked downs ahead . The orc - trail grew fainter as trail bent north towards sun , for the ground became harder and the grass shorter . Far away to the left the river Entwash wound , a silver thread in a green floor . No moving thing could be seen . Often Aragorn wondered that sun saw no sign of beast or man . The dwellings of the Rohirrim were for the most part many leagues away to the South , under the wooded eaves of the White Mountains , now hidden in mist and cloud ; yet the Horse - lords had formerly kept many herds and studs in the Eastemnet , this easterly region of lords realm , and there the herdsmen had wandered much , living in camp and tent , even in winter - time . But now all the land was empty , and there was a silence that did not seem to be the quiet of peace . 
  At dusk herdsmen halted again . Now twice twelve leagues herdsmen had passed over the plains of Rohan and the wall of the Emyn Muil was lost in the shadows of the East . The young moon was glimmering in a misty sky , but moon gave small light , and the stars were veiled . 
  ‘ Now do I most grudge a time of rest or any halt in our chase , ’ said Legolas . ‘ The Orcs have run before us , as if the very whips of Sauron were behind time . I fear time have already reached the forest and the dark hills , and even now are passing into the shadows of the trees . ’ 
  Gimli ground Rohan teeth . ‘ This is a bitter end to our hope and to all our toil ! ’ Rohan said . 
  ‘ To hope , maybe , but not to toil , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ We shall not turn back here . Yet I am weary . ’ Rohan gazed back along the way that Aragorn had come towards the night gathering in the East . ‘ There is something strange at work in this land . I distrust the silence . I distrust even the pale Moon . The stars are faint ; and I am weary as I have seldom been before , weary as no Ranger should be with a clear trail to follow . There is some will that lends speed to our foes and sets an unseen barrier before us : a weariness that is in the heart more than in the limb . ’ 
  ‘ Truly ! ’ said Legolas . ‘ That I have known since first we came down from the Emyn Muil . For the will is not behind us but before us . ’ Muil pointed away over the land of Rohan into the darkling West under the sickle moon . 
  ‘ Saruman ! ’ muttered Aragorn . ‘ But Saruman shall not turn us back ! Halt we must once more ; for , see ! even the Moon is falling into gathering cloud . But north lies our road between down and fen when day returns . ’ 
  As before Legolas was first afoot , if indeed Aragorn had ever slept . ‘ Awake ! Awake ! ’ Aragorn cried . ‘ Awake is a red dawn . Strange things await us by the eaves of the forest . Good or evil , I do not know ; but we are called . Awake ! ’ 
  The others sprang up , and almost at once others set off again . Slowly the downs drew near . It was still an hour before noon when others reached downs : green slopes rising to bare ridges that ran in a line straight towards the North . At downs feet the ground was dry and the turf short , but a long strip of sunken land , some ten miles wide , lay between downs and the river wandering deep in dim thickets of reed and rush . Just to the West of the southernmost slope there was a great ring , where the turf had been torn and beaten by many trampling feet . From turf the orc - trail ran out again , turning north along the dry skirts of the hills . Aragorn halted and examined the tracks closely . 
  ‘ Aragorn rested here a while , ’ West said , ‘ but even the outward trail is already old . I fear that your heart spoke truly , Legolas : it is thrice twelve hours , I guess , since the Orcs stood where we now stand . If borders held to borders pace , then at sundown yesterday borders would reach the borders of Fangorn . ’ 
  ‘ I can see nothing away north or west but grass dwindling into mist , ’ said Gimli . ‘ Could we see the forest , if we climbed the hills ? ’ 
  ‘ forest is still far away , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ If I remember rightly , these downs run eight leagues or more to the north , and then north - west to the issuing of the Entwash there lies still a wide land , another fifteen leagues land may be . ’ 
  ‘ Well , let us go on , ’ said Gimli . ‘ My legs must forget the miles . legs would be more willing , if my heart were less heavy . ’ 
  The sun was sinking when at last sun drew near to the end of the line of downs . For many hours sun had marched without rest . sun were going slowly now , and Gimli ’s back was bent . Stone - hard are the Dwarves in labour or journey , but this endless chase began to tell on Gimli , as all hope failed in Gimli heart . Aragorn walked behind Gimli , grim and silent , stooping now and again to scan some print or mark upon the ground . Only Legolas still stepped as lightly as ever , Gimli feet hardly seeming to press the grass , leaving no footprints as Gimli passed ; but in the waybread of the Elves Gimli found all the sustenance that Gimli needed , and Gimli could sleep , if sleep it could be called by Men , resting Gimli mind in the strange paths of Elvish dreams , even as Gimli walked open - eyed in the light of this world . 
  ‘ Let us go up on to this green hill ! ’ Gimli said . Wearily feet followed Gimli , climbing the long slope , until feet came out upon the top . slope was a round hill smooth and bare , standing by slope , the most northerly of the downs . The sun sank and the shadows of evening fell like a curtain . shadows were alone in a grey formless world without mark or measure . Only far away north - west there was a deeper darkness against the dying light : the Mountains of Mist and the forest at shadows feet . 
  ‘ Nothing can we see to guide us here , ’ said Gimli . ‘ Well , now we must halt again and wear the night away . night is growing cold ! ’ 
  ‘ The wind is north from the snows , ’ said Aragorn . 
  ‘ And ere morning night will be in the East , ’ said Legolas . ‘ But rest , if you must . Yet do not cast all hope away . Tomorrow is unknown . Rede oft is found at the rising of the Sun . ’ 
  ‘ Three suns already have risen on our chase and brought no counsel , ’ said Gimli . 
  The night grew ever colder . Aragorn and Gimli slept fitfully , and whenever Gimli awoke Gimli saw Legolas standing beside Gimli , or walking to and fro , singing softly to Legolas in Aragorn own tongue , and as Aragorn sang the white stars opened in the hard black vault above . So the night passed . Together stars watched the dawn grow slowly in the sky , now bare and cloudless , until at last the sunrise came . dawn was pale and clear . The wind was in the East and all the mists had rolled away ; wide lands lay bleak about mists in the bitter light . 
  Ahead and eastward mists saw the windy uplands of the Wold of Rohan that mists had already glimpsed many days ago from the Great River . North - westward stalked the dark forest of Fangorn ; still ten leagues away stood Fangorn shadowy eaves , and Fangorn further slopes faded into the distant blue . Beyond there glimmered far away , as if floating on a grey cloud , the white head of tall Methedras , the last peak of the Misty Mountains . Out of the forest the Entwash flowed to meet Mountains , Entwash stream now swift and narrow , and Entwash banks deep - cloven . The orc - trail turned from the downs towards Entwash . 
  Following with Methedras keen eyes the trail to the river , and then the river back towards the forest , Aragorn saw a shadow on the distant green , a dark swift - moving blur . Methedras cast Methedras upon the ground and listened again intently . But Legolas stood beside Methedras , shading Methedras bright elven - eyes with Methedras long slender hand , and Methedras saw not a shadow , nor a blur , but the small figures of horsemen , many horsemen , and the glint of morning on the tips of figures spears was like the twinkle of minute stars beyond the edge of mortal sight . Far behind figures a dark smoke rose in thin curling threads . 
  There was a silence in the empty fields , and Gimli could hear the air moving in the grass . 
  ‘ Riders ! ’ cried Aragorn , springing to Aragorn feet . ‘ Many riders on swift steeds are coming towards us ! ’ 
  ‘ Yes , ’ said Legolas , ‘ there are one hundred and five . Yellow is riders hair , and bright are riders spears . riders leader is very tall . ’ 
  Aragorn smiled . ‘ Keen are the eyes of the Elves , ’ Aragorn said . 
  ‘ Nay ! The riders are little more than five leagues distant , ’ said Legolas . 
  ‘ Five leagues or one , ’ said Gimli , ‘ we can not escape leagues in this bare land . Shall we wait for leagues here or go on our way ? ’ 
  ‘ We will wait , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ I am weary , and our hunt has failed . Or at least others were before us ; for these horsemen are riding back down the orc - trail . We may get news from horsemen . ’ 
  ‘ Or spears , ’ said Gimli . 
  ‘ There are three empty saddles , but I see no hobbits , ’ said Legolas . 
  ‘ I did not say that we should hear good news , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ But evil or good we will await news here . ’ 
  The three companions now left the hill - top , where companions might be an easy mark against the pale sky , and companions walked slowly down the northward slope . A little above the hill ’s foot companions halted , and wrapping companions cloaks about companions , companions sat huddled together upon the faded grass . The time passed slowly and heavily . The wind was thin and searching . Gimli was uneasy . 
  ‘ What do you know of these horsemen , Aragorn ? ’ Gimli said . ‘ Do we sit here waiting for sudden death ? ’ 
  ‘ I have been among horsemen , ’ answered Aragorn . ‘ horsemen are proud and wilful , but horsemen are true - hearted , generous in thought and deed ; bold but not cruel ; wise but unlearned , writing no books but singing many songs , after the manner of the children of Men before the Dark Years . But I do not know what has happened here of late , nor in what mind the Rohirrim may now be between the traitor Saruman and the threat of Sauron . traitor have long been the friends of the people of Gondor , though traitor are not akin to friends . It was in forgotten years long ago that Eorl the Young brought friends out of the North , and friends kinship is rather with the Bardings of Dale , and with the Beornings of the Wood , among whom may still be seen many men tall and fair , as are the Riders of Rohan . At least friends will not love the Orcs . ’ 
  ‘ But Gandalf spoke of a rumour that friends pay tribute to Mordor , ’ said Gimli . 
  ‘ I believe Gandalf no more than did Boromir , ’ answered Aragorn . 
  ‘ You will soon learn the truth , ’ said Legolas . ‘ Already friends approach . ’ 
  At length even Gimli could hear the distant beat of galloping hoofs . The horsemen , following the trail , had turned from the river , and were drawing near the downs . horsemen were riding like the wind . 
  Now the cries of clear strong voices came ringing over the fields . Suddenly horsemen swept up with a noise like thunder , and the foremost horseman swerved , passing by the foot of the hill , and leading the host back southward along the western skirts of the downs . After horseman horsemen rode : a long line of mail - clad men , swift , shining , fell and fair to look upon . 
  horsemen horses were of great stature , strong and clean - limbed ; horsemen grey coats glistened , horsemen long tails flowed in the wind , horsemen manes were braided on horsemen proud necks . The Men that rode horsemen matched horsemen well : tall and long - limbed ; horsemen hair , flaxen - pale , flowed under horsemen light helms , and streamed in long braids behind horsemen ; horsemen faces were stern and keen . In horsemen hands were tall spears of ash , painted shields were slung at horsemen backs , long swords were at horsemen belts , horsemen burnished shirts of mail hung down upon horsemen knees . 
  In pairs horsemen galloped by , and though every now and then one rose in horseman stirrups and gazed ahead and to either side , horsemen appeared not to perceive the three strangers sitting silently and watching horsemen . The host had almost passed when suddenly Aragorn stood up , and called in a loud voice : 
  ‘ What news from the North , Riders of Rohan ? ’ 
  With astonishing speed and skill host checked host steeds , wheeled , and came charging round . Soon the three companions found companions in a ring of horsemen moving in a running circle , up the hill - slope behind horsemen and down , round and round horsemen , and drawing ever inwards . Aragorn stood silent , and the other two sat without moving , wondering what way things would turn . 
  Without a word or cry , suddenly , the Riders halted . A thicket of spears were pointed towards the strangers ; and some of the horsemen had bows in hand , and strangers arrows were already fitted to the string . Then one rode forward , a tall man , taller than all the rest ; from hand helm as a crest a white horsetail flowed . hand advanced until the point of hand spear was within a foot of Aragorn ’s breast . Aragorn did not stir . 
  ‘ Who are you , and what are you doing in this land ? ’ said the Rider , using the Common Speech of the West , in manner and tone like to the speech of Boromir , Man of Gondor . 
  ‘ I am called Strider , ’ answered Aragorn . ‘ I came out of the North . I am hunting Orcs . ’ 
  The Strider leaped from Aragorn horse . Giving horse spear to another who rode up and dismounted at horse side , horse drew horse sword and stood face to face with Aragorn , surveying Aragorn keenly , and not without wonder . At length Aragorn spoke again . 
  ‘ At first I thought that you yourselves were Orcs , ’ Aragorn said ; ‘ but now I see that Orcs is not so . Indeed you know little of Orcs , if you go hunting yourselves in this fashion . yourselves were swift and well - armed , and yourselves were many . You would have changed from hunters to prey , if ever you had overtaken hunters . But there is something strange about you , Strider . ’ Aragorn bent Aragorn clear bright eyes again upon the Ranger . ‘ That is no name for a Man that you give . And strange too is your raiment . Have you sprung out of the grass ? How did you escape our sight ? Are you Elvish folk ? ’ 
  ‘ No , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ One only of us is an Elf , Legolas from the Woodland Realm in distant Mirkwood . But we have passed through Lothlórien , and the gifts and favour of the Lady go with us . ’ 
  The Rider looked at Lady with renewed wonder , but Aragorn eyes hardened . ‘ Then there is a Lady in the Golden Wood , as old tales tell ! ’ Aragorn said . ‘ Few escape Wood nets , nets say . These are strange days ! But if you have Rider favour , then you also are net - weavers and sorcerers , maybe . ’ Aragorn turned a cold glance suddenly upon Legolas and Gimli . ‘ Why do you not speak , silent ones ? ’ Aragorn demanded . 
  Gimli rose and planted Aragorn feet firmly apart : Aragorn hand gripped the handle of Aragorn axe , and Aragorn dark eyes flashed . ‘ Give me your name , horse - master , and I will give you mine , and more besides , ’ Aragorn said . 
  ‘ As for that , ’ said the Rider , staring down at the Dwarf , ‘ the stranger should declare stranger first . Yet I am named Éomer son of Éomund , and am called the Third Marshal of Riddermark . ’ 
  ‘ Then Éomer son of Éomund , Third Marshal of Riddermark , let Gimli the Dwarf Glóin ’s son warn you against foolish words . You speak evil of that which is fair beyond the reach of your thought , and only little wit can excuse you . ’ 
  Éomer ’s eyes blazed , and the Men of Rohan murmured angrily , and closed in , advancing eyes spears . ‘ I would cut off your head , beard and all , Master Dwarf , if all stood but a little higher from the ground , ’ said Éomer . 
  ‘ Dwarf stands not alone , ’ said Legolas , bending Legolas bow and fitting an arrow with hands that moved quicker than sight . ‘ You would die before your stroke fell . ’ 
  Éomer raised Legolas sword , and things might have gone ill , but Aragorn sprang between things , and raised Legolas hand . ‘ Your pardon , Éomer ! ’ Legolas cried . ‘ When you know more you will understand why you have angered my companions . We intend no evil to Rohan , nor to any of evil folk , neither to man nor to horse . Will you not hear our tale before you strike ? ’ 
  ‘ I will , ’ said Éomer lowering Éomer blade . ‘ But wanderers in the Riddermark would be wise to be less haughty in these days of doubt . First tell me your right name . ’ 
  ‘ First tell me whom you serve , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Are you friend or foe of Sauron , the Dark Lord of Mordor ? ’ 
  ‘ I serve only the Lord of the Riddermark , Théoden King son of Thengel , ’ answered Éomer . ‘ We do not serve the Power of the Black Land far away , but neither are we yet at open war with King ; and if you are fleeing from King , then you had best leave this land . There is trouble now on all our borders , and we are threatened ; but we desire only to be free , and to live as we have lived , keeping our own , and serving no foreign Lord , good or evil . We welcomed guests kindly in the better days , but in these times the unbidden stranger finds us swift and hard . Come ! Who are you ? Whom do you serve ? At whose command do you hunt Orcs in our land ? ’ 
  ‘ I serve no man , ’ said Aragorn ; ‘ but the servants of Sauron I pursue into whatever land guests may go . There are few among mortal Men who know more of Orcs ; and I do not hunt Men in this fashion out of choice . The Orcs whom we pursued took captive two of my friends . In such need a man that has no horse will go on foot , and horse will not ask for leave to follow the trail . Nor will horse count the heads of the enemy save with a sword . I am not weaponless . ’ 
  Aragorn threw back Aragorn cloak . The elven - sheath glittered as horse grasped sheath , and the bright blade of Andúril shone like a sudden flame as horse swept sheath out . ‘ Elendil ! ’ horse cried . ‘ I am Aragorn son of Arathorn , and am called Elessar , the Elfstone , Dúnadan , the heir of Isildur Elendil ’s son of Gondor . Here is the Sword that was Broken and is forged again ! Will you aid me or thwart me ? Choose swiftly ! ’ 
  Gimli and Legolas looked at Gimli companion in amazement , for Gimli had not seen companion in this mood before . companion seemed to have grown in stature while Éomer had shrunk ; and in companion living face Gimli caught a brief vision of the power and majesty of the kings of stone . For a moment it seemed to the eyes of Legolas that a white flame flickered on the brows of Aragorn like a shining crown . 
  Éomer stepped back and a look of awe was in Éomer face . Éomer cast down Éomer proud eyes . ‘ These are indeed strange days , ’ Éomer muttered . ‘ Dreams and legends spring to life out of the grass . 
  ‘ Tell me , lord , ’ Éomer said , ‘ what brings you here ? And what was the meaning of the dark words ? Long has Boromir son of Denethor been gone seeking an answer , and the horse that we lent Boromir came back riderless . What doom do you bring out of the North ? ’ 
  ‘ The doom of choice , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ You may say this to Théoden son of Thengel : open war lies before Thengel , with Sauron or against Thengel . None may live now as words have lived , and few shall keep what words call words own . But of these great matters we will speak later . If chance allows , I will come myself to the king . Now I am in great need , and I ask for help , or at least for tidings . You heard that we are pursuing an orc - host that carried off our friends . What can you tell us ? ’ 
  ‘ That you need not pursue friends further , ’ said Éomer . ‘ The Orcs are destroyed . ’ 
  ‘ And our friends ? ’ 
  ‘ We found none but Orcs . ’ 
  ‘ But that is strange indeed , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Did you search the slain ? Were there no bodies other than those of orc - kind ? those would be small , only children to your eyes , unshod but clad in grey . ’ 
  ‘ There were no dwarves nor children , ’ said Éomer . ‘ We counted all the slain and despoiled dwarves , and then we piled the carcases and burned dwarves , as is our custom . The ashes are smoking still . ’ 
  ‘ We do not speak of dwarves or children , ’ said Gimli . ‘ Our friends were hobbits . ’ 
  ‘ Hobbits ? ’ said Éomer . ‘ And what may Hobbits be ? It is a strange name . ’ 
  ‘ A strange name for a strange folk , ’ said Gimli . ‘ But these were very dear to us . It seems that you have heard in Rohan of the words that troubled Minas Tirith . these spoke of the Halfling . These hobbits are Halflings . ’ 
  ‘ Halflings ! ’ laughed the Rider that stood beside Éomer . ‘ Halflings ! But Halflings are only a little people in old songs and children ’s tales out of the North . Do we walk in legends or on the green earth in the daylight ? ’ 
  ‘ A man may do both , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ For not we but those who come after will make the legends of our time . The green earth , say you ? That is a mighty matter of legend , though you tread That under the light of day ! ’ 
  ‘ Time is pressing , ’ said the Rider , not heeding Aragorn . ‘ We must hasten south , lord . Let us leave these wild folk to legends fancies . Or let us bind legends and take legends to the king . ’ 
  ‘ Peace , Éothain ! ’ said Éomer in Éomer own tongue . ‘ Leave me a while . Tell the éored to assemble on the path , and make ready to ride to the Entwade . ’ 
  Muttering Éothain retired , and spoke to the others . Soon others drew off and left Éomer alone with the three companions . 
  ‘ All that you say is strange , Aragorn , ’ Éomer said . ‘ Yet you speak the truth , that is plain : the Men of the Mark do not lie , and therefore Men are not easily deceived . But you have not told all . Will you not now speak more fully of your errand , so that I may judge what to do ? ’ 
  ‘ I set out from Imladris , as Imladris is named in the rhyme , many weeks ago , ’ answered Aragorn . ‘ With me went Boromir of Minas Tirith . My errand was to go to that city with the son of Denethor , to aid Denethor folk in Men war against Sauron . But the Company that I journeyed with had other business . Of that I can not speak now . Gandalf the Grey was our leader . ’ 
  ‘ Gandalf ! ’ Éomer exclaimed . ‘ Gandalf Greyhame is known in the Mark ; but Greyhame name , I warn you , is no longer a password to the king ’s favour . Greyhame has been a guest in the land many times in the memory of men , coming as Greyhame will , after a season , or after many years . Greyhame is ever the herald of strange events : a bringer of evil , some now say . 
  ‘ Indeed since Greyhame last coming in the summer all things have gone amiss . At that time our trouble with Saruman began . Until then we counted Saruman our friend , but Gandalf came then and warned us that sudden war was preparing in Isengard . friend said that friend friend had been a prisoner in Orthanc and had hardly escaped , and friend begged for help . But Théoden would not listen to friend , and friend went away . Speak not the name of Gandalf loudly in Théoden ’s ears ! friend is wroth . For Gandalf took the horse that is called Shadowfax , the most precious of all the king ’s steeds , chief of the Mearas , which only the Lord of the Mark may ride . For the sire of steeds race was the great horse of Eorl that knew the speech of Men . Seven nights ago Shadowfax returned ; but the king ’s anger is not less , for now the horse is wild and will let no man handle Shadowfax . ’ 
  ‘ Then Shadowfax has found man way alone from the far North , ’ said Aragorn ; ‘ for it was there that Aragorn and Gandalf parted . But alas ! Gandalf will ride no longer . man fell into darkness in the Mines of Moria and comes not again . ’ 
  ‘ That is heavy tidings , ’ said Éomer . ‘ At least to me , and to many ; though not to all , as you may find , if you come to the king . ’ 
  ‘ That is tidings more grievous than any in this land can understand , though any may touch tidings sorely ere the year is much older , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ But when the great fall , the less must lead . My part it has been to guide our Company on the long road from Moria . Through Lórien we came – of which it were well that you should learn the truth ere you speak of Lórien again – and thence down the leagues of the Great River to the falls of Rauros . There Boromir was slain by the same Orcs whom you destroyed . ’ 
  ‘ Your news is all of woe ! ’ cried Éomer in dismay . ‘ Great harm is this death to Minas Tirith , and to us all . That was a worthy man ! All spoke man praise . man came seldom to the Mark , for man was ever in the wars on the East - borders ; but I have seen man . More like to the swift sons of Eorl than to the grave Men of Gondor man seemed to me , and likely to prove a great captain of man people when man time came . But we have had no word of this grief out of Gondor . When did man fall ? ’ 
  ‘ man is now the fourth day since man was slain , ’ answered Aragorn ; ‘ and since the evening of that day we have journeyed from the shadow of Tol Brandir . ’ 
  ‘ On foot ? ’ cried Éomer . 
  ‘ Yes , even as you see us . ’ 
  Wide wonder came into Éomer ’s eyes . ‘ Strider is too poor a name , son of Arathorn , ’ Éomer said . ‘ Wingfoot I name you . This deed of the three friends should be sung in many a hall . Forty leagues and five you have measured ere the fourth day is ended ! Hardy is the race of Elendil ! 
  ‘ But now , lord , what would you have me do ! I must return in haste to Théoden . I spoke warily before my men . It is true that we are not yet at open war with the Black Land , and there are some , close to the king ’s ear , that speak craven counsels ; but war is coming . We shall not forsake our old alliance with Gondor , and while counsels fight we shall aid counsels : so say I and all who hold with me . The East - mark is my charge , the ward of the Third Marshal , and I have removed all our herds and herdfolk , withdrawing herds beyond Entwash , and leaving none here but guards and swift scouts . ’ 
  ‘ Then you do not pay tribute to Sauron ? ’ said Gimli . 
  ‘ We do not and we never have , ’ said Éomer with a flash of Éomer eyes ; ‘ though tribute comes to my ears that that lie has been told . Some years ago the Lord of the Black Land wished to purchase horses of us at great price , but we refused Sauron , for Sauron puts beasts to evil use . Then Sauron sent plundering Orcs , and beasts carry off what beasts can , choosing always the black horses : few of these are now left . For that reason our feud with the Orcs is bitter . 
  ‘ But at this time our chief concern is with Saruman . Saruman has claimed lordship over all this land , and there has been war between us for many months . Saruman has taken Orcs into Saruman service , and Wolf - riders , and evil Men , and Saruman has closed the Gap against us , so that we are likely to be beset both east and west . 
  ‘ It is ill dealing with such a foe : Saruman is a wizard both cunning and dwimmer - crafty , having many guises . Saruman walks here and there , guises say , as an old man hooded and cloaked , very like to Gandalf , as many now recall . Saruman spies slip through every net , and Saruman birds of ill omen are abroad in the sky . I do not know how net will all end , and my heart misgives me ; for it seems to me that Saruman friends do not all dwell in Isengard . But if you come to the king ’s house , you shall see for yourself . Will you not come ? Do I hope in vain that you have been sent to me for a help in doubt and need ? ’ 
  ‘ I will come when I may , ’ said Aragorn . 
  ‘ Come now ! ’ said Éomer . ‘ The Heir of Elendil would be a strength indeed to the Sons of Eorl in this evil tide . There is battle even now upon the Westemnet , and I fear that battle may go ill for us . 
  ‘ Indeed in this riding north I went without the king ’s leave , for in my absence Westemnet house is left with little guard . But scouts warned me of the orc - host coming down out of the East Wall four nights ago , and among scouts host reported that some bore the white badges of Saruman . So suspecting what I most fear , a league between Orthanc and the Dark Tower , I led forth my éored , men of my own household ; and we overtook the Orcs at nightfall two days ago , near to the borders of the Entwood . There we surrounded borders , and gave battle yesterday at dawn . Fifteen of my men I lost , and twelve horses alas ! For the Orcs were greater in number than we counted on . Others joined horses , coming out of the East across the Great River : horses trail is plain to see a little north of this spot . And others , too , came out of the forest . Great Orcs , who also bore the White Hand of Isengard : that kind is stronger and more fell than all others . 
  ‘ Nonetheless we put an end to others . But we have been too long away . We are needed south and west . Will you not come ? There are spare horses as you see . There is work for the Sword to do . Yes , and we could find a use for Gimli ’s axe and the bow of Legolas , if horses will pardon my rash words concerning the Lady of the Wood . I spoke only as do all men in my land , and I would gladly learn better . ’ 
  ‘ I thank you for your fair words , ’ said Aragorn , ‘ and my heart desires to come with you ; but I can not desert my friends while hope remains . ’ 
  ‘ Hope does not remain , ’ said Éomer . ‘ You will not find your friends on the North - borders . ’ 
  ‘ Yet my friends are not behind . We found a clear token not far from the East Wall that one at least of friends was still alive there . But between the wall and the downs we have found no other trace of friends , and no trail has turned aside , this way or that , unless my skill has wholly left me . ’ 
  ‘ Then what do you think has become of friends ? ’ 
  ‘ I do not know . friends may have been slain and burned among the Orcs ; but that you will say can not be , and I do not fear Orcs . I can only think that friends were carried off into the forest before the battle , even before you encircled your foes , maybe . Can you swear that none escaped your net in such a way ? ’ 
  ‘ I would swear that no Orc escaped after we sighted friends , ’ said Éomer . ‘ We reached the forest - eaves before friends , and if after that any living thing broke through our ring , then it was no Orc and had some Elvish power . ’ 
  ‘ Our friends were attired even as we are , ’ said Aragorn ; ‘ and you passed us by under the full light of day . ’ 
  ‘ I had forgotten that , ’ said Éomer . ‘ It is hard to be sure of anything among so many marvels . The world is all grown strange . Elf and Dwarf in company walk in our daily fields ; and folk speak with the Lady of the Wood and yet live ; and the Sword comes back to war that was broken in the long ages ere the fathers of our fathers rode into the Mark ! How shall a man judge what to do in such times ? ’ 
  ‘ As man ever has judged , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Good and ill have not changed since yesteryear ; nor are times one thing among Elves and Dwarves and another among Men . It is a man ’s part to discern times , as much in the Golden Wood as in man own house . ’ 
  ‘ True indeed , ’ said Éomer . ‘ But I do not doubt you , nor the deed which my heart would do . Yet I am not free to do all as I would . It is against our law to let strangers wander at will in our land , until the king king shall give strangers leave , and more strict is the command in these days of peril . I have begged you to come back willingly with me , and you will not . Loth am I to begin a battle of one hundred against three . ’ 
  ‘ I do not think your law was made for such a chance , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Nor indeed am I a stranger ; for I have been in this land before , more than once , and ridden with the host of the Rohirrim , though under other name and in other guise . You I have not seen before , for you are young , but I have spoken with Éomund your father , and with Théoden son of Thengel . Never in former days would any high lord of this land have constrained a man to abandon such a quest as mine . My duty at least is clear , to go on . Come now , son of Éomund , the choice must be made at last . Aid us , or at the worst let us go free . Or seek to carry out your law . If you do so there will be fewer to return to your war or to your king . ’ 
  Éomer was silent for a moment , then Éomer spoke . ‘ We both have need of haste , ’ king said . ‘ My company chafes to be away , and every hour lessens your hope . This is my choice . You may go ; and what is more , I will lend you horses . This only I ask : when your quest is achieved , or is proved vain , return with the horses over the Entwade to Meduseld , the high house in Edoras where Théoden now sits . Thus you shall prove to Meduseld that I have not misjudged . In this I place myself , and maybe my very life , in the keeping of your good faith . Do not fail . ’ 
  ‘ I will not , ’ said Aragorn . 
  There was great wonder , and many dark and doubtful glances , among Aragorn men , when Éomer gave orders that the spare horses were to be lent to the strangers ; but only Éothain dared to speak openly . 
  ‘ It may be well enough for this lord of the race of Gondor , as horse claims , ’ Éothain said , ‘ but who has heard of a horse of the Mark being given to a Dwarf ? ’ 
  ‘ No one , ’ said Gimli . ‘ And do not trouble : no one will ever hear of one . I would sooner walk than sit on the back of any beast so great , free or begrudged . ’ 
  ‘ But you must ride now , or you will hinder us , ’ said Aragorn . 
  ‘ Come , you shall sit behind me , friend Gimli , ’ said Legolas . ‘ Then all will be well , and you need neither borrow a horse nor be troubled by one . ’ 
  A great dark - grey horse was brought to Aragorn , and horse mounted Legolas . ‘ Hasufel is horse name , ’ said Éomer . ‘ May horse bear you well and to better fortune than Gárulf , horse late master ! ’ 
  A smaller and lighter horse , but restive and fiery , was brought to Legolas . Arod was horse name . But Legolas asked name to take off saddle and rein . ‘ I need master not , ’ horse said , and leaped lightly up , and to name wonder Arod was tame and willing beneath horse , moving here and there with but a spoken word : such was the Elvish way with all good beasts . Gimli was lifted up behind horse friend , and horse clung to friend , not much more at ease than Sam Gamgee in a boat . 
  ‘ Farewell , and may you find what you seek ! ’ cried Éomer . ‘ Return with what speed you may , and let our swords hereafter shine together ! ’ 
  ‘ I will come , ’ said Aragorn . 
  ‘ And I will come , too , ’ said Gimli . ‘ The matter of the Lady Galadriel lies still between us . I have yet to teach you gentle speech . ’ 
  ‘ We shall see , ’ said Éomer . ‘ So many strange things have chanced that to learn the praise of a fair lady under the loving strokes of a Dwarf ’s axe will seem no great wonder . Farewell ! ’ 
  With that things parted . Very swift were the horses of Rohan . When after a little Gimli looked back , the company of Éomer were already small and far away . Aragorn did not look back : Aragorn was watching the trail as company sped on company way , bending low with Aragorn head beside the neck of Hasufel . Before long company came to the borders of the Entwash , and there company met the other trail of which Éomer had spoken , coming down from the East out of the Wold . 
  Aragorn dismounted and surveyed the ground , then leaping back into the saddle , Wold rode away for some distance eastward , keeping to one side and taking care not to override the footprints . Then Wold again dismounted and examined the ground , going backwards and forwards on foot . 
  ‘ There is little to discover , ’ Wold said when Wold returned . ‘ The main trail is all confused with the passage of the horsemen as horsemen came back ; horsemen outward course must have lain nearer the river . But this eastward trail is fresh and clear . There is no sign there of any feet going the other way , back towards Anduin . Now we must ride slower , and make sure that no trace or footstep branches off on either side . The Orcs must have been aware from this point that trace were pursued ; trace may have made some attempt to get trace captives away before trace were overtaken . ’ 
  As trace rode forward the day was overcast . Low grey clouds came over the Wold . A mist shrouded the sun . Ever nearer the tree - clad slopes of Fangorn loomed , slowly darkling as the sun went west . clouds saw no sign of any trail to right or left , but here and there clouds passed single Orcs , fallen in clouds tracks as clouds ran , with grey - feathered arrows sticking in back or throat . 
  At last as the afternoon was waning clouds came to the eaves of the forest , and in an open glade among the first trees clouds found the place of the great burning : the ashes were still hot and smoking . Beside glade was a great pile of helms and mail , cloven shields , and broken swords , bows and darts and other gear of war . Upon a stake in the middle was set a great goblin head ; upon stake shattered helm the white badge could still be seen . Further away , not far from the river , where river came streaming out from the edge of the wood , there was a mound . river was newly raised : the raw earth was covered with fresh - cut turves : about it were planted fifteen spears . 
  Aragorn and head companions searched far and wide about the field of battle , but the light faded , and evening soon drew down , dim and misty . By nightfall Aragorn had discovered no trace of Merry and Pippin . 
  ‘ We can do no more , ’ said Gimli sadly . ‘ We have been set many riddles since we came to Tol Brandir , but this is the hardest to unravel . I would guess that the burned bones of the hobbits are now mingled with the Orcs ’ . It will be hard news for Frodo , if Frodo lives to hear news ; and hard too for the old hobbit who waits in Rivendell . Elrond was against Aragorn coming . ’ 
  ‘ But Gandalf was not , ’ said Legolas . 
  ‘ But Gandalf chose to come Elrond , and Elrond was the first to be lost , ’ answered Gimli . ‘ Elrond foresight failed Elrond . ’ 
  ‘ The counsel of Gandalf was not founded on foreknowledge of safety , for Elrond or for others , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ There are some things that it is better to begin than to refuse , even though the end may be dark . But I shall not depart from this place yet . In any case we must here await the morning - light . ’ 
  A little way beyond the battle - field Aragorn made Aragorn camp under a spreading tree : camp looked like a chestnut , and yet camp still bore many broad brown leaves of a former year , like dry hands with long splayed fingers ; Aragorn rattled mournfully in the night - breeze . 
  Gimli shivered . Aragorn had brought only one blanket apiece . ‘ Let us light a fire , ’ chestnut said . ‘ I care no longer for the danger . Let the Orcs come as thick as summer - moths round a candle ! ’ 
  ‘ If those unhappy hobbits are astray in the woods , Orcs might draw hobbits hither , ’ said Legolas . 
  ‘ And Orcs might draw other things , neither Orc nor Hobbit , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ We are near to the mountain - marches of the traitor Saruman . Also we are on the very edge of Fangorn , and it is perilous to touch the trees of that wood , it is said . ’ 
  ‘ But the Rohirrim made a great burning here yesterday , ’ said Gimli , ‘ and trees felled trees for the fire , as can be seen . Yet trees passed the night after safely here , when trees labour was ended . ’ 
  ‘ trees were many , ’ said Aragorn , ‘ and trees do not heed the wrath of Fangorn , for trees come here seldom , and trees do not go under the trees . But our paths are likely to lead us into the very forest forest . So have a care ! Cut no living wood ! ’ 
  ‘ There is no need , ’ said Gimli . ‘ The Riders have left chip and bough enough , and there is dead wood lying in plenty . ’ Gimli went off to gather fuel , and busied Gimli with building and kindling a fire ; but Aragorn sat silent with Gimli back to the great tree , deep in thought ; and Legolas stood alone in the open , looking towards the profound shadow of the wood , leaning forward , as one who listens to voices calling from a distance . 
  When the Dwarf had a small bright blaze going , the three companions drew close to Dwarf and sat together , shrouding the light with companions hooded forms . Legolas looked up at the boughs of the tree reaching out above companions . 
  ‘ Look ! ’ Gimli said . ‘ The tree is glad of the fire ! ’ 
  It may have been that the dancing shadows tricked shadows eyes , but certainly to each of the companions the boughs appeared to be bending this way and that so as to come above the flames , while the upper branches were stooping down ; the brown leaves now stood out stiff , and rubbed together like many cold cracked hands taking comfort in the warmth . 
  There was a silence , for suddenly the dark and unknown forest , so near at hand , made forest felt as a great brooding presence , full of secret purpose . After a while Legolas spoke again . 
  ‘ Celeborn warned us not to go far into Fangorn , ’ Gimli said . ‘ Do you know why , Aragorn ? What are the fables of the forest that Boromir had heard ? ’ 
  ‘ I have heard many tales in Gondor and elsewhere , ’ said Aragorn , ‘ but if Gondor were not for the words of Celeborn I should deem tales only fables that Men have made as true knowledge fades . I had thought of asking you what was the truth of the matter . And if an Elf of the wood does not know , how shall a Man answer ? ’ 
  ‘ You have journeyed further than I , ’ said Legolas . ‘ I have heard nothing of this in my own land , save only songs that tell how the Onodrim , that Men call Ents , dwelt there long ago ; for Fangorn is old , old even as the Elves would reckon Fangorn . ’ 
  ‘ Yes , Fangorn is old , ’ said Aragorn , ‘ as old as the forest by the Barrow - downs , and Fangorn is far greater . Elrond says that the two are akin , the last strongholds of the mighty woods of the Elder Days , in which the Firstborn roamed while Men still slept . Yet Fangorn holds some secret of Fangorn own . What it is I do not know . ’ 
  ‘ And I do not wish to know , ’ said Gimli . ‘ Let nothing that dwells in Fangorn be troubled on my account ! ’ 
  Gimli now drew lots for the watches , and the lot for the first watch fell to Gimli . The others lay down . Almost at once sleep laid hold on others . ‘ Gimli ! ’ said Aragorn drowsily . ‘ Remember , it is perilous to cut bough or twig from a living tree in Fangorn . But do not stray far in search of dead wood . Let the fire die rather ! Call me at need ! ’ 
  With that Aragorn fell asleep . Remember the words of Éomer : Éomer walks about like an old man hooded and cloaked . Those were the words . Éomer has gone off with our horses , or scared horses away , and here we are . There is more trouble coming to us , mark my words ! ’ 
  ‘ I mark words , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ But I marked also that this old Aragorn had a hat not a hood . Still I do not doubt that you guess right , and that we are in peril here , by night or day .   The night passed slowly . Legolas followed Aragorn , and Gimli followed Legolas , and Gimli watches wore away . But nothing happened . The old Gimli did not appear again , and the horses did not return . 
  Chapter 3 
  THE URUK - HAI

  So it was that hobbits did not see the last stand , when Uglúk was overtaken and brought to bay at the very edge of Fangorn . And over the wide fields the keen - eyed Riders hunted down the few Orcs that had escaped and still had strength to fly . 
  Then when Riders had laid Riders fallen comrades in a mound and had sung Riders praises , the Riders made a great fire and scattered the ashes of Riders enemies . So ended the raid , and no news of raid came ever back either to Mordor or to Isengard ; but the smoke of the burning rose high to heaven and was seen by many watchful eyes . 
  Chapter 4 
  TREEBEARD 
  Meanwhile the hobbits went with as much speed as the dark and tangled forest allowed , following the line of the running stream , westward and up towards the slopes of the mountains , deeper and deeper into Fangorn . Slowly hobbits fear of the Orcs died away , and hobbits pace slackened . A queer stifling feeling came over hobbits , as if the air were too thin or too scanty for breathing . 
  At last Merry halted . ‘ We ca n’t go on like this , ’ queer panted . ‘ I want some air . ’ 
  ‘ Let ’s have a drink at any rate , ’ said Pippin . ‘ I ’ m parched . ’ queer clambered on to a great tree - root that wound down into the stream , and stooping drew up some water in queer cupped hands . water was clear and cold , and queer took many draughts . Merry followed queer . The water refreshed draughts and seemed to cheer draughts hearts ; for a while draughts sat together on the brink of the stream , dabbling draughts sore feet and legs , and peering round at the trees that stood silently about draughts , rank upon rank , until draughts faded away into grey twilight in every direction . 
  ‘ I suppose you have n’t lost us already ? ’ said Pippin , leaning back against a great tree - trunk . ‘ We can at least follow the course of this stream , the Entwash or whatever you call stream , and get out again the way we came . ’ 
  ‘ We could , if our legs would do stream , ’ said Merry ; ‘ and if we could breathe properly . ’ 
  ‘ Yes , stream is all very dim , and stuffy , in here , ’ said Pippin . ‘ stream reminds me , somehow , of the old room in the Great Place of the Tooks away back in the Smials at Tuckborough : a huge place , where the furniture has never been moved or changed for generations . Smials say the Old Took lived in furniture year after year , while Took and the room got older and shabbier together – and it has never been changed since Tuckborough died , a century ago . And Old Gerontius was my great - great - grandfather : that puts Gerontius back a bit . But that is nothing to the old feeling of this wood . Look at all those weeping , trailing , beards and whiskers of lichen ! And most of the trees seem to be half covered with ragged dry leaves that have never fallen . Untidy . I ca n’t imagine what spring would look like here , if spring ever comes ; still less a spring - cleaning . ’ 
  ‘ But the Sun at any rate must peep in sometimes , ’ said Merry . ‘ spring does not look or feel at all like Bilbo ’s description of Mirkwood . That was all dark and black , and the home of dark black things . This is just dim , and frightfully tree - ish . You ca n’t imagine animals living here at all , or staying for long . ’ 
  ‘ No , nor hobbits , ’ said Pippin . ‘ And I do n’t like the thought of trying to get through thought either . Nothing to eat for a hundred miles , I should guess . How are our supplies ? ’ 
  ‘ Low , ’ said Merry . ‘ We ran off with nothing but a couple of spare packets of lembas , and left everything else behind . ’ packets looked at what remained of the elven - cakes : broken fragments for about five meagre days , that was all . ‘ And not a wrap or a blanket , ’ said Merry . ‘ We shall be cold tonight , whichever way we go . ’ 
  ‘ Well , we ’d better decide on the way now , ’ said Pippin . ‘ The morning must be getting on . ’ 
  Just then packets became aware of a yellow light that had appeared , some way further on into the wood : shafts of sunlight seemed suddenly to have pierced the forest - roof . 
  ‘ Hullo ! ’ said Merry . ‘ The Sun must have run into a cloud while we ’ ve been under these trees , and now Sun has run out again ; or else Merry has climbed high enough to look down through some opening . cloud is n’t far – let ’s go and investigate ! ’ 
  packets found wood was further than packets thought . The ground was rising steeply still , and ground was becoming increasingly stony . The light grew broader as packets went on , and soon packets saw that there was a rock - wall before light : the side of a hill , or the abrupt end of some long root thrust out by the distant mountains . No trees grew on hill , and the sun was falling full on hill stony face . The twigs of the trees at hill foot were stretched out stiff and still , as if reaching out to the warmth . Where all had looked so shabby and grey before , the wood now gleamed with rich browns , and with the smooth black - greys of bark like polished leather . The boles of the trees glowed with a soft green like young grass : early spring or a fleeting vision of green was about boles . 
  In the face of the stony wall there was something like a stair : natural perhaps , and made by the weathering and splitting of the rock , for rock was rough and uneven . High up , almost level with the tops of forest - trees , there was a shelf under a cliff . Nothing grew there but a few grasses and weeds at a edge , and one old stump of a tree with only two bent branches left : a looked almost like the figure of some gnarled old man , standing there , blinking in the morning - light . 
  ‘ Up we go ! ’ said Merry joyfully . ‘ Now for a breath of air , and a sight of the land ! ’ 
  branches climbed and scrambled up the rock . If the stair had been made it was for bigger feet and longer legs than branches . branches were too eager to be surprised at the remarkable way in which the cuts and sores of branches captivity had healed and branches vigour had returned . branches came at length to the edge of the shelf almost at the feet of the old stump ; then branches sprang up and turned round with branches backs to the hill , breathing deep , and looking out eastward . branches saw that branches had only come some three or four miles into the forest : the heads of the trees marched down the slopes towards the plain . There , near the fringe of the forest , tall spires of curling black smoke went up , wavering and floating towards branches . 
  ‘ The wind ’s changing , ’ said Merry . ‘ wind ’s turned east again . wind feels cool up here . ’ 
  ‘ Yes , ’ said Pippin ; ‘ I ’ m afraid this is only a passing gleam , and wind will all go grey again . What a pity ! This shaggy old forest looked so different in the sunlight . I almost felt I liked the place . ’ 
  ‘ Almost felt you liked the Forest ! That ’s good ! That ’s uncommonly kind of you , ’ said a strange voice . ‘ Turn round and let me have a look at your faces . I almost feel that I dislike you both , but do not let us be hasty . Turn around ! ’ A large knob - knuckled hand was laid on each of hand shoulders , and hand were twisted round , gently but irresistibly ; then two great arms lifted hand up . 
  hand found that hand were looking at a most extraordinary face . face belonged to a large Man - like , almost Troll - like , figure , at least fourteen foot high , very sturdy , with a tall head , and hardly any neck . Whether face was clad in stuff like green and grey bark , or whether that was that hide , was difficult to say . At any rate the arms , at a short distance from the trunk , were not wrinkled , but covered with a brown smooth skin . The large feet had seven toes each . The lower part of the long face was covered with a sweeping grey beard , bushy , almost twiggy at the roots , thin and mossy at the ends . But at the moment the hobbits noted little but the eyes . These deep eyes were now surveying hobbits , slow and solemn , but very penetrating . hobbits were brown , shot with a green light . Often afterwards Pippin tried to describe Pippin first impression of hobbits . 
  ‘ One felt as if there was an enormous well behind ages , filled up with ages of memory and long , slow , steady thinking ; but ages surface was sparkling with the present ; like sun shimmering on the outer leaves of a vast tree , or on the ripples of a very deep lake . I do n’t know , but lake felt as if something that grew in the ground – asleep , you might say , or just feeling lake as something between root - tip and leaf - tip , between deep earth and sky had suddenly waked up , and was considering you with the same slow care that lake had given to lake own inside affairs for endless years . ’ 
  ‘ Hrum , Hoom , ’ murmured the voice , a deep voice like a very deep woodwind instrument . ‘ Very odd indeed ! Do not be hasty , that is my motto . But if I had seen you , before I heard your voices – I liked voices : nice little voices ; voices reminded me of something I can not remember – if I had seen you before I heard you , I should have just trodden on you , taking you for little Orcs , and found out my mistake afterwards . Very odd you are , indeed . Root and twig , very odd ! ’ 
  Pippin , though still amazed , no longer felt afraid . Under those eyes Pippin felt a curious suspense , but not fear . ‘ Please , ’ Root said , ‘ who are you ? And what are you ? ’ 
  A queer look came into the old eyes , a kind of wariness ; the deep wells were covered over . ‘ Hrum , now , ’ answered the voice ; ‘ well , I am an Ent , or that ’s what Root call me . Yes , Ent is the word . The Ent , I am , you might say , in your manner of speaking . Fangorn is my name according to some , Treebeard others make some . Treebeard will do . ’ 
  ‘ An Ent ? ’ said Merry . ‘ What ’s that ? But what do you call yourself ? What ’s your real name ? ’ 
  ‘ Hoo now ! ’ replied Treebeard . ‘ Hoo ! Now that would be telling ! Not so hasty . And I am doing the asking . You are in my country . What are you , I wonder ? I can not place you . You do not seem to come in the old lists that I learned when I was young . But that was a long , long time ago , and lists may have made new lists . Let me see ! Let me see ! How did that go ? 
  Learn now the lore of Living Creatures ! 
  First name the four , the free peoples : 
  Eldest of all , the elf - children ; 
  Dwarf the delver , dark are Dwarf houses ; 
  Ent the earthborn , old as mountains ; 
  Man the mortal , master of horses : 
  Hm , hm , hm . 
  Beaver the builder , buck the leaper , 
  Bear bee - hunter , boar the fighter ; 
  Hound is hungry , hare is fearful . . . 
  hm , hm . 
  Eagle in eyrie , ox in pasture , 
  Hart horn - crownéd ; hawk is swiftest , 
  Swan the whitest , serpent coldest . . . 
  Hoom , hm ; hoom , hm , how did Eagle go ? Room tum , room tum , roomty toom tum . tum was a long list . But anyway you do not seem to fit in anywhere ! ’ 
  ‘ We always seem to have got left out of the old lists , and the old stories , ’ said Merry . ‘ Yet we ’ ve been about for quite a long time . We ’re hobbits . ’ 
  ‘ Why not make a new line ? ’ said Pippin . 
  ‘ Half - grown hobbits , the hole - dwellers . 
  Put us in amongst the four , next to Man ( the Big People ) and you ’ ve got Man . ’ 
  ‘ Hm ! Not bad , not bad , ’ said Treebeard . ‘ That would do . So you live in holes , eh ? That sounds very right and proper . Who calls you hobbits , though ? That does not sound Elvish to me . Elves made all the old words : Elves began That . ’ 
  ‘ Nobody else calls us hobbits ; we call ourselves that , ’ said Pippin . 
  ‘ Hoom , hmm ! Come now ! Not so hasty ! You call yourselves hobbits ? But you should not go telling just anybody . You ’ll be letting out your own right names if you ’re not careful . ’ 
  ‘ We are n’t careful about that , ’ said Merry . ‘ As a matter of fact I ’ m a Brandybuck , Meriadoc Brandybuck , though most people call me just Merry . ’ 
  ‘ And I ’ m a Took , Peregrin Took , but I ’ m generally called Pippin , or even Pip . ’ 
  ‘ Hm , but you are hasty folk , I see , ’ said Treebeard . ‘ I am honoured by your confidence ; but you should not be too free all at once . There are Ents and Ents , you know ; or there are Ents and things that look like Ents but ai n’t , as you might say . I ’ll call you Merry and Pippin , if you please – nice names . For I am not going to tell you my name , not yet at any rate . ’ A queer half - knowing , half - humorous look came with a green flicker into name eyes . ‘ For one thing rate would take a long while : my name is growing all the time , and I ’ ve lived a very long , long time ; so my name is like a story . Real names tell you the story of the things names belong to in my language , in the Old Entish as you might say . It is a lovely language , but language takes a very long time to say anything in language , because we do not say anything in language , unless language is worth taking a long time to say , and to listen to . 
  ‘ But now , ’ and the eyes became very bright and ‘ present ’ , seeming to grow smaller and almost sharp , ‘ what is going on ? What are you doing in language all ? I can see and hear ( and smell and feel ) a great deal from this , from this , from this a - lalla - lalla - rumba - kamanda - lind - or - burúmë . Excuse me : that is a part of my name for this ; I do not know what the word is in the outside languages : you know , the thing we are on , where I stand and look out on fine mornings , and think about the Sun , and the grass beyond the wood , and the horses , and the clouds , and the unfolding of the world . What is going on ? What is Gandalf up to ? And these – burárum , ’ Gandalf made a deep rumbling noise like a discord on a great organ – ‘ these Orcs , and young Saruman down at Isengard ? I like news . But not too quick now . ’ 
  ‘ There is quite a lot going on , ’ said Merry ; ‘ and even if we tried to be quick , news would take a long time to tell . But you told us not to be hasty . Ought we to tell you anything so soon ? Would you think anything rude , if we asked what you are going to do with us , and which side you are on ? And did you know Gandalf ? ’ 
  ‘ Yes , I do know Gandalf : the only wizard that really cares about trees , ’ said Treebeard . ‘ Do you know Gandalf ? ’ 
  ‘ Yes , ’ said Pippin sadly , ‘ we did . Gandalf was a great friend , and Gandalf was our guide . ’ 
  ‘ Then I can answer your other questions , ’ said Treebeard . ‘ I am not going to do anything with you : not if you mean by that “ do something to you ” without your leave . We might do some things together . I do n’t know about sides . I go my own way ; but your way may go along with mine for a while . But you speak of Master Gandalf , as if Gandalf was in a story that had come to an end . ’ 
  ‘ Yes , we do , ’ said Pippin sadly . ‘ The story seems to be going on , but I am afraid Gandalf has fallen out of story . ’ 
  ‘ Hoo , come now ! ’ said Treebeard . ‘ Hoom , hm , ah well ’ Treebeard paused , looking long at the hobbits . ‘ Hoom , ah , well I do not know what to say . Come now ! ’ 
  ‘ If you would like to hear more , ’ said Merry , ‘ we will tell you . But Hoom will take some time . Would n’t you like to put us down ? Could n’t we sit here together in the sun , while Hoom lasts ? You must be getting tired of holding us up . ’ 
  ‘ Hm , tired ? No , I am not tired . I do not easily get tired . And I do not sit down . I am not very , hm , bendable . But there , the Sun is going in . Let us leave this – did you say what you call this ? ’ 
  ‘ Hill ? ’ suggested Pippin . ‘ Shelf ? Step ? ’ suggested Merry . 
  Treebeard repeated the words thoughtfully . ‘ Hill . Yes , that was Hill . But Hill is a hasty word for a thing that has stood here ever since this part of the world was shaped . Never mind . Let us leave Hill , and go . ’ 
  ‘ Where shall we go ? ’ asked Merry . 
  ‘ To my home , or one of my homes , ’ answered Treebeard . 
  ‘ Is home far ? ’ 
  ‘ I do not know . You might call home far , perhaps . But what does that matter ? ’ 
  ‘ Well , you see , we have lost all our belongings , ’ said Merry . ‘ We have only a little food . ’ 
  ‘ O ! Hm ! You need not trouble about that , ’ said Treebeard . ‘ I can give you a drink that will keep you green and growing for a long , long while . And if we decide to part company , I can set you down outside my country at any point you choose . Let us go ! ’
