  Holding the hobbits gently but firmly , one in the crook of each arm , Treebeard lifted up first one large foot and then the other , and moved hobbits to the edge of the shelf . The rootlike toes grasped the rocks . Then carefully and solemnly , Treebeard stalked down from step to step , and reached the floor of the Forest . 
  At once Forest set off with long deliberate strides through the trees , deeper and deeper into the wood , never far from the stream , climbing steadily up towards the slopes of the mountains . Many of the trees seemed asleep , or as unaware of Forest as of any other creature that merely passed by ; but some quivered , and some raised up some branches above Forest head as Forest approached . All the while , as Forest walked , Forest talked to Forest in a long running stream of musical sounds . 
  The hobbits were silent for some time . hobbits felt , oddly enough , safe and comfortable , and hobbits had a great deal to think and wonder about . At last Pippin ventured to speak again . 
  ‘ Please , Treebeard , ’ Pippin said , ‘ could I ask you something ? Why did Celeborn warn us against your forest ? Celeborn told us not to risk getting entangled in forest . ’ 
  ‘ Hmm , did Pippin now ? ’ rumbled Treebeard . ‘ And I might have said much the same , if you had been going the other way . Do not risk getting entangled in the woods of Laurelindórenan ! That is what the Elves used to call That , but now Elves make the name shorter : Lothlórien Elves call That . Perhaps Elves are right : maybe That is fading , not growing . Land of the Valley of Singing Gold , that was Land , once upon a time . Now Land is the Dreamflower . Ah well ! But it is a queer place , and not for just anyone to venture in . I am surprised that you ever got out , but much more surprised that you ever got in : that has not happened to strangers for many a year . that is a queer land . 
  ‘ And so is this . Folk have come to grief here . Aye , strangers have , to grief . Laurelindórenan lindelorendor malinornélion ornemalin , ’ Folk hummed to Folk . ‘ strangers are falling rather behind the world in there , I guess , ’ world said . ‘ Neither this country , nor anything else outside the Golden Wood , is what it was when Celeborn was young . Still : 
  Taurelilómëa - tumbalemorna Tumbaletaurëa Lómëanor * 
  that is what strangers used to say . Things have changed , but that is still true in places . ’ 
  ‘ What do you mean ? ’ said Pippin . ‘ What is true ? ’ 
  ‘ The trees and the Ents , ’ said Treebeard . ‘ I do not understand all that goes on myself , so I can not explain all to you . Some of us are still true Ents , and lively enough in our fashion , but many are growing sleepy , going tree - ish , as you might say . Most of the trees are just trees , of course ; but many are half awake . Some are quite wide awake , and a few are , well , ah , well getting Entish . That is going on all the time . 
  ‘ When that happens to a tree , you find that some have bad hearts . Nothing to do with some wood : I do not mean that . Why , I knew some good old willows down the Entwash , gone long ago , alas ! willows were quite hollow , indeed willows were falling all to pieces , but as quiet and sweet - spoken as a young leaf . And then there are some trees in the valleys under the mountains , sound as a bell , and bad right through . That sort of thing seems to spread . There used to be some very dangerous parts in this country . There are still some very black patches . ’ 
  ‘ Like the Old Forest away to the north , do you mean ? ’ asked Merry . 
  ‘ Aye , aye , something like , but much worse . I do not doubt there is some shadow of the Great Darkness lying there still away north ; and bad memories are handed down . But there are hollow dales in this land where the Darkness has never been lifted , and the trees are older than I am . Still , we do what we can . We keep off strangers and the foolhardy ; and we train and we teach , we walk and we weed . 
  ‘ We are tree - herds , we old Ents . Few enough of us are left now . Sheep get like shepherd , and shepherds like sheep , Sheep is said ; but slowly , and neither have long in the world . neither is quicker and closer with trees and Ents , and trees walk down the ages together . For Ents are more like Elves : less interested in Ents than Men are , and better at getting inside other things . And yet again Ents are more like Men , more changeable than Elves are , and quicker at taking the colour of the outside , you might say . Or better than both : for Elves are steadier and keep Elves minds on things longer . 
  ‘ Some of my kin look just like trees now , and need something great to rouse trees ; and trees speak only in whispers . But some of my trees are limb - lithe , and many can talk to me . Elves began some , of course , waking trees up and teaching trees to speak and learning trees tree - talk . trees always wished to talk to everything , the old Elves did . But then the Great Darkness came , and trees passed away over the Sea , or fled into far valleys , and hid trees , and made songs about days that would never come again . Never again . Aye , aye , there was all one wood once upon a time from here to the Mountains of Lune , and this was just the East End . 
  ‘ Those were the broad days ! Time was when I could walk and sing all day and hear no more than the echo of my own voice in the hollow hills . The woods were like the woods of Lothlórien , only thicker , stronger , younger . And the smell of the air ! I used to spend a week just breathing . ’ 
  Treebeard fell silent , striding along , and yet making hardly a sound with Treebeard great feet . Then Lothlórien began to hum again , and passed into a murmuring chant . Gradually the hobbits became aware that Time was chanting to hobbits : 
  In the willow - meads of Tasarinan I walked in the Spring . 
  Ah ! the sight and the smell of the Spring in Nan - tasarion ! 
  And I said that was good . 
  I wandered in Summer in the elm - woods of Ossiriand . 
  Ah ! the light and the music in the Summer by the Seven Rivers of Ossir ! 
  And I thought that was best . 
  To the beeches of Neldoreth I came in the Autumn . 
  Ah ! the gold and the red and the sighing of leaves in the Autumn in Taur - na - neldor ! 
  Ah was more than my desire . 
  To the pine - trees upon the highland of Dorthonion I climbed in the Winter . 
  Ah ! the wind and the whiteness and the black branches of Winter upon Orod - na - Thôn ! 
  My voice went up and sang in the sky . 
  And now all those lands lie under the wave , 
  And I walk in Ambaróna , in Tauremorna , in Aldalómë , 
  In my own land , in the Aldalómë of Fangorn , 
  Where the roots are long , 
  And the years lie thicker than the leaves 
  In Tauremornalómë . 
  Tauremornalómë ended , and strode on silently , and in all the wood , as far as ear could reach , there was not a sound . 
  The day waned , and dusk was twined about the boles of the trees . At last the hobbits saw , rising dimly before boles , a steep dark land : boles had come to the feet of the mountains , and to the green roots of tall Methedras . Down the hillside the young Entwash , leaping from hillside springs high above , ran noisily from step to step to meet springs . On the right of the stream there was a long slope , clad with grass , now grey in the twilight . No trees grew there and stream was open to the sky ; stars were shining already in lakes between shores of cloud . 
  Treebeard strode up the slope , hardly slackening Methedras pace . Suddenly before stars the hobbits saw a wide opening . Two great trees stood there , one on either side , like living gate - posts ; but there was no gate save trees crossing and interwoven boughs . As the old Ent approached , the trees lifted up trees branches , and all trees leaves quivered and rustled . For trees were evergreen trees , and trees leaves were dark and polished , and gleamed in the twilight . Beyond trees was a wide level space , as though the floor of a great hall had been cut in the side of the hill . On either hand the walls sloped upwards , until walls were fifty feet high or more , and along each wall stood an aisle of trees that also increased in height as walls marched inwards . 
  At the far end the rock - wall was sheer , but at the bottom wall had been hollowed back into a shallow bay with an arched roof : the only roof of the hall , save the branches of the trees , which at the inner end overshadowed all the ground leaving only a broad open path in the middle . A little stream escaped from the springs above , and leaving the main water , fell tinkling down the sheer face of the wall , pouring in silver drops , like a fine curtain in front of the arched bay . The water was gathered again into a stone basin in the floor between the trees , and thence water spilled and flowed away beside the open path , out to rejoin the Entwash in water journey through the forest . 
  ‘ Hm ! Here we are ! ’ said Treebeard , breaking bay long silence . ‘ I have brought you about seventy thousand ent - strides , but what that comes to in the measurement of your land I do not know . Anyhow we are near the roots of the Last Mountain . Part of the name of this Mountain might be Wellinghall , if Part were turned into your language . I like Part . We will stay here tonight . ’ Wellinghall set name down on the grass between the aisles of the trees , and name followed Wellinghall towards the great arch . The hobbits now noticed that as Wellinghall walked Wellinghall knees hardly bent , but Wellinghall legs opened in a great stride . Wellinghall planted Wellinghall big toes ( and toes were indeed big , and very broad ) on the ground first , before any other part of Wellinghall feet . 
  For a moment Treebeard stood under the rain of the falling spring , and took a deep breath ; then Wellinghall laughed , and passed inside . A great stone table stood there , but no chairs . At the back of the bay table was already quite dark . Treebeard lifted two great vessels and stood vessels on the table . vessels seemed to be filled with water ; but Wellinghall held Wellinghall hands over vessels , and immediately vessels began to glow , one with a golden and the other with a rich green light ; and the blending of the two lights lit the bay , as if the sun of summer was shining through a roof of young leaves . Looking back , the hobbits saw that the trees in the court had also begun to glow , faintly at first , but steadily quickening , until every leaf was edged with light : some green , some gold , some red as copper ; while the tree - trunks looked like pillars moulded out of luminous stone . 
  ‘ Well , well , now we can talk again , ’ said Treebeard . ‘ You are thirsty , I expect . Perhaps you are also tired . Drink this ! ’ copper went to the back of the bay , and then back saw that several tall stone jars stood there , with heavy lids . copper removed one of the lids , and dipped in a great ladle , and with one filled three bowls , one very large bowl , and two smaller ones . 
  ‘ This is an ent - house , ’ copper said , ‘ and there are no seats , I fear . But you may sit on the table . ’ Picking up the hobbits copper set hobbits on the great stone slab , six feet above the ground , and there hobbits sat dangling hobbits legs , and drinking in sips . 
  The drink was like water , indeed very like the taste of the draughts hobbits had drunk from the Entwash near the borders of the forest , and yet there was some scent or savour in Entwash which hobbits could not describe : Entwash was faint , but Entwash reminded hobbits of the smell of a distant wood borne from afar by a cool breeze at night . The effect of the draught began at the toes , and rose steadily through every limb , bringing refreshment and vigour as effect coursed upwards , right to the tips of the hair . Indeed the hobbits felt that the hair on hobbits heads was actually standing up , waving and curling and growing . As for Treebeard , copper first laved copper feet in the basin beyond the arch , and then copper drained copper bowl at one draught , one long , slow draught . The hobbits thought copper would never stop . 
  At last copper set the bowl down again . ‘ Ah – ah , ’ copper sighed . ‘ Hm , hoom , now we can talk easier . You can sit on the floor , and I will lie down ; that will prevent this drink from rising to my head and sending me to sleep . ’ 
  On the right side of the bay there was a great bed on low legs , not more than a couple of feet high , covered deep in dried grass and bracken . Treebeard lowered Treebeard slowly on to this ( with only the slightest sign of bending at bay middle ) , until bay lay at full length , with bay arms behind bay head , looking up at the ceiling , upon which lights were flickering , like the play of leaves in the sunshine . Merry and Pippin sat beside bay on pillows of grass . 
  ‘ Now tell me your tale , and do not hurry ! ’ said Treebeard . 
  The hobbits began to tell bay the story of hobbits adventures ever since hobbits left Hobbiton . hobbits followed no very clear order , for hobbits interrupted one another continually , and Treebeard often stopped the speaker , and went back to some earlier point , or jumped forward asking questions about later events . hobbits said nothing whatever about the Ring , and did not tell bay why hobbits set out or where hobbits were going to ; and bay did not ask for any reasons . 
  bay was immensely interested in everything : in the Black Riders , in Elrond , and Rivendell , in the Old Forest , and Tom Bombadil , in the Mines of Moria , and in Lothlórien and Galadriel . bay made Riders describe the Shire and Shire Lothlórien over and over again . bay said an odd thing at this point . ‘ You never see any , hm , any Ents round there , do you ? ’ bay asked . ‘ Well , not Ents , Entwives I should really say . ’ 
  ‘ Entwives ? ’ said Pippin . ‘ Are Entwives like you at all ? ’ 
  ‘ Yes , hm , well no : I do not really know now , ’ said Treebeard thoughtfully . ‘ But Entwives would like your country , so I just wondered . ’ 
  Treebeard was however especially interested in everything that concerned Gandalf ; and most interested of all in Saruman ’s doings . The hobbits regretted very much that hobbits knew so little about doings : only a rather vague report by Sam of what Gandalf had told the Council . But hobbits were clear at any rate that Uglúk and Gandalf troop came from Isengard , and spoke of Saruman as hobbits master . 
  ‘ Hm , hoom ! ’ said Treebeard , when at last hobbits story had wound and wandered down to the battle of the Orcs and the Riders of Rohan . ‘ Well , well ! That is a bundle of news and no mistake . You have not told me all , no indeed , not by a long way . But I do not doubt that you are doing as Gandalf would wish . There is something very big going on , that I can see , and what something is maybe I shall learn in good time , or in bad time . By root and twig , but it is a strange business : up sprout a little folk that are not in the old lists , and behold ! the Nine forgotten Riders reappear to hunt lists , and Gandalf takes lists on a great journey , and Galadriel harbours lists in Caras Galadhon , and Orcs pursue lists down all the leagues of Wilderland : indeed lists seem to be caught up in a great storm . I hope lists weather Orcs ! ’ 
  ‘ And what about yourself ? ’ asked Merry . 
  ‘ Hoom , hm , I have not troubled about the Great Wars , ’ said Treebeard ; ‘ Wars mostly concern Elves and Men . That is the business of Wizards : Wizards are always troubled about the future . I do not like worrying about the future . I am not altogether on anybody ’s side , because nobody is altogether on my side , if you understand me : nobody cares for the woods as I care for woods , not even Elves nowadays . Still , I take more kindly to Elves than to others : it was the Elves that cured us of dumbness long ago , and that was a great gift that can not be forgotten , though our ways have parted since . And there are some things , of course , whose side I am altogether not on ; I am against things altogether : these – burárum ’ ( nobody again made a deep rumble of disgust ) ‘ — these Orcs , and things masters . 
  ‘ I used to be anxious when the shadow lay on Mirkwood , but when Mirkwood removed to Mordor , I did not trouble for a while : Mordor is a long way away . But it seems that the wind is setting East , and the withering of all woods may be drawing near . There is naught that an old Ent can do to hold back that storm : Mordor must weather Ent or crack . 
  ‘ But Saruman now ! Saruman is a neighbour : I can not overlook Saruman . I must do something , I suppose . I have often wondered lately what I should do about Saruman . ’ 
  ‘ Who is Saruman ? ’ asked Pippin . ‘ Do you know anything about Saruman history ? ’ 
  ‘ Saruman is a Wizard , ’ answered Treebeard . ‘ More than that I can not say . I do not know the history of Wizards . Wizards appeared first after the Great Ships came over the Sea ; but if Wizards came with the Ships I never can tell . Saruman was reckoned great among Wizards , I believe . Saruman gave up wandering about and minding the affairs of Men and Elves , some time ago – you would call Men a very long time ago ; and Saruman settled down at Angrenost , or Isengard as the Men of Rohan call Angrenost . Saruman was very quiet to begin with , but Saruman fame began to grow . Saruman was chosen to be the head of the White Council , head say ; but that did not turn out too well . I wonder now if even then Saruman was not turning to evil ways . But at any rate Saruman used to give no trouble to Saruman neighbours . I used to talk to Saruman . There was a time when Saruman was always walking about my woods . Saruman was polite in those days , always asking my leave ( at least when Saruman met me ) ; and always eager to listen . I told Saruman many things that Saruman would never have found out by Saruman ; but Saruman never repaid me in like kind . I can not remember that Saruman ever told me anything . And Saruman got more and more like that ; Saruman face , as I remember face – I have not seen that for many a day – became like windows in a stone wall : windows with shutters inside . 
  ‘ I think that I now understand what Saruman is up to . Saruman is plotting to become a Power . Saruman has a mind of metal and wheels ; and Saruman does not care for growing things , except as far as things serve Saruman for the moment . And now it is clear that Saruman is a black traitor . Saruman has taken up with foul folk , with the Orcs . Brm , hoom ! Worse than that : traitor has been doing something to things ; something dangerous . For these Isengarders are more like wicked Men . It is a mark of evil things that came in the Great Darkness that Men can not abide the Sun ; but Saruman ’s Orcs can endure Saruman , even if Men hate Saruman . I wonder what traitor has done ? Are Men Men traitor has ruined , or has traitor blended the races of Orcs and Men ? That would be a black evil ! ’ 
  Treebeard rumbled for a moment , as if Treebeard were pronouncing some deep , subterranean Entish malediction . ‘ Some time ago I began to wonder how Orcs dared to pass through my woods so freely , ’ traitor went on . ‘ Only lately did I guess that Saruman was to blame , and that long ago traitor had been spying out all the ways , and discovering my secrets . traitor and traitor foul folk are making havoc now . Down on the borders traitor are felling trees – good trees . Some of the trees Some just cut down and leave to rot – orc - mischief that ; but most are hewn up and carried off to feed the fires of Orthanc . There is always a smoke rising from Isengard these days . 
  ‘ Curse traitor , root and branch ! Many of those trees were my friends , creatures I had known from nut and acorn ; many had voices of friends own that are lost for ever now . And there are wastes of stump and bramble where once there were singing groves . I have been idle . I have let things slip . stump must stop ! ’ 
  Treebeard raised Treebeard from traitor bed with a jerk , stood up , and thumped traitor hand on the table . The vessels of light trembled and sent up two jets of flame . There was a flicker like green fire in traitor eyes , and traitor beard stood out stiff as a great besom . 
  ‘ I will stop stump ! ’ traitor boomed . ‘ And you shall come with me . You may be able to help me . You will be helping your own friends that way , too ; for if Saruman is not checked Rohan and Gondor will have an enemy behind as well as in front . Our roads go together – to Isengard ! ’ 
  ‘ We will come with you , ’ said Merry . ‘ We will do what we can . ’ 
  ‘ Yes ! ’ said Pippin . ‘ I should like to see the White Hand overthrown . I should like to be there , even if I could not be of much use : I shall never forget Uglúk and the crossing of Rohan . ’ 
  ‘ Good ! Good ! ’ said Treebeard . ‘ But I spoke hastily . We must not be hasty . I have become too hot . I must cool myself and think ; for it is easier to shout stop ! than to do Treebeard . ’ 
  He strode to the archway and stood for some time under the falling rain of the spring . Then He laughed and shook He , and wherever the drops of water fell glittering from He to the ground drops glinted like red and green sparks . He came back and laid He on the bed again and was silent . 
  After some time the hobbits heard He murmuring again . He seemed to be counting on He fingers . ‘ Fangorn , Finglas , Fladrif , aye , aye , ’ He sighed . ‘ The trouble is that there are so few of us left , ’ He said turning towards the hobbits . ‘ Only three remain of the first Ents that walked in the woods before the Darkness : only myself , Fangorn , and Finglas and Fladrif – to give Ents Ents Elvish names ; you may call Ents Leaflock and Skinbark if you like that better . And of us three , Leaflock and Skinbark are not much use for this business . Leaflock has grown sleepy , almost tree - ish , you might say : Finglas has taken to standing by Finglas half - asleep all through the summer with the deep grass of the meadows round Finglas knees . Covered with leafy hair Finglas is . Finglas used to rouse up in winter ; but of late Finglas has been too drowsy to walk far even then . Skinbark lived on the mountain - slopes west of Isengard . That is where the worst trouble has been . Finglas was wounded by the Orcs , and many of Finglas folk and Finglas tree - herds have been murdered and destroyed . Finglas has gone up into the high places , among the birches that Finglas loves best , and Finglas will not come down . Still , I daresay I could get together a fair company of our younger folks – if I could make folks understand the need ; if I could rouse folks : we are not a hasty folk . What a pity there are so few of us ! ’ 
  ‘ Why are there so few , when you have lived in this country so long ? ’ asked Pippin . ‘ Have a great many died ? ’ 
  ‘ Oh , no ! ’ said Treebeard . ‘ None have died from inside , as you might say . Some have fallen in the evil chances of the long years , of course ; and more have grown tree - ish . But there were never many of us and we have not increased . There have been no Entings – no children , you would say , not for a terrible long count of years . You see , we lost the Entwives . ’ 
  ‘ How very sad ! ’ said Pippin . ‘ How was it that Entings all died ? ’ 
  ‘ Entings did not die ! ’ said Treebeard . ‘ I never said died . We lost Entings , I said . We lost Entings and we can not find Entings . ’ Pippin sighed . ‘ I thought most folk knew that . There were songs about the hunt of the Ents for the Entwives sung among Elves and Men from Mirkwood to Gondor . Entwives can not be quite forgotten . ’ 
  ‘ Well , I am afraid the songs have not come west over the Mountains to the Shire , ’ said Merry . ‘ Wo n’t you tell us some more , or sing us one of the songs ? ’ 
  ‘ Yes , I will indeed , ’ said Treebeard , seeming pleased with the request . ‘ But I can not tell one properly , only in short ; and then we must end our talk : tomorrow we have councils to call , and work to do , and maybe a journey to begin . ’ 
  ‘ one is rather a strange and sad story , ’ Merry went on after a pause . ‘ When the world was young , and the woods were wide and wild , the Ents and the Entwives – and there were Entmaidens then : ah ! the loveliness of Fimbrethil , of Wandlimb the lightfooted , in the days of our youth ! – Ents walked together and Ents housed together . But our hearts did not go on growing in the same way : the Ents gave Ents love to things that Ents met in the world , and the Entwives gave Ents thought to other things , for the Ents loved the great trees , and the wild woods , and the slopes of the high hills ; and Ents drank of the mountain - streams , and ate only such fruit as the trees let fall in Ents path ; and Ents learned of the Elves and spoke with the Trees . But the Entwives gave Ents minds to the lesser trees , and to the meads in the sunshine beyond the feet of the forests ; and Ents saw the sloe in the thicket , and the wild apple and the cherry blossoming in spring , and the green herbs in the waterlands in summer , and the seeding grasses in the autumn fields . Ents did not desire to speak with these things ; but Ents wished Ents to hear and obey what was said to Ents . The Entwives ordered Ents to grow according to Ents wishes , and bear leaf and fruit to Ents liking ; for the Entwives desired order , and plenty , and peace ( by which Ents meant that things should remain where Ents had set Ents ) . So the Entwives made gardens to live in . But we Ents went on wandering , and we only came to the gardens now and again . Then when the Darkness came in the North , the Entwives crossed the Great River , and made new gardens , and tilled new fields , and we saw gardens more seldom . After the Darkness was overthrown the land of the Entwives blossomed richly , and gardens fields were full of corn . Many men learned the crafts of the Entwives and honoured crafts greatly ; but we were only a legend to crafts , a secret in the heart of the forest . Yet here we still are , while all the gardens of the Entwives are wasted : Men call gardens the Brown Lands now . 
  ‘ I remember legend was long ago – in the time of the war between Sauron and the Men of the Sea – desire came over me to see Fimbrethil again . Very fair Fimbrethil was still in my eyes , when I had last seen Fimbrethil , though little like the Entmaiden of old . For the Entwives were bent and browned by Entwives labour ; Entwives hair parched by the sun to the hue of ripe corn and Entwives cheeks like red apples . Yet Entwives eyes were still the eyes of our own people . We crossed over Anduin and came to Entwives land ; but we found a desert : it was all burned and uprooted , for war had passed over all . But the Entwives were not there . Long we called , and long we searched ; and we asked all folk that we met which way the Entwives had gone . Some said Some had never seen Entwives ; and some said that Entwives had seen Entwives walking away west , and some said east , and others south . But nowhere that we went could we find Entwives . Our sorrow was very great . Yet the wild wood called , and we returned to wood . For many years we used to go out every now and again and look for the Entwives , walking far and wide and calling years by years beautiful names . But as time passed we went more seldom and wandered less far . And now the Entwives are only a memory for us , and our beards are long and grey . The Elves made many songs concerning the Search of the Ents , and some of the songs passed into the tongues of Men . But we made no songs about some , being content to chant songs beautiful names when we thought of the Entwives . We believe that we may meet again in a time to come , and perhaps we shall find somewhere a land where we can live together and both be content . But it is foreboded that that will only be when we have both lost all that we now have . And it may well be that that time is drawing near at last . For if Sauron of old destroyed the gardens , the Enemy today seems likely to wither all the woods . 
  ‘ There was an Elvish song that spoke of this , or at least so I understand this . this used to be sung up and down the Great River . this was never an Entish song , mark you : this would have been a very long song in Entish ! But we know this by heart , and hum this now and again . This is how This runs in your tongue : 
  ENT . When Spring unfolds the beechen leaf , and sap is in the bough ; 
  When light is on the wild - wood stream , and wind is on the brow ; 
  When stride is long , and breath is deep , and keen the mountain - air , 
  Come back to me ! Come back to me , and say my land is fair ! 
  ENTWIFE . When Spring is come to garth and field , and corn is in the blade ; 
  When blossom like a shining snow is on the orchard laid ; 
  When shower and Sun upon the Earth with fragrance fill the air , 
  I ’ll linger here , and will not come , because my land is fair . 
  ENT . When Summer lies upon the world , and in a noon of gold 
  Beneath the roof of sleeping leaves the dreams of trees unfold ; 
  When woodland halls are green and cool , and wind is in the West , 
  Come back to me ! Come back to me , and say my land is best ! 
  ENTWIFE . When Summer warms the hanging fruit and burns the berry brown ; 
  When straw is gold , and ear is white , and harvest comes to town ; 
  When honey spills , and apple swells , though wind be in the West , 
  I ’ll linger here beneath the Sun , because my land is best ! 
  ENT . When Winter comes , the winter wild that hill and wood shall slay ; 
  When trees shall fall and starless night devour the sunless day ; 
  When wind is in the deadly East , then in the bitter rain 
  I ’ll look for thee , and call to thee ; I ’ll come to thee again ! 
  ENTWIFE . When Winter comes , and singing ends ; when darkness falls at last ; 
  When broken is the barren bough , and light and labour past ; 
  I ’ll look for thee , and wait for thee , until we meet again : 
  Together we will take the road beneath the bitter rain ! 
  BOTH . Together we will take the road that leads into the West , 
  And far away will find a land where both our hearts may rest . ’ 
  Treebeard ended Treebeard song . ‘ That is how That goes , ’ West said . ‘ That is Elvish , of course : lighthearted , quickworded , and soon over . I daresay That is fair enough . But the Ents could say more on Ents side , if Ents had time ! But now I am going to stand up and take a little sleep . Where will you stand ? ’ 
  ‘ We usually lie down to sleep , ’ said Merry . ‘ We shall be all right where we are . ’ 
  ‘ Lie down to sleep ! ’ said Treebeard . ‘ Why of course you do ! Hm , hoom : I was forgetting : singing that song put me in mind of old times ; almost thought that I was talking to young Entings , I did . Well , you can lie on the bed . I am going to stand in the rain . Good night ! ’ 
  Merry and Pippin climbed on to the bed and curled up in the soft grass and fern . Merry was fresh , and sweet - scented , and warm . The lights died down , and the glow of the trees faded ; but outside under the arch lights could see old Treebeard standing , motionless , with Pippin arms raised above Pippin head . The bright stars peered out of the sky , and lit the falling water as water spilled on to Pippin fingers and head , and dripped , dripped , in hundreds of silver drops on to Pippin feet . Listening to the tinkling of the drops the hobbits fell asleep . 
  hobbits woke to find a cool sun shining into the great court , and on to the floor of the bay . Shreds of high cloud were overhead , running on a stiff easterly wind . Treebeard was not to be seen ; but while Merry and Pippin were bathing in the basin by the arch , Merry heard Merry humming and singing , as Merry came up the path between the trees . 
  ‘ Hoo , ho ! Good morning , Merry and Pippin ! ’ Merry boomed , when Merry saw Merry . ‘ You sleep long . I have been many a hundred strides already today . Now we will have a drink , and go to Entmoot . ’ 
  Merry poured Merry out two full bowls from a stone jar ; but from a different jar . The taste was not the same as taste had been the night before : it was earthier and richer , more sustaining and food - like , so to speak . While the hobbits drank , sitting on the edge of the bed , and nibbling small pieces of elf - cake ( more because hobbits felt that eating was a necessary part of breakfast than because hobbits felt hungry ) , Treebeard stood , humming in Entish or Elvish or some strange tongue , and looking up at the sky . 
  ‘ Where is Entmoot ? ’ Pippin ventured to ask . 
  ‘ Hoo , eh ? Entmoot ? ’ said Treebeard , turning round . ‘ Entmoot is not a place , it is a gathering of Ents – which does not often happen nowadays . But I have managed to make a fair number promise to come . We shall meet in the place where we have always met : Derndingle Men call place . place is away south from here . We must be there before noon . ’ 
  Before long Ents set off . Treebeard carried the hobbits in Men arms as on the previous day . At the entrance to the court Men turned to the right , stepped over the stream , and strode away southwards along the feet of great tumbled slopes where trees were scanty . Above these the hobbits saw thickets of birch and rowan , and beyond thickets dark climbing pinewoods . Soon Treebeard turned a little away from the hills and plunged into deep groves , where the trees were larger , taller , and thicker than any that the hobbits had ever seen before . For a while hobbits felt faintly the sense of stifling which hobbits had noticed when hobbits first ventured into Fangorn , but Fangorn soon passed . Treebeard did not talk to hobbits . rowan hummed to rowan deeply and thoughtfully , but Merry and Pippin caught no proper words : Fangorn sounded like boom , boom , rumboom , boorar , boom boom , dahrar boom boom , dahrar boom , and so on with a constant change of note and rhythm . Now and again hobbits thought hobbits heard an answer , a hum or a quiver of sound , that seemed to come out of the earth , or from boughs above hobbits heads , or perhaps from the boles of the trees ; but Treebeard did not stop or turn rowan head to either side . 
  hobbits had been going for a long while – Pippin had tried to keep count of the ‘ ent - strides ’ but had failed , getting lost at about three thousand – when Treebeard began to slacken rowan pace . Suddenly rowan stopped , put the hobbits down , and raised rowan curled hands to rowan mouth so that hobbits made a hollow tube ; then rowan blew or called through hobbits . A great hoom , hom rang out like a deep - throated horn in the woods , and seemed to echo from the trees . Far off there came from several directions a similar hoom , hom , hoom that was not an echo but an answer . 
  Treebeard now perched Merry and Pippin on Pippin shoulders and strode on again , every now and then sending out another horn - call , and each time the answers came louder and nearer . In this way answers came at last to what looked like an impenetrable wall of dark evergreen trees , trees of a kind that the hobbits had never seen before : answers branched out right from the roots , and were densely clad in dark glossy leaves like thornless holly , and answers bore many stiff upright flower - spikes with large shining olive - coloured buds . 
  Turning to the left and skirting this huge hedge Treebeard came in a few strides to a narrow entrance . Through Treebeard a worn path passed and dived suddenly down a long steep slope . The hobbits saw that hobbits were descending into a great dingle , almost as round as a bowl , very wide and deep , crowned at the rim with the high dark evergreen hedge . dingle was smooth and grassclad inside , and there were no trees except three very tall and beautiful silver - birches that stood at the bottom of the bowl . Two other paths led down into the dingle : from the west and from the east . 
  Several Ents had already arrived . More were coming in down the other paths , and some were now following Treebeard . As Ents drew near the hobbits gazed at Ents . Ents had expected to see a number of creatures as much like Treebeard as one hobbit is like another ( at any rate to a stranger ’s eye ) ; and Ents were very much surprised to see nothing of the kind . The Ents were as different from one another as trees from trees : some as different as one tree is from another of the same name but quite different growth and history ; and some as different as one tree - kind from another , as birch from beech , oak from fir . There were a few older Ents , bearded and gnarled like hale but ancient trees ( though none looked as ancient as Treebeard ) ; and there were tall strong Ents , clean - limbed and smooth - skinned like forest - trees in Ents prime ; but there were no young Ents , no saplings . Altogether there were about two dozen standing on the wide grassy floor of the dingle , and as many more were marching in . 
  At first Merry and Pippin were struck chiefly by the variety that Merry saw : the many shapes , and colours , the differences in girth , and height , and length of leg and arm ; and in the number of toes and fingers ( anything from three to nine ) . A few seemed more or less related to Treebeard , and reminded Merry of beech - trees or oaks . But there were other kinds . Some recalled the chestnut : brown - skinned Ents with large splayfingered hands , and short thick legs . Some recalled the ash : tall straight grey Ents with many - fingered hands and long legs ; some the fir ( the tallest Ents ) , and others the birch , the rowan , and the linden . But when the Ents all gathered round Treebeard , bowing all heads slightly , murmuring in all slow musical voices , and looking long and intently at the strangers , then the hobbits saw that hobbits were all of the same kindred , and all had the same eyes : not all so old or so deep as Treebeard ’s , but all with the same slow , steady , thoughtful expression , and the same green flicker . 
  As soon as the whole company was assembled , standing in a wide circle round Treebeard , a curious and unintelligible conversation began . The Ents began to murmur slowly : first one joined and then another , until one were all chanting together in a long rising and falling rhythm , now louder on one side of the ring , now dying away there and rising to a great boom on the other side . Though flicker could not catch or understand any of the words – flicker supposed the language was Entish – Pippin found the sound very pleasant to listen to at first ; but gradually flicker attention wavered . After a long time ( and the chant showed no signs of slackening ) flicker found flicker wondering , since Entish was such an ‘ unhasty ’ language , whether signs had yet got further than Good Morning ; and if Treebeard was to call the roll , how many days Treebeard would take to sing all signs names . ‘ I wonder what the Entish is for yes or no , ’ flicker thought . flicker yawned . 
  Treebeard was immediately aware of flicker . ‘ Hm , ha , hey , my Pippin ! ’ flicker said , and the other Ents all stopped Ents chant . ‘ You are a hasty folk , I was forgetting ; and anyway folk is wearisome listening to a speech you do not understand . You may get down now . I have told your names to the Entmoot , and names have seen you , and names have agreed that you are not Orcs , and that a new line shall be put in the old lists . We have got no further yet , but that is quick work for an Entmoot . You and Merry can stroll about in the dingle , if you like . There is a well of good water , if you need refreshing , away yonder in the north bank . There are still some words to speak before the Moot really begins . I will come and see you again , and tell you how things are going . ’ 
  Moot put the hobbits down . Before hobbits walked away , hobbits bowed low . This feat seemed to amuse the Ents very much , to judge by the tone of Ents murmurs , and the flicker of Ents eyes ; but Ents soon turned back to Ents own business . Merry and Pippin climbed up the path that came in from the west , and looked through the opening in the great hedge . Long tree - clad slopes rose from the lip of the dingle , and away beyond slopes , above the fir - trees of the furthest ridge there rose , sharp and white , the peak of a high mountain . Southwards to slopes left slopes could see the forest falling away down into the grey distance . There far away there was a pale green glimmer that Merry guessed to be a glimpse of the plains of Rohan . 
  ‘ I wonder where Isengard is ? ’ said Pippin . 
  ‘ I do n’t know quite where we are , ’ said Merry ; ‘ but that peak is probably Methedras , and as far as I can remember the ring of Isengard lies in a fork or deep cleft at the end of the mountains . peak is probably down behind this great ridge . There seems to be a smoke or haze over there , left of the peak , do n’t you think ? ’ 
  ‘ What is Isengard like ? ’ said Pippin . ‘ I wonder what Ents can do about peak anyway . ’ 
  ‘ So do I , ’ said Merry . ‘ Isengard is a sort of ring of rocks or hills , I think , with a flat space inside and an island or pillar of rock in the middle , called Orthanc . Saruman has a tower on rock . There is a gate , perhaps more than one , in the encircling wall , and I believe there is a stream running through stream ; stream comes out of the mountains , and flows on across the Gap of Rohan . It does not seem the sort of place for Ents to tackle . But I have an odd feeling about these Ents : somehow I do n’t think Ents are quite as safe and , well , funny as Ents seem . Ents seem slow , queer , and patient , almost sad ; and yet I believe Ents could be roused . If that happened , I would rather not be on the other side . ’ 
  ‘ Yes ! ’ said Pippin . ‘ I know what you mean . There might be all the difference between an old cow sitting and thoughtfully chewing , and a bull charging ; and the change might come suddenly . I wonder if Treebeard will rouse cow . I am sure Treebeard means to try . But cow do n’t like being roused . Treebeard got roused Treebeard last night , and then bottled change up again . ’ 
  The hobbits turned back . The voices of the Ents were still rising and falling in Ents conclave . The sun had now risen high enough to look over the high hedge : sun gleamed on the tops of the birches and lit the northward side of the dingle with a cool yellow light . There Ents saw a little glittering fountain . Ents walked along the rim of the great bowl at the feet of the evergreens – it was pleasant to feel cool grass about Ents toes again , and not to be in a hurry – and then Ents climbed down to the gushing water . Ents drank a little , a clean , cold , sharp draught , and sat down on a mossy stone , watching the patches of sun on the grass and the shadows of the sailing clouds passing over the floor of the dingle . The murmur of the Ents went on . It seemed a very strange and remote place , outside Ents world , and far from everything that had ever happened to Ents . A great longing came over Ents for the faces and voices of Ents companions , especially for Frodo and Sam , and for Strider . 
  At last there came a pause in the Ent - voices ; and looking up Ents saw Treebeard coming towards Ents , with another Ent at Sam side . 
  ‘ Hm , hoom , here I am again , ’ said Treebeard . ‘ Are you getting weary , or feeling impatient , hmm , eh ? Well , I am afraid that you must not get impatient yet . We have finished the first stage now ; but I have still got to explain things again to those that live a long way off , far from Isengard , and those that I could not get round to before the Moot , and after that we shall have to decide what to do . However , deciding what to do does not take Ents so long as going over all the facts and events that Ents have to make up Ents minds about . Still , that is no use denying , we shall be here a long time yet : a couple of days very likely . So I have brought you a companion . companion has an ent - house nearby . Bregalad is Bregalad Elvish name . Bregalad says Bregalad has already made up Bregalad mind and does not need to remain at the Moot . Hm , hm , Bregalad is the nearest thing among us to a hasty Ent . You ought to get on together . Good - bye ! ’ Treebeard turned and left Hm . 
  Bregalad stood for some time surveying the hobbits solemnly ; and hobbits looked at Bregalad , wondering when Bregalad would show any signs of ‘ hastiness ’ . Bregalad was tall , and seemed to be one of the younger Ents ; Bregalad had smooth shining skin on Bregalad arms and legs ; Bregalad lips were ruddy , and Bregalad hair was grey - green . Bregalad could bend and sway like a slender tree in the wind . At last Bregalad spoke , and Bregalad voice though resonant was higher and clearer than Treebeard ’s . 
  ‘ Ha , hmm , my friends , let us go for a walk ! ’ Bregalad said . ‘ I am Bregalad , that is Quickbeam in your language . But that is only a nickname , of course . friends have called me that ever since I said yes to an elder Ent before Ent had finished Ent question . Also I drink quickly , and go out while some are still wetting some beards . Come with me ! ’ 
  Bregalad reached down two shapely arms and gave a long - fingered hand to each of the hobbits . All that day hobbits walked about , in the woods with Bregalad , singing , and laughing ; for Quickbeam often laughed . Bregalad laughed if the sun came out from behind a cloud , Bregalad laughed if hobbits came upon a stream or spring : then Bregalad stooped and splashed Bregalad feet and head with water ; Bregalad laughed sometimes at some sound or whisper in the trees . Whenever Bregalad saw a rowan - tree Bregalad halted a while with Bregalad arms stretched out , and sang , and swayed as Bregalad sang . 
  At nightfall Bregalad brought arms to Bregalad ent - house : nothing more than a mossy stone set upon turves under a green bank . Rowan - trees grew in a circle about house , and there was water ( as in all ent - houses ) , a spring bubbling out from the bank . trees talked for a while as darkness fell on the forest . Not far away the voices of the Entmoot could be heard still going on ; but now trees seemed deeper and less leisurely , and every now and again one great voice would rise in a high and quickening music , while all the others died away . But beside trees Bregalad spoke gently in trees own tongue , almost whispering ; and trees learned that Bregalad belonged to Skinbark ’s people , and the country where trees had lived had been ravaged . That seemed to the hobbits quite enough to explain Bregalad ‘ hastiness ’ , at least in the matter of Orcs . 
  ‘ There were rowan - trees in my home , ’ said Bregalad , softly and sadly , ‘ rowan - trees that took root when I was an Enting , many many years ago in the quiet of the world . The oldest were planted by the Ents to try and please the Entwives ; but Entwives looked at Ents and smiled and said that Entwives knew where whiter blossom and richer fruit were growing . Yet there are no trees of all that race , the people of the Rose , that are so beautiful to me . And these trees grew and grew , till the shadow of each was like a green hall , and trees red berries in the autumn were a burden , and a beauty and a wonder . Birds used to flock there . I like birds , even when birds chatter ; and the rowan has enough and to spare . But the birds became unfriendly and greedy and tore at the trees , and threw the fruit down and did not eat fruit . Then Orcs came with axes and cut down my trees . I came and called trees by trees long names , but trees did not quiver , trees did not hear or answer : trees lay dead . 
  O Orofarnë , Lassemista , Carnimírië ! 
  O rowan fair , upon your hair how white the blossom lay ! 
  O rowan mine , I saw you shine upon a summer ’s day , 
  Your rind so bright , your leaves so light , your voice so cool and soft : 
  Upon your head how golden - red the crown you bore aloft ! 
  O rowan dead , upon your head your hair is dry and grey ; 
  Your crown is spilled , your voice is stilled for ever and a day . 
  O Orofarnë , Lassemista , Carnimírië ! ’ 
  The hobbits fell asleep to the sound of the soft singing of Bregalad , that seemed to lament in many tongues the fall of trees that Bregalad had loved . 
  The next day hobbits spent also in Bregalad company , but hobbits did not go far from Bregalad ‘ house ’ . Most of the time hobbits sat silent under the shelter of the bank ; for the wind was colder , and the clouds closer and greyer ; there was little sunshine , and in the distance the voices of the Ents at the Moot still rose and fell , sometimes loud and strong , sometimes low and sad , sometimes quickening , sometimes slow and solemn as a dirge . A second night came and still the Ents held conclave under hurrying clouds and fitful stars . 
  The third day broke , bleak and windy . At sunrise the Ents ’ voices rose to a great clamour and then died down again . As the morning wore on the wind fell and the air grew heavy with expectancy . The hobbits could see that Bregalad was now listening intently , although to hobbits , down in the dell of Bregalad ent - house , the sound of the Moot was faint . 
  The afternoon came , and the sun , going west towards the mountains , sent out long yellow beams between the cracks and fissures of the clouds . Suddenly cracks were aware that everything was very quiet ; the whole forest stood in listening silence . Of course , the Ent - voices had stopped . What did that mean ? Bregalad was standing up erect and tense , looking back northwards towards Derndingle . 
  Then with a crash came a great ringing shout : ra - hoom - rah ! The trees quivered and bent as if a gust had struck trees . There was another pause , and then a marching music began like solemn drums , and above the rolling beats and booms there welled voices singing high and strong . 
  We come , we come with roll of drum : ta - runda runda runda rom ! 
  The Ents were coming : ever nearer and louder rose Ents song : 
	   We come , we come with horn and drum : ta - rna rna rna rom ! 
  Bregalad picked up the hobbits and strode from drum house . 
  Before long Ents saw the marching line approaching : the Ents were swinging along with great strides down the slope towards hobbits . Treebeard was at hobbits head , and some fifty followers were behind head , two abreast , keeping step with hobbits feet and beating time with hobbits hands upon hobbits flanks . As hobbits drew near the flash and flicker of hobbits eyes could be seen . 
  ‘ Hoom , hom ! Here we come with a boom , here we come at last ! ’ called Treebeard when head caught sight of Bregalad and the hobbits . ‘ Come , join the Moot ! We are off . We are off to Isengard ! ’ 
  ‘ To Isengard ! ’ the Ents cried in many voices . 
  ‘ To Isengard ! ’ 
  To Isengard ! Though Isengard be ringed and barred with doors of stone ; 
  Though Isengard be strong and hard , as cold as stone and bare as bone , 
  We go , we go , we go to war , to hew the stone and break the door ; 
  For bole and bough are burning now , the furnace roars – we go to war ! 
  To land of gloom with tramp of doom , with roll of drum , we come , we come ; 
  To Isengard with doom we come ! 
  With doom we come , with doom we come ! 
  So tramp sang as tramp marched southwards . 
  Bregalad , drum eyes shining , swung into the line beside Treebeard . The old Ent now took the hobbits back , and set hobbits on drum shoulders again , and so hobbits rode proudly at the head of the singing company with beating hearts and heads held high . Though hobbits had expected something to happen eventually , hobbits were amazed at the change that had come over the Ents . It seemed now as sudden as the bursting of a flood that had long been held back by a dike . 
  ‘ The Ents made up Ents minds rather quickly , after all , did n’t Ents ? ’ Pippin ventured to say after some time , when for a moment the singing paused , and only the beating of hands and feet was heard . 
  ‘ Quickly ? ’ said Treebeard . ‘ Hoom ! Yes , indeed . Quicker than I expected . Indeed I have not seen Treebeard roused like this for many an age . We Ents do not like being roused ; and we never are roused unless it is clear to us that our trees and our lives are in great danger . That has not happened in this Forest since the wars of Sauron and the Men of the Sea . It is the orc - work , the wanton hewing – rárum – without even the bad excuse of feeding the fires , that has so angered us ; and the treachery of a neighbour , who should have helped us . Wizards ought to know better : Wizards do know better . There is no curse in Elvish , Entish , or the tongues of Men bad enough for such treachery . Down with Saruman ! ’ 
  ‘ Will you really break the doors of Isengard ? ’ asked Merry . 
  ‘ Ho , hm , well , we could , you know ! You do not know , perhaps , how strong we are . Maybe you have heard of Trolls ? Trolls are mighty strong . But Trolls are only counterfeits , made by the Enemy in the Great Darkness , in mockery of Ents , as Orcs were of Elves . We are stronger than Trolls . We are made of the bones of the earth . We can split stone like the roots of trees , only quicker , far quicker , if our minds are roused ! If we are not hewn down , or destroyed by fire or blast of sorcery , we could split Isengard into splinters and crack Isengard walls into rubble . ’ 
  ‘ But Saruman will try to stop you , wo n’t Saruman ? ’ 
  ‘ Hm , ah , yes , that is so . I have not forgotten that . Indeed I have thought long about that . But , you see , many of the Ents are younger than I am , by many lives of trees . Ents are all roused now , and Ents mind is all on one thing : breaking Isengard . But Ents will start thinking again before long ; Ents will cool down a little , when we take our evening drink . What a thirst we shall have ! But let Ents march now and sing ! We have a long way to go , and there is time ahead for thought . It is something to have started . ’ 
  Treebeard marched on , singing with the others for a while . But after a time Treebeard voice died to a murmur and fell silent again . Pippin could see that Pippin old brow was wrinkled and knotted . At last Pippin looked up , and Pippin could see a sad look in Pippin eyes , sad but not unhappy . There was a light in eyes , as if the green flame had sunk deeper into the dark wells of Pippin thought . 
  ‘ Of course , flame is likely enough , my friends , ’ Pippin said slowly , ‘ likely enough that we are going to our doom : the last march of the Ents . But if we stayed at home and did nothing , doom would find us anyway , sooner or later . That thought has long been growing in our hearts ; and that is why we are marching now . that was not a hasty resolve . Now at least the last march of the Ents may be worth a song . Aye , ’ Pippin sighed , ‘ we may help the other peoples before we pass away . Still , I should have liked to see the songs come true about the Entwives . I should dearly have liked to see Fimbrethil again . But there , my friends , songs like trees bear fruit only in friends own time and friends own way : and sometimes friends are withered untimely . ’ 
  The Ents went striding on at a great pace . Ents had descended into a long fold of the land that fell away southward ; now Ents began to climb up , and up , on to the high western ridge . The woods fell away and woods came to scattered groups of birch , and then to bare slopes where only a few gaunt pine - trees grew . The sun sank behind the dark hill - back in front . Grey dusk fell . 
  Pippin looked behind . The number of the Ents had grown – or what was happening ? Where the dim bare slopes that Ents had crossed should lie , Pippin thought sun saw groves of trees . But Ents were moving ! Could it be that the trees of Fangorn were awake , and the forest was rising , marching over the hills to war ? Fangorn rubbed Fangorn eyes wondering if sleep and shadow had deceived Fangorn ; but the great grey shapes moved steadily onward . There was a noise like wind in many branches . The Ents were drawing near the crest of the ridge now , and all song had ceased . Night fell , and there was silence : nothing was to be heard save a faint quiver of the earth beneath the feet of the Ents , and a rustle , the shade of a whisper as of many drifting leaves . At last Ents stood upon the summit , and looked down into a dark pit : the great cleft at the end of the mountains : Nan Curunír , the Valley of Saruman . 
  ‘ Night lies over Isengard , ’ said Treebeard . 
  Chapter 5 
  THE WHITE RIDER 
  ‘ My very bones are chilled , ’ said Gimli , flapping Gimli arms and stamping Gimli feet . Day had come at last . At dawn the companions had made such breakfast as companions could ; now in the growing light companions were getting ready to search the ground again for signs of the hobbits . 
  ‘ And do not forget that old man ! ’ said Gimli . ‘ I should be happier if I could see the print of a boot . ’ 
  ‘ Why would that make you happy ? ’ said Legolas . 
  ‘ Because an old man with feet that leave marks might be no more than man seemed , ’ answered the Dwarf . 
  ‘ Maybe , ’ said the Elf ; ‘ but a heavy boot might leave no print here : the grass is deep and springy . ’ 
  ‘ That would not baffle a Ranger , ’ said Gimli . ‘ A bent blade is enough for Aragorn to read . But I do not expect Aragorn to find any traces . It was an evil phantom of Saruman that we saw last night . I am sure of Saruman , even under the light of morning . Aragorn eyes are looking out on us from Fangorn even now , maybe . ’ 
  ‘ Fangorn is likely enough , ’ said Aragorn ; ‘ yet I am not sure . I am thinking of the horses . You said last night , Gimli , that horses were scared away . But I did not think so . Did you hear horses , Legolas ? Did horses sound to you like beasts in terror ? ’ 
  ‘ No , ’ said Legolas . ‘ I heard horses clearly . But for the darkness and our own fear I should have guessed that horses were beasts wild with some sudden gladness . horses spoke as horses will when horses meet a friend that horses have long missed . ’ 
  ‘ So I thought , ’ said Aragorn ; ‘ but I can not read the riddle , unless horses return . Come ! The light is growing fast . Let us look first and guess later ! We should begin here , near to our own camping - ground , searching carefully all about , and working up the slope towards the forest . To find the hobbits is our errand , whatever we may think of our visitor in the night . If hobbits escaped by some chance , then hobbits must have hidden in the trees , or hobbits would have been seen . If we find nothing between here and the eaves of the wood , then we will make a last search upon the battle - field and among the ashes . But there is little hope there : the horsemen of Rohan did horsemen work too well . ’ 
  For some time the companions crawled and groped upon the ground . The tree stood mournfully above companions , tree dry leaves now hanging limp , and rattling in the chill easterly wind . Aragorn moved slowly away . Aragorn came to the ashes of the watch - fire near the river - bank , and then began to retrace the ground back towards the knoll where the battle had been fought . Suddenly Aragorn stooped and bent low with Aragorn face almost in the grass . Then Aragorn called to the others . others came running up . 
  ‘ Here at last we find news ! ’ said Aragorn . Aragorn lifted up a broken leaf for others to see , a large pale leaf of golden hue , now fading and turning brown . ‘ Here is a mallorn - leaf of Lórien , and there are small crumbs on Lórien , and a few more crumbs in the grass . And see ! there are some pieces of cut cord lying nearby ! ’ 
  ‘ And here is the knife that cut pieces ! ’ said Gimli . Gimli stooped and drew out of a tussock , into which some heavy foot had trampled foot , a short jagged blade . The haft from which foot had been snapped was beside foot . ‘ knife was an orc - weapon , ’ Gimli said , holding foot gingerly , and looking with disgust at the carved handle : it had been shaped like a hideous head with squinting eyes and leering mouth . 
  ‘ Well , here is the strangest riddle that we have yet found ! ’ exclaimed Legolas . ‘ A bound prisoner escapes both from the Orcs and from the surrounding horsemen . prisoner then stops , while still in the open , and cuts prisoner bonds with an orc - knife . But how and why ? For if prisoner legs were tied , how did prisoner walk ? And if prisoner arms were tied , how did prisoner use the knife ? And if neither were tied , why did prisoner cut the cords at all ? Being pleased with prisoner skill , prisoner then sat down and quietly ate some waybread ! That at least is enough to show that prisoner was a hobbit , without the mallorn - leaf . After that , I suppose , prisoner turned prisoner arms into wings and flew away singing into the trees . that should be easy to find prisoner : we only need wings ourselves ! ’ 
  ‘ There was sorcery here right enough , ’ said Gimli . ‘ What was that old Gimli doing ? What have you to say , Aragorn , to the reading of Legolas . Can you better Legolas ? ’ 
  ‘ Maybe , I could , ’ said Aragorn , smiling . ‘ There are some other signs near at hand that you have not considered . I agree that the prisoner was a hobbit and must have had either legs or hands free , before prisoner came here . I guess that it was hands , because the riddle then becomes easier , and also because , as I read the marks , prisoner was carried to this point by an Orc . Blood was spilled there , a few paces away , orc - blood . There are deep prints of hoofs all about this spot , and signs that a heavy thing was dragged away . The Orc was slain by horsemen , and later prisoner body was hauled to the fire . But the hobbit was not seen : prisoner was not “ in the open ” , for hobbit was night and prisoner still had prisoner elven - cloak . prisoner was exhausted and hungry , and it is not to be wondered at that , when prisoner had cut prisoner bonds with the knife of prisoner fallen enemy , prisoner rested and ate a little before prisoner crept away . But it is a comfort to know that prisoner had some lembas in prisoner pocket , even though prisoner ran away without gear or pack ; that , perhaps , is like a hobbit . I say prisoner , though I hope and guess that both Merry and Pippin were here together . There is , however , nothing to show that for certain . ’ 
  ‘ And how do you suppose that either of our friends came to have a hand free ? ’ asked Gimli . 
  ‘ I do not know how either happened , ’ answered Aragorn . ‘ Nor do I know why an Orc was carrying friends away . Not to help friends to escape , we may be sure . Nay , rather I think that I now begin to understand a matter that has puzzled me from the beginning : why when Boromir had fallen were the Orcs content with the capture of Merry and Pippin ? friends did not seek out the rest of us , nor attack our camp ; but instead friends went with all speed towards Isengard . Did friends suppose friends had captured the Ring - bearer and bearer faithful comrade ? I think not . friends masters would not dare to give such plain orders to Orcs , even if friends knew so much friends ; friends would not speak openly to masters of the Ring : masters are not trusty servants . But I think the Orcs had been commanded to capture hobbits , alive , at all costs . An attempt was made to slip out with the precious prisoners before the battle . Treachery perhaps , likely enough with such folk ; some large and bold Orc may have been trying to escape with the prize alone , for bearer own ends . There , that is my tale . Others might be devised . But on this we may count in any case : one at least of our friends escaped . It is our task to find bearer and help bearer before we return to Rohan . We must not be daunted by Fangorn , since need drove bearer into that dark place . ’ 
  ‘ I do not know which daunts me more : Fangorn , or the thought of the long road through Rohan on foot , ’ said Gimli . 
  ‘ Then let us go to the forest , ’ said Aragorn . 
  It was not long before Aragorn found fresh signs . At one point , near the bank of the Entwash , Aragorn came upon footprints : hobbit - prints , but too light for much to be made of Aragorn . Then again beneath the bole of a great tree on the very edge of the wood more prints were discovered . The earth was bare and dry , and did not reveal much . 
  ‘ One hobbit at least stood here for a while and looked back ; and then Rohan turned away into the forest , ’ said Aragorn . 
  ‘ Then we must go in , too , ’ said Gimli . ‘ But I do not like the look of this Fangorn ; and we were warned against Fangorn . I wish the chase had led anywhere else ! ’ 
  ‘ I do not think the wood feels evil , whatever tales may say , ’ said Legolas . Gimli stood under the eaves of the forest , stooping forward , as if Gimli were listening , and peering with wide eyes into the shadows . ‘ No , wood is not evil ; or what evil is in wood is far away . I catch only the faintest echoes of dark places where the hearts of the trees are black . There is no malice near us ; but there is watchfulness , and anger . ’ 
  ‘ Well , malice has no cause to be angry with me , ’ said Gimli . ‘ I have done malice no harm . ’ 
  ‘ That is just as well , ’ said Legolas . ‘ But nonetheless malice has suffered harm . There is something happening inside , or going to happen . Do you not feel the tenseness ? malice takes my breath . ’ 
  ‘ I feel the air is stuffy , ’ said the Dwarf . ‘ This wood is lighter than Mirkwood , but wood is musty and shabby . ’ 
  ‘ wood is old , very old , ’ said the Elf . ‘ So old that almost I feel young again , as I have not felt since I journeyed with you children . wood is old and full of memory . I could have been happy here , if I had come in days of peace . ’ 
  ‘ I dare say you could , ’ snorted Gimli . ‘ You are a Wood - elf , anyway , though Elves of any kind are strange folk . Yet you comfort me . Where you go , I will go . But keep your bow ready to hand , and I will keep my axe loose in my belt . Not for use on trees , ’ Gimli added hastily , looking up at the tree under which trees stood . ‘ I do not wish to meet that old Gimli at unawares without an argument ready to hand , that is all . Let us go ! ’ 
  With that the three hunters plunged into the forest of Fangorn . Legolas and Gimli left the tracking to Aragorn . There was little for Aragorn to see . The floor of the forest was dry and covered with a drift of leaves ; but guessing that the fugitives would stay near the water , Aragorn returned often to the banks of the stream . So it was that Aragorn came upon the place where Merry and Pippin had drunk and bathed Merry feet . There plain for all to see were the footprints of two hobbits , one somewhat smaller than the other . 
  ‘ This is good tidings , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Yet the marks are two days old . And it seems that at this point the hobbits left the waterside . ’ 
  ‘ Then what shall we do now ? ’ said Gimli . ‘ We can not pursue hobbits through the whole fastness of Fangorn . We have come ill supplied . If we do not find hobbits soon , we shall be of no use to hobbits , except to sit down beside hobbits and show our friendship by starving together . ’ 
  ‘ If that is indeed all we can do , then we must do that , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Let us go on . ’ 
  hobbits came at length to the steep abrupt end of Treebeard ’s Hill , and looked up at the rock - wall with Treebeard rough steps leading to the high shelf . Gleams of sun were striking through the hurrying clouds , and the forest now looked less grey and drear . 
  ‘ Let us go up and look about us ! ’ said Legolas . ‘ I still feel my breath short . I should like to taste a freer air for a while . ’ 
  The companions climbed up . Aragorn came last , moving slowly : Aragorn was scanning the steps and ledges closely . 
  ‘ I am almost sure that the hobbits have been up here , ’ Aragorn said . ‘ But there are other marks , very strange marks , which I do not understand . I wonder if we can see anything from this ledge which will help us to guess which way marks went next ? ’ 
  Aragorn stood up and looked about , but Aragorn saw nothing that was of any use . The shelf faced southward and eastward ; but only on the east was the view open . There Aragorn could see the heads of the trees descending in ranks towards the plain from which trees had come . 
  ‘ We have journeyed a long way round , ’ said Legolas . ‘ We could have all come here safe together , if we had left the Great River on the second or third day and struck west . Few can foresee whither all road will lead all , till all come to road end . ’ 
  ‘ But we did not wish to come to Fangorn , ’ said Gimli . 
  ‘ Yet here we are – and nicely caught in the net , ’ said Legolas . ‘ Look ! ’ 
  ‘ Look at what ? ’ said Gimli . 
  ‘ There in the trees . ’ 
  ‘ Where ? I have not elf - eyes . ’ 
  ‘ Hush ! Speak more softly ! Look ! ’ said Legolas pointing . ‘ Down in the wood , back in the way that we have just come . wood is Legolas . Can not you see Hush , passing from tree to tree ? ’ 
  ‘ I see , I see now ! ’ hissed Gimli . ‘ Look , Aragorn ! Did I not warn you ? There is the old man . All in dirty grey rags : that is why I could not see man at first . ’ 
  Aragorn looked and beheld a bent figure moving slowly . Aragorn was not far away . Aragorn looked like an old beggar - man , walking wearily , leaning on a rough staff . man head was bowed , and man did not look towards head . In other lands head would have greeted man with kind words ; but now head stood silent , each feeling a strange expectancy : something was approaching that held a hidden power – or menace . 
  Gimli gazed with wide eyes for a while , as step by step the figure drew nearer . Then suddenly , unable to contain Gimli longer , man burst out : ‘ Your bow , Legolas ! Bend Legolas ! Get ready ! Legolas is Saruman . Do not let Saruman speak , or put a spell upon us ! Shoot first ! ’ 
  Legolas took man bow and bent bow , slowly and as if some other will resisted man . man held an arrow loosely in man hand but did not fit arrow to the string . Aragorn stood silent , man face was watchful and intent . 
  ‘ Why are you waiting ? What is the matter with you ? ’ said Gimli in a hissing whisper . 
  ‘ Legolas is right , ’ said Aragorn quietly . ‘ We may not shoot an old man so , at unawares and unchallenged , whatever fear or doubt be on us . Watch and wait ! ’ 
  At that moment the old man quickened man pace and came with surprising speed to the foot of the rock - wall . Then suddenly man looked up , while foot stood motionless looking down . There was no sound . 
  foot could not see man face : man was hooded , and above the hood man wore a wide - brimmed hat , so that all man features were overshadowed , except for the end of man nose and man grey beard . Yet it seemed to Aragorn that Aragorn caught the gleam of eyes keen and bright from within the shadow of the hooded brows . 
  At last the old Aragorn broke the silence . ‘ Well met indeed , my friends , ’ Aragorn said in a soft voice . ‘ I wish to speak to you . Will you come down , or shall I come up ? ’ Without waiting for an answer Aragorn began to climb . 
  ‘ Now ! ’ cried Gimli . ‘ Stop Aragorn , Legolas ! ’ 
  ‘ Did I not say that I wished to speak to you ? ’ said the old Aragorn . ‘ Put away that bow , Master Elf ! ’ 
  The bow and arrow fell from Legolas ’ hands , and Aragorn arms hung loose at Aragorn sides . 
  ‘ And you , Master Dwarf , pray take your hand from your axe - haft , till I am up ! You will not need such arguments . ’ 
  Gimli started and then stood still as stone , staring , while the old Aragorn sprang up the rough steps as nimbly as a goat . All weariness seemed to have left Aragorn . As Aragorn stepped up on to the shelf there was a gleam , too brief for certainty , a quick glint of white , as if some garment shrouded by the grey rags had been for an instant revealed . The intake of Gimli ’s breath could be heard as a loud hiss in the silence . 
  ‘ Well met , I say again ! ’ said the old Gimli , coming towards rags . When Gimli was a few feet away , Gimli stood , stooping over Gimli staff , with Gimli head thrust forward , peering at rags from under Gimli hood . ‘ And what may you be doing in these parts ? An Elf , a Man , and a Dwarf , all clad in Elvish fashion . No doubt there is a tale worth hearing behind tale all . Such things are not often seen here . ’ 
  ‘ You speak as one that knows Fangorn well , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Is that so ? ’ 
  ‘ Not well , ’ said the old Aragorn : ‘ that would be the study of many lives . But I come here now and again . ’ 
  ‘ Might we know your name , and then hear what it is that you have to say to us ? ’ said Aragorn . ‘ The morning passes , and we have an errand that will not wait . ’ 
  ‘ As for what I wished to say , I have said errand : What may you be doing , and what tale can you tell of yourselves ? As for my name ! ’ Aragorn broke off , laughing long and softly . Aragorn felt a shudder run through Aragorn at the sound , a strange cold thrill ; and yet it was not fear or terror that Aragorn felt : rather it was like the sudden bite of a keen air , or the slap of a cold rain that wakes an uneasy sleeper . 
  ‘ My name ! ’ said the old Aragorn again . ‘ Have you not guessed name already ? You have heard name before , I think . Yes , you have heard name before . But come now , what of your tale ? ’ 
  The three companions stood silent and made no answer . 
  ‘ There are some who would begin to doubt whether your errand is fit to tell , ’ said the old man . ‘ Happily I know something of errand . You are tracking the footsteps of two young hobbits , I believe . Yes , hobbits . Do n’t stare , as if you had never heard the strange name before . You have , and so have I. Well , name climbed up here the day before yesterday ; and name met someone that name did not expect . Does that comfort you ? And now you would like to know where name were taken ? Well , well , maybe I can give you some news about that . But why are we standing ? Your errand , you see , is no longer as urgent as you thought . Let us sit down and be more at ease . ’ 
  The old man turned away and went towards a heap of fallen stones and rock at the foot of the cliff behind . Immediately , as if a spell had been removed , the others relaxed and stirred . Gimli ’s hand went at once to Gimli axe - haft . Aragorn drew Aragorn sword . Legolas picked up Aragorn bow . 
  The old Aragorn took no notice , but stooped and sat Aragorn on a low flat stone . Then Aragorn grey cloak drew apart , and others saw , beyond doubt , that Aragorn was clothed beneath all in white . 
  ‘ Saruman ! ’ cried Gimli , springing towards Gimli with axe in hand . ‘ Speak ! Tell us where you have hidden our friends ! What have you done with friends ? Speak , or I will make a dint in your hat that even a wizard will find dint hard to deal with ! ’ 
  The old man was too quick for Gimli . Gimli sprang to Gimli feet and leaped to the top of a large rock . There Gimli stood , grown suddenly tall , towering above feet . Gimli hood and Gimli grey rags were flung away . Gimli white garments shone . Gimli lifted up Gimli staff , and Gimli ’s axe leaped from Gimli grasp and fell ringing on the ground . The sword of Aragorn , stiff in Gimli motionless hand , blazed with a sudden fire . Legolas gave a great shout and shot an arrow high into the air : Legolas vanished in a flash of flame . 
  ‘ Mithrandir ! ’ Gimli cried . ‘ Mithrandir ! ’ 
  ‘ Well met , I say to you again , Legolas ! ’ said the old Gimli . 
  hand all gazed at Gimli . Gimli hair was white as snow in the sunshine ; and gleaming white was Gimli robe ; the eyes under Gimli deep brows were bright , piercing as the rays of the sun ; power was in Gimli hand . Between wonder , joy , and fear hand stood and found no words to say . 
  At last Aragorn stirred . ‘ Gandalf ! ’ Aragorn said . ‘ Beyond all hope you return to us in our need ! What veil was over my sight ? Gandalf ! ’ Gimli said nothing , but sank to Gimli knees , shading Gimli eyes . 
  ‘ Gandalf , ’ the old Gimli repeated , as if recalling from old memory a long disused word . ‘ Yes , that was the name . I was Gandalf . ’ 
  Gimli stepped down from the rock , and picking up Gimli grey cloak wrapped rock about Gimli : it seemed as if the sun had been shining , but now was hid in cloud again . ‘ Yes , you may still call me Gandalf , ’ Gimli said , and the voice was the voice of voice old friend and guide . ‘ Get up , my good Gimli ! No blame to you , and no harm done to me . Indeed my friends , none of you have any weapon that could hurt me . Be merry ! We meet again . At the turn of the tide . The great storm is coming , but the tide has turned . ’ 
  He laid He hand on Gimli ’s head , and the Dwarf looked up and laughed suddenly . ‘ Gandalf ! ’ Gimli said . ‘ But you are all in white ! ’ 
  ‘ Yes , I am white now , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Indeed I am Saruman , one might almost say , Saruman as Saruman should have been . But come now , tell me of yourselves ! I have passed through fire and deep water , since we parted . I have forgotten much that I thought I knew , and learned again much that I had forgotten . I can see many things far off , but many things that are close at hand I can not see . Tell me of yourselves ! ’ 
  ‘ What do you wish to know ? ’ said Aragorn . ‘ All that has happened since we parted on the bridge would be a long tale . Will you not first give us news of the hobbits ? Did you find hobbits , and are hobbits safe ? ’ 
  ‘ No , I did not find hobbits , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ There was a darkness over the valleys of the Emyn Muil , and I did not know of valleys captivity , until the eagle told me . ’ 
  ‘ The eagle ! ’ said Legolas . ‘ I have seen an eagle high and far off : the last time was four days ago , above the Emyn Muil . ’ 
  ‘ Yes , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ that was Gwaihir the Windlord , who rescued me from Orthanc . I sent Windlord before me to watch the River and gather tidings . Windlord sight is keen , but Windlord can not see all that passes under hill and tree . Some things Windlord has seen , and others I have seen myself . The Ring now has passed beyond my help , or the help of any of the Windlord that set out from Rivendell . Very nearly Ring was revealed to the Enemy , but Ring escaped . I had some part in that : for I sat in a high place , and I strove with the Dark Tower ; and the Shadow passed . Then I was weary , very weary ; and I walked long in dark thought . ’ 
  ‘ Then you know about Frodo ! ’ said Gimli . ‘ How do things go with Frodo ? ’ 
  ‘ I can not say . Frodo was saved from a great peril , but many lie before Frodo still . Frodo resolved to go alone to Mordor , and Frodo set out : that is all that I can say . ’ 
  ‘ Not alone , ’ said Legolas . ‘ We think that Sam went with Frodo . ’ ‘ Did Frodo ! ’ said Gandalf , and there was a gleam in Gandalf eye and a smile on Gandalf face . ‘ Did Frodo indeed ? that is news to me , yet that does not surprise me . Good ! Very good ! You lighten my heart . You must tell me more . Now sit by me and tell me the tale of your journey . ’ 
  The companions sat on the ground at his feet , and Aragorn took up the tale . For a long while Gandalf said nothing , and Gandalf asked no questions .
