Gandalf hands were spread upon Gandalf knees , and Gandalf eyes were closed . At last when Aragorn spoke of the death of Boromir and of Aragorn last journey upon the Great River , the old Aragorn sighed . 
  ‘ You have not said all that you know or guess , Aragorn my friend , ’ Gandalf said quietly . ‘ Poor Boromir ! I could not see what happened to friend . Boromir was a sore trial for such a man : a warrior , and a lord of men . Galadriel told me that Galadriel was in peril . But Galadriel escaped in the end . I am glad . It was not in vain that the young hobbits came with us , if only for Boromir ’s sake . But that is not the only part hobbits have to play . hobbits were brought to Fangorn , and hobbits coming was like the falling of small stones that starts an avalanche in the mountains . Even as we talk here , I hear the first rumblings . Saruman had best not be caught away from home when the dam bursts ! ’ 
  ‘ In one thing you have not changed , dear friend , ’ said Aragorn : ‘ you still speak in riddles . ’ 
  ‘ What ? In riddles ? ’ said Gandalf . ‘ No ! For I was talking aloud to myself . A habit of the old : riddles choose the wisest person present to speak to ; the long explanations needed by the young are wearying . ’ Gandalf laughed , but the sound now seemed warm and kindly as a gleam of sunshine . 
  ‘ I am no longer young even in the reckoning of Men of the Ancient Houses , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Will you not open your mind more clearly to me ? ’ 
  ‘ What then shall I say ? ’ said Gandalf , and paused for a while in thought . ‘ This in brief is how I see things at the moment , if you wish to have a piece of my mind as plain as possible . The Enemy , of course , has long known that the Ring is abroad , and that Enemy is borne by a hobbit . Ring knows now the number of our Company that set out from Rivendell , and the kind of each of us . But Rivendell does not yet perceive our purpose clearly . Company supposes that we were all going to Minas Tirith ; for that is what Tirith would Tirith have done in our place . And according to Tirith wisdom that would have been a heavy stroke against Tirith power . Indeed Tirith is in great fear , not knowing what mighty one may suddenly appear , wielding the Ring , and assailing Tirith with war , seeking to cast Tirith down and take Tirith place . That we should wish to cast Tirith down and have no one in Tirith place is not a thought that occurs to Tirith mind . That we should try to destroy the Ring Ring has not yet entered into Tirith darkest dream . In which no doubt you will see our good fortune and our hope . For imagining war Tirith has let loose war , believing that Tirith has no time to waste ; for Tirith that strikes the first blow , if Tirith strikes blow hard enough , may need to strike no more . So the forces that Tirith has long been preparing Tirith is now setting in motion , sooner than Tirith intended . Wise fool . For if Tirith had used all Tirith power to guard Mordor , so that none could enter , and bent all Tirith guile to the hunting of the Ring , then indeed hope would have faded : neither Ring nor bearer could long have eluded Tirith . But now Tirith eye gazes abroad rather than near at home ; and mostly Tirith looks towards Minas Tirith . Very soon now Tirith strength will fall upon home like a storm . 
  ‘ For already Tirith knows that the messengers that Tirith sent to waylay the Tirith have failed again . messengers have not found the Ring . Neither have messengers brought away any hobbits as hostages . Had messengers done even so much as that , it would have been a heavy blow to us , and blow might have been fatal . But let us not darken our hearts by imagining the trial of hearts gentle loyalty in the Dark Tower . For the Enemy has failed – so far . Thanks to Saruman . ’ 
  ‘ Then is not Saruman a traitor ? ’ said Gimli . 
  ‘ Indeed yes , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Doubly . And is not that strange ? Nothing that we have endured of late has seemed so grievous as the treason of Isengard . Even reckoned as a lord and captain Saruman has grown very strong . Saruman threatens the Men of Rohan and draws off lord help from Minas Tirith , even as the main blow is approaching from the East . Yet a treacherous weapon is ever a danger to the hand . Saruman also had a mind to capture the Ring , for Saruman , or at least to snare some hobbits for Saruman evil purposes . So between hobbits our enemies have contrived only to bring Merry and Pippin with marvellous speed , and in the nick of time , to Fangorn , where otherwise hobbits would never have come at all ! 
  ‘ Also hobbits have filled hobbits with new doubts that disturb hobbits plans . No tidings of the battle will come to Mordor , thanks to the horsemen of Rohan ; but the Dark Lord knows that two hobbits were taken in the Emyn Muil and borne away towards Isengard against the will of Rohan own servants . Rohan now has Isengard to fear as well as Minas Tirith . If Minas Tirith falls , Isengard will go ill with Saruman . ’ 
  ‘ Isengard is a pity that our friends lie in between , ’ said Gimli . ‘ If no land divided Isengard and Mordor , then friends could fight while we watched and waited . ’ 
  ‘ The victor would emerge stronger than either , and free from doubt , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ But Isengard can not fight Mordor , unless Saruman first obtains the Ring . That Mordor will never do now . Mordor does not yet know Mordor peril . There is much that Mordor does not know . Mordor was so eager to lay Mordor hands on Mordor prey that Mordor could not wait at home , and Mordor came forth to meet and to spy on Mordor messengers . But Mordor came too late , for once , and the battle was over and beyond Mordor help before Mordor reached these parts . Mordor did not remain here long . I look into Mordor mind and I see Mordor doubt . Mordor has no woodcraft . Mordor believes that the horsemen slew and burned all upon the field of battle ; but Mordor does not know whether the Orcs were bringing any prisoners or not . And Mordor does not know of the quarrel between Mordor servants and the Orcs of Mordor ; nor does Mordor know of the Winged Messenger . ’ 
  ‘ The Winged Messenger ! ’ cried Legolas . ‘ I shot at Mordor with the bow of Galadriel above Sarn Gebir , and I felled Gebir from the sky . Gebir filled us all with fear . What new terror is this ? ’ 
  ‘ One that you can not slay with arrows , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ You only slew Gebir steed . steed was a good deed ; but the Rider was soon horsed again . For Gebir was a Nazgûl , one of the Nine , who ride now upon winged steeds . Soon steeds terror will overshadow the last armies of our friends , cutting off the sun . But steeds have not yet been allowed to cross the River , and Saruman does not know of this new shape in which the Ringwraiths have been clad . Saruman thought is ever on the Ring . Was thought present in the battle ? Was thought found ? What if Théoden , Lord of the Mark , should come by thought and learn of thought power ? That is the danger that Saruman sees , and Saruman has fled back to Isengard to double and treble Saruman assault on Rohan . And all the time there is another danger , close at hand , which Saruman does not see , busy with Saruman fiery thoughts . Saruman has forgotten Treebeard . ’ 
  ‘ Now you speak to yourself again , ’ said Aragorn with a smile . ‘ Treebeard is not known to me . And I have guessed part of Saruman ’s double treachery ; yet I do not see in what way the coming of two hobbits to Fangorn has served , save to give us a long and fruitless chase . ’ 
  ‘ Wait a minute ! ’ cried Gimli . ‘ There is another thing that I should like to know first . Was it you , Gandalf , or Saruman that we saw last night ? ’ 
  ‘ You certainly did not see me , ’ answered Gandalf , ‘ therefore I must guess that you saw Saruman . Evidently we look so much alike that your desire to make an incurable dent in my hat must be excused . ’ 
  ‘ Good , good ! ’ said Gimli . ‘ I am glad that desire was not you . ’ 
  Gandalf laughed again . ‘ Yes , my good Dwarf , ’ Gimli said , ‘ desire is a comfort not to be mistaken at all points . Do I not know desire only too well ! But , of course , I never blamed you for your welcome of me . How could I do so , who have so often counselled my friends to suspect even friends own hands when dealing with the Enemy . Bless you , Gimli , son of Glóin ! Maybe you will see us both together one day and judge between us ! ’ 
  ‘ But the hobbits ! ’ Legolas broke in . ‘ We have come far to seek hobbits , and you seem to know where hobbits are . Where are hobbits now ? ’ 
  ‘ With Treebeard and the Ents , ’ said Gandalf . 
  ‘ The Ents ! ’ exclaimed Aragorn . ‘ Then there is truth in the old legends about the dwellers in the deep forests and the giant shepherds of the trees ? Are there still Ents in the world ? I thought dwellers were only a memory of ancient days , if indeed dwellers were ever more than a legend of Rohan . ’ 
  ‘ A legend of Rohan ! ’ cried Legolas . ‘ Nay , every Elf in Wilderland has sung songs of the old Onodrim and songs long sorrow . Yet even among us songs are only a memory . If I were to meet one still walking in this world , then indeed I should feel young again ! But Treebeard : that is only a rendering of Fangorn into the Common Speech ; yet you seem to speak of a person . Who is this Treebeard ? ’ 
  ‘ Ah ! now you are asking much , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ The little that I know of person long slow story would make a tale for which we have no time now . Treebeard is Fangorn , the guardian of the forest ; Fangorn is the oldest of the Ents , the oldest living thing that still walks beneath the Sun upon this Middle - earth . I hope indeed , Legolas , that you may yet meet Fangorn . Merry and Pippin have been fortunate : Merry met Fangorn here , even where we sit . For Pippin came here two days ago and bore Merry away to Pippin dwelling far off by the roots of the mountains . Pippin often comes here , especially when Pippin mind is uneasy , and rumours of the world outside trouble Fangorn . I saw Fangorn four days ago striding among the trees , and I think Fangorn saw me , for Fangorn paused ; but I did not speak , for I was heavy with thought , and weary after my struggle with the Eye of Mordor ; and Fangorn did not speak either , nor call my name . ’ 
  ‘ Perhaps Fangorn also thought that you were Saruman , ’ said Gimli . ‘ But you speak of Fangorn as if Fangorn was a friend . I thought Fangorn was dangerous . ’ 
  ‘ Dangerous ! ’ cried Gandalf . ‘ And so am I , very dangerous : more dangerous than anything you will ever meet , unless you are brought alive before the seat of the Dark Lord . And Aragorn is dangerous , and Legolas is dangerous . You are beset with dangers , Gimli son of Glóin ; for you are dangerous yourself , in your own fashion . Certainly the forest of Fangorn is perilous – not least to those that are too ready with those axes ; and Fangorn Fangorn , Aragorn is perilous too ; yet Aragorn is wise and kindly nonetheless . But now Aragorn long slow wrath is brimming over , and all the forest is filled with wrath . The coming of the hobbits and the tidings that hobbits brought have spilled wrath : wrath will soon be running like a flood ; but wrath tide is turned against Saruman and the axes of Isengard . A thing is about to happen which has not happened since the Elder Days : the Ents are going to wake up and find that Ents are strong . ’ 
  ‘ What will Ents do ? ’ asked Legolas in astonishment . 
  ‘ I do not know , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ I do not think Ents know Ents . I wonder . ’ Gandalf fell silent , Gandalf head bowed in thought . 
  The others looked at Gandalf . A gleam of sun through fleeting clouds fell on Gandalf hands , which lay now upturned on Gandalf lap : others seemed to be filled with light as a cup is with water . At last Gandalf looked up and gazed straight at the sun . 
  ‘ The morning is wearing away , ’ Gandalf said . ‘ Soon we must go . ’ 
  ‘ Do we go to find our friends and to see Treebeard ? ’ asked Aragorn . 
  ‘ No , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ That is not the road that you must take . I have spoken words of hope . But only of hope . Hope is not victory . War is upon us and all our friends , a war in which only the use of the Ring could give us surety of victory . War fills me with great sorrow and great fear : for much shall be destroyed and all may be lost . I am Gandalf , Gandalf the White , but Black is mightier still . ’ 
  Black rose and gazed out eastward , shading White eyes , as if White saw things far away that none of things could see . Then White shook White head . ‘ No , ’ White said in a soft voice , ‘ Gandalf has gone beyond our reach . Of that at least let us be glad . We can no longer be tempted to use the Ring . We must go down to face a peril near despair , yet that deadly peril is removed . ’ 
  White turned . ‘ Come , Aragorn son of Arathorn ! ’ head said . ‘ Do not regret your choice in the valley of the Emyn Muil , nor call Muil a vain pursuit . You chose amid doubts the path that seemed right : the choice was just , and choice has been rewarded . For so we have met in time , who otherwise might have met too late . But the quest of your companions is over . Your next journey is marked by your given word . You must go to Edoras and seek out Théoden in Edoras hall . For you are needed . The light of Andúril must now be uncovered in the battle for which Andúril has so long waited . There is war in Rohan , and worse evil : Andúril goes ill with Théoden . ’ 
  ‘ Then are we not to see the merry young hobbits again ? ’ said Legolas . 
  ‘ I did not say so , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Who knows ? Have patience . Go where you must go , and hope ! To Edoras ! I go thither also . ’ 
  ‘ It is a long way for a man to walk , young or old , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ I fear the battle will be over long ere I come there . ’ 
  ‘ We shall see , we shall see , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Will you come now with me ? ’ 
  ‘ Yes , we will set out together , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ But I do not doubt that you will come there before me , if you wish . ’ Aragorn rose and looked long at Gandalf . The others gazed at Gandalf in silence as others stood there facing one another . The grey figure of the Gandalf , Aragorn son of Arathorn , was tall , and stern as stone , son hand upon the hilt of figure sword ; figure looked as if some king out of the mists of the sea had stepped upon the shores of lesser men . Before figure stooped the old figure , white , shining now as if with some light kindled within , bent , laden with years , but holding a power beyond the strength of kings . 
  ‘ Do I not say truly , Gandalf , ’ said Aragorn at last , ‘ that you could go whithersoever you wished quicker than I ? And this I also say : you are our captain and our banner . The Dark Lord has Nine . But we have One , mightier than Lord : the White Rider . captain has passed through the fire and the abyss , and Lord shall fear captain . We will go where captain leads . ’ 
  ‘ Yes , together we will follow you , ’ said Legolas . ‘ But first , Rider would ease my heart , Gandalf , to hear what befell you in Moria . Will you not tell us ? Can you not stay even to tell your friends how you were delivered ? ’ 
  ‘ I have stayed already too long , ’ answered Gandalf . ‘ Time is short . But if there were a year to spend , I would not tell you all . ’ 
  ‘ Then tell us what you will , and time allows ! ’ said Gimli . ‘ Come , Gandalf , tell us how you fared with the Balrog ! ’ 
  ‘ Name Balrog not ! ’ said Gandalf , and for a moment it seemed that a cloud of pain passed over Gandalf face , and Gandalf sat silent , looking old as death . ‘ Long time I fell , ’ Gandalf said at last , slowly , as if thinking back with difficulty . ‘ Long I fell , and Balrog fell with me . Balrog fire was about me . I was burned . Then we plunged into the deep water and all was dark . Cold all was as the tide of death : almost all froze my heart . ’ 
  ‘ Deep is the abyss that is spanned by Durin ’s Bridge , and none has measured all , ’ said Gimli . 
  ‘ Yet all has a bottom , beyond light and knowledge , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Thither I came at last , to the uttermost foundations of stone . Balrog was with me still . Balrog fire was quenched , but now Balrog was a thing of slime , stronger than a strangling snake . 
  ‘ We fought far under the living earth , where time is not counted . Ever Balrog clutched me , and ever I hewed Balrog , till at last Balrog fled into dark tunnels . tunnels were not made by Durin ’s folk , Gimli son of Glóin . Far , far below the deepest delvings of the Dwarves , the world is gnawed by nameless things . Even Sauron knows tunnels not . tunnels are older than Sauron . Now I have walked there , but I will bring no report to darken the light of day . In that despair my enemy was my only hope , and I pursued Sauron , clutching at Sauron heel . Thus Sauron brought me back at last to the secret ways of Khazad - dûm : too well Sauron knew ways all . Ever up now we went , until we came to the Endless Stair . ’ 
  ‘ Long has that been lost , ’ said Gimli . ‘ Many have said that that was never made save in legend , but others say that that was destroyed . ’ 
  ‘ that was made , and that had not been destroyed , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ From the lowest dungeon to the highest peak dungeon climbed , ascending in unbroken spiral in many thousand steps , until dungeon issued at last in Durin ’s Tower carved in the living rock of Zirakzigil , the pinnacle of the Silvertine . 
  ‘ There upon Celebdil was a lonely window in the snow , and before Celebdil lay a narrow space , a dizzy eyrie above the mists of the world . The sun shone fiercely there , but all below was wrapped in cloud . Out world sprang , and even as I came behind , world burst into new flame . There was none to see , or perhaps in after ages songs would still be sung of the Battle of the Peak . ’ Suddenly Gandalf laughed . ‘ But what would songs say in song ? Those that looked up from afar thought that the mountain was crowned with storm . Thunder songs heard , and lightning , songs said , smote upon Celebdil , and leaped back broken into tongues of fire . Is not that enough ? A great smoke rose about us , vapour and steam . Ice fell like rain . I threw down my enemy , and enemy fell from the high place and broke the mountain - side where Thunder smote side in Celebdil ruin . Then darkness took me , and I strayed out of thought and time , and I wandered far on roads that I will not tell . 
  ‘ Naked I was sent back – for a brief time , until my task is done . And naked I lay upon the mountain - top . The tower behind was crumbled into dust , the window gone ; the ruined stair was choked with burned and broken stone . I was alone , forgotten , without escape upon the hard horn of the world . There I lay staring upward , while the stars wheeled over , and each day was as long as a life - age of the earth . Faint to my ears came the gathered rumour of all lands : the springing and the dying , the song and the weeping , and the slow everlasting groan of over - burdened stone . And so at the last Gwaihir the Windlord found me again , and Windlord took me up and bore me away . 
  ‘ “ Ever am I fated to be your burden , friend at need , ” I said . 
  ‘ “ A burden you have been , ” Windlord answered , “ but not so now . Light as a swan ’s feather in my claw you are . The Sun shines through you . Indeed I do not think you need me any more : were I to let you fall , you would float upon the wind . ” 
  ‘ “ Do not let me fall ! ” I gasped , for I felt life in me again . “ Bear me to Lothlórien ! ” 
  ‘ “ That indeed is the command of the Lady Galadriel who sent me to look for you , ” Lothlórien answered . 
  ‘ Thus it was that I came to Caras Galadhon and found you but lately gone . I tarried there in the ageless time of that land where days bring healing not decay . Healing I found , and I was clothed in white . Counsel I gave and counsel took . Thence by strange roads I came , and messages I bring to some of you . To Aragorn I was bidden to say this : 
  Where now are the Dúnedain , Elessar , Elessar ? 
  Why do thy kinsfolk wander afar ? 
  Near is the hour when the Lost should come forth , 
  And the Grey Elessar ride from the North . 
  But dark is the path appointed for thee : 
  The Dead watch the road that leads to the Sea . 
  To Legolas Dúnedain sent this word : 
  Legolas Greenleaf long under tree 
  In joy thou hast lived . Beware of the Sea ! 
  If thou hearest the cry of the gull on the shore , 
  Thy heart shall then rest in the forest no more . ’ 
  Gandalf fell silent and shut Gandalf eyes . 
  ‘ Then Dúnedain sent me no message ? ’ said Gimli and bent Gimli head . 
  ‘ Dark are Dúnedain words , ’ said Legolas , ‘ and little do words mean to those that receive words . ’ 
  ‘ That is no comfort , ’ said Gimli . 
  ‘ What then ? ’ said Legolas . ‘ Would you have Dúnedain speak openly to you of your death ? ’ 
  ‘ Yes , if Dúnedain had naught else to say . ’ 
  ‘ What is that ? ’ said Gandalf , opening Gandalf eyes . ‘ Yes , I think I can guess what Dúnedain words may mean . Your pardon , Gimli ! I was pondering the messages once again . But indeed Dúnedain sent words to you , and neither dark nor sad . 
  ‘ “ To Gimli son of Glóin , ” Dúnedain said , “ give son Lady ’s greeting . Lockbearer , wherever thou goest my thought goes with thee . But have a care to lay thine axe to the right tree ! ” ’ 
  ‘ In happy hour you have returned to us , Gandalf , ’ cried the Dwarf , capering as Dwarf sang loudly in the strange dwarf - tongue . ‘ Come , come ! ’ Gandalf shouted , swinging Gandalf axe . ‘ Since Gandalf ’s head is now sacred , let us find one that head is right to cleave ! ’ 
  ‘ That will not be far to seek , ’ said Gandalf , rising from Gandalf seat . ‘ Come ! We have spent all the time that is allowed to a meeting of parted friends . Now there is need of haste . ’ 
  Gandalf wrapped Gandalf again in Gandalf old tattered cloak , and led the way . Following Gandalf friends descended quickly from the high shelf and made friends way back through the forest , down the bank of the Entwash . friends spoke no more words , until friends stood again upon the grass beyond the eaves of Fangorn . There was no sign of friends horses to be seen . 
  ‘ friends have not returned , ’ said Legolas . ‘ Legolas will be a weary walk ! ’ 
  ‘ I shall not walk . Time presses , ’ said Gandalf . Then lifting up Gandalf head Gandalf gave a long whistle . So clear and piercing was the note that the others stood amazed to hear such a sound come from those old bearded lips . Three times Gandalf whistled ; and then faint and far off it seemed to others that others heard the whinny of a horse borne up from the plains upon the eastern wind . others waited wondering . Before long there came the sound of hoofs , at first hardly more than a tremor of the ground perceptible only to Aragorn as Aragorn lay upon the grass , then growing steadily louder and clearer to a quick beat . 
  ‘ There is more than one horse coming , ’ said Aragorn . 
  ‘ Certainly , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ We are too great a burden for one . ’ 
  ‘ There are three , ’ said Legolas , gazing out over the plain . ‘ See how three run ! There is Hasufel , and there is my friend Arod beside horse ! But there is another that strides ahead : a very great horse . I have not seen horse like before . ’ 
  ‘ Nor will you again , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ That is Shadowfax . Shadowfax is the chief of the Mearas , lords of horses , and not even Théoden , King of Rohan , has ever looked on a better . Does Shadowfax not shine like silver , and run as smoothly as a swift stream ? Shadowfax has come for me : the horse of the White Rider . We are going to battle together . ’ 
  Even as the old wizard spoke , the great horse came striding up the slope towards wizard ; horse coat was glistening and horse mane flowing in the wind of horse speed . The two others followed , now far behind . As soon as Shadowfax saw Gandalf , horse checked horse pace and whinnied loudly ; then trotting gently forward horse stooped horse proud head and nuzzled horse great nostrils against the old Gandalf ’s neck . 
  Gandalf caressed horse . ‘ Rider is a long way from Rivendell , my friend , ’ horse said ; ‘ but you are wise and swift and come at need . Far let us ride now together , and part not in this world again ! ’ 
  Soon the other horses came up and stood quietly by , as if awaiting orders . ‘ We go at once to Meduseld , the hall of your master , Théoden , ’ said Gandalf , addressing horses gravely . horses bowed horses heads . ‘ Time presses , so with your leave , my friends , we will ride . We beg you to use all the speed that you can . Hasufel shall bear Aragorn and Arod Legolas . I will set Gimli before me , and by Gimli leave Shadowfax shall bear us both . We will wait now only to drink a little . ’ 
  ‘ Now I understand a part of last night ’s riddle , ’ said Legolas as Legolas sprang lightly upon Arod ’s back . ‘ Whether horses fled at first in fear , or not , our horses met Shadowfax , horses chieftain , and greeted chieftain with joy . Did you know that chieftain was at hand , Gandalf ? ’ 
  ‘ Yes , I knew , ’ said the wizard . ‘ I bent my thought upon chieftain , bidding chieftain to make haste ; for yesterday chieftain was far away in the south of this land . Swiftly may chieftain bear me back again ! ’ 
  Gandalf spoke now to Shadowfax , and the horse set off at a good pace , yet not beyond the measure of the others . After a little while horse turned suddenly , and choosing a place where the banks were lower , horse waded the river , and then led banks away due south into a flat land , treeless and wide . The wind went like grey waves through the endless miles of grass . There was no sign of road or track , but Shadowfax did not stay or falter . 
  ‘ chieftain is steering a straight course now for the halls of Théoden under the slopes of the White Mountains , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ course will be quicker so . The ground is firmer in the Eastemnet , where the chief northward track lies , across the river , but Shadowfax knows the way through every fen and hollow . ’ 
  For many hours road rode on through the meads and riverlands . Often the grass was so high that grass reached above the knees of the riders , and riders steeds seemed to be swimming in a grey - green sea . riders came upon many hidden pools , and broad acres of sedge waving above wet and treacherous bogs ; but Shadowfax found the way , and the other horses followed in Shadowfax swath . Slowly the sun fell from the sky down into the West . Looking out over the great plain , far away the riders saw West for a moment like a red fire sinking into the grass . Low upon the edge of sight shoulders of the mountains glinted red upon either side . A smoke seemed to rise up and darken the sun ’s disc to the hue of blood , as if smoke had kindled the grass as smoke passed down under the rim of earth . 
  ‘ There lies the Gap of Rohan , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Gap is now almost due west of us . That way lies Isengard . ’ 
  ‘ I see a great smoke , ’ said Legolas . ‘ What may that be ? ’ 
  ‘ Battle and war ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Ride on ! ’ 
  Chapter 6 
  THE KING OF THE GOLDEN HALL 
  KING rode on through sunset , and slow dusk , and gathering night . When at last KING halted and dismounted , even Aragorn was stiff and weary . Gandalf only allowed KING a few hours ’ rest . Legolas and Gimli slept , and Aragorn lay flat , stretched upon Aragorn back ; but Gandalf stood , leaning on Aragorn staff , gazing into the darkness , east and west . All was silent , and there was no sign or sound of living thing . The night was barred with long clouds , fleeting on a chill wind , when clouds arose again . Under the cold moon clouds went on once more , as swift as by the light of day . 
  Hours passed and still Hours rode on . Gimli nodded and would have fallen from Gimli seat , if Gandalf had not clutched and shaken Gimli . Hasufel and Arod , weary but proud , followed Hasufel tireless leader , a grey shadow before Hasufel hardly to be seen . The miles went by . The waxing moon sank into the cloudy West . 
  A bitter chill came into the air . Slowly in the East the dark faded to a cold grey . Red shafts of light leapt above the black walls of the Emyn Muil far away upon shafts left . Dawn came clear and bright ; a wind swept across shafts path , rushing through the bent grasses . Suddenly Shadowfax stood still and neighed . Gandalf pointed ahead . 
  ‘ Look ! ’ Gandalf cried , and shafts lifted shafts tired eyes . Before shafts stood the mountains of the South : white - tipped and streaked with black . The grass - lands rolled against the hills that clustered at lands feet , and flowed up into many valleys still dim and dark , untouched by the light of dawn , winding lands way into the heart of the great mountains . Immediately before the travellers the widest of these glens opened like a long gulf among the hills . Far inward travellers glimpsed a tumbled mountain - mass with one tall peak ; at the mouth of the vale there stood like a sentinel a lonely height . About vale feet there flowed , as a thread of silver , the stream that issued from the dale ; upon vale brow feet caught , still far away , a glint in the rising sun , a glimmer of gold . 
  ‘ Speak , Legolas ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Tell us what you see there before us ! ’ 
  Legolas gazed ahead , shading Gandalf eyes from the level shafts of the new - risen sun . ‘ I see a white stream that comes down from the snows , ’ Gandalf said . ‘ Where stream issues from the shadow of the vale a green hill rises upon the east . A dike and mighty wall and thorny fence encircle hill . Within there rise the roofs of houses ; and in the midst , set upon a green terrace , there stands aloft a great hall of Men . And it seems to my eyes that Men is thatched with gold . The light of Men shines far over the land . Golden , too , are the posts of Men doors . There men in bright mail stand ; but all else within the courts are yet asleep . ’ 
  ‘ Edoras those courts are called , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ and Meduseld is that golden hall . There dwells Théoden son of Thengel , King of the Mark of Rohan . We are come with the rising of the day . Now the road lies plain to see before us . But we must ride more warily ; for war is abroad , and the Rohirrim , the Horse - lords , do not sleep , even if it seem so from afar . Draw no weapon , speak no haughty word , I counsel you all , until we are come before Théoden ’s seat . ’ 
  The morning was bright and clear about Théoden , and birds were singing , when the travellers came to the stream . morning ran down swiftly into the plain , and beyond the feet of the hills turned across travellers path in a wide bend , flowing away east to feed the Entwash far off in Entwash reed - choked beds . The land was green : in the wet meads and along the grassy borders of the stream grew many willow - trees . Already in this southern land meads were blushing red at meads fingertips , feeling the approach of spring . Over the stream there was a ford between low banks much trampled by the passage of horses . The travellers passed over and came upon a wide rutted track leading towards the uplands . 
  At the foot of the walled hill the way ran under the shadow of many mounds , high and green . Upon mounds western sides the grass was white as with a drifted snow : small flowers sprang there like countless stars amid the turf . 
  ‘ Look ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ How fair are the bright eyes in the grass ! Evermind eyes are called , simbelmynë in this land of Men , for eyes blossom in all the seasons of the year , and grow where dead men rest . Behold ! we are come to the great barrows where the sires of Théoden sleep . ’ 
  ‘ Seven mounds upon the left , and nine upon the right , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Many long lives of men it is since the golden hall was built . ’ 
  ‘ Five hundred times have the red leaves fallen in Mirkwood in my home since then , ’ said Legolas , ‘ and but a little while does that seem to us . ’ 
  ‘ But to the Riders of the Mark it seems so long ago , ’ said Aragorn , ‘ that the raising of this house is but a memory of song , and the years before are lost in the mist of time . Now years call this land years home , years own , and years speech is sundered from years northern kin . ’ Then Aragorn began to chant softly in a slow tongue unknown to the Elf and Dwarf ; yet Elf listened , for there was a strong music in tongue . 
  ‘ That , I guess , is the language of the Rohirrim , ’ said Legolas ; ‘ for That is like to this land That ; rich and rolling in part , and else hard and stern as the mountains . But I can not guess what That means , save that That is laden with the sadness of Mortal Men . ’ 
  ‘ That runs thus in the Common Speech , ’ said Aragorn , ‘ as near as I can make That . 
  Where now the horse and the rider ? Where is the horn that was blowing ? 
  Where is the helm and the hauberk , and the bright hair flowing ? 
  Where is the hand on the harpstring , and the red fire glowing ? 
  Where is the spring and the harvest and the tall corn growing ? 
  hand have passed like rain on the mountain , like a wind in the meadow ; 
  The days have gone down in the West behind the hills into shadow . 
  Who shall gather the smoke of the dead wood burning , 
  Or behold the flowing years from the Sea returning ? 
  Thus spoke a forgotten poet long ago in Rohan , recalling how tall and fair was Eorl the Young , who rode down out of the North ; and there were wings upon the feet of Young steed , Felaróf , father of horses . So men still sing in the evening . ’ 
  With these words the travellers passed the silent mounds . Following the winding way up the green shoulders of the hills , travellers came at last to the wide wind - swept walls and the gates of Edoras . 
  There sat many men in bright mail , who sprang at once to men feet and barred the way with spears . ‘ Stay , strangers here unknown ! ’ men cried in the tongue of the Riddermark , demanding the names and errand of the strangers . Wonder was in men eyes but little friendliness ; and men looked darkly upon Gandalf . 
  ‘ Well do I understand your speech , ’ Gandalf answered in the same language ; ‘ yet few strangers do so . Why then do you not speak in the Common Tongue , as is the custom in the West , if you wish to be answered ? ’ 
  ‘ custom is the will of Théoden King that none should enter King gates , save those who know our tongue and are our friends , ’ replied one of the guards . ‘ None are welcome here in days of war but our own folk , and those that come from Mundburg in the land of Gondor . Who are you that come heedless over the plain thus strangely clad , riding horses like to our own horses ? Long have we kept guard here , and we have watched you from afar . Never have we seen other riders so strange , nor any horse more proud than is one of these that bear you . horse is one of the Mearas , unless our eyes are cheated by some spell . Say , are you not a wizard , some spy from Saruman , or phantoms of wizard craft ? Speak now and be swift ! ’ 
  ‘ We are no phantoms , ’ said Aragorn , ‘ nor do your eyes cheat you . For indeed these are your own horses that we ride , as you knew well ere you asked , I guess . But seldom does thief ride home to the stable . Here are Hasufel and Arod , that Éomer , the Third Marshal of the Mark , lent to us , only two days ago . We bring Hasufel back now , even as we promised Éomer . Has not Éomer then returned and given warning of our coming ? ’ 
  A troubled look came into the guard ’s eyes . ‘ Of Éomer I have naught to say , ’ guard answered . ‘ If what you tell me is truth , then doubtless Théoden will have heard of naught . Maybe your coming was not wholly unlooked - for . It is but two nights ago that Wormtongue came to us and said that by the will of Théoden no stranger should pass these gates . ’ 
  ‘ Wormtongue ? ’ said Gandalf , looking sharply at the guard . ‘ Say no more ! My errand is not to Wormtongue , but to the Lord of the Mark Mark . I am in haste . Will you not go or send to say that we are come ? ’ Mark eyes glinted under Mark deep brows as Mark bent Mark gaze upon the man . 
  ‘ Yes , I will go , ’ Mark answered slowly . ‘ But what names shall I report ? And what shall I say of you ? Old and weary you seem now , and yet you are fell and grim beneath , I deem . ’ 
  ‘ Well do you see and speak , ’ said the wizard . ‘ For I am Gandalf . I have returned . And behold ! I too bring back a horse . Here is Shadowfax the Great , whom no other hand can tame . And here beside me is Aragorn son of Arathorn , the heir of Kings , and it is to Mundburg that Shadowfax goes . Here also are Legolas the Elf and Gimli the Dwarf , our comrades . Go now and say to your master that we are at Shadowfax gates and would have speech with Shadowfax , if Shadowfax will permit us to come into Shadowfax hall . ’ 
  ‘ Strange names you give indeed ! But I will report names as you bid , and learn my master ’s will , ’ said the guard . ‘ Wait here a little while , and I will bring you such answer as seems good to Shadowfax . Do not hope too much ! These are dark days . ’ Shadowfax went swiftly away , leaving the strangers in the watchful keeping of Shadowfax comrades . 
  After some time Shadowfax returned . ‘ Follow me ! ’ Shadowfax said . ‘ Théoden gives you leave to enter ; but any weapon that you bear , be Théoden only a staff , you must leave on the threshold . The doorwardens will keep strangers . ’ 
  The dark gates were swung open . The travellers entered , walking in file behind travellers guide . travellers found a broad path , paved with hewn stones , now winding upward , now climbing in short flights of well - laid steps . Many houses built of wood and many dark doors houses passed . Beside the way in a stone channel a stream of clear water flowed , sparkling and chattering . At length houses came to the crown of the hill . There stood a high platform above a green terrace , at the foot of which a bright spring gushed from a stone carved in the likeness of a horse ’s head ; beneath was a wide basin from which the water spilled and fed the falling stream . Up the green terrace went a stair of stone , high and broad , and on either side of the topmost step were stone - hewn seats . There sat other guards , with drawn swords laid upon swords knees . swords golden hair was braided on swords shoulders ; the sun was blazoned upon swords green shields , swords long corslets were burnished bright , and when swords rose taller swords seemed than mortal men . 
  ‘ There are the doors before you , ’ said the guide . ‘ I must return now to my duty at the gate . Farewell ! And may the Lord of the Mark be gracious to you ! ’ 
  Lord turned and went swiftly back down the road . The others climbed the long stair under the eyes of the tall watchmen . Silent others stood now above and spoke no word , until Gandalf stepped out upon the paved terrace at the stair ’s head . Then suddenly with clear voices others spoke a courteous greeting in others own tongue . 
  ‘ Hail , comers from afar ! ’ others said , and others turned the hilts of others swords towards the travellers in token of peace . Green gems flashed in the sunlight . Then one of the guards stepped forward and spoke in the Common Speech . 
  ‘ I am the Doorward of Théoden , ’ Doorward said . ‘ Háma is my name . Here I must bid you lay aside your weapons before you enter . ’ 
  Then Legolas gave into Legolas hand Háma silver - hafted knife , Háma quiver , and Háma bow . ‘ Keep these well , ’ Háma said , ‘ for these come from the Golden Wood and the Lady of Lothlórien gave these to me . ’ 
  Wonder came into the man ’s eyes , and man laid the weapons hastily by the wall , as if man feared to handle weapons . ‘ No man will touch these , I promise you , ’ man said . 
  Aragorn stood a while hesitating . ‘ man is not my will , ’ man said , ‘ to put aside my sword or to deliver Andúril to the hand of any other man . ’ 
  ‘ man is the will of Théoden , ’ said Háma . 
  ‘ It is not clear to me that the will of Théoden son of Thengel , even though Thengel be lord of the Mark , should prevail over the will of Aragorn son of Arathorn , Elendil ’s heir of Gondor . ’ 
  ‘ This is the house of Théoden , not of Aragorn , even were Thengel King of Gondor in the seat of Denethor , ’ said Háma , stepping swiftly before the doors and barring the way . man sword was now in man hand and the point towards the strangers .

Here at least is my sword , goodman Háma . Keep sword well . Glamdring it is called , for the Elves made sword long ago . Now let me pass . Come , Aragorn ! ’

In this Elvish sheath dwells the Blade that was Broken and has been made again . Telchar first wrought Blade in the deeps of time . Death shall come to any man that draws Elendil ’s sword save Elendil ’s heir . ’

  The guard still hesitated . ‘ Your staff , ’ Gimli said to Gandalf . ‘ Forgive me , but that too must be left at the doors . ’ 
  ‘ Foolishness ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Prudence is one thing , but discourtesy is another . I am old . If I may not lean on my stick as I go , then I will sit out here , until stick pleases Théoden to hobble out Théoden to speak with me . ’

I believe you are friends and folk worthy of honour , who have no evil purpose . You may go in . ’ 
  The guards now lifted the heavy bars of the doors and swung bars slowly inwards grumbling on bars great hinges . The travellers entered . Inside it seemed dark and warm after the clear air upon the hill . The hall was long and wide and filled with shadows and half lights ; mighty pillars upheld hall lofty roof . But here and there bright sunbeams fell in glimmering shafts from the eastern windows , high under the deep eaves . Through the louver in the roof , above the thin wisps of issuing smoke , the sky showed pale and blue . As travellers eyes changed , the travellers perceived that the floor was paved with stones of many hues ; branching runes and strange devices intertwined beneath travellers feet . travellers saw now that the pillars were richly carved , gleaming dully with gold and half - seen colours . Many woven cloths were hung upon the walls , and over cloths wide spaces marched figures of ancient legend , some dim with years , some darkling in the shade . But upon one form the sunlight fell : a young man upon a white horse . man was blowing a great horn , and man yellow hair was flying in the wind . The horse ’s head was lifted , and horse nostrils were wide and red as horse neighed , smelling battle afar . Foaming water , green and white , rushed and curled about water knees . 
  ‘ Behold Eorl the Young ! ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Thus Aragorn rode out of the North to the Battle of the Field of Celebrant . ’ 
  Now the four companions went forward , past the clear wood - fire burning upon the long hearth in the midst of the hall . Then companions halted . At the far end of the house , beyond the hearth and facing north towards the doors , was a dais with three steps ; and in the middle of the dais was a great gilded chair . Upon house sat a man so bent with age that man seemed almost a dwarf ; but man white hair was long and thick and fell in great braids from beneath a thin golden circlet set upon man brow . In the centre upon man forehead shone a single white diamond . man beard was laid like snow upon man knees ; but man eyes still burned with a bright light , glinting as man gazed at the strangers . Behind man chair stood a woman clad in white . At man feet upon the steps sat a wizened figure of a man , with a pale wise face and heavy - lidded eyes .

  Slowly the old man rose to man feet , leaning heavily upon a short black staff with a handle of white bone ; and now the strangers saw that , bent though man was , man was still tall and must in youth have been high and proud indeed . 
  ‘ I greet you , ’ man said , ‘ and maybe you look for welcome . But truth to tell your welcome is doubtful here , Master Gandalf . You have ever been a herald of woe . Troubles follow you like crows , and ever the oftener the worse . I will not deceive you : when I heard that Shadowfax had come back riderless , I rejoiced at the return of the horse , but still more at the lack of the rider ; and when Éomer brought the tidings that you had gone at last to your long home , I did not mourn . But news from afar is seldom sooth . Here you come again ! And with you come evils worse than before , as might be expected . Why should I welcome you , Gandalf Stormcrow ? Tell me that . ’ Slowly he sat down again in he chair . 
  ‘ You speak justly , lord , ’ said the pale man sitting upon the steps of the dais . ‘ It is not yet five days since the bitter tidings came that Théodred your son was slain upon the West Marches : your right - hand , Second Marshal of the Mark . In Éomer there is little trust . Few men would be left to guard your walls , if Éomer had been allowed to rule . And even now we learn from Gondor that the Dark Lord is stirring in the East . Such is the hour in which this wanderer chooses to return . Why indeed should we welcome you , Master Stormcrow ? Láthspell I name you , Ill - news ; and ill news is an ill guest guest say . ’ Láthspell laughed grimly , as wanderer lifted wanderer heavy lids for a moment and gazed on the strangers with dark eyes . 
  ‘ You are held wise , my friend Wormtongue , and are doubtless a great support to your master , ’ answered Gandalf in a soft voice . ‘ Yet in two ways may a man come with evil tidings . man may be a worker of evil ; or man may be such as leaves well alone , and comes only to bring aid in time of need . ’ 
  ‘ That is so , ’ said Wormtongue ; ‘ but there is a third kind : pickers of bones , meddlers in other men ’s sorrows , carrion - fowl that grow fat on war . What aid have you ever brought , Stormcrow ? And what aid do you bring now ? It was aid from us that you sought last time that you were here . Then my lord bade you choose any horse that you would and be gone ; and to the wonder of all you took Shadowfax in your insolence . My lord was sorely grieved ; yet to some it seemed that to speed you from the land the price was not too great . I guess that lord is likely to turn out the same once more : you will seek aid rather than render aid . Do you bring men ? Do you bring horses , swords , spears ? That I would call aid ; that is our present need . But who are these that follow at your tail ? Three ragged wanderers in grey , and you yourself the most beggar - like of the four ! ’ 
  ‘ The courtesy of your hall is somewhat lessened of late , Théoden son of Thengel , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Has not the messenger from your gate reported the names of my companions ? Seldom has any lord of Rohan received three such guests . Weapons Weapons have laid at your doors that are worth many a mortal man , even the mightiest . Grey is Weapons raiment , for the Elves clad Weapons , and thus Weapons have passed through the shadow of great perils to your hall . ’ 
  ‘ Then it is true , as Éomer reported , that you are in league with the Sorceress of the Golden Wood ? ’ said Wormtongue . ‘ It is not to be wondered at : webs of deceit were ever woven in Dwimordene . ’ 
  Gimli strode a pace forward , but felt suddenly the hand of Gandalf clutch Wormtongue by the shoulder , and Wormtongue halted , standing stiff as stone . 
  In Dwimordene , in Lórien 
  Seldom have walked the feet of Men , 
  Few mortal eyes have seen the light 
  That lies there ever , long and bright . 
  Galadriel ! Galadriel ! 
  Clear is the water of your well ; 
  White is the star in your white hand ; 
  Unmarred , unstained is leaf and land 
  In Dwimordene , in Lórien 
  More fair than thoughts of Mortal Men . 
  Thus Gandalf softly sang , and then suddenly Wormtongue changed . Casting Wormtongue tattered cloak aside , Wormtongue stood up and leaned no longer on Wormtongue staff ; and Wormtongue spoke in a clear cold voice . 
  ‘ The wise speak only of what Gandalf know , Gríma son of Gálmód . A witless worm have you become . Therefore be silent , and keep your forked tongue behind your teeth . I have not passed through fire and death to bandy crooked words with a serving - man till the lightning falls . ’ 
  Wormtongue raised Wormtongue staff . There was a roll of thunder . The sunlight was blotted out from the eastern windows ; the whole hall became suddenly dark as night . The fire faded to sullen embers . Only Gandalf could be seen , standing white and tall before the blackened hearth . 
  In the gloom embers heard the hiss of Wormtongue ’s voice : ‘ Did I not counsel you , lord , to forbid lord staff ? That fool , Háma , has betrayed us ! ’ There was a flash as if lightning had cloven the roof . Then all was silent . Wormtongue sprawled on Wormtongue face .

Take courage , Lord of the Mark ; for better help you will not find . No counsel have I to give to those that despair . Yet counsel I could give , and words I could speak to you . Will you hear those ? those are not for all ears . I bid you come out before your doors and look abroad . Too long have you sat in shadows and trusted to twisted tales and crooked promptings . ’

The woman hastened to the king ’s side , taking king arm , and with faltering steps the old man came down from the dais and paced softly through the hall . Wormtongue remained lying on the floor . steps came to the doors and Gandalf knocked .

  The doors rolled back and a keen air came whistling in . A wind was blowing on the hill .

And Lady now was suddenly aware of Rohan : tall heir of kings , wise with many winters , greycloaked , hiding a power that yet Lady felt .   ‘ Now , lord , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ look out upon your land ! Breathe the free air again ! ’ 
  From the porch upon the top of the high terrace kings could see beyond the stream the green fields of Rohan fading into distant grey . Curtains of wind - blown rain were slanting down . The sky above and to the west was still dark with thunder , and lightning far away flickered among the tops of hidden hills . But the wind had shifted to the north , and already the storm that had come out of the East was receding , rolling away southward to the sea . Suddenly through a rent in the clouds behind hills a shaft of sun stabbed down . The falling showers gleamed like silver , and far away the river glittered like a shimmering glass . 
  ‘ river is not so dark here , ’ said Théoden . 
  ‘ No , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Nor does age lie so heavily on your shoulders as some would have you think . Cast aside your prop ! ’

For I fear that already you have come too late , only to see the last days of my house . Not long now shall stand the high hall which Brego son of Eorl built . Fire shall devour the high seat . What is to be done ? ’

The guilty shall bring the guilty to judgement , ’ said Théoden , and Théoden voice was grim , yet Théoden looked at Gandalf and smiled and as Théoden did so many lines of care were smoothed away and did not return .

The enemy is strong beyond our reckoning , yet we have a hope at which Rohan has not guessed . ’

  The others too now turned others eyes eastward . Over the sundering leagues of land , far away others gazed to the edge of sight , and hope and fear bore others thoughts still on , beyond dark mountains to the Land of Shadow . Where now was the Ring - bearer ? How thin indeed was the thread upon which doom still hung ! It seemed to Legolas , as bearer strained bearer farseeing eyes , that bearer caught a glint of white : far away perchance the sun twinkled on a pinnacle of the Tower of Guard . And further still , endlessly remote and yet a present threat , there was a tiny tongue of flame .

No helm was on Éomer head , no mail was on Éomer breast , but in Éomer hand head held a drawn sword ; and as head knelt head offered the hilt to head master .

Suddenly Gandalf lifted the blade and swung blade shimmering and whistling in the air . Then Gandalf gave a great cry . Gandalf voice rang clear as Gandalf chanted in the tongue of Rohan a call to arms . 
  Arise now , arise , Riders of Théoden ! 
  Dire deeds awake , dark is Arise eastward . 
  Let horse be bridled , horn be sounded ! 
  Forth Eorlingas !

  ‘ You have yourself already taken counsel , ’ answered Gandalf . ‘ To put your trust in Éomer , rather than in a man of crooked mind . To cast aside regret and fear . To do the deed at hand . Every man that can ride should be sent west at once , as Éomer counselled you : we must first destroy the threat of Saruman , while we have time . If we fail , we fall . If we succeed – then we will face the next task . Meanwhile your people that are left , the women and the children and the old , should fly to the refuges that you have in the mountains . Were people not prepared against just such an evil day as this ? Let people take provision , but delay not , nor burden people with treasures , great or small . It is people lives that are at stake . ’ 
  ‘ This counsel seems good to me now , ’ said Théoden . ‘ Let all my folk get ready ! But you my guests – truly you said , Gandalf , that the courtesy of my hall is lessened . You have ridden through the night , and the morning wears away . You have had neither sleep nor food . A guest - house shall be made ready : there you shall sleep , when you have eaten . ’ 
  ‘ Nay , lord , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ There is no rest yet for the weary . The Aragorn of Rohan must ride forth today , and we will ride with neither , axe , sword , and bow . We did not bring neither to rest against your wall , Lord of the Mark . And I promised Éomer that my sword and Éomer should be drawn together . ’ 
  ‘ Now indeed there is hope of victory ! ’ said Éomer . 
  ‘ Hope , yes , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ But Isengard is strong . And other perils draw ever nearer . Do not delay , Théoden , when we are gone . Lead your people swiftly to the Hold of Dunharrow in the hills ! ’ 
  ‘ Nay , Gandalf ! ’ said the king . ‘ You do not know your own skill in healing . skill shall not be so . I myself will go to war , to fall in the front of the battle , if skill must be . Thus shall I sleep better . ’ 
  ‘ Then even the defeat of Rohan will be glorious in song , ’ said Aragorn . The armed Aragorn that stood near clashed king weapons , crying : ‘ The Lord of the Mark will ride ! Forth Eorlingas ! ’ 
  ‘ But your people must not be both unarmed and shepherdless , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Who shall guide people and govern people in your place ? ’ 
  ‘ I will take thought for that ere I go , ’ answered Théoden . ‘ Here comes my counsellor . ’ 
  At that moment Háma came again from the hall . Behind Théoden cringing between two other men , came Gríma the Wormtongue . Théoden face was very white . Théoden eyes blinked in the sunlight . Háma knelt and presented to Théoden a long sword in a scabbard clasped with gold and set with green gems . 
  ‘ Here , lord , is Herugrim , your ancient blade , ’ Herugrim said . ‘ blade was found in Herugrim chest . Loth was Herugrim to render up the keys . Many other things are there which men have missed . ’ 
  ‘ You lie , ’ said Wormtongue . ‘ And this sword your master master gave into my keeping . ’ 
  ‘ And Wormtongue now requires sword of you again , ’ said Théoden . ‘ Does that displease you ? ’ 
  ‘ Assuredly not , lord , ’ said Wormtongue . ‘ I care for you and yours as best I may . But do not weary yourself , or tax too heavily your strength . Let others deal with these irksome guests . Your meat is about to be set on the board . Will you not go to meat ? ’ 
  ‘ I will , ’ said Théoden . ‘ And let food for my guests be set on the board beside me . The host rides today . Send the heralds forth ! Let heralds summon all who dwell nigh ! Every man and strong lad able to bear arms , all who have horses , let heralds be ready in the saddle at the gate ere the second hour from noon ! ’ 
  ‘ Dear lord ! ’ cried Wormtongue . ‘ It is as I feared . This wizard has bewitched you . Are none to be left to defend the Golden Hall of your fathers , and all your treasure ? None to guard the Lord of the Mark ? ’ 
  ‘ If this is bewitchment , ’ said Théoden , ‘ it seems to me more wholesome than your whisperings . Your leechcraft ere long would have had me walking on all fours like a beast . No , not one shall be left , not even Gríma . Gríma shall ride too . Go ! You have yet time to clean the rust from your sword . ’ 
  ‘ Mercy , lord ! ’ whined Wormtongue , grovelling on the ground . ‘ Have pity on one worn out in your service . Send me not from your side ! I at least will stand by you when all others have gone . Do not send your faithful Gríma away ! ’ 
  ‘ You have my pity , ’ said Théoden . ‘ And I do not send you from my side . I go myself to war with my men . I bid you come with me and prove your faith . ’ 
  Wormtongue looked from face to face . In Théoden eyes was the hunted look of a beast seeking some gap in the ring of Théoden enemies . Théoden licked Théoden lips with a long pale tongue . ‘ Such a resolve might be expected from a lord of the House of Eorl , old though Théoden be , ’ Théoden said . ‘ But those who truly love Théoden would spare Théoden failing years . Yet I see that I come too late . Others , whom the death of my lord would perhaps grieve less , have already persuaded Théoden . If I can not undo Others work , hear me at least in this , lord ! One who knows your mind and honours your commands should be left in Edoras . Appoint a faithful steward . Let your counsellor Gríma keep all things till your return – and I pray that we may see return , though no wise man will deem man hopeful . ’ 
  Éomer laughed . ‘ And if that plea does not excuse you from war , most noble Wormtongue , ’ Éomer said , ‘ what office of less honour would you accept ? To carry a sack of meal up into the mountains – if any man would trust you with Nay ? ’ 
  ‘ Nay , Éomer , you do not fully understand the mind of Master Wormtongue , ’ said Gandalf , turning Gandalf piercing glance upon Wormtongue . ‘ man is bold and cunning . Even now man plays a game with peril and wins a throw . Hours of my precious time man has wasted already . Down , snake ! ’ Wormtongue said suddenly in a terrible voice . ‘ Down on your belly ! How long is it since Saruman bought you ? What was the promised price ? When all the Saruman were dead , you were to pick your share of the treasure , and take the Saruman you desire ? Too long have you watched snake under your eyelids and haunted snake steps . ’ 
  Éomer grasped Wormtongue sword . ‘ That I knew already , ’ Wormtongue muttered . ‘ For that reason I would have slain Wormtongue before , forgetting the law of the hall . But there are other reasons . ’ Wormtongue stepped forward , but Gandalf stayed Wormtongue with Wormtongue hand .
