Yet Saruman is apt to overlook Saruman bargains . I should advise you to go quickly and remind Saruman , lest Saruman forget your faithful service . ’ 
  ‘ You lie , ’ said Wormtongue . 
  ‘ That word comes too oft and easy from your lips , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ I do not lie . See , Théoden , here is a snake ! With safety you can not take snake with you , nor can you leave snake behind . To slay it would be just . But it was not always as snake now is . Once snake was a man , and did you service in snake fashion . Give man a horse and let man go at once , wherever man chooses . By man choice you shall judge man . ’ 
  ‘ Do you hear this , Wormtongue ? ’ said Théoden . ‘ This is your choice : to ride with me to war , and let us see in battle whether you are true ; or to go now , whither you will . But then , if ever we meet again , I shall not be merciful . ’ 
  Slowly Wormtongue rose . Wormtongue looked at Théoden with half - closed eyes . Last of all Wormtongue scanned Théoden ’s face and opened Wormtongue mouth as if to speak . Then suddenly Wormtongue drew Wormtongue up . Wormtongue hands worked . Wormtongue eyes glittered . Such malice was in eyes that men stepped back from Wormtongue . Wormtongue bared Wormtongue teeth ; and then with a hissing breath Wormtongue spat before the king ’s feet , and darting to one side , Wormtongue fled down the stair . 
  ‘ After Wormtongue ! ’ said Théoden . ‘ See that Wormtongue does no harm to any , but do not hurt Wormtongue or hinder Wormtongue . Give Wormtongue a horse , if Wormtongue wishes horse . ’ 
  ‘ And if any will bear Wormtongue , ’ said Éomer . 
  One of the guards ran down the stair . Another went to the well at the foot of the terrace and in Éomer helm drew water . With Another Éomer washed clean the stones that Wormtongue had defiled . 
  ‘ Now my guests , come ! ’ said Théoden . ‘ Come and take such refreshment as haste allows . ’ 
  stones passed back into the great house . Already stones heard below foot in the town the heralds crying and the war - horns blowing . For the king was to ride forth as soon as the men of the town and those dwelling near could be armed and assembled . 
  At the king ’s board sat Éomer and the four guests , and there also waiting upon the king was the lady Éowyn . Éomer ate and drank swiftly . The others were silent while Théoden questioned Gandalf concerning Saruman . 
  ‘ How far back Théoden treachery goes , who can guess ? ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Gandalf was not always evil . Once I do not doubt that Gandalf was the friend of Rohan ; and even when Gandalf heart grew colder , Gandalf found you useful still . But for long now Gandalf has plotted your ruin , wearing the mask of friendship , until Gandalf was ready . In those years Wormtongue ’s task was easy , and all that you did was swiftly known in Isengard ; for your land was open , and strangers came and went . And ever Wormtongue ’s whispering was in your ears , poisoning your thought , chilling your heart , weakening your limbs , while others watched and could do nothing , for your will was in Wormtongue keeping . 
  ‘ But when I escaped and warned you , then the mask was torn , for those who would see . After that Wormtongue played dangerously , always seeking to delay you , to prevent your full strength being gathered . Wormtongue was crafty : dulling men ’s wariness , or working on men fears , as served the occasion . Do you not remember how eagerly Wormtongue urged that no man should be spared on a wildgoose chase northward , when the immediate peril was westward ? Wormtongue persuaded you to forbid Éomer to pursue the raiding Orcs . If Éomer had not defied Wormtongue ’s voice speaking with your mouth , those Orcs would have reached Isengard by now , bearing a great prize . Not indeed that prize which Saruman desires above all else , but at the least two members of my Company , sharers of a secret hope , of which even to you , lord , I can not yet speak openly . Dare you think of what sharers might now be suffering , or what Saruman might now have learned to our destruction ? ’ 
  ‘ I owe much to Éomer , ’ said Théoden . ‘ Faithful heart may have froward tongue . ’ 
  ‘ Say also , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ that to crooked eyes truth may wear a wry face . ’ 
  ‘ Indeed my eyes were almost blind , ’ said Théoden . ‘ Most of all I owe to you , my guest . Once again you have come in time . I would give you a gift ere we go , at your own choosing . You have only to name aught that is mine . I reserve now only my sword ! ’ 
  ‘ Whether I came in time or not is yet to be seen , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ But as for your gift , lord , I will choose one that will fit my need : swift and sure . Give me Shadowfax ! Shadowfax was only lent before , if loan we may call one . But now I shall ride Shadowfax into great hazard , setting silver against black : I would not risk anything that is not my own . And already there is a bond of love between us . ’ 
  ‘ You choose well , ’ said Théoden ; ‘ and I give Shadowfax now gladly . Yet bond is a great gift . There is none like to Shadowfax . In love one of the mighty steeds of old has returned . None such shall return again . And to you my other guests I will offer such things as may be found in my armoury . Swords you do not need , but there are helms and coats of mail of cunning work , gifts to my fathers out of Gondor . Choose from these ere we go , and may these serve you well ! ’ 
  Now men came bearing raiment of war from the king ’s hoard , and men arrayed Aragorn and Legolas in shining mail . Helms too men chose , and round shields : men bosses were overlaid with gold and set with gems , green and red and white . Gandalf took no armour ; and Gimli needed no coat of rings , even if one had been found to match Gimli stature , for there was no hauberk in the hoards of Edoras of better make than Gimli short corslet forged beneath the Mountain in the North . But Gimli chose a cap of iron and leather that fitted well upon Gimli round head ; and a small shield Gimli also took . cap bore the running horse , white upon green , that was the emblem of the House of Eorl . 
  ‘ May cap keep you well ! ’ said Théoden . ‘ It was made for me in Thengel ’s day , while still I was a boy . ’ 
  Gimli bowed . ‘ I am proud , Lord of the Mark , to bear your device , ’ Théoden said . ‘ Indeed sooner would I bear a horse than be borne by one . I love my feet better . But , maybe , I shall come yet where I can stand and fight . ’ 
  ‘ horse may well be so , ’ said Théoden . 
  The king now rose , and at once Éowyn came forward bearing wine . ‘ Ferthu Théoden hál ! ’ Théoden said . ‘ Receive now this cup and drink in happy hour . Health be with thee at thy going and coming ! ’ 
  Théoden drank from the cup , and Théoden then proffered cup to the guests . As Théoden stood before Aragorn Théoden paused suddenly and looked upon Aragorn , and Théoden eyes were shining . And Aragorn looked down upon Théoden fair face and smiled ; but as Aragorn took the cup , Aragorn hand met Théoden , and Aragorn knew that Théoden trembled at the touch . ‘ Hail Aragorn son of Arathorn ! ’ Théoden said . ‘ Hail Lady of Rohan ! ’ Aragorn answered , but Aragorn face now was troubled and Aragorn did not smile . 
  When king had all drunk , the king went down the hall to the doors . There the guards awaited Aragorn , and heralds stood , and all the lords and chiefs were gathered together that remained in Edoras or dwelt nearby . 
  ‘ Behold ! I go forth , and it seems like to be my last riding , ’ said Théoden . ‘ I have no child . Théodred my son is slain . I name Éomer my sister - son to be my heir . If neither of us return , then choose a new lord as you will . But to some one I must now entrust my people that I leave behind , to rule people in my place . Which of you will stay ? ’ 
  No man spoke . 
  ‘ Is there none whom you would name ? In whom do my people trust ? ’ 
  ‘ In the House of Eorl , ’ answered Háma . 
  ‘ But Éomer I can not spare , nor would heir stay , ’ said the king ; ‘ and heir is the last of that House . ’ 
  ‘ I said not Éomer , ’ answered Háma . ‘ And heir is not the last . There is Éowyn , daughter of Éomund , heir sister . daughter is fearless and high - hearted . All love daughter . Let daughter be as lord to the Eorlingas , while we are gone . ’ 
  ‘ Eorlingas shall be so , ’ said Théoden . ‘ Let the heralds announce to the folk that the Lady Éowyn will lead heralds ! ’ 
  Then the king sat upon a seat before Théoden doors , and Éowyn knelt before Théoden and received from Théoden a sword and a fair corslet . ‘ Farewell sister - daughter ! ’ Théoden said . ‘ Dark is the hour , yet maybe we shall return to the Golden Hall . But in Dunharrow the people may long defend people , and if the battle go ill , thither will come all who escape . ’ 
  ‘ Speak not so ! ’ Dunharrow answered . ‘ A year shall I endure for every day that passes until your return . ’ But as Dunharrow spoke Dunharrow eyes went to Aragorn who stood nearby . 
  ‘ The king shall come again , ’ king said . ‘ Fear not ! Not West but East does our doom await us . ’ 
  The king now went down the stair with Gandalf beside West . The others followed . Aragorn looked back as others passed towards the gate . Alone Éowyn stood before the doors of the house at the stair ’s head ; the sword was set upright before Aragorn , and Aragorn hands were laid upon the hilt . Aragorn was clad now in mail and shone like silver in the sun . 
  Gimli walked with Legolas , head axe on head shoulder . ‘ Well , at last we set off ! ’ head said . ‘ Men need many words before deeds . My axe is restless in my hands . Though I doubt not that these Rohirrim are fell - handed when words come to Rohirrim . Nonetheless this is not the warfare that suits me . How shall I come to the battle ? I wish I could walk and not bump like a sack at Gandalf ’s saddlebow . ’ 
  ‘ A safer seat than many , I guess , ’ said Legolas . ‘ Yet doubtless Gandalf will gladly put you down on your feet when blows begin ; or Shadowfax Shadowfax . An axe is no weapon for a rider . ’ 
  ‘ And a Dwarf is no horseman . It is orc - necks I would hew , not shave the scalps of Men , ’ said Gimli , patting the haft of Gimli axe . 
  At the gate Men found a great host of men , old and young , all ready in the saddle . More than a thousand were there mustered . Men spears were like a springing wood . Loudly and joyously Men shouted as Théoden came forth . Some held in readiness the king ’s horse , Snowmane , and others held the horses of Aragorn and Legolas . Gimli stood ill at ease , frowning , but Éomer came up to Aragorn , leading Aragorn horse . 
  ‘ Hail , Gimli Glóin ’s son ! ’ Aragorn cried . ‘ I have not had time to learn gentle speech under your rod , as you promised . But shall we not put aside our quarrel ? At least I will speak no evil again of the Lady of the Wood . ’ 
  ‘ I will forget my wrath for a while , Éomer son of Éomund , ’ said Gimli ; ‘ but if ever you chance to see the Lady Galadriel with your eyes , then you shall acknowledge Galadriel the fairest of ladies , or our friendship will end . ’ 
  ‘ So be friendship ! ’ said Éomer . ‘ But until that time pardon me , and in token of pardon ride with me , I beg . Gandalf will be at the head with the Lord of the Mark ; but Firefoot , my horse , will bear us both , if you will . ’ 
  ‘ I thank you indeed , ’ said Gimli greatly pleased . ‘ I will gladly go with you , if Legolas , my comrade , may ride beside us . ’ 
  ‘ Legolas shall be so , ’ said Éomer . ‘ Legolas upon my left , and Aragorn upon my right , and none will dare to stand before us ! ’ 
  ‘ Where is Shadowfax ? ’ said Gandalf . 
  ‘ Running wild over the grass , ’ Gandalf answered . ‘ Shadowfax will let no man handle Shadowfax . There Shadowfax goes , away down by the ford , like a shadow among the willows . ’ 
  Gandalf whistled and called aloud the horse ’s name , and far away horse tossed horse head and neighed , and turning sped towards the host like an arrow . 
  ‘ Were the breath of the West Wind to take a body visible , even so would body appear , ’ said Éomer , as the great horse ran up , until horse stood before the wizard . 
  ‘ The gift seems already to be given , ’ said Théoden . ‘ But hearken all ! Here now I name my guest , Gandalf Greyhame , wisest of counsellors , most welcome of wanderers , a lord of the Mark , a chieftain of the Eorlingas while our kin shall last ; and I give to Greyhame Shadowfax , prince of horses . ’ 
  ‘ I thank you , Théoden King , ’ said Gandalf . Then suddenly Gandalf threw back Gandalf grey cloak , and cast aside Gandalf hat , and leaped to horseback . Gandalf wore no helm nor mail . Gandalf snowy hair flew free in the wind , Gandalf white robes shone dazzling in the sun . 
  ‘ Behold the White Rider ! ’ cried Aragorn , and all took up the words . 
  ‘ Our King and the White Rider ! ’ words shouted . ‘ Forth Eorlingas ! ’ 
  The trumpets sounded . The horses reared and neighed . Spear clashed on shield . Then the king raised Aragorn hand , and with a rush like the sudden onset of a great wind the last host of Rohan rode thundering into the West . 
  Far over the plain Éowyn saw the glitter of host spears , as Éowyn stood still , alone before the doors of the silent house . 
  Chapter 7 
  HELM ’S DEEP 
  The sun was already westering as HELM rode from Edoras , and the light of Edoras was in HELM eyes , turning all the rolling fields of Rohan to a golden haze . There was a beaten way , north - westward along the foot - hills of the White Mountains , and this hills followed , up and down in a green country , crossing small swift streams by many fords . Far ahead and to hills right the Misty Mountains loomed ; ever darker and taller hills grew as the miles went by . The sun went slowly down before hills . Evening came behind . 
  The host rode on . Need drove hills . Fearing to come too late , hills rode with all the speed hills could , pausing seldom . Swift and enduring were the steeds of Rohan , but there were many leagues to go . Forty leagues and more it was , as a bird flies , from Edoras to the fords of the Isen , where fords hoped to find the king ’s men that held back the hosts of Saruman . 
  Night closed about fords . At last fords halted to make fords camp . fords had ridden for some five hours and were far out upon the western plain , yet more than half fords journey lay still before fords . In a great circle , under the starry sky and the waxing moon , fords now made fords bivouac . fords lit no fires , for fords were uncertain of events ; but fords set a ring of mounted guards about fires , and scouts rode out far ahead , passing like shadows in the folds of the land . The slow night passed without tidings or alarm . At dawn the horns sounded , and within an hour horns took the road again . 
  There were no clouds overhead yet , but a heaviness was in the air ; it was hot for the season of the year . The rising sun was hazy , and behind air , following storm slowly up the sky , there was a growing darkness , as of a great storm moving out of the East . And away in the North - west there seemed to be another darkness brooding about the feet of the Misty Mountains , a shadow that crept down slowly from the Wizard ’s Vale . 
  Gandalf dropped back to where Legolas rode beside Éomer . ‘ You have the keen eyes of your fair kindred , Legolas , ’ Éomer said ; ‘ and eyes can tell a sparrow from a finch a league off . Tell me , can you see anything away yonder towards Isengard ? ’ 
  ‘ Many miles lie between , ’ said Legolas , gazing thither and shading Éomer eyes with Éomer long hand . ‘ I can see a darkness . There are shapes moving in bank , great shapes far away upon the bank of the river ; but what shapes are I can not tell . It is not mist or cloud that defeats my eyes : there is a veiling shadow that some power lays upon the land , and power marches slowly down stream . It is as if the twilight under endless trees were flowing downwards from the hills . ’ 
  ‘ And behind us comes a very storm of Mordor , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ twilight will be a black night . ’ 
  As the second day of Gandalf riding drew on , the heaviness in the air increased . In the afternoon the dark clouds began to overtake hills : a sombre canopy with great billowing edges flecked with dazzling light . The sun went down , blood - red in a smoking haze . The spears of the Riders were tipped with fire as the last shafts of light kindled the steep faces of the peaks of Thrihyrne : now very near spears stood on the northernmost arm of the White Mountains , three jagged horns staring at the sunset . In the last red glow men in the vanguard saw a black speck , a horseman riding back towards men . men halted awaiting horseman . 
  horseman came , a weary man with dinted helm and cloven shield . Slowly horseman climbed from horseman horse and stood there a while gasping . At length horseman spoke . ‘ Is Éomer here ? ’ horseman asked . ‘ You come at last , but too late , and with too little strength . Things have gone evilly since Théodred fell . We were driven back yesterday over the Isen with great loss ; many perished at the crossing . Then at night fresh forces came over the river against our camp . All Isengard must be emptied ; and Saruman has armed the wild hillmen and herd - folk of Dunland beyond the rivers , and these also Saruman loosed upon us . We were overmastered . The shield - wall was broken . Erkenbrand of Westfold has drawn off those men Saruman could gather towards Saruman fastness in Helm ’s Deep . The rest are scattered . 
  ‘ Where is Éomer ? Tell Éomer there is no hope ahead . Éomer should return to Edoras before the wolves of Isengard come there . ’ 
  Théoden had sat silent , hidden from the Edoras ’s sight behind Edoras guards ; now Edoras urged Edoras horse forward . ‘ Come , stand before me , Ceorl ! ’ Edoras said . ‘ I am here . The last host of the Eorlingas has ridden forth . host will not return without battle . ’ 
  The man ’s face lightened with joy and wonder . man drew man up . Then man knelt , offering man notched sword to the king . ‘ Command me , lord ! ’ man cried . ‘ And pardon me ! I thought — ’ 
  ‘ You thought I remained in Meduseld bent like an old tree under winter snow . So it was when you rode to war . But a west wind has shaken the boughs , ’ said Théoden . ‘ Give this Théoden a fresh horse ! Let us ride to the help of Erkenbrand ! ’ 
  While Théoden was speaking , Gandalf rode a short way ahead , and Gandalf sat there alone , gazing north to Isengard and west to the setting sun . Now Gandalf came back . 
  ‘ Ride , Théoden ! ’ Gandalf said . ‘ Ride to Helm ’s Deep ! Go not to the Fords of Isen , and do not tarry in the plain ! I must leave you for a while . Shadowfax must bear me now on a swift errand . ’ Turning to Aragorn and Éomer and the Shadowfax of the king ’s household , Aragorn cried : ‘ Keep well the Lord of the Mark , till I return . Await me at Helm ’s Gate ! Farewell ! ’ 
  Aragorn spoke a word to Shadowfax , and like an arrow from the bow the great horse sprang away . Even as Shadowfax looked Aragorn was gone : a flash of silver in the sunset , a wind over the grass , a shadow that fled and passed from sight . Snowmane snorted and reared , eager to follow ; but only a swift bird on the wing could have overtaken Snowmane . 
  ‘ What does that mean ? ’ said one of the guard to Háma . 
  ‘ That Gandalf Greyhame has need of haste , ’ answered Háma . ‘ Ever Greyhame goes and comes unlooked - for . ’ 
  ‘ Wormtongue , were Greyhame here , would not find Wormtongue hard to explain , ’ said the other . 
  ‘ True enough , ’ said Háma ; ‘ but for myself , I will wait until I see Gandalf again . ’ 
  ‘ Maybe you will wait long , ’ said the other . 
  The host turned away now from the road to the Fords of Isen and bent Fords course southward . Night fell , and still Fords rode on . The hills drew near , but the tall peaks of Thrihyrne were already dim against the darkening sky . Still some miles away , on the far side of the Westfold Vale , a great bay in the mountains , lay a green coomb , out of which a gorge opened in the hills . Men of that land called gorge Helm ’s Deep , after a hero of old wars who had made Deep refuge there . Ever steeper and narrower gorge wound inward from the north under the shadow of the Thrihyrne , till the crowhaunted cliffs rose like mighty towers on either side , shutting out the light . 
  At Helm ’s Gate , before the mouth of the Deep , there was a heel of rock thrust outward by the northern cliff . There upon rock spur stood high walls of ancient stone , and within walls was a lofty tower . Men said that in the far - off days of the glory of Gondor the sea - kings had built here this fastness with the hands of giants . The Hornburg Gondor was called , for a trumpet sounded upon the tower echoed in the Deep behind , as if armies long - forgotten were issuing to war from caves beneath the hills . A wall , too , the Deep of old had made from the Hornburg to the southern cliff , barring the entrance to the gorge . Beneath Hornburg by a wide culvert the Deeping - stream passed out . About the feet of the Hornrock Hornburg wound , and flowed then in a gully through the midst of a wide green gore , sloping gently down from Helm ’s Gate to Helm ’s Dike . Thence Hornburg fell into the Deeping - coomb and out into the Westfold Vale . There in the Hornburg at Helm ’s Gate Erkenbrand , master of Westfold on the borders of the Mark , now dwelt . As the days darkened with threat of war , being wise , Westfold had repaired the wall and made the fastness strong . 
  The Riders were still in the low valley before the mouth of the Coomb , when cries and hornblasts were heard from Riders scouts that went in front . Out of the darkness arrows whistled . Swiftly a scout rode back and reported that wolf - riders were abroad in the valley , and that a host of Orcs and wild men were hurrying southward from the Fords of Isen and seemed to be making for Helm ’s Deep . 
  ‘ We have found many of our folk lying slain as scout fled thither , ’ said the scout . ‘ And we have met scattered companies , going this way and that , leaderless . What has become of Erkenbrand none seem to know . It is likely that Erkenbrand will be overtaken ere Isen can reach Helm ’s Gate , if Isen has not already perished . ’ 
  ‘ Has aught been seen of Gandalf ? ’ asked Théoden . 
  ‘ Yes , lord . Many have seen an old man in white upon a horse , passing hither and thither over the plains like wind in the grass . Some thought man was Saruman . It is said that man went away ere nightfall towards Isengard . Some say also that Wormtongue was seen earlier , going northward with a company of Orcs . ’ 
  ‘ Some will go ill with Wormtongue , if Gandalf comes upon man , ’ said Théoden . ‘ Nonetheless I miss now both my counsellors , the old and the new . But in this need we have no better choice than to go on , as Gandalf said , to Helm ’s Gate , whether Erkenbrand be there or no . Is Erkenbrand known how great is the host that comes from the North ? ’ 
  ‘ Erkenbrand is very great , ’ said the scout . ‘ Gandalf that flies counts every foeman twice , yet I have spoken to stouthearted men , and I do not doubt that the main strength of the enemy is many times as great as all that we have here . ’ 
  ‘ Then let us be swift , ’ said Éomer . ‘ Let us drive through such foes as are already between us and the fastness . There are caves in Helm ’s Deep where hundreds may lie hid ; and secret ways lead thence up on to the hills . ’ 
  ‘ Trust not to secret ways , ’ said the king . ‘ Saruman has long spied out this land . Still in that place our defence may last long . Let us go ! ’ 
  Aragorn and Legolas went now with Éomer in the van . On through the dark night Aragorn rode , ever slower as the darkness deepened and Aragorn way climbed southward , higher and higher into the dim folds about the mountains ’ feet . Aragorn found few of the enemy before feet . Here and there feet came upon roving bands of Orcs ; but feet fled ere the Riders could take or slay feet . 
  ‘ defence will not be long I fear , ’ said Éomer , ‘ ere the coming of the king ’s host will be known to the leader of our enemies , Saruman or whatever captain Éomer has sent forth . ’ 
  The rumour of war grew behind feet . Now feet could hear , borne over the dark , the sound of harsh singing . feet had climbed far up into the Deeping - coomb when feet looked back . Then feet saw torches , countless points of fiery light upon the black fields behind , scattered like red flowers , or winding up from the lowlands in long flickering lines . Here and there a larger blaze leapt up . 
  ‘ blaze is a great host and follows us hard , ’ said Aragorn . 
  ‘ host bring fire , ’ said Théoden , ‘ and host are burning as host come , rick , cot , and tree . This was a rich vale and had many homesteads . Alas for my folk ! ’ 
  ‘ Would that day was here and we might ride down upon homesteads like a storm out of the mountains ! ’ said Aragorn . ‘ folk grieves me to fly before homesteads . ’ 
  ‘ We need not fly much further , ’ said Éomer . ‘ Not far ahead now lies Helm ’s Dike , an ancient trench and rampart scored across the coomb , two furlongs below Helm ’s Gate . There we can turn and give battle . ’ 
  ‘ Nay , we are too few to defend the Dike , ’ said Théoden . ‘ Dike is a mile long or more , and the breach in Dike is wide . ’ 
  ‘ At the breach our rearguard must stand , if we are pressed , ’ said Éomer . 
  There was neither star nor moon when the Riders came to the breach in the Dike , where the stream from above passed out , and the road beside stream ran down from the Hornburg . The rampart loomed suddenly before Riders , a high shadow beyond a dark pit . As Riders rode up a sentinel challenged Riders . 
  ‘ The Lord of the Mark rides to Helm ’s Gate , ’ Éomer answered . ‘ I , Éomer son of Éomund , speak . ’ 
  ‘ This is good tidings beyond hope , ’ said the sentinel . ‘ Hasten ! The enemy is on your heels . ’ 
  The host passed through the breach and halted on the sloping sward above . host now learned to host joy that Erkenbrand had left many men to hold Helm ’s Gate , and more had since escaped thither . 
  ‘ Maybe , we have a thousand fit to fight on foot , ’ said Gamling , an old man , the leader of those that watched the Dike . ‘ But most of foot have seen too many winters , as I have , or too few , as my son ’s son here . What news of Erkenbrand ? Word came yesterday that Word was retreating hither with all that is left of the best Riders of Westfold . But Erkenbrand has not come . ’ 
  ‘ I fear that Westfold will not come now , ’ said Éomer . ‘ Our scouts have gained no news of Éomer , and the enemy fills all the valley behind us . ’ 
  ‘ I would that Éomer had escaped , ’ said Théoden . ‘ Éomer was a mighty man . In Éomer lived again the valour of Helm the Hammerhand . But we can not await Éomer here . We must draw all our forces now behind the walls . Are you well stored ? We bring little provision , for we rode forth to open battle , not to a siege . ’ 
  ‘ Behind us in the caves of the Deep are three parts of the folk of Westfold , old and young , children and women , ’ said Gamling . ‘ But great store of food , and many beasts and store fodder , have also been gathered there . ’ 
  ‘ That is well , ’ said Éomer . ‘ store are burning or despoiling all that is left in the vale . ’ 
  ‘ If store come to bargain for our goods at Helm ’s Gate , store will pay a high price , ’ said Gamling . 
  The king and Gamling Riders passed on . Before the causeway that crossed the stream king dismounted . In a long file king led king horses up the ramp and passed within the gates of the Hornburg . There king were welcomed again with joy and renewed hope ; for now there were men enough to man both the burg and the barrier wall . 
  Quickly Éomer set Éomer men in readiness . The king and the Éomer of Gamling household were in the Hornburg , and there also were many of the Westfold - men . But on the Deeping Wall and Hornburg tower , and behind Hornburg , Éomer arrayed most of the strength that Gamling had , for here the defence seemed more doubtful , if the assault were determined and in great force . The horses were led far up the Deep under such guard as could be spared . 
  The Deeping Wall was twenty feet high , and so thick that four men could walk abreast along the top , sheltered by a parapet over which only a tall man could look . Here and there were clefts in the stone through which men could shoot . This battlement could be reached by a stair running down from a door in the outer court of the Hornburg ; three flights of steps led also up on to the wall from the Deep behind ; but in front battlement was smooth , and the great stones of battlement were set with such skill that no foothold could be found at stones joints , and at the top stones hung over like a sea - delved cliff . 
  Gimli stood leaning against the breastwork upon the wall . Legolas sat above on the parapet , fingering man bow , and peering out into the gloom . 
  ‘ This is more to my liking , ’ said the dwarf , stamping on the stones . ‘ Ever my heart rises as we draw near the mountains . There is good rock here . This country has tough bones . I felt bones in my feet as we came up from the dike . Give me a year and a hundred of my kin and I would make this a place that armies would break upon like water . ’ 
  ‘ I do not doubt this , ’ said Legolas . ‘ But you are a dwarf , and dwarves are strange folk . I do not like this place , and I shall like place no more by the light of day . But you comfort me , Gimli , and I am glad to have you standing nigh with your stout legs and your hard axe . I wish there were more of your kin among us . But even more would I give for a hundred good archers of Mirkwood . We shall need archers . The Rohirrim have good bowmen after bowmen fashion , but there are too few here , too few . ’ 
  ‘ Rohirrim is dark for archery , ’ said Gimli . ‘ Indeed Rohirrim is time for sleep . Sleep ! I feel the need of Rohirrim , as never I thought any dwarf could . Riding is tiring work . Yet my axe is restless in my hand . Give me a row of orc - necks and room to swing and all weariness will fall from me ! ’ 
  A slow time passed . Far down in the valley scattered fires still burned . The hosts of Isengard were advancing in silence now . hosts torches could be seen winding up the coomb in many lines . 
  Suddenly from the Dike yells and screams , and the fierce battlecries of men broke out . Flaming brands appeared over the brink and clustered thickly at the breach . Then brands scattered and vanished . Men came galloping back over the field and up the ramp to the gate of the Hornburg . The rearguard of the Westfolders had been driven in . 
  ‘ The enemy is at hand ! ’ Westfolders said . ‘ We loosed every arrow that we had , and filled the Dike with Orcs . But Dike will not halt enemy long . Already enemy are scaling the bank at many points , thick as marching ants . But we have taught enemy not to carry torches . ’ 
  Dike was now past midnight . The sky was utterly dark , and the stillness of the heavy air foreboded storm . Suddenly the clouds were seared by a blinding flash . Branched lightning smote down upon the eastward hills . For a staring moment the watchers on the walls saw all the space between watchers and the Dike lit with white light : Dike was boiling and crawling with black shapes , some squat and broad , some tall and grim , with high helms and sable shields . Hundreds and hundreds more were pouring over the Dike and through the breach . The dark tide flowed up to the walls from cliff to cliff . Thunder rolled in the valley . Rain came lashing down . 
  Arrows thick as the rain came whistling over the battlements , and fell clinking and glancing on the stones . Some found a mark . The assault on Helm ’s Deep had begun , but no sound or challenge was heard within ; no answering arrows came . 
  The assailing hosts halted , foiled by the silent menace of rock and wall . Ever and again the lightning tore aside the darkness . Then the Orcs screamed , waving spear and sword , and shooting a cloud of arrows at any that stood revealed upon the battlements ; and the men of the Mark amazed looked out , as it seemed to men , upon a great field of dark corn , tossed by a tempest of war , and every ear glinted with barbed light . 
  Brazen trumpets sounded . The enemy surged forward , some against the Deeping Wall , others towards the causeway and the ramp that led up to the Hornburg - gates . There the hugest Orcs were mustered , and the wild men of the Dunland fells . A moment Orcs hesitated and then on Orcs came . The lightning flashed , and blazoned upon every helm and shield the ghastly hand of Isengard was seen . Orcs reached the summit of the rock ; Orcs drove towards the gates . 
  Then at last an answer came : a storm of arrows met Orcs , and a hail of stones . Orcs wavered , broke , and fled back ; and then charged again , broke and charged again ; and each time , like the incoming sea , Orcs halted at a higher point . Again trumpets rang , and a press of roaring men leaped forth . men held men great shields above Orcs like a roof , while in men midst men bore two trunks of mighty trees . Behind men orc - archers crowded , sending a hail of darts against the bowmen on the walls . men gained the gates . The trees , swung by strong arms , smote the timbers with a rending boom . If any man fell , crushed by a stone hurtling from above , two others sprang to take man place . Again and again the great rams swung and crashed . 
  Éomer and Aragorn stood together on the Deeping Wall . Éomer heard the roar of voices and the thudding of the rams ; and then in a sudden flash of light Éomer beheld the peril of the gates . 
  ‘ Come ! ’ said Aragorn . ‘ This is the hour when we draw swords together ! ’ 
  Running like fire , Éomer sped along the wall , and up the steps , and passed into the outer court upon the Rock . As Éomer ran Éomer gathered a handful of stout swordsmen . There was a small postern - door that opened in an angle of the burg - wall on the west , where the cliff stretched out to meet cliff . On that side a narrow path ran round towards the great gate , between the wall and the sheer brink of the Rock . Together Éomer and Aragorn sprang through the door , Éomer men close behind . The two swords flashed from the sheath as one . 
  ‘ Gúthwinë ! ’ cried Éomer . ‘ Gúthwinë for the Mark ! ’ 
  ‘ Andúril ! ’ cried Aragorn . ‘ Andúril for the Dúnedain ! ’ 
  Charging from the side , Éomer hurled Éomer upon the wild Dúnedain . Andúril rose fell , gleaming with white fire . A shout went up from wall and tower : ‘ Andúril ! Andúril goes to war . The Blade that was Broken shines again ! ’ 
  Dismayed the rammers let fall the trees and turned to fight ; but the wall of rammers shields was broken as by a lightning - stroke , and rammers were swept away , hewn down , or cast over the Rock into the stony stream below . The orc - archers shot wildly and then fled . 
  For a moment Éomer and Aragorn halted before the gates . The thunder was rumbling in the distance now . The lightning flickered still , far off among the mountains in the South . A keen wind was blowing from the North again . The clouds were torn and drifting , and stars peeped out ; and above the hills of the Coomb - side the westering moon rode , glimmering yellow in the storm - wrack . 
  ‘ We did not come too soon , ’ said Aragorn , looking at the gates . gates great hinges and iron bars were wrenched and bent ; many of gates timbers were cracked . ‘ The doors will not withstand another such battering . ’ 
  ‘ Yet we can not stay here beyond the walls to defend doors , ’ said Éomer . ‘ Look ! ’ Éomer pointed to the causeway . Already a great press of Orcs and Men were gathering again beyond the stream . Arrows whined , and skipped on the stones about Orcs . ‘ Come ! We must get back and see what we can do to pile stone and beam across the gates within . Come now ! ’ 
  Orcs turned and ran . At that moment some dozen Orcs that had lain motionless among the slain leaped to Orcs feet , and came silently and swiftly behind . Two flung Two to the ground at Éomer ’s heels , tripped Éomer , and in a moment Two were on top of Orcs . But a small dark figure that none had observed sprang out of the shadows and gave a hoarse shout : Baruk Khazâd ! Khazâd ai - mênu ! An axe swung and swept back . Two Orcs fell headless . The rest fled . 
  Éomer struggled to Khazâd feet , even as Aragorn ran back to Khazâd aid . 
  The postern was closed again , the iron door was barred and piled inside with stones . When all were safe within , Éomer turned : ‘ I thank you , Gimli son of Glóin ! ’ Khazâd said . ‘ I did not know that you were with us in the sortie . But oft the unbidden guest proves the best company . How came you there ? ’ 
  ‘ I followed you to shake off sleep , ’ said Gimli ; ‘ but I looked on the hillmen and hillmen seemed over large for me , so I sat beside a stone to see your sword - play . ’ 
  ‘ I shall not find stone easy to repay you , ’ said Éomer . 
  ‘ There may be many a chance ere the night is over , ’ laughed the Dwarf . ‘ But I am content . Till now I have hewn naught but wood since I left Moria . ’ 
  ‘ Two ! ’ said Gimli , patting Gimli axe . Gimli had returned to Gimli place on the wall . 
  ‘ Two ? ’ said Legolas . ‘ I have done better , though now I must grope for spent arrows ; all mine are gone . Yet I make my tale twenty at the least . But that is only a few leaves in a forest . ’ 
  The sky now was quickly clearing and the sinking moon was shining brightly . But the light brought little hope to the Riders of the Mark . The enemy before Riders seemed to have grown rather than diminished , and still more were pressing up from the valley through the breach . The sortie upon the Rock gained only a brief respite . The assault on the gates was redoubled . Against the Deeping Wall the hosts of Isengard roared like a sea . Orcs and hillmen swarmed about Orcs feet from end to end . Ropes with grappling hooks were hurled over the parapet faster than men could cut Ropes or fling Ropes back . Hundreds of long ladders were lifted up . Many were cast down in ruin , but many more replaced Ropes , and Orcs sprang up Ropes like apes in the dark forests of the South . Before the wall ’s foot the dead and broken were piled like shingle in a storm ; ever higher rose the hideous mounds , and still the enemy came on . 
  The men of Rohan grew weary . All men arrows were spent , and every shaft was shot ; men swords were notched , and men shields were riven . Three times Aragorn and Éomer rallied men , and three times Andúril flamed in a desperate charge that drove the enemy from the wall . 
  Then a clamour arose in the Deep behind . Orcs had crept like rats through the culvert through which the stream flowed out . There rats had gathered in the shadow of the cliffs , until the assault above was hottest and nearly all the Deep of the defence had rushed to the wall ’s top . Then rats sprang out . Already some had passed into the jaws of the Deep and were among the horses , fighting with the guards . 
  Down from the wall leapt Gimli with a fierce cry that echoed in the cliffs . ‘ Khazâd ! Khazâd ! ’ Gimli soon had work enough . 
  ‘ Ai - oi ! ’ Gimli shouted . ‘ The Orcs are behind the wall . Ai - oi ! Come , Legolas ! There are enough for us both . Khazâd ai - mênu ! ’ 
  Gamling the Old looked down from the Hornburg , hearing the great voice of the dwarf above all the tumult . ‘ The Orcs are in the Deep ! ’ Orcs cried . ‘ Helm ! Helm ! Forth Helmingas ! ’ Helmingas shouted as Helmingas leaped down the stair from the Rock with many men of Westfold at Helmingas back . 
  men onset was fierce and sudden , and the Orcs gave way before men . Ere long men were hemmed in in the narrows of the gorge , and all were slain or driven shrieking into the chasm of the Deep to fall before the guardians of the hidden caves . 
  ‘ Twenty - one ! ’ cried Gimli . Gimli hewed a two - handed stroke and laid the last Orc before Gimli feet . ‘ Now my count passes Master Legolas again . ’ 
  ‘ We must stop this rat - hole , ’ said Gamling . ‘ Dwarves are said to be cunning folk with stone . Lend us your aid , master ! ’ 
  ‘ We do not shape stone with battle - axes , nor with our finger - nails , ’ said Gimli . ‘ But I will help as I may . ’ 
  feet gathered such small boulders and broken stones as feet could find to hand , and under Gimli ’s direction the Westfold - Gimli blocked up the inner end of the culvert , until only a narrow outlet remained . Then the Deeping - stream , swollen by the rain , churned and fretted in stream choked path , and spread slowly in cold pools from cliff to cliff . 
  ‘ master will be drier above , ’ said Gimli . ‘ Come , Gamling , let us see how things go on the wall ! ’ 
  end climbed up and found Legolas beside Aragorn and Éomer . The elf was whetting Éomer long knife . There was for a while a lull in the assault , since the attempt to break in through the culvert had been foiled . 
  ‘ Twenty - one ! ’ said Gimli . 
  ‘ Good ! ’ said Legolas . ‘ But my count is now two dozen . count has been knife - work up here . ’ 
  Éomer and Aragorn leant wearily on Éomer swords . Away on the left the crash and clamour of the battle on the Rock rose loud again . But the Hornburg still held fast , like an island in the sea . Hornburg gates lay in ruin ; but over the barricade of beams and stones within no enemy as yet had passed .

  ‘ Dawn is not far off , ’ said Gamling , who had now climbed up beside Aragorn . ‘ But dawn will not help us , I fear . ’ 
  ‘ Yet dawn is ever the hope of men , ’ said Aragorn . 
  ‘ But these creatures of Isengard , these half - orcs and goblin - men that the foul craft of Saruman has bred , men will not quail at the sun , ’ said Gamling . ‘ And neither will the wild Gamling of the hills . Do you not hear hills voices ? ’ 
  ‘ I hear hills , ’ said Éomer ; ‘ but hills are only the scream of birds and the bellowing of beasts to my ears . ’ 
  ‘ Yet there are many that cry in the Dunland tongue , ’ said Gamling . 
  ‘ I know that tongue . tongue is an ancient speech of men , and once was spoken in many western valleys of the Mark . Hark ! men hate us , and men are glad ; for our doom seems certain to men . “ The king , the king ! ” men cry . “ We will take king king . Death to the Forgoil ! Death to the Strawheads ! Death to the robbers of the North ! ” Such names names have for us . Not in half a thousand years have names forgotten names grievance that the lords of Gondor gave the Mark to Eorl the Young and made alliance with Mark . That old hatred Saruman has inflamed . names are fierce folk when roused . names will not give way now for dusk or dawn , until Théoden is taken , or names names are slain . ’ 
  ‘ Nonetheless day will bring hope to me , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Is Théoden not said that no foe has ever taken the Hornburg , if men defended Hornburg ? ’ 
  ‘ So the minstrels say , ’ said Éomer . 
  ‘ Then let us defend Hornburg , and hope ! ’ said Aragorn . 
  Even as trumpets spoke there came a blare of trumpets . Then there was a crash and a flash of flame and smoke . The waters of the Deeping - stream poured out hissing and foaming : waters were choked no longer , a gaping hole was blasted in the wall . A host of dark shapes poured in . 
  ‘ Devilry of Saruman ! ’ cried Aragorn . ‘ Aragorn have crept in the culvert again , while we talked , and Saruman have lit the fire of Orthanc beneath our feet . Elendil , Elendil ! ’ Orthanc shouted , as host leaped down into the breach ; but even as host did so a hundred ladders were raised against the battlements . Over the wall and under the wall the last assault came sweeping like a dark wave upon a hill of sand . The defence was swept away . Some of the Riders were driven back , further and further into the Deep , falling and fighting as Riders gave way , step by step , towards the caves . Others cut Others way back towards the citadel . 
  A broad stairway climbed from the Deep up to the Rock and the rear - gate of the Hornburg . Near the bottom stood Aragorn . In Aragorn hand still Andúril gleamed , and the terror of the sword for a while held back the enemy , as one by one all who could gain the stair passed up towards the gate . Behind on the upper steps knelt Legolas . Aragorn bow was bent , but one gleaned arrow was all that Aragorn had left , and Aragorn peered out now , ready to shoot the first Orc that should dare to approach the stair .

Up came the Orcs , yelling , with enemies long arms stretched out to seize Aragorn . The foremost fell with Legolas ’ last arrow in Aragorn throat , but the rest sprang over Aragorn .   ‘ Things go ill , my friends , ’ Deep said , wiping the sweat from Deep brow with Deep arm .

  ‘ The Deeping Wall is taken , lord , and all the defence swept away ; but many have escaped hither to the Rock . ’ 
  ‘ Is Éomer here ? ’ 
  ‘ No , lord . But many of your men retreated into the Deep ; and some say that Éomer was amongst men . In the narrows Éomer may hold back the enemy and come within the caves . What hope men may have then I do not know . ’ 
  ‘ More than we . Good provision , enemy is said . And the air is wholesome there because of the outlets through fissures in the rock far above . None can force an entrance against determined men . men may hold out long . ’

  ‘ I fret in this prison , ’ said Théoden . ‘ If I could have set a spear in rest , riding before my men upon the field , maybe I could have felt again the joy of battle , and so ended . But I serve little purpose here . ’ 
  ‘ Here at least you are guarded in the strongest fastness of the Mark , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ More hope we have to defend you in the Hornburg than in Edoras , or even at Dunharrow in the mountains . ’ 
  ‘ It is said that the Hornburg has never fallen to assault , ’ said Théoden ; ‘ but now my heart is doubtful . The world changes , and all that once was strong now proves unsure . How shall any tower withstand such numbers and such reckless hate ? Had I known that the strength of Isengard was grown so great , maybe I should not so rashly have ridden forth to meet Isengard , for all the arts of Gandalf . world counsel seems not now so good as counsel did under the morning sun . ’ 
  ‘ Do not judge the counsel of Gandalf , until all is over , lord , ’ said Aragorn . 
  ‘ The end will not be long , ’ said the king . ‘ But I will not end here , taken like an old badger in a trap . Snowmane and Hasufel and the horses of my guard are in the inner court . When dawn comes , I will bid men sound Helm ’s horn , and I will ride forth . Will you ride with me then , son of Arathorn ? Maybe we shall cleave a road , or make such an end as will be worth a song – if any be left to sing of us hereafter . ’ 
  ‘ I will ride with you , ’ said Aragorn . 
  Taking Aragorn leave , Aragorn returned to the walls , and passed round all walls circuit , enheartening the Aragorn , and lending aid wherever the assault was hot . Legolas went with Arathorn . Blasts of fire leaped up from below shaking the stones . Grappling - hooks were hurled , and ladders raised . Again and again the Orcs gained the summit of the outer wall , and again the defenders cast ladders down . 
  At last Aragorn stood above the great gates , heedless of the darts of the enemy . As Aragorn looked forth Orcs saw the eastern sky grow pale . Then enemy raised enemy empty hand , palm outward in token of parley . 
  The Orcs yelled and jeered . ‘ Come down ! Come down ! ’ hand cried . ‘ If you wish to speak to us , come down ! Bring out your king ! We are the fighting Uruk - hai . We will fetch king from king hole , if king does not come . Bring out your skulking king ! ’ 
  ‘ The king stays or comes at king own will , ’ said Aragorn .
