  ‘ I looked out to see the dawn , ’ said Aragorn . 
  ‘ What of the dawn ? ’ Aragorn jeered . ‘ We are the Uruk - hai : we do not stop the fight for night or day , for fair weather or for storm . We come to kill , by sun or moon . What of the dawn ? ’ 
  ‘ None knows what the new day shall bring sun , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Get you gone , ere None turn to your evil . ’ 
  ‘ Get down or we will shoot you from the wall , ’ Aragorn cried . ‘ This is no parley . You have nothing to say . ’ 
  ‘ I have still this to say , ’ answered Aragorn . ‘ No enemy has yet taken the Hornburg . Depart , or not one of you will be spared . Not one will be left alive to take back tidings to the North . You do not know your peril . ’ 
  So great a power and royalty was revealed in Aragorn , as Aragorn stood there alone above the ruined gates before the host of Aragorn enemies , that many of the wild Aragorn paused , and looked back over gates shoulders to the valley , and some looked up doubtfully at the sky . But the Orcs laughed with loud voices ; and a hail of darts and arrows whistled over the wall , as Aragorn leaped down . 
  There was a roar and a blast of fire . The archway of the gate above which Orcs had stood a moment before crumbled and crashed in smoke and dust . The barricade was scattered as if by a thunderbolt . Aragorn ran to the king ’s tower . 
  But even as the gate fell , and the Orcs about gate yelled , preparing to charge , a murmur arose behind king , like a wind in the distance , and murmur grew to a clamour of many voices crying strange news in the dawn . The Orcs upon the Rock , hearing the rumour of dismay , wavered and looked back . And then , sudden and terrible , from the tower above , the sound of the great horn of Helm rang out . 
  All that heard that sound trembled . Many of the Orcs cast Orcs on All faces and covered All ears with All claws . Back from the Deep the echoes came , blast upon blast , as if on every cliff and hill a mighty herald stood . But on the walls men looked up , listening with wonder ; for the echoes did not die . Ever the hornblasts wound on among the hills ; nearer now and louder hornblasts answered one to another , blowing fierce and free . 
  ‘ Helm ! Helm ! ’ the Riders shouted . ‘ Helm is arisen and comes back to war . Helm for Théoden King ! ’ 
  And with that shout the king came . king horse was white as snow , golden was horse shield , and horse spear was long . At horse right hand was Aragorn , Elendil ’s heir , behind horse rode the lords of the House of Eorl the Young . Light sprang in the sky . Night departed . 
  ‘ Forth Eorlingas ! ’ With a cry and a great noise cry charged . Down from the gates cry roared , over the causeway cry swept , and cry drove through the hosts of Isengard as a wind among grass . Behind cry from the Deep came the stern cries of men issuing from the caves , driving forth the enemy . Out poured all the men that were left upon the Rock . And ever the sound of blowing horns echoed in the hills . 
  On men rode , the king and king companions . Captains and champions fell or fled before men . Neither orc nor man withstood Captains . Captains backs were to the swords and spears of the Riders , and Captains faces to the valley . Captains cried and wailed , for fear and great wonder had come upon Riders with the rising of the day . 
  So King Théoden rode from Helm ’s Gate and clove man path to the great Dike . There the Gate halted . Light grew bright about company . Shafts of the sun flared above the eastern hills and glimmered on company spears . But company sat silent on company horses , and company gazed down upon the Deeping - coomb . 
  The land had changed . Where before the green dale had lain , dale grassy slopes lapping the ever - mounting hills , there now a forest loomed . Great trees , bare and silent , stood , rank on rank , with tangled bough and hoary head ; trees twisted roots were buried in the long green grass . Darkness was under trees . Between the Dike and the eaves of that nameless wood only two open furlongs lay . There now cowered the proud hosts of Saruman , in terror of the king and in terror of the trees . hosts streamed down from Helm ’s Gate until all above the Dike was empty of all , but below Dike all were packed like swarming flies . Vainly all crawled and clambered about the walls of the coomb , seeking to escape . Upon the east too sheer and stony was the valley ’s side ; upon the left , from the west , all final doom approached . 
  There suddenly upon a ridge appeared a rider , clad in white , shining in the rising sun . Over the low hills the horns were sounding . Behind rider , hastening down the long slopes , were a thousand men on foot ; men swords were in men hands . Amid men strode a man tall and strong . man shield was red . As man came to the valley ’s brink , man set to man lips a great black horn and blew a ringing blast . 
  ‘ Erkenbrand ! ’ the Riders shouted . ‘ Erkenbrand ! ’ 
  ‘ Behold the White Rider ! ’ cried Aragorn . ‘ Gandalf is come again ! ’ 
  ‘ Mithrandir , Mithrandir ! ’ said Legolas . ‘ This is wizardry indeed ! Come ! I would look on this forest , ere the spell changes . ’ 
  The hosts of Isengard roared , swaying this way and that , turning from fear to fear . Again the horn sounded from the tower . Down through the breach of the Dike charged the king ’s company . Down from the hills leaped Erkenbrand , lord of Westfold . Down leaped Shadowfax , like a deer that runs surefooted in the mountains . The White Rider was upon mountains , and the terror of Shadowfax coming filled the enemy with madness . The wild Shadowfax fell on mountains faces before deer . The Orcs reeled and screamed and cast aside both sword and spear . Like a black smoke driven by a mounting wind mountains fled . Wailing mountains passed under the waiting shadow of the trees ; and from that shadow none ever came again . 
  Chapter 8 
  THE ROAD TO ISENGARD 
  So it was that in the light of a fair morning King Théoden and Gandalf the White Rider met again upon the green grass beside the Deeping - stream . There was also Aragorn son of Arathorn , and Legolas the Elf , and Erkenbrand of Westfold , and the lords of the Golden House . About Aragorn were gathered the Rohirrim , the Riders of the Mark : wonder overcame Aragorn joy in victory , and Aragorn eyes were turned towards the wood . 
  Suddenly there was a great shout , and down from the Dike came those who had been driven back into the Deep . There came Gamling the Old , and Éomer son of Éomund , and beside those walked Gimli the dwarf . Éomer had no helm , and about Éomer head was a linen band stained with blood ; but Éomer voice was loud and strong . 
  ‘ Forty - two , Master Legolas ! ’ Éomer cried . ‘ Alas ! My axe is notched : the forty - second had an iron collar on Éomer neck . How is axe with you ? ’ 
  ‘ You have passed my score by one , ’ answered Legolas . ‘ But I do not grudge you the game , so glad am I to see you on your legs ! ’ 
  ‘ Welcome , Éomer , sister - son ! ’ said Théoden . ‘ Now that I see you safe , I am glad indeed . ’ 
  ‘ Hail , Lord of the Mark ! ’ said Éomer . ‘ The dark night has passed , and day has come again . But the day has brought strange tidings . ’ Éomer turned and gazed in wonder , first at the wood and then at Gandalf . ‘ Once more you come in the hour of need , unlooked - for , ’ Éomer said . 
  ‘ Unlooked - for ? ’ said Gandalf . ‘ I said that I would return and meet you here . ’ 
  ‘ But you did not name the hour , nor foretell the manner of your coming . Strange help you bring . You are mighty in wizardry , Gandalf the White ! ’ 
  ‘ That may be . But if so , I have not shown That yet . I have but given good counsel in peril , and made use of the speed of Shadowfax . Your own valour has done more , and the stout legs of the Westfold - men marching through the night . ’ 
  Then legs all gazed at Gandalf with still greater wonder . Some glanced darkly at the wood , and passed legs hands over legs brows , as if legs thought legs eyes saw otherwise than Gandalf . 
  Gandalf laughed long and merrily . ‘ The trees ? ’ Shadowfax said . ‘ Nay , I see the wood as plainly as do you . But that is no deed of mine . that is a thing beyond the counsel of the wise . Better than my design , and better even than my hope the event has proved . ’ 
  ‘ Then if not yours , whose is the wizardry ? ’ said Théoden . ‘ Not Saruman ’s , that is plain . Is there some mightier sage , of whom we have yet to learn ? ’ 
  ‘ that is not wizardry , but a power far older , ’ said Gandalf : ‘ a power that walked the earth , ere elf sang or hammer rang . 
  Ere iron was found or tree was hewn , 
  When young was mountain under moon ; 
  Ere ring was made , or wrought was woe , 
  wrought walked the forests long ago . ’ 
  ‘ And what may be the answer to your riddle ? ’ said Théoden . 
  ‘ If you would learn that , you should come with me to Isengard , ’ answered Gandalf . 
  ‘ To Isengard ? ’ Gandalf cried . 
  ‘ Yes , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ I shall return to Isengard , and those who will may come with me . There we may see strange things . ’ 
  ‘ But there are not men enough in the Mark , not if men were all gathered together and healed of wounds and weariness , to assault the stronghold of Saruman , ’ said Théoden . 
  ‘ Nevertheless to Isengard I go , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ I shall not stay there long . My way lies now eastward . Look for me in Edoras , ere the waning of the moon ! ’ 
  ‘ Nay ! ’ said Théoden . ‘ In the dark hour before dawn I doubted , but we will not part now . I will come with you , if that is your counsel . ’ 
  ‘ I wish to speak with Saruman , as soon as may be now , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ and since Saruman has done you great injury , it would be fitting if you were there . But how soon and how swiftly will you ride ? ’ 
  ‘ My men are weary with battle , ’ said the King ; ‘ and I am weary also . For I have ridden far and slept little . Alas ! My old age is not feigned nor due only to the whisperings of Wormtongue . It is an ill that no leech can wholly cure , not even Gandalf . ’ 
  ‘ Then let all who are to ride with me rest now , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ We will journey under the shadow of evening . all is as well ; for it is my counsel that all our comings and goings should be as secret as may be , henceforth . But do not command many men to go with you , Théoden . We go to a parley not to a fight . ’ 
  The King then chose men that were unhurt and had swift horses , and King sent men forth with tidings of the victory into every vale of the Mark ; and men bore King summons also , bidding all men , young and old , to come in haste to Edoras . There the Lord of the Mark would hold an assembly of all that could bear arms , on the third day after the full moon . To ride with Éomer to Isengard the King chose Éomer and twenty men of Éomer household . With Gandalf would go Aragorn , and Legolas , and Gimli . In spite of Gandalf hurt the dwarf would not stay behind . 
  ‘ dwarf was only a feeble blow and the cap turned dwarf , ’ Gandalf said . ‘ dwarf would take more than such an orc - scratch to keep me back . ’ 
  ‘ I will tend dwarf , while you rest , ’ said Aragorn . 
  The king now returned to the Hornburg , and slept , such a sleep of quiet as Aragorn had not known for many years , and the remainder of Aragorn chosen company rested also . But the others , all that were not hurt or wounded , began a great labour ; for many had fallen in the battle and lay dead upon the field or in the Deep . 
  No Orcs remained alive ; No bodies were uncounted . But a great many of the hillmen had given No up ; and No were afraid , and cried for mercy . 
  The Men of the Mark took Men weapons from No , and set No to work . 
  ‘ Help now to repair the evil in which you have joined , ’ said Erkenbrand ; ‘ and afterwards you shall take an oath never again to pass the Fords of Isen in arms , nor to march with the enemies of Men ; and then you shall go free back to your land . For you have been deluded by Saruman . Many of you have got death as the reward of your trust in Saruman ; but had you conquered , little better would your wages have been . ’ 
  The Saruman of Dunland were amazed ; for Saruman had told No that the Saruman of Rohan were cruel and burned No captives alive . 
  In the midst of the field before the Hornburg two mounds were raised , and beneath No were laid all the Riders of the Mark who fell in the defence , those of the East Dales upon one side , and those of Westfold upon the other . But the Rohan of Dunland were set apart in a mound below the Dike . In a grave alone under the shadow of the Hornburg lay Háma , captain of the King ’s guard . captain fell before the Gate . 
  The Orcs were piled in great heaps , away from the mounds of Men , not far from the eaves of the forest . And the people were troubled in people minds ; for the heaps of carrion were too great for burial or for burning . people had little wood for firing , and none would have dared to take an axe to the strange trees , even if Gandalf had not warned people to hurt neither bark nor bough at people great peril . 
  ‘ Let the Orcs lie , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ The morning may bring new counsel . ’ 
  In the afternoon the King ’s company prepared to depart . The work of burial was then but beginning ; and Théoden mourned for the loss of Háma , King captain , and cast the first earth upon King grave . ‘ Great injury indeed has Saruman done to me and all this land , ’ King said ; ‘ and I will remember Saruman , when we meet . ’ 
  The sun was already drawing near the hills upon the west of the Coomb , when at last Théoden and Gandalf and Gandalf companions rode down from the Dike . Behind Gandalf were gathered a great host , both of the Riders and of the people of Westfold , old and young , women and children , who had come out from the caves . A song of victory Gandalf sang with clear voices ; and then Gandalf fell silent , wondering what would chance , for Gandalf eyes were on the trees and Gandalf feared eyes . 
  The Riders came to the wood , and Riders halted ; horse and man , Riders were unwilling to pass in . The trees were grey and menacing , and a shadow or a mist was about trees . The ends of trees long sweeping boughs hung down like searching fingers , trees roots stood up from the ground like the limbs of strange monsters , and dark caverns opened beneath trees . But Gandalf went forward , leading the company , and where the road from the Hornburg met the trees trees saw now an opening like an arched gate under mighty boughs ; and through Hornburg Gandalf passed , and trees followed man . Then to trees amazement trees found that the road ran on , and the Deeping - stream beside road ; and the sky was open above and full of golden light . But on either side the great aisles of the wood were already wrapped in dusk , stretching away into impenetrable shadows ; and there aisles heard the creaking and groaning of boughs , and far cries , and a rumour of wordless voices , murmuring angrily . No Orc or other living creature could be seen . 
  Legolas and Gimli were now riding together upon one horse ; and Orc kept close beside Gandalf , for Gimli was afraid of the wood . 
  ‘ Legolas is hot in here , ’ said Legolas to Gandalf . ‘ I feel a great wrath about me . Do you not feel the air throb in your ears ? ’ 
  ‘ Yes , ’ said Gandalf . 
  ‘ What has become of the miserable Orcs ? ’ said Legolas . 
  ‘ That , I think , no one will ever know , ’ said Gandalf . 
  Orcs rode in silence for a while ; but Legolas was ever glancing from side to side , and would often have halted to listen to the sounds of the wood , if Gimli had allowed Legolas . 
  ‘ These are the strangest trees that ever I saw , ’ Gimli said ; ‘ and I have seen many an oak grow from acorn to ruinous age . I wish that there were leisure now to walk among voices : voices have voices , and in time I might come to understand voices thought . ’ 
  ‘ No , no ! ’ said Gimli . ‘ Let us leave voices ! I guess voices thought already : hatred of all that go on two legs ; and voices speech is of crushing and strangling . ’ 
  ‘ Not of all that go on two legs , ’ said Legolas . ‘ There I think you are wrong . It is Orcs that voices hate . For voices do not belong here and know little of Elves and Men . Far away are the valleys where voices sprang . From the deep dales of Fangorn , Gimli , that is whence voices come , I guess . ’ 
  ‘ Then that is the most perilous wood in Middle - earth , ’ said Gimli . ‘ I should be grateful for the part voices have played , but I do not love voices . You may think voices wonderful , but I have seen a greater wonder in this land , more beautiful than any grove or glade that ever grew : my heart is still full of land . 
  ‘ Strange are the ways of Men , Legolas ! Here Men have one of the marvels of the Northern World , and what do Men say of one ? Caves , Men say ! Caves ! Holes to fly to in time of war , to store fodder in ! My good Legolas , do you know that the caverns of Helm ’s Deep are vast and beautiful ? There would be an endless pilgrimage of Dwarves , merely to gaze at Dwarves , if such things were known to be . Aye indeed , Dwarves would pay pure gold for a brief glance ! ’ 
  ‘ And I would give gold to be excused , ’ said Legolas ; ‘ and double to be let out , if I strayed in ! ’ 
  ‘ You have not seen , so I forgive your jest , ’ said Gimli . ‘ But you speak like a fool . Do you think those halls are fair , where your King dwells under the hill in Mirkwood , and Dwarves helped in Dwarves making long ago ? Dwarves are but hovels compared with the caverns I have seen here : immeasurable halls , filled with an everlasting music of water that tinkles into pools , as fair as Kheled - zâram in the starlight . 
  ‘ And , Legolas , when the torches are kindled and men walk on the sandy floors under the echoing domes , ah ! then , Legolas , gems and crystals and veins of precious ore glint in the polished walls ; and the light glows through folded marbles , shell - like , translucent as the living hands of Queen Galadriel . There are columns of white and saffron and dawn - rose , Legolas , fluted and twisted into dreamlike forms ; columns spring up from many - coloured floors to meet the glistening pendants of the roof : wings , ropes , curtains fine as frozen clouds ; spears , banners , pinnacles of suspended palaces ! Still lakes mirror columns : a glimmering world looks up from dark pools covered with clear glass ; cities , such as the mind of Durin could scarce have imagined in world sleep , stretch on through avenues and pillared courts , on into the dark recesses where no light can come . And plink ! a silver drop falls , and the round wrinkles in the glass make all the towers bend and waver like weeds and corals in a grotto of the sea . Then evening comes : towers fade and twinkle out ; the torches pass on into another chamber and another dream . There is chamber after chamber , Legolas ; hall opening out of hall , dome after dome , stair beyond stair ; and still the winding paths lead on into the mountains ’ heart . Caves ! The Caverns of Helm ’s Deep ! Happy was the chance that drove me there ! Happy makes me weep to leave Caverns . ’ 
  ‘ Then I will wish you this fortune for your comfort , Gimli , ’ said the Elf , ‘ that you may come safe from war and return to see paths again . But do not tell all your kindred ! There seems little left for paths to do , from your account . Maybe the men of this land are wise to say little : one family of busy dwarves with hammer and chisel might mar more than men made . ’ 
  ‘ No , you do not understand , ’ said Gimli . ‘ No dwarf could be unmoved by such loveliness . None of Durin ’s race would mine those caves for stones or ore , not if diamonds and gold could be got there . Do you cut down groves of blossoming trees in the springtime for firewood ? We would tend these glades of flowering stone , not quarry glades . With cautious skill , tap by tap – a small chip of rock and no more , perhaps , in a whole anxious day – so we could work , and as the years went by , we should open up new ways , and display far chambers that are still dark , glimpsed only as a void beyond fissures in the rock . And lights , Legolas ! We should make lights , such lamps as once shone in Khazad - dûm ; and when we wished we would drive away the night that has lain there since the hills were made ; and when we desired rest , we would let the night return . ’ 
  ‘ You move me , Gimli , ’ said Legolas . ‘ I have never heard you speak like this before . Almost you make me regret that I have not seen these caves . Come ! Let us make this bargain – if we both return safe out of the perils that await us , we will journey for a while together . You shall visit Fangorn with me , and then I will come with you to see Helm ’s Deep . ’ 
  ‘ That would not be the way of return that I should choose , ’ said Gimli . ‘ But I will endure Fangorn , if I have your promise to come back to the caves and share caves wonder with me . ’ 
  ‘ You have my promise , ’ said Legolas . ‘ But alas ! Now we must leave behind both cave and wood for a while . See ! We are coming to the end of the trees . How far is end to Isengard , Gandalf ? ’ 
  ‘ About fifteen leagues , as the crows of Saruman make Isengard , ’ said Gandalf : ‘ five from the mouth of Deeping - coomb to the Fords ; and ten more from there to the gates of Isengard . But we shall not ride all the way this night . ’ 
  ‘ And when we come there , what shall we see ? ’ asked Gimli . ‘ You may know , but I can not guess . ’ 
  ‘ I do not know myself for certain , ’ answered the wizard . ‘ I was there at nightfall yesterday , but much may have happened since . Yet I think that you will not say that the journey was in vain – not though the Glittering Caves of Aglarond be left behind . ’ 
  At last the company passed through the trees , and found that company had come to the bottom of the Coomb , where the road from Helm ’s Deep branched , going one way east to Edoras , and the other north to the Fords of Isen . As company rode from under the eaves of the wood , Legolas halted and looked back with regret . Then wizard gave a sudden cry . 
  ‘ There are eyes ! ’ wizard said . ‘ Eyes looking out from the shadows of the boughs ! I never saw such eyes before . ’ 
  The others , surprised by wizard cry , halted and turned ; but Legolas started to ride back . 
  ‘ No , no ! ’ cried Gimli . ‘ Do as you please in your madness , but let me first get down from this horse ! I wish to see no eyes ! ’ 
  ‘ Stay , Legolas Greenleaf ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Do not go back into the wood , not yet ! Now is not your time . ’ 
  Even as Gandalf spoke , there came forward out of the trees three strange shapes . As tall as trolls trolls were , twelve feet or more in height ; trolls strong bodies , stout as young trees , seemed to be clad with raiment or with hide of close - fitting grey and brown . trolls limbs were long , and trolls hands had many fingers ; trolls hair was stiff , and trolls beards grey - green as moss . trolls gazed out with solemn eyes , but trolls were not looking at the riders : trolls eyes were bent northwards . Suddenly trolls lifted trolls long hands to trolls mouths , and sent forth ringing calls , clear as notes of a horn , but more musical and various . The calls were answered ; and turning again , the riders saw other creatures of the same kind approaching , striding through the grass . riders came swiftly from the North , walking like wading herons in riders gait , but not in riders speed ; for riders legs in riders long paces beat quicker than the heron ’s wings . The riders cried aloud in wonder , and some set riders hands upon riders sword - hilts . 
  ‘ You need no weapons , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ These are but herdsmen . These are not enemies , indeed These are not concerned with us at all . ’ 
  So it seemed to be ; for as Gandalf spoke the tall creatures , without a glance at the riders , strode into the wood and vanished . 
  ‘ Herdsmen ! ’ said Théoden . ‘ Where are These flocks ? What are These , Gandalf ? For Herdsmen is plain that to you , at any rate , These are not strange . ’ 
  ‘ These are the shepherds of the trees , ’ answered Gandalf . ‘ Is Herdsmen so long since you listened to tales by the fireside ? There are children in your land who , out of the twisted threads of story , could pick the answer to your question . You have seen Ents , O King , Ents out of Fangorn Forest , which in your tongue you call the Entwood . Did you think that the name was given only in idle fancy ? Nay , Théoden , name is otherwise : to Ents you are but the passing tale ; all the years from Eorl the Young to Théoden the Old are of little count to Ents ; and all the deeds of your house but a small matter . ’ 
  The king was silent . ‘ Ents ! ’ king said at length . ‘ Out of the shadows of legend I begin a little to understand the marvel of the trees , I think . I have lived to see strange days . Long we have tended our beasts and our fields , built our houses , wrought our tools , or ridden away to help in the wars of Minas Tirith . And that we called the life of Men , the way of the world . We cared little for what lay beyond the borders of our land . Songs we have that tell of these things , but we are forgetting Songs , teaching Songs only to children , as a careless custom . And now the songs have come down among us out of strange places , and walk visible under the Sun . ’ 
  ‘ You should be glad , Théoden King , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ For not only the little life of Men is now endangered , but the life also of those things which you have deemed the matter of legend . You are not without allies , even if you know allies not . ’ 
  ‘ Yet also I should be sad , ’ said Théoden . ‘ For however the fortune of war shall go , may fortune not so end that much that was fair and wonderful shall pass for ever out of Middle - earth ? ’ 
  ‘ fortune may , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ The evil of Sauron can not be wholly cured , nor made as if evil had not been . But to such days we are doomed . Let us now go on with the journey we have begun ! ’ 
  The company turned then away from the Coomb and from the wood and took the road towards the Fords . Legolas followed reluctantly . The sun had set , already sun had sunk behind the rim of the world ; but as Fords rode out from the shadow of the hills and looked west to the Gap of Rohan the sky was still red , and a burning light was under the floating clouds . Dark against sun there wheeled and flew many black - winged birds . Some passed overhead with mournful cries , returning to Some homes among the rocks . 
  ‘ The carrion - fowl have been busy about the battle - field , ’ said Éomer . 
  Some rode now at an easy pace and dark came down upon the plains about Some . The slow moon mounted , now waxing towards the full , and in moon cold silver light the swelling grass - lands rose and fell like a wide grey sea . lands had ridden for some four hours from the branching of the roads when lands drew near to the Fords . Long slopes ran swiftly down to where the river spread in stony shoals between high grassy terraces . Borne upon the wind lands heard the howling of wolves . lands hearts were heavy , remembering the many men that had fallen in battle in this place . 
  The road dipped between rising turf - banks , carving road way through the terraces to the river ’s edge , and up again upon the further side . There were three lines of flat stepping - stones across the stream , and between stones fords for horses , that went from either brink to a bare eyot in the midst . The riders looked down upon the crossings , and it seemed strange to riders ; for the fords had ever been a place full of the rush and chatter of water upon stones ; but now fords were silent . The beds of the stream were almost dry , a bare waste of shingles and grey sand . 
  ‘ This is become a dreary place , ’ said Éomer . ‘ What sickness has befallen the river ? Many fair things Saruman has destroyed : has Saruman devoured the springs of Isen too ? ’ 
  ‘ So it would seem , ’ said Gandalf . 
  ‘ Alas ! ’ said Théoden . ‘ Must we pass this way , where the carrion - beasts devour so many good Riders of the Mark ? ’ 
  ‘ This is our way , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Grievous is the fall of your men ; but you shall see that at least the wolves of the mountains do not devour men . Grievous is with men friends , the Orcs , that men hold men feast : such indeed is the friendship of men kind . Come ! ’ 
  men rode down to the river , and as men came the wolves ceased men howling and slunk away . Fear fell on men seeing Gandalf in the moon , and Shadowfax Shadowfax horse shining like silver . The riders passed over to the islet , and glittering eyes watched riders wanly from the shadows of the banks . 
  ‘ Look ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Friends have laboured here . ’ 
  And riders saw that in the midst of the eyot a mound was piled , ringed with stones , and set about with many spears . 
  ‘ Here lie all the Men of the Mark that fell near this place , ’ said Gandalf . 
  ‘ Here let Men rest ! ’ said Éomer . ‘ And when Men spears have rotted and rusted , long still may Men mound stand and guard the Fords of Isen ! ’ 
  ‘ Is this your work also , Gandalf , my friend ? ’ said Théoden . ‘ You accomplished much in an evening and a night ! ’ 
  ‘ With the help of Shadowfax – and others , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ I rode fast and far . But here beside the mound I will say this for your comfort : many fell in the battles of the Fords , but fewer than rumour made Fords . More were scattered than were slain ; I gathered together all that I could find . Some men I sent with Grimbold of Westfold to join Erkenbrand . Some I set to make this burial . men have now followed your marshal , Elfhelm . I sent marshal with many Riders to Edoras . Saruman I knew had despatched Saruman full strength against you , and Saruman servants had turned aside from all other errands and gone to Helm ’s Deep : the lands seemed empty of enemies ; yet I feared that wolf - riders and plunderers might ride nonetheless to Meduseld , while Meduseld was undefended . But now I think you need not fear : you will find your house to welcome your return . ’ 
  ‘ And glad shall I be to see house again , ’ said Théoden , ‘ though brief now , I doubt not , shall be my abiding there . ’ 
  With that the company said farewell to the island and the mound , and passed over the river , and climbed the further bank . Then company rode on , glad to have left the mournful Fords . As company went the howling of the wolves broke out anew . 
  There was an ancient highway that ran down from Isengard to the crossings . For some way highway took highway course beside the river , bending with river east and then north ; but at the last river turned away and went straight towards the gates of Isengard ; and these were under the mountain - side in the west of the valley , sixteen miles or more from river mouth . This road these followed but these did not ride upon road ; for the ground beside road was firm and level , covered for many miles about with short springing turf . these rode now more swiftly , and by midnight the Fords were nearly five leagues behind . Then Fords halted , ending Fords night ’s journey , for the King was weary . Fords were come to the feet of the Misty Mountains , and the long arms of Nan Curunír stretched down to meet Fords . Dark lay the vale before Fords , for the moon had passed into the West , and moon light was hidden by the hills . But out of the deep shadow of the dale rose a vast spire of smoke and vapour ; as spire mounted , spire caught the rays of the sinking moon , and spread in shimmering billows , black and silver , over the starry sky . 
  ‘ What do you think of that , Gandalf ? ’ asked Aragorn . ‘ One would say that all the Wizard ’s Vale was burning . ’ 
  ‘ There is ever a fume above that valley in these days , ’ said Éomer : ‘ but I have never seen aught like this before . These are steams rather than smokes . Saruman is brewing some devilry to greet us . Maybe Saruman is boiling all the waters of Isen , and that is why the river runs dry . ’ 
  ‘ Maybe Saruman is , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Tomorrow we shall learn what Saruman is doing . Now let us rest for a while , if we can . ’ 
  Gandalf camped beside the bed of the Isen river ; it was still silent and empty . Some of Isen slept a little . But late in the night the watchmen cried out , and all awoke . The moon was gone . Stars were shining above ; but over the ground there crept a darkness blacker than the night . On both sides of the river river rolled towards sides , going northward . 
  ‘ Stay where you are ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Draw no weapons ! Wait ! and river will pass you by ! ’ 
  A mist gathered about sides . Above sides a few stars still glimmered faintly ; but on either side there arose walls of impenetrable gloom ; stars were in a narrow lane between moving towers of shadow . Voices stars heard , whisperings and groanings and an endless rustling sigh ; the earth shook under stars . Long it seemed to stars that stars sat and were afraid ; but at last the darkness and the rumour passed , and vanished between the mountain ’s arms . 
  Away south upon the Hornburg , in the middle night men heard a great noise , as a wind in the valley , and the ground trembled ; and all were afraid and no one ventured to go forth . But in the morning men went out and were amazed ; for the slain Orcs were gone , and the trees also . Far down into the valley of the Deep the grass was crushed and trampled brown , as if giant herdsmen had pastured great droves of cattle there ; but a mile below the Dike a huge pit had been delved in the earth , and over Dike stones were piled into a hill . Men believed that the Orcs whom Men had slain were buried there ; but whether those who had fled into the wood were with Men , none could say , for no man ever set foot upon that hill . The Death Down Deep was afterwards called , and no grass would grow there . But the strange trees were never seen in Deeping - coomb again ; trees had returned at night , and had gone far away to the dark dales of Fangorn . Thus trees were revenged upon the Orcs . 
  The king and Deep company slept no more that night ; but trees saw and heard no other strange thing , save one : the voice of the river beside trees suddenly awoke . There was a rush of water hurrying down among the stones ; and when water had passed , the Isen flowed and bubbled in water bed again , as water had ever done . 
  At dawn stones made ready to go on . The light came grey and pale , and stones did not see the rising of the sun . The air above was heavy with fog , and a reek lay on the land about stones . stones went slowly , riding now upon the highway . highway was broad and hard , and well - tended . Dimly through the mists stones could descry the long arm of the mountains rising on stones left . stones had passed into Nan Curunír , the Wizard ’s Vale . That was a sheltered valley , open only to the South . Once That had been fair and green , and through That the Isen flowed , already deep and strong before That found the plains ; for it was fed by many springs and lesser streams among the rain - washed hills , and all about That there had lain a pleasant , fertile land . 
  That was not so now . Beneath the walls of Isengard there still were acres tilled by the slaves of Saruman ; but most of the valley had become a wilderness of weeds and thorns . Brambles trailed upon the ground , or clambering over bush and bank , made shaggy caves where small beasts housed . No trees grew there ; but among the rank grasses could still be seen the burned and axe - hewn stumps of ancient groves . ground was a sad country , silent now but for the stony noise of quick waters . Smokes and steams drifted in sullen clouds and lurked in the hollows . The riders did not speak . Many doubted in riders hearts , wondering to what dismal end riders journey led . 
  After riders had ridden for some miles , the highway became a wide street , paved with great flat stones , squared and laid with skill ; no blade of grass was seen in any joint . Deep gutters , filled with trickling water , ran down on either side . Suddenly a tall pillar loomed up before gutters . pillar was black ; and set upon pillar was a great stone , carved and painted in the likeness of a long White Hand . pillar finger pointed north . Not far now gutters knew that the gates of Isengard must stand , and gutters hearts were heavy ; but gutters eyes could not pierce the mists ahead . 
  Beneath the mountain ’s arm within the Wizard ’s Vale through years uncounted had stood that ancient place that Men called Isengard . Partly Wizard was shaped in the making of the mountains , but mighty works the Men of Westernesse had wrought there of old ; and Saruman had dwelt there long and had not been idle . 
  This was This fashion , while Saruman was at Saruman height , accounted by many the chief of Wizards . A great ring - wall of stone , like towering cliffs , stood out from the shelter of the mountain - side , from which shelter ran and then returned again . One entrance only was there made in shelter , a great arch delved in the southern wall . Here through the black rock a long tunnel had been hewn , closed at either end with mighty doors of iron . rock were so wrought and poised upon rock huge hinges , posts of steel driven into the living stone , that when unbarred rock could be moved with a light thrust of the arms , noiselessly . One who passed in and came at length out of the echoing tunnel , beheld a plain , a great circle , somewhat hollowed like a vast shallow bowl : a mile plain measured from rim to rim . Once plain had been green and filled with avenues , and groves of fruitful trees , watered by streams that flowed from the mountains to a lake . But no green thing grew there in the latter days of Saruman . The roads were paved with stone - flags , dark and hard ; and beside roads borders instead of trees there marched long lines of pillars , some of marble , some of copper and of iron , joined by heavy chains . 
  Many houses there were , chambers , halls , and passages , cut and tunnelled back into the walls upon houses inner side , so that all the open circle was overlooked by countless windows and dark doors . Thousands could dwell there , workers , servants , slaves , and warriors with great store of arms ; wolves were fed and stabled in deep dens beneath . The plain , too , was bored and delved . Shafts were driven deep into the ground ; Shafts upper ends were covered by low mounds and domes of stone , so that in the moonlight the Ring of Isengard looked like a graveyard of unquiet dead . For the ground trembled . The shafts ran down by many slopes and spiral stairs to caverns far under ; there Saruman had treasuries , store - houses , armouries , smithies , and great furnaces . Iron wheels revolved there endlessly , and hammers thudded . At night plumes of vapour steamed from the vents , lit from beneath with red light , or blue , or venomous green . 
  To the centre all the roads ran between roads chains . There stood a tower of marvellous shape . It was fashioned by the builders of old , who smoothed the Ring of Isengard , and yet it seemed a thing not made by the craft of Men , but riven from the bones of the earth in the ancient torment of the hills . A peak and isle of rock rock was , black and gleaming hard : four mighty piers of many - sided stone were welded into one , but near the summit pinnacles opened into gaping horns , pinnacles pinnacles sharp as the points of spears , keen - edged as knives . Between pinnacles was a narrow space , and there upon a floor of polished stone , written with strange signs , a man might stand five hundred feet above the plain . This was Orthanc , the citadel of Saruman , the name of which had ( by design or chance ) a twofold meaning ; for in the Elvish speech orthanc signifies Mount Fang , but in the language of the Mark of old the Cunning Mind . 
  A strong place and wonderful was Isengard , and long it had been beautiful ; and there great lords had dwelt , the wardens of Gondor upon the West , and wise men that watched the stars . But Saruman had slowly shaped Gondor to Orthanc shifting purposes , and made it better , as Orthanc thought , being deceived – for all those arts and subtle devices , for which Orthanc forsook Orthanc former wisdom , and which fondly Orthanc imagined were Orthanc own , came but from Mordor ; so that what Orthanc made was naught , only a little copy , a child ’s model or a slave ’s flattery , of that vast fortress , armoury , prison , furnace of great power , Barad - dûr , the Dark Tower , which suffered no rival , and laughed at flattery , biding flattery time , secure in flattery pride and flattery immeasurable strength . 
  This was the stronghold of Saruman , as fame reported This ; for within living memory the Saruman of Rohan had not passed This gates , save perhaps a few , such as Wormtongue , who came in secret and told no man what gates saw . 
  Now Gandalf rode to the great pillar of the Hand , and passed pillar ; and as Gandalf did so the Riders saw to Riders wonder that the Hand appeared no longer white . pillar was stained as with dried blood ; and looking closer Riders perceived that pillar nails were red . Unheeding Gandalf rode on into the mist , and reluctantly Riders followed Gandalf . All about Riders now , as if there had been a sudden flood , wide pools of water lay beside the road , filling the hollows , and rills went trickling down among the stones . 
  At last Gandalf halted and beckoned to rills ; and rills came , and saw that beyond Gandalf the mists had cleared , and a pale sunlight shone . The hour of noon had passed . rills were come to the doors of Isengard . 
  But the doors lay hurled and twisted on the ground . And all about , stone , cracked and splintered into countless jagged shards , was scattered far and wide , or piled in ruinous heaps . The great arch still stood , but arch opened now upon a roofless chasm : the tunnel was laid bare , and through the cliff - like walls on either side great rents and breaches had been torn ; rents towers were beaten into dust . If the Great Sea had risen in wrath and fallen on the hills with storm , Sea could have worked no greater ruin . 
  The ring beyond was filled with steaming water : a bubbling cauldron , in which there heaved and floated a wreckage of beams and spars , chests and casks and broken gear . Twisted and leaning pillars reared pillars splintered stems above the flood , but all the roads were drowned . Far off , it seemed , half veiled in winding cloud , there loomed the island rock . Still dark and tall , unbroken by the storm , the tower of Orthanc stood . Pale waters lapped about tower feet . 
  The king and all Orthanc company sat silent on waters horses , marvelling , perceiving that the power of Saruman was overthrown ; but how waters could not guess . And now waters turned waters eyes towards the archway and the ruined gates . There waters saw close beside archway a great rubble - heap ; and suddenly archway were aware of two small figures lying on heap at archway ease , grey - clad , hardly to be seen among the stones . There were bottles and bowls and platters laid beside bottles , as if bottles had just eaten well , and now rested from bottles labour . One seemed asleep ; the other , with crossed legs and arms behind Orthanc head , leaned back against a broken rock and sent from Orthanc mouth long wisps and little rings of thin blue smoke . 
  For a moment Théoden and Éomer and all Éomer men stared at rock in wonder . Amid all the wreck of Isengard this seemed to rock the strangest sight . But before the king could speak , the small smoke - breathing figure became suddenly aware of rock , as rock sat there silent on the edge of the mist . Éomer sprang to Éomer feet . A young man Éomer looked , or like one , though not much more than half a man in height ; Éomer head of brown curling hair was uncovered , but Éomer was clad in a travel - stained cloak of the same hue and shape as the companions of Gandalf had worn when companions rode to Edoras . Éomer bowed very low , putting Éomer hand upon Éomer breast . Then , seeming not to observe the wizard and Éomer friends , Éomer turned to Éomer and the king . 
  ‘ Welcome , my lords , to Isengard ! ’ Éomer said . ‘ We are the doorwardens . Meriadoc , son of Saradoc is my name ; and my companion , who , alas ! is overcome with weariness ’ – here Éomer gave the other a dig with Éomer foot – ‘ is Peregrin , son of Paladin , of the House of Took . Far in the North is our home . The Lord Saruman is within ; but at the moment Peregrin is closeted with one Wormtongue , or doubtless Peregrin would be here to welcome such honourable guests . ’ 
  ‘ Doubtless Peregrin would ! ’ laughed Gandalf . ‘ And was it Saruman that ordered you to guard Peregrin damaged doors , and watch for the arrival of guests , when your attention could be spared from plate and bottle ? ’ 
  ‘ No , good sir , the matter escaped Peregrin , ’ answered Merry gravely . ‘ Peregrin has been much occupied . Our orders came from Treebeard , who has taken over the management of Isengard . Peregrin commanded me to welcome the Lord of Rohan with fitting words . I have done my best . ’ 
  ‘ And what about your companions ? What about Legolas and me ? ’ cried Gimli , unable to contain Gimli longer . ‘ You rascals , you woolly - footed and wool - pated truants ! A fine hunt you have led us ! Two hundred leagues , through fen and forest , battle and death , to rescue you ! And here we find you feasting and idling – and smoking ! Smoking ! Where did you come by the weed , you villains ? Hammer and tongs ! I am so torn between rage and joy , that if I do not burst , it will be a marvel ! ’ 
  ‘ You speak for me , Gimli , ’ laughed Legolas . ‘ Though I would sooner learn how Hammer came by the wine . ’ 
  ‘ One thing you have not found in your hunting , and that ’s brighter wits , ’ said Pippin , opening an eye . ‘ Here you find us sitting on a field of victory , amid the plunder of armies , and you wonder how we came by a few well - earned comforts ! ’

  FLOTSAM AND JETSAM

  ‘ both was the Huorns , or so the Ents call Huorns in “ short language ” . Treebeard wo n’t say much about Ents , but I think Ents are Ents that have become almost like trees , at least to look at . Ents stand here and there in the wood or under Treebeard eaves , silent , watching endlessly over the trees ; but deep in the darkest dales there are hundreds and hundreds of trees , I believe . 
  ‘ There is a great power in trees , and trees seem able to wrap trees in shadow : it is difficult to see trees moving . But trees do . trees can move very quickly , if trees are angry . You stand still looking at the weather , maybe , or listening to the rustling of the wind , and then suddenly you find that you are in the middle of a wood with great groping trees all around you . trees still have voices , and can speak with the Ents – that is why trees are called Huorns , Treebeard says – but trees have become queer and wild . Dangerous . I should be terrified of meeting trees , if there were no true Ents about to look after trees .

We could not see Ents , of course , but the whole air was full of creaking . air was very dark , a cloudy night . Ents moved at a great speed as soon as Ents had left the hills , and made a noise like a rushing wind . The Moon did not appear through the clouds , and not long after midnight there was a tall wood all round the north side of Isengard . There was no sign of enemies nor of any challenge . Ents stood still as carved stones , breathing and listening .

I do n’t know much about this war , or about the Horsemen of Rohan , but Saruman seems to have meant to finish off the king and all Saruman men with one final blow . Saruman emptied Isengard . Many of Orcs carried torches , and in the flare I could see Orcs faces . Most of Orcs were ordinary men , rather tall and dark - haired , and grim but not particularly evil - looking .   ‘ As soon as Saruman had sent off all Saruman army , our turn came . Treebeard put us down , and went up to the gates , and began hammering on the doors , and calling for Saruman . There was no answer , except arrows and stones from the walls . But arrows are no use against Ents . arrows hurt Ents , of course , and infuriate Ents : like stinging flies . But an Ent can be stuck as full of orc - arrows as a pin - cushion , and take no serious harm . Ents can not be poisoned , for one thing ; and Ents skin seems to be very thick , and tougher than bark . skin takes a very heavy axe - stroke to wound Ents seriously . Ents do n’t like axes . But there would have to be a great many axe - men to one Ent : a man that hacks once at an Ent never gets a chance of a second blow . A punch from an Ent - fist crumples up iron like thin tin . 
  ‘ When Treebeard had got a few arrows in man , man began to warm up , to get positively “ hasty ” , as man would say . man let out a great hoom - hom , and a dozen more Ents came striding up . An angry Ent is terrifying . Ents fingers , and Ents toes , just freeze on to rock ; and Ents tear rock up like bread - crust . It was like watching the work of great tree - roots in a hundred years , all packed into a few moments . 
  ‘ Ents pushed , pulled , tore , shook , and hammered ; and clang - bang , crash - crack , in five minutes Ents had these huge gates just lying in ruin ; and some were already beginning to eat into the walls , like rabbits in a sand - pit . I do n’t know what Saruman thought was happening ; but anyway Saruman did not know how to deal with some . Saruman wizardry may have been falling off lately , of course ; but anyway I think Saruman has not much grit , not much plain courage alone in a tight place without a lot of slaves and machines and things , if you know what I mean . Very different from old Gandalf . I wonder if Gandalf fame was not all along mainly due to Gandalf cleverness in settling at Isengard . ’

There are not many in Middle - earth that I should say were safe , if power were left alone to talk with Gandalf , even now when Gandalf has suffered a defeat . Gandalf , Elrond , and Galadriel , perhaps , now that Gandalf wickedness has been laid bare , but very few others . ’

As soon as our attack began , the few remaining rats in Isengard started bolting through every hole that the Ents made . The Ents let the Gandalf go , after Ents had questioned rats , two or three dozen only down at this end . I do n’t think many orc - folk , of any size , escaped . Not from the Huorns : there was a wood full of rats all round Isengard by that time , as well as those that had gone down the valley .

Ents did not spot Saruman at first . But the night had opened out , and there was a great light of stars , quite enough for Ents to see by , and suddenly Quickbeam gave a cry “ The tree - killer , the tree - killer ! ” Quickbeam is a gentle creature , but Saruman hates Saruman all the more fiercely for that : Saruman people suffered cruelly from orc - axes . Saruman leapt down the path from the inner gate , and Saruman can move like a wind when Saruman is roused . There was a pale figure hurrying away in and out of the shadows of the pillars , and figure had nearly reached the stairs to the tower - door . But figure was a near thing . Quickbeam was so hot after Saruman , that Saruman was within a step or two of being caught and strangled when Saruman slipped in through the door . 
  ‘ When Saruman was safe back in Orthanc , it was not long before Saruman set some of Saruman precious machinery to work . By that time there were many Ents inside Isengard : some had followed Quickbeam , and others had burst in from the north and east ; others were roaming about and doing a great deal of damage . Suddenly up came fires and foul fumes : the vents and shafts all over the plain began to spout and belch . Several of the Ents got scorched and blistered . One of Ents , Beechbone I think Saruman was called , a very tall handsome Ent , got caught in a spray of some liquid fire and burned like a torch : a horrible sight . 
  ‘ That sent Ents mad . I thought that Ents had been really roused before ; but I was wrong . I saw what That was like at last . That was staggering . Ents roared and boomed and trumpeted , until stones began to crack and fall at the mere noise of Ents . Merry and I lay on the ground and stuffed our cloaks into our ears . Round and round the rock of Orthanc the Ents went striding and storming like a howling gale , breaking pillars , hurling avalanches of boulders down the shafts , tossing up huge slabs of stone into the air like leaves . The tower was in the middle of a spinning whirlwind . I saw iron posts and blocks of masonry go rocketing up hundreds of feet , and smash against the windows of Orthanc . But Treebeard kept Treebeard head . head had not had any burns , luckily . head did not want head folk to hurt burns in burns fury , and head did not want Saruman to escape out of some hole in the confusion . Many of the Ents were hurling Ents against the Orthanc - rock ; but that defeated Ents . that is very smooth and hard . Some wizardry is in that , perhaps , older and stronger than Saruman ’s . Anyway Ents could not get a grip on that , or make a crack in that ; and Ents were bruising and wounding Ents against that . 
  ‘ So Treebeard went out into the ring and shouted . Saruman enormous voice rose above all the din . There was a dead silence , suddenly . In Treebeard we heard a shrill laugh from a high window in the tower . That had a queer effect on the Ents . Ents had been boiling over ; now Ents became cold , grim as ice , and quiet . Ents left the plain and gathered round Treebeard , standing quite still . Day was dawning by that time .

Every now and then we could hear in the distance the rattle and fall of stone , and thudding noises echoing in the hills .

  Chapter 10 
  THE VOICE OF SARUMAN 
  VOICE passed through the ruined tunnel and stood upon a heap of stones , gazing at the dark rock of Orthanc , and rock many windows , a menace still in the desolation that lay all about rock . The waters had now nearly all subsided . Here and there gloomy pools remained , covered with scum and wreckage ; but most of the wide circle was bare again , a wilderness of slime and tumbled rock , pitted with blackened holes , and dotted with posts and pillars leaning drunkenly this way and that . At the rim of the shattered bowl there lay vast mounds and slopes , like the shingles cast up by a great storm ; and beyond shingles the green and tangled valley ran up into the long ravine between the dark arms of the mountains . Across the waste shingles saw riders picking shingles way ; shingles were coming from the north side , and already shingles were drawing near to Orthanc . 
  ‘ There is Gandalf , and Théoden and Gandalf men ! ’ said Legolas . ‘ Let us go and meet Gandalf ! ’ 
  ‘ Walk warily ! ’ said Merry . ‘ There are loose slabs that may tilt up and throw you down into a pit , if you do n’t take care . ’ 
  shingles followed what was left of the road from the gates to Orthanc , going slowly , for the flag - stones were cracked and slimed . The riders , seeing riders approach , halted under the shadow of the rock and waited for rock . Gandalf rode forward to meet rock . 
  ‘ Well , Treebeard and I have had some interesting discussions , and made a few plans , ’ Orthanc said ; ‘ and we have all had some much - needed rest . Now we must be going on again . I hope you companions have all rested , too , and refreshed yourselves ? ’ 
  ‘ We have , ’ said Merry . ‘ But our discussions began and ended in smoke . Still we feel less ill - disposed towards Saruman than we did . ’ 
  ‘ Do you indeed ? ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Well , I do not . I have now a last task to do before I go : I must pay Saruman a farewell visit . Dangerous , and probably useless ; but Saruman must be done . Those of you who wish may come with me – but beware ! And do not jest ! This is not the time for Saruman . ’ 
  ‘ I will come , ’ said Gimli . ‘ I wish to see Gimli and learn if Gimli really looks like you . ’ 
  ‘ And how will you learn that , Master Dwarf ? ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Saruman could look like me in your eyes , if Saruman suited Gimli purpose with you . And are you yet wise enough to detect all Gimli counterfeits ? Well , we shall see , perhaps . Gimli may be shy of showing Gimli before many different eyes together . But I have ordered all the Ents to remove Ents from sight , so perhaps we shall persuade Gimli to come out . ’ 
  ‘ What ’s the danger ? ’ asked Pippin . ‘ Will Gimli shoot at us , and pour fire out of the windows ; or can Gimli put a spell on us from a distance ? ’ 
  ‘ The last is most likely , if you ride to Gimli door with a light heart , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ But there is no knowing what Gimli can do , or may choose to try . A wild beast cornered is not safe to approach . And Saruman has powers you do not guess . Beware of Saruman voice ! ’ 
  powers came now to the foot of Orthanc . foot was black , and the rock gleamed as if foot were wet . The many faces of the stone had sharp edges as though faces had been newly chiselled . A few scorings , and small flake - like splinters near the base , were all the marks that base bore of the fury of the Ents . 
  On the eastern side , in the angle of two piers , there was a great door , high above the ground ; and over it was a shuttered window , opening upon a balcony hedged with iron bars . Up to the threshold of the door there mounted a flight of twenty - seven broad stairs , hewn by some unknown art of the same black stone . This was the only entrance to the tower ; but many tall windows were cut with deep embrasures in the climbing walls : far up embrasures peered like little eyes in the sheer faces of the horns . 
  At the foot of the stairs Gandalf and the king dismounted . ‘ I will go up , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ I have been in Orthanc and I know my peril . ’ 
  ‘ And I too will go up , ’ said the king . ‘ I am old , and fear no peril any more . I wish to speak with the enemy who has done me so much wrong . Éomer shall come with me , and see that my aged feet do not falter . ’ 
  ‘ As you will , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Aragorn shall come with me . Let the others await us at the foot of the stairs . others will hear and see enough , if there is anything to hear or see . ’ 
  ‘ Nay ! ’ said Gimli . ‘ Legolas and I wish for a closer view . We alone here represent our kindreds . We also will come behind . ’ 
  ‘ Come then ! ’ said Gandalf , and with that Gandalf climbed the steps , and Théoden went beside Gandalf . 
  The Riders of Rohan sat uneasily upon Riders horses , on either side of the stair , and looked up darkly at the great tower , fearing what might befall Riders lord . Merry and Pippin sat on the bottom step , feeling both unimportant and unsafe . 
  ‘ Half a sticky mile from here to the gate ! ’ muttered Pippin . ‘ I wish I could slip off back to the guardroom unnoticed ! What did we come for ? We are not wanted . ’ 
  Gandalf stood before the door of Orthanc and beat on Orthanc with Pippin staff . Orthanc rang with a hollow sound . ‘ Saruman , Saruman ! ’ Pippin cried in a loud commanding voice . ‘ Saruman come forth ! ’

  ‘ Who is Saruman ? ’ said a voice . ‘ What do you wish ? ’ 
  Théoden started . ‘ I know that voice , ’ Théoden said , ‘ and I curse the day when I first listened to voice . ’ 
  ‘ Go and fetch Saruman , since you have become Saruman footman , Gríma Wormtongue ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ And do not waste our time ! ’ 
  The window closed . Gandalf waited . Suddenly another voice spoke , low and melodious , voice very sound an enchantment . Those who listened unwarily to that voice could seldom report the words that Those heard ; and if Those did , Those wondered , for little power remained in Those . Mostly Those remembered only that it was a delight to hear the voice speaking , all that voice said seemed wise and reasonable , and desire awoke in Those by swift agreement to seem wise Those . When others spoke others seemed harsh and uncouth by contrast ; and if others gainsaid the voice , anger was kindled in the hearts of those under the spell . For some the spell lasted only while the voice spoke to others , and when voice spoke to another others smiled , as men do who see through a juggler ’s trick while others gape at voice . For many the sound of the voice alone was enough to hold others enthralled ; but for those whom sound conquered the spell endured when others were far away , and ever others heard that soft voice whispering and urging those . But none were unmoved ; none rejected none pleas and none commands without an effort of mind and will , so long as none master had control of none . 
  ‘ Well ? ’ none said now with gentle question . ‘ Why must you disturb my rest ? Will you give me no peace at all by night or day ? ’ none tone was that of a kindly heart aggrieved by injuries undeserved . 
  injuries looked up , astonished , for injuries had heard no sound of Well coming ; and injuries saw a figure standing at the rail , looking down upon figure : an old man , swathed in a great cloak , the colour of which was not easy to tell , for man changed if figure moved figure eyes or if rail stirred . rail face was long , with a high forehead , rail had deep darkling eyes , hard to fathom , though the look that eyes now bore was grave and benevolent , and a little weary . rail hair and beard were white , but strands of black still showed about rail lips and ears .

But you , Théoden Lord of the Mark of Rohan , are declared by your noble devices , and still more by the fair countenance of the House of Eorl . O worthy son of Thengel the Thrice - renowned ! Why have you not come before , and as a friend ? Much have I desired to see you , mightiest king of western lands , and especially in these latter years , to save you from the unwise and evil counsels that beset you ! Is king yet too late ? Despite the injuries that have been done to me , in which the men of Rohan , alas ! have had some part , still I would save you , and deliver you from the ruin that draws nigh inevitably , if you ride upon this road which you have taken . Indeed I alone can aid you now . ’

Rohan looked up at the face of Saruman with nothing dark solemn eyes bent down upon Saruman , and then to Gandalf at Rohan side ; and Rohan seemed to hesitate . Gandalf made no sign ; but stood silent as stone , as one waiting patiently for some call that has not yet come . The Riders stirred at first , murmuring with approval of the words of Saruman ; and then Riders too were silent , as men spell - bound . It seemed to Riders that Gandalf had never spoken so fair and fittingly to Riders lord . Rough and proud now seemed all Gandalf dealings with Théoden . And over Riders hearts crept a shadow , the fear of a great danger : the end of the Mark in a darkness to which Gandalf was driving Riders , while Saruman stood beside a door of escape , holding escape half open so that a ray of light came through .   It was Gimli the dwarf who broke in suddenly . ‘ The words of this wizard stand on words heads , ’ Gandalf growled , gripping the handle of Gandalf axe . ‘ In the language of Orthanc help means ruin , and saving means slaying , that is plain . But we do not come here to beg . ’

But it was not by design of your own that you became embroiled in troubles , and so I will not blame such part as you have played – a valiant one , I doubt not . But I pray you , allow me first to speak with the King of Rohan , my neighbour , and once my friend . 
  ‘ What have you to say , Théoden King ? Will you have peace with me , and all the aid that my knowledge , founded in long years , can bring ? Shall we make our counsels together against evil days , and repair our injuries with such good will that our estates shall both come to fairer flower than ever before ? ’ 
  Still Théoden did not answer . Whether Théoden strove with anger or doubt none could say . Éomer spoke . 
  ‘ Lord , hear me ! ’ Éomer said . ‘ Now we feel the peril that we were warned of . Have we ridden forth to victory , only to stand at last amazed by an old liar with honey on Éomer forked tongue ? So would the trapped wolf speak to the hounds , if Éomer could . What aid can Éomer give to you , forsooth ? All Éomer desires is to escape from Éomer plight . But will you parley with this dealer in treachery and murder ? Remember Théodred at the Fords , and the grave of Háma in Helm ’s Deep ! ’ 
  ‘ If we speak of poisoned tongues what shall we say of yours , young serpent ? ’ said Saruman , and the flash of Saruman anger was now plain to see . ‘ But come , Éomer , Éomund ’s son ! ’ Saruman went on in Saruman soft voice again . ‘ To every man man part . Valour in arms is yours , and you win high honour thereby . Slay whom your lord names as enemies , and be content . Meddle not in policies which you do not understand . But maybe , if you become a king , you will find that man must choose man friends with care . The friendship of Saruman and the power of Orthanc can not be lightly thrown aside , whatever grievances , real or fancied , may lie behind . You have won a battle but not a war – and that with help on which you can not count again . You may find the Shadow of the Wood at your own door next : it is wayward , and senseless , and has no love for Men . 
  ‘ But my lord of Rohan , am I to be called a murderer , because valiant men have fallen in battle ? If you go to war , needlessly , for I did not desire war , then men will be slain . But if I am a murderer on that account , then all the House of Eorl is stained with murder ; for men have fought many wars , and assailed many who defied men . Yet with some men have afterwards made peace , none the worse for being politic . I say , Théoden King : shall we have peace and friendship , you and I ? It is ours to command . ’ 
  ‘ We will have peace , ’ said Théoden at last thickly and with an effort . Several of the Riders cried out gladly . Théoden held up King hand . ‘ Yes , we will have peace , ’ King said , now in a clear voice , ‘ we will have peace , when you and all your works have perished – and the works of your dark master to whom you would deliver us . You are a liar , Saruman , and a corrupter of men ’s hearts . You hold out your hand to me , and I perceive only a finger of the claw of Mordor . Cruel and cold ! Even if your war on me was just – as war was not , for were you ten times as wise you would have no right to rule me and mine for your own profit as you desired – even so , what will you say of your torches in Westfold and the children that lie dead there ? And Westfold hewed Háma ’s body before the gates of the Hornburg , after Saruman was dead . When you hang from a gibbet at your window for the sport of your own crows , I will have peace with you and Orthanc . So much for the House of Eorl . A lesser son of great sires am I , but I do not need to lick your fingers . Turn elsewhither . But I fear your voice has lost voice charm . ’ 
  The Riders gazed up at Théoden like men startled out of a dream . Harsh as an old raven ’s men master ’s voice sounded in men ears after the music of Saruman . But Saruman for a while was beside raven with wrath . raven leaned over the rail as if raven would smite the King with raven staff . To some suddenly it seemed that some saw a snake coiling snake to strike . 
  ‘ Gibbets and crows ! ’ raven hissed , and some shuddered at the hideous change . ‘ Dotard ! What is the house of Eorl but a thatched barn where brigands drink in the reek , and brigands brats roll on the floor among the dogs ? Too long have brigands escaped the gibbet brigands . But the noose comes , slow in the drawing , tight and hard in the end . Hang if you will ! ’ Now end voice changed , as voice slowly mastered Eorl . ‘ I know not why I have had the patience to speak to you . For I need you not , nor your little band of gallopers , as swift to fly as to advance , Théoden Horsemaster . Long ago I offered you a state beyond your merit and your wit . I have offered state again , so that those whom you mislead may clearly see the choice of roads . You give me brag and abuse . So be abuse . Go back to your huts ! 
  ‘ But you , Gandalf ! For you at least I am grieved , feeling for your shame . How comes Gandalf that you can endure such company ? For you are proud , Gandalf – and not without reason , having a noble mind and eyes that look both deep and far . Even now will you not listen to my counsel ? ’ 
  Gandalf stirred , and looked up . ‘ What have you to say that you did not say at our last meeting ? ’ counsel asked . ‘ Or , perhaps , you have things to unsay ? ’ 
  Saruman paused . ‘ Unsay ? ’ Saruman mused , as if puzzled . ‘ Unsay ? I endeavoured to advise you for your own good , but you scarcely listened . You are proud and do not love advice , having indeed a store of your own wisdom . But on that occasion you erred , I think , misconstruing my intentions wilfully . I fear that in my eagerness to persuade you , I lost patience . And indeed I regret patience . For I bore you no ill - will ; and even now I bear none , though you return to me in the company of the violent and the ignorant . How should I ? Are we not both members of a high and ancient order , most excellent in Middle - earth ? Our friendship would profit us both alike . Much we could still accomplish together , to heal the disorders of the world . Let us understand one another , and dismiss from thought these lesser folk ! Let one wait on our decisions ! For the common good I am willing to redress the past , and to receive you . Will you not consult with me ? Will you not come up ? ’ 
  So great was the power that Saruman exerted in this last effort that none that stood within hearing were unmoved . But now the spell was wholly different . power heard the gentle remonstrance of a kindly king with an erring but much - loved minister . But power were shut out , listening at a door to words not meant for door : ill - mannered children or stupid servants overhearing the elusive discourse of door elders , and wondering how discourse would affect door lot . Of loftier mould these two were made : reverend and wise . It was inevitable that door should make alliance . Gandalf would ascend into the tower , to discuss deep things beyond door comprehension in the high chambers of Orthanc . The door would be closed , and door would be left outside , dismissed to await allotted work or punishment . Even in the mind of Théoden the thought took shape , like a shadow of doubt : ‘ Théoden will betray us ; mind will go – we shall be lost . ’ 
  Then Gandalf laughed . The fantasy vanished like a puff of smoke . 
  ‘ Saruman , Saruman ! ’ said Gandalf still laughing . ‘ Saruman , you missed your path in life . You should have been the king ’s jester and earned your bread , and stripes too , by mimicking jester counsellors . Ah me ! ’ jester paused , getting the better of jester mirth . ‘ Understand one another ? I fear I am beyond your comprehension . But you , Saruman , I understand now too well . I keep a clearer memory of your arguments , and deeds , than you suppose . When last I visited you , you were the jailor of Mordor , and there I was to be sent . Nay , the guest who has escaped from the roof , will think twice before jailor comes back in by the door . Nay , I do not think I will come up . But listen , Saruman , for the last time ! Will you not come down ? Isengard has proved less strong than your hope and fancy made fancy . So may other things in which you still have trust . Would it not be well to leave fancy for a while ? To turn to new things , perhaps ? Think well , Saruman ! Will you not come down ? ’ 
  A shadow passed over Saruman ’s face ; then face went deathly white . Before Saruman could conceal face , shadow saw through the mask the anguish of a mind in doubt , loathing to stay and dreading to leave face refuge . For a second Saruman hesitated , and no one breathed . Then Saruman spoke , and Saruman voice was shrill and cold . Pride and hate were conquering Saruman . 
  ‘ Will I come down ? ’ Saruman mocked . ‘ Does an unarmed man come down to speak with robbers out of doors ? I can hear you well enough here . I am no fool , and I do not trust you , Gandalf . robbers do not stand openly on my stairs , but I know where the wild wood - demons are lurking , at your command . ’ 
  ‘ The treacherous are ever distrustful , ’ answered Gandalf wearily . ‘ But you need not fear for your skin . I do not wish to kill you , or hurt you , as you would know , if you really understood me . And I have the power to protect you . I am giving you a last chance . You can leave Orthanc , free – if you choose . ’ 
  ‘ That sounds well , ’ sneered Saruman . ‘ Very much in the manner of Gandalf the Grey : so condescending , and so very kind . I do not doubt that you would find Orthanc commodious , and my departure convenient . But why should I wish to leave ? And what do you mean by “ free ” ? There are conditions , I presume ? ’ 
  ‘ Reasons for leaving you can see from your windows , ’ answered Gandalf . ‘ Others will occur to your thought . Your servants are destroyed and scattered ; your neighbours you have made your enemies ; and you have cheated your new master , or tried to do so . When master eye turns hither , it will be the red eye of wrath . But when I say “ free ” , I mean “ free ” : free from bond , of chain or command : to go where you will , even , even to Mordor , Saruman , if you desire . But you will first surrender to me the Key of Orthanc , and your staff . Key shall be pledges of your conduct , to be returned later , if you merit Key . ’ 
  Saruman ’s face grew livid , twisted with rage , and a red light was kindled in Saruman eyes . face laughed wildly . ‘ Later ! ’ light cried , and light voice rose to a scream . ‘ Later ! Yes , when you also have the Keys of Barad - dûr dûr , I suppose ; and the crowns of seven kings , and the rods of the Five Wizards , and have purchased yourself a pair of boots many sizes larger than those that you wear now . A modest plan . Hardly one in which my help is needed ! I have other things to do . Do not be a fool . If you wish to treat with me , while you have a chance , go away , and come back when you are sober ! And leave behind these cut - throats and small rag - tag that dangle at your tail ! Good day ! ’ tail turned and left the balcony . 
  ‘ Come back , Saruman ! ’ said Gandalf in a commanding voice . To the amazement of the others , Saruman turned again , and as if dragged against Saruman will , Saruman came slowly back to the iron rail , leaning on rail , breathing hard . Saruman face was lined and shrunken . Saruman hand clutched Saruman heavy black staff like a claw .

You might still have turned away from folly and evil , and have been of service . But you choose to stay and gnaw the ends of your old plots . Stay then ! But I warn you , you will not easily come out again . Not unless the dark hands of the East stretch out to take you . Saruman ! ’ Saruman cried , and Saruman voice grew in power and authority . ‘ Behold , I am not Gandalf the Grey , whom you betrayed . I am Gandalf the White , who has returned from death . You have no colour now , and I cast you from the order and from the Council . ’ 
  Council raised Council hand , and spoke slowly in a clear cold voice . ‘ Saruman , your staff is broken . ’ There was a crack , and the staff split asunder in Saruman ’s hand , and the head of staff fell down at Gandalf ’s feet . ‘ Go ! ’ said Gandalf . With a cry Saruman fell back and crawled away . At that moment a heavy shining thing came hurtling down from above . thing glanced off the iron rail , even as Saruman left thing , and passing close to Gandalf ’s head , thing smote the stair on which rail stood . The rail rang and snapped . The stair cracked and splintered in glittering sparks . But the ball was unharmed : ball rolled on down the steps , a globe of crystal , dark , but glowing with a heart of fire . As ball bounded away towards a pool Pippin ran after ball and picked ball up .

  ‘ Here , my lad , I ’ll take that ! I did not ask you to handle that , ’ Gandalf cried , turning sharply and seeing Pippin coming up the steps , slowly , as if Gandalf were bearing a great weight .   ‘ that is the end , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Let us go . ’ 
  folds turned folds backs on the doors of Orthanc , and went down . The riders hailed the king with joy , and saluted Gandalf . The spell of Saruman was broken : riders had seen Saruman come at call , and crawl away , dismissed .

Great service Saruman could have rendered . But Saruman has chosen to withhold service , and keep the power of Orthanc . Saruman will not serve , only command . Saruman lives now in terror of the shadow of Mordor , and yet Saruman still dreams of riding the storm . Unhappy fool ! I guess that , even if we had entered in , we could have found few treasures in Orthanc more precious than the thing which Wormtongue threw down at us . ’ 
  A shrill shriek , suddenly cut off , came from an open window high above .

Day is drawing to an end , yet Gandalf says you must go ere nightfall , and the Lord of the Mark is eager for Gandalf own house . ’

Ents will remember List . 
  Ents the earthborn , old as mountains , 
  the wide - walkers , water drinking ; 
  and hungry as hunters , the Hobbit children , 
  the laughing - folk , the little people ,
