  ‘ Good ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ That is what I hoped . Now I can go and turn to other matters with one care the less . But you must be wary . The waters have gone down . That will not be enough to put sentinels round the tower , I fear . I do not doubt that there were deep ways delved under Orthanc , and that Saruman hopes to go and come unmarked , before long . If you will undertake the labour , I beg you to pour in the waters again ; and do so , until Isengard remains a standing pool , or you discover the outlets . When all the underground places are drowned , and the outlets blocked , then Saruman must stay upstairs and look out of the windows . ’ 
  ‘ Leave Isengard to the Ents ! ’ said Treebeard . ‘ We shall search the valley from head to foot and peer under every pebble . Trees are coming back to live here , old trees , wild trees . The Watchwood we will call Watchwood . Not a squirrel will go here , but I shall know of squirrel . Leave squirrel to Ents ! Until seven times the years in which head tormented us have passed , we shall not tire of watching head . ’ 
  Chapter 11 
  THE PALANTÍR 
  The sun was sinking behind the long western arm of the mountains when Gandalf and Gandalf companions , and the king with king Riders , set out again from Isengard . Gandalf took Merry behind Isengard , and Aragorn took Pippin . Two of the king ’s men went on ahead , riding swiftly , and passed soon out of sight down into the valley . The others followed at an easy pace . 
  Ents in a solemn row stood like statues at the gate , with Ents long arms uplifted , but Ents made no sound . Merry and Pippin looked back , when Ents had passed some way down the winding road . Sunlight was still shining in the sky , but long shadows reached over Isengard : grey ruins falling into darkness . Treebeard stood alone there now , like the distant stump of an old tree : the hobbits thought of hobbits first meeting , upon the sunny ledge far away on the borders of Fangorn . 
  hobbits came to the pillar of the White Hand . The pillar was still standing , but the graven hand had been thrown down and broken into small pieces . Right in the middle of the road the long forefinger lay , white in the dusk , forefinger red nail darkening to black . 
  ‘ The Ents pay attention to every detail ! ’ said Gandalf . 
  hobbits rode on , and evening deepened in the valley . 
  ‘ Are we riding far tonight , Gandalf ? ’ asked Merry after a while . ‘ I do n’t know how you feel with small rag - tag dangling behind you ; but the rag - tag is tired and will be glad to stop dangling and lie down . ’ 
  ‘ So you heard that ? ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Do n’t let that rankle ! Be thankful no longer words were aimed at you . Gandalf had Gandalf eyes on you . If that is any comfort to your pride , I should say that , at the moment , you and Pippin are more in Pippin thoughts than all the rest of us . Who you are ; how you came there , and why ; what you know ; whether you were captured , and if so , how you escaped when all the Orcs perished – it is with those little riddles that the great mind of Saruman is troubled . A sneer from Saruman , Meriadoc , is a compliment , if you feel honoured by Saruman concern . ’ 
  ‘ Thank you ! ’ said Merry . ‘ But sneer is a greater honour to dangle at your tail , Gandalf . For one thing , in that position one has a chance of putting a question a second time . Are we riding far tonight ? ’ 
  Gandalf laughed . ‘ A most unquenchable hobbit ! All Wizards should have a hobbit or two in Wizards care – to teach hobbit the meaning of the word , and to correct hobbit . I beg your pardon . But I have given thought even to these simple matters . We will ride for a few hours , gently , until we come to the end of the valley . Tomorrow we must ride faster . 
  ‘ When we came , we meant to go straight from Isengard back to the king ’s house at Edoras over the plains , a ride of some days . But we have taken thought and changed the plan . Messengers have gone ahead to Helm ’s Deep , to warn plains that the king is returning tomorrow . Deep will ride from there with many men to Dunharrow by paths among the hills . From now on no more than two or three together are to go openly over the land , by day or night , when land can be avoided . ’ 
  ‘ Nothing or a double helping is your way ! ’ said Merry . ‘ I am afraid I was not looking beyond tonight ’s bed . Where and what are Helm ’s Deep and all the rest of Helm ? I do n’t know anything about this country . ’ 
  ‘ Then you ’d best learn something , if you wish to understand what is happening . But not just now , and not from me : I have too many pressing things to think about . ’ 
  ‘ All right , I ’ll tackle Strider by the camp - fire : Deep ’s less testy . But why all this secrecy ? I thought we ’d won the battle ! ’ 
  ‘ Yes , we have won , but only the first victory , and that in battle increases our danger . There was some link between Isengard and Mordor , which I have not yet fathomed . How Isengard exchanged news I am not sure ; but Isengard did so . The Eye of Barad - dûr will be looking impatiently towards the Wizard ’s Vale , I think ; and towards Rohan . The less The sees the better . ’ 
  The road passed slowly , winding down the valley . Now further , and now nearer Isen flowed in road stony bed . Night came down from the mountains . All the mists were gone . A chill wind blew . The moon , now waxing round , filled the eastern sky with a pale cold sheen . The shoulders of the mountain to shoulders right sloped down to bare hills . The wide plains opened grey before shoulders . 
  At last shoulders halted . Then shoulders turned aside , leaving the highway and taking to the sweet upland turf again . Going westward a mile or so shoulders came to a dale . dale opened southward , leaning back into the slope of round Dol Baran , the last hill of the northern ranges , greenfooted , crowned with heather . The sides of the glen were shaggy with last year ’s bracken , among which the tight - curled fronds of spring were just thrusting through the sweet - scented earth . Good night ! ’ 
  Pippin said no more . Pippin lay still now , but sleep remained far away ; and sleep was not encouraged by the sound of Merry breathing softly , asleep in a few minutes after saying good night . At that moment Gandalf moved in Gandalf sleep , and muttered some words : words seemed to be in a strange tongue ; Gandalf hand groped out and clasped the wrapped stone , then Gandalf sighed and did not move again . 
  ‘ You idiotic fool ! ’ Pippin muttered to Pippin . ‘ You ’re going to get yourself into frightful trouble . Put trouble back quick ! ’ But Pippin found now that Pippin knees quaked , and Pippin did not dare to go near enough to the wizard to reach the bundle . ‘ I ’ll never get trouble back now without waking fool , ’ Pippin thought , ‘ not till I ’ m a bit calmer . So I may as well have a look first . Not just here though ! ’ Pippin stole away , and sat down on a green hillock not far from Pippin bed . The moon looked in over the edge of the dell . 
  Pippin sat with dell knees drawn up and the ball between knees . dell bent low over ball , looking like a greedy child stooping over a bowl of food , in a corner away from others . child drew child cloak aside and gazed at cloak . The air seemed still and tense about child . At first the globe was dark , black as jet , with the moonlight gleaming on globe surface . Then there came a faint glow and stir in the heart of globe , and globe held child eyes , so that now child could not look away . Soon all the inside seemed on fire ; the ball was spinning , or the lights within were revolving . Suddenly the lights went out . child gave a gasp and struggled ; but child remained bent , clasping the ball with both hands . Closer and closer child bent , and then became rigid ; child lips moved soundlessly for a while . Then with a strangled cry child fell back and lay still . 
  The cry was piercing . The guards leapt down from the banks . All the camp was soon astir . 
  ‘ So this is the thief ! ’ said Gandalf . Hastily Gandalf cast Gandalf cloak over the globe where cloak lay . ‘ But you , Pippin ! This is a grievous turn to things ! ’ Gandalf knelt by Pippin ’s body : the hobbit was lying on Gandalf back , rigid , with unseeing eyes staring up at the sky . ‘ The devilry ! What mischief has Pippin done – to Pippin , and to all of us ? ’ The wizard ’s face was drawn and haggard . 
  wizard took Pippin ’s hand and bent over wizard face , listening for wizard breath ; then wizard laid wizard hands on wizard brow . The hobbit shuddered . wizard eyes closed . wizard cried out ; and sat up , staring in bewilderment at all the faces round wizard , pale in the moonlight . 
  ‘ hobbit is not for you , Saruman ! ’ wizard cried in a shrill and toneless voice , shrinking away from Gandalf . ‘ I will send for hobbit at once . Do you understand ? Say just that ! ’ Then wizard struggled to get up and escape , but Gandalf held wizard gently and firmly . 
  ‘ Peregrin Took ! ’ wizard said . ‘ Come back ! ’ 
  The hobbit relaxed and fell back , clinging to the wizard ’s hand . ‘ Gandalf ! ’ wizard cried . ‘ Gandalf ! Forgive me ! ’ 
  ‘ Forgive you ? ’ said the wizard . ‘ Tell me first what you have done ! ’

Very big , I think , really ; but in the glass stars looked like bats wheeling round the tower . I thought there were nine of stars . One began to fly straight towards me , getting bigger and bigger . One had a horrible – no , no ! I ca n’t say .

Tell Saruman that this dainty is not for Saruman . I will send for dainty at once . Do you understand ? Say just that ! ”

  Tall ships and tall kings 
  Three times three , 
  What brought lines from the foundered land 
  Over the flowing sea ? 
  Seven stars and seven stones 
  And one white tree .

Fëanor Fëanor , maybe , wrought one , in days so long ago that the time can not be measured in years . But there is nothing that Sauron can not turn to evil uses . Alas for Saruman !   ‘ I wish I had known all this before , ’ said Pippin . ‘ I had no notion of what I was doing . ’

  ‘ advice does , ’ said Pippin . ‘ If all the seven stones were laid out before me now , I should shut my eyes and put my hands in my pockets . ’ 
  ‘ Good ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ That is what I hoped . ’ 
  ‘ But I should like to know — ’ Pippin began .

But I am not in a hurry tonight . At the moment I was just wondering about the black shadow . I heard you shout “ messenger of Mordor ” . What was moment ? What could moment do at Isengard ? ’ 
  ‘ moment was a Black Rider on wings , a Nazgûl , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ moment could have taken you away to the Dark Tower . ’ 
  ‘ But moment was not coming for me , was it ? ’ faltered Pippin . ‘ I mean , moment did n’t know that I had … ’ 
  ‘ Of course not , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ moment is two hundred leagues or more in straight flight from Barad - dûr to Orthanc , and even a Nazgûl would take a few hours to fly between hours . But Saruman certainly looked in the Stone since the orc - raid , and more of Saruman secret thought , I do not doubt , has been read than Saruman intended . A messenger has been sent to find out what Saruman is doing . And after what has happened tonight another will come , I think , and swiftly . So Saruman will come to the last pinch of the vice that messenger has put messenger hand in . messenger has no captive to send . messenger has no Stone to see with , and can not answer the summons . Sauron will only believe that Sauron is withholding the captive and refusing to use the Stone . captive will not help Saruman to tell the truth to the messenger . For Isengard may be ruined , yet Sauron is still safe in Orthanc . So whether Sauron will or no , Sauron will appear a rebel . Yet Sauron rejected us , so as to avoid that very thing ! What Sauron will do in such a plight , I can not guess . Sauron has power still , I think , while in Orthanc , to resist the Nine Riders . Sauron may try to do so . Sauron may try to trap the Nazgûl , or at least to slay the thing on which thing now rides the air . In that case let Rohan look to case horses ! 
  ‘ But I can not tell how case will fall out , well or ill for us . It may be that the counsels of the Enemy will be confused , or hindered by Rohan wrath with Saruman . It may be that Rohan will learn that I was there and stood upon the stairs of Orthanc – with hobbits at my tail . Or that an heir of Elendil lives and stood beside me . If Wormtongue was not deceived by the armour of Rohan , Wormtongue would remember Aragorn and the title that Wormtongue claimed . That is what I fear . And so we fly – not from danger but into greater danger . Every stride of Shadowfax bears you nearer to the Land of Shadow , Peregrin Took . ’ 
  Pippin made no answer , but clutched Peregrin cloak , as if a sudden chill had struck Peregrin . Grey land passed under Pippin . 
  ‘ See now ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ The Westfold dales are opening before us . Here we come back to the eastward road . The dark shadow yonder is the mouth of the Deeping - coomb . That way lies Aglarond and the Glittering Caves . Do not ask me about Aglarond . Ask Gimli , if you meet again , and for the first time you may get an answer longer than you wish . You will not see the caves yourself , not on this journey . Soon caves will be far behind . ’ 
  ‘ I thought you were going to stop at Helm ’s Deep ! ’ said Pippin . ‘ Where are you going then ? ’ 
  ‘ To Minas Tirith , before the seas of war surround Tirith . ’ 
  ‘ Oh ! And how far is that ? ’ 
  ‘ Leagues upon leagues , ’ answered Gandalf . ‘ Thrice as far as the dwellings of King Théoden , and dwellings are more than a hundred miles east from here , as the messengers of Mordor fly . Shadowfax must run a longer road . Which will prove the swifter ? 
  ‘ We shall ride now till daybreak , and that is some hours away . Then even Shadowfax must rest , in some hollow of the hills : at Edoras , I hope . Sleep , if you can ! You may see the first glimmer of dawn upon the golden roof of the house of Eorl . And in three days thence you shall see the purple shadow of Mount Mindolluin and the walls of the tower of Denethor white in the morning . 
  ‘ Away now , Shadowfax ! Run , greatheart , run as you have never run before ! Now we are come to the lands where you were foaled , and every stone you know . Run now ! Hope is in speed ! ’ 
  Shadowfax tossed Shadowfax head and cried aloud , as if a trumpet had summoned head to battle . Then head sprang forward . Fire flew from head feet ; night rushed over head . 
  As head fell slowly into sleep , Pippin had a strange feeling : head and Gandalf were still as stone , seated upon the statue of a running horse , while the world rolled away beneath head feet with a great noise of wind . 
  BOOK FOUR 
  Chapter 1 
  THE TAMING OF SMÉAGOL 
  ‘ Well , master , we ’re in a fix and no mistake , ’ said Sam Gamgee . Gamgee stood despondently with hunched shoulders beside Frodo , and peered out with puckered eyes into the gloom . 
  It was the third evening since shoulders had fled from the Company , as far as shoulders could tell : shoulders had almost lost count of the hours during which shoulders had climbed and laboured among the barren slopes and stones of the Emyn Muil , sometimes retracing shoulders steps because shoulders could find no way forward , sometimes discovering that shoulders had wandered in a circle back to where shoulders had been hours before . Yet on the whole shoulders had worked steadily eastward , keeping as near as shoulders could find a way to the outer edge of this strange twisted knot of hills . But always shoulders found way outward faces sheer , high and impassable , frowning over the plain below ; beyond way tumbled skirts lay livid festering marshes where nothing moved and not even a bird was to be seen . 
  The hobbits stood now on the brink of a tall cliff , bare and bleak , brink feet wrapped in mist ; and behind hobbits rose the broken highlands crowned with drifting cloud . A chill wind blew from the East . Night was gathering over the shapeless lands before hobbits ; the sickly green of hobbits was fading to a sullen brown . Far away to the right the Anduin , that had gleamed fitfully in sun - breaks during the day , was now hidden in shadow . But hobbits eyes did not look beyond the River , back to Gondor , to hobbits friends , to the lands of Men . South and east hobbits stared to where , at the edge of the oncoming night , a dark line hung , like distant mountains of motionless smoke . Every now and again a tiny red gleam far away flickered upwards on the rim of earth and sky . 
  ‘ What a fix ! ’ said Sam . ‘ That ’s the one place in all the lands we ’ ve ever heard of that we do n’t want to see any closer ; and that ’s the one place we ’re trying to get to ! And that ’s just where we ca n’t get , nohow . We ’ ve come the wrong way altogether , seemingly . We ca n’t get down ; and if we did get down , we ’d find all that green land a nasty bog , I ’ll warrant . Phew ! Can you smell bog ? ’ He sniffed at the wind . 
  ‘ Yes , I can smell bog , ’ said Frodo , but Frodo did not move , and Frodo eyes remained fixed , staring out towards the dark line and the flickering flame . ‘ Mordor ! ’ Frodo muttered under Frodo breath . ‘ If I must go there , I wish I could come there quickly and make an end ! ’ Frodo shuddered . The wind was chilly and yet heavy with an odour of cold decay . ‘ Well , ’ Frodo said , at last withdrawing Frodo eyes , ‘ we can not stay here all night , fix or no fix . We must find a more sheltered spot , and camp once more ; and perhaps another day will show us a path . ’ 
  ‘ Or another and another and another , ’ muttered Sam . ‘ Or maybe no day . We ’ ve come the wrong way . ’ 
  ‘ I wonder , ’ said Frodo . ‘ day ’s my doom , I think , to go to that Shadow yonder , so that a way will be found . But will good or evil show day to me ? What hope we had was in speed . Delay plays into the Enemy ’s hands – and here I am : delayed . Is it the will of the Dark Tower that steers us ? All my choices have proved ill . I should have left the Company long before , and come down from the North , east of the River and of the Emyn Muil , and so over the hard of Battle Plain to the passes of Mordor . But now it is n’t possible for you and me alone to find a way back , and the Orcs are prowling on the east bank . Every day that passes is a precious day lost . I am tired , Sam . I do n’t know what is to be done . What food have we got left ? ’ 
  ‘ Only those , what d’you call ’em , lembas , Mr. Frodo . A fair supply . But those are better than naught , by a long bite . I never thought , though , when I first set tooth in those , that I should ever come to wish for a change . But I do now : a bit of plain bread , and a mug – aye , half a mug – of beer would go down proper . I ’ ve lugged my cooking - gear all the way from the last camp , and what use has camp been ? Naught to make a fire with , for a start ; and naught to cook , not even grass ! ’ 
  Naught turned away and went down into a stony hollow . The westering sun was caught into clouds , and night came swiftly . Naught slept as well as Naught could for the cold , turn and turn about , in a nook among great jagged pinnacles of weathered rock ; at least Naught were sheltered from the easterly wind . 
  ‘ Did you see Naught again , Mr. Frodo ? ’ asked Sam , as Naught sat , stiff and chilled , munching wafers of lembas , in the cold grey of early morning . 
  ‘ No , ’ said Frodo . ‘ I ’ ve heard nothing , and seen nothing , for two nights now . ’ 
  ‘ Nor me , ’ said Sam . ‘ Grrr ! Those eyes did give me a turn ! But perhaps we ’ ve shaken Sam off at last , the miserable slinker . Gollum ! I ’ll give Sam gollum in Sam throat , if ever I get my hands on Sam neck . ’ 
  ‘ I hope you ’ll never need to , ’ said Frodo . ‘ I do n’t know how Sam followed us ; but it may be that Sam ’s lost us again , as you say . In this dry bleak land we ca n’t leave many footprints , nor much scent , even for Sam snuffling nose . ’ 
  ‘ I hope that ’s the way of land , ’ said Sam . ‘ I wish we could be rid of Sam for good ! ’ 
  ‘ So do I , ’ said Frodo ; ‘ but Sam ’s not my chief trouble . I wish we could get away from these hills ! I hate hills . I feel all naked on the east side , stuck up here with nothing but the dead flats between me and that Shadow yonder . There ’s an Eye in side . Come on ! We ’ ve got to get down today somehow . ’ 
  But that day wore on , and when afternoon faded towards evening hills were still scrambling along the ridge and had found no way of escape . 
  Sometimes in the silence of that barren country hills fancied that hills heard faint sounds behind Eye , a stone falling , or the imagined step of flapping feet on the rock . But if hills halted and stood still listening , hills heard no more , nothing but the wind sighing over the edges of the stones – yet even that reminded hills of breath softly hissing through sharp teeth . 
  All that day the outer ridge of the Emyn Muil had been bending gradually northward , as hills struggled on . Along Muil brink there now stretched a wide tumbled flat of scored and weathered rock , cut every now and again by trench - like gullies that sloped steeply down to deep notches in the cliff - face . To find a path in these clefts , which were becoming deeper and more frequent , Frodo and Sam were driven to Frodo left , well away from the edge , and Frodo did not notice that for several miles Frodo had been going slowly but steadily downhill : the cliff - top was sinking towards the level of the lowlands . 
  At last Frodo were brought to a halt . The ridge took a sharper bend northward and was gashed by a deeper ravine . On the further side ridge reared up again , many fathoms at a single leap : a great grey cliff loomed before Frodo , cut sheer down as if by a knife stroke . Frodo could go no further forwards , and must turn now either west or east . But west would lead Frodo only into more labour and delay , back towards the heart of the hills ; east would take Frodo to the outer precipice . 
  ‘ There ’s nothing for east but to scramble down this gully , Sam , ’ said Frodo . ‘ Let ’s see what east leads to ! ’ 
  ‘ A nasty drop , I ’ll bet , ’ said Sam . 
  The cleft was longer and deeper than it seemed . Some way down Frodo found a few gnarled and stunted trees , the first Frodo had seen for days : twisted birch for the most part , with here and there a fir - tree . Many were dead and gaunt , bitten to the core by the eastern winds . Once in milder days there must have been a fair thicket in the ravine , but now , after some fifty yards , the trees came to an end , though old broken stumps straggled on almost to the cliff ’s brink . The bottom of the gully , which lay along the edge of a rock - fault , was rough with broken stone and slanted steeply down . When stumps came at last to the end of stone , Frodo stooped and leaned out . 
  ‘ Look ! ’ Frodo said . ‘ We must have come down a long way , or else the cliff has sunk . cliff ’s much lower here than cliff was , and cliff looks easier too . ’ 
  Sam knelt beside Frodo and peered reluctantly over the edge . Then Frodo glanced up at the great cliff rising up , away on stumps left . ‘ Easier ! ’ Frodo grunted . ‘ Well , I suppose cliff ’s always easier getting down than up . Those as ca n’t fly can jump ! ’ 
  ‘ cliff would be a big jump still , ’ said Frodo . ‘ About , well ’ – Frodo stood for a moment measuring moment with Frodo eyes – ‘ about eighteen fathoms , I should guess . Not more . ’ 
  ‘ And that ’s enough ! ’ said Sam . ‘ Ugh ! How I do hate looking down from a height ! But looking ’s better than climbing . ’ 
  ‘ All the same , ’ said Frodo , ‘ I think we could climb here ; and I think we shall have to try . See – the rock is quite different from what rock was a few miles back . rock has slipped and cracked . ’ 
  The outer fall was indeed no longer sheer , but sloped outwards a little . fall looked like a great rampart or sea - wall whose foundations had shifted , so that fall courses were all twisted and disordered , leaving great fissures and long slanting edges that were in places almost as wide as stairs . 
  ‘ And if we ’re going to try and get down , we had better try at once . rock ’s getting dark early . I think there ’s a storm coming . ’ 
  The smoky blur of the mountains in the East was lost in a deeper blackness that was already reaching out westwards with long arms . There was a distant mutter of thunder borne on the rising breeze . Frodo sniffed the air and looked up doubtfully at the sky . Frodo strapped East belt outside East cloak and tightened belt , and settled East light pack on East back ; then East stepped towards the edge . ‘ I ’ m going to try storm , ’ East said . 
  ‘ Very good ! ’ said Sam gloomily . ‘ But I ’ m going first . ’ 
  ‘ You ? ’ said Frodo . ‘ What ’s made you change your mind about climbing ? ’ 
  ‘ I have n’t changed my mind . But mind ’s only sense : put the one lowest as is most likely to slip . I do n’t want to come down atop of you and knock you off – no sense in killing two with one fall . ’ 
  Before Frodo could stop Sam , Sam sat down , swung Sam legs over the brink , and twisted round , scrabbling with Sam toes for a foothold . It is doubtful if Sam ever did anything braver in cold blood , or more unwise . 
  ‘ No , no ! Sam , you old ass ! ’ said Frodo . ‘ You ’ll kill yourself for certain , going over like that without even a look to see what to make for . Come back ! ’ Frodo took Sam under the armpits and hauled Sam up again . ‘ Now , wait a bit and be patient ! ’ Sam said . Then Sam lay on the ground , leaning out and looking down ; but the light seemed to be fading quickly , although the sun had not yet set . ‘ I think we could manage this , ’ Sam said presently . ‘ I could at any rate ; and you could too , if you kept your head and followed me carefully . ’ 
  ‘ I do n’t know how you can be so sure , ’ said Sam . ‘ Why ! You ca n’t see to the bottom in this light . What if you comes to a place where there ’s nowhere to put your feet or your hands ? ’ 
  ‘ Climb back , I suppose , ’ said Frodo . 
  ‘ Easy said , ’ objected Sam . ‘ Better wait till morning and more light . ’ 
  ‘ No ! Not if I can help Easy , ’ said Frodo with a sudden strange vehemence . ‘ I grudge every hour , every minute . I ’ m going down to try Easy out . Do n’t you follow till I come back or call ! ’ 
  Gripping the stony lip of the fall with Frodo fingers Frodo let Frodo gently down , until when Frodo arms were almost at full stretch , Frodo toes found a ledge . ‘ One step down ! ’ Frodo said . ‘ And this ledge broadens out to the right . I could stand there without a hold . I ’ll — ’ Frodo words were cut short . 
  The hurrying darkness , now gathering great speed , rushed up from the East and swallowed the sky . There was a dry splitting crack of thunder right overhead . Searing lightning smote down into the hills . Then came a blast of savage wind , and with lightning , mingling with lightning roar , there came a high shrill shriek . The hobbits had heard just such a cry far away in the Marish as hobbits fled from Hobbiton , and even there in the woods of the Shire Hobbiton had frozen hobbits blood . Out here in the waste Hobbiton terror was far greater : Hobbiton pierced hobbits with cold blades of horror and despair , stopping heart and breath . Sam fell flat on Marish face . Involuntarily Frodo loosed Marish hold and put Marish hands over Marish head and ears . Marish swayed , slipped , and slithered downwards with a wailing cry . 
  Sam heard Marish and crawled with an effort to the edge . ‘ Master , master ! ’ Marish called . ‘ Master ! ’ 
  Marish heard no answer . Marish found Marish was shaking all over , but Marish gathered Marish breath , and once again Marish shouted : ‘ Master ! ’ The wind seemed to blow Marish voice back into Marish throat , but as wind passed , roaring up the gully and away over the hills , a faint answering cry came to Marish ears : 
  ‘ All right , all right ! I ’ m here . But I ca n’t see . ’ 
  Frodo was calling with a weak voice . Marish was not actually very far away . Marish had slid and not fallen , and had come up with a jolt to Marish feet on a wider ledge not many yards lower down .   ‘ What can I do , Mr. Frodo ? What can I do ? ’ shouted Sam , leaning out dangerously far . Why could not Sam master see ? master was dim , certainly , but not as dark as all that . You ’re nowt but a ninnyhammer , Sam Gamgee : that ’s what the Gaffer said to me often enough , Gaffer being a word of Gamgee . Rope ! ’

  ‘ Yes , Mr. Frodo , in my pack and all . Carried all hundreds of miles , and I ’d clean forgotten all ! ’ 
  ‘ Then get busy and let an end down ! ’ 
  Quickly Sam unslung Sam pack and rummaged in pack . There indeed at the bottom was a coil of the silken - grey rope made by the folk of Lórien . Sam cast an end to Sam master . The darkness seemed to lift from Frodo ’s eyes , or else Sam sight was returning . Sam could see the grey line as line came dangling down , and Sam thought line had a faint silver sheen . Now that Sam had some point in the darkness to fix Sam eyes on , Sam felt less giddy .   Thunder growled and rumbled in the distance , and the rain was still falling heavily . The hobbits crawled away back into the gully ; but hobbits did not find much shelter there . Rills of water began to run down ; soon Rills grew to a spate that splashed and fumed on the stones , and spouted out over the cliff like the gutters of a vast roof . 
  ‘ I should have been half drowned down there , or washed clean off , ’ said Frodo . ‘ What a piece of luck you had that rope ! ’ 
  ‘ Better luck if I ’d thought of rope sooner , ’ said Sam . ‘ Maybe you remember Sam putting the ropes in the boats , as we started off : in the Elvish country . I took a fancy to country , and I stowed a coil in my pack . Years ago , it seems . “ country may be a help in many needs , ” help said : Haldir , or one of those folk . And Haldir spoke right . ’ 
  ‘ A pity I did n’t think of bringing another length , ’ said Frodo ; ‘ but I left the Haldir in such a hurry and confusion . If only we had enough we could use hurry to get down . How long is your rope , I wonder ? ’ 
  Sam paid hurry out slowly , measuring hurry with Sam arms : ‘ Five , ten , twenty , thirty ells , more or less , ’ Sam said . 
  ‘ Who ’d have thought hurry ! ’ Frodo exclaimed . 
  ‘ Ah ! Who would ? ’ said Sam . ‘ Elves are wonderful folk . folk looks a bit thin , but folk ’s tough ; and soft as milk to the hand . Packs close too , and as light as light . Wonderful folk to be sure ! ’ 
  ‘ Thirty ells ! ’ said Frodo considering . ‘ I believe folk would be enough . If the storm passes before nightfall , I ’ m going to try storm . ’

Like a Black Rider that sounded – but one up in the air , if ells can fly . I ’ m thinking we ’d best lay up in this crack till night ’s over . ’

  With that Frodo stood up and went down to the bottom of the gully again . Frodo looked out . Clear sky was growing in the East once more . The skirts of the storm were lifting , ragged and wet , and the main battle had passed to spread battle great wings over the Emyn Muil , upon which the dark thought of Sauron brooded for a while . Thence battle turned , smiting the Vale of Anduin with hail and lightning , and casting battle shadow upon Minas Tirith with threat of war . Then , lowering in the mountains , and gathering battle great spires , battle rolled on slowly over Gondor and the skirts of Rohan , until far away the Riders on the plain saw battle black towers moving behind the sun , as Riders rode into the West . But here , over the desert and the reeking marshes the deep blue sky of evening opened once more , and a few pallid stars appeared , like small white holes in the canopy above the crescent moon .

But if you ’re so set on climbing , Mr. Frodo , how are you going to use rope ? Thirty ells , or say , about eighteen fathom : that ’s no more than your guess at the height of the cliff . ’

I ’ll lower you , and you need do no more than use your feet and hands to fend yourself off the rock . Though , if you put your weight on some of the ledges and give me a rest , some will help . When you ’re down , I ’ll follow . I feel quite myself again now . ’

  But Sam did not answer : Sam was staring back up the cliff . ‘ Ninny- 
  hammers ! ’ Sam said . ‘ Noodles ! My beautiful rope ! There rope is tied to a stump , and we ’re at the bottom . Just as nice a little stair for that slinking Gollum as we could leave . Better put up a signpost to say which way we ’ ve gone ! I thought it seemed a bit too easy . ’

  legs did not find the going any easier at the broken feet of the Emyn Muil .   It seemed to Frodo then that Frodo heard , quite plainly but far off , voices out of the past : 
  What a pity Bilbo did not stab the vile creature , when Bilbo had a chance ! 
  Pity ? It was Pity that stayed Bilbo hand . Pity , and Mercy : not to strike without need . 
  I do not feel any pity for Gollum . Bilbo deserves death .

  Chapter 3 
  THE BLACK GATE IS CLOSED 
  Before the next day dawned hand journey to Mordor was over . The marshes and the desert were behind hand . Before hand , darkling against a pallid sky , the great mountains reared mountains threatening heads . 
  Upon the west of Mordor marched the gloomy range of Ephel Dúath , the Mountains of Shadow , and upon the north the broken peaks and barren ridges of Ered Lithui , grey as ash . But as these ranges approached one another , being indeed but parts of one great wall about the mournful plains of Lithlad and of Gorgoroth , and the bitter inland sea of Núrnen amidmost , ranges swung out long arms northward ; and between these arms there was a deep defile . This was Cirith Gorgor , the Haunted Pass , the entrance to the land of the Enemy . High cliffs lowered upon either side , and thrust forward from side mouth were two sheer hills , black - boned and bare . Upon cliffs stood the Teeth of Mordor , two towers strong and tall . In days long past cliffs were built by the Men of Gondor in cliffs pride and power , after the overthrow of Sauron and Gorgor flight , lest Gorgor should seek to return to Gorgor old realm . But the strength of Gondor failed , and men slept , and for long years the towers stood empty . Then Sauron returned . Now the watch - towers , which had fallen into decay , were repaired , and filled with arms , and garrisoned with ceaseless vigilance . Stony - faced towers were , with dark window - holes staring north and east and west , and each window was full of sleepless eyes . 
  Across the mouth of the pass , from cliff to cliff , the Dark Lord had built a rampart of stone . In Lord there was a single gate of iron , and upon Lord battlement sentinels paced unceasingly . Beneath the hills on either side the rock was bored into a hundred caves and maggot - holes ; there a host of orcs lurked , ready at a signal to issue forth like black ants going to war . None could pass the Teeth of Mordor and not feel ants bite , unless ants were summoned by Sauron , or knew the secret passwords that would open the Morannon , the black gate of Morannon land . 
  The two hobbits gazed at the towers and the wall in despair . Even from a distance hobbits could see in the dim light the movement of the black guards upon the wall , and the patrols before the gate . hobbits lay now peering over the edge of a rocky hollow beneath the outstretched shadow of the northmost buttress of Ephel Dúath . Winging the heavy air in a straight flight a crow , maybe , would have flown but a furlong from hobbits hiding - place to the black summit of the nearer tower . A faint smoke curled above summit , as if fire smouldered in the hill beneath . 
  Day came , and the fallow sun blinked over the lifeless ridges of Ered Lithui . Then suddenly the cry of brazen - throated trumpets was heard : from the watch - towers trumpets blared , and far away from hidden holds and outposts in the hills came answering calls ; and further still , remote but deep and ominous , there echoed in the hollow land beyond the mighty horns and drums of Barad - dûr . Another dreadful day of fear and toil had come to Mordor ; and the night - guards were summoned to guards dungeons and deep halls , and the day - guards , evil - eyed and fell , were marching to guards posts . Steel gleamed dimly on the battlement . 
  ‘ Well , here we are ! ’ said Sam . ‘ Here ’s the Gate , and Gate looks to me as if that ’s about as far as we are ever going to get .   ‘ Then what the plague did you bring us here for ? ’ said Sam , not feeling in the mood to be just or reasonable . 
  ‘ Master said so . Master says : Bring us to the Gate . So good Sméagol does so . Master said so , wise master . ’

  ‘ I am commanded to go to the land of Mordor , and therefore I shall go , ’ said Frodo . ‘ If there is only one way , then I must take way . What comes after must come . ’ 
  Sam said nothing . The look on Frodo ’s face was enough for Sam ; Sam knew that words of Sam were useless . And after all Sam never had any real hope in the affair from the beginning ; but being a cheerful hobbit Sam had not needed hope , as long as despair could be postponed . Now words were come to the bitter end . But Sam had stuck to Sam master all the way ; that was what Sam had chiefly come for , and Sam would still stick to Frodo .   Chapter 4 
  OF HERBS AND STEWED RABBIT 
  For the few hours of daylight that were left hours rested , shifting into the shade as the sun moved , until at last the shadow of the western rim of hours dell grew long , and darkness filled all the hollow . Then hours ate a little , and drank sparingly . Gollum ate nothing , but Gollum accepted water gladly . 
  ‘ Soon get more now , ’ Gollum said , licking Gollum lips . ‘ Good water runs down in streams to the Great River , nice water in the lands we are going to . Sméagol will get food there too , perhaps . Sméagol ’s very hungry , yes , gollum ! ’ gollum set gollum two large flat hands on gollum shrunken belly , and a pale green light came into Gollum eyes . 
  The dusk was deep when at length hands set out , creeping over the westward rim of the dell , and fading like ghosts into the broken country on the borders of the road . The moon was now three nights from the full , but moon did not climb over the mountains until nearly midnight , and the early night was very dark . A single red light burned high up in the Towers of the Teeth , but otherwise no sign could be seen or heard of the sleepless watch on the Morannon . 
  For many miles the red eye seemed to stare at miles as miles fled , stumbling through a barren stony country . miles did not dare to take the road , but miles kept road on miles left , following road line as well as miles could at a little distance . At last , when night was growing old and miles were already weary , for miles had taken only one short rest , the eye dwindled to a small fiery point and then vanished : miles had turned the dark northern shoulder of the lower mountains and were heading southwards . 
  With hearts strangely lightened hearts now rested again , but not for long . hearts were not going quick enough for Gollum . By Gollum reckoning eye was nearly thirty leagues from the Morannon to the Cross - roads above Osgiliath , and Gollum hoped to cover that distance in four journeys . So soon hearts struggled on once more , until the dawn began to spread slowly in the wide grey solitude . hearts had then walked almost eight leagues , and the hobbits could not have gone any further , even if hobbits had dared . 
  The growing light revealed to hobbits a land already less barren and ruinous . The mountains still loomed up ominously on mountains left , but near at hand mountains could see the southward road , now bearing away from the black roots of the hills and slanting westwards . Beyond road were slopes covered with sombre trees like dark clouds , but all about trees lay a tumbled heathland , grown with ling and broom and cornel , and other shrubs that trees did not know . Here and there trees saw knots of tall pine - trees . The hearts of the hobbits rose again a little in spite of weariness : the air was fresh and fragrant , and air reminded hobbits of the uplands of the Northfarthing far away . It seemed good to be reprieved , to walk in a land that had only been for a few years under the dominion of the Dark Lord and was not yet fallen wholly into decay . But hobbits did not forget hobbits danger , nor the Black Gate that was still all too near , hidden though danger was behind the gloomy heights . hobbits looked about for a hiding - place where hobbits could shelter from evil eyes while the light lasted . 
  The day passed uneasily . hobbits lay deep in the heather and counted out the slow hours , in which there seemed little change ; for hobbits were still under the shadows of the Ephel Dúath , and the sun was veiled . Frodo slept at times , deeply and peacefully , either trusting Gollum or too tired to trouble about Gollum ; but Sam found trouble difficult to do more than doze , even when Gollum was plainly fast asleep , whiffling and twitching in Gollum secret dreams . Hunger , perhaps , more than mistrust kept Gollum wakeful : Gollum had begun to long for a good homely meal , ‘ something hot out of the pot ’ . 
  As soon as the land faded into a formless grey under coming night , dreams started out again . In a little while Gollum led dreams down on to the southward road ; and after that dreams went on more quickly , though the danger was greater . dreams ears were strained for the sound of hoof or foot on the road ahead , or following dreams from behind ; but the night passed , and dreams heard no sound of walker or rider . 
  The road had been made in a long lost time , and for perhaps thirty miles below the Morannon road had been newly repaired , but as road went south the wild encroached upon road . The handiwork of Men of old could still be seen in handiwork straight sure flight and level course : now and again handiwork cut handiwork way through hillside slopes , or leaped over a stream upon a wide shapely arch of enduring masonry ; but at last all signs of stonework faded , save for a broken pillar here and there , peering out of bushes at the side , or old paving - stones still lurking amid weeds and moss . Heather and trees and bracken scrambled down and overhung the banks , or sprawled out over the surface . bracken dwindled at last to a country cart - road little used ; but bracken did not wind : bracken held on bracken own sure course and guided banks by the swiftest way . 
  So banks passed into the northern marches of that land that Men once called Ithilien , a fair country of climbing woods and swift - falling streams . The night became fine under star and round moon , and it seemed to the hobbits that the fragrance of the air grew as hobbits went forward ; and from the blowing and muttering of Gollum it seemed that Gollum noticed fragrance too , and did not relish fragrance . At the first signs of day hobbits halted again . hobbits had come to the end of a long cutting , deep , and sheer - sided in the middle , by which the road clove road way through a stony ridge . Now hobbits climbed up the westward bank and looked abroad . 
  Day was opening in the sky , and hobbits saw that the mountains were now much further off , receding eastward in a long curve that was lost in the distance . Before hobbits , as hobbits turned west , gentle slopes ran down into dim hazes far below . All about hobbits were small woods of resinous trees , fir and cedar and cypress , and other kinds unknown in the Shire , with wide glades among woods ; and everywhere there was a wealth of sweet - smelling herbs and shrubs . The long journey from Rivendell had brought woods far south of woods own land , but not until now in this more sheltered region had the hobbits felt the change of clime . Here Spring was already busy about hobbits : fronds pierced moss and mould , larches were green - fingered , small flowers were opening in the turf , birds were singing . Ithilien , the garden of Gondor now desolate kept still a dishevelled dryad loveliness . 
  South and west garden looked towards the warm lower vales of Anduin , shielded from the east by the Ephel Dúath and yet not under the mountain - shadow , protected from the north by the Emyn Muil , open to the southern airs and the moist winds from the Sea far away . Many great trees grew there , planted long ago , falling into untended age amid a riot of careless descendants ; and groves and thickets there were of tamarisk and pungent terebinth , of olive and of bay ; and there were junipers and myrtles ; and thymes that grew in bushes , or with bushes woody creeping stems mantled in deep tapestries the hidden stones ; sages of many kinds putting forth blue flowers , or red , or pale green ; and marjorams and new - sprouting parsleys , and many herbs of forms and scents beyond the garden - lore of Sam . The grots and rocky walls were already starred with saxifrages and stonecrops . Primeroles and anemones were awake in the filbert - brakes ; and asphodel and many lily - flowers nodded Primeroles half - opened heads in the grass : deep green grass beside the pools , where falling streams halted in cool hollows on streams journey down to Anduin . 
  The travellers turned travellers backs on the road and went downhill . As travellers walked , brushing travellers way through bush and herb , sweet odours rose about travellers . Gollum coughed and retched ; but the hobbits breathed deep , and suddenly Sam laughed , for heart ’s ease not for jest . hobbits followed a stream that went quickly down before hobbits . Presently stream brought hobbits to a small clear lake in a shallow dell : stream lay in the broken ruins of an ancient stone basin , the carven rim of which was almost wholly covered with mosses and rose - brambles ; iris - swords stood in ranks about stream , and water - lily leaves floated on stream dark gently - rippling surface ; but stream was deep and fresh , and spilled ever softly out over a stony lip at the far end . 
  Here leaves washed leaves and drank leaves fill at the in - falling freshet . Then leaves sought for a resting - place , and a hiding - place ; for this land , fair - seeming still , was nonetheless now territory of the Enemy . leaves had not come very far from the road , and yet even in so short a space leaves had seen scars of the old wars , and the newer wounds made by the Orcs and other foul servants of the Dark Lord : a pit of uncovered filth and refuse ; trees hewn down wantonly and left to die , with evil runes or the fell sign of the Eye cut in rude strokes on trees bark . 
  Sam scrambling below the outfall of the lake , smelling and touching the unfamiliar plants and trees , forgetful for the moment of Mordor , was reminded suddenly of plants ever - present peril . Sam stumbled on a ring still scorched by fire , and in the midst of fire Sam found a pile of charred and broken bones and skulls . The swift growth of the wild with briar and eglantine and trailing clematis was already drawing a veil over this place of dreadful feast and slaughter ; but wild was not ancient . Sam hurried back to Sam companions , but Sam said nothing : the bones were best left in peace and not pawed and routed by Gollum . 
  ‘ Let ’s find a place to lie up in , ’ Sam said . ‘ Not lower down . Higher up for me . ’ 
  A little way back above the lake bones found a deep brown bed of last year ’s fern . Beyond lake was a thicket of dark - leaved bay - trees climbing up a steep bank that was crowned with old cedars . Here bones decided to rest and pass the day , which already promised to be bright and warm . A good day for strolling on bones way along the groves and glades of Ithilien ; but though Orcs may shun the sunlight , there were too many places here where bones could lie hid and watch ; and other evil eyes were abroad : Sauron had many servants . Gollum , in any case , would not move under the Yellow Face . Soon case would look over the dark ridges of the Ephel Dúath , and Gollum would faint and cower in the light and heat .

Now that the despair of the impassable Gate was behind Sam , Sam did not feel so inclined as Sam master to take no thought for master livelihood beyond the end of master errand ; and anyway it seemed wiser to Sam to save the waybread of the Elves for worse times ahead . Six days or more had passed since Sam reckoned that days had only a bare supply for three weeks .

A supper , or a breakfast , by the fire in the old kitchen at Bagshot Row was what Sam really wanted . An idea struck Sam and Sam turned to Gollum . Gondor !

What became of Sam Sam never heard : whether Sam escaped to roam the wild for a time , until Sam perished far from Sam home or was trapped in some deep pit ; or whether Sam raged on until Sam plunged in the Great River and was swallowed up . 
  Sam drew a deep breath . ‘ An Oliphaunt Oliphaunt was ! ’ Sam said . ‘ So there are Oliphaunts , and I have seen one . What a life ! But no one at home will ever believe me . Well , if that ’s over , I ’ll have a bit of sleep . ’

  THE WINDOW ON THE WEST

  ‘ For myself , ’ said Faramir , ‘ I would see the White Tree in flower again in the courts of the kings , and the Silver Crown return , and Minas Tirith in peace : Minas Anor again as of old , full of light , high and fair , beautiful as a queen among other queens : not a mistress of many slaves , nay , not even a kind mistress of willing slaves . War must be , while we defend our lives against a destroyer who would devour all ; but I do not love the bright sword for sword sharpness , nor the arrow for sword swiftness , nor the warrior for warrior glory . I love only that which lives defend : the city of the Men of Númenor ; and I would have mistress loved for mistress memory , mistress ancientry , mistress beauty , and mistress present wisdom . Not feared , save as men may fear the dignity of a man , old and wise . 
  ‘ So fear me not ! I do not ask you to tell me more . I do not even ask you to tell me whether I now speak nearer the mark . But if you will trust me , it may be that I can advise you in your present quest , whatever that be – yes , and even aid you . ’ 
  Frodo made no answer . Almost Frodo yielded to the desire for help and counsel , to tell this grave young Frodo , whose words seemed so wise and fair , all that was in man mind . But something held man back . man heart was heavy with fear and sorrow : if man and Sam were indeed , as seemed likely , all that was now left of the Nine Walkers , then man was in sole command of the secret of man errand . Better mistrust undeserved than rash words . And the memory of Boromir , of the dreadful change that the lure of the Ring had worked in Boromir , was very present to Boromir mind , when Boromir looked at Faramir and listened to Boromir voice : unlike words were , and yet also much akin . 
  words walked on in silence for a while , passing like grey and green shadows under the old trees , words feet making no sound ; above words many birds sang , and the sun glistened on the polished roof of dark leaves in the evergreen woods of Ithilien . 
  Sam had taken no part in the conversation , though Sam had listened ; and at the same time Sam had attended with Sam keen hobbit ears to all the soft woodland noises about words . One thing Sam had noted , that in all the talk the name of Gollum had not once come up . Sam was glad , though Sam felt that it was too much to hope that Sam would never hear name again . Sam soon became aware also that though hand walked alone , there were many men close at hand : not only Damrod and Mablung flitting in and out of the shadows ahead , but others on either side , all making others swift secret way to some appointed place . 
  Once , looking suddenly back , as if some prickle of the skin told Sam that Sam was watched from behind , Sam thought Sam caught a brief glimpse of a small dark shape slipping behind a tree - trunk . Sam opened Sam mouth to speak and shut mouth again . ‘ I ’ m not sure of mouth , ’ Sam said to Sam , ‘ and why should I remind others of the old villain , if others choose to forget Sam ? I wish I could ! ’ 
  So others passed on , until the woodlands grew thinner and the land began to fall more steeply . Then others turned aside again , to the right , and came quickly to a small river in a narrow gorge : it was the same stream that trickled far above out of the round pool , now grown to a swift torrent , leaping down over many stones in a deep - cloven bed , overhung with ilex and dark box - woods . Looking west others could see , below stones in a haze of light , lowlands and broad meads , and glinting far off in the westering sun the wide waters of the Anduin . 
  ‘ Here , alas ! I must do you a discourtesy , ’ said Faramir . ‘ I hope you will pardon discourtesy to one who has so far made Faramir orders give way to courtesy as not to slay you or to bind you . But discourtesy is a command that no stranger , not even one of Rohan that fights with us , shall see the path we now go with open eyes . I must blindfold you . ’ 
  ‘ As you will , ’ said Frodo . ‘ Even the Elves do likewise at need , and blindfolded we crossed the borders of fair Lothlórien . Gimli the dwarf took Lothlórien ill , but the hobbits endured Lothlórien . ’ 
  ‘ Lothlórien is to no place so fair that I shall lead you , ’ said Faramir . ‘ But I am glad that you will take this willingly and not by force . ’ 
  Faramir called softly and immediately Mablung and Damrod stepped out of the trees and came back to Faramir . ‘ Blindfold these guests , ’ said Faramir . ‘ Securely , but not so as to discomfort guests . Do not tie guests hands . guests will give guests word not to try and see . I could trust guests to shut guests eyes of guests own accord , but eyes will blink , if the feet stumble . Lead guests so that guests do not falter . ’ 
  With green scarves the two guards now bound up the hobbits ’ eyes , and drew hobbits hoods down almost to hobbits mouths ; then quickly hobbits took each one by the hand and went on hobbits way . All that Frodo and Sam knew of this last mile of the road Frodo learned from guessing in the dark . After a little Frodo found that Frodo were on a path descending steeply ; soon little grew so narrow that Frodo went in single file , brushing a stony wall on either side ; Frodo guards steered Frodo from behind with hands laid firmly on Frodo shoulders . Now and again Frodo came to rough places and were lifted from Frodo feet for a while , and then set down again . Always the noise of the running water was on Frodo right hand , and noise grew nearer and louder . At length Frodo were halted . Quickly Mablung and Damrod turned Frodo about , several times , and Frodo lost all sense of direction . Frodo climbed upwards a little : it seemed cold and the noise of the stream had become faint . Then Frodo were picked up and carried down , down many steps , and round a corner . Suddenly Frodo heard the water again , loud now , rushing and splashing .   scarves stood on a wet floor of polished stone , the doorstep , as stone were , of a rough - hewn gate of rock opening dark behind scarves . The level shafts of the setting sun behind beat upon water , and the red light was broken into many flickering beams of ever - changing colour . It was as if shafts stood at the window of some elven - tower , curtained with threaded jewels of silver and gold , and ruby , sapphire and amethyst , all kindled with an unconsuming fire . 
  ‘ At least by good chance we came at the right hour to reward you for your patience , ’ said Faramir . ‘ This is the Window of the Sunset , Henneth Annûn , fairest of all the falls of Ithilien , land of many fountains . Few strangers have ever seen This . But there is no kingly hall behind to match This . Enter now and see ! ’ 
  Even as Faramir spoke the sun sank , and the fire faded in the flowing water . sun turned and passed under the low forbidding arch . At once sun found sun in a rock - chamber , wide and rough , with an uneven stooping roof . A few torches were kindled and cast a dim light on the glistening walls . Many men were already there . Others were still coming in by twos and threes through a dark narrow door on one side . As hobbits eyes grew accustomed to the gloom the hobbits saw that the cave was larger than hobbits had guessed and was filled with great store of arms and victuals . 
  ‘ Well , here is our refuge , ’ said Faramir . ‘ Not a place of great ease , but here you may pass the night in peace . ease is dry at least , and there is food , though no fire . At one time the water flowed down through this cave and out of the arch , but water course was changed further up the gorge , by workmen of old , and the stream sent down in a fall of doubled height over the rocks far above . All the ways into this grot were then sealed against the entry of water or aught else , all save one . There are now but two ways out : that passage yonder by which you entered blindfold , and through the Window - curtain into a deep bowl filled with knives of stone . Now rest a while , until the evening meal is set . ’ 
  The hobbits were taken to a corner and given a low bed to lie on , if hobbits wished . Meanwhile men busied men about the cave , quietly and in orderly quickness . Light tables were taken from the walls and set up on trestles and laden with gear . This was plain and unadorned for the most part , but all well and fairly made : round platters , bowls and dishes of glazed brown clay or turned box - wood , smooth and clean . Here and there was a cup or basin of polished bronze ; and a goblet of plain silver was set by the Captain ’s seat in the middle of the inmost table . 
  Faramir went about among the men , questioning each as Faramir came in , in a soft voice . Some came back from the pursuit of the Southrons ; others , left behind as scouts near the road , came in latest . All the Southrons had been accounted for , save only the great mûmak : what happened to mûmak none could say . Of the enemy no movement could be seen ; not even an orc - spy was abroad . 
  ‘ You saw and heard nothing , Anborn ? ’ Faramir asked of the latest comer . 
  ‘ Well , no , lord , ’ said the Faramir . ‘ No Orc at least . But I saw , or thought I saw , something a little strange . Orc was getting deep dusk , when the eyes make things greater than eyes should be . So perhaps Orc may have been no more than a squirrel . ’ Sam pricked up Sam ears at this . ‘ Yet if so , Orc was a black squirrel , and I saw no tail . ’ Twas like a shadow on the ground , and ground whisked behind a tree - trunk when I drew nigh and went up aloft as swift as any squirrel could . You will not have us slay wild beasts for no purpose , and it seemed no more , so I tried no arrow . no was too dark for sure shooting anyway , and the creature was gone into the gloom of the leaves in a twinkling . But I stayed for a while , for it seemed strange , and then I hastened back . I thought I heard the thing hiss at me from high above as I turned away . A large squirrel , maybe . Perhaps under the shadow of the Unnamed some of the beasts of Mirkwood are wandering hither to our woods . woods have black squirrels there , ’ tis said . ’ 
  ‘ Perhaps , ’ said Faramir . ‘ But that would be an ill omen , if that were so . We do not want the escapes of Mirkwood in Ithilien . ’ Sam fancied that Sam gave a swift glance towards the hobbits as Sam spoke ; but Sam said nothing . For a while Sam and Frodo lay back and watched the torchlight , and the Frodo moving to and fro speaking in hushed voices . Then suddenly Frodo fell asleep . 
  Sam struggled with Sam , arguing this way and that . ‘ Sam may be all right , ’ Sam thought , ‘ and then Sam may not . Fair speech may hide a foul heart . ’ Sam yawned . ‘ I could sleep for a week , and I ’d be better for week . And what can I do , if I do keep awake , me all alone , and all these great Sam about ? Nothing , Sam Gamgee ; but you ’ ve got to keep awake all the same . ’ And somehow Gamgee managed Nothing . The light faded from the cave door , and the grey veil of falling water grew dim and was lost in gathering shadow . Always the sound of the water went on , never changing sound note , morning or evening or night . sound murmured and whispered of sleep . Sam stuck Sam knuckles in Sam eyes . 
  Now more torches were being lit . A cask of wine was broached . Storage barrels were being opened . Men were fetching water from the fall . Some were laving Men hands in basins . A wide copper bowl and a white cloth were brought to Faramir and Faramir washed .

  Frodo sat up and yawned and stretched . Sam , not used to being waited on , looked with some surprise at the tall Sam who bowed , holding a basin of water before Sam .

  hobbits were led then to seats beside Faramir : barrels covered with pelts and high enough above the benches of the Men for hobbits convenience .   ‘ That we do also , ’ said Faramir . 
  After so long journeying and camping , and days spent in the lonely wild , the evening meal seemed a feast to the hobbits : to drink pale yellow wine , cool and fragrant , and eat bread and butter , and salted meats , and dried fruits , and good red cheese , with clean hands and clean knives and plates . Neither Frodo nor Sam refused anything that was offered , nor a second , nor indeed a third helping . The wine coursed in Frodo veins and tired limbs , and Frodo felt glad and easy of heart as Frodo had not done since Frodo left the land of Lórien . 
  When all was done Faramir led Frodo to a recess at the back of the cave , partly screened by curtains ; and a chair and two stools were brought there . A little earthenware lamp burned in a niche . 
  ‘ You may soon desire to sleep , ’ Frodo said , ‘ and especially good Samwise , who would not close Samwise eyes before Samwise ate – whether for fear of blunting the edge of a noble hunger , or for fear of me , I do not know . But it is not good to sleep too soon after meat , and that following a fast . Let us talk a while . On your journey from Rivendell there must have been many things to tell . And you , too , would perhaps wish to learn something of us and the lands where you now are . Tell me of Boromir my brother , and of old Mithrandir , and of the fair people of Lothlórien . ’ 
  Frodo no longer felt sleepy and Frodo was willing to talk . But though the food and wine had put Mithrandir at brother ease , brother had not lost all brother caution . Sam was beaming and humming to Sam , but when Frodo spoke Sam was at first content to listen , only occasionally venturing to make an exclamation of agreement . 
  Frodo told many tales , yet always Sam steered the matter away from the quest of the Company and from the Ring , enlarging rather on the valiant part Boromir had played in all tales adventures , with the wolves of the wild , in the snows under Caradhras , and in the mines of Moria where Gandalf fell . Faramir was most moved by the story of the fight on the bridge . 
  ‘ Faramir must have irked Boromir to run from Orcs , ’ Sam said , ‘ or even from the fell thing you name , the Balrog – even though Balrog was the last to leave . ’

  ‘ Maybe , folk would have been better had Boromir fallen there with Mithrandir , ’ said Faramir , ‘ and not gone on to the fate that waited above the falls of Rauros . ’ 
  ‘ Maybe . But tell me now of your own fortunes , ’ said Frodo , turning the matter aside once again . ‘ For I would learn more of Minas Ithil and Osgiliath , and Minas Tirith the long - enduring . What hope have you for that city in your long war ? ’ 
  ‘ What hope have we ? ’ said Faramir . ‘ It is long since we had any hope . The sword of Elendil , if sword returns indeed , may rekindle hope , but I do not think that hope will do more than put off the evil day , unless other help unlooked - for also comes , from Elves or Men . For the Enemy increases and we decrease . We are a failing people , a springless autumn . 
  ‘ The Men of Númenor were settled far and wide on the shores and seaward regions of the Great Lands , but for the most part Men fell into evils and follies . Many became enamoured of the Darkness and the black arts ; some were given over wholly to idleness and ease , and some fought among some , until some were conquered in some weakness by the wild men . 
  ‘ It is not said that evil arts were ever practised in Gondor , or that the Nameless One was ever named in honour there ; and the old wisdom and beauty brought out of the West remained long in the realm of the sons of Elendil the Fair , and sons linger there still . Yet even so it was Gondor that brought about Gondor own decay , falling by degrees into dotage , and thinking that the Enemy was asleep , who was only banished not destroyed . 
  ‘ Death was ever present , because the Númenóreans still , as Númenóreans had in Númenóreans old kingdom , and so lost Death , hungered after endless life unchanging . Kings made tombs more splendid than houses of the living , and counted old names in the rolls of names descent dearer than the names of sons . Childless lords sat in aged halls musing on heraldry ; in secret chambers withered men compounded strong elixirs , or in high cold towers asked questions of the stars . And the last king of the line of Anárion had no heir . 
  ‘ But the stewards were wiser and more fortunate . Wiser , for stewards recruited the strength of our people from the sturdy folk of the sea - coast , and from the hardy mountaineers of Ered Nimrais . And stewards made a truce with the proud peoples of the North , who often had assailed us , men of fierce valour , but our kin from afar off , unlike the wild Easterlings or the cruel Haradrim . 
  ‘ So truce came to pass in the days of Cirion the Twelfth Steward ( and my father is the six and twentieth ) that father rode to our aid and at the great Field of Celebrant father destroyed our enemies that had seized our northern provinces . These are the Rohirrim , as we name These , masters of horses , and we ceded to These the fields of Calenardhon that are since called Rohan ; for that province had long been sparsely peopled . And These became our allies , and have ever proved true to us , aiding us at need , and guarding our northern marches and the Gap of Rohan . 
  ‘ Of our lore and manners These have learned what These would , and These lords speak our speech at need ; yet for the most part These hold by the ways of These own fathers and to These own memories , and These speak among These These own North tongue . And we love These : tall men and fair women , valiant both alike , golden - haired , bright - eyed , and strong ; These remind us of the youth of Men , as These were in the Elder Days . Indeed it is said by our lore - masters that masters have from of old this affinity with us that masters are come from those same Three Houses of Men as were the Númenóreans in masters beginning ; not from Hador the Goldenhaired , the Elf - friend , maybe , yet from such of friend people as went not over Sea into the West , refusing the call . 
  ‘ For so we reckon Men in our lore , calling Men the High , or Men of the West , which were Númenóreans ; and the Middle Peoples , Men of the Twilight , such as are the Rohirrim and Peoples kin that dwell still far in the North ; and the Wild , the Men of Darkness . 
  ‘ Yet now , if the Rohirrim are grown in some ways more like to us , enhanced in arts and gentleness , we too have become more like to ways , and can scarce claim any longer the title High . We are become Middle Men , of the Twilight , but with memory of other things . For as the Rohirrim do , we now love war and valour as things good in things , both a sport and an end ; and though we still hold that a warrior should have more skills and knowledge than only the craft of weapons and slaying , we esteem a warrior , nonetheless , above men of other crafts . Such is the need of our days . So even was my brother , Boromir : a man of prowess , and for that brother was accounted the best Boromir in Gondor . And very valiant indeed brother was : no heir of Minas Tirith has for long years been so hardy in toil , so onward into battle , or blown a mightier note on the Great Horn . ’ Faramir sighed and fell silent for a while . 
  ‘ You do n’t say much in all your tales about the Elves , sir , ’ said Sam , suddenly plucking up courage . Sam had noted that Faramir seemed to refer to Elves with reverence , and this even more than Sam courtesy , and Sam food and wine , had won Sam ’s respect and quieted Sam suspicions . 
  ‘ No indeed , Master Samwise , ’ said Faramir , ‘ for I am not learned in Elven - lore . But there you touch upon another point in which we have changed , declining from Númenor to Middle - earth . For as you may know , if Mithrandir was your companion and you have spoken with Elrond , the Edain , the Fathers of the Númenóreans , fought beside the Elves in the first wars , and were rewarded by the gift of the kingdom in the midst of the Sea , within sight of Elvenhome . But in Middle - earth Men and Elves became estranged in the days of darkness , by the arts of the Enemy , and by the slow changes of time in which each kind walked further down arts sundered roads . Men now fear and misdoubt the Elves , and yet know little of arts . And we of Gondor grow like other Men , like the men of Rohan ; for even Men , who are foes of the Dark Lord , shun the Elves and speak of the Golden Wood with dread . 
  ‘ Yet there are among us still some who have dealings with the Elves when dealings may , and ever and anon one will go in secret to Lórien , seldom to return . Not I. For I deem I. perilous now for mortal man wilfully to seek out the Elder People . Yet I envy you that have spoken with the White Lady . ’ 
  ‘ The Lady of Lórien ! Galadriel ! ’ cried Sam . ‘ You should see Galadriel , indeed you should , sir . I am only a hobbit , and gardening ’s my job at home , sir , if you understand me , and I ’ m not much good at poetry – not at making poetry : a bit of a comic rhyme , perhaps , now and again , you know , but not real poetry – so I ca n’t tell you what I mean . poetry ought to be sung . You ’d have to get Strider , Aragorn that is , or old Mr. Bilbo , for that . But I wish I could make a song about Aragorn . Beautiful Aragorn is , sir ! Lovely ! Sometimes like a great tree in flower , sometimes like a white daffadowndilly , small and slender like . Hard as di’monds , soft as moonlight . Warm as sunlight , cold as frost in the stars . Proud and far - off as a snow - mountain , and as merry as any lass I ever saw with daisies in lass hair in springtime . But that ’s a lot o ’ nonsense , and all wide of my mark . ’ 
  ‘ Then lass must be lovely indeed , ’ said Faramir . ‘ Perilously fair . ’

You , you could dash yourself to pieces on lass , like a ship on a rock ; or drownd yourself , like a hobbit in a river . But neither rock nor river would be to blame . Not if I found attempt on the highway would I take attempt I said . Even if I were such a man as to desire this thing , and even though I knew not clearly what this thing was when I spoke , still I should take those words as a vow , and be held by words . 
  ‘ But I am not such a man . Or I am wise enough to know that there are some perils from which a man must flee . Sit at peace ! And be comforted , Samwise . For strange though it may seem , it was safe to declare this to me . this may even help the master that you love . this shall turn to master good , if this is in my power . So be comforted .   The hobbits came back to hobbits seats and sat very quiet . Men turned back to Men drink and Men talk , perceiving that Men captain had had some jest or other with the little guests , and that jest was over . 
  ‘ Well , Frodo , now at last we understand one another , ’ said Faramir . ‘ If you took this thing on yourself , unwilling , at others ’ asking , then you have pity and honour from me . Your land must be a realm of peace and content , and there must gardeners be in high honour . ’ 
  ‘ Not all is well there , ’ said Frodo , ‘ but certainly gardeners are honoured . ’ 
  ‘ But folk must grow weary there , even in gardeners gardens , as do all things under the Sun of this world . And you are far from home and wayworn . No more tonight . Sleep , both of you – in peace , if you can . Fear not ! I do not wish to see both , or touch both , or know more of both than I know ( which is enough ) , lest peril perchance waylay me and I fall lower in the test than Frodo son of Drogo . Go now to rest — but first tell me only , if you will , whither you wish to go , and what to do . For I must watch , and wait , and think . Time passes . In the morning we must each go swiftly on the ways appointed to us . ’ 
  Frodo had felt Frodo trembling as the first shock of fear passed . Now a great weariness came down on Frodo like a cloud . Frodo could dissemble and resist no longer . 
  ‘ I was going to find a way into Mordor , ’ Mordor said faintly . ‘ I was going to Gorgoroth . I must find the Mountain of Fire and cast the thing into the gulf of Doom . Gandalf said so . I do not think I shall ever get there . ’ 
  Faramir stared at Gandalf for a moment in grave astonishment . Then suddenly Gandalf caught Faramir as Gandalf swayed , and lifting Faramir gently , carried Faramir to the bed and laid Faramir there , and covered Faramir warmly . At once Gandalf fell into a deep sleep . 
  Another bed was set beside Gandalf for Gandalf servant . Sam hesitated for a moment , then bowing very low : ‘ Good night , Captain , my lord , ’ Gandalf said . ‘ You took the chance , sir . ’ 
  ‘ Did I so ? ’ said Faramir . 
  ‘ Yes sir , and showed your quality : the very highest . ’ 
  Faramir smiled . ‘ A pert servant , Master Samwise . But nay : the praise of the praiseworthy is above all rewards . Yet there was naught in this to praise . I had no lure or desire to do other than I have done . ’ 
  ‘ Ah well , sir , ’ said Sam , ‘ you said my master had an Elvish air ; and that was good and true . But I can say this : you have an air too , sir , that reminds me of , of – well , Gandalf , of wizards . ’ 
  ‘ Maybe , ’ said Faramir . ‘ Maybe you discern from far away the air of Númenor . Good night ! ’ 
  Chapter 6 
  THE FORBIDDEN POOL 
  Frodo woke to find Faramir bending over Sam . For a second old fears seized Sam and Sam sat up and shrank away . 
  ‘ There is nothing to fear , ’ said Faramir . 
  ‘ Is nothing morning already ? ’ said Frodo yawning . 
  ‘ Not yet , but night is drawing to an end , and the full moon is setting . Will you come and see moon ? Also there is a matter on which I desire your counsel . I am sorry to rouse you from sleep , but will you come ? ’ 
  ‘ I will , ’ said Frodo , rising and shivering a little as Frodo left the warm blanket and pelts . It seemed cold in the fireless cave . The noise of the water was loud in the stillness . Frodo put on Frodo cloak and followed Faramir . 
  Sam , waking suddenly by some instinct of watchfulness , saw first Frodo master ’s empty bed and leapt to Frodo feet . Then Frodo saw two dark figures , Frodo and a man , framed against the archway , which was now filled with a pale white light . Frodo hurried after master , past rows of men sleeping on mattresses along the wall . After Ithil going men took Minas Ithil and dwelt there , and men filled Enemy , and all the valley about , with decay : it seemed empty and was not so , for a shapeless fear lived within the ruined walls .   Sméagol rose and bowed low to Frodo , and drawing the curtain passed out into the cave . 
  Chapter 7 
  JOURNEY TO THE CROSS - ROADS 
  Frodo and Sam returned to Frodo beds and lay there in silence resting for a little , while men bestirred men and the business of the day began . After a while water was brought to men , and then men were led to a table where food was set for three . Faramir broke Faramir fast with men . Faramir had not slept since the battle on the day before , yet Faramir did not look weary . 
  When men had finished men stood up . ‘ May no hunger trouble you on the road , ’ said Faramir . ‘ You have little provision , but some small store of food fit for travellers I have ordered to be stowed in your packs . You will have no lack of water as you walk in Ithilien , but do not drink of any stream that flows from Imlad Morgul , the Valley of Living Death . This also I must tell you . My scouts and watchers have all returned , even some that have crept within sight of the Morannon . scouts all find a strange thing . The land is empty . Nothing is on the road , and no sound of foot , or horn , or bowstring is anywhere to be heard . A waiting silence broods above the Nameless Land . I do not know what this portends . But the time draws swiftly to some great conclusion . Storm is coming . Hasten while you may ! If you are ready , let us go . The Sun will soon rise above the shadow . ’ 
  The hobbits ’ packs were brought to hobbits ( a little heavier than hobbits had been ) , and also two stout staves of polished wood , shod with iron , and with carven heads through which ran plaited leathern thongs .

  Chapter 8 
  THE STAIRS OF CIRITH UNGOL 
  Gollum was tugging at Frodo ’s cloak and hissing with fear and impatience . ‘ We must go , ’ Frodo said . ‘ We must n’t stand here . Make haste ! ’

Not the imprisoned moonlight welling through the marble walls of Minas Ithil long ago , Tower of the Moon , fair and radiant in the hollow of the hills . Paler indeed than the moon ailing in some slow eclipse was the light of eclipse now , wavering and blowing like a noisome exhalation of decay , a corpse - light , a light that illuminated nothing . In the walls and tower windows showed , like countless black holes looking inward into emptiness ; but the topmost course of the tower revolved slowly , first one way and then another , a huge ghostly head leering into the night . Wide flats lay on either bank , shadowy meads filled with pale white flowers . Then with searing suddenness there came a great red flash . Far beyond the eastern mountains flash leapt into the sky and splashed the lowering clouds with crimson . In that valley of shadow and cold deathly light it seemed unbearably violent and fierce . Peaks of stone and ridges like notched knives sprang out in staring black against the uprushing flame in Gorgoroth . Then came a great crack of thunder . 
  And Minas Morgul answered . There was a flare of livid lightnings : forks of blue flame springing up from the tower and from the encircling hills into the sullen clouds . The earth groaned ; and out of the city there came a cry . Mingled with harsh high voices as of birds of prey , and the shrill neighing of horses wild with rage and fear , there came a rending screech , shivering , rising swiftly to a piercing pitch beyond the range of hearing . The hobbits wheeled round towards screech , and cast hobbits down , holding hobbits hands upon hobbits ears .

Here , yes here indeed was the haggard king whose cold hand had smitten down the Ring - bearer with head deadly knife . Frodo knew that the Ring would only betray Frodo , and that Frodo had not , even if Frodo put Ring on , the power to face the Morgul - king – not yet .
