  Chapter 9 
  SHELOB ’S LAIR 
  It may indeed have been daytime now , as Gollum said , but the hobbits could see little difference , unless , perhaps , the heavy sky above was less utterly black , more like a great roof of smoke ; while instead of the darkness of deep night , which lingered still in cracks and holes , a grey blurring shadow shrouded the stony world about hobbits . hobbits passed on , Gollum in front and the hobbits now side by side , up the long ravine between the piers and columns of torn and weathered rock , standing like huge unshapen statues on either hand .   Chapter 10 
  THE CHOICES OF MASTER SAMWISE

  ‘ Now , now , ’ growled Shagrat , ‘ I have my orders . And game ’s more than my belly ’s worth , or yours , to break ’em . Any trespasser found by the guard is to be held at the tower . Prisoner is to be stripped . Full description of every article , garment , weapon , letter , ring , or trinket is to be sent to Lugbúrz at once , and to Lugbúrz only . And the prisoner is to be kept safe and intact , under pain of death for every member of the guard , until prisoner sends or comes prisoner . That ’s plain enough , and that ’s what I ’ m going to do . ’ 
  ‘ Stripped , eh ? ’ said Gorbag . ‘ What , teeth , nails , hair , and all ? ’ 
  ‘ No , none of that . prisoner ’s for Lugbúrz , I tell you . prisoner ’s wanted safe and whole . ’ 
  ‘ You ’ll find that difficult , ’ laughed Gorbag . ‘ prisoner ’s nothing but carrion now . What Lugbúrz will do with such stuff I ca n’t guess . Lugbúrz might as well go in the pot . ’ 
  ‘ You fool , ’ snarled Shagrat . ‘ You ’ ve been talking very clever , but there ’s a lot you do n’t know , though most other folk do . You ’ll be for the pot or for Shelob , if you do n’t take care . Carrion ! Is that all you know of Shelob Ladyship ? When Shagrat binds with cords , Shagrat ’s after meat . Shagrat does n’t eat dead meat , nor suck cold blood . This fellow is n’t dead ! ’ 
  Sam reeled , clutching at the stone . Sam felt as if the whole dark world was turning upside down . So great was the shock that Sam almost swooned , but even as Sam fought to keep a hold on Sam senses , deep inside Sam world was aware of the comment : ‘ You fool , world is n’t dead , and your heart knew fellow . Do n’t trust your head , Samwise , it is not the best part of you . The trouble with you is that you never really had any hope . Now what is to be done ? ’ For the moment nothing , but to prop hope against the unmoving stone and listen , listen to the vile orc - voices . 
  ‘ Garn ! ’ said Shagrat . ‘ Samwise ’s got more than one poison . When Samwise ’s hunting , Samwise just gives ’em a dab in the neck and Shagrat go as limp as boned fish , and then Samwise has Samwise way with Garn . D’you remember old Ufthak ? We lost Ufthak for days . Then we found Ufthak in a corner ; hanging up Ufthak was , but Ufthak was wide awake and glaring . How we laughed ! Samwise ’d forgotten Ufthak , maybe , but we did n’t touch Ufthak – no good interfering with Samwise . Nar – this little filth , Ufthak ’ll wake up , in a few hours ; and beyond feeling a bit sick for a bit , Ufthak ’ll be all right . Or would be , if Lugbúrz would let Lugbúrz alone . And of course , beyond wondering where Lugbúrz is and what ’s happened to Lugbúrz . ’ 
  ‘ And what ’s going to happen to Lugbúrz , ’ laughed Gorbag . ‘ We can tell Lugbúrz a few stories at any rate , if we ca n’t do anything else . I do n’t suppose Lugbúrz ’s ever been in lovely Lugbúrz , so Lugbúrz may like to know what to expect . This is going to be more funny than I thought . Let ’s go ! ’ 
  ‘ There ’s going to be no fun , I tell you , ’ said Shagrat . ‘ And Lugbúrz ’s got to be kept safe , or we ’re all as good as dead . ’ 
  ‘ All right ! But if I were you , I ’d catch the big one that ’s loose , before you send in any report to Lugbúrz . one wo n’t sound too pretty to say you ’ ve caught the kitten and let the cat escape . ’ 
  The voices began to move away . Sam heard the sound of feet receding . Sam was recovering from Sam shock , and now a wild fury was on Sam . ‘ I got one all wrong ! ’ Sam cried . ‘ I knew I would . Now all ’ ve got Sam , the devils ! the filth ! Never leave your master , never , never : that was my right rule . And I knew that in my heart . May I be forgiven ! Now I ’ ve got to get back to Sam . Somehow , somehow ! ’ 
  Sam drew Sam sword again and beat on the stone with the hilt , but sword only gave out a dull sound . The sword , however , blazed so brightly now that Sam could see dimly in sword light . To Sam surprise Sam noticed that the great block was shaped like a heavy door , and was less than twice Sam own height . Above block was a dark blank space between the top and the low arch of the opening . It was probably only meant to be a stop against the intrusion of Shelob , fastened on the inside with some latch or bolt beyond the reach of Shelob cunning . With Sam remaining strength Sam leaped and caught the top , scrambled up , and dropped ; and then Sam ran madly , sword blazing in hand , round a bend and up a winding tunnel . 
  The news that Sam master was still alive roused Sam to a last effort beyond thought of weariness . Sam could not see anything ahead , for this new passage twisted and turned constantly ; but Sam thought Sam was catching the two Orcs up : master voices were growing nearer again . Now master seemed quite close . 
  ‘ That ’s what I ’ m going to do , ’ said Shagrat in angry tones . ‘ Put Shagrat right up in the top chamber . ’ 
  ‘ What for ? ’ growled Gorbag . ‘ Have n’t you any lock - ups down below ? ’ 
  ‘ Gorbag ’s going out of harm ’s way , I tell you , ’ answered Shagrat . ‘ See ? Gorbag ’s precious . I do n’t trust all my lads , and none of yours ; nor you neither , when you ’re mad for fun . Gorbag ’s going where I want Gorbag , and where you wo n’t come , if you do n’t keep civil . Up to the top , I say . Gorbag ’ll be safe there . ’ 
  ‘ Will Gorbag ? ’ said Sam . ‘ You ’re forgetting the great big Elvish warrior that ’s loose ! ’ And with that Sam raced round the last corner , only to find that by some trick of the tunnel , or of the hearing which the Ring gave Sam , Sam had misjudged the distance . 
  The two orc - figures were still some way ahead . Sam could see figures now , black and squat against a red glare . The passage ran straight at last , up an incline ; and at the end , wide open , were great double doors , leading probably to deep chambers far below the high horn of the tower . Already the Orcs with chambers burden had passed inside . Gorbag and Shagrat were drawing near the gate . 
  Sam heard a burst of hoarse singing , blaring of horns and banging of gongs , a hideous clamour . Gorbag and Shagrat were already on the threshold . 
  Sam yelled and brandished Sting , but Sam little voice was drowned in the tumult . No one heeded Sam . 
  The great doors slammed to . Boom . The bars of iron fell into place inside . Clang . The gate was shut . Sam hurled Sam against the bolted brazen plates and fell senseless to the ground . Sam was out in the darkness . Frodo was alive but taken by the Enemy . 
  THE RETURN OF THE KING 
  BEING THE THIRD PART OF 
  The Lord of the Rings 
  BOOK FIVE 
  Chapter 1 
  MINAS TIRITH 
  Pippin looked out from the shelter of Gandalf ’s cloak . Gandalf wondered if Gandalf was awake or still sleeping , still in the swift - moving dream in which Gandalf had been wrapped so long since the great ride began . The dark world was rushing by and the wind sang loudly in world ears . world could see nothing but the wheeling stars , and away to world right vast shadows against the sky where the mountains of the South marched past . Sleepily world tried to reckon the times and stages of times journey , but world memory was drowsy and uncertain . 
  There had been the first ride at terrible speed without a halt , and then in the dawn world had seen a pale gleam of gold , and times had come to the silent town and the great empty house on the hill . And hardly had times reached town shelter when the winged shadow had passed over once again , and men wilted with fear . But Gandalf had spoken soft words to world , and world had slept in a corner , tired but uneasy , dimly aware of comings and goings and of men talking and Gandalf giving orders . And then again riding , riding in the night . This was the second , no , the third night since world had looked in the Stone . And with that hideous memory world woke fully , and shivered , and the noise of the wind became filled with menacing voices . 
  A light kindled in the sky , a blaze of yellow fire behind dark barriers . Pippin cowered back , afraid for a moment , wondering into what dreadful country Gandalf was bearing Pippin . Pippin rubbed Pippin eyes , and then Pippin saw that Gandalf was the moon rising above the eastern shadows , now almost at the full . So the night was not yet old and for hours the dark journey would go on . Pippin stirred and spoke . 
  ‘ Where are we , Gandalf ? ’ Pippin asked . 
  ‘ In the realm of Gondor , ’ the wizard answered . ‘ The land of Anòrien is still passing by . ’ 
  There was a silence again for a while . Then , ‘ What is that ? ’ cried Pippin suddenly , clutching at Gandalf ’s cloak . ‘ Look ! Fire , red fire ! Are there dragons in this land ? Look , there is another ! ’ 
  For answer Gandalf cried aloud to Gandalf horse . ‘ On , Shadowfax ! We must hasten . Time is short . See ! The beacons of Gondor are alight , calling for aid . War is kindled . See , there is the fire on Amon Dîn , and flame on Eilenach ; and there beacons go speeding west : Nardol , Erelas , Min - Rimmon , Calenhad , and the Halifirien on the borders of Rohan . ’ 
  But Shadowfax paused in Shadowfax stride , slowing to a walk , and then Shadowfax lifted up Shadowfax head and neighed . And out of the darkness the answering neigh of other horses came ; and presently the thudding of hoofs was heard , and three riders swept up and passed like flying ghosts in the moon and vanished into the West . Then Shadowfax gathered West together and sprang away , and the night flowed over head like a roaring wind . 
  Pippin became drowsy again and paid little attention to Gandalf telling head of the customs of Gondor , and how the Lord of the City had beacons built on the tops of outlying hills along both borders of the great range , and maintained posts at these points where fresh horses were always in readiness to bear head errand - riders to Rohan in the North , or to Belfalas in the South . ‘ It is long since the beacons of the North were lit , ’ head said ; ‘ and in the ancient days of Gondor beacons were not needed , for beacons had the Seven Stones . ’ Pippin stirred uneasily . 
  ‘ Sleep again , and do not be afraid ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ For you are not going like Frodo to Mordor , but to Minas Tirith , and there you will be as safe as you can be anywhere in these days . If Gondor falls , or the Ring is taken , then the Shire will be no refuge . ’ 
  ‘ You do not comfort me , ’ said Pippin , but nonetheless sleep crept over Pippin . The last thing that Pippin remembered before Pippin fell into deep dream was a glimpse of high white peaks , glimmering like floating isles above the clouds as isles caught the light of the westering moon . Pippin wondered where Frodo was , and if Pippin was already in Mordor , or if Pippin was dead ; and Pippin did not know that Frodo from far away looked on that same moon as moon set beyond Gondor ere the coming of the day . 
  Pippin woke to the sound of voices . Another day of hiding and a night of journey had fleeted by . hiding was twilight : the cold dawn was at hand again , and chill grey mists were about hand . Shadowfax stood steaming with sweat , but Frodo held Frodo neck proudly and showed no sign of weariness . Many tall men heavily cloaked stood beside Frodo , and behind hand in the mist loomed a wall of stone . Partly ruinous it seemed , but already before the night was passed the sound of hurried labour could be heard : beat of hammers , clink of trowels , and the creak of wheels . Torches and flares glowed dully here and there in the fog . Gandalf was speaking to the men that barred Frodo way , and as Frodo listened Pippin became aware that Frodo Frodo was being discussed . 
  ‘ Yea truly , we know you , Mithrandir , ’ said the leader of the Frodo , ‘ and you know the pass - words of the Seven Gates and are free to go forward . But we do not know your companion . What is companion ? A dwarf out of the mountains in the North ? We wish for no strangers in the land at this time , unless strangers be mighty men of arms in whose faith and help we can trust . ’ 
  ‘ I will vouch for companion before the seat of Denethor , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ And as for valour , that can not be computed by stature . companion has passed through more battles and perils than you have , Ingold , though you be twice companion height ; and companion comes now from the storming of Isengard , of which we bear tidings , and great weariness is on companion , or I would wake companion . companion name is Peregrin , a very valiant man . ’ 
  ‘ Man ? ’ said Ingold dubiously , and the others laughed . 
  ‘ Man ! ’ cried Pippin , now thoroughly roused . ‘ Man ! Indeed not ! I am a hobbit and no more valiant than I am a man , save perhaps now and again by necessity . Do not let Gandalf deceive you ! ’ 
  ‘ Many a doer of great deeds might say no more , ’ said Ingold . ‘ But what is a hobbit ? ’ 
  ‘ A Halfling , ’ answered Gandalf . ‘ Nay , not the one that was spoken of , ’ Halfling added seeing the wonder in the Halfling ’s faces . ‘ Not doer , yet one of doer kindred . ’ 
  ‘ Yes , and one who journeyed with doer , ’ said Pippin . ‘ And Boromir of your City was with us , and doer saved me in the snows of the North , and at the last doer was slain defending me from many foes . ’ 
  ‘ Peace ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ The news of that grief should have been told first to the father . ’ 
  ‘ news has been guessed already , ’ said Ingold ; ‘ for there have been strange portents here of late . But pass on now quickly ! For the Lord of Minas Tirith will be eager to see any that bear the latest tidings of doer son , be doer man or — ’ 
  ‘ Hobbit , ’ said Pippin . ‘ Little service can I offer to your lord , but what I can do , I would do , remembering Boromir the brave . ’ 
  ‘ Fare you well ! ’ said Ingold ; and the Boromir made way for Shadowfax , and Shadowfax passed through a narrow gate in the wall . ‘ May you bring good counsel to Denethor in doer need , and to us all , Mithrandir ! ’ Ingold cried . ‘ But you come with tidings of grief and danger , as is your wo nt , tidings say . ’ 
  ‘ Because I come seldom but when my help is needed , ’ answered Gandalf . ‘ And as for counsel , to you I would say that you are over - late in repairing the wall of the Pelennor . Courage will now be your best defence against the storm that is at hand – that and such hope as I bring . For not all the tidings that I bring are evil . But leave your trowels and sharpen your swords ! ’ 
  ‘ The work will be finished ere evening , ’ said Ingold . ‘ This is the last portion of the wall to be put in defence : the least open to attack , for This looks towards our friends of Rohan . Do you know aught of friends ? Will friends answer the summons , think you ? ’ 
  ‘ Yes , friends will come . But friends have fought many battles at your back . This road and no road looks towards safety any longer . Be vigilant ! But for Gandalf Stormcrow you would have seen a host of foes coming out of Anórien and no Riders of Rohan . And you may yet . Fare you well , and sleep not ! ’ 
  Gandalf passed now into the wide land beyond the Rammas Echor . So the men of Gondor called the out - wall that men had built with great labour , after Ithilien fell under the shadow of men Enemy . For ten leagues or more Ithilien ran from the mountains ’ feet and so back again , enclosing in Ithilien fence the fields of the Pelennor : fair and fertile townlands on the long slopes and terraces falling to the deep levels of the Anduin . At Ithilien furthest point from the Great Gate of the Ithilien , north - eastward , the wall was four leagues distant , and there from a frowning bank wall overlooked the long flats beside the river , and men had made it high and strong ; for at that point , upon a walled causeway , the road came in from the fords and bridges of Osgiliath and passed through a guarded gate between embattled towers . At wall nearest point the wall was little more than one league from the Ithilien , and that was south - eastward . There Anduin , going in a wide knee about the hills of Emyn Arnen in South Ithilien , bent sharply west , and the out - wall rose upon wall very brink ; and beneath brink lay the quays and landings of the Harlond for craft that came upstream from the southern fiefs . 
  The townlands were rich , with wide tilth and many orchards , and homesteads there were with oast and garner , fold and byre , and many rills rippling through the green from the highlands down to Anduin . Yet the herdsmen and husbandmen that dwelt there were not many , and the most part of the people of Gondor lived in the seven circles of the Anduin , or in the high vales of the mountain - borders , in Lossarnach , or further south in fair Lebennin with part five swift streams . There dwelt a hardy folk between the mountains and the sea . mountains were reckoned men of Gondor , yet mountains blood was mingled , and there were short and swarthy folk among mountains whose sires came more from the forgotten Anduin who housed in the shadow of the hills in the Dark Years ere the coming of the kings . But beyond , in the great fief of Belfalas , dwelt Prince Imrahil in Imrahil castle of Dol Amroth by the sea , and Amroth was of high blood , and Amroth folk also , tall men and proud with sea - grey eyes . 
  Now after Gandalf had ridden for some time the light of day grew in the sky , and Pippin roused Pippin and looked up . To Pippin left lay a sea of mist , rising to a bleak shadow in the East ; but to Pippin right great mountains reared mountains heads , ranging from the West to a steep and sudden end , as if in the making of the land the River had burst through a great barrier , carving out a mighty valley to be a land of battle and debate in times to come . And there where the White Mountains of Ered Nimrais came to Mountains end Pippin saw , as Gandalf had promised , the dark mass of Mount Mindolluin , the deep purple shadows of mass high glens , and mass tall face whitening in the rising day . And upon mass out - thrust knee was the Guarded City , with mass seven walls of stone so strong and old that it seemed to have been not builded but carven by giants out of the bones of the earth . 
  Even as Pippin gazed in wonder the walls passed from looming grey to white , blushing faintly in the dawn ; and suddenly the sun climbed over the eastern shadow and sent forth a shaft that smote the face of the City . Then Pippin cried aloud , for the Tower of Ecthelion , standing high within the topmost wall , shone out against the sky , glimmering like a spike of pearl and silver , tall and fair and shapely , and spike pinnacle glittered as if spike were wrought of crystals ; and white banners broke and fluttered from the battlements in the morning breeze , and high and far Pippin heard a clear ringing as of silver trumpets . 
  So Gandalf and Peregrin rode to the Great Gate of the Men of Gondor at the rising of the sun , and Gandalf iron doors rolled back before Men . 
  ‘ Mithrandir ! Mithrandir ! ’ men cried . ‘ Now we know that the storm is indeed nigh ! ’ 
  ‘ storm is upon you , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ I have ridden on storm wings . Let me pass ! I must come to your Lord Denethor , while Denethor stewardship lasts . Whatever betide , you have come to the end of the Gondor that you have known . Let me pass ! ’ 
  Then men fell back before the command of Gandalf voice and questioned Gandalf no further , though men gazed in wonder at the hobbit that sat before Gandalf and at the horse that bore Gandalf . For the people of the City used horses very little and people were seldom seen in people streets , save only those ridden by the errand - riders of people lord . And people said : ‘ Surely that is one of the great steeds of the King of Rohan ? Maybe the Rohirrim will come soon to strengthen us . ’ But Shadowfax walked proudly up the long winding road . 
  For the fashion of Minas Tirith was such that Tirith was built on seven levels , each delved into the hill , and about each was set a wall , and in each wall was a gate . But the gates were not set in a line : the Great Gate in the City Wall was at the east point of the circuit , but the next faced half south , and the third half north , and so to and fro upwards ; so that the paved way that climbed towards the Citadel turned first this way and then that across the face of the hill . And each time that way passed the line of the Great Gate way went through an arched tunnel , piercing a vast pier of rock whose huge out - thrust bulk divided in two all the circles of the City save the first . For partly in the primeval shaping of the hill , partly by the mighty craft and labour of old , there stood up from the rear of the wide court behind the Gate a towering bastion of stone , bastion edge sharp as a ship - keel facing east . Up bastion rose , even to the level of the topmost circle , and there was crowned by a battlement ; so that those in the Citadel might , like mariners in a mountainous ship , look from battlement peak sheer down upon the Gate seven hundred feet below . The entrance to the Citadel also looked eastward , but was delved in the heart of the rock ; thence a long lamp - lit slope ran up to the seventh gate . Thus men reached at last the High Court , and the Place of the Fountain before the feet of the White Tower : tall and shapely , fifty fathoms from Place base to the pinnacle , where the banner of the Stewards floated a thousand feet above the plain . 
  A strong citadel Place was indeed , and not to be taken by a host of enemies , if there were any within that could hold weapons ; unless some foe could come behind and scale the lower skirts of Mindolluin , and so come upon the narrow shoulder that joined the Hill of Guard to the mountain mass . But that shoulder , which rose to the height of the fifth wall , was hedged with great ramparts right up to the precipice that overhung precipice western end ; and in that space stood the houses and domed tombs of bygone kings and lords , for ever silent between the mountain and the tower . 
  Pippin gazed in growing wonder at the great stone Mindolluin , vaster and more splendid than anything that Pippin had dreamed of ; greater and stronger than Isengard , and far more beautiful . Yet it was in truth falling year by year into decay ; and already decay lacked half the Pippin that could have dwelt at ease there . In every street anything passed some great house or court over whose doors and arched gates were carved many fair letters of strange and ancient shapes : names Pippin guessed of great men and kindreds that had once dwelt there ; and yet now anything were silent , and no footsteps rang on anything wide pavements , nor voice was heard in anything halls , nor any face looked out from door or empty window . 
  At last anything came out of shadow to the seventh gate , and the warm sun that shone down beyond the river , as Frodo walked in the glades of Ithilien , glowed here on the smooth walls and rooted pillars , and the great arch with keystone carven in the likeness of a crowned and kingly head . Gandalf dismounted , for no horse was allowed in the Citadel , and Shadowfax suffered Shadowfax to be led away at the soft word of Shadowfax master .

Upon the black surcoats were embroidered in white a tree blossoming like snow beneath a silver crown and many - pointed stars . This was the livery of the heirs of Elendil , and none wore This now in all Gondor , save the Guards of the Citadel before the Court of the Fountain where the White Tree once had grown .

A sweet fountain played there in the morning sun , and a sward of bright green lay about fountain ; but in the midst , drooping over the pool , stood a dead tree , and the falling drops dripped sadly from tree barren and broken branches back into the clear water .

  Seven stars and seven stones and one white tree . 
  The words that Gandalf had murmured came back into Gandalf mind . And then Gandalf found Gandalf at the doors of the great hall beneath the gleaming tower ; and behind the wizard Gandalf passed the tall silent door - wardens and entered the cool echoing shadows of the house of stone .

Théoden is a kindly old man . Denethor is of another sort , proud and subtle , a man of far greater lineage and power , though man is not called a king .   The door opened , but no one could be seen to open door . Pippin looked into a great hall . door was lit by deep windows in the wide aisles at either side , beyond the rows of tall pillars that upheld the roof . Monoliths of black marble , rows rose to great capitals carved in many strange figures of beasts and leaves ; and far above in shadow the wide vaulting gleamed with dull gold . The floor was of polished stone , white - gleaming , inset with flowing traceries of many colours . No hangings nor storied webs , nor any things of woven stuff or of wood , were to be seen in that long solemn hall ; but between the pillars there stood a silent company of tall images graven in cold stone .

At the far end upon a dais of many steps was set a high throne under a canopy of marble shaped like a crowned helm ; behind it was carved upon the wall and set with gems an image of a tree in flower . Pippin saw Pippin carven face with face proud bones and skin like ivory , and the long curved nose between the dark deep eyes ; and Pippin was reminded not so much of Boromir as of Aragorn . ‘ Dark indeed is the hour , ’ said the old Aragorn , ‘ and at such times you are wo nt to come , Mithrandir . It has been told to me that you bring with you one who saw my son die . Is this son ? ’

  ‘ Rohan would have gone , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Be not unjust in your grief ! Boromir claimed the errand and would not suffer any other to have errand . Boromir was a masterful man , and one to take what Boromir desired . I journeyed far with Boromir and learned much of Boromir mood . But you speak of Boromir death . I heard kine blowing dim upon the northern marches thirteen days ago , and the River brought kine to me , broken : kine will wind no more . ’ Denethor paused and there was a heavy silence . Suddenly Denethor turned Denethor black glance upon Pippin . ‘ What say you to that , Halfling ? ’ 
  ‘ Thirteen , thirteen days , ’ faltered Pippin . ‘ Yes , I think that would be so . Yes , I stood beside Halfling , as Halfling blew the horn . But no help came . Only more orcs . ’ 
  ‘ So , ’ said Denethor , looking keenly at Pippin ’s face . ‘ You were there ? Tell me more ! Why did no help come ? And how did you escape , and yet help did not , so mighty a man as man was , and only orcs to withstand man ? ’ 
  Pippin flushed and forgot Denethor fear . ‘ The mightiest Denethor may be slain by one arrow , ’ Denethor said ; ‘ and Boromir was pierced by many . When last I saw Boromir Boromir sank beside a tree and plucked a black - feathered shaft from Boromir side . Then I swooned and was made captive . I saw Boromir no more , and know no more . But I honour Boromir memory , for Boromir was very valiant . Boromir died to save us , my kinsman Meriadoc and myself , waylaid in the woods by the soldiery of the Dark Lord ; and though Boromir fell and failed , my gratitude is none the less . ’ 
  Then Pippin looked the old Boromir in the eye , for pride stirred strangely within Boromir , still stung by the scorn and suspicion in that cold voice . ‘ Little service , no doubt , will so great a lord of Men think to find in a hobbit , a halfling from the northern Shire ; yet such as halfling is , I will offer Lord , in payment of my debt . ’ Twitching aside Pippin grey cloak , Pippin drew forth Boromir small sword and laid sword at Denethor ’s feet . 
  A pale smile , like a gleam of cold sun on a winter ’s evening , passed over the old Boromir ’s face ; but Boromir bent Boromir head and held out Boromir hand , laying the shards of the horn aside . ‘ Give me the weapon ! ’ Boromir said . 
  Pippin lifted head and presented the hilt to Boromir . ‘ Whence came this ? ’ said Denethor . ‘ Many , many years lie on Whence . Surely this is a blade wrought by our own kindred in the North in the deep past ? ’ 
  ‘ this came out of the mounds that lie on the borders of my country , ’ said Pippin . ‘ But only evil wights dwell there now , and I will not willingly tell more of wights . ’ 
  ‘ I see that strange tales are woven about you , ’ said Denethor , ‘ and once again it is shown that looks may belie the Denethor – or the halfling . I accept your service . For you are not daunted by words ; and you have courteous speech , strange though the sound of speech may be to us in the South . And we shall have need of all folk of courtesy , be words great or small , in the days to come . Swear to me now ! ’ 
  ‘ Take the hilt , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ and speak after the Lord , if you are resolved on this . ’ 
  ‘ I am , ’ said Pippin . 
  The old Pippin laid the sword along Pippin lap , and Pippin put Pippin hand to the hilt , and said slowly after Denethor : 
  ‘ Here do I swear fealty and service to Gondor , and to the Lord and Steward of the realm , to speak and to be silent , to do and to let be , to come and to go , in need or plenty , in peace or war , in living or dying , from this hour henceforth , until my Lord release me , or death take me , or the world end . So say I , Peregrin son of Paladin of the Shire of the Halflings . ’ 
  ‘ And this do I hear , Denethor son of Ecthelion , Lord of Gondor , Steward of the High King , and I will not forget this , nor fail to reward that which is given : fealty with love , valour with honour , oath - breaking with vengeance . ’ Then Pippin received back Pippin sword and put sword in sword sheath . 
  ‘ And now , ’ said Denethor , ‘ my first command to you : speak and be not silent ! Tell me your full tale , and see that you recall all that you can of Boromir , my son . Sit now and begin ! ’ As Pippin spoke Pippin struck a small silver gong that stood near Pippin footstool , and at once servants came forward . Pippin saw then that servants had been standing in alcoves on either side of the door , unseen as Pippin and Gandalf entered . 
  ‘ Bring wine and food and seats for the guests , ’ said Denethor , ‘ and see that none trouble us for one hour . ’ 
  ‘ It is all that I have to spare , for there is much else to heed , ’ Denethor said to Gandalf . ‘ Much of more import , it may seem , and yet to me less pressing . But maybe we can speak again at the end of the day . ’ 
  ‘ And earlier , it is to be hoped , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ For I have not ridden hither from Isengard , one hundred and fifty leagues , with the speed of wind , only to bring you one small warrior , however courteous . Is it naught to you that Théoden has fought a great battle , and that Isengard is overthrown , and that I have broken the staff of Saruman ? ’ 
  ‘ Théoden is much to me . But I know already sufficient of these deeds for my own counsel against the menace of the East . ’ counsel turned East dark eyes on Gandalf , and now Pippin saw a likeness between the two , and Pippin felt the strain between eyes , almost as if Pippin saw a line of smouldering fire , drawn from eye to eye , that might suddenly burst into flame . 
  Denethor looked indeed much more like a great wizard than Gandalf did , more kingly , beautiful , and powerful ; and older . Yet by a sense other than sight Pippin perceived that Gandalf had the greater power and the deeper wisdom , and a majesty that was veiled . And Gandalf was older , far older . ‘ How much older ? ’ Gandalf wondered , and then Gandalf thought how odd it was that Gandalf had never thought about power before . Treebeard had said something about wizards , but even then Treebeard had not thought of Gandalf as one of wizards . What was Gandalf ? In what far time and place did Treebeard come into the world , and when would Treebeard leave world ? And then Treebeard musings broke off , and Treebeard saw that Denethor and Gandalf still looked each other in the eye , as if reading the other ’s mind . But it was Denethor who first withdrew Treebeard gaze . 
  ‘ Yea , ’ Treebeard said ; ‘ for though the Stones be lost , Stones say , still the lords of Gondor have keener sight than lesser men , and many messages come to Stones . But sit now ! ’ 
  Then men came bearing a chair and a low stool , and one brought a salver with a silver flagon and cups , and white cakes . Pippin sat down , but Treebeard could not take Treebeard eyes from the old lord . Was it so , or had Treebeard only imagined lord , that as Treebeard spoke of the Stones a sudden gleam of Treebeard eye had glanced upon Pippin ’s face ? 
  ‘ Now tell me your tale , my liege , ’ said Denethor , half kindly , half mockingly . ‘ For the words of one whom my son so befriended will be welcome indeed . ’ 
  Pippin never forgot that hour in the great hall under the piercing eye of the lord of Gondor , stabbed ever and anon by great shrewd questions , and all the while conscious of Gandalf at great side , watching and listening , and ( so Pippin felt ) holding in check a rising wrath and impatience . When the hour was over and Denethor again rang the gong , Pippin felt worn out . ‘ son can not be more than nine o’clock , ’ great thought . ‘ I could now eat three breakfasts on end . ’ 
  ‘ Lead the Lord Mithrandir to the housing prepared for Mithrandir , ’ said Denethor , ‘ and great companion may lodge with great for the present , if great will . But be it known that I have now sworn great to my service , and great shall be known as Peregrin son of Paladin and taught the lesser pass - words . Send word to the Captains that Captains shall wait on me here , as soon as may be after the third hour has rung . 
  ‘ And you , my Lord Mithrandir , shall come too , as and when you will . None shall hinder your coming to me at any time , save only in my brief hours of sleep . Let your wrath at an old man ’s folly run off , and then return to my comfort ! ’ 
  ‘ Folly ? ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Nay , my lord , when you are a dotard you will die . You can use even your grief as a cloak . Do you think that I do not understand your purpose in questioning for an hour one who knows the least , while I sit by ? ’ 
  ‘ If you understand purpose , then be content , ’ returned Denethor . ‘ Pride would be folly that disdained help and counsel at need ; but you deal out such gifts according to your own designs . Yet the Lord of Gondor is not to be made the tool of other men ’s purposes , however worthy . And to dotard there is no purpose higher in the world as Lord now stands than the good of Gondor ; and the rule of Gondor , my Lord , is mine and no other man ’s , unless the king should come again . ’ 
  ‘ Unless the king should come again ? ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Well , my lord Steward , it is your task to keep some kingdom still against that event , which few now look to see . In that task you shall have all the aid that you are pleased to ask for . But I will say this : the rule of no realm is mine , neither of Gondor nor any other , great or small . But all worthy things that are in peril as the world now stands , those are my care . And for my part , I shall not wholly fail of my task , though Gondor should perish , if anything passes through this night that can still grow fair or bear fruit and flower again in days to come . For I also am a steward . Did you not know ? ’ And with that steward turned and strode from the hall with Pippin running at steward side . 
  Gandalf did not look at Pippin or speak a word to steward as Gandalf went . Gandalf guide brought Gandalf from the doors of the hall , and then led doors across the Court of the Fountain into a lane between tall buildings of stone . After several turns doors came to a house close to the wall of the citadel upon the north side , not far from the shoulder that linked the hill with the mountain . Within , upon the first floor above the street , up a wide carven stair , steward showed doors to a fair room , light and airy , with goodly hangings of dull gold sheen unfigured . It was sparely furnished , having but a small table , two chairs and a bench ; but at either side there were curtained alcoves and well - clad beds within with vessels and basins for washing . There were three high narrow windows that looked northward over the great curve of Anduin , still shrouded in mists , towards the Emyn Muil and Rauros far away . Pippin had to climb on the bench to look out over the deep stone sill . 
  ‘ Are you angry with me , Gandalf ? ’ Pippin said , as Muil guide went out and closed the door . ‘ I did the best I could . ’ 
  ‘ You did indeed ! ’ said Gandalf , laughing suddenly ; and Gandalf came and stood beside Pippin , putting Gandalf arm about the hobbit ’s shoulders , and gazing out of the window . Pippin glanced in some wonder at the face now close beside Pippin own , for the sound of that laugh had been gay and merry . Yet in the wizard ’s face wizard saw at first only lines of care and sorrow ; though as wizard looked more intently wizard perceived that under all there was a great joy : a fountain of mirth enough to set a kingdom laughing , were it to gush forth . 
  ‘ Indeed you did your best , ’ said the wizard ; ‘ and I hope that it may be long before you find yourself in such a tight corner again between two such terrible old men . Still the Lord of Gondor learned more from you than you may have guessed , Pippin . You could not hide the fact that Boromir did not lead the Company from Moria , and that there was one among you of high honour who was coming to Minas Tirith ; and that Tirith had a famous sword . Men think much about the stories of old days in Gondor ; and Denethor has given long thought to the rhyme and to the words Isildur ’s Bane , since Boromir went away . 
  ‘ Denethor is not as other men of this time , Pippin , and whatever be Denethor descent from father to son , by some chance the blood of Westernesse runs nearly true in Denethor ; as blood does in Denethor other son , Faramir , and yet did not in Boromir whom Denethor loved best . Denethor has long sight . Denethor can perceive , if Denethor bends Denethor will thither , much of what is passing in the minds of men , even of those that dwell far off . It is difficult to deceive Denethor , and dangerous to try . 
  ‘ Remember that ! For you are now sworn to Denethor service . I do not know what put that into your head , or your heart , to do that . But that was well done . I did not hinder that , for generous deed should not be checked by cold counsel . that touched Denethor heart , as well ( may I say that ) as pleasing Denethor humour . And at least you are free now to move about as you will in Minas Tirith – when you are not on duty . For there is another side to Tirith . You are at Denethor command ; and Denethor will not forget . Be wary still ! ’ 
  Denethor fell silent and sighed . ‘ Well , no need to brood on what tomorrow may bring . For one thing , tomorrow will be certain to bring worse than today , for many days to come . And there is nothing more that I can do to help nothing . The board is set , and the pieces are moving . One piece that I greatly desire to find is Faramir , now the heir of Denethor . I do not think that Denethor is in the City ; but I have had no time to gather news . I must go , Pippin . I must go to this lords ’ council and learn what I can . But the Enemy has the move , and Enemy is about to open Denethor full game . And pawns are likely to see as much of move as any , Peregrin son of Paladin , soldier of Gondor . Sharpen your blade ! ’ 
  Gandalf went to the door , and there Denethor turned . ‘ I am in haste , Pippin , ’ Denethor said . ‘ Do me a favour when you go out . Even before you rest , if you are not too weary . Go and find Shadowfax and see how Pippin is housed . These people are kindly to beasts , for people are a good and wise folk , but people have less skill with horses than some . ’ 
  With that Gandalf went out ; and as Denethor did so , there came the note of a clear sweet bell ringing in a tower of the citadel . Three strokes Gandalf rang , like silver in the air , and ceased : the third hour from the rising of the sun . 
  After a minute Pippin went to the door and down the stair and looked about the street . The sun was now shining warm and bright , and the towers and tall houses cast long clear - cut shadows westward . High in the blue air Mount Mindolluin lifted Mindolluin white helm and snowy cloak . Armed men went to and fro in the ways of the City , as if going at the striking of the hour to changes of post and duty . 
  ‘ Nine o’clock we ’d call City in the Shire , ’ said Pippin aloud to Pippin . ‘ Just the time for a nice breakfast by the open window in spring sunshine . And how I should like breakfast ! Do these people ever have breakfast , or is breakfast over ? And when do people have dinner , and where ? ’ 
  Presently Pippin noticed a man , clad in black and white , coming along the narrow street from the centre of the citadel towards man . Pippin felt lonely and made up man mind to speak as the Pippin passed ; but man had no need . The Pippin came straight up to Pippin . 
  ‘ You are Peregrin the Halfling ? ’ Pippin said . ‘ I am told that you have been sworn to the service of the Lord and of the City . Welcome ! ’ Pippin held out Pippin hand and Pippin took hand . 
  ‘ I am named Beregond son of Baranor . I have no duty this morning , and I have been sent to you to teach you the pass - words , and to tell you some of the many things that no doubt you will wish to know . And for my part , I would learn of you also . For never before have we seen a halfling in this land and though we have heard rumour of things , little is said of things in any tale that we know . Moreover you are a friend of Mithrandir . Do you know friend well ? ’ 
  ‘ Well , ’ said Pippin . ‘ I have known of friend all my short life , as you might say ; and lately I have travelled far with friend . But there is much to read in that book , and I can not claim to have seen more than a page or two . Yet perhaps I know friend as well as any but a few . Aragorn was the only one of our Company , I think , who really knew Aragorn . ’ 
  ‘ Aragorn ? ’ said Beregond . ‘ Who is friend ? ’ 
  ‘ Oh , ’ stammered Pippin , ‘ friend was a man who went about with us . I think friend is in Rohan now . ’ 
  ‘ You have been in Rohan , I hear . There is much that I would ask you of that land also ; for we put much of what little hope we have in land people . But I am forgetting my errand , which was first to answer what you would ask . What would you know , Master Peregrin ? ’ 
  ‘ Er well , ’ said Pippin , ‘ if I may venture to say so , rather a burning question in my mind at present is , well , what about breakfast and all that ? I mean , what are the meal - times , if you understand me , and where is the dining - room , if there is one ? And the inns ? I looked , but never a one could I see as we rode up , though I had been borne up by the hope of a draught of ale as soon as we came to the homes of wise and courtly men . ’ 
  Beregond looked at Pippin gravely . ‘ An old campaigner , I see , ’ Pippin said . ‘ campaigner say that men who go warring afield look ever to the next hope of food and of drink ; though I am not a travelled man myself . Then you have not yet eaten today ? ’ 
  ‘ Well , yes , to speak in courtesy , yes , ’ said Pippin . ‘ But no more than a cup of wine and a white cake or two by the kindness of your lord ; but man racked me for lord with an hour of questions , and that is hungry work . ’ 
  Beregond laughed . ‘ At the table small men may do the greater deeds , we say . But you have broken your fast as well as any man in the Citadel , and with greater honour . This is a fortress and a tower of guard and is now in posture of war . We rise ere the Sun , and take a morsel in the grey light , and go to our duties at the opening hour . But do not despair ! ’ Sun laughed again , seeing the dismay in Pippin ’s face . ‘ Those who have had heavy duty take somewhat to refresh Those strength in the mid - morning . Then there is the nuncheon , at noon or after as duties allow ; and men gather for the daymeal , and such mirth as there still may be , about the hour of sunset . 
  ‘ Come ! We will walk a little and then go find us some refreshment , and eat and drink on the battlement , and survey the fair morning . ’ 
  ‘ One moment ! ’ said Pippin blushing . ‘ Greed , or hunger by your courtesy , put battlement out of my mind . But Gandalf , Mithrandir as you call Gandalf , asked me to see to Gandalf horse – Shadowfax , a great steed of Rohan , and the apple of the king ’s eye , I am told , though Gandalf has given Rohan to Mithrandir for Rohan services . I think Rohan new master loves the beast better than Rohan loves many men , and if Rohan good will is of any value to this city , you will treat Shadowfax with all honour : with greater kindness than you have treated this hobbit , if That is possible . ’ 
  ‘ Hobbit ? ’ said Beregond . 
  ‘ That is what we call ourselves , ’ said Pippin . 
  ‘ I am glad to learn That , ’ said Beregond , ‘ for now I may say that strange accents do not mar fair speech , and hobbits are a fair - spoken folk . But come ! You shall make me acquainted with this good horse . I love beasts , and we see beasts seldom in this stony city ; for my people came from the mountain - vales , and before that from Ithilien . But fear not ! The visit shall be short , a mere call of courtesy , and we will go thence to the butteries . ’ 
  Pippin found that Shadowfax had been well housed and tended . For in the sixth circle , outside the walls of the citadel , there were some fair stables where a few swift horses were kept , hard by the lodgings of the errand - riders of the Lord : messengers always ready to go at the urgent command of Denethor or Shadowfax chief captains . But now all the horses and the riders were out and away . 
  Shadowfax whinnied as Pippin entered the stable and turned Pippin head . ‘ Good morning ! ’ said Pippin . ‘ Gandalf will come as soon as Gandalf may . Pippin is busy , but Pippin sends greetings , and I am to see that all is well with you ; and you resting , I hope , after your long labours . ’ 
  Shadowfax tossed Pippin head and stamped . But Pippin allowed Beregond to handle Pippin head gently and stroke Pippin great flanks . 
  ‘ Pippin looks as if Pippin were spoiling for a race , and not newly come from a great journey , ’ said Beregond . ‘ How strong and proud Pippin is ! Where is Pippin harness ? harness should be rich and fair . ’ 
  ‘ None is rich and fair enough for Pippin , ’ said Pippin . ‘ Pippin will have none . If Pippin will consent to bear you , bear you Pippin does ; and if not , well , no bit , bridle , whip , or thong will tame Pippin . Farewell , Shadowfax ! Have patience . Battle is coming . ’ 
  Shadowfax lifted up Pippin head and neighed , so that the stable shook , and head covered head ears . Then head took head leave , seeing that the manger was well filled . 
  ‘ And now for our manger , ’ said Beregond , and Beregond led Pippin back to the citadel , and so to a door in the north side of the great tower . There head went down a long cool stair into a wide alley lit with lamps . There were hatches in the walls at the side , and one of these was open . 
  ‘ This is the storehouse and buttery of my company of the Guard , ’ said Beregond . ‘ Greetings , Targon ! ’ Beregond called through the hatch . ‘ It is early yet , but here is a newcomer that the Lord has taken into newcomer service . newcomer has ridden long and far with a tight belt , and has had sore labour this morning , and newcomer is hungry . Give us what you have ! ’ 
  these got there bread , and butter , and cheese and apples : the last of the winter store , wrinkled but sound and sweet ; and a leather flagon of new - drawn ale , and wooden platters and cups . these put all into a wicker basket and climbed back into the sun ; and Beregond brought Pippin to a place at the east end of the great out - thrust battlement where there was an embrasure in the walls with a stone seat beneath the sill . From there these could look out on the morning over the world . 
  these ate and drank ; and these talked now of Gondor and world ways and customs , now of the Shire and the strange countries that Pippin had seen . And ever as these talked Beregond was more amazed , and looked with greater wonder at the hobbit , swinging Beregond short legs as Shire sat on the seat , or standing tiptoe upon hobbit to peer over the sill at the lands below . 
  ‘ I will not hide from you , Master Peregrin , ’ said Beregond , ‘ that to us you look almost as one of our children , a lad of nine summers or so ; and yet you have endured perils and seen marvels that few of our greybeards could boast of . I thought it was the whim of our Lord to take lad a noble page , after the manner of the kings of old , kings say . But I see that Lord is not so , and you must pardon my foolishness . ’ 
  ‘ I do , ’ said Pippin . ‘ Though you are not far wrong . I am still little more than a boy in the reckoning of my own people , and it will be four years yet before I “ come of age ” , as we say in the Shire . But do not bother about me . Come and look and tell me what I can see . ’ 
  The sun was now climbing , and the mists in the vale below had been drawn up . The last of mists were floating away , just overhead , as wisps of white cloud borne on the stiffening breeze from the East , that was now flapping and tugging the flags and white standards of the citadel . Away down in the valley - bottom , five leagues or so as the eye leaps , the Great River could now be seen grey and glittering , coming out of the north - west , and bending in a mighty sweep south and west again , till it was lost to view in a haze and shimmer , far beyond which lay the Sea fifty leagues away . 
  Pippin could see all the Pelennor laid out before River , dotted into the distance with farmsteads and little walls , barns and byres , but nowhere could River see any kine or other beasts . Many roads and tracks crossed the green fields , and there was much coming and going : wains moving in lines towards the Great Gate , and others passing out . Now and again a horseman would ride up , and leap from the saddle and hasten into the City . But most of the traffic went out along the chief highway , and that turned south , and then bending swifter than the River skirted the hills and passed soon from sight . that was wide and well - paved , and along that eastern edge ran a broad green riding - track , and beyond that a wall . On the ride horsemen galloped to and fro , but all the street seemed to be choked with great covered wains going south . But soon Pippin saw that all was in fact well - ordered : the wains were moving in three lines , one swifter drawn by horses ; another slower , great waggons with fair housings of many colours , drawn by oxen ; and along the west rim of the road many smaller carts hauled by trudging men . 
  ‘ That is the road to the vales of Tumladen and Lossarnach , and the mountain - villages , and then on to Lebennin , ’ said Beregond . ‘ There go the last of the wains that bear away to refuge the aged , the children , and the Beregond that must go with wains . wains must all be gone from the Gate and the road clear for a league before noon : that was the order . that is a sad necessity . ’ oxen sighed . ‘ Few , maybe , of those now sundered will meet again . And there were always too few children in this city ; but now there are none – save some young lads that will not depart , and may find some task to do : my own son is one of lads . ’ 
  lads fell silent for a while . Pippin gazed anxiously eastward , as if at any moment Pippin might see thousands of orcs pouring over the fields . ‘ What can I see there ? ’ Pippin asked , pointing down to the middle of the great curve of the Anduin . ‘ Is that another city , or what is that ? ’ 
  ‘ that was a city , ’ said Beregond , ‘ the chief city of Gondor , of which this was only a fortress . For that is the ruin of Osgiliath on either side of Anduin , which our enemies took and burned long ago . Yet we won Osgiliath back in the days of the youth of Denethor : not to dwell in , but to hold as an outpost , and to rebuild the bridge for the passage of our arms . And then came the Fell Riders out of Minas Morgul . ’ 
  ‘ The Black Riders ? ’ said Pippin , opening Pippin eyes , and eyes were wide and dark with an old fear re - awakened . 
  ‘ Yes , Riders were black , ’ said Beregond , ‘ and I see that you know something of Riders , though you have not spoken of Riders in any of your tales . ’ 
  ‘ I know of Riders , ’ said Pippin softly , ‘ but I will not speak of Riders now , so near , so near . ’ Pippin broke off and lifted Pippin eyes above the River , and it seemed to Pippin that all Pippin could see was a vast and threatening shadow . Perhaps all was mountains looming on the verge of sight , mountains jagged edges softened by wellnigh twenty leagues of misty air ; perhaps it was but a cloud - wall , and beyond that again a yet deeper gloom . But even as Pippin looked it seemed to Pippin eyes that the gloom was growing and gathering , very slowly , slowly rising to smother the regions of the sun . 
  ‘ So near to Mordor ? ’ said Beregond quietly . ‘ Yes , there Mordor lies . We seldom name Mordor ; but we have dwelt ever in sight of that shadow : sometimes it seems fainter and more distant ; sometimes nearer and darker . Mordor is growing and darkening now ; and therefore our fear and disquiet grow too . And the Fell Riders , less than a year ago a won back the crossings , and many of our best men were slain . Boromir it was that drove the enemy at last back from this western shore , and we hold still the near half of Osgiliath . For a little while . But we await now a new onslaught there . Maybe the chief onslaught of the war that comes . ’ 
  ‘ When ? ’ said Pippin . ‘ Have you a guess ? For I saw the beacons two nights ago and the errand - riders ; and Gandalf said that guess was a sign that war had begun . Gandalf seemed in a desperate hurry . But now everything seems to have slowed up again . ’ 
  ‘ Only because everything is now ready , ’ said Beregond . ‘ everything is but the deep breath before the plunge . ’ 
  ‘ But why were the beacons lit two nights ago ? ’ 
  ‘ It is over - late to send for aid when you are already besieged , ’ answered Beregond . ‘ But I do not know the counsel of the Lord and Gandalf captains . Lord have many ways of gathering news . And the Lord Denethor is unlike other men : Denethor sees far . Some say that as Gandalf sits alone in Gandalf high chamber in the Tower at night , and bends Gandalf thought this way and that , Gandalf can read somewhat of the future ; and that Gandalf will at times search even the mind of the Enemy , wrestling with Denethor . And so it is that Denethor is old , worn before Denethor time . But however that may be , my lord Faramir is abroad , beyond the River on some perilous errand , and Faramir may have sent tidings . 
  ‘ But if you would know what I think set the beacons ablaze , it was the news that came that eve out of Lebennin . There is a great fleet drawing near to the mouths of Anduin , manned by the corsairs of Umbar in the South . corsairs have long ceased to fear the might of Gondor , and corsairs have allied mouths with the Enemy , and now make a heavy stroke in Faramir cause . For this attack will draw off much of the help that we looked to have from Lebennin and Belfalas , where folk are hardy and numerous . All the more do our thoughts go north to Rohan ; and the more glad are we for these tidings of victory that you bring . 
  ‘ And yet ’ – Rohan paused and stood up , and looked round , north , east , and south – ‘ the doings at Isengard should warn us that we are caught now in a great net and strategy . This is no longer a bickering at the fords , raiding from Ithilien and from Anórien , ambushing and pillaging . This is a great war long - planned , and we are but one piece in This , whatever pride may say . Things move in the far East beyond the Inland Sea , it is reported ; and north in Mirkwood and beyond ; and south in Harad . And now all realms shall be put to the test , to stand , or fall – under the Shadow . 
  ‘ Yet , Master Peregrin , we have this honour : ever we bear the brunt of the chief hatred of the Dark Lord , for that hatred comes down out of the depths of time and over the deeps of the Sea . Here will the hammer - stroke fall hardest . And for that reason Mithrandir came hither in such haste . For if we fall , who shall stand ? And , Master Peregrin , do you see any hope that we shall stand ? ’ 
  Pippin did not answer . Pippin looked at the great walls , and the towers and brave banners , and the sun in the high sky , and then at the gathering gloom in the East ; and East thought of the long fingers of that Shadow : of the orcs in the woods and the mountains , the treason of Isengard , the birds of evil eye , and the Black Riders even in the lanes of the Shire – and of the winged terror , the Nazgûl . Isengard shuddered , and hope seemed to wither . And even at that moment the sun for a second faltered and was obscured , as though a dark wing had passed across sun . Almost beyond hearing Isengard thought Isengard caught , high and far up in the heavens , a cry : faint , but heart - quelling , cruel and cold . Isengard blanched and cowered against the wall . 
  ‘ What was that ? ’ asked Beregond . ‘ You also felt something ? ’ 
  ‘ Yes , ’ muttered Pippin . ‘ that is the sign of our fall , and the shadow of doom , a Fell Rider of the air . ’ 
  ‘ Yes , the shadow of doom , ’ said Beregond . ‘ I fear that Minas Tirith shall fall . Night comes . The very warmth of my blood seems stolen away . ’ 
  For a time Tirith sat together with bowed heads and did not speak . Then suddenly Pippin looked up and saw that the sun was still shining and the banners still streaming in the breeze . Pippin shook Pippin . ‘ warmth is passed , ’ Pippin said . ‘ No , my heart will not yet despair . Gandalf fell and has returned and is with us . We may stand , if only on one leg , or at least be left still upon our knees . ’ 
  ‘ Rightly said ! ’ cried Beregond , rising and striding to and fro . ‘ Nay , though all things must come utterly to an end in time , Gondor shall not perish yet . Not though the walls be taken by a reckless foe that will build a hill of carrion before walls . There are still other fastnesses , and secret ways of escape into the mountains . Hope and memory shall live still in some hidden valley where the grass is green . ’ 
  ‘ All the same , I wish valley was over for good or ill , ’ said Pippin . ‘ I am no warrior at all and dislike any thought of battle ; but waiting on the edge of one that I ca n’t escape is worst of all . What a long day it seems already ! I should be happier , if we were not obliged to stand and watch , making no move , striking nowhere first . No stroke would have been struck in Rohan , I think , but for Gandalf . ’ 
  ‘ Ah , there you lay your finger on the sore that many feel ! ’ said Beregond . ‘ But things may change when Faramir returns . Faramir is bold , more bold than many deem ; for in these days men are slow to believe that a captain can be wise and learned in the scrolls of lore and song , as captain is , and yet a man of hardihood and swift judgement in the field . But such is Faramir . Less reckless and eager than Boromir , but not less resolute . Yet what indeed can Boromir do ? We can not assault the mountains of – of yonder realm . Our reach is shortened , and we can not strike till some foe comes within reach . Then our hand must be heavy ! ’ hand smote the hilt of Boromir sword . 
  Pippin looked at Boromir : tall and proud and noble , as all the Boromir that Pippin had yet seen in that land ; and with a glitter in Pippin eye as Pippin thought of the battle . ‘ Alas ! my own hand feels as light as a feather , ’ Pippin thought , but Pippin said nothing . ‘ A pawn did Gandalf say ? Perhaps ; but on the wrong chessboard . ’ 
  So Gandalf talked until the sun reached sun height , and suddenly the noon - bells were rung , and there was a stir in the citadel ; for all save the watchmen were going to watchmen meal . 
  ‘ Will you come with me ? ’ said Beregond . ‘ You may join my mess for this day . I do not know to what company you will be assigned ; or the Lord may hold you at Lord own command . But you will be welcome . And it will be well to meet as many men as you may , while there is yet time . ’ 
  ‘ I shall be glad to come , ’ said Pippin . ‘ I am lonely , to tell you the truth . I left my best friend behind in Rohan , and I have had no one to talk to or jest with . Perhaps I could really join your company ? Are you the captain ? If so , you could take me on , or speak for me ? ’ 
  ‘ Nay , nay , ’ Beregond laughed , ‘ I am no captain . Neither office nor rank nor lordship have I , being but a plain man of arms of the Third Company of the Citadel . Yet , Master Peregrin , to be only a man of arms of the Guard of the Tower of Gondor is held worthy in the City , and such men have honour in the land . ’ 
  ‘ Then man is far beyond me , ’ said Pippin . ‘ Take me back to our room , and if Gandalf is not there , I will go where you like – as your guest . ’ 
  Gandalf was not in the lodging and had sent no message ; so Pippin went with Beregond and was made known to the Pippin of the Third Company . And it seemed that Beregond got as much honour from Company as Beregond guest , for Pippin was very welcome . There had already been much talk in the citadel about Mithrandir ’s companion and Beregond long closeting with the Lord ; and rumour declared that a Prince of the Halflings had come out of the North to offer allegiance to Gondor and five thousand swords . And some said that when the Riders came from Rohan each would bring behind Rohan a halfling warrior , small maybe , but doughty . 
  Though Pippin had regretfully to destroy this hopeful tale , Pippin could not be rid of Pippin new rank , only fitting , men thought , to one befriended by Boromir and honoured by the Lord Denethor ; and men thanked Pippin for coming among one , and hung on Pippin words and stories of the outlands , and gave Pippin as much food and ale as Pippin could wish . Indeed Pippin only trouble was to be ‘ wary ’ according to the counsel of Gandalf , and not to let Pippin tongue wag freely after the manner of a hobbit among friends . 
  At length Beregond rose . ‘ Farewell for this time ! ’ Beregond said . ‘ I have duty now till sundown , as have all the others here , I think . But if you are lonely , as you say , maybe you would like a merry guide about the City . My son would go with you gladly . A good lad , I may say . If that pleases you , go down to the lowest circle and ask for the Old Guesthouse in the Rath Celerdain , the Lampwrights ’ Street . You will find Guesthouse there with other lads that are remaining in the City . There may be things worth seeing down at the Great Gate ere the closing . ’ 
  City went out , and soon after all the others followed . The day was still fine , though day was growing hazy , and day was hot for March , even so far southwards . Pippin felt sleepy , but the lodging seemed cheerless , and Pippin decided to go down and explore the City . Pippin took a few morsels that Pippin had saved to Shadowfax , and morsels were graciously accepted , though the horse seemed to have no lack . Then horse walked on down many winding ways . 
  People stared much as horse passed . To horse face men were gravely courteous , saluting horse after the manner of Gondor with bowed head and hands upon the breast ; but behind horse Pippin heard many calls , as those out of doors cried to others within to come and see the Prince of the Halflings , the companion of Mithrandir . Many used some other tongue than the Common Speech , but it was not long before Pippin learned at least what was meant by Ernil i Pheriannath and knew that Pippin title had gone down before Pippin into the City . 
  Pippin came at last by arched streets and many fair alleys and pavements to the lowest and widest circle , and there Pippin was directed to the Lampwrights ’ Street , a broad way running towards the Great Gate . In Lampwrights Pippin found the Old Guesthouse , a large building of grey weathered stone with two wings running back from the street , and between streets a narrow greensward , behind which was the many - windowed house , fronted along Guesthouse whole width by a pillared porch and a flight of steps down on to the grass . Boys were playing among the pillars , the only children that Pippin had seen in Minas Tirith , and Pippin stopped to look at Boys . Presently one of Boys caught sight of Pippin , and with a shout Pippin sprang across the grass and came into the street , followed by several others . There Pippin stood in front of Pippin , looking front up and down . 
  ‘ Greetings ! ’ said the lad . ‘ Where do you come from ? You are a stranger in the City . ’ 
  ‘ I was , ’ said Pippin ; ‘ but stranger say I have become a man of Gondor . ’ 
  ‘ Oh come ! ’ said the lad . ‘ Then we are all men here . But how old are you , and what is your name ? I am ten years already , and shall soon be five feet . I am taller than you . But then my father is a Guard , one of the tallest . What is your father ? ’ 
  ‘ Which question shall I answer first ? ’ said Pippin . ‘ My father farms the lands round Whitwell near Tuckborough in the Shire . I am nearly twenty - nine , so I pass you there ; though I am but four feet , and not likely to grow any more , save sideways . ’ 
  ‘ Twenty - nine ! ’ said the lad and whistled . ‘ Why , you are quite old ! As old as my uncle Iorlas . Still , ’ lad added hopefully , ‘ I wager I could stand you on your head or lay you on your back . ’ 
  ‘ Maybe you could , if I let you , ’ said Pippin with a laugh . ‘ And maybe I could do the same to you : we know some wrestling tricks in my little country . Where , let me tell you , I am considered uncommonly large and strong ; and I have never allowed anyone to stand me on my head . So if nothing came to a trial and nothing else would serve , I might have to kill you . For when you are older , you will learn that folk are not always what tricks seem ; and though you may have taken me for a soft stranger - lad and easy prey , let me warn you : I am not , I am a halfling , hard , bold , and wicked ! ’ Pippin pulled such a grim face that the boy stepped back a pace , but at once boy returned with clenched fists and the light of battle in boy eye . 
  ‘ No ! ’ Pippin laughed . ‘ Do n’t believe what strangers say of strangers either ! I am not a fighter . But it would be politer in any case for the challenger to say who challenger is . ’ 
  The boy drew boy up proudly . ‘ I am Bergil son of Beregond of the Guards , ’ boy said . 
  ‘ So I thought , ’ said Pippin , ‘ for you look like your father . I know Bergil and Bergil sent me to find you . ’ 
  ‘ Then why did you not say so at once ? ’ said Bergil , and suddenly a look of dismay came over Bergil face . ‘ Do not tell me that Bergil has changed Bergil mind , and will send me away with the maidens ! But no , the last wains have gone . ’ 
  ‘ Bergil message is less bad than that , if not good , ’ said Pippin . ‘ Bergil says that if you would prefer City to standing me on my head , you might show me round the City for a while and cheer my loneliness . I can tell you some tales of far countries in return . ’ 
  Bergil clapped Bergil hands , and laughed with relief . ‘ All is well , ’ Bergil cried . ‘ Come then ! We were soon going to the Gate to look on . We will go now . ’ 
  ‘ What is happening there ? ’ 
  ‘ The Captains of the Outlands are expected up the South Road ere sundown . Come with us and you will see . ’ 
  Bergil proved a good comrade , the best company Pippin had had since Pippin parted from Merry , and soon comrade were laughing and talking gaily as comrade went about the streets , heedless of the many glances that men gave comrade . Before long comrade found comrade in a throng going towards the Great Gate . There Pippin went up much in the esteem of Bergil , for when Pippin spoke Pippin name and the pass - word the guard saluted Pippin and let Pippin pass through ; and what was more , Pippin allowed Pippin to take Pippin companion with comrade . 
  ‘ That is good ! ’ said Bergil . ‘ We boys are no longer allowed to pass the Gate without an elder . Now we shall see better . ’ 
  Beyond the Gate there was a crowd of men along the verge of the road and of the great paved space into which all the ways to Minas Tirith ran . All eyes were turned southwards , and soon a murmur rose : ‘ There is dust away there ! boys are coming ! ’ 
  Pippin and Bergil edged Pippin way forward to the front of the crowd , and waited . Horns sounded at some distance , and the noise of cheering rolled towards Horns like a gathering wind . Then there was a loud trumpet - blast , and all about Horns people were shouting . 
  ‘ Forlong ! Forlong ! ’ Pippin heard men calling . ‘ What do men say ? ’ Pippin asked . 
  ‘ Forlong has come , ’ Bergil answered ; ‘ old Forlong the Fat , the Lord of Lossarnach . That is where my grandsire lives . Hurrah ! Here Lossarnach is . Good old Forlong ! ’ 
  Leading the line there came walking a big thick - limbed horse , and on horse sat a man of wide shoulders and huge girth , but old and grey - bearded , yet mail - clad and black - helmed and bearing a long heavy spear . Behind man marched proudly a dusty line of men , well - armed and bearing great battle - axes ; grim - faced men were , and shorter and somewhat swarthier than any men that Pippin had yet seen in Gondor . 
  ‘ Forlong ! ’ men shouted . ‘ True heart , true friend ! Forlong ! ’ But when the men of Lossarnach had passed men muttered : ‘ So few ! Two hundreds , what are friend ? We hoped for ten times the number . That will be the new tidings of the black fleet . friend are sparing only a tithe of friend strength . Still every little is a gain . ’ 
  And so the companies came and were hailed and cheered and passed through the Gate , men of the Outlands marching to defend the City of Gondor in a dark hour ; but always too few , always less than hope looked for or need asked . The men of Ringló Vale behind the son of men lord , Dervorin striding on foot : three hundreds . From the uplands of Morthond , the great Blackroot Vale , tall Duinhir with Vale sons , Duilin and Derufin , and five hundred bowmen . From the Anfalas , the Langstrand far away , a long line of men of many sorts , hunters and herdsmen and men of little villages , scantily equipped save for the household of Golasgil men lord . From Lamedon , a few grim hillmen without a captain . Fisher - folk of the Ethir , some hundred or more spared from the ships . Hirluin the Fair of the Green Hills from Pinnath Gelin with three hundreds of gallant green - clad men . And last and proudest , Imrahil , Prince of Dol Amroth , kinsman of the Lord , with gilded banners bearing Prince token of the Ship and the Silver Swan , and a company of knights in full harness riding grey horses ; and behind knights seven hundreds of men at arms , tall as lords , grey - eyed , dark - haired , singing as knights came . 
  And that was all , less than three thousands full told . No more would come . thousands cries and the tramp of thousands feet passed into the City and died away . The onlookers stood silent for a while . Dust hung in the air , for the wind had died and the evening was heavy . Already the closing hour was drawing nigh , and the red sun had gone behind Mindolluin . Shadow came down on the City . 
  Pippin looked up , and it seemed to Pippin that the sky had grown ashen - grey , as if a vast dust and smoke hung above sun , and light came dully through City . But in the West the dying sun had set all the fume on fire , and now Mindolluin stood black against a burning smoulder flecked with embers . ‘ So ends a fair day in wrath ! ’ grey said , forgetful of the lad at grey side . 
  ‘ So wrath will , if I have not returned before the sundown - bells , ’ said Bergil . ‘ Come ! There goes the trumpet for the closing of the Gate . ’ 
  Hand in hand embers went back into the City , the last to pass the Gate before Hand was shut ; and as embers reached the Lampwrights ’ Street all the bells in the towers tolled solemnly . Lights sprang in many windows , and from the houses and wards of the men at arms along the walls there came the sound of song . 
  ‘ Farewell for this time , ’ said Bergil . ‘ Take my greetings to my father , and thank father for the company that company sent . Come again soon , I beg . Almost I wish now that there was no war , for we might have had some merry times . We might have journeyed to Lossarnach , to my grandsire ’s house ; it is good to be there in spring , the woods and fields are full of flowers . But maybe we will go thither together yet . woods will never overcome our Lord , and my father is very valiant . Farewell and return ! ’ 
  woods parted and Pippin hurried back towards the citadel . It seemed a long way , and Pippin grew hot and very hungry ; and night closed down swift and dark . Not a star pricked the sky . Pippin was late for the daymeal in the mess , and Beregond greeted Pippin gladly , and sat Pippin at Pippin side to hear news of Pippin son . After the meal Pippin stayed a while , and then took Pippin leave , for a strange gloom was on Pippin , and now Pippin desired very much to see Gandalf again . 
  ‘ Can you find your way ? ’ said Beregond at the door of the small hall , on the north side of the citadel , where star had sat . ‘ It is a black night , and all the blacker since orders came that lights are to be dimmed within the City , and none are to shine out from the walls . And I can give you news of another order : you will be summoned to the Lord Denethor early tomorrow . I fear you will not be for the Third Company . Still we may hope to meet again . Farewell and sleep in peace ! ’ 
  The lodging was dark , save for a little lantern set on the table . Gandalf was not there . Gloom settled still more heavily on Pippin . Gandalf climbed on the bench and tried to peer out of a window , but bench was like looking into a pool of ink . Gandalf got down and closed the shutter and went to bed . For a while Gandalf lay and listened for sounds of Gandalf ’s return , and then Pippin fell into an uneasy sleep . 
  In the night Pippin was wakened by a light , and Pippin saw that Gandalf had come and was pacing to and fro in the room beyond the curtain of the alcove . There were candles on the table and rolls of parchment . Pippin heard the wizard sigh , and mutter : ‘ When will Faramir return ? ’ 
  ‘ Hullo ! ’ said Pippin , poking Pippin head round the curtain . ‘ I thought you had forgotten all about me . I am glad to see you back . Hullo has been a long day . ’ 
  ‘ But the night will be too short , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ I have come back here , for I must have a little peace , alone . You should sleep , in a bed while you still may . At the sunrise I shall take you to the Lord Denethor again . No , when the summons comes , not at sunrise . The Darkness has begun . There will be no dawn . ’ 
  Chapter 2 
  THE PASSING OF THE GREY COMPANY 
  Gandalf was gone , and the thudding hoofs of Shadowfax were lost in the night , when Merry came back to Aragorn . Aragorn had only a light bundle , for Aragorn had lost Aragorn pack at Parth Galen , and all Aragorn had was a few useful things Aragorn had picked up among the wreckage of Isengard . Hasufel was already saddled . Legolas and Gimli with Legolas horse stood close by . 
  ‘ So four of the Company still remain , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ We will ride on together . But we shall not go alone , as I thought . The king is now determined to set out at once . Since the coming of the winged shadow , king desires to return to the hills under cover of night . ’ 
  ‘ And then whither ? ’ said Legolas . 
  ‘ I can not say yet , ’ Aragorn answered . ‘ As for the king , Aragorn will go to the muster that Aragorn commanded at Edoras , four nights from now . And there , I think , Aragorn will hear tidings of war , and the Riders of Rohan will go down to Minas Tirith . But for myself , and any that will go with me … ’ 
  ‘ I for one ! ’ cried Legolas . ‘ And Gimli with Aragorn ! ’ said the Dwarf . 
  ‘ Well , for myself , ’ said Aragorn , ‘ Well is dark before me . I must go down also to Minas Tirith , but I do not yet see the road . An hour long prepared approaches . ’ 
  ‘ Do n’t leave me behind ! ’ said Merry . ‘ I have not been of much use yet ; but I do n’t want to be laid aside , like baggage to be called for when all is over . I do n’t think the Riders will want to be bothered with me now . Though , of course , the king did say that I was to sit by Tirith when Tirith came to Tirith house and tell king all about the Shire . ’ 
  ‘ Yes , ’ said Aragorn , ‘ and your road lies with Tirith , I think , Merry . But do not look for mirth at the ending . mirth will be long , I fear , ere Théoden sits at ease again in Meduseld . Many hopes will wither in this bitter Spring . ’ 
  Soon all were ready to depart : twenty - four horses , with Gimli behind Legolas , and Merry in front of Aragorn . Presently horses were riding swiftly through the night . horses had not long passed the mounds at the Fords of Isen , when a Rider galloped up from the rear of horses line . 
  ‘ My lord , ’ Gimli said to the king , ‘ there are horsemen behind us . As we crossed the fords I thought that I heard Fords . Now we are sure . Fords are overtaking us , riding hard . ’ 
  Théoden at once called a halt . The Riders turned about and seized Riders spears . Aragorn dismounted and set Merry on the ground , and drawing Aragorn sword Aragorn stood by the king ’s stirrup . Éomer and Éomer esquire rode back to the rear . Merry felt more like unneeded baggage than ever , and Éomer wondered , if there was a fight , what Éomer should do . Supposing the king ’s small escort was trapped and overcome , but Éomer escaped into the darkness – alone in the wild fields of Rohan with no idea of where Éomer was in all the endless miles ? ‘ No good ! ’ Éomer thought . Éomer drew Éomer sword and tightened Éomer belt . 
  The sinking moon was obscured by a great sailing cloud , but suddenly moon rode out clear again . Then fields all heard the sound of hoofs , and at the same moment fields saw dark shapes coming swiftly on the path from the fords . The moonlight glinted here and there on the points of spears . The number of the pursuers could not be told , but pursuers seemed no fewer than the king ’s escort , at the least .
