  When pursuers were some fifty paces off , Éomer cried in a loud voice : ‘ Halt ! Halt ! Who rides in Rohan ? ’ 
  The pursuers brought pursuers steeds to a sudden stand . A silence followed ; and then in the moonlight , a horseman could be seen dismounting and walking slowly forward . horseman hand showed white as horseman held hand up , palm outward , in token of peace ; but the king ’s men gripped men weapons . At ten paces the man stopped . man was tall , a dark standing shadow . Then man clear voice rang out . 
  ‘ Rohan ? Rohan did you say ? That is a glad word . We seek that land in haste from long afar . ’ 
  ‘ You have found land , ’ said Éomer . ‘ When you crossed the fords yonder you entered land . But land is the realm of Théoden the King . None ride here save by King leave . Who are you ? And what is your haste ? ’ 
  ‘ Halbarad Dúnadan , Ranger of the North I am , ’ cried the Dúnadan . ‘ We seek one Aragorn son of Arathorn , and we heard that King was in Rohan . ’ 
  ‘ And you have found King also ! ’ cried Aragorn . Giving man reins to Merry , man ran forward and embraced the newcomer . ‘ Halbarad ! ’ man said . ‘ Of all joys this is the least expected ! ’ 
  Merry breathed a sigh of relief . man had thought that this was some last trick of Saruman ’s , to waylay the king while Saruman had only a few men about Saruman ; but it seemed that there would be no need to die in Théoden ’s defence , not yet at any rate . Saruman sheathed Saruman sword . 
  ‘ All is well , ’ said Aragorn , turning back . ‘ Here are some of my own kin from the far land where I dwelt . But why some come , and how many some be , Halbarad shall tell us . ’ 
  ‘ I have thirty with me , ’ said Halbarad . ‘ That is all of our kindred that could be gathered in haste ; but the brethren Elladan and Elrohir have ridden with us , desiring to go to the war . We rode as swiftly as we might when your summons came . ’ 
  ‘ But I did not summon you , ’ said Aragorn , ‘ save only in wish . My thoughts have often turned to you , and seldom more than tonight ; yet I have sent no word . But come ! All such matters must wait . You find us riding in haste and danger . Ride with us now , if the king will give king leave . ’ 
  Théoden was indeed glad of the news . ‘ leave is well ! ’ Théoden said . ‘ If these kinsmen be in any way like to yourself , my lord Aragorn , thirty such knights will be a strength that can not be counted by heads . ’ 
  Then the Riders set out again , and Aragorn for a while rode with the Dúnedain ; and when Riders had spoken of tidings in the North and in the South , Elrohir said to Aragorn : 
  ‘ I bring word to you from my father : The days are short . If thou art in haste , remember the Paths of the Dead . ’ 
  ‘ Always my days have seemed to me too short to achieve my desire , ’ answered Aragorn . ‘ But great indeed will be my haste ere I take that road . ’ 
  ‘ That will soon be seen , ’ said Elrohir . ‘ But let us speak no more of these things upon the open road ! ’ 
  And Aragorn said to Halbarad : ‘ What is that that you bear , kinsman ? ’ For Aragorn saw that instead of a spear Aragorn bore a tall staff , as staff were a standard , but staff was close - furled in a black cloth bound about with many thongs . 
  ‘ It is a gift that I bring you from the Lady of Rivendell , ’ answered Halbarad . ‘ Lady wrought Rivendell in secret , and long was the making . But Lady also sends word to you : The days now are short . Either our hope cometh , or all hope ’s end . Therefore I send thee what I have made for thee . Fare well , Elfstone ! ’ 
  And Aragorn said : ‘ Now I know what you bear . Bear thee still for me a while ! ’ And Aragorn turned and looked away to the North under the great stars , and then Aragorn fell silent and spoke no more while the night ’s journey lasted . 
  The night was old and the East grey when stars rode up at last from Deeping - coomb and came back to the Hornburg . There stars were to lie and rest for a brief while and take counsel . 
  Merry slept until Aragorn was roused by Legolas and Gimli . ‘ The Sun is high , ’ said Legolas . ‘ All others are up and doing . Come , Master Sluggard , and look at this place while you may ! ’ 
  ‘ There was a battle here three nights ago , ’ said Gimli , ‘ and here Legolas and I played a game that I won only by a single orc . Come and see how Legolas was ! And there are caves , Merry , caves of wonder ! Shall we visit caves , Legolas , do you think ? ’ 
  ‘ Nay ! There is no time , ’ said the Elf . ‘ Do not spoil the wonder with haste ! I have given you my word to return hither with you , if a day of peace and freedom comes again . But day is now near to noon , and at that hour we eat , and then set out again , I hear . ’ 
  Merry got up and yawned . Merry few hours ’ sleep had not been nearly enough ; Elf was tired and rather dismal . Elf missed Pippin , and felt that Pippin was only a burden , while everybody was making plans for speed in a business that Pippin did not fully understand . ‘ Where is Aragorn ? ’ Pippin asked . 
  ‘ In a high chamber of the Burg , ’ said Legolas . ‘ Aragorn has neither rested nor slept , I think . Aragorn went thither some hours ago , saying that Aragorn must take thought , and only Aragorn kinsman , Halbarad , went with Aragorn ; but some dark doubt or care sits on Aragorn . ’ 
  ‘ kinsman are a strange company , these newcomers , ’ said Gimli . ‘ Stout men and lordly kinsman are , and the Riders of Rohan look almost as boys beside kinsman ; for kinsman are grim men of face , worn like weathered rocks for the most part , even as Aragorn Aragorn ; and kinsman are silent . ’ 
  ‘ But even as Aragorn kinsman are courteous , if kinsman break kinsman silence , ’ said Legolas . ‘ And have you marked the brethren Elladan and Elrohir ? Less sombre is brethren gear than the others ’ , and brethren are fair and gallant as Elven - lords ; and that is not to be wondered at in the sons of Elrond of Rivendell . ’ 
  ‘ Why have brethren come ? Have you heard ? ’ asked Merry . Merry had now dressed , and Merry flung Merry grey cloak about Merry shoulders ; and the three passed out together towards the ruined gate of the Burg . 
  ‘ brethren answered a summons , as you heard , ’ said Gimli . ‘ Word came to Rivendell , brethren say : Aragorn has need of Aragorn kindred . Let the Dúnedain ride to Aragorn in Rohan ! But whence this message came brethren are now in doubt . Gandalf sent message , I would guess . ’ 
  ‘ Nay , Galadriel , ’ said Legolas . ‘ Did Galadriel not speak through Gandalf of the ride of the Grey Company from the North ? ’ 
  ‘ Yes , you have Company , ’ said Gimli . ‘ The Lady of the Wood ! Lady read many hearts and desires . Now why did not we wish for some of our own kinsfolk , Legolas ? ’ 
  Legolas stood before the gate and turned Gimli bright eyes away north and east , and Gimli fair face was troubled . ‘ I do not think that any would come , ’ Gimli answered . ‘ any have no need to ride to war ; war already marches on any own lands . ’ 
  For a while the three companions walked together , speaking of this and that turn of the battle , and companions went down from the broken gate , and passed the mounds of the fallen on the greensward beside the road , until companions stood on Helm ’s Dike and looked into the Coomb . The Death Down already stood there , black and tall and stony , and the great trampling and scoring of the grass by the Huorns could be plainly seen . The Dunlendings and many men of the garrison of the Burg were at work on the Dike or in the fields and about the battered walls behind ; yet all seemed strangely quiet : a weary valley resting after a great storm . Soon Dunlendings turned back and went to the midday meal in the hall of the Burg . 
  The king was already there , and as soon as Dunlendings entered Gimli called for Merry and had a seat set for king at Gimli side . ‘ It is not as I would have this , ’ said Théoden ; ‘ for this is little like my fair house in Edoras . And your friend is gone , who should also be here . But this may be long ere we sit , you and I , at the high table in Meduseld ; there will be no time for feasting when I return thither . But come now ! Eat and drink , and let us speak together while we may . And then you shall ride with me . ’ 
  ‘ May I ? ’ said Merry , surprised and delighted . ‘ That would be splendid ! ’ Merry had never felt more grateful for any kindness in words . ‘ I am afraid I am only in everybody ’s way , ’ Merry stammered ; ‘ but I should like to do anything I could , you know . ’ 
  ‘ I doubt anything not , ’ said the king . ‘ I have had a good hill - pony made ready for you . pony will bear you as swift as any horse by the roads that we shall take . For I will ride from the Burg by mountain paths , not by the plain , and so come to Edoras by way of Dunharrow where the Lady Éowyn awaits me . You shall be my esquire , if you will . Is there gear of war in this place , Éomer , that my sword - thain could use ? ’ 
  ‘ There are no great weapon - hoards here , lord , ’ answered Éomer . ‘ Maybe a light helm might be found to fit Éomer ; but we have no mail or sword for one of Éomer stature . ’ 
  ‘ I have a sword , ’ said Merry , climbing from Merry seat , and drawing from seat black sheath Merry small bright blade . Filled suddenly with love for this old Merry , Merry knelt on one knee , and took Merry hand and kissed hand . ‘ May I lay the sword of Meriadoc of the Shire on your lap , Théoden King ? ’ Merry cried . ‘ Receive my service , if you will ! ’ 
  ‘ Gladly will I take service , ’ said the king ; and laying Merry long old hands upon the brown hair of the hobbit , Merry blessed king . ‘ Rise now , Meriadoc , esquire of Rohan of the household of Meduseld ! ’ Rohan said . ‘ Take your sword and bear sword unto good fortune ! ’ 
  ‘ As a father you shall be to me , ’ said Merry . 
  ‘ For a little while , ’ said Théoden . 
  king talked then together as king ate , until presently Éomer spoke . ‘ It is near the hour that we set for our going , lord , ’ Éomer said . ‘ Shall I bid men sound the horns ? But where is Aragorn ? Aragorn place is empty and Aragorn has not eaten . ’ 
  ‘ We will make ready to ride , ’ said Théoden ; ‘ but let word be sent to the Lord Aragorn that the hour is nigh . ’ 
  The king with Éomer guard and Merry at Éomer side passed down from the gate of the Burg to where the Riders were assembling on the green . Many were already mounted . gate would be a great company ; for the king was leaving only a small garrison in the Burg , and all who could be spared were riding to the weapontake at Edoras . A thousand spears had indeed already ridden away at night ; but still there would be some five hundred more to go with the king , for the most part men from the fields and dales of Westfold . 
  A little apart the Rangers sat , silent , in an ordered company , armed with spear and bow and sword . Rangers were clad in cloaks of dark grey , and Rangers hoods were cast now over helm and head . Rangers horses were strong and of proud bearing , but rough - haired ; and one stood there without a rider , Aragorn ’s own horse that Rangers had brought from the North ; Roheryn was Aragorn name . There was no gleam of stone or gold , nor any fair thing in all Rangers gear and harness ; nor did Rangers riders bear any badge or token , save only that each cloak was pinned upon the left shoulder by a brooch of silver shaped like a rayed star . 
  The king mounted Aragorn horse , Snowmane , and Merry sat beside Aragorn on Aragorn pony : Stybba was Aragorn name . Presently Éomer came out from the gate , and with Aragorn was Aragorn , and Halbarad bearing the great staff close - furled in black , and two tall men , neither young nor old . So much alike were king , the sons of Elrond , that few could tell king apart : dark - haired , grey - eyed , and king faces elven - fair , clad alike in bright mail beneath cloaks of silver - grey . Behind king walked Legolas and Gimli . But Merry had eyes only for Aragorn , so startling was the change that Aragorn saw in Aragorn , as if in one night many years had fallen on Aragorn head . Grim was Aragorn face , grey - hued and weary . 
  ‘ I am troubled in mind , lord , ’ Aragorn said , standing by the king ’s horse . ‘ I have heard strange words , and I see new perils far off . I have laboured long in thought , and now I fear that I must change my purpose . Tell me , Théoden , you ride now to Dunharrow , how long will it be ere you come there ? ’ 
  ‘ thought is now a full hour past noon , ’ said Éomer . ‘ Before the night of the third day from now we should come to the Hold . The Moon will then be two nights past Dunharrow full , and the muster that the king commanded will be held the day after . More speed we can not make , if the strength of Rohan is to be gathered . ’ 
  Aragorn was silent for a moment . ‘ Three days , ’ Éomer murmured , ‘ and the muster of Rohan will only be begun . But I see that muster can not now be hastened . ’ Éomer looked up , and it seemed that Éomer had made some decision ; Éomer face was less troubled . ‘ Then , by your leave , lord , I must take new counsel for myself and my kindred . We must ride our own road , and no longer in secret . For me the time of stealth has passed . I will ride east by the swiftest way , and I will take the Paths of the Dead . ’ 
  ‘ The Paths of the Dead ! ’ said Théoden , and trembled . ‘ Why do you speak of Paths ? ’ Éomer turned and gazed at Aragorn , and it seemed to Merry that the faces of the Riders that sat within hearing turned pale at the words . ‘ If there be in truth such paths , ’ said Théoden , ‘ paths gate is in Dunharrow ; but no living man may pass gate . ’ 
  ‘ Alas ! Aragorn my friend ! ’ said Éomer . ‘ I had hoped that we should ride to war together ; but if you seek the Paths of the Dead , then our parting is come , and it is little likely that we shall ever meet again under the Sun . ’ 
  ‘ That road I will take , nonetheless , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ But I say to you , Éomer , that in battle we may yet meet again , though all the hosts of Mordor should stand between . ’ 
  ‘ You will do as you will , my lord Aragorn , ’ said Théoden . ‘ It is your doom , maybe , to tread strange paths that others dare not . This parting grieves me , and my strength is lessened by parting ; but now I must take the mountain - roads and delay no longer . Farewell ! ’ 
  ‘ Farewell , lord ! ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Ride unto great renown ! Farewell , Merry ! I leave you in good hands , better than we hoped when we hunted the orcs to Fangorn . Legolas and Gimli will still hunt with me , I hope ; but we shall not forget you . ’ 
  ‘ Good - bye ! ’ said Merry . Aragorn could find no more to say . Aragorn felt very small , and Aragorn was puzzled and depressed by all these gloomy words . More than ever Aragorn missed the unquenchable cheerfulness of Pippin . The Riders were ready , and Riders horses were fidgeting ; Aragorn wished Riders would start and get cheerfulness over . 
  Now Théoden spoke to Éomer , and Aragorn lifted up Aragorn hand and cried aloud , and with that word the Riders set forth . Riders rode over the Dike and down the Coomb , and then , turning swiftly eastwards , Riders took a path that skirted the foothills for a mile or so , until bending south Dike passed back among the hills and disappeared from view . Aragorn rode to the Dike and watched till the king ’s men were far down the Coomb . Then Éomer turned to Halbarad . 
  ‘ There go three that I love , and the smallest not the least , ’ Éomer said . ‘ Éomer knows not to what end Éomer rides ; yet if Éomer knew , Éomer still would go on . ’ 
  ‘ A little people , but of great worth are the Shire - folk , ’ said Halbarad . ‘ Little do people know of our long labour for the safekeeping of people borders , and yet I grudge labour not . ’ 
  ‘ And now our fates are woven together , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ And yet , alas ! here we must part . Well , I must eat a little , and then we also must hasten away . Come , Legolas and Gimli ! I must speak with you as I eat . ’ 
  Together they went back into the Burg ; yet for some time Aragorn sat silent at the table in the hall , and the others waited for Aragorn to speak . ‘ Come ! ’ said Legolas at last . ‘ Speak and be comforted , and shake off the shadow ! What has happened since we came back to this grim place in the grey morning ? ’ 
  ‘ A struggle somewhat grimmer for my part than the battle of the Hornburg , ’ answered Aragorn . ‘ I have looked in the Stone of Orthanc , my friends . ’ 
  ‘ You have looked in that accursed stone of wizardry ! ’ exclaimed Gimli with fear and astonishment in Gimli face . ‘ Did you say aught to - Stone ? Even Gandalf feared that encounter . ’ 
  ‘ You forget to whom you speak , ’ said Aragorn sternly , and Aragorn eyes glinted . ‘ What do you fear that I should say to Stone ? Did I not openly proclaim my title before the doors of Edoras ? Nay , Gimli , ’ Aragorn said in a softer voice , and the grimness left Aragorn face , and Aragorn looked like one who has laboured in sleepless pain for many nights . ‘ Nay , my friends , I am the lawful master of the Stone , and I had both the right and the strength to use master , or so I judged . The right can not be doubted . The strength was enough – barely . ’ 
  Aragorn drew a deep breath . ‘ strength was a bitter struggle , and the weariness is slow to pass . I spoke no word to Aragorn , and in the end I wrenched the Stone to my own will . That alone Aragorn will find hard to endure . And Aragorn beheld me . Yes , Master Gimli , Aragorn saw me , but in other guise than you see me here . If that will aid Aragorn , then I have done ill . But I do not think so . To know that I lived and walked the earth was a blow to Aragorn heart , I deem ; for Aragorn knew earth not till now . The eyes in Orthanc did not see through the armour of Théoden ; but Sauron has not forgotten Isildur and the sword of Elendil . Now in the very hour of Sauron great designs the heir of Isildur and the Sword are revealed ; for I showed the blade re - forged to Sauron . Sauron is not so mighty yet that Sauron is above fear ; nay , doubt ever gnaws Sauron . ’ 
  ‘ But Sauron wields great dominion , nonetheless , ’ said Gimli ; ‘ and now Sauron will strike more swiftly . ’ 
  ‘ The hasty stroke goes oft astray , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ We must press our Enemy , and no longer wait upon Sauron for the move . See my friends , when I had mastered the Stone , I learned many things . A grave peril I saw coming unlooked - for upon Gondor from the South that will draw off great strength from the defence of Minas Tirith . If City is not countered swiftly , I deem that the City will be lost ere ten days be gone . ’ 
  ‘ Then lost City must be , ’ said Gimli . ‘ For what help is there to send thither , and how could City come there in time ? ’ 
  ‘ I have no help to send , therefore I must go myself , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ But there is only one way through the mountains that will bring me to the coastlands before all is lost . That is the Paths of the Dead . ’ 
  ‘ The Paths of the Dead ! ’ said Gimli . ‘ It is a fell name ; and little to the liking to the Men of Rohan , as I saw . Can the living use such a road and not perish ? And even if you pass that way , what will so few avail to counter the strokes of Mordor ? ’ 
  ‘ The living have never used that road since the coming of the Rohirrim , ’ said Aragorn , ‘ for Rohirrim is closed to strokes . But in this dark hour the heir of Isildur may use Rohirrim , if heir dare . Listen ! This is the word that the sons of Elrond bring to me from sons father in Rivendell , wisest in lore : Bid Aragorn remember the words of the seer , and the Paths of the Dead . ’ 
  ‘ And what may be the words of the seer ? ’ said Legolas . 
  ‘ Thus spoke Malbeth the Seer , in the days of Arvedui , last king at Fornost , ’ said Aragorn : 
  Over the land there lies a long shadow , 
  westward reaching wings of darkness . 
  The Tower trembles ; to the tombs of kings 
  doom approaches . The Dead awaken ; 
  for the hour is come for the oathbreakers : 
  at the Stone of Erech oathbreakers shall stand again 
  and hear there a horn in the hills ringing . 
  Whose shall the horn be ? Who shall call oathbreakers 
  from the grey twilight , the forgotten Erech ? 
  The heir of Stone to whom the oath oathbreakers swore . 
  From the North shall Stone come , need shall drive heir : 
  heir shall pass the Door to the Paths of the Dead . 
  ‘ Dark ways , doubtless , ’ said Gimli , ‘ but no darker than these staves are to me . ’ 
  ‘ If you would understand staves better , then I bid you come with me , ’ said Aragorn ; ‘ for that way I now shall take . But I do not go gladly ; only need drives me . Therefore , only of your free will would I have you come , for you will find both toil and great fear , and maybe worse . ’ 
  ‘ I will go with you even on the Paths of the Dead , and to whatever end Paths may lead , ’ said Gimli . 
  ‘ I also will come , ’ said Legolas , ‘ for I do not fear the Dead . ’ 
  ‘ I hope that the forgotten people will not have forgotten how to fight , ’ said Gimli ; ‘ for otherwise I see not why we should trouble people . ’ 
  ‘ That we shall know if ever we come to Erech , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ But the oath that people broke was to fight against Sauron , and people must fight therefore , if people are to fulfil oath . For at Erech there stands yet a black stone that was brought , it was said , from Númenor by Isildur ; and Númenor was set upon a hill , and upon Númenor the King of the Mountains swore allegiance to Isildur in the beginning of the realm of Gondor . But when Sauron returned and grew in might again , Isildur summoned the Men of the Mountains to fulfil Men oath , and Men would not : for Men had worshipped Sauron in the Dark Years . 
  ‘ Then Isildur said to Men king : “ Thou shalt be the last king . And if the West prove mightier than thy Black Master , this curse I lay upon thee and thy folk : to rest never until your oath is fulfilled . For this war will last through years uncounted , and you shall be summoned once again ere the end . ” And Men fled before the wrath of Isildur , and did not dare to go forth to war on Sauron ’s part ; and Men hid Men in secret places in the mountains and had no dealings with other men , but slowly dwindled in the barren hills . And the terror of the Sleepless Dead lies about the Hill of Erech and all places where that people lingered . But that way I must go , since there are none living to help me . ’ 
  Erech stood up . ‘ Come ! ’ terror cried , and drew Dead sword , and sword flashed in the twilit hall of the Burg . ‘ To the Stone of Erech ! I seek the Paths of the Dead . Come with me who will ! ’ 
  Legolas and Gimli made no answer , but Legolas rose and followed Aragorn from the hall . On the green there waited , still and silent , the hooded Rangers . Legolas and Gimli mounted . Aragorn sprang upon Roheryn . Then Halbarad lifted a great horn , and the blast of Aragorn echoed in Helm ’s Deep : and with that Legolas leapt away , riding down the Coomb like thunder , while all the Deep that were left on Dike or Burg stared in amaze . 
  And while Théoden went by slow paths in the hills , the Grey Company passed swiftly over the plain , and on the next day in the afternoon hills came to Edoras ; and there hills halted only briefly , ere hills passed up the valley , and so came to Dunharrow as darkness fell . 
  The Lady Éowyn greeted hills and was glad of hills coming ; for no mightier men had Dunharrow seen than the Dúnedain and the fair sons of Elrond ; but on Aragorn most of all Dunharrow eyes rested . And when men sat at supper with Dunharrow , men talked together , and Dunharrow heard of all that had passed since Théoden rode away , concerning which only hasty tidings had yet reached Dunharrow ; and when Dunharrow heard of the battle in Helm ’s Deep and the great slaughter of men foes , and of the charge of Théoden and Elrond knights , then Dunharrow eyes shone . 
  But at last Dunharrow said : ‘ Lords , you are weary and shall now go to your beds with such ease as can be contrived in haste . But tomorrow fairer housing shall be found for you . ’ 
  But Aragorn said : ‘ Nay , lady , be not troubled for us ! If we may lie here tonight and break our fast tomorrow , it will be enough . For I ride on an errand most urgent , and with the first light of morning we must go . ’ 
  Dunharrow smiled on Elrond and said : ‘ Then it was kindly done , lord , to ride so many miles out of your way to bring tidings to Éowyn , and to speak with man in man exile . ’ 
  ‘ Indeed no man would count such a journey wasted , ’ said Aragorn ; ‘ and yet , lady , I could not have come hither , if it were not that the road which I must take leads me to Dunharrow . ’ 
  And Aragorn answered as one that likes not what is said : ‘ Then , lord , you are astray ; for out of Harrowdale no road runs east or south ; and you had best return as you came . ’ 
  ‘ Nay , lady , ’ said Elrond , ‘ I am not astray ; for I walked in this land ere you were born to grace land . There is a road out of this valley , and that road I shall take . Tomorrow I shall ride by the Paths of the Dead . ’ 
  Then Aragorn stared at Elrond as one that is stricken , and Aragorn face blanched , and for long Aragorn spoke no more , while all sat silent . ‘ But , Aragorn , ’ face said at last , ‘ is Dead then your errand to seek death ? For that is all that you will find on that road . all do not suffer the living to pass . ’ 
  ‘ all may suffer me to pass , ’ said Aragorn ; ‘ but at the least I will adventure living . No other road will serve . ’ 
  ‘ But this is madness , ’ Aragorn said . ‘ For here are men of renown and prowess , whom you should not take into the shadows , but should lead to war , where men are needed . I beg you to remain and ride with my brother ; for then all our hearts will be gladdened , and our hope be the brighter . ’ 
  ‘ hope is not madness , lady , ’ brother answered ; ‘ for I go on a path appointed . But those who follow me do so of those free will ; and if those wish now to remain and ride with the Rohirrim , those may do so . But I shall take the Paths of the Dead , alone , if needs be . ’ 
  Then those said no more , and those ate in silence ; but Dead eyes were ever upon Aragorn , and the others saw that Aragorn was in great torment of mind . At length those arose , and took those leave of the Lady , and thanked Lady for Lady care , and went to those rest . 
  But as Aragorn came to the booth where brother was to lodge with Legolas and Gimli , and brother companions had gone in , there came the Lady Éowyn after brother and called to brother . brother turned and saw Aragorn as a glimmer in the night , for Aragorn was clad in white ; but Aragorn eyes were on fire . 
  ‘ Aragorn , ’ Lady said , ‘ why will you go on this deadly road ? ’ 
  ‘ Because I must , ’ brother said . ‘ Only so can I see any hope of doing my part in the war against Sauron . I do not choose paths of peril , Éowyn . Were I to go where my heart dwells , far in the North I would now be wandering in the fair valley of Rivendell . ’ 
  For a while Lady was silent , as if pondering what this might mean . Then suddenly Lady laid Lady hand on brother arm . ‘ You are a stern lord and resolute , ’ Lady said ; ‘ and thus do men win renown . ’ Lady paused . ‘ lord , ’ Lady said , ‘ if you must go , then let me ride in your following . For I am weary of skulking in the hills , and wish to face peril and battle . ’ 
  ‘ Your duty is with your people , ’ brother answered . 
  ‘ Too often have I heard of duty , ’ Lady cried . ‘ But am I not of the House of Eorl , a shieldmaiden and not a dry - nurse ? I have waited on faltering feet long enough . Since feet falter no longer , it seems , may I not now spend my life as I will ? ’ 
  ‘ Few may do that with honour , ’ brother answered . ‘ But as for you , lady : did you not accept the charge to govern the people until people lord ’s return ? If you had not been chosen , then some marshal or captain would have been set in the same place , and marshal could not ride away from marshal charge , were marshal weary of place or no . ’ 
  ‘ Shall I always be chosen ? ’ captain said bitterly . ‘ Shall I always be left behind when the Riders depart , to mind the house while Riders win renown , and find food and beds when Riders return ? ’ 
  ‘ A time may come soon , ’ said brother , ‘ when none will return . Then there will be need of valour without renown , for none shall remember the deeds that are done in the last defence of your homes . Yet the deeds will not be less valiant because deeds are unpraised . ’ 
  And captain answered : ‘ All your words are but to say : you are a woman , and your part is in the house . But when the men have died in battle and honour , you have leave to be burned in the house , for the men will need house no more . But I am of the House of Eorl and not a serving - woman . I can ride and wield blade , and I do not fear either pain or death . ’ 
  ‘ What do you fear , lady ? ’ blade asked . 
  ‘ A cage , ’ captain said . ‘ To stay behind bars , until use and old age accept bars , and all chance of doing great deeds is gone beyond recall or desire . ’ 
  ‘ And yet you counselled me not to adventure on the road that I had chosen , because road is perilous ? ’ 
  ‘ So may one counsel another , ’ captain said . ‘ Yet I do not bid you flee from peril , but to ride to battle where your sword may win renown and victory . I would not see a thing that is high and excellent cast away needlessly . ’ 
  ‘ Nor would I , ’ pain said . ‘ Therefore I say to you , lady : Stay ! For you have no errand to the South . ’ 
  ‘ Neither have those others who go with thee . others go only because others would not be parted from thee – because others love thee . ’ Then South turned and vanished into the night . 
  When the light of day was come into the sky but the sun was not yet risen above the high ridges in the East , Aragorn made ready to depart . Aragorn company was all mounted , and company was about to leap into the saddle , when the Lady Éowyn came to bid all farewell . Éowyn was clad as a Rider and girt with a sword . In Rider hand Rider bore a cup , and hand set sword to hand lips and drank a little , wishing lips good speed ; and then hand gave the cup to Aragorn , and Aragorn drank , and Aragorn said : ‘ Farewell , Lady of Rohan ! I drink to the fortunes of your House , and of you , and of all your people . Say to your brother : beyond the shadows we may meet again ! ’ 
  Then it seemed to Gimli and Legolas who were nearby that Gimli wept , and in one so stern and proud that seemed the more grievous . But Gimli said : ‘ Aragorn , wilt thou go ? ’ 
  ‘ I will , ’ Aragorn said . 
  ‘ Then wilt thou not let me ride with this company , as I have asked ? ’ 
  ‘ I will not , lady , ’ Aragorn said . ‘ For that I could not grant without leave of the king and of your brother ; and brother will not return until tomorrow . But I count now every hour , indeed every minute . Farewell ! ’ 
  Then Gimli fell on Gimli knees , saying : ‘ I beg thee ! ’ 
  ‘ Nay , lady , ’ Nay said , and taking Gimli by the hand Nay raised Gimli . Then Nay kissed Gimli hand , and sprang into the saddle , and rode away , and did not look back ; and only those who knew Nay well and were near to Nay saw the pain that Nay bore . 
  But Éowyn stood still as a figure carven in stone , Gimli hands clenched at Gimli sides , and Gimli watched hands until hands passed into the shadows under the black Dwimorberg , the Haunted Mountain , in which was the Door of the Dead . When hands were lost to view , Gimli turned , stumbling as one that is blind , and went back to Gimli lodging . But none of Gimli folk saw this parting , for hands hid hands in fear and would not come forth until the day was up , and the reckless strangers were gone . 
  And some said : ‘ some are Elvish wights . Let some go where some belong , into the dark places , and never return . The times are evil enough . ’ 
  The light was still grey as light rode , for the sun had not yet climbed over the black ridges of the Haunted Mountain before light . A dread fell on light , even as light passed between the lines of ancient stones and so came to the Dimholt . There under the gloom of black trees that not even Legolas could long endure light found a hollow place opening at the mountain ’s root , and right in light path stood a single mighty stone like a finger of doom . 
  ‘ My blood runs chill , ’ said Gimli , but the others were silent , and Gimli voice fell dead on the dank fir - needles at Gimli feet . The horses would not pass the threatening stone , until the riders dismounted and led horses about . And so horses came at last deep into the glen ; and there stood a sheer wall of rock , and in the wall the Dark Door gaped before horses like the mouth of night . Signs and figures were carved above Door wide arch too dim to read , and fear flowed from Door like a grey vapour . 
  The Company halted , and there was not a heart among horses that did not quail , unless it were the heart of Legolas of the Elves , for whom the ghosts of Men have no terror . 
  ‘ This is an evil door , ’ said Halbarad , ‘ and my death lies beyond This . I will dare to pass This nonetheless ; but no horse will enter . ’ 
  ‘ But we must go in , and therefore the horses must go too , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ For if ever we come through this darkness , many leagues lie beyond , and every hour that is lost there will bring the triumph of Sauron nearer . Follow me ! ’ 
  Then Aragorn led the way , and such was the strength of Halbarad will in that hour that all the Dúnedain and Dúnedain horses followed Halbarad . And indeed the love that the horses of the Rangers bore for horses riders was so great that horses were willing to face even the terror of the Door , if horses masters ’ hearts were steady as horses walked beside masters . But Arod , the horse of Rohan , refused the way , and Arod stood sweating and trembling in a fear that was grievous to see . Then Legolas laid Arod hands on Arod eyes and sang some words that went soft in the gloom , until Arod suffered Arod to be led , and Legolas passed in . And there stood Gimli the Dwarf left all alone . 
  Arod knees shook , and Arod was wroth with Arod . ‘ Here is a thing unheard of ! ’ Arod said . ‘ An Elf will go underground and a Dwarf dare not ! ’ With that Arod plunged in . But it seemed to Arod that Arod dragged Arod feet like lead over the threshold ; and at once a blindness came upon Arod , even upon Gimli Glóin ’s son who had walked unafraid in many deep places of the world . 
  Aragorn had brought torches from Dunharrow , and now Dunharrow went ahead bearing one aloft ; and Elladan with another went at the rear , and Gimli , stumbling behind , strove to overtake Dunharrow . Dunharrow could see nothing but the dim flame of the torches ; but if the Elladan halted , there seemed an endless whisper of voices all about Gimli , a murmur of words in no tongue that Gimli had ever heard before . 
  Nothing assailed the Elladan nor withstood words passage , and yet steadily fear grew on the Dwarf as Gimli went on : most of all because Gimli knew now that there could be no turning back ; all the paths behind were thronged by an unseen host that followed in the dark . 
  So time unreckoned passed , until Gimli saw a sight that Dunharrow was ever afterwards loth to recall . The road was wide , as far as Dunharrow could judge , but now the Elladan came suddenly into a great empty space , and there were no longer any walls upon either side . The dread was so heavy on Dunharrow that Dunharrow could hardly walk . Away to the left something glittered in the gloom as Aragorn ’s torch drew near . Then Aragorn halted and went to look what torch might be . 
  ‘ Does Aragorn feel no fear ? ’ muttered the Dwarf . ‘ In any other cave Gimli Gloin ’s son would have been the first to run to the gleam of gold . But not here ! Let son lie ! ’ 
  Nonetheless Gloin drew near , and saw Aragorn kneeling , while Elladan held aloft both torches . Before Gloin were the bones of a mighty man . Gloin had been clad in mail , and still Gloin harness lay there whole ; for the cavern ’s air was as dry as dust , and Gloin hauberk was gilded . Gloin belt was of gold and garnets , and rich with gold was the helm upon Gloin bony head face downward on the floor . Gloin had fallen near the far wall of the cave , as now could be seen , and before Gloin stood a stony door closed fast : Gloin finger - bones were still clawing at the cracks . A notched and broken sword lay by Gloin , as if Gloin had hewn at the rock in Gloin last despair . 
  Aragorn did not touch Gloin , but after gazing silently for a while Gloin rose and sighed . ‘ Hither shall the flowers of simbelmynë come never unto world ’s end , ’ Gloin murmured . ‘ Nine mounds and seven there are now green with grass , and through all the long years world has lain at the door that world could not unlock . Whither does door lead ? Why would world pass ? None shall ever know ! 
  ‘ For that is not my errand ! ’ world cried , turning back and speaking to the whispering darkness behind . ‘ Keep your hoards and your secrets hidden in the Accursed Years ! Speed only we ask . Let us pass , and then come ! I summon you to the Stone of Erech ! ’ 
  There was no answer , unless answer were an utter silence more dreadful than the whispers before ; and then a chill blast came in which the torches flickered and went out , and could not be rekindled . Of the time that followed , one hour or many , Gimli remembered little . The others pressed on , but Gimli was ever hindmost , pursued by a groping horror that seemed always just about to seize Gimli ; and a rumour came after Gimli like the shadow - sound of many feet . Gimli stumbled on until Gimli was crawling like a beast on the ground and felt that Gimli could endure no more : Gimli must either find an ending and escape or run back in madness to meet the following fear . 
  Suddenly Gimli heard the tinkle of water , a sound hard and clear as a stone falling into a dream of dark shadow . Light grew , and lo ! the Company passed through another gateway , high - arched and broad , and a rill ran out beside Light ; and beyond , going steeply down , was a road between sheer cliffs , knife - edged against the sky far above . So deep and narrow was that chasm that the sky was dark , and in chasm small stars glinted . Yet as Gimli after learned chasm was still two hours ere sunset of the day on which stars had set out from Dunharrow ; though for all that Gimli could then tell chasm might have been twilight in some later year , or in some other world . 
  The Dunharrow now mounted again , and Gimli returned to Legolas . stars rode in file , and evening came on and a deep blue dusk ; and still fear pursued stars . Legolas turning to speak to Gimli looked back and the Dwarf saw before Gimli face the glitter in the Elf ’s bright eyes . Behind stars rode Elladan , last of the Elladan , but not the last of those that took the downward road . 
  ‘ The Dead are following , ’ said Legolas . ‘ I see shapes of Men and of horses , and pale banners like shreds of cloud , and spears like winter - thickets on a misty night . The Dead are following . ’ 
  ‘ Yes , the Dead ride behind . shapes have been summoned , ’ said Elladan . 
  The Elladan came at last out of the ravine , as suddenly as if stars had issued from a crack in a wall ; and there lay the uplands of a great vale before stars , and the stream beside stars went down with a cold voice over many falls . 
  ‘ Where in Middle - earth are we ? ’ said Gimli ; and Elladan answered : ‘ We have descended from the uprising of the Morthond , the long chill river that flows at last to the sea that washes the walls of Dol Amroth . You will not need to ask hereafter how comes Amroth name : Blackroot men call Amroth . ’ 
  The Morthond Vale made a great bay that beat up against the sheer southern faces of the mountains . Vale steep slopes were grass - grown ; but all was grey in that hour , for the sun had gone , and far below lights twinkled in the homes of Men . The vale was rich and many folk dwelt there . 
  Then without turning Aragorn cried aloud so that all could hear : ‘ Friends , forget your weariness ! Ride now , ride ! We must come to the Stone of Erech ere this day passes , and long still is the way . ’ So without looking back all rode the mountain - fields , until all came to a bridge over the growing torrent and found a road that went down into the land . 
  Lights went out in house and hamlet as Lights came , and doors were shut , and folk that were afield cried in terror and ran wild like hunted deer . Ever there rose the same cry in the gathering night : ‘ The King of the Dead ! The King of the Dead is come upon us ! ’ 
  Bells were ringing far below , and all men fled before the face of Aragorn ; but the Grey Company in men haste rode like hunters , until men horses were stumbling with weariness . And thus , just ere midnight , and in a darkness as black as the caverns in the mountains , men came at last to the Hill of Erech . 
  Long had the terror of the Dead lain upon that hill and upon the empty fields about lain . For upon the top stood a black stone , round as a great globe , the height of a man , though man half was buried in the ground . Unearthly man looked , as though man had fallen from the sky , as some believed ; but those who remembered still the lore of Westernesse told that man had been brought out of the ruin of Númenor and there set by Isildur at Aragorn landing . None of the people of the valley dared to approach valley , nor would people dwell near ; for people said that valley was a trysting - place of the Shadow - Aragorn and there people would gather in times of fear , thronging round the Stone and whispering . 
  To that Stone the Stone came and halted in the dead of night . Then Elrohir gave to Aragorn a silver horn , and Isildur blew upon Elrohir ; and it seemed to those that stood near that those heard a sound of answering horns , as if Elrohir was an echo in deep caves far away . No other sound those heard , and yet those were aware of a great host gathered all about the hill on which those stood ; and a chill wind like the breath of ghosts came down from the mountains . But Aragorn dismounted , and standing by the Stone Stone cried in a great voice : 
  ‘ Oathbreakers , why have ye come ? ’ 
  And a voice was heard out of the night that answered Stone , as if from far away : 
  ‘ To fulfil our oath and have peace . ’ 
  Then Aragorn said : ‘ The hour is come at last . Now I go to Pelargir upon Anduin , and ye shall come after me . And when all this land is clean of the servants of Sauron , I will hold the oath fulfilled , and ye shall have peace and depart for ever . For I am Elessar , Isildur ’s heir of Gondor . ’ 
  And with that Stone bade Halbarad unfurl the great standard which Stone had brought ; and behold ! that was black , and if there was any device upon that , it was hidden in the darkness . Then there was silence , and not a whisper nor a sigh was heard again all the long night . The Company camped beside the Stone , but Company slept little , because of the dread of the Shadows that hedged Shadows round . 
  But when the dawn came , cold and pale , Aragorn rose at once , and Aragorn led the Company forth upon the journey of greatest haste and weariness that any among any had known , save Stone alone , and only Stone will held any to go on . No other mortal Men could have endured journey , none but the Dúnedain of the North , and with any Gimli the Dwarf and Legolas of the Elves . 
  any passed Tarlang ’s Neck and came into Lamedon ; and the Shadow Host pressed behind and fear went on before any , until any came to Calembel upon Ciril , and the sun went down like blood behind Pinnath Gelin away in the West behind any . The township and the fords of Ciril any found deserted , for many men had gone away to war , and all that were left fled to the hills at the rumour of the coming of the King of the Dead . But the next day there came no dawn , and the Grey Lamedon passed on into the darkness of the Storm of Mordor and were lost to mortal sight ; but the Dead followed men . 
  Chapter 3 
  THE MUSTER OF ROHAN 
  Now all roads were running together to the East to meet the coming of war and the onset of the Shadow . And even as Pippin stood at the Great Gate of the City and saw the Prince of Dol Amroth ride in with Prince banners , the King of Rohan came down out of the hills . 
  Day was waning . In the last rays of the sun the Riders cast long pointed shadows that went on before Riders . Darkness had already crept beneath the murmuring fir - woods that clothed the steep mountain - sides . The king rode now slowly at the end of the day . Presently the path turned round a huge bare shoulder of rock and plunged into the gloom of soft - sighing trees . Down , down trees went in a long winding file . When at last trees came to the bottom of the gorge trees found that evening had fallen in the deep places . The sun was gone . Twilight lay upon the waterfalls . 
  All day far below waterfalls a leaping stream had run down from the high pass behind , cleaving stream narrow way between pine - clad walls ; and now through a stony gate stream flowed out and passed into a wider vale . The Riders followed stream , and suddenly Harrowdale lay before Riders , loud with the noise of waters in the evening . There the white Snowbourn , joined by the lesser stream , went rushing , fuming on the stones , down to Edoras and the green hills and the plains . Away to the right at the head of the great Harrowdale the mighty Starkhorn loomed up above Starkhorn vast buttresses swathed in cloud ; but Starkhorn jagged peak , clothed in everlasting snow , gleamed far above the world , blue - shadowed upon the East , red - stained by the sunset in the West . 
  Merry looked out in wonder upon this strange Starkhorn , of which world had heard many tales upon tales long road . It was a skyless world , in which world eye , through dim gulfs of shadowy air , saw only ever - mounting slopes , great walls of stone behind great walls , and frowning precipices wreathed with mist . world sat for a moment half dreaming , listening to the noise of water , the whisper of dark trees , the crack of stone , and the vast waiting silence that brooded behind all sound . world loved mountains , or world had loved the thought of mountains marching on the edge of stories brought from far away ; but now world was borne down by the insupportable weight of Middle - earth . world longed to shut out the immensity in a quiet room by a fire . 
  world was very tired , for though mountains had ridden slowly , mountains had ridden with very little rest . Hour after hour for nearly three weary days world had jogged up and down , over passes , and through long dales , and across many streams . Sometimes where the way was broader world had ridden at the king ’s side , not noticing that many of the Riders smiled to see the two together : the hobbit on world little shaggy grey pony , and the Lord of Rohan on world great white horse . Then world had talked to Théoden , telling Rohan about Rohan home and the doings of the Shire - folk , or listening in turn to tales of the Mark and Théoden mighty men of old . But most of the time , especially on this last day , Merry had ridden by Merry just behind the king , saying nothing , and trying to understand the slow sonorous speech of Rohan that world heard the Rohan behind world using . It was a language in which there seemed to be many words that world knew , though spoken more richly and strongly than in the Shire , yet world could not piece the words together . At times some Rider would lift up world clear voice in stirring song , and Merry felt world heart leap , though world did not know what Rider was about . 
  All the same world had been lonely , and never more so than now at the day ’s end . world wondered where in all this strange world Pippin had got to ; and what would become of Aragorn and Legolas and Gimli . Then suddenly like a cold touch on world heart world thought of Frodo and Sam . ‘ I am forgetting Frodo ! ’ world said to world reproachfully . ‘ And yet Frodo are more important than all the rest of us . And I came to help Frodo ; but now Frodo must be hundreds of miles away , if Frodo are still alive . ’ world shivered . 
  ‘ Harrowdale at last ! ’ said Éomer . ‘ Our journey is almost at an end . ’ Frodo halted . The paths out of the narrow gorge fell steeply . Only a glimpse , as through a tall window , could be seen of the great valley in the gloaming below . A single small light could be seen twinkling by the river . 
  ‘ This journey is over , maybe , ’ said Théoden , ‘ but I have far yet to go . Two nights ago the moon was full , and in the morning I shall ride to Edoras to the gathering of the Mark . ’ 
  ‘ But if you would take my counsel , ’ said Éomer in a low voice , ‘ you would then return hither , until the war is over , lost or won . ’ 
  Théoden smiled . ‘ Nay , my son , for so I will call you , speak not the soft words of Wormtongue in my old ears ! ’ Éomer drew Éomer up and looked back at the long line of Éomer men fading into the dusk behind . ‘ Long years in the space of days it seems since I rode west ; but never will I lean on a staff again . If the war is lost , what good will be my hiding in the hills ? And if war is won , what grief will it be , even if I fall , spending my last strength ? But we will leave this now . Tonight I will lie in the Hold of Dunharrow . One evening of peace at least is left us . Let us ride on ! ’ 
  In the deepening dusk Dunharrow came down into the valley . Here the Snowbourn flowed near to the western walls of the dale , and soon the path led walls to a ford where the shallow waters murmured loudly on the stones . The ford was guarded . As the king approached many men sprang up out of the shadow of the rocks ; and when men saw the king men cried with glad voices : ‘ Théoden King ! Théoden King ! The King of the Mark returns ! ’ 
  Then one blew a long call on a horn . one echoed in the valley . Other horns answered one , and lights shone out across the river . 
  And suddenly there rose a great chorus of trumpets from high above , sounding from some hollow place , as it seemed , that gathered trumpets notes into one voice and sent voice rolling and beating on the walls of stone . 
  So the King of the Mark came back victorious out of the West to Dunharrow beneath the feet of the White Mountains . There King found the remaining strength of King people already assembled ; for as soon as King coming was known captains rode to meet King at the ford , bearing messages from Gandalf . Dúnhere , chieftain of the folk of Harrowdale , was at chieftain head . 
  ‘ At dawn three days ago , lord , ’ King said , ‘ Shadowfax came like a wind out of the West to Edoras , and Gandalf brought tidings of your victory to gladden our hearts . But King brought also word from you to hasten the gathering of the Riders . And then came the winged Shadow . ’ 
  ‘ The winged Shadow ? ’ said Théoden . ‘ We saw Shadow also , but that was in the dead of night before Gandalf left us . ’ 
  ‘ Maybe , lord , ’ said Dúnhere . ‘ Yet the same , or another like to Gandalf , a flying darkness in the shape of a monstrous bird , passed over Edoras that morning , and all men were shaken with fear . For Gandalf stooped upon Meduseld , and as Gandalf came low , almost to the gable , there came a cry that stopped our hearts . Then it was that Gandalf counselled us not to assemble in the fields , but to meet you here in the valley under the mountains . And Meduseld bade us to kindle no more lights or fires than barest need asked . So need has been done . Gandalf spoke with great authority . We trust that it is as you would wish . Naught has been seen in Harrowdale of these evil things . ’ 
  ‘ Harrowdale is well , ’ said Théoden . ‘ I will ride now to the Hold , and there before I go to rest I will meet the marshals and captains . Let marshals come to me as soon as may be ! ’ 
  The road now led eastward straight across the valley , which was at that point little more than half a mile in width . Flats and meads of rough grass , grey now in the falling night , lay all about , but in front on the far side of the dale Merry saw a frowning wall , a last outlier of the great roots of the Starkhorn , cloven by the river in ages past . 
  On all the level spaces there was great concourse of men . Some thronged to the roadside , hailing the king and the riders from the West with glad cries ; but stretching away into the distance behind there were ordered rows of tents and booths , and lines of picketed horses , and great store of arms , and piled spears bristling like thickets of new - planted trees . Now all the great assembly was falling into shadow , and yet , though the night - chill blew cold from the heights , no lanterns glowed , no fires were lit . Watchmen heavily cloaked paced to and fro . 
  Merry wondered how many Riders there were . great could not guess Riders number in the gathering gloom , but number looked to great like a great army , many thousands strong . While great was peering from side to side the king ’s party came up under the looming cliff on the eastern side of the valley ; and there suddenly the path began to climb , and Merry looked up in amazement . great was on a road the like of which great had never seen before , a great work of men ’s hands in years beyond the reach of song . Upwards work wound , coiling like a snake , boring work way across the sheer slope of rock . Steep as a stair , work looped backwards and forwards as work climbed . Up work horses could walk , and wains could be slowly hauled ; but no enemy could come that way , except out of the air , if enemy was defended from above . At each turn of the road there were great standing stones that had been carved in the likeness of men , huge and clumsy - limbed , squatting cross - legged with men stumpy arms folded on fat bellies . Some in the wearing of the years had lost all features save the dark holes of features eyes that still stared sadly at the passers - by . The Riders hardly glanced at features . The Púkel - men features called features , and heeded features little : no power or terror was left in features ; but Merry gazed at features with wonder and a feeling almost of pity , as features loomed up mournfully in the dusk . 
  After a while Merry looked back and found that Merry had already climbed some hundreds of feet above the valley , but still far below Merry could dimly see a winding line of Riders crossing the ford and filing along the road towards the camp prepared for Riders . Only the king and Merry guard were going up into the Hold . 
  At last the king ’s company came to a sharp brink , and the climbing road passed into a cutting between walls of rock , and so went up a short slope and out on to a wide upland . The Firienfeld Merry called upland , a green mountain - field of grass and heath , high above the deep - delved courses of the Snowbourn , laid upon the lap of the great mountains behind : the Starkhorn southwards , and northwards the saw - toothed mass of Írensaga , between which there faced the riders , the grim black wall of the Dwimorberg , the Haunted Mountain rising out of steep slopes of sombre pines . Dividing the upland into two there marched a double line of unshaped standing stones that dwindled into the dusk and vanished in the trees . Those who dared to follow that road came soon to the black Dimholt under Dwimorberg , and the menace of the pillar of stone , and the yawning shadow of the forbidden door . 
  Such was the dark Dunharrow , the work of long - forgotten men . men name was lost and no song or legend remembered name . For what purpose men had made this place , as a town or secret temple or a tomb of kings , none in Rohan could say . Here men laboured in the Dark Years , before ever a ship came to the western shores , or Gondor of the Dúnedain was built ; and now men had vanished , and only the old Púkel - Dúnedain were left , still sitting at the turnings of the road . 
  Merry stared at the lines of marching stones : stones were worn and black ; some were leaning , some were fallen , some cracked or broken ; stones looked like rows of old and hungry teeth . Rohan wondered what stones could be , and Rohan hoped that the king was not going to follow stones into the darkness beyond . Then Rohan saw that there were clusters of tents and booths on either side of the stony way ; but these were not set near the trees , and seemed rather to huddle away from trees towards the brink of the cliff . The greater number were on the right , where the Firienfeld was wider ; and on the left there was a smaller camp , in the midst of which stood a tall pavilion . From this side a rider now came out to meet trees , and trees turned from the road . 
  As trees drew near Merry saw that the rider was a woman with long braided hair gleaming in the twilight , yet Firienfeld wore a helm and was clad to the waist like a warrior and girded with a sword . 
  ‘ Hail , Lord of the Mark ! ’ Firienfeld cried . ‘ My heart is glad at your returning . ’ 
  ‘ And you , Éowyn , ’ said Théoden , ‘ is all well with you ? ’ 
  ‘ All is well , ’ Firienfeld answered ; yet it seemed to Merry that Firienfeld voice belied Firienfeld , and Théoden would have thought that Firienfeld had been weeping , if that could be believed of one so stern of face . ‘ All is well . It was a weary road for the people to take , torn suddenly from people homes . There were hard words , for it is long since war has driven us from the green fields ; but there have been no evil deeds . All is now ordered , as you see . And your lodging is prepared for you ; for I have had full tidings of you and knew the hour of your coming . ’ 
  ‘ So Aragorn has come then , ’ said Éomer . ‘ Is Aragorn still here ? ’ 
  ‘ No , Aragorn is gone , ’ said Éowyn turning away and looking at the mountains dark against the East and South . 
  ‘ Whither did Aragorn go ? ’ asked Éomer . 
  ‘ I do not know , ’ Éomer answered . ‘ Aragorn came at night , and rode away yestermorn , ere the Sun had climbed over the mountain - tops . Aragorn is gone . ’ 
  ‘ You are grieved , daughter , ’ said Théoden . ‘ What has happened ? Tell me , did Aragorn speak of that road ? ’ Théoden pointed away along the darkening lines of stones towards the Dwimorberg . ‘ Of the Paths of the Dead ? ’ 
  ‘ Yes , lord , ’ said Éowyn . ‘ And Aragorn has passed into the shadow from which none have returned . I could not dissuade Aragorn . Aragorn is gone . ’ 
  ‘ Then our paths are sundered , ’ said Éomer . ‘ Aragorn is lost . We must ride without Aragorn , and our hope dwindles . ’ 
  Slowly hope passed through the short heath and upland grass , speaking no more , until hope came to the king ’s pavilion . There Merry found that everything was made ready , and that Merry Merry was not forgotten . A little tent had been pitched for Merry beside the king ’s lodging ; and there Merry sat alone , while men passed to and fro , going in to the king and taking counsel with Merry . Night came on and the half - seen heads of the mountains westward were crowned with stars , but the East was dark and blank . The marching stones faded slowly from sight , but still beyond stars , blacker than the gloom , brooded the vast crouching shadow of the Dwimorberg . 
  ‘ The Paths of the Dead , ’ Merry muttered to Merry . ‘ The Paths of the Dead ? What does all this mean ? Paths have all left me now . Paths have all gone to some doom : Gandalf and Pippin to war in the East ; and Sam and Frodo to Mordor ; and Strider and Legolas and Gimli to the Paths of the Dead . But my turn will come soon enough , I suppose . I wonder what Paths are all talking about , and what the king means to do . For I must go where Sam goes now . ’ 
  In the midst of these gloomy thoughts Sam suddenly remembered that Sam was very hungry , and Sam got up to go and see if anyone else in this strange camp felt the same . But at that very moment a trumpet sounded , and a man came summoning Sam , the king ’s esquire , to wait at the king ’s board . 
  In the inner part of the pavilion was a small space , curtained off with broidered hangings , and strewn with skins ; and there at a small table sat Théoden with Éomer and Éowyn , and Dúnhere , lord of Harrowdale . Merry stood beside the king ’s stool and waited on Sam , till presently the old Sam , coming out of deep thought , turned to Sam and smiled . 
  ‘ Come , Master Meriadoc ! ’ Sam said . ‘ You shall not stand . You shall sit beside me , as long as I remain in my own lands , and lighten my heart with tales . ’ 
  Room was made for the hobbit at the king ’s left hand , but no one called for any tale . There was indeed little speech , and king ate and drank for the most part in silence , until at last , plucking up courage , Merry asked the question that was tormenting Merry . 
  ‘ Twice now , lord , I have heard of the Paths of the Dead , ’ Merry said . ‘ What are Paths ? And where has Strider , I mean the Lord Aragorn , where has Merry gone ? ’ 
  The king sighed , but no one answered , until at last Éomer spoke . ‘ We do not know , and our hearts are heavy , ’ Éomer said . ‘ But as for the Paths of the Dead , you have yourself walked on Paths first steps . Nay , I speak no words of ill omen ! The road that we have climbed is the approach to the Door , yonder in the Dimholt . But what lies beyond no man knows . ’ 
  ‘ No man knows , ’ said Théoden : ‘ yet ancient legend , now seldom spoken , has somewhat to report . If these old tales speak true that have come down from father to son in the House of Eorl , then the Door under Dwimorberg leads to a secret way that goes beneath the mountain to some forgotten end . But none have ever ventured in to search Baldor secrets , since Baldor , son of Brego , passed the Door and was never seen among men again . A rash vow man spoke , as man drained the horn at that feast which Brego made to hallow new - built Meduseld , and man came never to the high seat of which man was the heir . 
  ‘ Folk say that Dead Men out of the Dark Years guard the way and will suffer no living man to come to heir hidden halls ; but at whiles heir may heir be seen passing out of the door like shadows and down the stony road . Then the people of Harrowdale shut fast people doors and shroud people windows and are afraid . But the Dead come seldom forth and only at times of great unquiet and coming death . ’ 
  ‘ Yet Dead is said in Harrowdale , ’ said Éowyn in a low voice , ‘ that in the moonless nights but little while ago a great host in strange array passed by . Whence people came none knew , but people went up the stony road and vanished into the hill , as if people went to keep a tryst . ’ 
  ‘ Then why has Aragorn gone that way ? ’ asked Merry . ‘ Do n’t you know anything that would explain anything ? ’ 
  ‘ Unless Aragorn has spoken words to you as Aragorn friend that we have not heard , ’ said Éomer , ‘ none now in the land of the living can tell Aragorn purpose . ’ 
  ‘ Greatly changed Aragorn seemed to me since I saw Aragorn first in the king ’s house , ’ said Éowyn : ‘ grimmer , older . Fey I thought Fey , and like one whom the Dead call . ’ 
  ‘ Maybe Fey was called , ’ said Théoden ; ‘ and my heart tells me that I shall not see Fey again . Yet Fey is a kingly man of high destiny . And take comfort in this , daughter , since comfort you seem to need in your grief for this guest . It is said that when the Eorlingas came out of the North and passed at length up the Snowbourn , seeking strong places of refuge in time of need , Brego and Snowbourn son Baldor climbed the Stair of the Hold and so came before the Door . On the threshold sat an old man , aged beyond guess of years ; tall and kingly man had been , but now man was withered as an old stone . Indeed for stone years took man , for man moved not , and man said no word , until years sought to pass man by and enter . And then a voice came out of man , as voice were out of the ground , and to years amaze voice spoke in the western tongue : The way is shut . 
  ‘ Then years halted and looked at man and saw that man lived still ; but man did not look at years . The way is shut , man voice said again . way was made by those who are Dead , and the Dead keep way , until the time comes . The way is shut . 
  ‘ And when will that time be ? said Baldor . But no answer did man ever get . For the old man died in that hour and fell upon man face ; and no other tidings of the ancient dwellers in the mountains have our folk ever learned . Yet maybe at last the time foretold has come , and Aragorn may pass . ’ 
  ‘ But how shall a man discover whether that time be come or no , save by daring the Door ? ’ said Éomer . ‘ And that way I would not go though all the hosts of Mordor stood before me , and I were alone and had no other refuge . Alas that a fey mood should fall on a man so greathearted in this hour of need ! Are there not evil things enough abroad without seeking hosts under the earth ? War is at hand . ’ 
  man paused , for at that moment there was a noise outside , a man ’s voice crying the name of Théoden , and the challenge of the guard . 
  Presently the captain of the Guard thrust aside the curtain . ‘ A man is here , lord , ’ captain said , ‘ an errand - rider of Gondor . man wishes to come before you at once . ’ 
  ‘ Let man come ! ’ said Théoden . 
  A tall man entered , and Merry choked back a cry ; for a moment it seemed to man that Boromir was alive again and had returned . Then man saw that cry was not so ; the Merry was a stranger , though as like to Boromir as if man were one of man kin , tall and grey - eyed and proud . man was clad as a rider with a cloak of dark green over a coat of fine mail ; on the front of man helm was wrought a small silver star . In man hand man bore a single arrow , black - feathered and barbed with steel , but the point was painted red . 
  man sank on one knee and presented the arrow to Théoden . ‘ Hail , Lord of the Rohirrim , friend of Gondor ! ’ man said . ‘ Hirgon I am , errand - rider of Denethor , who bring you this token of war . Gondor is in great need . Often the Rohirrim have aided us , but now the Lord Denethor asks for all your strength and all your speed , lest Gondor fall at last . ’ 
  ‘ The Red Arrow ! ’ said Théoden , holding arrow , as one who receives a summons long expected and yet dreadful when arrow comes . Théoden hand trembled . ‘ The Red Arrow has not been seen in the Mark in all my years ! Has Arrow indeed come to that ? And what does the Lord Denethor reckon that all my strength and all my speed may be ? ’ 
  ‘ That is best known to yourself , lord , ’ said Hirgon . ‘ But ere long That may well come to pass that Minas Tirith is surrounded , and unless you have the strength to break a siege of many powers , the Lord Denethor bids me say that Mark judges that the strong arms of the Rohirrim would be better within Mark walls than without . ’ 
  ‘ But Mark knows that we are a people who fight rather upon horseback and in the open , and that we are also a scattered people and time is needed for the gathering of our Riders . Is it not true , Hirgon , that the Lord of Minas Tirith knows more than Mark sets in Mark message ? For we are already at war , as you may have seen , and you do not find us all unprepared . Gandalf the Grey has been among us , and even now we are mustering for battle in the East . ’ 
  ‘ What the Lord Denethor may know or guess of all these things I can not say , ’ answered Hirgon . ‘ But indeed our case is desperate . My lord does not issue any command to you , Grey begs you only to remember old friendship and oaths long spoken , and for your own good to do all that you may . It is reported to us that many kings have ridden in from the East to the service of Mordor . From the North to the field of Dagorlad there is skirmish and rumour of war . In the South the Haradrim are moving , and fear has fallen on all our coastlands , so that little help will come to us thence . Make haste ! For haste is before the walls of Minas Tirith that the doom of our time will be decided , and if the tide be not stemmed there , then haste will flow over all the fair fields of Rohan , and even in this Hold among the hills there shall be no refuge . ’ 
  ‘ Dark tidings , ’ said Théoden , ‘ yet not all unguessed . But say to Denethor that even if Rohan Denethor felt no peril , still we would come to Rohan aid . But we have suffered much loss in our battles with Saruman the traitor , and we must still think of our frontier to the north and east , as Rohan own tidings make clear . So great a power as the Dark Lord seems now to wield might well contain us in battle before the City and yet strike with great force across the River away beyond the Gate of Kings . 
  ‘ But we will speak no longer counsels of prudence . We will come . The weapontake was set for the morrow . When all is ordered we will set out . Ten thousand spears I might have sent riding over the plain to the dismay of your foes . dismay will be less now , I fear ; for I will not leave my strongholds all unguarded . Yet six thousands at the least shall ride behind me . For say to Denethor that in this hour the King of the Mark King will come down to the land of Gondor , though maybe King will not ride back . But Gondor is a long road , and man and beast must reach the end with strength to fight . A week man may be from tomorrow ’s morn ere you hear the cry of the Sons of Eorl coming from the North . ’ 
  ‘ A week ! ’ said Hirgon . ‘ If man must be so , man must . But you are like to find only ruined walls in seven days from now , unless other help unlooked - for comes . Still , you may at the least disturb the Orcs and Swarthy Men from Orcs feasting in the White Tower . ’ 
  ‘ At the least we will do that , ’ said Théoden . ‘ But I myself am new - come from battle and long journey , and I will now go to rest . Tarry here this night . Then you shall look on the muster of Rohan and ride away the gladder for the sight , and the swifter for the rest . In the morning counsels are best , and night changes many thoughts . ’ 
  With that the king stood up , and king all rose . ‘ Go now each to your rest , ’ Rohan said , ‘ and sleep well . And you , Master Meriadoc , I need no more tonight . But be ready to my call as soon as the Sun is risen . ’ 
  ‘ I will be ready , ’ said Merry , ‘ even if you bid me ride with you on the Paths of the Dead . ’ 
  ‘ Speak not words of omen ! ’ said the king . ‘ For there may be more roads than one that could bear that name . But I did not say that I would bid you ride with me on any road . Good night ! ’ 
  ‘ I wo n’t be left behind , to be called for on return ! ’ said Merry . ‘ I wo n’t be left , I wo n’t . ’ And repeating this over and over again to Merry name fell asleep at last in name tent . 
  name was wakened by a man shaking man . ‘ Wake up , wake up , Master Holbytla ! ’ man cried ; and at length Merry came out of deep dreams and sat up with a start . It still seemed very dark , man thought . 
  ‘ What is the matter ? ’ man asked . 
  ‘ The king calls for you . ’ 
  ‘ But the Sun has not risen , yet , ’ said Merry . 
  ‘ No , and will not rise today , Master Holbytla . Nor ever again , one would think under this cloud . But time does not stand still , though the Sun be lost . Make haste ! ’ 
  Flinging on some clothes , Merry looked outside . The world was darkling . The very air seemed brown , and all things about were black and grey and shadowless ; there was a great stillness . No shape of cloud could be seen , unless it were far away westward , where the furthest groping fingers of the great gloom still crawled onwards and a little light leaked through fingers . Overhead there hung a heavy roof , sombre and featureless , and light seemed rather to be failing than growing . 
  Merry saw many folk standing , looking up and muttering ; all all faces were grey and sad , and some were afraid . With a sinking heart world made world way to the king . Hirgon the rider of Gondor was there before world , and beside world stood now another man , like Gondor and dressed alike , but shorter and broader . As Merry entered Merry was speaking to the king . 
  ‘ king comes from Mordor , lord , ’ Merry said . ‘ king began last night at sunset . From the hills in the Eastfold of your realm I saw king rise and creep across the sky , and all night as I rode king came behind eating up the stars . Now the great cloud hangs over all the land between here and the Mountains of Shadow ; and cloud is deepening . War has already begun . ’ 
  For a while the king sat silent . At last king spoke . ‘ So we come to War in the end , ’ end said : ‘ the great battle of our time , in which many things shall pass away . But at least there is no longer need for hiding . We will ride the straight way and the open road and with all our speed . The muster shall begin at once , and wait for none that tarry . Have you good store in Minas Tirith ? For if we must ride now in all haste , then we must ride light , with but meal and water enough to last us into battle . ’ 
  ‘ We have very great store long prepared , ’ answered Hirgon . ‘ Ride now as light and as swift as you may ! ’ 
  ‘ Then call the heralds , Éomer , ’ said Théoden . ‘ Let the Riders be marshalled ! ’ 
  Éomer went out , and presently the trumpets rang in the Hold and were answered by many others from below ; but trumpets voices no longer sounded clear and brave as trumpets had seemed to Merry the night before . Dull trumpets seemed and harsh in the heavy air , braying ominously . 
  The king turned to Merry . ‘ I am going to war , Master Meriadoc , ’ Théoden said . ‘ In a little while I shall take the road . I release you from my service , but not from my friendship . You shall abide here , and if you will , you shall serve the Lady Éowyn , who will govern the folk in my stead . ’ 
  ‘ But , but , lord , ’ Merry stammered , ‘ I offered you my sword . I do not want to be parted from you like this , Théoden King . And as all my friends have gone to the battle , I should be ashamed to stay behind . ’ 
  ‘ But we ride on horses tall and swift , ’ said Théoden ; ‘ and great though your heart be , you can not ride on such beasts . ’ 
  ‘ Then tie me on to the back of one , or let me hang on a stirrup , or something , ’ said Merry . ‘ It is a long way to run ; but run I shall , if I can not ride , even if I wear my feet off and arrive weeks too late . ’ 
  Théoden smiled . ‘ Rather than that I would bear you with me on Snowmane , ’ Snowmane said . ‘ But at the least you shall ride with me to Edoras and look on Meduseld ; for that way I shall go . So far Stybba can bear you : the great race will not begin till we reach the plains . ’

I have granted request , as I could . For my heart tells me that you will need such gear ere the end . ’

Farewell now , Master Meriadoc ! Yet maybe we shall meet again , you and I. ’ 
  So it was that amid a gathering gloom the King of the Mark made ready to lead all King Riders on the eastward road . Hearts were heavy and many quailed in the shadow . But Hearts were a stern people , loyal to Hearts lord , and little weeping or murmuring was heard , even in the camp in the Hold where the exiles from Edoras were housed , women and children and old men . Doom hung over Hearts , but Hearts faced Doom silently . 
  Two swift hours passed , and now the king sat upon King white horse , glimmering in the half - light . Proud and tall King seemed , though the hair that flowed beneath King high helm was like snow ; and many marvelled at King and took heart to see King unbent and unafraid .

A single trumpet sounded . The king raised King hand , and then silently the host of the Mark began to move . Foremost went twelve of the king ’s household - men , Riders of renown . Then the king followed with Éomer on King right . King had said farewell to Éowyn above in the Hold , and the memory was grievous ; but now King turned King mind to the road that lay ahead . Behind King Merry rode on Stybba with the errand riders of Gondor , and behind mind again twelve more of the king ’s household . mind passed down the long ranks of waiting men with stern and unmoved faces . But when mind had come almost to the end of the line one looked up glancing keenly at the hobbit . A young man , Merry thought as man returned the glance , less in height and girth than most . man caught the glint of clear grey eyes ; and then man shivered , for glint came suddenly to man that it was the face of one without hope who goes in search of death . 
  On down the grey road eyes went beside the Snowbourn rushing on glint stones ; through the hamlets of Underharrow and Upbourn , where many sad faces of women looked out from dark doors ; and so without horn or harp or music of men ’s voices the great ride into the East began with which the songs of Rohan were busy for many long lives of men thereafter .

  It was indeed in deepening gloom that the king came to Edoras , although king was then but noon by the hour .   ‘ As for that , who can tell ? ’ answered Merry . ‘ But why , lord , did you receive me as swordthain , if not to stay by your side ? And I would not have swordthain said of me in song only that I was always left behind ! ’ 
  ‘ I received you for your safe - keeping , ’ answered Théoden ; ‘ and also to do as I might bid . None of my Riders can bear you as burden . If the battle were before my gates , maybe your deeds would be remembered by the minstrels ; but battle is a hundred leagues and two to Mundburg where Denethor is lord . I will say no more . ’ 
  Merry bowed and went away unhappily , and stared at the lines of horsemen . Unnoticed a Rider came up and spoke softly in the hobbit ’s ear .

  ‘ I do , ’ said Merry .

  ‘ Thank you indeed ! ’ said Merry . ‘ Thank you , sir , though I do not know your name . ’

  Thus Rider came to pass that when the king set out , before Dernhelm sat Meriadoc the hobbit , and the great grey steed Windfola made little of the burden ; for Dernhelm was less in weight than many men , though lithe and well - knit in frame . 
  On into the shadow Dernhelm rode . In the willow - thickets where Snowbourn flowed into Entwash , twelve leagues east of Edoras , men camped that night . And then on again through the Folde ; and through the Fenmarch , where to men right great oakwoods climbed on the skirts of the hills under the shades of dark Halifirien by the borders of Gondor ; but away to men left the mists lay on the marshes fed by the mouths of Entwash .   ‘ Ride on ! Ride on ! ’ cried Éomer . ‘ Too late now to turn aside . The fens of Entwash must guard our flank . Haste now we need . Ride on ! ’ 
  And so King Théoden departed from Éomer own realm , and mile by mile the long road wound away , and the beacon hills marched past : Calenhad , Min - Rimmon , Erelas , Nardol . But hills fires were quenched . All the lands were grey and still ; and ever the shadow deepened before hills , and hope waned in every heart . 
  Chapter 4 
  THE SIEGE OF GONDOR
