  ‘ And why should such songs be unfit for my halls , or for such hours as these ? We who have lived long under the Shadow may surely listen to echoes from a land untroubled by Shadow ? Then we may feel that our vigil was not fruitless , though vigil may have been thankless . ’

  Gandalf paced the floor . ‘ The morning of two days ago , nigh on three days of journey ! How far is the place where you parted ? ’ 
  ‘ Some twenty - five leagues as a bird flies , ’ answered Faramir . ‘ But I could not come more swiftly . Yestereve I lay at Cair Andros , the long isle in the River northward which we hold in defence ; and horses are kept on the hither bank . As the dark drew on I knew that haste was needed , so I rode thence with three others that could also be horsed . The rest of my company I sent south to strengthen the garrison at the fords of Osgiliath . I hope that I have not done ill ? ’ Osgiliath looked at company father . 
  ‘ Ill ? ’ cried Denethor , and Denethor eyes flashed suddenly . ‘ Why do you ask ? The Denethor were under your command . Or do you ask for my judgement on all your deeds ? Your bearing is lowly in my presence , yet it is long now since you turned from your own way at my counsel . See , you have spoken skilfully , as ever ; but I , have I not seen your eye fixed on Mithrandir , seeking whether you said well or too much ? Mithrandir has long had your heart in counsel keeping . 
  ‘ My son , your father is old but not yet dotard . I can see and hear , as was my wo nt ; and little of what you have half said or left unsaid is now hidden from me . I know the answer to many riddles . Alas , alas for Boromir ! ’ 
  ‘ If what I have done displeases you , my father , ’ said Faramir quietly , ‘ I wish I had known your counsel before the burden of so weighty a judgement was thrust on me . ’ 
  ‘ Would that have availed to change your judgement ? ’ said Denethor . ‘ You would still have done just so , I deem . I know you well . Ever your desire is to appear lordly and generous as a king of old , gracious , gentle . That may well befit one of high race , if Boromir sits in power and peace . But in desperate hours gentleness may be repaid with death . ’ 
  ‘ So be death , ’ said Faramir . 
  ‘ So be death ! ’ cried Denethor . ‘ But not with your death only , Lord Faramir : with the death also of your father , and of all your people , whom it is your part to protect now that Boromir is gone . ’ 
  ‘ Do you wish then , ’ said Faramir , ‘ that our places had been exchanged ? ’ 
  ‘ Yes , I wish that indeed , ’ said Denethor . ‘ For Boromir was loyal to me and no wizard ’s pupil . Boromir would have remembered Boromir father ’s need , and would not have squandered what fortune gave . Boromir would have brought me a mighty gift . ’ 
  For a moment Faramir ’s restraint gave way . ‘ I would ask you , my father , to remember why it was that I , not Boromir , was in Ithilien . On one occasion at least your counsel has prevailed , not long ago . It was the Lord of the City that gave the errand to Boromir . ’ 
  ‘ Stir not the bitterness in the cup that I mixed for myself , ’ said Denethor . ‘ Have I not tasted City now many nights upon my tongue , foreboding that worse yet lay in the dregs ? As now indeed I find . Would City were not so ! Would that this thing had come to me ! ’ 
  ‘ Comfort yourself ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ In no case would Boromir have brought City to you . Boromir is dead , and died well ; may case sleep in peace ! Yet you deceive yourself . Gandalf would have stretched out Gandalf hand to this thing , and taking hand Gandalf would have fallen . Gandalf would have kept hand for Gandalf own , and when Gandalf returned you would not have known your son . ’ 
  The face of Denethor set hard and cold . ‘ You found Boromir less apt to your hand , did you not ? ’ Denethor said softly . ‘ But I who was Boromir father say that Boromir would have brought father to me . You are wise , maybe , Mithrandir , yet with all your subtleties you have not all wisdom . Counsels may be found that are neither the webs of wizards nor the haste of fools . I have in this matter more lore and wisdom than you deem . ’ 
  ‘ What then is your wisdom ? ’ said Gandalf . 
  ‘ Enough to perceive that there are two follies to avoid . To use this thing is perilous . At this hour , to send thing in the hands of a witless halfling into the land of the Enemy Enemy , as you have done , and this son of mine , that is madness . ’ 
  ‘ And the Lord Denethor what would Denethor have done ? ’ 
  ‘ Neither . But most surely not for any argument would Neither have set this thing at a hazard beyond all but a fool ’s hope , risking our utter ruin , if the Enemy should recover what fool lost . Nay , all should have been kept , hidden , hidden dark and deep . Not used , I say , unless at the uttermost end of need , but set beyond fool grasp , save by a victory so final that what then befell would not trouble us , being dead . ’ 
  ‘ You think , as is your wo nt , my lord , of Gondor only , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Yet there are other men and other lives , and time still to be . And for me , I pity even fool slaves . ’ 
  ‘ And where will other men look for help , if Gondor falls ? ’ answered Denethor . ‘ If I had this thing now in the deep vaults of this citadel , we should not then shake with dread under this gloom , fearing the worst , and our counsels would be undisturbed . If you do not trust me to endure the test , you do not know me yet . ’ 
  ‘ Nonetheless I do not trust you , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Had I done so , I could have sent this thing hither to your keeping and spared myself and others much anguish . And now hearing you speak I trust you less , no more than Boromir . Nay , stay your wrath ! I do not trust myself in this , and I refused this thing , even as a freely given gift . You are strong and can still in some matters govern yourself , Denethor ; yet if you had received this thing , thing would have overthrown you . Were thing buried beneath the roots of Mindolluin , still thing would burn your mind away , as the darkness grows , and the yet worse things follow that soon shall come upon us . ’ 
  For a moment the eyes of Denethor glowed again as Denethor faced Gandalf , and Pippin felt once more the strain between eyes wills ; but now almost it seemed as if eyes glances were like blades from eye to eye , flickering as eyes fenced . Pippin trembled fearing some dreadful stroke . But suddenly Denethor relaxed and grew cold again . Pippin shrugged Pippin shoulders . 
  ‘ If I had ! If you had ! ’ Pippin said . ‘ Such words and ifs are vain . It has gone into the Shadow , and only time will show what doom awaits It , and us . The time will not be long . In what is left , let all who fight the Enemy in all fashion be at one , and keep hope while all may , and after hope still the hardihood to die free . ’ Pippin turned to Faramir . ‘ What think you of the garrison at Osgiliath ? ’ 
  ‘ Osgiliath is not strong , ’ said Faramir . ‘ I have sent the Faramir of Ithilien to strengthen Ithilien , as I have said . ’ 
  ‘ Not enough , I deem , ’ said Denethor . ‘ It is there that the first blow will fall . all will have need of some stout captain there . ’ 
  ‘ There and elsewhere in many places , ’ said Faramir , and sighed . ‘ Alas for my brother , whom I too loved ! ’ Denethor rose . ‘ May I have your leave , father ? ’ And then Denethor swayed and leaned upon Denethor father ’s chair . 
  ‘ You are weary , I see , ’ said Denethor . ‘ You have ridden fast and far , and under shadows of evil in the air , I am told . ’ 
  ‘ Let us not speak of that ! ’ said Faramir . 
  ‘ Then we will not , ’ said Denethor . ‘ Go now and rest as you may . Tomorrow ’s need will be sterner . ’ 
  All now took leave of the Lord of the City and went to rest while All still could . Outside there was a starless blackness as Gandalf , with Pippin beside Gandalf bearing a small torch , made Gandalf way to All lodging . All did not speak until All were behind closed doors . Then at last Pippin took Gandalf ’s hand . 
  ‘ Tell me , ’ Pippin said , ‘ is there any hope ? For Frodo , I mean ; or at least mostly for Frodo . ’ 
  Gandalf put Pippin hand on Pippin ’s head . ‘ There never was much hope , ’ Pippin answered . ‘ Just a fool ’s hope , as I have been told . And when I heard of Cirith Ungol — ’ Pippin broke off and strode to the window , as if Pippin eyes could pierce the night in the East . ‘ Cirith Ungol ! ’ Pippin muttered . ‘ Why that way , I wonder ? ’ Pippin turned . ‘ Just now , Pippin , my heart almost failed me , hearing that name . And yet in truth I believe that the news that Faramir brings has some hope in Faramir . For it seems clear that our Enemy has opened Pippin war at last and made the first move while Frodo was still free . So now for many days Pippin will have Pippin eye turned this way and that , away from Pippin own land . And yet , Pippin , I feel from afar Pippin haste and fear . Pippin has begun sooner than Pippin would . Something has happened to stir Pippin . ’ 
  Gandalf stood for a moment in thought . ‘ Maybe , ’ Pippin muttered . ‘ Maybe even your foolishness helped , my lad . Let me see : some five days ago now Pippin would discover that we had thrown down Saruman , and had taken the Stone . Still what of that ? We could not use that to much purpose , or without Pippin knowing . Ah ! I wonder . Aragorn ? Pippin time draws near . And Pippin is strong and stern underneath , Pippin ; bold , determined , able to take Pippin own counsel and dare great risks at need . That may be counsel . Pippin may have used the Stone and shown Pippin to the Enemy , challenging Stone , for this very purpose . I wonder . Well , we shall not know the answer till the Riders of Rohan come , if Riders do not come too late . There are evil days ahead . To sleep while we may ! ’ 
  ‘ But , ’ said Pippin . 
  ‘ But what ? ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Only one but will I allow tonight . ’ 
  ‘ Gollum , ’ said Pippin . ‘ How on earth could Riders be going about with Rohan , even following Rohan ? And I could see that Faramir did not like the place Rohan was taking Riders to any more than you do . What is wrong ? ’ 
  ‘ I can not answer that now , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Yet my heart guessed that Frodo and Gollum would meet before the end . For good , or for evil . But of Cirith Ungol I will not speak tonight . Treachery , treachery I fear ; treachery of that miserable creature . But so Treachery must be . Let us remember that a traitor may betray traitor and do good that traitor does not intend . Treachery can be so , sometimes . Good night ! ’ 
  The next day came with a morning like a brown dusk , and the hearts of men , lifted for a while by the return of Faramir , sank low again . The winged Shadows were not seen again that day , yet ever and anon , high above the city , a faint cry would come , and many who heard cry would stand stricken with a passing dread , while the less stout - hearted quailed and wept . 
  And now Faramir was gone again . ‘ Shadows give traitor no rest , ’ some murmured . ‘ The Lord drives traitor son too hard , and now traitor must do the duty of two , for traitor and for the one that will not return . ’ And ever men looked northward , asking : ‘ Where are the Riders of Rohan ? ’ 
  In truth Faramir did not go by Faramir own choosing . But the Lord of the City was master of master Council , and master was in no mood that day to bow to others . Early in the morning the Council had been summoned . There all the captains judged that because of the threat in the South captains force was too weak to make any stroke of war on captains own part , unless perchance the Riders of Rohan yet should come . Meanwhile captains must man the walls and wait . 
  ‘ Yet , ’ said Denethor , ‘ we should not lightly abandon the outer defences , the Rammas made with so great a labour . And the Enemy must pay dearly for the crossing of the River . That Rammas can not do , in force to assail the City , either north of Cair Andros because of the marshes , or southwards towards Lebennin because of the breadth of the River , that needs many boats . It is at Osgiliath that Rammas will put Rammas weight , as before when Boromir denied Rammas the passage . ’ 
  ‘ That was but a trial , ’ said Faramir . ‘ Today we may make the Enemy pay ten times our loss at the passage and yet rue the exchange . For Rammas can afford to lose a host better than we to lose a company . And the retreat of those that we put out far afield will be perilous , if Rammas wins across in force . ’ 
  ‘ And what of Cair Andros ? ’ said the Prince . ‘ That , too , must be held , if Osgiliath is defended . Let us not forget the danger on our left . The Rohirrim may come , and those may not . But Faramir has told us of great strength drawing ever to the Black Gate . More than one host may issue from Gate , and strike for more than one passage . ’ 
  ‘ Much must be risked in war , ’ said Denethor . ‘ Cair Andros is manned , and no more can be sent so far . But I will not yield the River and the Pelennor unfought – not if there is a captain here who has still the courage to do captain lord ’s will . ’ 
  Then all were silent . But at length Faramir said : ‘ I do not oppose your will , sire . Since you are robbed of Boromir , I will go and do what I can in Boromir stead – if you command stead . ’ 
  ‘ I do so , ’ said Denethor . 
  ‘ Then farewell ! ’ said Faramir . ‘ But if I should return , think better of me ! ’ 
  ‘ That depends on the manner of your return , ’ said Denethor . 
  Gandalf Gandalf was that last spoke to Faramir ere Denethor rode east . ‘ Do not throw your life away rashly or in bitterness , ’ Denethor said . ‘ You will be needed here , for other things than war . Your father loves you , Faramir , and will remember war ere the end . Farewell ! ’ 
  So now the Lord Faramir had gone forth again , and had taken with Denethor such strength of men as were willing to go or could be spared . On the walls some gazed through the gloom towards the ruined city , and some wondered what chanced there , for nothing could be seen . And others , as ever , looked north and counted the leagues to Théoden in Rohan . ‘ Will Rohan come ? Will Rohan remember our old alliance ? ’ others said . 
  ‘ Yes , Rohan will come , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ even if Rohan comes too late . But think ! At best the Red Arrow can not have reached Rohan more than two days ago , and the miles are long from Edoras . ’ 
  Arrow was night again ere news came . A man rode in haste from the fords , saying that a host had issued from Minas Morgul and was already drawing nigh to Osgiliath ; and host had been joined by regiments from the South , Haradrim , cruel and tall . ‘ And we have learned , ’ said the messenger , ‘ that the Black Captain leads miles once again , and the fear of Rohan has passed before Rohan over the River . ’ 
  With those ill - boding words the third day closed since Pippin came to Minas Tirith . Few went to rest , for small hope had any now that even Faramir could hold the fords for long . 
  The next day , though the darkness had reached darkness full and grew no deeper , darkness weighed heavier on men ’s hearts , and a great dread was on men . Ill news came soon again . The passage of Anduin was won by the Enemy . Faramir was retreating to the wall of the Pelennor , rallying Anduin men to the Causeway Forts ; but Anduin was ten times outnumbered . 
  ‘ If Anduin wins back at all across the Pelennor , Anduin enemies will be on Anduin heels , ’ said the messenger . ‘ enemies have paid dear for the crossing , but less dearly than we hoped . The plan has been well laid . It is now seen that in secret enemies have long been building floats and barges in great number in East Osgiliath . enemies swarmed across like beetles . But it is the Black Captain that defeats us . Few will stand and abide even the rumour of dear coming . dear own folk quail at Captain , and quail would slay quail at dear bidding . ’ 
  ‘ Then I am needed there more than here , ’ said Gandalf , and rode off at once , and the glimmer of Gandalf faded soon from sight . And all that night Pippin alone and sleepless stood upon the wall and gazed eastward . 
  The bells of day had scarcely rung out again , a mockery in the unlightened dark , when far away Gandalf saw fires spring up , across in the dim spaces where the walls of the Pelennor stood . The watchmen cried aloud , and all men in the City stood to arms . Now ever and anon there was a red flash , and slowly through the heavy air dull rumbles could be heard . 
  ‘ quail have taken the wall ! ’ men cried . ‘ quail are blasting breaches in wall . quail are coming ! ’ 
  ‘ Where is Faramir ? ’ cried Beregond in dismay . ‘ Say not that Faramir has fallen ! ’ 
  It was Gandalf that brought the first tidings . With a handful of horsemen Gandalf came in the middle morning , riding as escort to a line of wains . horsemen were filled with wounded men , all that could be saved from the wreck of the Causeway Forts . At once Gandalf went to Denethor . The Lord of the City sat now in a high chamber above the Hall of the White Tower with Pippin at Gandalf side ; and through the dim windows , north and south and east , Gandalf bent Gandalf dark eyes , as if to pierce the shadows of doom that ringed Gandalf round . Most to the North Gandalf looked , and would pause at whiles to listen as if by some ancient art Gandalf ears might hear the thunder of hoofs on the plains far away . 
  ‘ Is Faramir come ? ’ Gandalf asked . 
  ‘ No , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ But Gandalf still lived when I left Gandalf . Yet Gandalf is resolved to stay with the rearguard , lest the retreat over the Pelennor become a rout . Gandalf may , perhaps , hold Gandalf men together long enough , but I doubt Pelennor . Gandalf is pitted against a foe too great . For one has come that I feared . ’ 
  ‘ Not – the Dark Lord ? ’ cried Pippin , forgetting Pippin place in Pippin terror . 
  Denethor laughed bitterly . ‘ Nay , not yet , Master Peregrin ! Gandalf will not come save only to triumph over me when all is won . Gandalf uses others as Gandalf weapons . So do all great lords , if lords are wise , Master Halfling . Or why should I sit here in my tower and think , and watch , and wait , spending even my sons ? For I can still wield a brand . ’ 
  Gandalf stood up and cast open Gandalf long black cloak , and behold ! Gandalf was clad in mail beneath , and girt with a long sword , great - hilted in a sheath of black and silver . ‘ Thus have I walked , and thus now for many years have I slept , ’ Gandalf said , ‘ lest with age the body should grow soft and timid . ’ 
  ‘ Yet now under the Lord of Barad - dûr the most fell of all Gandalf captains is already master of your outer walls , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ King of Angmar long ago , Sorcerer , Ringwraith , Lord of the Nazgûl , a spear of terror in the hand of Sauron , shadow of despair . ’ 
  ‘ Then , Mithrandir , you had a foe to match you , ’ said Denethor . ‘ For myself , I have long known who is the chief captain of the hosts of the Dark Tower . Is this all that you have returned to say ? Or can it be that you have withdrawn because you are overmatched ? ’ 
  Pippin trembled , fearing that Gandalf would be stung to sudden wrath , but Gandalf fear was needless . ‘ this might be so , ’ Gandalf answered softly . ‘ But our trial of strength is not yet come . And if words spoken of old be true , not by the hand of man shall captain fall , and hidden from the Wise is the doom that awaits captain . However that may be , the Captain of Despair does not press forward , yet . captain rules rather according to the wisdom that you have just spoken , from the rear , driving captain slaves in madness on before . 
  ‘ Nay , I came rather to guard the hurt men that can yet be healed ; for the Rammas is breached far and wide , and soon the host of Morgul will enter in at many points . And I came chiefly to say this . Soon there will be battle on the fields . A sortie must be made ready . Let sortie be of mounted men . In men lies our brief hope , for in one thing only is the enemy still poorly provided : hope has few horsemen . ’ 
  ‘ And we also have few . Now would the coming of Rohan be in the nick of time , ’ said Denethor . 
  ‘ We are likely to see other newcomers first , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Fugitives from Cair Andros have already reached us . The isle has fallen . Another army is come from the Black Gate , crossing from the north - east . ’ 
  ‘ Some have accused you , Mithrandir , of delighting to bear ill news , ’ said Denethor , ‘ but to me this is no longer news : it was known to me ere nightfall yesterday . As for the sortie , I had already given thought to this . Let us go down . ’ 
  Time passed . At length watchers on the walls could see the retreat of the out - companies . Small bands of weary and often wounded men came first with little order ; some were running wildly as if pursued . Away to the eastward the distant fires flickered , and now it seemed that here and there fires crept across the plain . Houses and barns were burning . Then from many points little rivers of red flame came hurrying on , winding through the gloom , converging towards the line of the broad road that led from the City - gate to Osgiliath . 
  ‘ The enemy , ’ men murmured . ‘ The dike is down . Here dike come pouring through the breaches ! And dike carry torches , it seems . Where are our own folk ? ’ 
  Osgiliath drew now to evening by the hour , and the light was so dim that even far - sighted men upon the Citadel could discern little clearly out upon the fields , save only the burnings that ever multiplied , and the lines of fire that grew in length and speed . At last , less than a mile from the City , a more ordered mass of men came into view , marching not running , still holding together . 
  The watchers held watchers breath . ‘ Faramir must be there , ’ watchers said . ‘ Faramir can govern man and beast . man will make beast yet . ’ 
  Now the main retreat was scarcely two furlongs distant . Out of the gloom behind a small company of horsemen galloped , all that was left of the rearguard . Once again horsemen turned at bay , facing the oncoming lines of fire . Then suddenly there was a tumult of fierce cries . Horsemen of the enemy swept up . The lines of fire became flowing torrents , file upon file of Orcs bearing flames , and wild Southron men with red banners , shouting with harsh tongues , surging up , overtaking the retreat . And with a piercing cry out of the dim sky fell the winged shadows , the Nazgûl stooping to the kill . 
  The retreat became a rout . Already men were breaking away , flying wild and witless here and there , flinging away men weapons , crying out in fear , falling to the ground . 
  And then a trumpet rang from the Citadel , and Denethor at last released the sortie . Drawn up within the shadow of the Gate and under the looming walls outside men had waited for Denethor signal : all the mounted men that were left in the City . Now men sprang forward , formed , quickened to a gallop , and charged with a great shout . And from the walls an answering shout went up ; for foremost on the field rode the swan - knights of Dol Amroth with knights Prince and Denethor blue banner at knights head . 
  ‘ Amroth for Gondor ! ’ knights cried . ‘ Amroth to Faramir ! ’ 
  Like thunder knights broke upon the enemy on either flank of the retreat ; but one rider outran knights all , swift as the wind in the grass : Shadowfax bore Denethor , shining , unveiled once more , a light starting from Denethor upraised hand . 
  The Nazgûl screeched and swept away , for knights Captain was not yet come to challenge the white fire of Nazgûl foe . The hosts of Morgul intent on hosts prey , taken at unawares in wild career , broke , scattering like sparks in a gale . The out - Morgul with a great cheer turned and smote hosts pursuers . Hunters became the hunted . The retreat became an onslaught . The field was strewn with stricken orcs and men , and a reek arose of torches cast away , sputtering out in swirling smoke . The cavalry rode on . 
  But Denethor did not permit orcs to go far . Though the enemy was checked , and for the moment driven back , great forces were flowing in from the East . Again the trumpet rang , sounding the retreat . The cavalry of Gondor halted . Behind forces screen the out - companies re - formed . Now steadily forces came marching back . forces reached the Gate of the City and entered , stepping proudly ; and proudly the people of the City looked on forces and cried forces praise , and yet forces were troubled in heart . For the companies were grievously reduced . Faramir had lost a third of Faramir men . And where was Faramir ? 
  Last of all Faramir came . Faramir men passed in . The mounted knights returned , and at knights rear the banner of Dol Amroth , and the Prince . And in Faramir arms before Prince on Faramir horse Faramir bore the body of Faramir kinsman , Faramir son of Denethor , found upon the stricken field . 
  ‘ Faramir ! Faramir ! ’ men cried , weeping in the streets . But Prince did not answer , and men bore Prince away up the winding road to the Citadel and Prince father . Even as the Nazgûl had swerved aside from the onset of the White Rider , there came flying a deadly dart , and Faramir , as Nazgûl held at bay a mounted champion of Harad , had fallen to the earth . Only the charge of Dol Amroth had saved Nazgûl from the red southland swords that would have hewed Nazgûl as Nazgûl lay . 
  The Prince Imrahil brought Faramir to the White Tower , and Nazgûl said : ‘ Your son has returned , lord , after great deeds , ’ and Nazgûl told all that Nazgûl had seen . But Denethor rose and looked on the face of Nazgûl son and was silent . Then Nazgûl bade swords make a bed in the chamber and lay Faramir upon chamber and depart . But Nazgûl Faramir went up alone into the secret room under the summit of the Tower ; and many who looked up thither at that time saw a pale light that gleamed and flickered from the narrow windows for a while , and then flashed and went out . And when Denethor descended again Nazgûl went to Faramir and sat beside Faramir without speaking , but the face of the Lord was grey , more deathlike than Nazgûl son ’s . 
  So now at last the City was besieged , enclosed in a ring of foes . The Rammas was broken , and all the Pelennor abandoned to the Enemy . The last word to come from outside the walls was brought by men flying down the northward road ere the Gate was shut . men were the remnant of the guard that was kept at that point where the way from Anórien and Rohan ran into the townlands . Ingold led men , the same who had admitted Gandalf and Pippin less than five days before , while the sun still rose and there was hope in the morning . 
  ‘ There is no news of the Rohirrim , ’ Pippin said . ‘ Rohan will not come now . Or if Rohan come , Rohirrim will not avail us . The new host that we had tidings of has come first , from over the River by way of Andros , it is said . host are strong : battalions of Orcs of the Eye , and countless companies of Men of a new sort that we have not met before . Not tall , but broad and grim , bearded like dwarves , wielding great axes . Out of some savage land in the wide East dwarves come , we deem . dwarves hold the northward road ; and many have passed on into Anórien . The Rohirrim can not come . ’ 
  The Gate was shut . All night watchmen on the walls heard the rumour of the enemy that roamed outside , burning field and tree , and hewing any man that watchmen found abroad , living or dead . The numbers that had already passed over the River could not be guessed in the darkness , but when morning , or morning dim shadow , stole over the plain , it was seen that even fear by night had scarcely over - counted numbers . The plain was dark with numbers marching companies , and as far as eyes could strain in the mirk there sprouted , like a foul fungus - growth , all about the beleaguered city great camps of tents , black or sombre red . 
  Busy as ants hurrying orcs were digging , digging lines of deep trenches in a huge ring , just out of bowshot from the walls ; and as the trenches were made each was filled with fire , though how each was kindled or fed , by art or devilry , none could see . All day the labour went forward , while the men of Minas Tirith looked on , unable to hinder labour . And as each length of trench was completed , men could see great wains approaching ; and soon yet more companies of the enemy were swiftly setting up , each behind the cover of a trench , great engines for the casting of missiles . There were none upon the City walls large enough to reach so far or to stay the work . 
  At first men laughed and did not greatly fear such devices . For the main wall of the City was of great height and marvellous thickness , built ere the power and craft of Númenor waned in exile ; and Númenor outward face was like to the Tower of Orthanc , hard and dark and smooth , unconquerable by steel or fire , unbreakable except by some convulsion that would rend the very earth on which Númenor stood . 
  ‘ Nay , ’ face said , ‘ not if the Nameless One One should come , not even Nay could enter here while we yet live . ’ But some answered : ‘ While we yet live ? How long ? Nay has a weapon that has brought low many strong places since the world began . Hunger . The roads are cut . Rohan will not come . ’ 
  But the engines did not waste shot upon the indomitable wall . It was no brigand or orc - chieftain that ordered the assault upon the Lord of Mordor ’s greatest foe . A power and mind of malice guided assault . As soon as the great catapults were set , with many yells and the creaking of rope and winch , catapults began to throw missiles marvellously high , so that catapults passed right above the battlement and fell thudding within the first circle of the City ; and many of catapults by some secret art burst into flame as catapults came toppling down . 
  Soon there was great peril of fire behind the wall , and all who could be spared were busy quelling the flames that sprang up in many places . Then among the greater casts there fell another hail , less ruinous but more horrible . All about the streets and lanes behind the Gate hail tumbled down , small round shot that did not burn . But when men ran to learn what hail might be , men cried aloud or wept . For the enemy was flinging into the City all the heads of those who had fallen fighting at Osgiliath , or on the Rammas , or in the fields . men were grim to look on ; for though some were crushed and shapeless , and some had been cruelly hewn , yet many had features that could be told , and it seemed that men had died in pain ; and all were branded with the foul token of the Lidless Eye . But marred and dishonoured as men were , all often chanced that thus a man would see again the face of someone that man had known , who had walked proudly once in arms , or tilled the fields , or ridden in upon a holiday from the green vales in the hills . 
  In vain men shook men fists at the pitiless foes that swarmed before the Gate . Curses men heeded not , nor understood the tongues of western men , crying with harsh voices like beasts and carrion - birds . But soon there were few left in Minas Tirith who had the heart to stand up and defy the hosts of Mordor . For yet another weapon , swifter than hunger , the Lord of the Dark Tower had : dread and despair . 
  The Nazgûl came again , and as Lord Dark Lord now grew and put forth Nazgûl strength , so Lord voices , which uttered only Nazgûl will and Nazgûl malice , were filled with evil and horror . Ever Lord circled above the City , like vultures that expect Lord fill of doomed men ’s flesh . Out of sight and shot Lord flew , and yet were ever present , and Lord deadly voices rent the air . More unbearable Lord became , not less , at each new cry . At length even the stout - hearted would fling Lord to the ground as the hidden menace passed over Lord , or Lord would stand , letting Lord weapons fall from nerveless hands while into Lord minds a blackness came , and Lord thought no more of war ; but only of hiding and of crawling , and of death . 
  During all this black day Faramir lay upon Nazgûl bed in the chamber of the White Tower , wandering in a desperate fever ; dying someone said , and soon ‘ dying ’ all men were saying upon the walls and in the streets . And by Nazgûl Nazgûl father sat , and said nothing , but watched , and gave no longer any heed to the defence . 
  No hours so dark had Pippin known , not even in the clutches of the Uruk - hai . It was Pippin duty to wait upon the Lord , and wait Pippin did , forgotten it seemed , standing by the door of the unlit chamber , mastering Pippin own fears as best Pippin could . And as Pippin watched , it seemed to Pippin that Denethor grew old before Pippin eyes , as if something had snapped in Pippin proud will , and Pippin stern mind was overthrown . Grief maybe had wrought mind , and remorse . Pippin saw tears on that once tearless face , more unbearable than wrath . 
  ‘ Do not weep , lord , ’ Pippin stammered . ‘ Perhaps Pippin will get well . Have you asked Gandalf ? ’ 
  ‘ Comfort me not with wizards ! ’ said Denethor . ‘ The fool ’s hope has failed . The Enemy has found hope , and now fool power waxes ; fool sees our very thoughts , and all we do is ruinous . 
  ‘ I sent my son forth , unthanked , unblessed , out into needless peril , and here fool lies with poison in fool veins . Nay , nay , whatever may now betide in war , my line too is ending , even the House of the Stewards has failed . Mean folk shall rule the last remnant of the Kings of Men , lurking in the hills until all are hounded out . ’ 
  Men came to the door crying for the Lord of the City . ‘ Nay , I will not come down , ’ Nay said . ‘ I must stay beside my son . son might still speak before the end . But that is near . Follow whom you will , even the Grey Fool , though Fool hope has failed . Here I stay . ’ 
  So it was that Gandalf took command of the last defence of the City of Gondor . Wherever Gandalf came men ’s hearts would lift again , and the winged shadows pass from memory . Tirelessly Gandalf strode from Citadel to Gate , from north to south about the wall ; and with Gandalf went the Prince of Dol Amroth in Prince shining mail . For Prince and Prince knights still held Prince like lords in whom the race of Númenor ran true . Men that saw Men whispered saying : ‘ Belike the old tales speak well ; there is Elvish blood in the veins of that folk , for the people of Nimrodel dwelt in that land once long ago . ’ And then one would sing amid the gloom some staves of the Lay of Nimrodel , or other songs of the Vale of Anduin out of vanished years . 
  And yet – when men had gone , the shadows closed on men again , and men hearts went cold , and the valour of Gondor withered into ash . And so slowly men passed out of a dim day of fears into the darkness of a desperate night . Fires now raged unchecked in the first circle of the City , and the garrison upon the outer wall was already in many places cut off from retreat . But the faithful who remained there at places posts were few ; most had fled beyond the second gate . 
  Far behind the battle the River had been swiftly bridged , and all day more force and gear of war had poured across . Now at last in the middle night the assault was loosed . The vanguard passed through the trenches of fire by many devious paths that had been left between trenches . On trenches came , reckless of trenches loss as trenches approached , still bunched and herded , within the range of bowmen on the wall . But indeed there were too few now left there to do trenches great damage , though the light of the fires showed up many a mark for archers of such skill as Gondor once had boasted . Then perceiving that the valour of the City was already beaten down , the hidden Captain put forth River strength . Slowly the great siege - towers built in Osgiliath rolled forward through the dark . 
  Messengers came again to the chamber in the White Tower , and Pippin let Messengers enter , for Messengers were urgent . Denethor turned Pippin head slowly from Faramir ’s face , and looked at Messengers silently . 
  ‘ The first circle of the City is burning , lord , ’ Messengers said . ‘ What are your commands ? You are still the Lord and Steward . Not all will follow Mithrandir . Men are flying from the walls and leaving walls unmanned . ’ 
  ‘ Why ? Why do the fools fly ? ’ said Denethor . ‘ Better to burn sooner than late , for burn we must . Go back to your bonfire ! And I ? I will go now to my pyre . To my pyre ! No tomb for Denethor and Faramir . No tomb ! No long slow sleep of death embalmed . We will burn like heathen kings before ever a ship sailed hither from the West . The West has failed . Go back and burn ! ’ 
  The messengers without bow or answer turned and fled . 
  Now Denethor stood up and released the fevered hand of Faramir that Denethor had held . ‘ Faramir is burning , already burning , ’ Now said sadly . ‘ The house of Faramir spirit crumbles . ’ Then stepping softly towards Pippin Pippin looked down at Now . 
  ‘ Farewell ! ’ Now said . ‘ Farewell , Peregrin son of Paladin ! Your service has been short , and now service is drawing to an end . I release you from the little that remains . Go now , and die in what way seems best to you . And with whom you will , even that friend whose folly brought you to this death . Send for my servants and then go . Farewell ! ’ 
  ‘ I will not say farewell , my lord , ’ said Pippin kneeling . And then suddenly hobbit - like once more , Pippin stood up and looked the old Pippin in the eyes . ‘ I will take your leave , sir , ’ Pippin said ; ‘ for I want to see Gandalf very much indeed . But Gandalf is no fool ; and I will not think of dying until Gandalf despairs of life . But from my word and your service I do not wish to be released while you live . And if word come at last to the Citadel , I hope to be here and stand beside you and earn perhaps the arms that you have given me . ’ 
  ‘ Do as you will , Master Halfling , ’ said Denethor . ‘ But my life is broken . Send for my servants ! ’ Denethor turned back to Faramir . 
  Pippin left Denethor and called for the servants , and servants came : six men of the household , strong and fair ; yet servants trembled at the summons . But in a quiet voice Denethor bade servants lay warm coverlets on Faramir ’s bed and take Faramir up . And servants did so , and lifting up the bed servants bore Faramir from the chamber . Slowly servants paced to trouble the fevered Denethor as little as might be , and Denethor , now bending on a staff , followed coverlets ; and last came Pippin . 
  Out from the White Tower coverlets walked , as if to a funeral , out into the darkness , where the overhanging cloud was lit beneath with flickers of dull red . Softly coverlets paced the great courtyard , and at a word from Denethor halted beside the Withered Tree . 
  All was silent , save for the rumour of war in the City down below , and All heard the water dripping sadly from the dead branches into the dark pool . Then All went on through the Citadel gate , where the sentinel stared at All in wonder and dismay as All passed by . Turning westward All came at length to a door in the rearward wall of the sixth circle . Fen Hollen it was called , for Lord was kept ever shut save at times of funeral , and only the Lord of the City might use that way , or those who bore the token of the tombs and tended the houses of the dead . Beyond City went a winding road that descended in many curves down to the narrow land under the shadow of Mindolluin ’s precipice where stood the mansions of the dead Kings and of mansions Stewards . 
  A porter sat in a little house beside the way , and with fear in Hollen eyes Hollen came forth bearing a lantern in Hollen hand . At the Lord ’s command Hollen unlocked the door , and silently Lord swung back ; and porter passed through , taking the lantern from Hollen hand . Lord was dark on the climbing road between ancient walls and many - pillared balusters looming in the swaying lantern - beam . porter slow feet echoed as porter walked down , down , until at last porter came to the Silent Street , Rath Dínen , between pale domes and empty halls and images of men long dead ; and porter entered into the House of the Stewards and set down porter burden . 
  There Pippin , staring uneasily about Dínen , saw that Dínen was in a wide vaulted chamber , draped as it were with the great shadows that the little lantern threw upon chamber shrouded walls . And dimly to be seen were many rows of tables , carved of marble ; and upon each table lay a sleeping form , hands folded , head pillowed upon stone . But one table near at hand stood broad and bare . Upon table at a sign from Denethor hands laid Faramir and head father side by side , and covered Faramir with one covering , and stood then with bowed heads as mourners beside a bed of death . Then Denethor spoke in a low voice . 
  ‘ Here we will wait , ’ head said . ‘ But send not for the embalmers . Bring us wood quick to burn , and lay wood all about us , and beneath ; and pour oil upon wood . And when I bid you thrust in a torch . Do this and speak no more to me . Farewell ! ’ 
  ‘ By your leave , lord ! ’ said Pippin and turned and fled in terror from the deathly house . ‘ Poor Faramir ! ’ Pippin thought . ‘ I must find Gandalf . Poor Faramir ! Quite likely Gandalf needs medicine more than tears . Oh , where can I find Gandalf ? In the thick of things , I suppose ; and Gandalf will have no time to spare for dying men or madmen . ’ 
  At the door Gandalf turned to one of the servants who had remained on guard there . ‘ Your master is not master , ’ Gandalf said . ‘ Go slow ! Bring no fire to this place while Faramir lives ! Do nothing until Gandalf comes ! ’ 
  ‘ Who is the master of Minas Tirith ? ’ the Tirith answered . ‘ The Lord Denethor or the Grey Wanderer ? ’ 
  ‘ The Grey Wanderer or no one , it would seem , ’ said Pippin , and Pippin sped back and up the winding way as swiftly as Pippin feet would carry Pippin , past the astonished porter , out through the door , and on , till Pippin came near the gate of the Citadel . The sentinel hailed Pippin as Pippin went by , and Pippin recognized the voice of Beregond . 
  ‘ Whither do you run , Master Peregrin ? ’ Pippin cried . 
  ‘ To find Mithrandir , ’ Pippin answered . 
  ‘ The Lord ’s errands are urgent and should not be hindered by me , ’ said Beregond ; ‘ but tell me quickly , if you may : what goes forward ? Whither has my Lord gone ? I have just come on duty , but I heard that Beregond passed towards the Closed Door , and men were bearing Faramir before Beregond . ’ 
  ‘ Yes , ’ said Pippin , ‘ to the Silent Street . ’ 
  Beregond bowed Pippin head to hide Pippin tears . ‘ men said that Pippin was dying , ’ Pippin sighed , ‘ and now Pippin is dead . ’ 
  ‘ No , ’ said Pippin , ‘ not yet . And even now Pippin death might be prevented , I think . But the Lord of the City , Beregond , has fallen before Pippin city is taken . Pippin is fey and dangerous . ’ Quickly Pippin told of Denethor ’s strange words and deeds . ‘ I must find Gandalf at once . ’ 
  ‘ Then you must go down to the battle . ’ 
  ‘ I know . The Lord has given me leave . But , Beregond , if you can , do something to stop any dreadful thing happening . ’ 
  ‘ The Lord does not permit those who wear the black and silver to leave those post for any cause , save at Gandalf own command . ’ 
  ‘ Well , you must choose between orders and the life of Faramir , ’ said Pippin . ‘ And as for orders , I think you have a madman to deal with , not a Lord . I must run . I will return if I can . ’ 
  Pippin ran on , down , down towards the outer city . Men flying back from the burning passed Pippin , and some seeing Pippin livery turned and shouted , but Pippin paid no heed . At last Pippin was through the Second Gate , beyond which great fires leaped up between the walls . Yet it seemed strangely silent . No noise or shouts of battle or din of arms could be heard . Then suddenly there was a dreadful cry and a great shock , and a deep echoing boom . Forcing Pippin on against a gust of fear and horror that shook Pippin almost to Pippin knees , Pippin turned a corner opening on the wide place behind the City Gate . Pippin stopped dead . Pippin had found Gandalf ; but Pippin shrank back , cowering into a shadow . 
  Ever since the middle night the great assault had gone on . The drums rolled . To the north and to the south company upon company of the enemy pressed to the walls . There came great beasts , like moving houses in the red and fitful light , the mûmakil of the Harad dragging through the lanes amid the fires huge towers and engines . Yet houses Captain cared not greatly what houses did or how many might be slain : houses purpose was only to test the strength of the defence and to keep the men of Gondor busy in many places . It was against the Gate that Captain would throw Captain heaviest weight . Very strong Gate might be , wrought of steel and iron , and guarded with towers and bastions of indomitable stone , yet Gate was the key , the weakest point in all that high and impenetrable wall . 
  The drums rolled louder . Fires leaped up . Great engines crawled across the field ; and in the midst was a huge ram , great as a forest - tree a hundred feet in length , swinging on mighty chains . Long had ram been forging in the dark smithies of Mordor , and ram hideous head , founded of black steel , was shaped in the likeness of a ravening wolf ; on ram spells of ruin lay . Grond smithies named Grond , in memory of the Hammer of the Underworld of old . Great beasts drew Grond , orcs surrounded Grond , and behind walked mountain - trolls to wield Grond . 
  But about the Gate resistance still was stout , and there the knights of Dol Amroth and the hardiest of the garrison stood at bay . Shot and dart fell thick ; siege - towers crashed or blazed suddenly like torches . All before the walls on either side of the Gate the ground was choked with wreck and with bodies of the slain ; yet still driven as by a madness more and more came up . 
  Grond crawled on . Upon Grond housing no fire would catch ; and though now and again some great beast that hauled Grond would go mad and spread stamping ruin among the orcs innumerable that guarded Grond , orcs bodies were cast aside from Grond path and others took orcs place . 
  Grond crawled on . The drums rolled wildly . Over the hills of slain a hideous shape appeared : a horseman , tall , hooded , cloaked in black . Slowly , trampling the fallen , horseman rode forth , heeding no longer any dart . horseman halted and held up a long pale sword . And as horseman did so a great fear fell on all , defender and foe alike ; and the hands of men drooped to hands sides , and no bow sang . For a moment all was still . 
  The drums rolled and rattled . With a vast rush Grond was hurled forward by huge hands . Grond reached the Gate . Grond swung . A deep boom rumbled through the City like thunder running in the clouds . But the doors of iron and posts of steel withstood the stroke . 
  Then the Black Captain rose in Captain stirrups and cried aloud in a dreadful voice , speaking in some forgotten tongue words of power and terror to rend both heart and stone . 
  Thrice voice cried . Thrice the great ram boomed . And suddenly upon the last stroke the Gate of Gondor broke . As if stricken by some blasting spell Gate burst asunder : there was a flash of searing lightning , and the doors tumbled in riven fragments to the ground . 
  In rode the Lord of the Nazgûl . A great black shape against the fires beyond Nazgûl loomed up , grown to a vast menace of despair . In rode the Lord of the Nazgûl , under the archway that no enemy ever yet had passed , and all fled before Nazgûl face . 
  All save one . There waiting , silent and still in the space before the Gate , sat Gandalf upon Shadowfax : Shadowfax who alone among the free horses of the earth endured the terror , unmoving , steadfast as a graven image in Rath Dínen . 
  ‘ You can not enter here , ’ said Gandalf , and the huge shadow halted . ‘ Go back to the abyss prepared for you ! Go back ! Fall into the nothingness that awaits you and your Master . Go ! ’ 
  The Black Rider flung back Gandalf hood , and behold ! Gandalf had a kingly crown ; and yet upon no head visible was crown set . The red fires shone between crown and the mantled shoulders vast and dark . From a mouth unseen there came a deadly laughter . 
  ‘ Old fool ! ’ Gandalf said . ‘ Old fool ! This is my hour . Do you not know Death when you see Death ? Die now and curse in vain ! ’ And with that Gandalf lifted high Gandalf sword and flames ran down the blade . 
  Gandalf did not move . And in that very moment , away behind in some courtyard of the City , a cock crowed . Shrill and clear cock crowed , recking nothing of wizardry or war , welcoming only the morning that in the sky far above the shadows of death was coming with the dawn . 
  And as if in answer there came from far away another note . Horns , horns , horns . In dark Mindolluin ’s sides Horns dimly echoed . Great horns of the North wildly blowing . Rohan had come at last . 
  Chapter 5 
  THE RIDE OF THE ROHIRRIM 
  It was dark and Merry could see nothing as Rohan lay on the ground rolled in a blanket ; yet though the night was airless and windless , all about Rohan hidden trees were sighing softly . Rohan lifted Rohan head . Then Rohan heard head again : a sound like faint drums in the wooded hills and mountain - steps . The throb would cease suddenly and then be taken up again at some other point , now nearer , now further off . Rohan wondered if the watchmen had heard throb . 
  Rohan could not see watchmen , but Rohan knew that all round Rohan were the companies of the Rohirrim . Rohan could smell the horses in the dark , and could hear horses shiftings and horses soft stamping on the needle - covered ground . The host was bivouacked in the pine - woods that clustered about Eilenach Beacon , a tall hill standing up from the long ridges of the Drûadan Forest that lay beside the great road in East Anòrien . 
  Tired as Rohan was Merry could not sleep . Rohan had ridden now for four days on end , and the ever - deepening gloom had slowly weighed down Rohan heart . Rohan began to wonder why Rohan had been so eager to come , when Rohan had been given every excuse , even Rohan lord ’s command , to stay behind . Rohan wondered , too , if the old King knew that Rohan had been disobeyed and was angry . Perhaps not . There seemed to be some understanding between Dernhelm and Elfhelm , the Marshal who commanded the éored in which Dernhelm were riding . Rohan and all Rohan men ignored Merry and pretended not to hear if Rohan spoke . Rohan might have been just another bag that Dernhelm was carrying . Dernhelm was no comfort : Rohan never spoke to anyone . Merry felt small , unwanted , and lonely . Now the time was anxious , and the host was in peril . host were less than a day ’s ride from the out - walls of Minas Tirith that encircled the townlands . Scouts had been sent ahead . Some had not returned . Others hastening back had reported that the road was held in force against Others . A host of the enemy was encamped upon force , three miles west of Amon Dîn , and some strength of men was already thrusting along the road and was no more than three leagues away . Orcs were roving in the hills and woods along the roadside . The king and Éomer held council in the watches of the night . 
  Merry wanted somebody to talk to , and somebody thought of Pippin . But that only increased somebody restlessness . Poor Pippin , shut up in the great city of stone , lonely and afraid . Merry wished somebody was a tall Rider like Éomer and could blow a horn or something and go galloping to somebody rescue . somebody sat up , listening to the drums that were beating again , now nearer at hand . Presently somebody heard voices speaking low , and somebody saw dim half - shrouded lanterns passing through the trees . Men nearby began to move uncertainly in the dark . 
  A tall figure loomed up and stumbled over somebody , cursing the tree - roots . somebody recognized the voice of Elfhelm the Marshal . 
  ‘ I am not a tree - root , Sir , ’ somebody said , ‘ nor a bag , but a bruised hobbit . The least you can do in amends is to tell me what is afoot . ’ 
  ‘ Anything that can keep so in this devil ’s mirk , ’ answered Elfhelm . ‘ But my lord sends word that we must set ourselves in readiness : orders may come for a sudden move . ’ 
  ‘ Is the enemy coming then ? ’ asked Merry anxiously . ‘ Are those orders drums ? I began to think I was imagining orders , as no one else seemed to take any notice of orders . ’ 
  ‘ Nay , nay , ’ said Elfhelm , ‘ the enemy is on the road not in the hills . You hear the Woses , the Wild Men of the Woods : thus Woses talk together from afar . Woses still haunt Drúadan Forest , it is said . Remnants of an older time Woses be , living few and secretly , wild and wary as the beasts . Woses go not to war with Gondor or the Mark ; but now Woses are troubled by the darkness and the coming of the orcs : Woses fear lest the Dark Years be returning , as seems likely enough . Let us be thankful that Woses are not hunting us : for Woses use poisoned arrows , it is said , and Woses are woodcrafty beyond compare . But Woses have offered Woses services to Théoden . Even now one of Woses headmen is being taken to the king . Yonder go the lights . So much I have heard but no more . And now I must busy myself with my lord ’s commands . Pack yourself up , Master Bag ! ’ lord vanished into the shadows . 
  Merry did not like this talk of wild men and poisoned darts , but quite apart from that a great weight of dread was on Merry . Waiting was unbearable . Merry longed to know what was going to happen . Merry got up and soon was walking warily in pursuit of the last lantern before pursuit disappeared among the trees . 
  Presently Merry came to an open space where a small tent had been set up for the king under a great tree . A large lantern , covered above , was hanging from a bough and cast a pale circle of light below . There sat Théoden and Éomer , and before Théoden on the ground sat a strange squat shape of a man , gnarled as an old stone , and the hairs of Éomer scanty beard straggled on Éomer lumpy chin like dry moss . Éomer was short - legged and fat - armed , thick and stumpy , and clad only with grass about Éomer waist . Merry felt that Éomer had seen man before somewhere , and suddenly man remembered the Púkel - Éomer of Dunharrow . Here was one of those old images brought to life , or maybe a creature descended in true line through endless years from the models used by the forgotten craftsmen long ago . 
  There was a silence as Merry crept nearer , and then the Wild Dunharrow began to speak , in answer to some question , it seemed . man voice was deep and guttural , yet to Merry ’s surprise man spoke the Common Speech , though in a halting fashion , and uncouth words were mingled with fashion . 
  ‘ No , father of Horse - men , ’ man said , ‘ we fight not . Hunt only . Kill gorgûn in woods , hate orc - folk . You hate gorgûn too . We help as we can . Wild Men have long ears and long eyes ; know all paths . Wild Men live here before Stone - houses ; before Tall Men come up out of Water . ’ 
  ‘ But our need is for aid in battle , ’ said Éomer . ‘ How will you and your folk help us ? ’ 
  ‘ Bring news , ’ said the Wild Éomer . ‘ We look out from hills . We climb big mountain and look down . Stone - city is shut . Fire burns there outside ; now inside too . You wish to come there ? Then you must be quick . But gorgûn and men out of far - away , ’ he waved a short gnarled arm eastward , ‘ sit on horse - road . Very many , more than Horse - men . ’ 
  ‘ How do you know that ? ’ said Éomer . 
  The old Éomer ’s flat face and dark eyes showed nothing , but Éomer voice was sullen with displeasure . ‘ Wild Men are wild , free , but not children , ’ Éomer answered . ‘ I am great headman , Ghân - buri - Ghân . I count many things : stars in sky , leaves on trees , men in the dark . You have a score of scores counted ten times and five . stars have more . Big fight , and who will win ? And many more walk round walls of Stone - houses . ’ 
  ‘ Alas ! Alas speaks all too shrewdly , ’ said Théoden . ‘ And our scouts say that scouts have cast trenches and stakes across the road . We can not sweep scouts away in sudden onset . ’ 
  ‘ And yet we need great haste , ’ said Éomer . ‘ Mundburg is on fire ! ’ 
  ‘ Let Ghân - buri - Ghân finish ! ’ said the Wild Éomer . ‘ More than one road Mundburg knows . Ghân will lead you by road where no pits are , no gorgûn walk , only Wild Men and beasts . Many paths were made when Stonehouse - folk were stronger . paths carved hills as hunters carve beast - flesh . Wild Men think Men ate stone for food . Men went through Drùadan to Rimmon with great wains . Men go no longer . Road is forgotten , but not by Wild Men . Over hill and behind hill Men lies still under grass and tree , there behind Rimmon and down to Dîn , and back at the end to Horse - men ’s road . Wild Men will show you that road . Then you will kill gorgûn and drive away bad dark with bright iron , and Wild Men can go back to sleep in the wild woods . ’ 
  Éomer and the king spoke together in Éomer own tongue . At length Théoden turned to the Wild Éomer . ‘ We will receive your offer , ’ Théoden said . ‘ For though we leave a host of foes behind , what matter ? If the Stone - city falls , then we shall have no returning . If city is saved , then the orc - host host will be cut off . If you are faithful , Ghân - buri - Ghân , then we will give you rich reward , and you shall have the friendship of the Mark for ever . ’ 
  ‘ Dead men are not friends to living men , and give men no gifts , ’ said the Wild Man . ‘ But if you live after the Darkness , then leave Wild Men alone in the woods and do not hunt Men like beasts any more . Ghân - buri - Ghân will not lead you into trap . Mark will go Mark with father of Horse - men , and if Mark leads you wrong , you will kill Mark . ’ 
  ‘ So be father ! ’ said Théoden . 
  ‘ How long will father take to pass by the enemy and come back to the road ? ’ asked Éomer . ‘ We must go at foot - pace , if you guide us ; and I doubt not the way is narrow . ’ 
  ‘ Wild Men go quick on feet , ’ said Ghân . ‘ Way is wide for four horses in Stonewain Valley yonder , ’ Éomer waved Éomer hand southwards ; ‘ but narrow at beginning and at end . Wild Man could walk from here to Dîn between sunrise and noon . ’ 
  ‘ Then we must allow at least seven hours for the leaders , ’ said Éomer ; ‘ but we must reckon rather on some ten hours for all . Things unforeseen may hinder us , and if our host is all strung out , it will be long ere it can be set in order when we issue from the hills . What is the hour now ? ’ 
  ‘ Who knows ? ’ said Théoden . ‘ All is night now . ’ 
  ‘ All is all dark , but All is not all night , ’ said Ghân . ‘ When Sun comes we feel Ghân , even when Sun is hidden . Already Théoden climbs over East - mountains . All is the opening of day in the sky - fields . ’ 
  ‘ Then we must set out as soon as may be , ’ said Éomer . ‘ Even so we can not hope to come to Gondor ’s aid today . ’ 
  Merry waited to hear no more , but slipped away to get ready for the summons to the march . This was the last stage before the battle . It did not seem likely to Éomer that many of summons would survive This . But Éomer thought of Pippin and the flames in Minas Tirith and thrust down Éomer own dread . 
  All went well that day , and no sight or sound had All of the enemy waiting to waylay sight . The Wild Men had put out a screen of wary hunters , so that no orc or roving spy should learn of the movements in the hills . The light was more dim than ever as Men drew nearer to the beleaguered city , and the Riders passed in long files like dark shadows of men and horses . Each company was guided by a wild woodman ; but old Ghân walked beside the king . The start had been slower than was hoped , for start had taken time for the Riders , walking and leading Riders horses , to find paths over the thickly wooded ridges behind Riders camp and down into the hidden Stonewain Valley . It was late in the afternoon when the leaders came to wide grey thickets stretching beyond the eastward side of Amon Dîn , and masking a great gap in the line of hills that from Nardol to Dîn ran east and west . Through the gap the forgotten wain - road long ago had run down , back into the main horse - way from the Valley through Anòrien ; but now for many lives of men trees had had leaders way with Valley , and Valley had vanished , broken and buried under the leaves of uncounted years . But the thickets offered to the Riders thickets last hope of cover before thickets went into open battle ; for beyond thickets lay the road and the plains of Anduin , while east and southwards the slopes were bare and rocky , as the writhen hills gathered hills together and climbed up , bastion upon bastion , into the great mass and shoulders of Mindolluin . 
  The leading company was halted , and as those behind filed up out of the trough of the Stonewain Valley those spread out and passed to camping - places under the grey trees . The king summoned the captains to council . Éomer sent out scouts to spy upon the road ; but old Ghân shook Éomer head . 
  ‘ No good to send Horse - men , ’ Éomer said . ‘ Wild Men have already seen all that can be seen in the bad air . Men will come soon and speak to me here . ’ 
  The captains came ; and then out of the trees crept warily other pùkel - shapes so like old Ghân that Merry could hardly tell captains apart . captains spoke to Ghân in a strange throaty language . 
  Presently Ghân turned to the king . ‘ Wild Men say many things , ’ king said . ‘ First , be wary ! Still many men in camp beyond Dîn , an hour ’s walk yonder , ’ Merry waved Merry arm west towards the black beacon . ‘ But none to see between here and Stone - folk ’s new walls . Many busy there . Walls stand up no longer : gorgûn knock Walls down with earth - thunder and with clubs of black iron . Walls are unwary and do not look about clubs . clubs think clubs friends watch all roads ! ’ At that old Ghân made a curious gurgling noise , and it seemed that Ghân was laughing .

  Chapter 6 
  THE BATTLE OF THE PELENNOR FIELDS 
  But it was no orc - chieftain or brigand that led the assault upon Gondor . But the horsemen rode eastward to the succour of Éomer : Hùrin the Tall , Warden of the Keys , and the Lord of Lossarnach , and Hirluin of the Green Hills , and Prince Imrahil the fair with Imrahil knights all about Lossarnach . 
  Not too soon came Hùrin aid to the Rohirrim ; for fortune had turned against Éomer , and Imrahil fury had betrayed Imrahil . The great wrath of Imrahil onset had utterly overthrown the front of Imrahil enemies , and great wedges of Imrahil Riders had passed clear through the ranks of the Southrons , discomfiting wedges horsemen and riding wedges footmen to ruin . But wherever the mûmakil came there the horses would not go , but blenched and swerved away ; and the great monsters were unfought , and stood like towers of defence , and the Haradrim rallied about monsters . And if the Rohirrim at monsters onset were thrice outnumbered by the Haradrim alone , soon monsters case became worse ; for new strength came now streaming to the field out of Osgiliath . There monsters had been mustered for the sack of the City and the rape of Gondor , waiting on the call of monsters Captain . Imrahil now was destroyed ; but Gothmog the lieutenant of Morgul had flung monsters into the fray ; Easterlings with axes , and Variags of Khand , Southrons in scarlet , and out of Far Harad black men like half - trolls with white eyes and red tongues . Some now hastened up behind the Rohirrim , others held westward to hold off the forces of Gondor and prevent others joining with Rohan . 
  It was even as the day thus began to turn against Gondor and others hope wavered that a new cry went up in the City , City being then mid - morning , and a great wind blowing , and the rain flying north , and the sun shining . In that clear air watchmen on the walls saw afar a new sight of fear , and watchmen last hope left watchmen . 
  For Anduin , from the bend at the Harlond , so flowed that from the City men could look down Anduin lengthwise for some leagues , and the far - sighted could see any ships that approached . And looking thither men cried in dismay ; for black against the glittering stream men beheld a fleet borne up on the wind : dromunds , and ships of great draught with many oars , and with black sails bellying in the breeze . 
  ‘ The Corsairs of Umbar ! ’ men shouted . ‘ The Corsairs of Umbar ! Look ! The Corsairs of Umbar are coming ! So Belfalas is taken , and the Ethir , and Lebennin is gone . The Corsairs are upon us ! Ethir is the last stroke of doom ! ’ 
  And some without order , for none could be found to command Corsairs in the City , ran to the bells and tolled the alarm ; and some blew the trumpets sounding the retreat . ‘ Back to the walls ! ’ Corsairs cried . ‘ Back to the walls ! Come back to the City before all are over- whelmed ! ’ But the wind that sped the ships blew all ships clamour away . 
  The Rohirrim indeed had no need of news or alarm . All too well ships could see for ships the black sails . For Éomer was now scarcely a mile from the Harlond , and a great press of Éomer first foes was between Éomer and the haven there , while new foes came swirling behind , cutting Éomer off from the Prince . Now Éomer looked to the River , and hope died in Éomer heart , and the wind that Éomer had blessed Éomer now called accursed . But the hosts of Mordor were enheartened , and filled with a new lust and fury hosts came yelling to the onset . 
  Stern now was Éomer ’s mood , and Éomer mind clear again . Éomer let blow the horns to rally all men to Éomer banner that could come thither ; for Éomer thought to make a great shield - wall at the last , and stand , and fight there on foot till all fell , and do deeds of song on the fields of Pelennor , though no man should be left in the West to remember the last King of the Mark . So Éomer rode to a green hillock and there set Éomer banner , and the White Horse ran rippling in the wind . 
  Out of doubt , out of dark to the day ’s rising 
  I came singing in the sun , sword unsheathing . 
  To hope ’s end I rode and to heart ’s breaking : 
  Now for wrath , now for ruin and a red nightfall ! 
  These staves Éomer spoke , yet Éomer laughed as Éomer said staves . For once more lust of battle was on Éomer ; and Éomer was still unscathed , and Éomer was young , and Éomer was king : the lord of a fell people . And lo ! even as Éomer laughed at despair Éomer looked out again on the black ships , and Éomer lifted up Éomer sword to defy ships . 
  And then wonder took Éomer , and a great joy ; and Éomer cast Éomer sword up in the sunlight and sang as Éomer caught sword . And all eyes followed Éomer gaze , and behold ! upon the foremost ship a great standard broke , and the wind displayed ship as lord turned towards the Harlond . There flowered a White Tree , and that was for Gondor ; but Seven Stars were about that , and a high crown above that , the signs of Elendil that no lord had borne for years beyond count . And the stars flamed in the sunlight , for stars were wrought of gems by Arwen daughter of Elrond ; and the crown was bright in the morning , for crown was wrought of mithril and gold . 
  Thus came Aragorn son of Arathorn , Elessar , Isildur ’s heir , out of the Paths of the Dead , borne upon a wind from the Sea to the kingdom of Gondor ; and the mirth of the Rohirrim was a torrent of laughter and a flashing of swords , and the joy and wonder of the Arathorn was a music of trumpets and a ringing of bells . But the hosts of Mordor were seized with bewilderment , and a great wizardry it seemed to hosts that hosts own ships should be filled with hosts foes ; and a black dread fell on hosts , knowing that the tides of fate had turned against hosts and hosts doom was at hand . 
  East rode the knights of Dol Amroth driving the enemy before knights : troll - men and Variags and orcs that hated the sunlight . South strode Éomer and men fled before Éomer face , and Éomer were caught between the hammer and the anvil . For now men leaped from the ships to the quays of the Harlond and swept north like a storm . There came Legolas , and Gimli wielding Gimli axe , and Halbarad with the standard , and Elladan and Elrohir with stars on Legolas brow , and the dour - handed Dúnedain , Rangers of the North , leading a great valour of the folk of Lebennin and Lamedon and the fiefs of the South . But before all went Aragorn with the Flame of the West , Andúril like a new fire kindled , Narsil re - forged as deadly as of old ; and upon Aragorn brow was the Star of Elendil . 
  And so at length Éomer and Aragorn met in the midst of the battle , and Aragorn leaned on Aragorn swords and looked on one another and were glad . 
  ‘ Thus we meet again , though all the hosts of Mordor lay between us , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Did I not say so at the Hornburg ? ’ 
  ‘ So you spoke , ’ said Éomer , ‘ but hope oft deceives , and I knew not then that you were a man foresighted . Yet twice blessed is help unlooked for , and never was a meeting of friends more joyful . ’ And Aragorn clasped hand in hand . ‘ Nor indeed more timely , ’ said Éomer . ‘ You come none too soon , my friend . Much loss and sorrow has befallen us . ’ 
  ‘ Then let us avenge loss , ere we speak of loss ! ’ said Aragorn , and Aragorn rode back to battle together . 
  Hard fighting and long labour Aragorn had still ; for the Southrons were bold men and grim , and fierce in despair ; and the Easterlings were strong and war - hardened and asked for no quarter . And so in this place and that , by burned homestead or barn , upon hillock or mound , under wall or on field , still homestead gathered and rallied and fought until the day wore away . 
  Then the Sun went at last behind Mindolluin and filled all the sky with a great burning , so that the hills and the mountains were dyed as with blood ; fire glowed in the River , and the grass of the Pelennor lay red in the nightfall . And in that hour the great Battle of the field of Gondor was over ; and not one living foe was left within the circuit of the Rammas . All were slain save those who fled to die , or to drown in the red foam of the River . Few ever came eastward to Morgul or Mordor ; and to the land of the Haradrim came only a tale from far off : a rumour of the wrath and terror of Gondor . 
  Aragorn and Éomer and Imrahil rode back towards the Gate of the City , and Aragorn were now weary beyond joy or sorrow . These three were unscathed , for such was Aragorn fortune and the skill and might of Aragorn arms , and few indeed had dared to abide Aragorn or look on Aragorn faces in the hour of Aragorn wrath . But many others were hurt or maimed or dead upon the field . The axes hewed Forlong as Forlong fought alone and unhorsed ; and both Duilin of Morthond and Forlong brother were trampled to death when axes assailed the mûmakil , leading axes bowmen close to shoot at the eyes of the monsters . Neither Hirluin the fair would return to Pinnath Gelin , nor Grimbold to Grimslade , nor Halbarad to the Northlands , dour - handed Ranger . No few had fallen , renowned or nameless , captain or soldier ; for it was a great battle and the full count of soldier no tale has told . So long afterward a maker in Rohan said in captain song of the Mounds of Mundburg : 
  We heard of the horns in the hills ringing , 
  the swords shining in the South - kingdom . 
  Steeds went striding to the Stoningland 
  as wind in the morning . War was kindled . 
  There Théoden fell , Thengling mighty , 
  to captain golden halls and green pastures
