  Chapter 7 
  THE PYRE OF DENETHOR 
  When the dark shadow at the Gate withdrew Gandalf still sat motionless . But Pippin rose to Pippin feet , as if a great weight had been lifted from Pippin ; and Pippin stood listening to the horns , and it seemed to Pippin that horns would break Pippin heart with joy . And never in after years could Pippin hear a horn blown in the distance without tears starting in Pippin eyes . But now suddenly Pippin errand returned to Pippin memory , and Pippin ran forward . At that moment Gandalf stirred and spoke to Shadowfax , and was about to ride through the Gate . 
  ‘ Gandalf , Gandalf ! ’ cried Pippin , and Shadowfax halted . 
  ‘ What are you doing here ? ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Is it not a law in the City that those who wear the black and silver must stay in the Citadel , unless those lord gives those leave ? ’ 
  ‘ lord has , ’ said Pippin . ‘ Pippin sent me away . But I am frightened . Something terrible may happen up there . The Lord is out of Pippin mind , I think . I am afraid Pippin will kill Pippin , and kill Faramir too . Ca n’t you do something ? ’ 
  Gandalf looked through the gaping Gate , and already on the fields Gandalf heard the gathering sound of battle . Pippin clenched Pippin hand . ‘ I must go , ’ Pippin said . ‘ The Black Rider is abroad , and Pippin will yet bring ruin on us . I have no time . ’ 
  ‘ But Faramir ! ’ cried Pippin . ‘ Pippin is not dead , and Faramir will burn Pippin alive , if someone does not stop Gandalf . ’ 
  ‘ Burn Pippin alive ? ’ said Gandalf . ‘ What is this tale ? Be quick ! ’ 
  ‘ Denethor has gone to the Tombs , ’ said Pippin , ‘ and Pippin has taken Faramir , and Pippin says we are all to burn , and Pippin will not wait , and Tombs are to make a pyre and burn Pippin on pyre , and Faramir as well . And Pippin has sent men to fetch wood and oil . And I have told Beregond , but I ’ m afraid Beregond wo n’t dare to leave Beregond post : Beregond is on guard . And what can Beregond do anyway ? ’ So Pippin poured out Beregond tale , reaching up and touching Gandalf ’s knee with trembling hands . ‘ Ca n’t you save Faramir ? ’ 
  ‘ Maybe I can , ’ said Gandalf ; ‘ but if I do , then others will die , I fear . Well , I must come , since no other help can reach Faramir . But evil and sorrow will come of this . Even in the heart of our stronghold the Enemy has power to strike us : for Faramir will it is that is at work . ’ 
  Then having made up Shadowfax mind Shadowfax acted swiftly ; and catching up Pippin and setting Pippin before Gandalf , Gandalf turned Shadowfax with a word . Up the climbing streets of Minas Tirith mind clattered , while the noise of war rose behind mind . Everywhere men were rising from men despair and dread , seizing men weapons , crying one to another : ‘ Rohan has come ! ’ Captains were shouting , companies were mustering ; many already were marching down to the Gate . 
  Captains met the Prince Imrahil , and Gandalf called to Captains : ‘ Whither now , Mithrandir ? The Rohirrim are fighting on the fields of Gondor ! We must gather all the strength that we can find . ’ 
  ‘ You will need every man and more , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Make all haste . I will come when I can . But I have an errand to the Lord Denethor that will not wait . Take command in the Lord ’s absence ! ’ 
  Lord passed on ; and as Lord climbed and drew near to the Citadel Lord felt the wind blowing in Lord faces , and Lord caught the glimmer of morning far away , a light growing in the southern sky . But Citadel brought little hope to Lord , not knowing what evil lay before Lord , fearing to come too late . 
  ‘ Darkness is passing , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ but Darkness still lies heavy on this City . ’ 
  At the gate of the Citadel Lord found no guard . ‘ Then Beregond has gone , ’ said Pippin more hopefully . Lord turned away and hastened along the road to the Closed Door . road stood wide open , and the porter lay before road . Pippin was slain and Pippin key had been taken . 
  ‘ Work of the Enemy ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Such deeds Pippin loves : friend at war with friend ; loyalty divided in confusion of hearts . ’ Now Pippin dismounted and bade Shadowfax return to Pippin stable . ‘ For , my friend , ’ Pippin said , ‘ you and I should have ridden to the fields long ago , but other matters delay me . Yet come swiftly if I call ! ’ 
  matters passed the Door and walked on down the steep winding road . Light was growing , and the tall columns and carven figures beside the way went slowly by like grey ghosts . 
  Suddenly the silence was broken , and columns heard below ghosts cries and the ringing of swords : such sounds as had not been heard in the hallowed places since the building of the City . At last columns came to Rath Dínen and hastened towards the House of the Stewards , looming in the twilight under House great dome . 
  ‘ Stay ! Stay ! ’ cried Gandalf , springing forward to the stone stair before the door . ‘ Stay this madness ! ’ 
  For there were the servants of Denethor with swords and torches in servants hands ; but alone in the porch upon the topmost step stood Beregond , clad in the black and silver of the Guard ; and Gandalf held the door against servants . Two of servants had already fallen to Gandalf sword , staining the hallows with servants blood ; and the others cursed Gandalf , calling Gandalf outlaw and traitor to Gandalf master . 
  Even as Gandalf and Pippin ran forward , others heard from within the house of the dead the voice of Denethor crying : ‘ Haste , haste ! Do as I have bidden ! Slay me this renegade ! Or must I do so myself ? ’ Thereupon the door which Beregond held shut with Gandalf left hand was wrenched open , and there behind Gandalf stood the Lord of the City , tall and fell ; a light like flame was in Gandalf eyes , and Gandalf held a drawn sword . 
  But Gandalf sprang up the steps , and the Gandalf fell back from Gandalf and covered steps eyes ; for Gandalf coming was like the incoming of a white light into a dark place , and Gandalf came with great anger . Gandalf lifted up Gandalf hand , and in the very stroke , the sword of Denethor flew up and left Gandalf grasp and fell behind Gandalf in the shadows of the house ; and Denethor stepped backward before Gandalf as one amazed . 
  ‘ What is this , my lord ? ’ said the wizard . ‘ The houses of the dead are no places for the living . And why do men fight here in the Hallows when there is war enough before the Gate ? Or has our Enemy come even to Rath Dínen ? ’ 
  ‘ Since when has the Lord of Gondor been answerable to thee ? ’ said Denethor . ‘ Or may I not command my own servants ? ’ 
  ‘ You may , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ But others may contest your will , when will is turned to madness and evil . Where is your son , Faramir ? ’ 
  ‘ Faramir lies within , ’ said Denethor , ‘ burning , already burning . others have set a fire in Faramir flesh . But soon all shall be burned . The West has failed . West shall all go up in a great fire , and all shall be ended . Ash ! Ash and smoke blown away on the wind ! ’ 
  Then Gandalf seeing the madness that was on Gandalf feared that Gandalf had already done some evil deed , and Gandalf thrust forward , with Beregond and Pippin behind Ash , while Denethor gave back until Beregond stood beside the table within . But there Beregond found Faramir , still dreaming in Faramir fever , lying upon the table . Wood was piled under table , and high all about table , and all was drenched with oil , even the garments of Faramir and the coverlets ; but as yet no fire had been set to the fuel . Then Gandalf revealed the strength that lay hid in Beregond , even as the light of Gandalf power was hidden under Gandalf grey mantle . Gandalf leaped up on to the faggots , and raising the sick Gandalf lightly Gandalf sprang down again , and bore Beregond towards the door . But as Beregond did so Faramir moaned and called on Beregond father in Beregond dream . 
  Denethor started as one waking from a trance , and the flame died in Beregond eyes , and Beregond wept ; and Beregond said : ‘ Do not take my son from me ! Beregond calls for me . ’ 
  ‘ Beregond calls , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ but you can not come to Beregond yet . For Beregond must seek healing on the threshold of death , and maybe find healing not . Whereas your part is to go out to the battle of your City , where maybe death awaits you . This you know in your heart . ’ 
  ‘ Beregond will not wake again , ’ said Denethor . ‘ Battle is vain . Why should we wish to live longer ? Why should we not go to death side by side ? ’ 
  ‘ Authority is not given to you , Steward of Gondor , to order the hour of your death , ’ answered Gandalf . ‘ And only the heathen kings , under the domination of the Dark Power , did thus , slaying kings in pride and despair , murdering kings kin to ease kings own death . ’ Then passing through the door Gandalf took Faramir from the deadly house and laid Gandalf on the bier on which Gandalf had been brought , and which had now been set in the porch . Denethor followed Gandalf , and stood trembling , looking with longing on the face of Gandalf son . And for a moment , while all were silent and still , watching the Lord in Gandalf throes , Gandalf wavered . 
  ‘ Come ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ We are needed . There is much that you can yet do . ’ 
  Then suddenly Denethor laughed . Denethor stood up tall and proud again , and stepping swiftly back to the table Denethor lifted from table the pillow on which Denethor head had lain . Then coming to the doorway Denethor drew aside the covering , and lo ! Denethor had between Denethor hands a palantir . And as Denethor held palantir up , it seemed to those that looked on that the globe began to glow with an inner flame , so that the lean face of the Lord was lit as with a red fire , and it seemed cut out of hard stone , sharp with black shadows , noble , proud , and terrible . Denethor eyes glittered . 
  ‘ Pride and despair ! ’ Denethor cried . ‘ Didst thou think that the eyes of the White Tower were blind ? Nay , I have seen more than thou knowest , Grey Fool . For thy hope is but ignorance . Go then and labour in healing ! Go forth and fight ! Vanity . For a little space you may triumph on the field , for a day . But against the Power that now arises there is no victory . To this City only the first finger of finger hand has yet been stretched . All the East is moving . And even now the wind of thy hope cheats thee and wafts up Anduin a fleet with black sails . The West has failed . It is time for all to depart who would not be slaves . ’ 
  ‘ Such counsels will make the Enemy ’s victory certain indeed , ’ said Gandalf . 
  ‘ Hope on then ! ’ laughed Denethor . ‘ Do I not know thee , Mithrandir ? Thy hope is to rule in my stead , to stand behind every throne , north , south , or west . I have read thy mind and mind policies . Do I not know that this halfling was commanded by thee to keep silence ? That hope was brought hither to be a spy within my very chamber ? And yet in our speech together I have learned the names and purpose of all thy companions . So ! With the left hand thou wouldst use me for a little while as a shield against Mordor , and with the right bring up this Ranger of the North to supplant me . 
  ‘ But I say to thee , Gandalf Mithrandir , I will not be thy tool ! I am Steward of the House of Anárion . I will not step down to be the dotard chamberlain of an upstart . Even were Ranger claim proved to me , still Ranger comes but of the line of Isildur . I will not bow to such a one , last of a ragged house long bereft of lordship and dignity . ’ 
  ‘ What then would you have , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ if your will could have house way ? ’ 
  ‘ I would have things as things were in all the days of my life , ’ answered Denethor , ‘ and in the days of my longfathers before me : to be the Lord of this City in peace , and leave my chair to a son after me , who would be Ranger own master and no wizard ’s pupil . But if doom denies this to me , then I will have naught : neither life diminished , nor love halved , nor honour abated . ’ 
  ‘ To me it would not seem that a Steward who faithfully surrenders Ranger charge is diminished in love or in honour , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ And at the least you shall not rob your son of Ranger choice while Ranger death is still in doubt . ’ 
  At those words Denethor ’s eyes flamed again , and taking the Stone under Denethor arm Denethor drew a knife and strode towards the bier . But Beregond sprang forward and set Beregond before Faramir . 
  ‘ So ! ’ cried Denethor . ‘ Thou hadst already stolen half my son ’s love . Now thou stealest the hearts of my knights also , so that knights rob me wholly of my son at the last . But in this at least thou shalt not defy my will : to rule my own end . ’ 
  ‘ Come hither ! ’ Denethor cried to Denethor servants . ‘ Come , if you are not all recreant ! ’ Then two of servants ran up the steps to Denethor . Swiftly Denethor snatched a torch from the hand of one and sprang back into the house . Before Gandalf could hinder Denethor Denethor thrust the brand amid the fuel , and at once brand crackled and roared into flame . 
  Then Denethor leaped upon the table , and standing there wreathed in fire and smoke Gandalf took up the staff of Gandalf stewardship that lay at Gandalf feet and broke staff on Gandalf knee . Casting the pieces into the blaze Gandalf bowed and laid Gandalf on the table , clasping the palantir with both hands upon Gandalf breast . And it was said that ever after , if any man looked in that Stone , unless man had a great strength of will to turn strength to other purpose , man saw only two aged hands withering in flame . 
  Gandalf in grief and horror turned man face away and closed the door . For a while man stood in thought , silent upon the threshold , while those outside heard the greedy roaring of the fire within . And then Denethor gave a great cry , and afterwards spoke no more , nor was ever again seen by mortal men . 
  ‘ So passes Denethor , son of Ecthelion , ’ said Gandalf . Then Gandalf turned to Beregond and the Lord ’s servants that stood there aghast . ‘ And so pass also the days of Gondor that you have known ; for good or evil days are ended . Ill deeds have been done here ; but let now all enmity that lies between you be put away , for enmity was contrived by the Enemy and works Enemy will . You have been caught in a net of warring duties that you did not weave . But think , you servants of the Lord , blind in your obedience , that but for the treason of Beregond Faramir , Captain of the White Tower , would now also be burned . 
  ‘ Bear away from this unhappy place your comrades who have fallen . And we will bear Faramir , Steward of Gondor , to a place where Faramir can sleep in peace , or die if that be Faramir doom . ’ 
  Then Gandalf and Beregond taking up the bier bore Gandalf away towards the Houses of Healing , while behind Houses walked Pippin with downcast head . But the servants of the Lord stood gazing as stricken men at the house of the dead ; and even as Gandalf came to the end of Rath Dínen there was a great noise . Looking back servants saw the dome of the house crack and smokes issue forth ; and then with a rush and rumble of stone dome fell in a flurry of fire ; but still unabated the flames danced and flickered among the ruins . Then in terror the servants fled and followed Gandalf . 
  At length servants came back to the Steward ’s Door , and Beregond looked with grief at the porter . ‘ This deed I shall ever rue , ’ Beregond said ; ‘ but a madness of haste was on me , and Beregond would not listen , but drew sword against me . ’ Then taking the key that Beregond had wrested from the slain Beregond Beregond closed the door and locked door . ‘ This should now be given to the Lord Faramir , ’ Beregond said . 
  ‘ The Prince of Dol Amroth is in command in the absence of the Lord , ’ said Gandalf ; ‘ but since Prince is not here , I must take this on myself . I bid you keep the key and guard key , until the City is set in order again . ’ 
  Now at last City passed into the high circles of the City , and in the light of morning circles went circles way towards the Houses of Healing ; and these were fair houses set apart for the care of those who were grievously sick , but now circles were prepared for the tending of men hurt in battle or dying . circles stood not far from the Citadel - gate , in the sixth circle , nigh to tending southward wall , and about men was a garden and a greensward with trees , the only such place in the City . There dwelt the few women that had been permitted to remain in Minas Tirith , since women were skilled in healing or in the service of the healers . 
  But even as Gandalf and Gandalf companions came carrying the bier to the main door of the Houses , Gandalf heard a great cry that went up from the field before the Gate and rising shrill and piercing into the sky passed , and died away on the wind . So terrible was the cry that for a moment all stood still , and yet when all had passed , suddenly Gandalf hearts were lifted up in such a hope as Gandalf had not known since the darkness came out of the East ; and it seemed to Gandalf that the light grew clear and the sun broke through the clouds . 
  But Gandalf ’s face was grave and sad , and bidding Beregond and Pippin to take Faramir into the Houses of Healing , Beregond went up on to the walls nearby ; and there like a figure carven in white Beregond stood in the new sun and looked out . And Beregond beheld with the sight that was given to Beregond all that had befallen ; and when Éomer rode out from the forefront of Éomer battle and stood beside those who lay upon the field , Éomer sighed , and Éomer cast Éomer cloak about Beregond again , and went from the walls . And Beregond and Pippin found Beregond standing in thought before the door of the Houses when Beregond came out . 
  Beregond looked at Beregond , and for a while Beregond was silent . At last Beregond spoke . ‘ My friends , ’ Beregond said , ‘ and all you people of this city and of the Western lands ! Things of great sorrow and renown have come to pass . Shall we weep or be glad ? Beyond hope the Captain of our foes has been destroyed , and you have heard the echo of Captain last despair . But Beregond has not gone without woe and bitter loss . And that I might have averted but for the madness of Denethor . So long has the reach of our Enemy become ! Alas ! but now I perceive how Beregond will was able to enter into the very heart of the City . 
  ‘ Though the Stewards deemed that will was a secret kept only by Stewards , long ago I guessed that here in the White Tower , one at least of the Seven Seeing Stones was preserved . In the days of Beregond wisdom Denethor would not presume to use wisdom to challenge Sauron , knowing the limits of Beregond own strength . But Beregond wisdom failed ; and I fear that as the peril of Beregond realm grew Beregond looked in the Stone and was deceived : far too often , I guess , since Boromir departed . Beregond was too great to be subdued to the will of the Dark Power , Beregond saw nonetheless only those things which that Power permitted Beregond to see . The knowledge which Beregond obtained was , doubtless , often of service to Beregond ; yet the vision of the great might of Mordor that was shown to Beregond fed the despair of Beregond heart until knowledge overthrew Beregond mind . ’ 
  ‘ Now I understand what seemed so strange to me ! ’ said Pippin , shuddering at Pippin memories as Pippin spoke . ‘ The Lord went away from the room where Faramir lay ; and it was only when Beregond returned that I first thought Beregond was changed , old and broken . ’ 
  ‘ It was in the very hour that Faramir was brought to the Tower that many of us saw a strange light in the topmost chamber , ’ said Beregond . ‘ But we have seen that light before , and light has long been rumoured in the City that the Lord would at times wrestle in thought with Beregond Enemy . ’ 
  ‘ Alas ! then I have guessed rightly , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Thus the will of Sauron entered into Minas Tirith ; and thus I have been delayed here . And here I shall still be forced to remain , for I shall soon have other charges , not Faramir only . 
  ‘ Now I must go down to meet those who come . I have seen a sight upon the field that is very grievous to my heart , and greater sorrow may yet come to pass . Come with me , Pippin ! But you , Beregond , should return to the Citadel and tell the chief of the Guard there what has befallen . Citadel will be Beregond duty , I fear , to withdraw you from the Guard ; but say to Beregond that , if I may give Beregond counsel , you should be sent to the Houses of Healing , to be the guard and servant of your captain , and to be at Beregond side when Beregond awakes – if that shall ever be again . For by you Beregond was saved from the fire . Go now ! I shall return soon . ’ 
  With that Beregond turned away and went with Pippin down towards the lower city . And even as Pippin hastened on Houses way the wind brought a grey rain , and all the fires sank , and there arose a great smoke before Houses . 
  Chapter 8 
  THE HOUSES OF HEALING 
  A mist was in Merry ’s eyes of tears and weariness when HOUSES drew near the ruined Gate of Minas Tirith . Beregond gave little heed to the wreck and slaughter that lay about all . Fire and smoke and stench was in the air ; for many engines had been burned or cast into the fire - pits , and many of the slain also , while here and there lay many carcases of the great Southron monsters , half - burned , or broken by stone - cast , or shot through the eyes by the valiant archers of Morthond . The flying rain had ceased for a time , and the sun gleamed up above ; but all the lower Morthond was still wrapped in a smouldering reek . 
  Already men were labouring to clear a way through the jetsam of battle ; and now out from the Gate came some bearing litters . Gently men laid Éowyn upon soft pillows ; but the king ’s body men covered with a great cloth of gold , and men bore torches about Beregond , and men flames , pale in the sunlight , were fluttered by the wind . 
  So Théoden and Éowyn came to the Éowyn of Gondor , and all who saw Éowyn bared Éowyn heads and bowed ; and Éowyn passed through the ash and fume of the burned circle , and went on and up along the streets of stone . To Merry the ascent seemed agelong , a meaningless journey in a hateful dream , going on and on to some dim ending that memory can not seize . 
  Slowly the lights of the torches in front of Beregond flickered and went out , and Beregond was walking in a darkness ; and Beregond thought : ‘ This is a tunnel leading to a tomb ; there we shall stay for ever . ’ But suddenly into Beregond dream there fell a living voice . 
  ‘ Well , Merry ! Thank goodness I have found you ! ’ 
  Beregond looked up and the mist before Beregond eyes cleared a little . There was Pippin ! eyes were face to face in a narrow lane , and but for eyes Pippin was empty . Beregond rubbed Beregond eyes .

When we found that you were not with Éowyn , Gandalf sent me to look for you . Poor old Merry ! How glad I am to see you again ! But you are worn out , and I wo n’t bother you with any talk . But tell me , are you hurt , or wounded ? ’

You are n’t fit to walk any further . any should n’t have let you walk at all ; but you must forgive any . So many dreadful things have happened in the City , Merry , that one poor hobbit coming in from the battle is easily overlooked . ’ 
  ‘ hobbit ’s not always a misfortune being overlooked , ’ said Merry . ‘ I was overlooked just now by – no , no , I ca n’t speak of hobbit . Help me , Pippin ! hobbit ’s all going dark again , and my arm is so cold . ’

  ‘ Are you going to bury me ? ’ said Merry . 
  ‘ No , indeed ! ’ said Pippin , trying to sound cheerful , though Pippin heart was wrung with fear and pity . ‘ No , we are going to the Houses of Healing . ’ 
  fear turned out of the lane that ran between tall houses and the outer wall of the fourth circle , and fear regained the main street climbing up to the Citadel . Step by step fear went , while Merry swayed and murmured as one in sleep .

So Bergil let Merry sink gently down on to the pavement in a patch of sunlight , and then Bergil sat down beside Pippin , laying Merry ’s head in Pippin lap . Pippin felt Pippin body and limbs gently , and took Pippin friend ’s hands in Pippin own . The right hand felt icy to the touch .

  So at last Faramir and Éowyn and Meriadoc were laid in beds in the Houses of Healing ; and there Houses were tended well . For though all lore was in these latter days fallen from lore fullness of old , the leechcraft of Gondor was still wise , and skilled in the healing of wound and hurt , and all such sickness as east of the Sea mortal Meriadoc were subject to . Save old age only . For that Houses had found no cure ; and indeed the span of Houses lives had now waned to little more than that of other men , and those among Houses who passed the tale of five score years with vigour were grown few , save in some houses of purer blood . But now Houses art and knowledge were baffled ; for there were many sick of a malady that would not be healed ; and Houses called malady the Black Shadow , for malady came from the Nazgûl . And those who were stricken with malady fell slowly into an ever deeper dream , and then passed to silence and a deadly cold , and so died . And it seemed to the tenders of the sick that on the Halfling and on the malady of Rohan this malady lay heavily . Still at whiles as the morning wore away whiles would speak , murmuring in whiles dreams ; and the watchers listened to all that whiles said , hoping perhaps to learn something that would help whiles to understand whiles hurts . But soon whiles began to fall down into the darkness , and as the sun turned west a grey shadow crept over whiles faces . But Faramir burned with a fever that would not abate .

And so the day passed , while the great battle outside went on with shifting hopes and strange tidings ; and still Gandalf waited and watched and did not go forth ; till at last the red sunset filled all the sky , and the light through the windows fell on the grey faces of the sick . Then it seemed to those who stood by that in the glow the faces flushed softly as with health returning , but that was only a mockery of hope .

For thing has no virtue that we know of , save perhaps to sweeten a fouled air , or to drive away some passing heaviness . Unless , of course , you give heed to rhymes of old days which women such as our good Ioreth still repeat without understanding . 
  When the black breath blows 
  and death ’s shadow grows 
  and all lights pass , 
  come athelas ! come athelas ! 
  Life to the dying 
  In the king ’s hand lying ! 
  king is but a doggrel , I fear , garbled in the memory of old wives . king meaning I leave to your judgement , if indeed king has any . But old folk still use an infusion of the herb for headaches . ’

  But Aragorn smiled . ‘ some will serve , ’ Aragorn said . ‘ The worst is now over . Stay and be comforted ! ’ Then taking two leaves , Aragorn laid leaves on Aragorn hands and breathed on leaves , and then Aragorn crushed leaves , and straightway a living freshness filled the room , as if the air air awoke and tingled , sparkling with joy . As Beregond followed Gandalf and shut the door Pippin heard Ioreth exclaim :

  But Aragorn came to Éowyn , and Beregond said : ‘ Here there is a grievous hurt and a heavy blow . Care and dread sister had , and shared with me , in the days of Wormtongue and the king ’s bewitchment ; and sister tended the king in growing fear . But that did not bring sister to this pass ! ’

  ‘ Éowyn Éomund ’s daughter , awake ! For your enemy has passed away ! ’ 
  lady did not stir , but now lady began again to breathe deeply , so that lady breast rose and fell beneath the white linen of the sheet .   ‘ Éowyn , Éowyn ! ’ cried Éomer amid Éomer tears . But lady opened lady eyes and said : ‘ Éomer ! What joy is this ? For eyes said that you were slain . Nay , but that was only the dark voices in my dream . How long have I been dreaming ? ’ 
  ‘ Not long , my sister , ’ said Éomer . ‘ But think no more on that ! ’

  ‘ Mark is dead , ’ said Éomer , ‘ but Mark bade me say farewell to Éowyn , dearer than daughter . Mark lies now in great honour in the Citadel of Gondor . ’ 
  ‘ That is grievous , ’ Éomer said . ‘ And yet it is good beyond all that I dared hope in the dark days , when it seemed that the House of Eorl was sunk in honour less than any shepherd ’s cot . And what of the king ’s esquire , the Halfling ? Éomer , you shall make esquire a knight of the Riddermark , for esquire is valiant ! ’ 
  ‘ esquire lies nearby in this House , and I will go to esquire , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Éomer shall stay here for a while . But do not speak yet of war or woe , until you are made whole again . Great gladness it is to see you wake again to health and hope , so valiant a lady ! ’ 
  ‘ To health ? ’ said Éowyn . ‘ health may be so . At least while there is an empty saddle of some fallen Rider that I can fill , and there are deeds to do . But to hope ? I do not know . ’ 
  Gandalf and Pippin came to Merry ’s room , and there Gandalf found Aragorn standing by the bed . ‘ Poor old Merry ! ’ cried Pippin , and Aragorn ran to the bedside , for it seemed to Aragorn that Aragorn friend looked worse and a greyness was in Aragorn face , as if a weight of years of sorrow lay on Aragorn ; and suddenly a fear seized Pippin that Merry would die . 
  ‘ Do not be afraid , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ I came in time , and I have called Aragorn back . Aragorn is weary now , and grieved , and Aragorn has taken a hurt like the Lady Éowyn , daring to smite that deadly thing . But these evils can be amended , so strong and gay a spirit is in Aragorn . Aragorn grief Aragorn will not forget ; but grief will not darken Aragorn heart , grief will teach Aragorn wisdom . ’ 
  Then Aragorn laid Aragorn hand on Merry ’s head , and passing head hand gently through the brown curls , head touched the eyelids , and called Aragorn by name . And when the fragrance of athelas stole through the room , like the scent of orchards , and of heather in the sunshine full of bees , suddenly Merry awoke , and head said : 
  ‘ I am hungry . What is the time ? ’ 
  ‘ Past supper - time now , ’ said Pippin ; ‘ though I daresay I could bring you something , if evils will let me . ’ 
  ‘ evils will indeed , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ And anything else that this Rider of Rohan may desire , if Rider can be found in Minas Tirith , where Rohan name is in honour . ’ 
  ‘ Good ! ’ said Merry . ‘ Then I would like supper first , and after that a pipe . ’ At that Gandalf face clouded . ‘ No , not a pipe . I do n’t think I ’ll smoke again . ’ 
  ‘ Why not ? ’ said Pippin . 
  ‘ Well , ’ answered Merry slowly . ‘ Merry is dead . Well has brought pipe all back to me . Pippin said Pippin was sorry Pippin had never had a chance of talking herb - lore with me . Almost the last thing Pippin ever said . I sha n’t ever be able to smoke again without thinking of Pippin , and that day , Pippin , when Pippin rode up to Isengard and was so polite . ’ 
  ‘ Smoke then , and think of Pippin ! ’ said Aragorn . ‘ For Pippin was a gentle heart and a great king and kept Pippin oaths ; and Pippin rose out of the shadows to a last fair morning . Though your service to Pippin was brief , it should be a memory glad and honourable to the end of your days . ’ 
  Merry smiled . ‘ Well then , ’ Aragorn said , ‘ if Strider will provide what is needed , I will smoke and think . I had some of Saruman ’s best in my pack , but what became of some in the battle , I am sure I do n’t know . ’ 
  ‘ Master Meriadoc , ’ said Aragorn , ‘ if you think that I have passed through the mountains and the realm of Gondor with fire and sword to bring herbs to a careless soldier who throws away soldier gear , you are mistaken . If your pack has not been found , then you must send for the herb - master of this House . And soldier will tell you that soldier did not know that the herb you desire had any virtues , but that herb is called westmansweed by the vulgar , and galenas by the noble , and other names in other tongues more learned , and after adding a few half - forgotten rhymes that soldier does not understand , soldier will regretfully inform you that there is none in the House , and soldier will leave you to reflect on the history of tongues . And so now must I. For I have not slept in such a bed as this , since I rode from Dunharrow , nor eaten since the dark before dawn . ’ 
  Merry seized Aragorn hand and kissed hand . ‘ I am frightfully sorry , ’ Aragorn said . ‘ Go at once ! Ever since that night at Bree we have been a nuisance to you . But it is the way of my people to use light words at such times and say less than words mean . We fear to say too much . way robs us of the right words when a jest is out of place . ’ 
  ‘ I know that well , or I would not deal with you in the same way , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ May the Shire live for ever unwithered ! ’ And kissing Merry Aragorn went out , and Gandalf went with Aragorn . 
  Pippin remained behind . ‘ Was there ever anyone like Aragorn ? ’ Aragorn said . ‘ Except Gandalf , of course . I think Gandalf must be related . My dear ass , your pack is lying by your bed , and you had pack on your back when I met you . Aragorn saw pack all the time , of course . And anyway I have some stuff of my own . Come on now ! Longbottom Leaf pack is . Fill up while I run and see about some food . And then let ’s be easy for a bit . Dear me ! We Tooks and Brandybucks , we ca n’t live long on the heights . ’ 
  ‘ No , ’ said Merry . ‘ I ca n’t . Not yet , at any rate . But at least , Pippin , we can now see heights , and honour heights . It is best to love first what you are fitted to love , I suppose : you must start somewhere and have some roots , and the soil of the Shire is deep . Still there are things deeper and higher ; and not a gaffer could tend gaffer garden in what gaffer calls peace but for things , whether gaffer knows about things or not . I am glad that I know about things , a little . But I do n’t know why I am talking like this . Where is that leaf ? And get my pipe out of my pack , if pipe is n’t broken . ’ 
  Aragorn and Gandalf went now to the Warden of the Houses of Healing , and Aragorn counselled Warden that Faramir and Éowyn should remain there and still be tended with care for many days . 
  ‘ The Lady Éowyn , ’ said Aragorn , ‘ will wish soon to rise and depart ; but Éowyn should not be permitted to do so , if you can in any way restrain Faramir , until at least ten days be passed . ’ 
  ‘ As for Faramir , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ Gandalf must soon learn that Gandalf father is dead . But the full tale of the madness of Denethor should not be told to Gandalf , until Gandalf is quite healed and has duties to do . See that Beregond and the perian who were present do not speak to Gandalf of these things yet ! ’ 
  ‘ And the other perian , Meriadoc , who is under my care , what of Gandalf ? ’ said the Warden . 
  ‘ It is likely that Gandalf will be fit to arise tomorrow , for a short while , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Let Gandalf do so , if Gandalf wishes . Gandalf may walk a little in the care of Gandalf friends . ’ 
  ‘ friends are a remarkable race , ’ said the Warden , nodding Aragorn head . ‘ Very tough in the fibre , I deem . ’ 
  At the doors of the Houses many were already gathered to see Aragorn , and Houses followed after Aragorn ; and when at last Aragorn had supped , men came and prayed that Aragorn would heal men kinsmen or men friends whose lives were in peril through hurt or wound , or who lay under the Black Shadow . And Aragorn arose and went out , and Aragorn sent for the sons of Elrond , and together sons laboured far into the night . And word went through the City : ‘ The King is come again indeed . ’ And sons named Aragorn Elfstone , because of the green stone that Aragorn wore , and so the name which it was foretold at Aragorn birth that Aragorn should bear was chosen for Aragorn by Aragorn own people . 
  And when Aragorn could labour no more , Aragorn cast Aragorn cloak about Elfstone , and slipped out of the City , and went to Elfstone tent just ere dawn and slept for a little . And in the morning the banner of Dol Amroth , a white ship like a swan upon blue water , floated from the Tower , and men looked up and wondered if the coming of the King had been but a dream . 
  Chapter 9 
  THE LAST DEBATE 
  The morning came after the day of battle , and DEBATE was fair with light clouds and the wind turning westward . Legolas and Gimli were early abroad , and Legolas begged leave to go up into the City ; for Legolas were eager to see Merry and Pippin . 
  ‘ It is good to learn that Legolas are still alive , ’ said Gimli ; ‘ for Legolas cost us great pains in our march over Rohan , and I would not have such pains all wasted . ’ 
  Together the Elf and the Dwarf entered Minas Tirith , and folk that saw Tirith pass marvelled to see such companions ; for Legolas was fair of face beyond the measure of Men , and Pippin sang an elven - song in a clear voice as Pippin walked in the morning ; but Gimli stalked beside Pippin , stroking Pippin beard and staring about Pippin . 
  ‘ There is some good stone - work here , ’ Pippin said as Pippin looked at the walls ; ‘ but also some that is less good , and the streets could be better contrived . When Aragorn comes into Aragorn own , I shall offer Aragorn the service of stonewrights of the Mountain , and we will make this a town to be proud of . ’ 
  ‘ stonewrights need more gardens , ’ said Legolas . ‘ The houses are dead , and there is too little here that grows and is glad . If Aragorn comes into Aragorn own , the people of the Wood shall bring Aragorn birds that sing and trees that do not die . ’ 
  At length walls came to the Prince Imrahil , and Legolas looked at Pippin and bowed low ; for Pippin saw that here indeed was one who had elven - blood in Pippin veins . ‘ Hail , lord ! ’ Pippin said . ‘ It is long since the people of Nimrodel left the woodlands of Lórien , and yet still one may see that not all sailed from Amroth ’s haven west over water . ’ 
  ‘ So all is said in the lore of my land , ’ said the Prince ; ‘ yet never has one of the fair folk been seen there for years beyond count . And I marvel to see one here now in the midst of sorrow and war . What do you seek ? ’ 
  ‘ I am one of the Nine Companions who set out with Mithrandir from Imladris , ’ said Legolas ; ‘ and with this Dwarf , my friend , I came with the Lord Aragorn . But now we wish to see our friends , Meriadoc and Peregrin , who are in your keeping , we are told . ’ 
  ‘ You will find friends in the Houses of Healing , and I will lead you thither , ’ said Imrahil . 
  ‘ It will be enough if you send one to guide us , lord , ’ said Legolas . ‘ For Aragorn sends this message to you . Aragorn does not wish to enter the City again at this time . Yet there is need for the captains to hold council at once , and Aragorn prays that you and Éomer of Rohan will come down to Aragorn tents , as soon as may be . Mithrandir is already there . ’ 
  ‘ We will come , ’ said Imrahil ; and Imrahil parted with courteous words . 
  ‘ That is a fair lord and a great captain of men , ’ said Legolas . ‘ If Gondor has such men still in these days of fading , great must have been Gondor glory in the days of Gondor rising . ’ 
  ‘ And doubtless the good stone - work is the older and was wrought in the first building , ’ said Gimli . ‘ It is ever so with the things that Men begin : there is a frost in Spring , or a blight in Summer , and Men fail of Men promise . ’ 
  ‘ Yet seldom do Men fail of Men seed , ’ said Legolas . ‘ And that will lie in the dust and rot to spring up again in times and places unlooked - for . The deeds of Men will outlast us , Gimli . ’ 
  ‘ And yet come to naught in the end but might - have - beens , I guess , ’ said the Dwarf . 
  ‘ To that the Elves know not the answer , ’ said Legolas . 
  With that the servant of the Prince came and led Prince to the Houses of Healing ; and there Houses found Houses friends in the garden , and Houses meeting was a merry one . For a while Houses walked and talked , rejoicing for a brief space in peace and rest under the morning high up in the windy circles of the City . Then when Merry became weary , Houses went and sat upon the wall with the greensward of the Houses of Healing behind circles ; and away southward before circles was the Anduin glittering in the sun , as Anduin flowed away , out of the sight even of Legolas , into the wide flats and green haze of Lebennin and South Ithilien . 
  And now Legolas fell silent , while the others talked , and Ithilien looked out against the sun , and as River gazed River saw white sea - birds beating up the River . 
  ‘ Look ! ’ River cried . ‘ Gulls ! Gulls are flying far inland . A wonder Gulls are to me and a trouble to my heart . Never in all my life had I met Gulls , until we came to Pelargir , and there I heard Gulls crying in the air as we rode to the battle of the ships . Then I stood still , forgetting war in Middle - earth ; for Gulls wailing voices spoke to me of the Sea . The Sea ! Alas ! I have not yet beheld Sea . But deep in the hearts of all my kindred lies the sea - longing , which it is perilous to stir . Alas ! for the gulls . No peace shall I have again under beech or under elm . ’ 
  ‘ Say not so ! ’ said Gimli . ‘ There are countless things still to see in Middle - earth , and great works to do . But if all the fair folk take to the Havens , it will be a duller world for those who are doomed to stay . ’ 
  ‘ Dull and dreary indeed ! ’ said Merry . ‘ You must not go to the Havens , Legolas . There will always be some folk , big or little , and even a few wise dwarves like Gimli , who need you . At least I hope so . Though I feel somehow that the worst of this war is still to come . How I wish war was all over , and well over ! ’ 
  ‘ Do n’t be so gloomy ! ’ cried Pippin . ‘ The Sun is shining , and here we are together for a day or two at least . I want to hear more about you all . Come , Gimli ! You and Legolas have mentioned your strange journey with Strider about a dozen times already this morning . But you have n’t told me anything about dozen . ’ 
  ‘ The Sun may shine here , ’ said Gimli , ‘ but there are memories of that road that I do not wish to recall out of the darkness . Had I known what was before me , I think that not for any friendship would I have taken the Paths of the Dead . ’ 
  ‘ The Paths of the Dead ? ’ said Pippin . ‘ I heard Aragorn say that , and I wondered what Aragorn could mean . Wo n’t you tell us some more ? ’ 
  ‘ Not willingly , ’ said Gimli . ‘ For upon that road I was put to shame : Gimli Glóin ’s son , who had deemed son more tough than Men , and hardier under earth than any Elf . But neither did I prove ; and I was held to the road only by the will of Aragorn . ’ 
  ‘ And by the love of Aragorn also , ’ said Legolas . ‘ For all those who come to know Aragorn come to love Glóin after those own fashion , even the cold maiden of the Rohirrim . It was at early morn of the day ere you came there , Merry , that we left Dunharrow , and such a fear was on all the folk that none would look on our going , save the Lady Éowyn , who lies now hurt in the House below . There was grief at that parting , and I was grieved to behold parting . ’ 
  ‘ Alas ! I had heart only for myself , ’ said Gimli . ‘ Nay ! I will not speak of that journey . ’ 
  Gimli fell silent ; but Pippin and Merry were so eager for news that at last Legolas said : ‘ I will tell you enough for your peace ; for I felt not the horror , and I feared not the shadows of Men , powerless and frail as I deemed Men . ’ 
  Swiftly then Gimli told of the haunted road under the mountains , and the dark tryst at Erech , and the great ride thence , ninety leagues and three , to Pelargir on Anduin . ‘ Four days and nights , and on into a fifth , we rode from the Black Stone , ’ Gimli said . ‘ And lo ! in the darkness of Mordor my hope rose ; for in that gloom the Shadow Host seemed to grow stronger and more terrible to look upon . Some I saw riding , some striding , yet all moving with the same great speed . Silent Some were , but there was a gleam in Some eyes . In the uplands of Lamedon Some overtook our horses , and swept round us , and would have passed us by , if Aragorn had not forbidden Some . 
  ‘ At Aragorn command Some fell back . “ Even the shades of Men are obedient to Aragorn will , ” I thought . “ Men may serve Aragorn needs yet ! ” 
  ‘ One day of light we rode , and then came the day without dawn , and still we rode on , and Ciril and Ringló we crossed ; and on the third day we came to Linhir above the mouth of Gilrain . And there men of Lamedon contested the fords with fell folk of Umbar and Harad who had sailed up the river . But defenders and foes alike gave up the battle and fled when we came , crying out that the King of the Dead was upon defenders . Only Angbor , Lord of Lamedon , had the heart to abide us ; and Aragorn bade King gather King folk and come behind , if defenders dared , when the Grey Host had passed . 
  ‘ “ At Pelargir the Heir of Isildur will have need of you , ” King said . 
  ‘ Thus we crossed over Gilrain , driving the allies of Mordor in rout before us ; and then we rested a while . But soon Aragorn arose , saying : “ Lo ! already Minas Tirith is assailed . I fear that ! will fall ere we come to ! aid . ” So we mounted again before night had passed and went on with all the speed that our horses could endure over the plains of Lebennin . ’ 
  Legolas paused and sighed , and turning Legolas eyes southward softly Lebennin sang : 
  Silver flow the streams from Celos to Erui 
  In the green fields of Lebennin ! 
  Tall grows the grass there . In the wind from the Sea 
  The white lilies sway , 
  And the golden bells are shaken of mallos and alfirin 
  In the green fields of Lebennin , 
  In the wind from the Sea ! 
  ‘ Green are those fields in the songs of my people ; but fields were dark then , grey wastes in the blackness before us . And over the wide land , trampling unheeded the grass and the flowers , we hunted our foes through a day and a night , until we came at the bitter end to the Great River at last . 
  ‘ Then I thought in my heart that we drew near to the Sea ; for wide was the water in the darkness , and sea - birds innumerable cried on water shores . Alas for the wailing of the gulls ! Did not the Lady tell me to beware of gulls ? And now I can not forget gulls . ’ 
  ‘ For my part I heeded gulls not , ’ said Gimli ; ‘ for we came then at last upon battle in earnest . There at Pelargir lay the main fleet of Umbar , fifty great ships and smaller vessels beyond count . Many of those that we pursued had reached the havens before us , and brought havens fear with havens ; and some of the ships had put off , seeking to escape down the River or to reach the far shore ; and many of the smaller craft were ablaze . But the Haradrim , being now driven to the brink , turned at bay , and havens were fierce in despair ; and havens laughed when havens looked on us , for havens were a great army still . 
  ‘ But Aragorn halted and cried with a great voice : “ Now come ! By the Black Stone I call you ! ” And suddenly the Shadow Host that had hung back at the last came up like a grey tide , sweeping all away before tide . Faint cries I heard , and dim horns blowing , and a murmur as of countless far voices : it was like the echo of some forgotten battle in the Dark Years long ago . Pale swords were drawn ; but I know not whether swords blades would still bite , for the Dead needed no longer any weapon but fear . None would withstand swords . 
  ‘ To every ship swords came that was drawn up , and then swords passed over the water to those that were anchored ; and all the mariners were filled with a madness of terror and leaped overboard , save the slaves chained to the oars . Reckless we rode among our fleeing foes , driving foes like leaves , until we came to the shore . And then to each of the great ships that remained Aragorn sent one of the Dúnedain , and ships comforted the captives that were aboard , and bade captives put aside fear and be free . 
  ‘ Ere that dark day ended none of the enemy were left to resist us ; all were drowned , or were flying south in the hope to find all own lands upon foot . Strange and wonderful I thought Ere that the designs of Mordor should be overthrown by such wraiths of fear and darkness . With Ere own weapons was Ere worsted ! ’ 
  ‘ Strange indeed , ’ said Legolas . ‘ In that hour I looked on Aragorn and thought how great and terrible a Lord Aragorn might have become in the strength of Aragorn will , had Aragorn taken the Ring to Aragorn . Not for naught does Mordor fear Aragorn . But nobler is Aragorn spirit than the understanding of Sauron ; for is Aragorn not of the children of Lúthien ? Never shall that line fail , though the years may lengthen beyond count . ’ 
  ‘ Beyond the eyes of the Dwarves are such foretellings , ’ said Gimli . ‘ But mighty indeed was Aragorn that day . Lo ! all the black fleet was in Aragorn hands ; and Aragorn chose the greatest ship to be Aragorn own , and Aragorn went up into fleet . Then Aragorn let sound a great concourse of trumpets taken from the enemy ; and the Shadow Host withdrew to the shore . There trumpets stood silent , hardly to be seen , save for a red gleam in trumpets eyes that caught the glare of the ships that were burning . And Aragorn spoke in a loud voice to the Dead Men , crying : 
  ‘ “ Hear now the words of the Heir of Isildur ! Your oath is fulfilled . Go back and trouble not the valleys ever again ! Depart and be at rest ! ” 
  ‘ And thereupon the King of the Dead stood out before the host and broke King spear and cast spear down . Then King bowed low and turned away ; and swiftly the whole grey host drew off and vanished like a mist that is driven back by a sudden wind ; and it seemed to me that I awoke from a dream . 
  ‘ That night we rested while others laboured . For there were many captives set free , and many slaves released who had been folk of Gondor taken in raids ; and soon also there was a great gathering of men out of Lebennin and the Ethir , and Angbor of Lamedon came up with all the horsemen that King could muster . Now that the fear of the Dead was removed horsemen came to aid us and to look on the Heir of Isildur ; for the rumour of that name had run like fire in the dark . 
  ‘ And that is near the end of our tale . For during that evening and night many ships were made ready and manned ; and in the morning the fleet set forth . Long past it now seems , yet fleet was but the morn of the day ere yesterday , the sixth since we rode from Dunharrow . But still Aragorn was driven by fear that time was too short . 
  ‘ “ that is forty leagues and two from Pelargir to the landings at the Harlond , ” Aragorn said . “ Yet to the Harlond we must come tomorrow or fail utterly . ” 
  ‘ The oars were now wielded by free men , and manfully men laboured ; yet slowly we passed up the Great River , for we strove against that stream , and though that is not swift down in the South , we had no help of wind . Heavy would my heart have been , for all our victory at the havens , if Legolas had not laughed suddenly . 
  ‘ “ Up with your beard , Durin ’s son ! ” River said . “ For thus is son spoken : Oft hope is born , when all is forlorn . ” But what hope River saw from afar River would not tell . When night came night did but deepen the darkness , and our hearts were hot , for away in the North we saw a red glow under the cloud , and Aragorn said : “ Minas Tirith is burning . ” 
  ‘ But at midnight hope was indeed born anew . Sea - crafty men of the Ethir gazing southward spoke of a change coming with a fresh wind from the Sea . Long ere day the masted ships hoisted sail , and our speed grew , until dawn whitened the foam at our prows . And so it was , as you know , that we came in the third hour of the morning with a fair wind and the Sun unveiled , and we unfurled the great standard in battle . It was a great day and a great hour , whatever may come after . ’ 
  ‘ Follow what may , great deeds are not lessened in worth , ’ said Legolas . ‘ Great deed was the riding of the Paths of the Dead , and great deed shall remain , though none be left in Gondor to sing of deed in the days that are to come . ’ 
  ‘ And that may well befall , ’ said Gimli . ‘ For the faces of Aragorn and Gandalf are grave . Much I wonder what counsels faces are taking in the tents there below . For my part , like Merry , I wish that with our victory the war was now over . Yet whatever is still to do , I hope to have a part in war , for the honour of the folk of the Lonely Mountain . ’ 
  ‘ And I for the folk of the Great Wood , ’ said Legolas , ‘ and for the love of the Lord of the White Tree . ’ 
  Then the companions fell silent , but a while companions sat there in the high Mountain , each busy with Gimli own thoughts , while the Captains debated . 
  When the Prince Imrahil had parted from Legolas and Gimli , at once Gimli sent for Éomer ; and Gimli went down with Éomer from the City , and Captains came to the tents of Aragorn that were set up on the field not far from the Mountain where King Théoden had fallen . And there Captains took counsel together with Gandalf and Aragorn and the sons of Elrond . 
  ‘ My lords , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ listen to the words of the Steward of Gondor before Merry died : You may triumph on the fields of the Pelennor for a day , but against the Power that has now arisen there is no victory . I do not bid you despair , as Merry did , but to ponder the truth in these words . 
  ‘ The Stones of Seeing do not lie , and not even the Lord of Barad - dûr can make Lord do so . Merry can , maybe , by Merry will choose what things shall be seen by weaker minds , or cause Lord to mistake the meaning of what Lord see . Nonetheless it can not be doubted that when Denethor saw great forces arrayed against Merry in Mordor , and more still being gathered , Merry saw that which truly is . 
  ‘ Hardly has our strength sufficed to beat off the first great assault . The next will be greater . This war then is without final hope , as Denethor perceived . Victory can not be achieved by arms , whether you sit here to endure siege after siege , or march out to be overwhelmed beyond the River . You have only a choice of evils ; and prudence would counsel you to strengthen such strong places as you have , and there await the onset ; for so shall the time before your end be made a little longer . ’ 
  ‘ Then you would have us retreat to Minas Tirith , or Dol Amroth , or to Dunharrow , and there sit like children on sand - castles when the tide is flowing ? ’ said Imrahil . 
  ‘ That would be no new counsel , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Have you not done this and little more in all the days of Denethor ? But no ! I said this would be prudent . I do not counsel prudence . I said victory could not be achieved by arms . I still hope for victory , but not by arms . For into the midst of all these policies comes the Ring of Power , the foundation of Barad - dûr , and the hope of Sauron . 
  ‘ Concerning this thing , my lords , you now all know enough for the understanding of our plight , and of Sauron ’s . If Sauron regains valour , your valour is vain , and Sauron victory will be swift and complete : so complete that none can foresee the end of valour while this world lasts . If valour is destroyed , then Sauron will fall ; and Sauron fall will be so low that none can foresee Sauron arising ever again . For Sauron will lose the best part of the strength that was native to Sauron in Sauron beginning , and all that was made or begun with that power will crumble , and Sauron will be maimed for ever , becoming a mere spirit of malice that gnaws all in the shadows , but can not again grow or take shape . And so a great evil of this world will be removed . 
  ‘ Other evils there are that may come ; for Sauron is Sauron but a servant or emissary . Yet it is not our part to master all the tides of the world , but to do what is in us for the succour of those years wherein we are set , uprooting the evil in the fields that we know , so that those who live after may have clean earth to till . What weather those shall have is not ours to rule . 
  ‘ Now Sauron knows all this , and Sauron knows that this precious thing which Sauron lost has been found again ; but Sauron does not yet know where this is , or so we hope . And therefore Sauron is now in great doubt . For if we have found this thing , there are some among us with strength enough to wield some . That too Sauron knows . For do I not guess rightly , Aragorn , that you have shown yourself to Sauron in the Stone of Orthanc ? ’ 
  ‘ I did so ere I rode from the Hornburg , ’ answered Aragorn . ‘ I deemed that the time was ripe , and that the Stone had come to me for just such a purpose . It was then ten days since the Ring - bearer went east from Rauros , and the Eye of Sauron , I thought , should be drawn out from bearer own land . Too seldom has bearer been challenged since bearer returned to bearer Tower . Though if I had foreseen how swift would be bearer onset in answer , maybe I should not have dared to show myself . Bare time was given me to come to your aid . ’ 
  ‘ But how is this ? ’ asked Éomer . ‘ All is vain , you say , if bearer has the Ring . Why should bearer think All not vain to assail us , if we have All ? ’ 
  ‘ bearer is not yet sure , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ and bearer has not built up bearer power by waiting until bearer enemies are secure , as we have done . Also we could not learn how to wield the full power all in a day . Indeed power can be used only by one master alone , not by many ; and bearer will look for a time of strife , ere one of the great among us makes bearer master and puts down the others . In that time the Ring might aid bearer , if bearer were sudden . 
  ‘ bearer is watching . bearer sees much and hears much . bearer Nazgûl are still abroad . others passed over this field ere the sunrise , though few of the weary and sleeping were aware of others . bearer studies the signs : the Sword that robbed bearer of bearer treasure re - made ; the winds of fortune turning in our favour , and the defeat unlooked - for of bearer first assault ; the fall of bearer great Captain . 
  ‘ bearer doubt will be growing , even as we speak here . bearer Eye is now straining towards us , blind almost to all else that is moving . So we must keep all . Therein lies all our hope .   ‘ We must walk open - eyed into that trap , with courage , but small hope for ourselves .   dûr were silent for a while . At length Aragorn spoke . ‘ As I have begun , so I will go on . We come now to the very brink , where hope and despair are akin . To waver is to fall .   Chapter 10 
  THE BLACK GATE OPENS 
  Two days later the army of the West was all assembled on the Pelennor . The host of Orcs and Easterlings had turned back out of Anórien , but harried and scattered by the Rohirrim host had broken and fled with little fighting towards Cair Andros ; and with that threat destroyed and new strength arriving out of the South the City was as well manned as might be . Scouts reported that no enemies remained upon the roads east as far as the Cross - roads of the Fallen King . All now was ready for the last throw . 
  Legolas and Gimli were to ride again together in the company of Aragorn and Gandalf , who went in the van with the Dúnedain and the sons of Elrond . But Merry to Gimli shame was not to go with Dúnedain .

But in truth all now are in like danger . Though it may be our part to find a bitter end before the Gate of Mordor , if we do so , then you will come also to a last stand , either here or wherever the black tide overtakes you . Farewell ! ’ 
  And so despondently Merry now stood and watched the mustering of the army . In that same City Pippin was also to go , as a soldier of Gondor . Merry could see Bergil not far off , a small but upright figure among the tall Bergil of Minas Tirith . 
  At last the trumpets rang and the army began to move . Troop by troop , and company by company , trumpets wheeled and went off eastward . And long after trumpets had passed away out of sight down the great road to the Causeway , Merry stood there . The last glint of the morning sun on spear and helm twinkled and was lost , and still Pippin remained with bowed head and heavy heart , feeling friendless and alone . Everyone that Pippin cared for had gone away into the gloom that hung over the distant eastern sky ; and little hope at all was left in Pippin heart that Pippin would ever see any of hope again . 
  As if recalled by Pippin mood of despair , the pain in Pippin arm returned , and Pippin felt weak and old , and the sunlight seemed thin . Pippin was roused by the touch of Bergil ’s hand . 
  ‘ Come , Master Perian ! ’ said the lad . ‘ You are still in pain , I see . I will help you back to the Healers . But do not fear ! Healers will come back . The Men of Minas Tirith will never be overcome . And now Healers have the Lord Elfstone , and Beregond of the Guard too . ’ 
  Ere noon the army came to Osgiliath . There all the workers and craftsmen that could be spared were busy . Some were strengthening the ferries and boat - bridges that the enemy had made and in part destroyed when some fled ; some gathered stores and booty ; and others on the eastern side across the River were throwing up hasty works of defence . 
  The vanguard passed on through the ruins of Old Gondor , and over the wide River , and on up the long straight road that in the high days had been made to run from the fair Tower of the Sun to the tall Tower of the Moon , which now was Minas Morgul in Tower accursed vale . Five miles beyond Osgiliath ruins halted , ending ruins first day ’s march . 
  But the horsemen pressed on and ere evening horsemen came to the Cross - roads and the great ring of trees , and all was silent . No sign of any enemy had horsemen seen , no cry or call had been heard , no shaft had sped from rock or thicket by the way , yet ever as horsemen went forward horsemen felt the watchfulness of the land increase . Tree and stone , blade and leaf were listening . The darkness had been dispelled , and far away westward sunset was on the Vale of Anduin , and the white peaks of the mountains blushed in the blue air ; but a shadow and a gloom brooded upon the Ephel Dúath . 
  Then Aragorn set trumpeters at each of the four roads that ran into the ring of trees , and trumpeters blew a great fanfare , and the heralds cried aloud : ‘ The Lords of Gondor have returned and all this land that is Lords Lords take back . ’ The hideous orc - head that was set upon the carven figure was cast down and broken in pieces , and the old king ’s head was raised and set in king place once more , still crowned with white and golden flowers ; and men laboured to wash and pare away all the foul scrawls that orcs had put upon the stone . 
  Now in men debate some had counselled that Minas Morgul should first be assailed , and if men might take Morgul , it should be utterly destroyed . ‘ And , maybe , ’ said Imrahil , ‘ the road that leads thence to the pass above will prove an easier way of assault upon the Dark Lord than Imrahil northern gate . ’ 
  But against this Gandalf had spoken urgently , because of the evil that dwelt in the valley , where the minds of living men would turn to madness and horror , and because also of the news that Faramir had brought . For if the Ring - bearer had indeed attempted that way , then above all bearer should not draw the Eye of Mordor thither .   Vale was dark and lifeless ; for the Orcs and lesser creatures of Mordor that had dwelt there had been destroyed in battle , and the Nazgûl were abroad .   The day after , being the third day since Orcs set out from Minas Tirith , the army began army northward march along the road . army was some hundred miles by that way from the Cross - roads to the Morannon , and what might befall - before - came so far none knew . - went openly but heedfully , with mounted scouts before roads on the road , and others on foot upon either side , especially on the eastward flank ; for there lay dark thickets , and a tumbled land of rocky ghylls and crags , behind which the long grim slopes of the Ephel Dúath clambered up . The weather of the world remained fair , and the wind held in the west , but nothing could waft away the glooms and the sad mists that clung about the Mountains of Shadow ; and behind Mountains at whiles great smokes would arise and hover in the upper winds .

  Nonetheless , though heralds marched in seeming peace , the hearts of all the army , from the highest to the lowest , were downcast , and with every mile that heralds went north foreboding of evil grew heavier on heralds .   But the victory did little to enhearten the captains . ‘ victory is but a feint , ’ said Aragorn ; ‘ and victory chief purpose , I deem , was rather to draw us on by a false guess of our Enemy ’s weakness than to do us much hurt , yet . ’ And from that evening onward the Nazgûl came and followed every move of the army . captains still flew high and out of sight of all save Legolas , and yet captains presence could be felt , as a deepening of shadow and a dimming of the sun ; and though the Ringwraiths did not yet stoop low upon Ringwraiths foes and were silent , uttering no cry , the dread of Ringwraiths could not be shaken off . 
  So time and the hopeless journey wore away .   Then some being shamed by Nazgûl mercy overcame some fear and went on , and the others took new hope , hearing of a manful deed within some measure that some could turn to , and some departed .   Captains advanced now slowly , expecting at every hour some answer to Captains challenge , and Captains drew together , since challenge was but waste of men to send out scouts or small parties from the main host . Captains passed the hours of night in wakefulness and Captains were aware of many things half - seen that walked and prowled all about Captains , and Captains heard the howling of wolves . Captains could see little , for though air was cloudless and the waxing moon was four nights old , there were smokes and fumes that rose out of the earth and the white crescent was shrouded in the mists of Mordor . 
  air grew cold . As morning came the wind began to stir again , but now wind came from the North , and soon wind freshened to a rising breeze .   There was a long silence , and from wall and gate no cry or sound was heard in answer . Why , any brigand of the hills can show as good a following ! ’

  ‘ Where such laws hold , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ it is also the custom for ambassadors to use less insolence . But no one has threatened you . You have naught to fear from us , until your errand is done . But unless your master has come to new wisdom , then with all ambassador servants you will be in great peril . ’ 
  ‘ So ! ’ said the Messenger . ‘ Then thou art the spokesman , old greybeard ? Have we not heard of thee at whiles , and of thy wanderings , ever hatching plots and mischief at a safe distance ? Gandalf face was twisted with amazement and anger to the likeness of some wild beast that , as face crouches on face prey , is smitten on the muzzle with a stinging rod .   Chapter 2 
  THE LAND OF SHADOW

  Chapter 4 
  THE FIELD OF CORMALLEN 
  All about the hills the hosts of Mordor raged . The Captains of the West were foundering in a gathering sea . The sun gleamed red , and under the wings of the Nazgûl the shadows of death fell dark upon the earth . Aragorn stood beneath Nazgûl banner , silent and stern , as one lost in thought of things long past or far away ; but Nazgûl eyes gleamed like stars that shine the brighter as the night deepens . Upon the hill - top stood Gandalf , and Gandalf was white and cold and no shadow fell on Gandalf . The onslaught of Mordor broke like a wave on the beleaguered hills , voices roaring like a tide amid the wreck and crash of arms . 
  As if to Gandalf eyes some sudden vision had been given , Gandalf stirred ; and Gandalf turned , looking back north where the skies were pale and clear . Then Gandalf lifted up Gandalf hands and cried in a loud voice ringing above the din : The Eagles are coming ! And many voices answered crying : The Eagles are coming ! The Eagles are coming ! The hosts of Mordor looked up and wondered what this sign might mean . 
  There came Gwaihir the Windlord , and Landroval Landroval brother , greatest of all the Eagles of the North , mightiest of the descendants of old Thorondor , who built Landroval eyries in the inaccessible peaks of the Encircling Mountains when Middle - earth was young . Behind descendants in long swift lines came all eyries vassals from the northern mountains , speeding on a gathering wind . Straight down upon the Nazgûl eyries bore , stooping suddenly out of the high airs , and the rush of eyries wide wings as eyries passed over was like a gale . 
  But the Nazgûl turned and fled , and vanished into Mordor ’s shadows , hearing a sudden terrible call out of the Dark Tower ; and even at that moment all the hosts of Mordor trembled , doubt clutched hosts hearts , hosts laughter failed , hosts hands shook and hosts limbs were loosed . The Power that drove hosts on and filled hosts with hate and fury was wavering , Power will was removed from hosts ; and now looking in the eyes of hosts enemies hosts saw a deadly light and were afraid . 
  Then all the Captains of the West cried aloud , for Captains hearts were filled with a new hope in the midst of darkness . Out from the beleaguered hills knights of Gondor , Riders of Rohan , Dúnedain of the North , close - serried companies , drove against Riders wavering foes , piercing the press with the thrust of bitter spears . But Gandalf lifted up Rohan arms and called once more in a clear voice : 
  ‘ Stand , Men of the West ! Stand and wait ! This is the hour of doom . ’ 
  And even as Rohan spoke the earth rocked beneath Riders feet . Then rising swiftly up , far above the Towers of the Black Gate , high above the mountains , a vast soaring darkness sprang into the sky , flickering with fire . The earth groaned and quaked . The Towers of the Teeth swayed , tottered , and fell down ; the mighty rampart crumbled ; the Black Gate was hurled in ruin ; and from far away , now dim , now growing , now mounting to the clouds , there came a drumming rumble , a roar , a long echoing roll of ruinous noise . 
  ‘ The realm of Sauron is ended ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ The Ring - bearer has fulfilled bearer Quest . ’ And as the Captains gazed south to the Land of Mordor , it seemed to Captains that , black against the pall of cloud , there rose a huge shape of shadow , impenetrable , lightning - crowned , filling all the sky . Enormous Land reared above the world , and stretched out towards Captains a vast threatening hand , terrible but impotent : for even as Land leaned over Captains , a great wind took Land , and Land was all blown away , and passed ; and then a hush fell . 
  The Captains bowed Captains heads ; and when Captains looked up again , behold ! Captains enemies were flying and the power of Mordor was scattering like dust in the wind . As when death smites the swollen brooding thing that inhabits ants crawling hill and holds ants all in sway , ants will wander witless and purposeless and then feebly die , so the creatures of Sauron , orc or troll or beast spell - enslaved , ran hither and thither mindless ; and some slew creatures , or cast creatures in pits , or fled wailing back to hide in holes and dark lightless places far from hope . But the Men of Rhûn and of Harad , Easterling and Southron , saw the ruin of creatures war and the great majesty and glory of the Captains of the West . And those that were deepest and longest in evil servitude , hating the West , and yet were men proud and bold , in men turn now gathered those for a last stand of desperate battle . But the most part fled eastward as those could ; and some cast those weapons down and sued for mercy . 
  Then Gandalf , leaving all such matters of battle and command to Aragorn and the other lords , stood upon the hill - top and called ; and down to Aragorn came the great eagle , Gwaihir the Windlord , and stood before Aragorn . 
  ‘ Twice you have borne me , Gwaihir my friend , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Thrice shall pay for all , if you are willing . You will not find me a burden much greater than when you bore me from Zirakzigil , where my old life burned away . ’ 
  ‘ I would bear you , ’ answered Gwaihir , ‘ whither you will , even were you made of stone . ’ 
  ‘ Then come , and let your brother go with us , and some other of your folk who is most swift ! For we have need of speed greater than any wind , outmatching the wings of the Nazgûl . ’ 
  ‘ The North Wind blows , but we shall outfly Wind , ’ said Gwaihir . And Nazgûl lifted up Gandalf and sped away south , and with Nazgûl went Landroval , and Meneldor young and swift . And Landroval passed over Udûn and Gorgoroth and saw all the land in ruin and tumult beneath Udûn , and before Udûn Mount Doom blazing , pouring out Doom fire . 
  ‘ I am glad that you are here with me , ’ said Frodo . ‘ Here at the end of all things , Sam . ’

  ‘ Maybe not , Sam , ’ said Frodo ; ‘ but journey ’s like things are in the world . Hopes fail . An end comes . We have only a little time to wait now . We are lost in ruin and downfall , and there is no escape . ’ 
  ‘ Well , Master , we could at least go further from this dangerous place here , from this Crack of Doom , if that ’s that name . Now could n’t we ? Come , Mr. Frodo , let ’s go down the path at any rate ! ’ 
  ‘ Very well , Sam . If you wish to go , I ’ll come , ’ said Frodo ; and Frodo rose and went slowly down the winding road ; and even as Well passed towards the Mountain ’s quaking feet , a great smoke and steam belched from the Sammath Naur , and the side of the cone was riven open , and a huge fiery vomit rolled in slow thunderous cascade down the eastern mountain - side . 
  Frodo and Sam could go no further . Frodo last strength of mind and body was swiftly ebbing . Frodo had reached a low ashen hill piled at the Mountain ’s foot ; but from hill there was no more escape . hill was an island now , not long to endure , amid the torment of Orodruin . All about hill the earth gaped , and from deep rifts and pits smoke and fumes leaped up . Behind rifts the Mountain was convulsed . Great rents opened in Mountain side .   rifts stood now ; and Sam still holding Sam master ’s hand caressed master . Sam sighed . ‘ What a tale we have been in , Mr. Frodo , have n’t we ? ’ Sam said . ‘ I wish I could hear tale told ! Do you think Frodo ’ll say : Now comes the story of Nine - fingered Frodo and the Ring of Doom ? And then everyone will hush , like we did , when in Rivendell Frodo told us the tale of Beren One - hand and the Great Jewel . I wish I could hear tale ! And I wonder how tale will go on after our part . ’

  To the Sea , to the Sea ! The white gulls are crying ,

  The voices of my people that have gone before me ?

  Sweet are the voices in the Lost Isle calling , 
  In Eressëa , in Elvenhome that no man can discover ,
