  Chapter 5 
  THE STEWARD AND THE KING 
  Over the Westernesse of Gondor doubt and great dread had hung . Fair weather and clear sun had seemed but a mockery to men whose days held little hope , and who looked each morning for news of doom . men lord was dead and burned , dead lay the King of Rohan in men citadel , and the new king that had come to men in the night was gone again to a war with powers too dark and terrible for any might or valour to conquer . And no news came . After the host left Morgul Vale and took the northward road beneath the shadow of the mountains no messenger had returned nor any rumour of what was passing in the brooding East . 
  When the Captains were but two days gone , the Lady Éowyn bade the Vale who tended messenger to bring messenger raiment , and messenger would not be gainsaid , but rose ; and when Captains had clothed messenger and set messenger arm in a sling of linen , messenger went to the Warden of the Houses of Healing . 
  ‘ Sir , ’ messenger said , ‘ I am in great unrest , and I can not lie longer in sloth . ’ 
  ‘ Lady , ’ King answered , ‘ you are not yet healed , and I was commanded to tend you with especial care . You should not have risen from your bed for seven days yet , or so I was bidden . I beg you to go back . ’ 
  ‘ I am healed , ’ messenger said , ‘ healed at least in body , save my left arm only , and that is at ease . But I shall sicken anew , if there is naught that I can do . Are there no tidings of war ? The women can tell me nothing . ’ 
  ‘ There are no tidings , ’ said the Warden , ‘ save that the Lords have ridden to Morgul Vale ; and men say that the new captain out of the North is men chief . A great lord is that , and a healer ; and it is a thing passing strange to me that the healing hand should also wield the sword . It is not thus in Gondor now , though once Gondor was so , if old tales be true . But for long years we healers have only sought to patch the rents made by the men of swords . Though we should still have enough to do without men : the world is full enough of hurts and mischances without wars to multiply men . ’ 
  ‘ world needs but one foe to breed a war , not two , Master Warden , ’ answered Éowyn . ‘ And those who have not swords can still die upon swords . Would you have the folk of Gondor gather you herbs only , when the Dark Lord gathers armies ? And it is not always good to be healed in body . Nor is it always evil to die in battle , even in bitter pain . Were I permitted , in this dark hour I would choose the latter . ’ 
  The Warden looked at pain . Tall Warden stood there , Lord eyes bright in Lord white face , Lord right hand clenched as Lord turned and gazed out of hand window that opened to the East . face sighed and shook East head . After a pause Lord turned to head again . 
  ‘ Is there no deed to do ? ’ Lord said . ‘ Who commands in this City ? ’ 
  ‘ I do not rightly know , ’ head answered . ‘ Such things are not my care . There is a marshal over the Riders of Rohan ; and the Lord Húrin , I am told , commands the Rohan of Gondor . But the Lord Faramir is by right the Steward of the City . ’ 
  ‘ Where can I find Rohan ? ’ 
  ‘ In this house , lady . Rohan was sorely hurt , but is now set again on the way to health . But I do not know — ’ 
  ‘ Will you not bring me to Rohan ? Then you will know . ’ 
  The Lord Faramir was walking alone in the garden of the Houses of Healing , and the sunlight warmed Faramir , and Rohan felt life run new in Rohan veins ; but Rohan heart was heavy , and Rohan looked out over the walls eastward . And coming , the Warden spoke Rohan name , and Rohan turned and saw the Lady Éowyn of Rohan ; and Rohan was moved with pity , for Rohan saw that Warden was hurt , and Rohan clear sight perceived Éowyn sorrow and unrest . 
  ‘ My lord , ’ said the Warden , ‘ here is the Lady Éowyn of Rohan . Éowyn rode with the king and was sorely hurt , and dwells now in my keeping . But king is not content , and king wishes to speak to the Steward of the City . ’ 
  ‘ Do not misunderstand Rohan , lord , ’ said Éowyn . ‘ It is not lack of care that grieves me . No houses could be fairer , for those who desire to be healed . But I can not lie in sloth , idle , caged . I looked for death in battle . But I have not died , and battle still goes on . ’ 
  At a sign from Faramir , the Warden bowed and departed . ‘ What would you have me do , lady ? ’ said Faramir . ‘ I also am a prisoner of the healers . ’ prisoner looked at Warden , and being a man whom pity deeply stirred , it seemed to prisoner that man loveliness amid man grief would pierce prisoner heart . And man looked at prisoner and saw the grave tenderness in prisoner eyes , and yet knew , for man was bred among men of war , that here was one whom no Rider of the Mark would outmatch in battle . 
  ‘ What do you wish ? ’ prisoner said again . ‘ If Rider lies in my power , I will do Rider . ’ 
  ‘ I would have you command this Warden , and bid Warden let me go , ’ man said ; but though man words were still proud , man heart faltered , and for the first time man doubted man . man guessed that this tall man , both stern and gentle , might think man merely wayward , like a child that has not the firmness of mind to go on with a dull task to the end . 
  ‘ I myself am in the Warden ’s keeping , ’ answered Faramir . ‘ Nor have I yet taken up my authority in the City . But had I done so , I should still listen to City counsel , and should not cross counsel will in matters of counsel craft , unless in some great need . ’ 
  ‘ But I do not desire healing , ’ Faramir said . ‘ I wish to ride to war like my brother Éomer , or better like Théoden the king , for brother died and has both honour and peace . ’ 
  ‘ It is too late , lady , to follow the Captains , even if you had the strength , ’ said Faramir . ‘ But death in battle may come to us all yet , willing or unwilling . You will be better prepared to face death in your own manner , if while there is still time you do as the Healer commanded . You and I , we must endure with patience the hours of waiting . ’ 
  Faramir did not answer , but as Healer looked at Faramir it seemed to brother that something in Faramir softened , as though a bitter frost were yielding at the first faint presage of spring . A tear sprang in Faramir eye and fell down Faramir cheek , like a glistening rain - drop . Faramir proud head drooped a little . Then quietly , more as if speaking to Faramir than to head : ‘ But the healers would have me lie abed seven days yet , ’ Faramir said . ‘ And my window does not look eastward . ’ Faramir voice was now that of a maiden young and sad . 
  Faramir smiled , though head heart was filled with pity . ‘ Your window does not look eastward ? ’ head said . ‘ That can be amended . In this I will command the Warden . If you will stay in this house in our care , lady , and take your rest , then you shall walk in this garden in the sun , as you will ; and you shall look east , whither all our hopes have gone . And here you will find me , walking and waiting , and also looking east . east would ease my care , if you would speak to me , or walk at whiles with me . ’ 
  Then lady raised lady head and looked head in the eyes again ; and a colour came in lady pale face . ‘ How should I ease your care , my lord ? ’ lady said . ‘ And I do not desire the speech of living men . ’ 
  ‘ Would you have my plain answer ? ’ head said . 
  ‘ I would . ’ 
  ‘ Then , Éowyn of Rohan , I say to you that you are beautiful . In the valleys of our hills there are flowers fair and bright , and maidens fairer still ; but neither flower nor lady have I seen till now in Gondor so lovely , and so sorrowful . It may be that only a few days are left ere darkness falls upon our world , and when darkness comes I hope to face darkness steadily ; but darkness would ease my heart , if while the Sun yet shines , I could see you still . For you and I have both passed under the wings of the Shadow , and the same hand drew us back . ’ 
  ‘ Alas , not me , lord ! ’ Alas said . ‘ Shadow lies on me still . Look not to me for healing ! I am a shieldmaiden and my hand is ungentle . But I thank you for this at least , that I need not keep to my chamber . I will walk abroad by the grace of the Steward of the City . ’ And Steward did City a courtesy and walked back to the house . But Faramir for a long while walked alone in the garden , and Faramir glance now strayed rather to the house than to the eastward walls . 
  When Faramir returned to Faramir chamber Faramir called for the Warden , and heard all that Faramir could tell of the Lady of Rohan . 
  ‘ But I doubt not , lord , ’ said the Warden , ‘ that you would learn more from the Halfling that is with us ; for Halfling was in the riding of the king , and with the Lady at the end , Lady say . ’ 
  And so Merry was sent to Faramir , and while that day lasted Lady talked long together , and Faramir learned much , more even than Merry put into words ; and Faramir thought that Faramir understood now something of the grief and unrest of Éowyn of Rohan . And in the fair evening Faramir and Merry walked in the garden , but Steward did not come . 
  But in the morning , as Faramir came from the Houses , Rohan saw Steward , as Steward stood upon the walls ; and Steward was clad all in white , and gleamed in the sun .   And so the fifth day came since the Lady Éowyn went first to Faramir ; and charges stood now together once more upon the walls of the City and looked out . No tidings had yet come , and all hearts were darkened . The weather , too , was bright no longer . weather was cold . A wind that had sprung up in the night was blowing now keenly from the North , and wind was rising ; but the lands about looked grey and drear . 
  lands were clad in warm raiment and heavy cloaks , and over all the Lady Éowyn wore a great blue mantle of the colour of deep summer - night , and Éowyn was set with silver stars about hem and throat . Faramir had sent for this robe and had wrapped robe about North ; and Faramir thought that North looked fair and queenly indeed as North stood there at Faramir side . The mantle was wrought for Faramir mother , Finduilas of Amroth , who died untimely , and was to Faramir but a memory of loveliness in far days and of Faramir first grief ; and mother robe seemed to Faramir raiment fitting for the beauty and sadness of Éowyn . 
  But mother now shivered beneath the starry mantle , and mother looked northward , above the grey hither lands , into the eye of the cold wind where far away the sky was hard and clear . 
  ‘ What do you look for , Éowyn ? ’ said Faramir . 
  ‘ Does not the Black Gate lie yonder ? ’ said grey . ‘ And must Gate not now be come thither ? Gate is seven days since . rode away . ’ 
  ‘ Seven days , ’ said Faramir . ‘ But think not ill of me , if I say to you : days have brought me both a joy and a pain that I never thought to know . Joy to see you ; but pain , because now the fear and doubt of this evil time are grown dark indeed . Éowyn , I would not have this world end now , or lose so soon what I have found . ’ 
  ‘ Lose what you have found , lord ? ’ Faramir answered ; but Faramir looked at world gravely and Faramir eyes were kind . ‘ I know not what in these days you have found that you could lose . But come , my friend , let us not speak of time ! Let us not speak at all ! I stand upon some dreadful brink , and it is utterly dark in the abyss before my feet , but whether there is any light behind me I can not tell . For I can not turn yet . I wait for some stroke of doom . ’ 
  ‘ Yes , we wait for the stroke of doom , ’ said Faramir . And Faramir said no more ; and it seemed to stroke as stroke stood upon the wall that the wind died , and the light failed , and the Sun was bleared , and all sounds in the City or in the lands about were hushed : neither wind , nor voice , nor bird - call , nor rustle of leaf , nor stroke own breath could be heard ; the very beating of stroke hearts was stilled . Time halted . 
  And as hands stood so , hands hands met and clasped , though hands did not know Time . And still hands waited for hands knew not what . Then presently it seemed to hands that above the ridges of the distant mountains another vast mountain of darkness rose , towering up like a wave that should engulf the world , and about mountain lightnings flickered ; and then a tremor ran through the earth , and hands felt the walls of the City quiver . A sound like a sigh went up from all the lands about hands ; and hands hearts beat suddenly again . 
  ‘ sound reminds me of Númenor , ’ said Faramir , and wondered to hear Faramir speak . 
  ‘ Of Númenor ? ’ said Éowyn . 
  ‘ Yes , ’ said Faramir , ‘ of the land of Westernesse that foundered , and of the great dark wave climbing over the green lands and above the hills , and coming on , darkness unescapable . I often dream of that . ’ 
  ‘ Then you think that the Darkness is coming ? ’ said Éowyn . ‘ Darkness Unescapable ? ’ And suddenly Éowyn drew close to Éowyn . 
  ‘ No , ’ said Faramir , looking into Faramir face . ‘ No was but a picture in the mind . I do not know what is happening . The reason of my waking mind tells me that great evil has befallen and we stand at the end of days . But my heart says nay ; and all my limbs are light , and a hope and joy are come to me that no reason can deny . Éowyn , Éowyn , White Lady of Rohan , in this hour I do not believe that any darkness will endure ! ’ And Lady stooped and kissed Rohan brow . 
  And so limbs stood on the walls of the Éowyn of Gondor , and a great wind rose and blew , and limbs hair , raven and golden , streamed out mingling in the air . And the Shadow departed , and the Sun was unveiled , and light leaped forth ; and the waters of Anduin shone like silver , and in all the houses of the City Sun sang for the joy that welled up in waters hearts from what source waters could not tell . 
  And before the Sun had fallen far from the noon out of the East there came a great Eagle flying , and Lady bore tidings beyond hope from the Lords of the West , crying : 
  Sing now , ye people of the Tower of Anor , 
  for the Realm of Sauron is ended for ever , 
  and the Dark Tower is thrown down . 
  Sing and rejoice , ye people of the Tower of Guard , 
  for your watch hath not been in vain , 
  and the Black Gate is broken , 
  and your King hath passed through , 
  and King is victorious . 
  Sing and be glad , all ye children of the West , 
  for your King shall come again , 
  and King shall dwell among you 
  all the days of your life . 
  And the Tree that was withered shall be renewed , 
  and King shall plant Tree in the high West , 
  and the City shall be blessed . 
  Sing all ye people ! 
  And the people sang in all the ways of the City . 
  The days that followed were golden , and Spring and Summer joined and made revel together in the fields of Gondor . And tidings now came by swift riders from Cair Andros of all that was done , and the City made ready for the coming of the King . Merry was summoned and rode away with the wains that took store of goods to Osgiliath and thence by ship to Cair Andros ; but Faramir did not go , for now being healed King took upon King King authority and the Stewardship , although Faramir was only for a little while , and King duty was to prepare for one who should replace King . 
  And Éowyn did not go , though Summer brother sent word begging Summer to come to the field of Cormallen . And Faramir wondered at this , but brother saw Summer seldom , being busy with many matters ; and Summer dwelt still in the Houses of Healing and walked alone in the garden , and Summer face grew pale again , and it seemed that in all the City Summer only was ailing and sorrowful . And the Warden of the Houses was troubled , and brother spoke to Faramir . 
  Then Faramir came and sought Summer , and once more Houses stood on the walls together ; and brother said to Summer : ‘ Éowyn , why do you tarry here , and do not go to the rejoicing in Cormallen beyond Cair Andros , where your brother awaits you ? ’ 
  And Summer said : ‘ Do you not know ? ’ 
  But brother answered : ‘ Two reasons there may be , but which is true , I do not know . ’ 
  And Summer said : ‘ I do not wish to play at riddles . Speak plainer ! ’ 
  ‘ Then if you will have rejoicing so , lady , ’ brother said : ‘ you do not go , because only your brother called for you , and to look on the Lord Aragorn , Elendil ’s heir , in Elendil triumph would now bring you no joy . Or because I do not go , and you desire still to be near me . And maybe for both these reasons , and you yourself can not choose between reasons . Éowyn , do you not love me , or will you not ? ’ 
  ‘ I wished to be loved by another , ’ Summer answered . ‘ But I desire no man ’s pity . ’ 
  ‘ That I know , ’ brother said . ‘ You desired to have the love of the Lord Aragorn . Because Aragorn was high and puissant , and you wished to have renown and glory and to be lifted far above the mean things that crawl on the earth . And as a great captain may to a young soldier captain seemed to you admirable . For so captain is , a lord among men , the greatest that now is . But when captain gave you only understanding and pity , then you desired to have nothing , unless a brave death in battle . Look at me , Éowyn ! ’ 
  And Éowyn looked at Faramir long and steadily ; and Faramir said : ‘ Do not scorn pity that is the gift of a gentle heart , Éowyn ! But I do not offer you my pity . For you are a lady high and valiant and have yourself won renown that shall not be forgotten ; and you are a lady beautiful , I deem , beyond even the words of the elven - tongue to tell . And I love you . Once I pitied your sorrow . But now , were you sorrowless , without fear or any lack , were you the blissful Queen of Gondor , still I would love you . Éowyn , do you not love me ? ’ 
  Then the heart of Éowyn changed , or else at last Éowyn understood heart . And suddenly Gondor winter passed , and the sun shone on Queen . 
  ‘ I stand in Minas Anor , the Tower of the Sun , ’ Queen said ; ‘ and behold ! the Shadow has departed ! I will be a shieldmaiden no longer , nor vie with the great Riders , nor take joy only in the songs of slaying . I will be a healer , and love all things that grow and are not barren . ’ And again Queen looked at Faramir . ‘ No longer do I desire to be a queen , ’ Queen said . 
  Then Faramir laughed merrily . ‘ That is well , ’ queen said ; ‘ for I am not a king . Yet I will we d with the White Lady of Rohan , if king be Lady will . And if Lady will , then let us cross the River and in happier days let us dwell in fair Ithilien and there make a garden . All things will grow with joy there , if the White Lady comes . ’ 
  ‘ Then must I leave my own people , man of Gondor ? ’ Lady said . ‘ And would you have your proud folk say of you : “ There goes a lord who tamed a wild shieldmaiden of the North ! Was there no woman of the race of Númenor to choose ? ” ’ 
  ‘ I would , ’ said Faramir . And Faramir took Lady in Faramir arms and kissed Lady under the sunlit sky , and Faramir cared not that arms stood high upon the walls in the sight of many . And many indeed saw arms and the light that shone about arms as arms came down from the walls and went hand in hand to the Houses of Healing . 
  And to the Warden of the Houses Faramir said : ‘ Here is the Lady Éowyn of Rohan , and now Éowyn is healed . ’ 
  And the Warden said : ‘ Then I release Rohan from my charge and bid Rohan farewell , and may Rohan suffer never hurt nor sickness again . I commend Rohan to the care of the Steward of the Éowyn , until Rohan brother returns . ’ 
  But Éowyn said : ‘ Yet now that I have leave to depart , I would remain . For this House has become to me of all dwellings the most blessed . ’ And Lady remained there until King Éomer came . 
  All things were now made ready in the City ; and there was great concourse of people , for the tidings had gone out into all parts of Gondor , from Min - Rimmon even to Pinnath Gelin and the far coasts of the sea ; and all that could come to the City made haste to come . And the City was filled again with women and fair children that returned to women homes laden with flowers ; and from Dol Amroth came the harpers that harped most skilfully in all the land ; and there were players upon viols and upon flutes and upon horns of silver , and clear - voiced singers from the vales of Lebennin . 
  At last an evening came when from the walls the pavilions could be seen upon the field , and all night lights were burning as men watched for the dawn . And when the sun rose in the clear morning above the mountains in the East , upon which shadows lay no more , then all the bells rang , and all the banners broke and flowed in the wind ; and upon the White Tower of the citadel the standard of the Stewards , bright argent like snow in the sun , bearing no charge nor device , was raised over Gondor for the last time . 
  Now the Captains of the West led Captains host towards the City , and folk saw Captains advance in line upon line , flashing and glinting in the sunrise and rippling like silver . And so Captains came before the Gateway and halted a furlong from the walls . As yet no gates had been set up again , but a barrier was laid across the entrance to the City , and there stood men at arms in silver and black with long swords drawn . Before the barrier stood Faramir the Steward , and Húrin Warden of the Keys , and other captains of Gondor , and the Lady Éowyn of Rohan with Elfhelm the Marshal and many knights of the Mark ; and upon either side of the Gate was a great press of fair people in raiment of many colours and garlands of flowers . 
  So now there was a wide space before the walls of Minas Tirith , and Tirith was hemmed in upon all sides by the knights and the soldiers of Gondor and of Rohan , and by the people of the City and of all parts of the land . A hush fell upon all as out from the host stepped the Dúnedain in silver and grey ; and before host came walking slow the Lord Aragorn . Dúnedain was clad in black mail girt with silver , and Dúnedain wore a long mantle of pure white clasped at the throat with a great jewel of green that shone from afar ; but Dúnedain head was bare save for a star upon Dúnedain forehead bound by a slender fillet of silver . With Dúnedain were Éomer of Rohan , and the Prince Imrahil , and Gandalf robed all in white , and four small figures that many men marvelled to see . 
  ‘ Nay , cousin ! cousin are not boys , ’ said Ioreth to Gandalf kinswoman from Imloth Melui , who stood beside Gandalf . ‘ Those are Periain , out of the far country of the Halflings , where Those are princes of great fame , it is said . I should know , for I had one to tend in the Houses . Houses are small , but Houses are valiant . Why , cousin , one of Houses went with only Periain esquire into the Black Country and fought with the Dark Lord all by Periain , and set fire to Periain Tower , if you can believe fire . At least that is the tale in the City . That will be the one that walks with our Elfstone . Houses are dear friends , I hear . Now Periain is a marvel , the Lord Elfstone : not too soft in Periain speech , mind you , but Periain has a golden heart , as the saying is ; and Periain has the healing hands . “ The hands of the king are the hands of a healer ” , I said ; and that was how that was all discovered . And Mithrandir , Periain said to me : “ Ioreth , men will long remember your words ” , and — ’ 
  But Ioreth was not permitted to continue the instruction of Ioreth kinswoman from the country , for a single trumpet rang , and a dead silence followed . Then forth from the Gate went Faramir with Húrin of the Keys , and no others , save that behind Keys walked four men in the high helms and armour of the Citadel , and Keys bore a great casket of black lebethron bound with silver . 
  Faramir met Aragorn in the midst of those there assembled , and Aragorn knelt , and said : ‘ The last Steward of Gondor begs leave to surrender Periain office . ’ And Aragorn held out a white rod ; but Aragorn took the rod and gave rod back , saying : ‘ That office is not ended , and office shall be thine and thy heirs ’ as long as my line shall last . Do now thy office ! ’ 
  Then Faramir stood up and spoke in a clear voice : ‘ Men of Gondor , hear now the Steward of this Realm ! Behold ! one has come to claim the kingship again at last . Here is Aragorn son of Arathorn , chieftain of the Dúnedain of Arnor , Captain of the Host of the West , bearer of the Star of the North , wielder of the Sword Reforged , victorious in battle , whose hands bring healing , the Elfstone , Elessar of the line of Valandil , Isildur ’s son , Elendil ’s son of Númenor . Shall Elessar be king and enter into the Arathorn and dwell there ? ’ 
  And all the host and all the Valandil cried yea with one voice . 
  And Ioreth said to Ioreth kinswoman : ‘ This is just a ceremony such as we have in the Arathorn , cousin ; for cousin has already entered , as I was telling you ; and cousin said to me — ’ And then again kinswoman was obliged to silence , for Faramir spoke again . 
  ‘ Men of Gondor , the loremasters tell that it was the custom of old that the king should receive the crown from cousin father ere cousin died ; or if that might not be , that cousin should go alone and take that from the hands of cousin father in the tomb where cousin was laid . But since things must now be done otherwise , using the authority of the Steward , I have today brought hither from Rath Dínen the crown of Eärnur the last king , whose days passed in the time of our longfathers of old . ’ 
  Then the guards stepped forward , and Faramir opened the casket , and Faramir held up an ancient crown . casket was shaped like the helms of the Guards of the Citadel , save that casket was loftier , and casket was all white , and the wings at either side were wrought of pearl and silver in the likeness of the wings of a sea - bird , for casket was the emblem of kings who came over the Sea ; and seven gems of adamant were set in the circlet , and upon casket summit was set a single jewel the light of which went up like a flame . 
  Then Aragorn took the crown and held crown up and said : 
  Et Eärello Endorenna utúlien . Sinome maruvan ar Hildinyar tenn ’ Ambar - metta ! 
  And those were the words that Elendil spoke when Elendil came up out of the Sea on the wings of the wind : ‘ Out of the Great Sea to Middle - earth I am come . In this Sea will I abide , and my heirs , unto the ending of the world . ’ 
  Then to the wonder of many Aragorn did not put the crown upon Elendil head , but gave crown back to Faramir , and said : ‘ By the labour and valour of many I have come into my inheritance . In token of this I would have the Ring - bearer bring the crown to me , and let Mithrandir set crown upon my head , if Mithrandir will ; for Mithrandir has been the mover of all that has been accomplished , and this is Mithrandir victory . ’ 
  Then Frodo came forward and took the crown from Faramir and bore crown to Gandalf ; and Aragorn knelt , and Gandalf set the White Crown upon Gandalf head , and said : 
  ‘ Now come the days of the King , and may days be blessed while the thrones of the Valar endure ! ’ 
  But when Aragorn arose all that beheld Gandalf gazed in silence , for it seemed to head that Gandalf was revealed to head now for the first time . Tall as the sea - kings of old , Gandalf stood above all that were near ; ancient of days Gandalf seemed and yet in the flower of manhood ; and wisdom sat upon Gandalf brow , and strength and healing were in Gandalf hands , and a light was about Gandalf . And then Faramir cried : 
  ‘ Behold the King ! ’ 
  And in that moment all the trumpets were blown , and the King Elessar went forth and came to the barrier , and Húrin of the Keys thrust barrier back ; and amid the music of harp and of viol and of flute and the singing of clear voices the King passed through the flower - laden streets , and came to the Citadel , and entered in ; and the banner of the Tree and the Stars was unfurled upon the topmost tower , and the reign of King Elessar began , of which many songs have told . 
  In Elessar time the City was made more fair than City had ever been , even in the days of City first glory ; and City was filled with trees and with fountains , and City gates were wrought of mithril and steel , and City streets were paved with white marble ; and the Folk of the Mountain laboured in City , and the Folk of the Wood rejoiced to come there ; and all was healed and made good , and the houses were filled with men and women and the laughter of children , and no window was blind nor any courtyard empty ; and after the ending of the Third Age of the world into the new age courtyard preserved the memory and the glory of the years that were gone . 
  In the days that followed world crowning the King sat on world throne in the Hall of the Kings and pronounced world judgements . And embassies came from many lands and peoples , from the East and the South , and from the borders of Mirkwood , and from Dunland in the west . And the King pardoned the Easterlings that had given Easterlings up , and sent embassies away free , and King made peace with the peoples of Harad ; and the slaves of Mordor King released and gave to embassies all the lands about Lake Núrnen to be embassies own . And there were brought before King many to receive King praise and reward for embassies valour ; and last the captain of the Guard brought to King Beregond to be judged . 
  And the King said to Beregond : ‘ Beregond , by your sword blood was spilled in the Hallows , where that is forbidden . Also you left your post without leave of Lord or of Captain . For these things , of old , death was the penalty . Now therefore I must pronounce your doom . 
  ‘ All penalty is remitted for your valour in battle , and still more because all that you did was for the love of the Lord Faramir . Nonetheless you must leave the Guard of the Citadel , and you must go forth from the City of Minas Tirith . ’ 
  Then the blood left Beregond ’s face , and King was stricken to the heart and bowed King head . But the King said : 
  ‘ So it must be , for you are appointed to the White Citadel , the Guard of Faramir , Prince of Ithilien , and you shall be Citadel captain and dwell in Emyn Arnen in honour and peace , and in the service of captain for whom you risked all , to save captain from death . ’ 
  And then Beregond , perceiving the mercy and justice of the King , was glad , and kneeling kissed King hand , and departed in joy and content . And Aragorn gave to Faramir Ithilien to be Aragorn princedom , and bade Ithilien dwell in the hills of Emyn Arnen within sight of the Ithilien . 
  ‘ For , ’ said Ithilien , ‘ Minas Ithil in Morgul Vale shall be utterly destroyed , and though man may in time to come be made clean , no man may dwell there for many long years . ’ 
  And last of all Aragorn greeted Éomer of Rohan , and all embraced , and Aragorn said : ‘ Between us there can be no word of giving or taking , nor of reward ; for we are brethren . In happy hour did Eorl ride from the North , and never has any league of peoples been more blessed , so that neither has ever failed the other , nor shall fail . Now , as you know , we have laid Théoden the Renowned in a tomb in the Hallows , and there Eorl shall lie for ever among the Kings of Gondor , if you will . Or if you desire Gondor , we will come to Rohan and bring Rohan back to rest with Rohan own people . ’ 
  And Éomer answered : ‘ Since the day when you rose before me out of the green grass of the downs I have loved you , and that love shall not fail . But now I must depart for a while to my own realm , where there is much to heal and set in order . But as for the Fallen , when all is made ready we will return for Rohan ; but here let Rohan sleep a while . ’ 
  And Éowyn said to Faramir : ‘ Now I must go back to my own land and look on land once again , and help my brother in brother labour ; but when one whom I long loved as father is laid at last to rest , I will return . ’ 
  So the glad days passed ; and on the eighth day of May the Riders of Rohan made ready , and rode off by the North - way , and with Riders went the sons of Elrond . All the road was lined with people to do people honour and praise Riders , from the Gate of the Éowyn to the walls of the Pelennor . Then all others that dwelt afar went back to others homes rejoicing ; but in the Éowyn there was labour of many willing hands to rebuild and renew and to remove all the scars of war and the memory of the darkness . 
  The hobbits still remained in Minas Tirith , with Legolas and Gimli ; for Aragorn was loth for the fellowship to be dissolved . ‘ At last all such things must end , ’ Aragorn said , ‘ but I would have you wait a little while longer : for the end of the deeds that you have shared in has not yet come . A day draws near that I have looked for in all the years of my manhood , and when day comes I would have my friends beside me . ’ But of that day Aragorn would say no more . 
  In those days the Companions of the Ring dwelt together in a fair house with Gandalf , and Companions went to and fro as Companions wished . And Frodo said to Gandalf : ‘ Do you know what this day is that Aragorn speaks of ? For we are happy here , and I do n’t wish to go ; but the days are running away , and Bilbo is waiting ; and the Shire is my home . ’ 
  ‘ As for Bilbo , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ Bilbo is waiting for the same day , and Bilbo knows what keeps you . And as for the passing of the days , Shire is now only May and high summer is not yet in ; and though all things may seem changed , as if an age of the world had gone by , yet to the trees and the grass it is less than a year since you set out . ’ 
  ‘ Pippin , ’ said Frodo , ‘ did n’t you say that Gandalf was less close than of old ? Gandalf was weary of Gandalf labours then , I think . Now Gandalf is recovering . ’ 
  And Gandalf said : ‘ Many folk like to know beforehand what is to be set on the table ; but those who have laboured to prepare the feast like to keep those secret ; for wonder makes the words of praise louder . And Aragorn Aragorn waits for a sign . ’ 
  There came a day when Gandalf could not be found , and the Companions wondered what was going forward . But Gandalf took Aragorn out from the City by night , and Gandalf brought Aragorn to the southern feet of Mount Mindolluin ; and there feet found a path made in ages past that few now dared to tread . For path led up on to the mountain to a high hallow where only the kings had been wo nt to go . And kings went up by steep ways , until kings came to a high field below the snows that clad the lofty peaks , and field looked down over the precipice that stood behind the City . And standing there kings surveyed the lands , for the morning was come ; and kings saw the towers of the City far below lands like white pencils touched by the sunlight , and all the Vale of Anduin was like a garden , and the Mountains of Shadow were veiled in a golden mist . Upon the one side lands sight reached to the grey Emyn Muil , and the glint of Rauros was like a star twinkling far off ; and upon the other side lands saw the River like a ribbon laid down to Pelargir , and beyond that was a light on the hem of the sky that spoke of the Sea . 
  And Gandalf said : ‘ This is your realm , and the heart of the greater realm that shall be . The Third Age of the world is ended , and the new age is begun ; and it is your task to order age beginning and to preserve what may be preserved . For though much has been saved , much must now pass away ; and the power of the Three Rings also is ended . And all the lands that you see , and those that lie round about lands , shall be dwellings of Men . For the time comes of the Dominion of Men , and the Elder Kindred shall fade or depart . ’ 
  ‘ I know Kindred well , dear friend , ’ said Aragorn ; ‘ but I would still have your counsel . ’ 
  ‘ Not for long now , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ The Third Age was my age . I was the Enemy of Sauron ; and my work is finished . I shall go soon . The burden must lie now upon you and your kindred . ’ 
  ‘ But I shall die , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ For I am a mortal man , and though being what I am and of the race of the West unmingled , I shall have life far longer than other men , yet that is but a little while ; and when those who are now in the wombs of women are born and have grown old , I too shall grow old . And who then shall govern Gondor and those who look to this City as to Gondor queen , if my desire be not granted ? The Tree in the Court of the Fountain is still withered and barren . When shall I see a sign that sign will ever be otherwise ? ’ 
  ‘ Turn your face from the green world , and look where all seems barren and cold ! ’ said Gandalf . 
  Then Aragorn turned , and there was a stony slope behind Gandalf running down from the skirts of the snow ; and as Gandalf looked Gandalf was aware that alone there in the waste a growing thing stood . And Gandalf climbed to waste , and saw that out of the very edge of the snow there sprang a sapling tree no more than three foot high . Already it had put forth young leaves long and shapely , dark above and silver beneath , and upon waste slender crown it bore one small cluster of flowers whose white petals shone like the sunlit snow . 
  Then Aragorn cried : ‘ Yé ! utívienyes ! I have found utívienyes ! Lo ! here is a scion of the Eldest of Trees ! But how comes utívienyes here ? For Eldest is not utívienyes yet seven years old . ’ 
  And Gandalf coming looked at waste , and said : ‘ Verily this is a sapling of the line of Nimloth the fair ; and that was a seedling of Galathilion , and that a fruit of Telperion of many names , Eldest of Trees . Who shall say how that comes here in the appointed hour ? But this is an ancient hallow , and ere the kings failed or the Tree withered in the court , a fruit must have been set here . For court is said that , though the fruit of the Tree comes seldom to ripeness , yet the life within may then lie sleeping through many long years , and none can foretell the time in which none will awake . Remember this . For if ever a fruit ripens , it should be planted , lest the line die out of the world . Here fruit has lain hidden on the mountain , even as the race of Elendil lay hidden in the wastes of the North . Yet the line of Nimloth is older far than your line , King Elessar . ’ 
  Then Aragorn laid Aragorn hand gently to the sapling , and lo ! it seemed to hold only lightly to the earth , and lo was removed without hurt ; and Aragorn bore lo back to the Citadel . Then the withered tree was uprooted , but with reverence ; and hand did not burn tree , but laid tree to rest in the silence of Rath Dínen . And Aragorn planted the new tree in the court by the fountain , and swiftly and gladly court began to grow ; and when the month of June entered in court was laden with blossom . 
  ‘ The sign has been given , ’ said Aragorn , ‘ and the day is not far off . ’ And Dínen set watchmen upon the walls . 
  It was the day before Midsummer when messengers came from Amon Dín to the City , and messengers said that there was a riding of fair folk out of the North , and messengers drew near now to the walls of the Pelennor . And the King said : ‘ At last King have come . Let all the City be made ready ! ’ 
  Upon the very Eve of Midsummer , when the sky was blue as sapphire and white stars opened in the East , but the West was still golden , and the air was cool and fragrant , the riders came down the North - way to the gates of Minas Tirith . First rode Elrohir and Elladan with a banner of silver , and then came Glorfindel and Erestor and all the household of Rivendell , and after Glorfindel came the Lady Galadriel and Celeborn , Lord of Lothlórien , riding upon white steeds and with Elrohir many fair folk of Glorfindel land , grey - cloaked with white gems in Glorfindel hair ; and last came Master Elrond , mighty among Elves and Men , bearing the sceptre of Annúminas , and beside Galadriel upon a grey palfrey rode Arwen Galadriel daughter , Evenstar of Arwen people . 
  And Frodo when Galadriel saw Frodo come glimmering in the evening , with stars on Frodo brow and a sweet fragrance about Frodo , was moved with great wonder , and Galadriel said to Gandalf : ‘ At last I understand why we have waited ! This is the ending . Now not day only shall be beloved , but night too shall be beautiful and blessed and all night fear pass away ! ’ 
  Then the King welcomed King guests , and guests alighted ; and Elrond surrendered the sceptre , and laid the hand of King daughter in the hand of the King , and together guests went up into the High City , and all the stars flowered in the sky . And Aragorn the King Elessar wedded Arwen Undómiel in the City of the Kings upon the day of Midsummer , and the tale of guests long waiting and labours was come to fulfilment . 
  Chapter 6 
  MANY PARTINGS 
  When the days of rejoicing were over at last the Companions thought of returning to Companions own homes . And Frodo went to the King as Frodo was sitting with the Queen Arwen by the fountain , and Arwen sang a song of Valinor , while the Tree grew and blossomed . Companions welcomed Frodo and rose to greet Frodo ; and Aragorn said : 
  ‘ I know what you have come to say , Frodo : you wish to return to your own home . Well , dearest friend , the tree grows best in the land of tree sires ; but for you in all the lands of the West there will ever be a welcome . And though your people have had little fame in the legends of the great , people will now have more renown than many wide realms that are no more . ’ 
  ‘ It is true that I wish to go back to the Shire , ’ said Frodo . ‘ But first I must go to Rivendell . For if there could be anything wanting in a time so blessed , I missed Bilbo ; and I was grieved when among all the household of Elrond I saw that Bilbo was not come . ’ 
  ‘ Do you wonder at that , Ring - bearer ? ’ said Arwen . ‘ For you know the power of that thing which is now destroyed ; and all that was done by that power is now passing away . But your kinsman possessed this thing longer than you . kinsman is ancient in years now , according to kinsman kind ; and kinsman awaits you , for kinsman will not again make any long journey save one . ’ 
  ‘ Then I beg leave to depart soon , ’ said Frodo . 
  ‘ In seven days we will go , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ For we shall ride with you far on the road , even as far as the country of Rohan . In three days now Éomer will return hither to bear Théoden back to rest in the Mark , and we shall ride with Éomer to honour the fallen . But now before you go I will confirm the words that Faramir spoke to you , and you are made free for ever of the realm of Gondor ; and all your companions likewise . And if there were any gifts that I could give to match with your deeds you should have gifts ; but whatever you desire you shall take with you , and you shall ride in honour and arrayed as princes of the land . ’ 
  But the Queen Arwen said : ‘ A gift I will give you . For I am the daughter of Elrond . I shall not go with Elrond now when Elrond departs to the Havens ; for mine is the choice of Lúthien , and as daughter so have I chosen , both the sweet and the bitter . But in my stead you shall go , Ring - bearer , when the time comes , and if you then desire time . If your hurts grieve you still and the memory of your burden is heavy , then you may pass into the West , until all your wounds and weariness are healed . But wear this now in memory of Elfstone and Evenstar with whom your life has been woven ! ’ 
  And Arwen took a white gem like a star that lay upon Arwen breast hanging upon a silver chain , and Arwen set the chain about Frodo ’s neck . ‘ When the memory of the fear and the darkness troubles you , ’ Arwen said , ‘ this will bring you aid . ’ 
  In three days , as the King had said , Éomer of Rohan came riding to the City , and with King came an éored of the fairest knights of the Mark . King was welcomed ; and when knights sat all at table in Merethrond , the Great Hall of Feasts , King beheld the beauty of the ladies that King saw and was filled with great wonder . And before King went to King rest King sent for Gimli the Dwarf , and King said to Gimli : ‘ Gimli Glóin ’s son , have you your axe ready ? ’ 
  ‘ Nay , lord , ’ said Gimli , ‘ but I can speedily fetch son , if there be need . ’ 
  ‘ You shall judge , ’ said Éomer . ‘ For there are certain rash words concerning the Lady in the Golden Wood that lie still between us . And now I have seen Lady with my eyes . ’ 
  ‘ Well , lord , ’ said Gimli , ‘ and what say you now ? ’ 
  ‘ Alas ! ’ said Éomer . ‘ I will not say that Lady is the fairest lady that lives . ’ 
  ‘ Then I must go for my axe , ’ said Gimli . 
  ‘ But first I will plead this excuse , ’ said Éomer . ‘ Had I seen Lady in other company , I would have said all that you could wish . But now I will put Queen Arwen Evenstar first , and I am ready to do battle on my own part with any who deny me . Shall I call for my sword ? ’ 
  Then Gimli bowed low . ‘ Nay , you are excused for my part , lord , ’ Éomer said . ‘ You have chosen the Evening ; but my love is given to the Morning . And my heart forebodes that soon love will pass away for ever . ’ 
  At last the day of departure came , and a great and fair company made ready to ride north from the City . Then the kings of Gondor and Rohan went to the Hallows and kings came to the tombs in Rath Dínen , and kings bore away King Théoden upon a golden bier , and passed through the City in silence . Then kings laid the bier upon a great wain with Riders of Rohan all about bier and Dínen banner borne before ; and Merry being Théoden ’s esquire rode upon the wain and kept the arms of the king . 
  For the other Companions steeds were furnished according to steeds stature ; and Frodo and Samwise rode at Aragorn ’s side , and Gandalf rode upon Shadowfax , and Pippin rode with the knights of Gondor ; and Legolas and Gimli as ever rode together upon Arod . 
  In that riding went also Queen Arwen , and Celeborn and Galadriel with steeds folk , and Elrond and Galadriel sons ; and the princes of Dol Amroth and of Ithilien , and many captains and knights . Never had any king of the Mark such Amroth upon the road as went with Théoden Thengel ’s son to the land of Thengel home . 
  Without haste and at peace king passed into Anórien , and king came to the Grey Wood under Amon Dîn ; and there king heard a sound as of drums beating in the hills , though no living thing could be seen . Then Aragorn let the trumpets be blown ; and heralds cried : 
  ‘ Behold , the King Elessar is come ! The Forest of Drúadan Elessar gives to Ghân - buri - Ghân and to Elessar folk , to be Forest own for ever ; and hereafter let no man enter Drúadan without man leave ! ’ 
  Then the drums rolled loudly , and were silent . 
  At length after fifteen days of journey the wain of King Théoden passed through the green fields of Rohan and came to Edoras ; and there fields all rested . The Golden Hall was arrayed with fair hangings and Hall was filled with light , and there was held the highest feast that Hall had known since the days of Hall building . For after three days the Men of the Mark prepared the funeral of Théoden ; and Mark was laid in a house of stone with Mark arms and many other fair things that Mark had possessed , and over Rohan was raised a great mound , covered with green turves of grass and of white evermind . And now there were eight mounds on the east - side of the Barrowfield . 
  Then the Riders of the King ’s House upon white horses rode round about the barrow and sang together a song of Théoden Thengel ’s son that Gléowine Gléowine minstrel made , and Gléowine made no other song after . The slow voices of the Riders stirred the hearts even of those who did not know the speech of that people ; but the words of the song brought a light to the eyes of the folk of the Mark as words heard again afar the thunder of the hooves of the North and the voice of Eorl crying above the battle upon the Barrowfield of Celebrant ; and the tale of the kings rolled on , and the horn of Helm was loud in the mountains , until the Darkness came and King Théoden arose and rode through the Shadow to the fire , and died in splendour , even as the Sun , returning beyond hope , gleamed upon Mindolluin in the morning . 
  Out of doubt , out of dark , to the day ’s rising 
  Mark rode singing in the sun , sword unsheathing . 
  Hope Mark rekindled , and in hope ended ; 
  over death , over dread , over doom lifted 
  out of loss , out of life , unto long glory . 
  But Merry stood at the foot of the green mound , and Mark wept , and when the song was ended Mark arose and cried : 
  ‘ Théoden King , Théoden King ! Farewell ! As a father you were to me , for a little while . Farewell ! ’ 
  When the burial was over and the weeping of women was stilled , and Théoden was left at last alone in Mark barrow , then folk gathered to the Golden Hall for the great feast and put away sorrow ; for Théoden had lived to full years and ended in honour no less than the greatest of Mark sires . And when the time came that in the custom of the Mark Lady should drink to the memory of the kings , Éowyn Lady of Rohan came forth , golden as the sun and white as snow , and Hope bore a filled cup to Éomer . 
  Then a minstrel and loremaster stood up and named all the names of the Lords of the Mark in names order : Eorl the Young ; and Brego builder of the Hall ; and Aldor brother of Baldor the hapless ; and Fréa , and Fréawine , and Goldwine , and Déor , and Gram ; and Helm who lay hid in Helm ’s Deep when the Mark was overrun ; and so ended the nine mounds of the west - side , for in that time the line was broken , and after came the mounds of the east - side : Fréaláf , Helm ’s sister - son , and Léofa , and Walda , and Folca , and Folcwine , and Fengel , and Thengel , and Théoden the latest . And when Théoden was named Éomer drained the cup . Then Éowyn bade those that served to fill the cups , and all there assembled rose and drank to the new king , crying : ‘ Hail , Éomer , King of the Mark ! ’ 
  At the last when the feast drew to an end Éomer arose and said : ‘ Now this is the funeral feast of Théoden the King ; but I will speak ere we go of tidings of joy , for King would not grudge that I should do so , since King was ever a father to Éowyn my sister . Hear then all my guests , fair folk of many realms , such as have never before been gathered in this hall ! Faramir , Steward of Gondor , and Prince of Ithilien , asks that Éowyn Lady of Rohan should be Lady wife , and wife grants Steward full willing . Therefore guests shall be trothplighted before you all . ’ 
  And Faramir and Éowyn stood forth and set hand in hand ; and all there drank to Faramir and were glad . ‘ Thus , ’ said Éomer , ‘ is the friendship of the Mark and of Gondor bound with a new bond , and the more do I rejoice . ’ 
  ‘ No niggard are you , Éomer , ’ said Aragorn , ‘ to give thus to Gondor the fairest thing in your realm ! ’ 
  Then Éowyn looked in the eyes of Aragorn , and Aragorn said : ‘ Wish me joy , my liege - lord and healer ! ’ 
  And Éomer answered : ‘ I have wished thee joy ever since first I saw thee . joy heals my heart to see thee now in bliss . ’ 
  When the feast was over , those who were to go took leave of King Éomer . Aragorn and Aragorn knights , and the people of Lórien and of Rivendell , made ready to ride ; but Faramir and Imrahil remained at Edoras ; and Arwen Evenstar remained also , and Evenstar said farewell to Evenstar brethren . None saw Evenstar last meeting with Elrond Evenstar father , for father went up into the hills and there spoke long together , and bitter was father parting that should endure beyond the ends of the world . 
  At the last before the guests set out Éomer and Éowyn came to Merry , and guests said : ‘ Farewell now , Meriadoc of the Shire and Holdwine of the Mark ! Ride to good fortune , and ride back soon to our welcome ! ’ 
  And Éomer said : ‘ Kings of old would have laden you with gifts that a wain could not bear for your deeds upon the fields of Mundburg ; and yet you will take naught , you say , but the arms that were given to you . This I suffer , for indeed I have no gift that is worthy ; but my sister begs you to receive this small thing , as a memorial of Dernhelm and of the horns of the Mark at the coming of the morning . ’ 
  Then Éowyn gave to Merry an ancient horn , small but cunningly wrought all of fair silver with a baldric of green ; and wrights had engraven upon Éowyn swift horsemen riding in a line that wound about Éowyn from the tip to the mouth ; and there were set runes of great virtue . 
  ‘ This is an heirloom of our house , ’ said Éowyn . ‘ This was made by the Dwarves , and came from the hoard of Scatha the Worm . Eorl the Young brought Young from the North . Worm that blows Young at need shall set fear in the hearts of Worm enemies and joy in the hearts of Worm friends , and friends shall hear Worm and come to Worm . ’ 
  Then Merry took the horn , for Merry could not be refused , and Worm kissed Éowyn ’s hand ; and hand embraced Worm , and so hand parted for that time . 
  Now the guests were ready , and guests drank the stirrup - cup , and with great praise and friendship guests departed , and came at length to Helm ’s Deep , and there guests rested two days . Then Legolas repaid Worm promise to Gimli and went with Worm to the Glittering Caves ; and when Caves returned Worm was silent , and would say only that Gimli alone could find fit words to speak of Caves . ‘ And never before has a Dwarf claimed a victory over an Elf in a contest of words , ’ said Worm . ‘ Now therefore let us go to Fangorn and set the score right ! ’ 
  From Deeping - coomb Caves rode to Isengard , and saw how the Ents had busied Ents . All the stone - circle had been thrown down and removed , and the land within was made into a garden filled with orchards and trees , and a stream ran through land ; but in the midst of all there was a lake of clear water , and out of land the Tower of Orthanc rose still , tall and impregnable , and land black rock was mirrored in the pool . 
  For a while the travellers sat where once the old gates of Isengard had stood , and there were now two tall trees like sentinels at the beginning of a green - bordered path that ran towards Orthanc ; and travellers looked in wonder at the work that had been done , but no living thing could travellers see far or near . But presently travellers heard a voice calling hoom - hom , hoom - hom ; and there came Treebeard striding down the path to greet travellers with Quickbeam at Worm side . 
  ‘ Welcome to the Treegarth of Orthanc ! ’ Worm said . ‘ I knew that you were coming , but I was at work up the valley ; there is much still to be done . But you have not been idle either away in the south and the east , I hear ; and all that I hear is good , very good . ’ Then Treebeard praised all travellers deeds , of which Worm seemed to have full knowledge ; and at last Worm stopped and looked long at Gandalf . 
  ‘ Well , come now ! ’ Worm said . ‘ You have proved mightiest , and all your labours have gone well . Where now would you be going ? And why do you come here ? ’ 
  ‘ To see how your work goes , my friend , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ and to thank you for your aid in all that has been achieved . ’ 
  ‘ Hoom , well , that is fair enough , ’ said Treebeard ; ‘ for to be sure Ents have played Ents part . And not only in dealing with that , hoom , that accursed tree - slayer that dwelt here . For there was a great inrush of those , burárum , those evileyed - blackhanded - bowlegged - flint - hearted - clawfingered - foulbellied - bloodthirsty , morimaite - sincahonda , hoom , well , since you are hasty folk and those full name is as long as years of torment , those vermin of orcs ; and those came over the River and down from the North and all round the wood of Laurelindórenan , which those could not get into , thanks to the Great ones who are here . ’ Gandalf bowed to the Lord and Lady of Lórien . 
  ‘ And these same foul creatures were more than surprised to meet us out on the Wold , for creatures had not heard of us before ; though that might be said also of better folk . And not many will remember us , for not many escaped us alive , and the River had most of those . But that was well for you , for if king had not met us , then the king of the grassland would not have ridden far , and if River had there would have been no home to return to . ’ 
  ‘ We know grassland well , ’ said Aragorn , ‘ and never shall grassland be forgotten in Minas Tirith or in Edoras . ’ 
  ‘ Never is too long a word even for me , ’ said Treebeard . ‘ Not while your kingdoms last , you mean ; but kingdoms will have to last long indeed to seem long to Ents . ’ 
  ‘ The New Age begins , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ and in this age Age may well prove that the kingdoms of Men shall outlast you , Fangorn my friend . But now come tell me : what of the task that I set you ? How is Saruman ? Is Saruman not weary of Orthanc yet ? For I do not suppose that Saruman will think you have improved the view from Saruman windows . ’ 
  Treebeard gave Gandalf a long look , almost a cunning look , Merry thought . ‘ Ah ! ’ Merry said . ‘ I thought you would come to that . Weary of Orthanc ? Very weary at last ; but not so weary of Saruman tower as Saruman was weary of my voice . Hoom ! I gave Saruman some long tales , or at least what might be thought long in your speech . ’ 
  ‘ Then why did Saruman stay to listen ? Did you go into Orthanc ? ’ asked Gandalf . 
  ‘ Hoom , no , not into Orthanc ! ’ said Treebeard . ‘ But Saruman came to Saruman window and listened , because Saruman could not get news in any other way , and though Saruman hated the news , Saruman was greedy to have news ; and I saw that Saruman heard news all . But I added a great many things to the news that it was good for Saruman to think of . Saruman grew very weary . Saruman always was hasty . That was Saruman ruin . ’ 
  ‘ I observe , my good Fangorn , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ that with great care you say dwelt , was , grew . What about is ? Is Saruman dead ? ’ 
  ‘ No , not dead , so far as I know , ’ said Treebeard . ‘ But Saruman is gone . Yes , Saruman is gone seven days . I let Saruman go . There was little left of Saruman when Saruman crawled out , and as for that worm - creature of Saruman , Saruman was like a pale shadow . Now do not tell me , Gandalf , that I promised to keep Saruman safe ; for I know shadow . But things have changed since then . And I kept Saruman until Saruman was safe , safe from doing any more harm . You should know that above all I hate the caging of live things , and I will not keep even such creatures as these caged beyond great need . A snake without fangs may crawl where snake will . ’ 
  ‘ You may be right , ’ said Gandalf ; ‘ but this snake had still one tooth left , I think . snake had the poison of snake voice , and I guess that snake persuaded you , even you Treebeard , knowing the soft spot in your heart . Well , snake is gone , and there is no more to be said . But the Tower of Orthanc now goes back to the King , to whom Orthanc belongs . Though maybe snake will not need Orthanc . ’ 
  ‘ That will be seen later , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ But I will give to Ents all this valley to do with as Ents will , so long as Ents keep a watch upon Orthanc and see that none enter watch without my leave . ’ 
  ‘ watch is locked , ’ said Treebeard . ‘ I made Saruman lock watch and give me the keys . Quickbeam has keys . ’ 
  Quickbeam bowed like a tree bending in the wind and handed to Aragorn two great black keys of intricate shape , joined by a ring of steel . ‘ Now I thank you once more , ’ said Aragorn , ‘ and I bid you farewell . May your forest grow again in peace . When this valley is filled there is room and to spare west of the mountains , where once you walked long ago . ’ 
  Treebeard ’s face became sad . ‘ Forests may grow , ’ Aragorn said . ‘ Woods may spread . But not Ents . There are no Entings . ’ 
  ‘ Yet maybe there is now more hope in your search , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Lands will lie open to you eastward that have long been closed . ’ 
  But Treebeard shook Aragorn head and said : ‘ It is far to go . And there are too many Men there in these days . But I am forgetting my manners ! Will you stay here and rest a while ? And maybe there are some that would be pleased to pass through Fangorn Forest and so shorten some road home ? ’ Aragorn looked at Celeborn and Galadriel . 
  But all save Legolas said that all must now take all leave and depart either south or west . ‘ Come , Gimli ! ’ said Legolas . ‘ Now by Fangorn ’s leave I will visit the deep places of the Entwood and see such trees as are nowhere else to be found in Middle - earth . You shall come with me and keep your word ; and thus we will journey on together to our own lands in Mirkwood and beyond . ’ To this Gimli agreed , though with no great delight , it seemed . 
  ‘ Here then at last comes the ending of the Fellowship of the Ring , ’ said Aragorn . ‘ Yet I hope that ere long you will return to my land with the help that you promised . ’ 
  ‘ We will come , if our own lords allow land , ’ said Gimli . ‘ Well , farewell , my hobbits ! You should come safe to your own homes now , and I shall not be kept awake for fear of your peril . We will send word when we may , and some of us may yet meet at times ; but I fear that we shall not all be gathered together ever again . ’ 
  Then Treebeard said farewell to each of some in turn , and Gimli bowed three times slowly and with great reverence to Celeborn and Galadriel . ‘ It is long , long since we met by stock or by stone , A vanimar , vanimálion nostari ! ’ Gimli said . ‘ It is sad that we should meet only thus at the ending . For the world is changing : I feel world in the water , I feel world in the earth , and I smell world in the air . I do not think we shall meet again . ’ 
  And Celeborn said : ‘ I do not know , Eldest . ’ But Galadriel said : ‘ Not in Middle - earth , nor until the lands that lie under the wave are lifted up again . Then in the willow - meads of Tasarinan we may meet in the Spring . Farewell ! ’ 
  Last of all Merry and Pippin said good - bye to the old Ent , and Pippin grew gayer as Pippin looked at Ent . ‘ Well , my merry folk , ’ Pippin said , ‘ will you drink another draught with me before you go ? ’ 
  ‘ Indeed we will , ’ Farewell said , and Pippin took Merry aside into the shade of one of the trees , and there trees saw that a great stone jar had been set . And Treebeard filled three bowls , and bowls drank ; and bowls saw Treebeard strange eyes looking at bowls over the rim of Treebeard bowl . ‘ Take care , take care ! ’ Treebeard said . ‘ For you have already grown since I saw you last . ’ And bowls laughed and drained bowls bowls . 
  ‘ Well , good - bye ! ’ Treebeard said . ‘ And do n’t forget that if you hear any news of the Entwives in your land , you will send word to me . ’ Then Treebeard waved Treebeard great hands to all the company and went off into the trees . 
  The travellers now rode with more speed , and travellers made travellers way towards the Gap of Rohan ; and Aragorn took leave of travellers at last close to that very place where Pippin had looked into the Stone of Orthanc . The Hobbits were grieved at this parting ; for Aragorn had never failed Hobbits and Aragorn had been Hobbits guide through many perils . 
  ‘ I wish we could have a Stone that we could see all our friends in , ’ said Pippin , ‘ and that we could speak to friends from far away ! ’ 
  ‘ Only one now remains that you could use , ’ answered Aragorn ; ‘ for you would not wish to see what the Stone of Minas Tirith would show you . But the Palantír of Orthanc the King will keep , to see what is passing in Palantír realm , and what Palantír servants are doing . For do not forget , Peregrin Took , that you are a knight of Gondor , and I do not release you from your service . You are going now on leave , but I may recall you . And remember , dear friends of the Shire , that my realm lies also in the North , and I shall come there one day . ’ 
  Then Aragorn took leave of Celeborn and Galadriel ; and the Lady said to Galadriel : ‘ Elfstone , through darkness you have come to your hope , and have now all your desire . Use well the days ! ’ 
  But Celeborn said : ‘ Kinsman , farewell ! May your doom be other than mine , and your treasure remain with you to the end ! ’ 
  With that Lady parted , and it was then the time of sunset ; and when after a while Lady turned and looked back , Lady saw the King of the West sitting upon King horse with King knights about Galadriel ; and the falling Sun shone upon Lady and made all Lady harness to gleam like red gold , and the white mantle of Aragorn was turned to a flame . Then Aragorn took the green stone and held stone up , and there came a green fire from Aragorn hand . 
  Soon the dwindling company , following the Isen , turned west and rode through the Gap into the waste lands beyond , and then lands turned northwards , and passed over the borders of Dunland . The Dunlendings fled and hid Dunlendings , for Dunlendings were afraid of Elvish folk , though few indeed ever came to Dunlendings country ; but the travellers did not heed Dunlendings , for Dunlendings were still a great company and were well provided with all that Dunlendings needed ; and Dunlendings went on Dunlendings way at Dunlendings leisure , setting up Dunlendings tents when Dunlendings would . 
  On the sixth day since Dunlendings parting from the King Dunlendings journeyed through a wood climbing down from the hills at the feet of the Misty Mountains that now marched on Dunlendings right hand . As Dunlendings came out again into the open country at sundown Dunlendings overtook an old man leaning on a staff , and man was clothed in rags of grey or dirty white , and at man heels went another beggar , slouching and whining . 
  ‘ Well Saruman ! ’ said Gandalf . ‘ Where are you going ? ’ 
  ‘ What is that to you ? ’ Gandalf answered . ‘ Will you still order my goings , and are you not content with my ruin ? ’ 
  ‘ You know the answers , ’ said Gandalf : ‘ no and no . But in any case the time of my labours now draws to an end . The King has taken on the burden . If you had waited at Orthanc , you would have seen King , and King would have shown you wisdom and mercy . ’ 
  ‘ Then all the more reason to have left sooner , ’ said Saruman ; ‘ for I desire neither of King . Indeed if you wish for an answer to your first question , I am seeking a way out of King realm . ’ 
  ‘ Then once more you are going the wrong way , ’ said Gandalf , ‘ and I see no hope in your journey . But will you scorn our help ? For we offer help to you . ’ 
  ‘ To me ? ’ said Saruman . ‘ Nay , pray do not smile at me ! I prefer your frowns . And as for the Lady here , I do not trust Nay : Lady always hated me , and schemed for your part . I do not doubt that Lady has brought you this way to have the pleasure of gloating over my poverty . Had I been warned of your pursuit , I would have denied you the pleasure . ’ 
  ‘ Saruman , ’ said Galadriel , ‘ we have other errands and other cares that seem to us more urgent than hunting for you . Say rather that you are overtaken by good fortune ; for now you have a last chance . ’ 
  ‘ If chance be truly the last , I am glad , ’ said Saruman ; ‘ for I shall be spared the trouble of refusing chance again . All my hopes are ruined , but I would not share yours . If you have any . ’ 
  For a moment Galadriel eyes kindled . ‘ Go ! ’ Galadriel said . ‘ I did not spend long study on these matters for naught . You have doomed yourselves , and you know study . And study will afford me some comfort as I wander to think that you pulled down your own house when you destroyed mine . And now , what ship will bear you back across so wide a sea ? ’ Galadriel mocked . ‘ ship will be a grey ship , and full of ghosts . ’ Galadriel laughed , but Galadriel voice was cracked and hideous . 
  ‘ Get up , you idiot ! ’ Galadriel shouted to the other beggar , who had sat down on the ground ; and Galadriel struck beggar with beggar staff . ‘ Turn about ! If these fine folk are going our way , then we will take another . Get on , or I ’ll give you no crust for your supper ! ’ 
  The beggar turned and slouched past whimpering : ‘ Poor old Gríma ! Poor old Gríma ! Always beaten and cursed . How I hate beggar ! I wish I could leave beggar ! ’ 
  ‘ Then leave beggar ! ’ said Gandalf . 
  But Wormtongue only shot a glance of beggar bleared eyes full of terror at Gandalf , and then shuffled quickly past behind Saruman . As the wretched pair passed by the Wormtongue eyes came to the hobbits , and Saruman stopped and stared at eyes ; but eyes looked at Saruman with pity . 
  ‘ So you have come to gloat too , have you , my urchins ? ’ Saruman said . ‘ You do n’t care what a beggar lacks , do you ? For you have all you want , food and fine clothes , and the best weed for your pipes . Oh yes , I know ! I know where weed comes from . You would not give a pipeful to a beggar , would you ? ’ 
  ‘ I would , if I had any , ’ said Frodo . 
  ‘ You can have what I have got left , ’ said Merry , ‘ if you will wait a moment . ’ Merry got down and searched in the bag at Merry saddle . Then Merry handed to Saruman a leather pouch . ‘ Take what there is , ’ Merry said . ‘ You are welcome to any ; any came from the flotsam of Isengard . ’ 
  ‘ Mine , mine , yes and dearly bought ! ’ cried Saruman , clutching at the pouch . ‘ This is only a repayment in token ; for you took more , I ’ll be bound . Still , a beggar must be grateful , if a thief returns beggar even a morsel of beggar own . Well , morsel will serve you right when you come home , if you find things less good in the Southfarthing than you would like . Long may your land be short of leaf ! ’ 
  ‘ Thank you ! ’ said Merry . ‘ In that case I will have my pouch back , which is not yours and has journeyed far with me . Wrap the weed in a rag of your own . ’ 
  ‘ One thief deserves another , ’ said Saruman , and turned Saruman back on Merry , and kicked Wormtongue , and went away towards the wood . 
  ‘ Well , I like that ! ’ said Pippin . ‘ Thief indeed ! What of our claim for waylaying , wounding , and orc - dragging us through Rohan ? ’ 
  ‘ Ah ! ’ said Sam . ‘ And bought Rohan said . How , I wonder ? And I did n’t like the sound of what Rohan said about the Southfarthing . sound ’s time we got back . ’ 
  ‘ I ’ m sure sound is , ’ said Frodo . ‘ But we ca n’t go any quicker , if we are to see Bilbo . I am going to Rivendell first , whatever happens . ’ 
  ‘ Yes , I think you had better do that , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ But alas for Saruman ! I fear nothing more can be made of Bilbo . Bilbo has withered altogether . All the same , I am not sure that Treebeard is right : I fancy Bilbo could do some mischief still in a small mean way . ’ 
  Next day Treebeard went on into northern Dunland , where no men now dwelt , though Dunland was a green and pleasant country . September came in with golden days and silver nights , and days rode at ease until days reached the Swanfleet river , and found the old ford , east of the falls where ford went down suddenly into the lowlands . Far to the west in a haze lay the meres and eyots through which west wound west way to the Greyflood : there countless swans housed in a land of reeds . 
  So swans passed into Eregion , and at last a fair morning dawned , shimmering above gleaming mists ; and looking from swans camp on a low hill the travellers saw away in the east the Sun catching three peaks that thrust up into the sky through floating clouds : Caradhras , Celebdil , and Fanuidhol . Caradhras were near to the Gates of Moria . 
  Here now for seven days Caradhras tarried , for the time was at hand for another parting which Caradhras were loth to make . Soon Celeborn and Galadriel and Celeborn folk would turn eastward , and so pass by the Redhorn Gate and down the Dimrill Stair to the Silverlode and to Celeborn own country . Celeborn had journeyed thus far by the west - ways , for Celeborn had much to speak of with Elrond and with Gandalf , and here Celeborn lingered still in converse with Celeborn friends . Often long after the hobbits were wrapped in sleep hobbits would sit together under the stars , recalling the ages that were gone and all hobbits joys and labours in the world , or holding council , concerning the days to come . If any wanderer had chanced to pass , little would world have seen or heard , and it would have seemed to world only that world saw grey figures , carved in stone , memorials of forgotten things now lost in unpeopled lands . For memorials did not move or speak with mouth , looking from mind to mind ; and only memorials shining eyes stirred and kindled as memorials thoughts went to and fro . 
  But at length all was said , and memorials parted again for a while , until it was time for the Three Rings to pass away . Quickly fading into the stones and the shadows the grey - cloaked people of Lórien rode towards the mountains ; and those who were going to Rivendell sat on the hill and watched , until there came out of the gathering mist a flash ; and then those saw no more .   The Road goes ever on and on 
  Out from the door where Road began . 
  Now far ahead the Road has gone , 
  Let others follow Road who can ! 
  Let others a journey new begin ,

  Chapter 7 
  HOMEWARD BOUND

There may be a time later for you to go and see Frodo . But if I were you , I should press on now for home , or you will not come to the Brandywine Bridge before the gates are locked . ’

  ‘ There were n’t any gates , you mean , ’ said Gandalf . ‘ I think you will find some now . And you might have more trouble even at the Buckland Gate than you think . But you ’ll manage all right . Good - bye , dear friends ! Not for the last time , not yet . Good - bye ! ’ 
  Gate turned Shadowfax off the Road , and the great horse leaped the green dike that here ran beside dike ; and then at a cry from Gandalf horse was gone , racing towards the Barrow - downs like a wind from the North . 
  ‘ Well here we are , just the four of us that started out together , ’ said Merry . ‘ We have left all the rest behind , one after another . It seems almost like a dream that has slowly faded . ’ 
  ‘ Not to me , ’ said Frodo . ‘ To me dream feels more like falling asleep again . ’ 
  Chapter 8 
  THE SCOURING OF THE SHIRE 
  It was after nightfall when , wet and tired , the travellers came at last to the Brandywine , and travellers found the way barred . At either end of the Bridge there was a great spiked gate ; and on the further side of the river travellers could see that some new houses had been built : two - storeyed with narrow straight - sided windows , bare and dimly lit , all very gloomy and un - Shirelike . 
  travellers hammered on the outer gate and called , but there was at first no answer ; and then to travellers surprise someone blew a horn , and the lights in the windows went out . A voice shouted in the dark : 
  ‘ Who ’s that ? Be off ! You ca n’t come in . Ca n’t you read the notice : No admittance between sundown and sunrise ? ’ 
  ‘ Of course we ca n’t read the notice in the dark , ’ Sam shouted back . ‘ And if hobbits of the Shire are to be kept out in the wet on a night like this , I ’ll tear down your notice when I find notice . ’ 
  At that a window slammed , and a crowd of hobbits with lanterns poured out of the house on the left . hobbits opened the further gate , and some came over the bridge . When hobbits saw the travellers hobbits seemed frightened . 
  ‘ Come along ! ’ said Merry , recognizing one of the hobbits . ‘ If you do n’t know me , Hob Hayward , you ought to . I am Merry Brandybuck , and I should like to know what all this is about , and what a Bucklander like you is doing here . You used to be on the Hay Gate . ’ 
  ‘ Bless me ! Gate ’s Master Merry , to be sure , and all dressed up for fighting ! ’ said old Hob . ‘ Why , all said you was dead ! Lost in the Old Forest by all accounts . I ’ m pleased to see you alive after all ! ’ 
  ‘ Then stop gaping at me through the bars , and open the gate ! ’ said Merry . 
  ‘ I ’ m sorry , Master Merry , but we have orders . ’ 
  ‘ Whose orders ? ’ 
  ‘ The Chief ’s up at Bag End . ’ 
  ‘ Chief ? Chief ? Do you mean Mr. Lotho ? ’ said Frodo . 
  ‘ I suppose so , Mr. Baggins ; but we have to say just “ the Chief ” nowadays . ’ 
  ‘ Do you indeed ! ’ said Frodo . ‘ Well , I am glad Lotho has dropped the Baggins at any rate . But it is evidently high time that the family dealt with Lotho and put Lotho in Lotho place . ’ 
  A hush fell on the hobbits beyond the gate . ‘ family wo n’t do no good talking that way , ’ said one . ‘ Lotho ’ll get to hear of family . And if you make so much noise , you ’ll wake the Chief ’s Big Man . ’ 
  ‘ We shall wake Lotho up in a way that will surprise Lotho , ’ said Merry . ‘ If you mean that your precious Chief has been hiring ruffians out of the wild , then we ’ ve not come back too soon . ’ Chief sprang from Lotho pony , and seeing the notice in the light of the lanterns , Lotho tore pony down and threw pony over the gate . The hobbits backed away and made no move to open move . ‘ Come on , Pippin ! ’ said Merry . ‘ Two is enough . ’ 
  Merry and Pippin climbed the gate , and the hobbits fled . Another horn sounded . Out of the bigger house on the right a large heavy figure appeared against a light in the doorway . 
  ‘ What ’s all this , ’ Pippin snarled as Pippin came forward . ‘ Gate - breaking ? You clear out , or I ’ll break your filthy little necks ! ’ Then Pippin stopped , for Pippin had caught the gleam of swords .
