  Bill Ferny flinched and shuffled to the gate and unlocked gate . ‘ Give me the key ! ’ said Merry . But the ruffian flung gate at ruffian head and then darted out into the darkness . As ruffian passed the ponies one of ponies let fly with ruffian heels and just caught ruffian as ruffian ran . ruffian went off with a yelp into the night and was never heard of again . 
  ‘ Neat work , Bill , ’ said Sam , meaning the pony . 
  ‘ So much for your Big Man , ’ said Merry . ‘ We ’ll see the Chief later . In the meantime we want a lodging for the night , and as you seem to have pulled down the Bridge Inn and built this dismal place instead , you ’ll have to put us up . ’ 
  ‘ I am sorry , Mr. Merry , ’ said Hob , ‘ but Inn is n’t allowed . ’ 
  ‘ What is n’t allowed ? ’ 
  ‘ Taking in folk off - hand like , and eating extra food , and all that , ’ said Hob . 
  ‘ What ’s the matter with the place ? ’ said Merry . ‘ Has that been a bad year , or what ? I thought that had been a fine summer and harvest . ’ 
  ‘ Well no , the year ’s been good enough , ’ said Hob . ‘ We grows a lot of food , but we do n’t rightly know what becomes of food . food ’s all these “ gatherers ” and “ sharers ” , I reckon , going round counting and measuring and taking off to storage . counting do more gathering than sharing , and we never see most of the stuff again . ’ 
  ‘ Oh come ! ’ said Pippin yawning . ‘ This is all too tiresome for me tonight . We ’ ve got food in our bags . Just give us a room to lie down in . room ’ll be better than many places I have seen . ’ 
  The hobbits at the gate still seemed ill at ease , evidently some rule or other was being broken ; but there was no gainsaying four such masterful travellers , all armed , and two of travellers uncommonly large and strong - looking . Frodo ordered the gates to be locked again . There was some sense at any rate in keeping a guard , while ruffians were still about . Then the four companions went into the hobbit guard - house and made companions as comfortable as companions could . It was a bare and ugly place , with a mean little grate that would not allow a good fire . In the upper rooms were little rows of hard beds , and on every wall there was a notice and a list of Rules . Pippin tore beds down . There was no beer and very little food , but with what the travellers brought and shared out travellers all made a fair meal ; and Pippin broke Rule 4 by putting most of next day ’s allowance of wood on the fire . 
  ‘ Well now , what about a smoke , while you tell us what has been happening in the Shire ? ’ Pippin said . 
  ‘ There is n’t no pipe - weed now , ’ said Hob ; ‘ at least only for the Chief ’s men . All the stocks seem to have gone . We do hear that waggon - loads of Chief went away down the old road out of the Southfarthing , over Sarn Ford way . That would be the end o ’ last year , after you left . But Hob had been going away quietly before that , in a small way . That Lotho — ’ 
  ‘ Now you shut up , Hob Hayward ! ’ cried several of the others . ‘ You know talk o ’ that sort is n’t allowed . The Chief will hear of sort , and we ’ll all be in trouble . ’ 
  ‘ Chief would n’t hear naught , if some of you here were n’t sneaks , ’ rejoined Hob hotly . 
  ‘ All right , all right ! ’ said Sam . ‘ That ’s quite enough . I do n’t want to hear no more . No welcome , no beer , no smoke , and a lot of rules and orc - talk instead . I hoped to have a rest , but I can see there ’s work and trouble ahead . Let ’s sleep and forget rest till morning ! ’ 
  The new ‘ Chief evidently had means of getting news . Chief was a good forty miles from the Bridge to Bag End , but someone made the journey in a hurry . So Frodo and someone friends soon discovered . 
  Frodo had not made any definite plans , but had vaguely thought of going down to Crickhollow together first , and resting there a bit . But now , seeing what things were like , things decided to go straight to Hobbiton . So the next day things set out along the Road and jogged along steadily . The wind had dropped but the sky was grey . The land looked rather sad and forlorn ; but land was after all the first of November and the fag - end of autumn . Still there seemed an unusual amount of burning going on , and smoke rose from many points round about . A great cloud of smoke was going up far away in the direction of the Woody End . 
  As evening fell points were drawing near to Frogmorton , a village right on the Road , about twenty - two miles from the Bridge . There points meant to stay the night ; The Floating Log at Frogmorton was a good inn . But as points came to the east end of the village points met a barrier with a large board saying NO ROAD ; and behind board stood a large band of Shirriffs with staves in points hands and feathers in points caps , looking both important and rather scared . 
  ‘ What ’s all this ? ’ said Frodo , feeling inclined to laugh . 
  ‘ This is what This is , Mr. Baggins , ’ said the leader of the Shirriffs , a two - feather hobbit : ‘ You ’re arrested for Gate - breaking , and Tearing up of Rules , and Assaulting Gate - keepers , and Trespassing , and Sleeping in Shire - buildings without Leave , and Bribing Guards with Food . ’ 
  ‘ And what else ? ’ said Frodo . 
  ‘ That ’ll do to go on with , ’ said the Shirriff - leader . 
  ‘ I can add some more , if you ’d like some , ’ said Sam . ‘ Calling your Chief Names , Wishing to punch Trespassing Pimply Face , and Thinking you Shirriffs look a lot of Tom - fools . ’ 
  ‘ There now , Mister , that ’ll do . Mister ’s the Chief ’s orders that you ’re to come along quiet . We ’re going to take you to Bywater and hand you over to the Chief ’s Men ; and when Bywater deals with your case you can have your say . But if you do n’t want to stay in the Lockholes any longer than you need , I should cut the say short , if I was you . ’ 
  To the discomfiture of the Shirriffs Frodo and Sam companions all roared with laughter . ‘ Do n’t be absurd ! ’ said Frodo . ‘ I am going where I please , and in my own time . I happen to be going to Bag End on business , but if you insist on going too , well that is your affair . ’ 
  ‘ Very well , Mr. Baggins , ’ said the leader , pushing the barrier aside . ‘ But do n’t forget I ’ ve arrested you . ’ 
  ‘ I wo n’t , ’ said Frodo . ‘ Never . But I may forgive you . Now I am not going any further today , so if you ’ll kindly escort me to The Floating Log , I ’ll be obliged . ’ 
  ‘ I ca n’t do that , Mr. Baggins . The inn ’s closed . There ’s a Shirriff - house at the far end of the village . I ’ll take you there . ’ 
  ‘ All right , ’ said Frodo . ‘ Go on and we ’ll follow . ’ 
  Sam had been looking the Shirriffs up and down and had spotted one that Sam knew . ‘ Hey , come here Robin Smallburrow ! ’ Sam called . ‘ I want a word with you . ’ 
  With a sheepish glance at Sam leader , who looked wrathful but did not dare to interfere , Shirriff Smallburrow fell back and walked beside Sam , who got down off Smallburrow pony .

And Frodo does n’t hold with folk moving about ; so if Leastways will or Leastways must , then Leastways has to go to the Shirriff - house and explain Leastways business . ’

Gave me a chance of walking round the country and seeing folk , and hearing the news , and knowing where the good beer was . But now beer ’s different . ’

Sam sends Men round everywhere , and if any of us small folk stand up for our rights , Men drag Sam off to the Lockholes . Men took old Flourdumpling , old Will Whitfoot the Mayor , first , and Men ’ ve taken a lot more . Lately Mayor ’s been getting worse . Often Men beat ’em now . ’

Most of hundreds are in Shirriffs against hundreds will , but not all . Even in the Shire there are some as like minding other folk ’s business and talking big . And there ’s worse than that : there ’s a few as do spy - work for the Chief and Shire Men . ’

  ‘ That ’s right . We are n’t allowed to send by That now , but Chief use the old Quick Post service , and keep special runners at different points . One came in from Whitfurrows last night with a “ secret message ” , and another took One on from here . And a message came back this afternoon saying you was to be arrested and taken to Bywater , not direct to the Lockholes . The Chief wants to see you at once , evidently . ’ 
  ‘ Bywater wo n’t be so eager when Mr. Frodo has finished with Bywater , ’ said Sam . 
  The Shirriff - house at Frogmorton was as bad as the Bridge - house . house had only one storey , but house had the same narrow windows , and it was built of ugly pale bricks , badly laid . Inside house was damp and cheerless , and supper was served on a long bare table that had not been scrubbed for weeks . The food deserved no better setting . The travellers were glad to leave the place . food was about eighteen miles to Bywater , and travellers set off at ten o’clock in the morning . travellers would have started earlier , only the delay so plainly annoyed the Shirriff - leader . The west wind had shifted northward and wind was turning colder , but the rain was gone . 
  It was rather a comic cavalcade that left the village , though the few folk that came out to stare at the ‘ get - up ’ of the travellers did not seem quite sure whether laughing was allowed . A dozen Shirriffs had been told off as escort to the ‘ prisoners ’ ; but Merry made escort march in front , while Frodo and Frodo friends rode behind . Merry , Pippin , and Sam sat at Merry ease laughing and talking and singing , while the Shirriffs stumped along trying to look stern and important . Frodo , however , was silent and looked rather sad and thoughtful .

The sun came out , and in spite of the chilly wind travellers were soon puffing and sweating . 
  At the Three - Farthing Stone travellers gave Three up . travellers had done nearly fourteen miles with only one rest at noon . Three was now three o’clock . travellers were hungry and very footsore and travellers could not stand the pace . 
  ‘ Well , come along in your own time ! ’ said Merry . ‘ We are going on . ’

  The travellers trotted on , and as the sun began to sink towards the White Downs far away on the western horizon travellers came to Bywater by Downs wide pool ; and there travellers had travellers first really painful shock . This was Frodo and Sam ’s own country , and travellers found out now that travellers cared about This more than any other place in the world . Many of the houses that houses had known were missing . Some seemed to have been burned down . The pleasant row of old hobbit - holes in the bank on the north side of the Pool were deserted , and houses little gardens that used to run down bright to the water ’s edge were rank with weeds . Worse , there was a whole line of the ugly new houses all along Pool Side , where the Hobbiton Road ran close to the bank . An avenue of trees had stood there . trees were all gone . And looking with dismay up the road towards Bag End trees saw a tall chimney of brick in the distance . chimney was pouring out black smoke into the evening air .

When houses reached The Green Dragon , the last house on the Hobbiton side , now lifeless and with broken windows , houses were disturbed to see half a dozen large ill - favoured Men lounging against the inn - wall ; houses were squint - eyed and sallow - faced .

  ‘ Yes , I see , ’ said Frodo . ‘ For one thing , I see that you ’re behind the times and the news here . Much has happened since you left the South . Your day is over , and all other ruffians ’ . The Dark Tower has fallen , and there is a King in Gondor . And Isengard has been destroyed , and your precious master is a beggar in the wilderness . I passed Isengard on the road . The King ’s messengers will ride up the Greenway now , not bullies from Isengard . ’

But that wo n’t stop us living in this fat little country where you have lazed long enough . And ’ - King snapped King fingers in Frodo ’s face - ‘ King ’s messengers ! That for messengers ! Scaring Bree - land peasants , and bullying bewildered hobbits , had been peasants work . Fearless hobbits with bright swords and grim faces were a great surprise . And there was a note in the voices of these newcomers that newcomers had not heard before . note chilled newcomers with fear .

And not in fool name even for much longer . fool ’s a prisoner in Bag End now , I expect , and very frightened . We ought to try and rescue fool . ’

  ‘ No ! ’ said Merry . ‘ No ’s no good “ getting under cover ” . That is just what people have been doing , and just what these ruffians like . ruffians will simply come down on us in force , corner us , and then drive us out , or burn us in . No , we have got to do something at once . ’

  ‘ Raise the Shire ! ’ said Merry . ‘ Now ! Wake all our people ! people hate all this , you can see : all of people except perhaps one or two rascals , and a few fools that want to be important , but do n’t at all understand what is really going on .   person rode back to the middle of the village . There Sam turned aside and galloped off down the lane that led south to Cotton ’s . Sam had not gone far when Sam heard a sudden clear horn - call go up ringing into the sky . Far over hill and field call echoed ; and so compelling was that call that Sam Sam almost turned and dashed back . Sam pony reared and neighed .

  Awake ! Awake ! Fear , Fire , Foes ! Awake ! 
  Fire , Foes ! Awake !

  ‘ Good , good ! ’ cried Farmer Cotton . ‘ So Shire ’s begun at last ! I ’ ve been itching for trouble all this year , but folks would n’t help . And I ’ ve had the wife and Rosie to think of . These ruffians do n’t stick at nothing . But come on now , lads ! Bywater is up ! We must be in nothing ! ’

  ‘ Perhaps not , ’ said Sam abashed . ‘ But I ’ m hurrying now . We ’re setting about the ruffians , and I ’ ve got to get back to Mr. Frodo . But I thought I ’d have a look and see how Mrs. Cotton was keeping , and you , Rosie . ’ 
  ‘ We ’re keeping nicely , thank you , ’ said Mrs. Cotton . ‘ Or should be , if look were n’t for these thieving ruffians . ’ 
  ‘ Well , be off with you ! ’ said Rosie . ‘ If you ’ ve been looking after Mr. Frodo all this while , what d’you want to leave Frodo for , as soon as things look dangerous ? ’ 
  This was too much for Sam . This needed a week ’s answer , or none . Sam turned away and mounted Sam pony . But as Sam started off , Rosie ran down the steps . 
  ‘ I think you look fine , Sam , ’ Rosie said . ‘ Go on now ! But take care of yourself , and come straight back as soon as you have settled the ruffians ! ’ 
  When Sam got back Sam found the whole village roused . Already , apart from many younger lads , more than a hundred sturdy hobbits were assembled with axes , and heavy hammers , and long knives , and stout staves ; and a few had hunting - bows . More were still coming in from outlying farms . 
  Some of the village - folk had lit a large fire , just to enliven things , and also because Some was one of the things forbidden by the Chief . Some burned bright as night came on . Others at Merry ’s orders were setting up barriers across the road at each end of the village . When the Shirriffs came up to the lower one Others were dumbfounded ; but as soon as Others saw how things were , most of Others took off Others feathers and joined in the revolt . The others slunk away . 
  Sam found Frodo and Sam friends by the fire talking to old Tom Cotton , while an admiring crowd of Bywater folk stood round and stared . 
  ‘ Well , what ’s the next move ? ’ said Farmer Cotton . 
  ‘ I ca n’t say , ’ said Frodo , ‘ until I know more . How many of these ruffians are there ? ’ 
  ‘ That ’s hard to tell , ’ said Cotton . ‘ ruffians moves about and comes and goes . There ’s sometimes fifty of ruffians in ruffians sheds up Hobbiton way ; but ruffians go out from there roving round , thieving or “ gathering ” as ruffians call way . Still there ’s seldom less than a score round the Boss , as ruffians names Boss . Cotton ’s at Bag End , or was ; but Cotton do n’t go outside the grounds now . No one ’s seen Cotton at all , in fact , for a week or two ; but the Cotton do n’t let no one go near . ’ 
  ‘ Hobbiton ’s not ruffians only place , is Hobbiton ? ’ said Pippin . 
  ‘ No , more ’s the pity , ’ said Cotton . ‘ There ’s a good few down south in Longbottom and by Sarn Ford , I hear ; and some more lurking in the Woody End ; and some ’ ve sheds at Waymeet . And then there ’s the Lockholes , as some call ’em : the old storage - tunnels at Michel Delving that some ’ ve made into prisons for those as stand up to some . Still I reckon there ’s not above three hundred of some in the Shire all told , and maybe less . We can master some , if we stick together . ’ 
  ‘ Have some got any weapons ? ’ asked Merry . 
  ‘ Whips , knives , and clubs , enough for Whips dirty work : that ’s all Whips ’ ve showed so far , ’ said Cotton . ‘ But I dare say Whips ’ ve got other gear , if gear comes to fighting . Some have bows , anyway . Whips ’ ve shot one or two of our folk . ’ 
  ‘ There you are , Frodo ! ’ said Merry . ‘ I knew we should have to fight . Well , Whips started the killing . ’ 
  ‘ Not exactly , ’ said Cotton . ‘ Leastways not the shooting . Tooks started that . You see , your dad , Mr. Peregrin , Peregrin ’s never had no truck with this Lotho , not from the beginning : said that if anyone was going to play the chief at this time of day , it would be the right Thain of the Shire and no upstart . And when Lotho sent Peregrin Men Tooks got no change out of Peregrin . Tooks are lucky , Tooks ’ ve got those deep holes in the Green Hills , the Great Smials and all , and the ruffians ca n’t come at ’em ; and Tooks wo n’t let the ruffians come on Tooks land . If Tooks do , Tooks hunt ’em . Tooks shot three for prowling and robbing . After that the ruffians turned nastier . And ruffians keep a pretty close watch on Tookland . No one gets in nor out of Tookland now . ’ 
  ‘ Good for the Tooks ! ’ cried Pippin . ‘ But someone is going to get in again , now . I am off to the Smials . Anyone coming with me to Tuckborough ? ’ 
  Pippin rode off with half a dozen lads on ponies . ‘ See you soon ! ’ Pippin cried . ‘ Anyone ’s only fourteen miles or so over the fields . I ’ll bring you back an army of Tooks in the morning . ’ Merry blew a horn - call after lads as lads rode off into the gathering night . The people cheered . 
  ‘ All the same , ’ said Frodo to all those who stood near , ‘ I wish for no killing ; not even of the ruffians , unless it must be done , to prevent ruffians from hurting hobbits . ’ 
  ‘ All right ! ’ said Merry . ‘ But we shall be having a visit from the Hobbiton gang any time now , I think . ruffians wo n’t come just to talk things over . We ’ll try to deal with ruffians neatly , but we must be prepared for the worst . Now I ’ ve got a plan . ’ 
  ‘ Very good , ’ said Frodo . ‘ You make the arrangements . ’ 
  Just then some hobbits , who had been sent out towards Hobbiton , came running in . ‘ arrangements ’re coming ! ’ hobbits said . ‘ A score or more . But two have gone off west across country . ’ 
  ‘ To Waymeet , that ’ll be , ’ said Cotton , ‘ to fetch more of the gang . Well , two ’s fifteen mile each way . We need n’t trouble about arrangements just yet . ’ 
  Merry hurried off to give orders . Farmer Cotton cleared the street , sending everyone indoors , except the older hobbits who had weapons of some sort . hobbits had not long to wait . Soon hobbits could hear loud voices , and then the tramping of heavy feet . Presently a whole squad of the ruffians came down the road . ruffians saw the barrier and laughed . ruffians did not imagine that there was anything in this little land that would stand up to twenty of ruffians kind together . 
  The hobbits opened the barrier and stood aside . ‘ Thank you ! ’ the Men jeered . ‘ Now run home to bed before you ’re whipped . ’ Then Men marched along the street shouting : ‘ Put those lights out ! Get indoors and stay there ! Or we ’ll take fifty of you to the Lockholes for a year . Get in ! The Boss is losing Boss temper . ’ 
  No one paid any heed to Men orders ; but as the ruffians passed , Men closed in quietly behind and followed ruffians . When the Men reached the fire there was Farmer Cotton standing all alone warming Cotton hands . 
  ‘ Who are you , and what d’you think you ’re doing ? ’ said the ruffian - leader . 
  Farmer Cotton looked at leader slowly . ‘ I was just going to ask you that , ’ leader said . ‘ This is n’t your country , and you ’re not wanted . ’ 
  ‘ Well , you ’re wanted anyhow , ’ said the leader . ‘ We want you . Take leader lads ! Lockholes for leader , and give leader something to keep leader quiet ! ’ 
  The Men took one step forward and stopped short . There rose a roar of voices all round voices , and suddenly voices were aware that Farmer Cotton was not all alone . voices were surrounded . In the dark on the edge of the firelight stood a ring of hobbits that had crept up out of the shadows . There was nearly two hundred of hobbits , all holding some weapon . 
  Merry stepped forward . ‘ We have met before , ’ Cotton said to the leader , ‘ and I warned you not to come back here . I warn you again : you are standing in the light and you are covered by archers . If you lay a finger on this farmer , or on anyone else , you will be shot at once . Lay down any weapons that you have ! ’ 
  The leader looked round . Cotton was trapped . But Cotton was not scared , not now with a score of Cotton fellows to back leader . Cotton knew too little of hobbits to understand Cotton peril . Foolishly Cotton decided to fight . peril would be easy to break out . 
  ‘ At ’em , lads ! ’ Cotton cried . ‘ Let ’em have peril ! ’ 
  With a long knife in Cotton left hand and a club in the other Cotton made a rush at the ring , trying to burst out back towards Hobbiton . Cotton aimed a savage blow at Merry who stood in Cotton way . Cotton fell dead with four arrows in Cotton . 
  That was enough for the others . others gave in . others weapons were taken from others , and others were roped together , and marched off to an empty hut that others had built others , and there others were tied hand and foot , and locked up under guard . The dead leader was dragged off and buried . 
  ‘ Seems almost too easy after all , do n’t leader ? ’ said Cotton . ‘ I said we could master Cotton . But we needed a call . You came back in the nick o ’ time , Mr. Merry . ’ 
  ‘ There ’s more to be done still , ’ said Merry . ‘ If you ’re right in your reckoning , we have n’t dealt with a tithe of Merry yet . But tithe ’s dark now . I think the next stroke must wait until morning . Then we must call on the Chief . ’ 
  ‘ Why not now ? ’ said Sam . ‘ Chief ’s not much more than six o’clock . And I want to see my gaffer . D’you know what ’s come of gaffer , Mr. Cotton ? ’ 
  ‘ gaffer ’s not too well , and not too bad , Sam , ’ said the farmer . ‘ farmer dug up Bagshot Row , and that was a sad blow to gaffer . gaffer ’s in one of farmer new houses that the Chief ’s Men used to build while farmer still did any work other than burning and thieving : not above a mile from the end of Bywater . But gaffer comes around to me , when gaffer gets a chance , and I see gaffer ’s better fed than some of the poor bodies . All against The Rules , of course . I ’d have had gaffer with me , but that was n’t allowed . ’ 
  ‘ Thank’ee indeed , Mr. Cotton , and I ’ll never forget that , ’ said Sam . ‘ But I want to see gaffer . That Boss and that Sharkey , as Boss spoke of , Rules might do a mischief up there before the morning . ’ 
  ‘ All right , Sam , ’ said Cotton . ‘ Choose a lad or two , and go and fetch lad to my house . You ’ll not have need to go near the old Hobbiton village over Water . My Jolly here will show you . ’ 
  Sam went off . Merry arranged for look - outs round the village and guards at the barriers during the night . Then Sam and Frodo went off with Farmer Cotton . Sam sat with the family in the warm kitchen , and the Cottons asked a few polite questions about Cottons travels , but hardly listened to the answers : Cottons were far more concerned with events in the Shire . 
  ‘ Jolly all began with Pimple , as we call Pimple , ’ said Farmer Cotton ; ‘ and Jolly began as soon as you ’d gone off , Mr. Frodo . Sam ’d funny ideas , had Pimple . Seems Sam wanted to own everything Sam , and then order other folk about . folk soon came out that Sam already did own a sight more than was good for Pimple ; and Pimple was always grabbing more , though where Pimple got the money was a mystery : mills and malt - houses and inns , and farms , and leaf - plantations . Pimple ’d already bought Sandyman ’s mill before Pimple came to Bag End , seemingly . 
  ‘ Of course Pimple started with a lot of property in the Southfarthing which Pimple had from Pimple dad ; and it seems Pimple ’d been selling a lot o ’ the best leaf , and sending leaf away quietly for a year or two . But at the end o ’ last year Pimple began sending away loads of stuff , not only leaf . Things began to get short , and winter coming on , too . Folk got angry , but Pimple had Pimple answer . A lot of Men , ruffians mostly , came with great waggons , some to carry off the goods south - away , and others to stay . And more came . And before we knew where we were ruffians were planted here and there all over the Shire , and were felling trees and digging and building ruffians sheds and houses just as ruffians liked . At first goods and damage was paid for by Pimple ; but soon ruffians began lording damage around and taking what ruffians wanted . 
  ‘ Then there was a bit of trouble , but not enough . Old Will the Mayor set off for Bag End to protest , but Mayor never got there . Ruffians laid hands on Old and took and locked End up in a hole in Michel Delving , and there Delving is now . And after that , no would be soon after New Year , there was n’t no more Mayor , and Pimple called Pimple Chief Shirriff , or just Chief , and did as Pimple liked ; and if anyone got “ uppish ” as Shirriff called anyone , Shirriff followed Will . So things went from bad to worse . There was n’t no smoke left , save for the Men ; and the Chief did n’t hold with beer , save for Pimple Men , and closed all the inns ; and everything except Rules got shorter and shorter , unless one could hide a bit of one ’s own when the ruffians went round gathering stuff up “ for fair distribution ” : which meant ruffians got stuff and we did n’t , except for the leavings which you could have at the Shirriff - houses , if you could stomach ruffians . All very bad . But since Sharkey came it ’s been plain ruination . ’ 
  ‘ Who is this Sharkey ? ’ said Merry . ‘ I heard one of the ruffians speak of Sharkey . ’ 
  ‘ The biggest ruffian o ’ the lot , seemingly , ’ answered Cotton . ‘ It was about last harvest , end o ’ September maybe , that we first heard of Cotton . We ’ ve never seen Cotton , but Cotton ’s up at Bag End ; and Cotton ’s the real Chief now , I guess . All the ruffians do what Cotton says ; and what Cotton says is mostly : hack , burn , and ruin ; and now hack ’s come to killing . There ’s no longer even any bad sense in hack . ruffians cut down trees and let ’em lie , ruffians burn houses and build no more . 
  ‘ Take Sandyman ’s mill now . Pimple knocked Sandyman down almost as soon as Pimple came to Bag End . Then Pimple brought in a lot o ’ dirty - looking Men to build a bigger one and fill one full o ’ wheels and outlandish contraptions . Only that fool Ted was pleased by that , and Ted works there cleaning wheels for the Men , where Ted dad was the Miller and Ted own master . Pimple ’s idea was to grind more and faster , or so Ted said . Ted ’s got other mills like idea . But you ’ ve got to have grist before you can grind ; and there was no more for the new mill to do than for the old . But since Sharkey came mills do n’t grind no more corn at all . mills ’re always a - hammering and a - letting out a smoke and a stench , and there is n’t no peace even at night in Hobbiton . And mills pour out filth a purpose ; mills ’ ve fouled all the lower Water , and Water ’s getting down into Brandywine . If mills want to make the Shire into a desert , mills ’re going the right way about Shire . I do n’t believe that fool of a Pimple ’s behind all this . ’s ’s Sharkey , I say . ’ 
  ‘ That ’s right ! ’ put in Young Tom . ‘ Why , Tom even took Pimple ’s old ma , that Lobelia , and Pimple was fond of Lobelia , if no one else was . Some of the Hobbiton folk , Tom saw one . Lobelia comes down the lane with Lobelia old umberella . Some of the ruffians were going up with a big cart . 
  ‘ “ Where be you a - going ? ” says Lobelia . 
  ‘ “ To Bag End , ” says ruffians . 
  ‘ “ What for ? ” says Lobelia . 
  ‘ “ To put up some sheds for Sharkey , ” says ruffians . 
  ‘ “ Who said you could ? ” says Lobelia . 
  ‘ “ Sharkey , ” says ruffians . “ So get out o ’ the road , old hagling ! ” 
  ‘ “ I ’ll give you Sharkey , you dirty thieving ruffians ! ” says Lobelia , and ups with Lobelia umberella and goes for the leader , near twice Lobelia size . So ruffians took Lobelia . Dragged Lobelia off to the Lockholes , at Lobelia age too . ruffians ’ ve took others we miss more , but there ’s no denying Lobelia showed more spirit than most . ’ 
  Into the middle of this talk came Sam , bursting in with Sharkey gaffer . Old Gamgee did not look much older , but Sharkey was a little deafer . 
  ‘ Good evening , Mr. Baggins ! ’ Sharkey said . ‘ Glad indeed I am to see you safe back . But I ’ ve a bone to pick with you , in a manner o ’ speaking , if I may make so bold . You did n’t never ought to have a ’ sold Bag End , as I always said . That ’s what started all the mischief . And while you ’ ve been trapessing in foreign parts , chasing Black Men up mountains from what my Sam says , though what for Sam do n’t make clear , Men ’ ve been and dug up Bagshot Row and ruined my taters ! ’ 
  ‘ I am very sorry , Mr. Gamgee , ’ said Frodo . ‘ But now I ’ ve come back , I ’ll do my best to make amends . ’ 
  ‘ Well , you ca n’t say fairer than that , ’ said the Gaffer . ‘ Mr. Frodo Baggins is a real gentlehobbit , I always have said , whatever you may think of some others of the name , begging your pardon . And I hope my Sam ’s behaved hisself and given satisfaction ? ’ 
  ‘ Perfect satisfaction , Mr. Gamgee , ’ said Frodo . ‘ Indeed , if you will believe satisfaction , Sam ’s now one of the most famous people in all the lands , and people are making songs about Sam deeds from here to the Sea and beyond the Great River . ’ Sam blushed , but Sam looked gratefully at Frodo , for Rosie ’s eyes were shining and Rosie was smiling at Sam . 
  ‘ satisfaction takes a lot o ’ believing , ’ said the Gaffer , ‘ though I can see Sam ’s been mixing in strange company . What ’s come of Sam weskit ? I do n’t hold with wearing ironmongery , whether ironmongery wears well or no . ’ 
  Farmer Cotton ’s household and all Sam guests were up early next morning . Nothing had been heard in the night , but more trouble would certainly come before the day was old . ‘ Seems as if none o ’ the ruffians were left up at Bag End , ’ said Cotton ; ‘ but the gang from Waymeet will be along any time now . ’ 
  After breakfast a messenger from the Tookland rode in . messenger was in high spirits . ‘ The Thain has raised all our country , ’ messenger said , ‘ and the news is going like fire all ways . The ruffians that were watching our land have fled off south , those that escaped alive . The Thain has gone after ruffians , to hold off the big gang down that way ; but Thain ’s sent Mr. Peregrin back with all the other folk Thain can spare . ’ 
  The next news was less good . Merry , who had been out all night , came riding in about ten o’clock . ‘ There ’s a big band about four miles away , ’ messenger said . ‘ ruffians ’re coming along the road from Waymeet , but a good many stray ruffians have joined up with ruffians . There must be close on a hundred of ruffians ; and ruffians ’re fire - raising as ruffians come . Curse ruffians ! ’ 
  ‘ Ah ! This lot wo n’t stay to talk , ruffians ’ll kill , if ruffians can , ’ said Farmer Cotton . ‘ If Tooks do n’t come sooner , we ’d best get behind cover and shoot without arguing . There ’s got to be some fighting before this is settled , Mr. Frodo . ’ 
  The Tooks did come sooner . Before long Tooks marched in , a hundred strong , from Tuckborough and the Green Hills with Pippin at hundred head . Merry now had enough sturdy hobbitry to deal with the ruffians . Scouts reported that Scouts were keeping close together . hundred knew that the countryside had risen against hundred , and plainly meant to deal with the rebellion ruthlessly , at countryside centre in Bywater . But however grim hundred might be , hundred seemed to have no leader among Scouts who understood warfare . Scouts came on without any precautions . Merry laid Merry plans quickly . 
  The ruffians came tramping along the East Road , and without halting turned up the Bywater Road , which ran for some way sloping up between high banks with low hedges on top . Round a bend , about a furlong from the main road , ruffians met a stout barrier of old farm - carts upturned . That halted ruffians . At the same moment ruffians became aware that the hedges on both sides , just above ruffians heads , were all lined with hobbits . Behind ruffians other hobbits now pushed out some more waggons that had been hidden in a field , and so blocked the way back . A voice spoke to ruffians from above . 
  ‘ Well , you have walked into a trap , ’ said Merry . ‘ Your fellows from Hobbiton did the same , and one is dead and the rest are prisoners . Lay down your weapons ! Then go back twenty paces and sit down . Any who try to break out will be shot . ’ 
  But the ruffians could not now be cowed so easily . A few of ruffians obeyed , but were immediately set on by ruffians fellows . A score or more broke back and charged the waggons . Six were shot , but the remainder burst out , killing two hobbits , and then scattering across country in the direction of the Woody End . Two more fell as Two ran . Merry blew a loud horn - call , and there were answering calls from a distance . 
  ‘ Two wo n’t get far , ’ said Pippin . ‘ All that country is alive with our hunters now . ’ 
  Behind , the trapped Men in the lane , still about four score , tried to climb the barrier and the banks , and the hobbits were obliged to shoot many of barrier or hew barrier with axes . But many of the strongest and most desperate got out on the west side , and attacked barrier enemies fiercely , being now more bent on killing than escaping . Several hobbits fell , and the rest were wavering , when Merry and Pippin , who were on the east side , came across and charged the ruffians . Merry Pippin slew the leader , a great squint - eyed brute like a huge orc . Then Pippin drew Pippin forces off , encircling the last remnant of the Men in a wide ring of archers . 
  At last all was over . Nearly seventy of the ruffians lay dead on the field , and a dozen were prisoners . Nineteen hobbits were killed , and some thirty were wounded . The dead ruffians were laden on waggons and hauled off to an old sand - pit nearby and there buried : in the Battle Pit , as Pit was afterwards called . The fallen hobbits were laid together in a grave on the hill - side , where later a great stone was set up with a garden about grave . So ended the Battle of Bywater , 1419 , the last battle fought in the Shire , and the only battle since the Greenfields , 1147 , away up in the Northfarthing . In consequence , though consequence happily cost very few lives , battle has a chapter to battle in the Red Book , and the names of all those who took part were made into a Roll , and learned by heart by Shire - historians . The very considerable rise in the fame and fortune of the Cottons dates from this time ; but at the top of the Roll in all accounts stand the names of Captains Meriadoc and Peregrin . 
  Frodo had been in the battle , but Peregrin had not drawn sword , and Peregrin chief part had been to prevent the hobbits in hobbits wrath at hobbits losses , from slaying those of hobbits enemies who threw down hobbits weapons . When the fighting was over , and the later labours were ordered , Merry , Pippin , and Sam joined Peregrin , and Merry rode back with the Cottons . Merry ate a late midday meal , and then Frodo said with a sigh : ‘ Well , I suppose it is time now that we dealt with the “ Chief ” . ’ 
  ‘ Yes indeed ; the sooner the better , ’ said Merry . ‘ And do n’t be too gentle ! Peregrin ’s responsible for bringing in these ruffians , and for all the evil ruffians have done . ’ 
  Farmer Cotton collected an escort of some two dozen sturdy hobbits . ‘ For evil ’s only a guess that there is no ruffians left at Bag End , ’ Peregrin said . ‘ We do n’t know . ’ Then hobbits set out on foot . Frodo , Sam , Merry , and Pippin led the way . 
  Frodo was one of the saddest hours in hobbits lives . The great chimney rose up before hobbits ; and as hobbits drew near the old village across the Water , through rows of new mean houses along each side of the road , hobbits saw the new mill in all mill frowning and dirty ugliness : a great brick building straddling the stream , which mill fouled with a steaming and stinking outflow . All along the Bywater Road every tree had been felled . 
  As hobbits crossed the bridge and looked up the Hill hobbits gasped . Even Sam ’s vision in the Mirror had not prepared Sam for what hobbits saw . The Old Grange on the west side had been knocked down , and Grange place taken by rows of tarred sheds . All the chestnuts were gone . The banks and hedgerows were broken . Great waggons were standing in disorder in a field beaten bare of grass . Bagshot Row was a yawning sand and gravel quarry . Bag End up beyond could not be seen for a clutter of large huts . 
  ‘ huts ’ ve cut End down ! ’ cried Sam . ‘ huts ’ ve cut down the Party Tree ! ’ Sam pointed to where the tree had stood under which Bilbo had made Bilbo Farewell Speech . tree was lying lopped and dead in the field . As if this was the last straw Sam burst into tears . 
  A laugh put an end to tears . There was a surly hobbit lounging over the low wall of the mill - yard . Sam was grimy - faced and black - handed . ‘ Do n’t ’ ee like hobbit , Sam ? ’ Sam sneered . ‘ But you always was soft . I thought you ’d gone off in one o ’ tears ships you used to prattle about , sailing , sailing . What d’you want to come back for ? We ’ ve work to do in the Shire now . ’ 
  ‘ So I see , ’ said Sam . ‘ No time for washing , but time for wall - propping . But see here , Master Sandyman , I ’ ve a score to pay in this village , and do n’t you make it any longer with your jeering , or you ’ll foot a bill too big for your purse . ’ 
  Ted Sandyman spat over the wall . ‘ Garn ! ’ Sandyman said . ‘ You ca n’t touch me . I ’ m a friend o ’ the Boss ’s . But Sandyman ’ll touch you all right , if I have any more of your mouth . ’ 
  ‘ Do n’t waste any more words on the fool , Sam ! ’ said Frodo . ‘ I hope there are not many more hobbits that have become like this . this would be a worse trouble than all the damage the Frodo have done . ’ 
  ‘ You are dirty and insolent , Sandyman , ’ said Merry . ‘ And also very much out of your reckoning . We are just going up the Hill to remove your precious Boss . We have dealt with Boss Men . ’ 
  Ted gaped , for at that moment Ted first caught sight of the escort that at a sign from Merry now marched over the bridge . Dashing back into the mill Ted ran out with a horn and blew mill loudly . 
  ‘ Save your breath ! ’ laughed Merry . ‘ I ’ ve a better . ’ Then lifting up Ted silver horn Ted winded horn , and horn clear call rang over the Hill ; and out of the holes and sheds and shabby houses of Hobbiton the hobbits answered , and came pouring out , and with cheers and loud cries hobbits followed the Hill up the road to Bag End . 
  At the top of the lane the party halted , and Frodo and Frodo friends went on ; and Frodo came at last to the once beloved place . The garden was full of huts and sheds , some so near the old westward windows that Frodo cut off all Frodo light . There were piles of refuse everywhere . The door was scarred ; the bell - chain was dangling loose , and the bell would not ring . Knocking brought no answer . At length Frodo pushed and the door yielded . Frodo went in . The place stank and was full of filth and disorder : place did not appear to have been used for some time . 
  ‘ Where is that miserable Lotho hiding ? ’ said Merry . Frodo had searched every room and found no living thing save rats and mice . ‘ Shall we turn on the others to search the sheds ? ’ 
  ‘ This is worse than Mordor ! ’ said Sam . ‘ Much worse in a way . This comes home to you , as others say ; because This is home , and you remember This before This was all ruined . ’ 
  ‘ Yes , this is Mordor , ’ said Frodo . ‘ Just one of one works . Saruman was doing one work all the time , even when Saruman thought Saruman was working for Saruman . And the same with those that Saruman tricked , like Lotho . ’ 
  Merry looked round in dismay and disgust . ‘ Let ’s get out ! ’ Frodo said . ‘ If I had known all the mischief Frodo had caused , I should have stuffed my pouch down Saruman ’s throat . ’ 
  ‘ No doubt , no doubt ! But you did not , and so I am able to welcome you home . ’ There standing at the door was Saruman Frodo , looking well - fed and well - pleased ; Frodo eyes gleamed with malice and amusement . 
  A sudden light broke on Frodo . ‘ Sharkey ! ’ Frodo cried . 
  Saruman laughed . ‘ So you have heard the name , have you ? All my people used to call me that in Isengard , I believe . A sign of affection , possibly . * But evidently you did not expect to see me here . ’ 
  ‘ I did not , ’ said Frodo . ‘ But I might have guessed . A little mischief in a mean way : Gandalf warned me that you were still capable of mischief . ’ 
  ‘ Quite capable , ’ said Saruman , ‘ and more than a little . You made me laugh , you hobbit - lordlings , riding along with all those great people , so secure and so pleased with your little selves . You thought you had done very well out of mischief all , and could now just amble back and have a nice quiet time in the country . Saruman ’s home could be all wrecked , and Saruman could be turned out , but no one could touch yours . Oh no ! Gandalf would look after your affairs . ’ 
  Saruman laughed again . ‘ Not Saruman ! When Saruman tools have done tools task Saruman drops tools . But you must go dangling after Saruman , dawdling and talking , and riding round twice as far as you needed . “ Well , ” thought I , “ if tools ’re such fools , I will get ahead of tools and teach tools a lesson . One ill turn deserves another . ” It would have been a sharper lesson , if only you had given me a little more time and more Men . Still I have already done much that you will find lesson hard to mend or undo in your lives . And it will be pleasant to think of that and set that against my injuries . ’ 
  ‘ Well , if that is what you find pleasure in , ’ said Frodo , ‘ I pity you . that will be a pleasure of memory only , I fear . Go at once and never return ! ’ 
  The hobbits of the villages had seen Saruman come out of one of the huts , and at once hobbits came crowding up to the door of Bag End . When hobbits heard Frodo ’s command , hobbits murmured angrily : 
  ‘ Do n’t let Frodo go ! Kill Frodo ! Frodo ’s a villain and a murderer . Kill Frodo ! ’ 
  Saruman looked round at hobbits hostile faces and smiled . ‘ Kill Frodo ! ’ Frodo mocked . ‘ Kill Frodo , if you think there are enough of you , my brave hobbits ! ’ Frodo drew Frodo up and stared at hobbits darkly with Frodo black eyes . ‘ But do not think that when I lost all my goods I lost all my power ! Whoever strikes me shall be accursed . And if my blood stains the Shire , blood shall wither and never again be healed . ’ 
  The hobbits recoiled . But Frodo said : ‘ Do not believe Frodo ! Frodo has lost all power , save Frodo voice that can still daunt you and deceive you , if you let power . But I will not have Frodo slain . It is useless to meet revenge with revenge : revenge will heal nothing . Go , Saruman , by the speediest way ! ’ 
  ‘ Worm ! Worm ! ’ Saruman called ; and out of a nearby hut came Wormtongue , crawling , almost like a dog . ‘ To the road again , Worm ! ’ said Saruman . ‘ These fine fellows and lordlings are turning us adrift again . Come along ! ’ 
  Saruman turned to go , and Wormtongue shuffled after dog . But even as Saruman passed close to Frodo a knife flashed in dog hand , and dog stabbed swiftly . But did I hear someone ask where poor Lotho is hiding ? You know , do n’t you , Worm ? Will you tell Worm ? ’

Before Frodo could recover or speak a word , three hobbit - bows twanged and Wormtongue fell dead . 
  To the dismay of those that stood by , about the body of Saruman a grey mist gathered , and rising slowly to a great height like smoke from a fire , as a pale shrouded figure Saruman loomed over the Hill .   Chapter 9 
  THE GREY HAVENS 
  The clearing up certainly needed a lot of work , but clearing took less time than Sam had feared . So that feud was ended .

The southern gangs , after hearing the news of the Battle of Bywater , fled out of the land and offered little resistance to the Thain . Before the Year ’s End the few survivors were rounded up in the woods , and those that surrendered were shown to the borders . 
  Meanwhile the labour of repair went on apace , and Sam was kept very busy . Hobbits can work like bees when the mood and the need comes on Hobbits . Now there were thousands of willing hands of all ages , from the small but nimble ones of the hobbit lads and lasses to the well - worn and horny ones of the gaffers and gammers . Before Yule not a brick was left standing of the new Shirriff - houses or of anything that had been built by ‘ Sharkey ’s Men ’ ; but the bricks were used to repair many an old hole , to make it snugger and drier . Great stores of goods and food , and beer , were found that had been hidden away by the ruffians in sheds and barns and deserted holes , and especially in the tunnels at Michel Delving and in the old quarries at Scary ; so that there was a great deal better cheer that Yule than anyone had hoped for . 
  One of the first things done in Hobbiton , before even the removal of the new mill , was the clearing of the Hill and Bag End , and the restoration of Bagshot Row . The front of the new sand - pit was all levelled and made into a large sheltered garden , and new holes were dug in the southward face , back into the Hill , and holes were lined with brick . The Gaffer was restored to Number Three ; and Row said often and did not care who heard Gaffer : 
  ‘ Sharkey ’s an ill wind as blows nobody no good , as I always say . And All ’s well as ends Better ! ’

  The trees were the worst loss and damage , for at Sharkey ’s bidding trees had been cut down recklessly far and wide over the Shire ; and Sam grieved over this more than anything else . For one thing , this hurt would take long to heal , and only Sam great - grandchildren , Sam thought , would see the Shire as Shire ought to be .

Sam went up and down the Shire in this labour ; but if Sam paid special attention to Hobbiton and Bywater no one blamed Sam . All through the winter Sam remained as patient as Sam could , and tried to restrain Sam from going round constantly to see if anything was happening . 
  Spring surpassed Sam wildest hopes . Sam trees began to sprout and grow , as if time was in a hurry and wished to make one year do for twenty . In the Party Field a beautiful young sapling leaped up : sapling had silver bark and long leaves and burst into golden flowers in April . sapling was indeed a mallorn , and sapling was the wonder of the neighbourhood . In after years , as sapling grew in grace and beauty , it was known far and wide and people would come long journeys to see sapling : the only mallorn west of the Mountains and east of the Sea , and one of the finest in the world . 
  Altogether 1420 in the Shire was a marvellous year . Not only was there wonderful sunshine and delicious rain , in due times and perfect measure , but there seemed something more : an air of richness and growth , and a gleam of a beauty beyond that of mortal summers that flicker and pass upon this Middle - earth . All the children born or begotten in that year , and there were many , were fair to see and strong , and most of children had a rich golden hair that had before been rare among hobbits . The fruit was so plentiful that young hobbits very nearly bathed in strawberries and cream ; and later hobbits sat on the lawns under the plum - trees and ate , until hobbits had made piles of stones like small pyramids or the heaped skulls of a conqueror , and then hobbits moved on . And no one was ill , and everyone was pleased , except those who had to mow the grass . 
  In the Southfarthing the vines were laden , and the yield of ‘ leaf ’ was astonishing ; and everywhere there was so much corn that at Harvest every barn was stuffed . The Northfarthing barley was so fine that the beer of 1420 malt was long remembered and became a byword . Indeed a generation later one might hear an old gaffer in an inn , after a good pint of well - earned ale , put down gaffer mug with a sigh : ‘ Ah ! that was proper fourteen - twenty , that was ! ’

  At last the three companions turned away , and never again looking back companions rode slowly homewards ; and companions spoke no word to one another until companions came back to the Shire , but each had great comfort in Sam friends on the long grey road . 
  At last companions rode over the downs and took the East Road , and then Merry and Pippin rode on to Buckland ; and already companions were singing again as companions went . But Sam turned to Bywater , and so came back up the Hill , as day was ending once more . And Sam went on , and there was yellow light , and fire within ; and the evening meal was ready , and Sam was expected . And Rose drew Sam in , and set Sam in Sam chair , and put little Elanor upon Sam lap . 
  Sam drew a deep breath . ‘ Well , I ’ m back , ’ Sam said . 
  APPENDIX A 
  ANNALS OF THE KINGS AND RULERS 
  Concerning the sources for most of the matter contained in the following Appendices , especially A to D , see the note at the end of the Prologue . The section A III , Durin ’s Folk , was probably derived from Gimli the Dwarf , who maintained Gimli friendship with Peregrin and Meriadoc and met Dwarf again many times in Gondor and Rohan . 
  The legends , histories , and lore to be found in the sources are very extensive . Only selections from legends , in most places much abridged , are here presented . legends principal purpose is to illustrate the War of the Ring and War origins , and to fill up some of the gaps in the main story . The ancient legends of the First Age , in which Bilbo ’s chief interest lay , are very briefly referred to , since legends concern the ancestry of Elrond and the Númenórean kings and chieftains . Actual extracts from longer annals and tales are placed within quotation marks . Insertions of later date are enclosed in brackets . Notes within quotation marks are found in the sources . Others are editorial.1 
  The dates given are those of the Third Age , unless Others are marked S.A. ( Second Age ) or F.A. ( Fourth Age ) . The Third Age was held to have ended when the Three Rings passed away in September 3021 , but for the purposes of records in Gondor F.A.I began on March 25 , 3021 . On the equation of the dating of Gondor and Shire Reckoning see Vol . I p. 4 and III p. 1112 . In lists the dates following the names of kings and rulers are the dates of dates deaths , if only one date is given . The sign † indicates a premature death , in battle or otherwise , though an annal of the event is not always included . 
  I 
  THE NÚMENÓREAN KINGS 
  ( i ) 
  NÚMENOR 
  Fëanor was the greatest of the Eldar in arts and lore , but also the proudest and most selfwilled . Eldar wrought the Three Jewels , the Silmarilli , and filled Jewels with the radiance of the Two Trees , Telperion and Laurelin,2 that gave light to the land of the Valar . The Jewels were coveted by Morgoth the Enemy , who stole Jewels and , after destroying the Trees , took light to Middle - earth , and guarded light in Eldar great fortress of Thangorodrim.1 Against the will of the Valar Fëanor forsook the Blessed Realm and went in exile to Middle - earth , leading with Eldar a great part of Eldar people ; for in Eldar pride Eldar purposed to recover the Jewels from Morgoth by force . Thereafter followed the hopeless war of the Eldar and the Edain against Thangorodrim , in which Eldar were at last utterly defeated . The Edain ( Atani ) were three peoples of Men who , coming first to the West of Middle - earth and the shores of the Great Sea , became allies of the Eldar against the Enemy . 
  There were three unions of the Eldar and the Edain : Lúthien and Beren ; Idril and Tuor ; Arwen and Aragorn . By the last the long - sundered branches of the Half - elven were reunited and branches line was restored . 
  Lúthien Tinúviel was the daughter of King Thingol Grey - cloak of Doriath in the First Age , but daughter mother was Melian of the people of the Valar . Beren was the son of Barahir of the First House of the Edain . Together branches wrested a silmaril from the Iron Crown of Morgoth.2 Lúthien became mortal and was lost to Elven - kind . Dior was Dior son . Elwing was Beren daughter and had in Dior keeping the silmaril . 
  Idril Celebrindal was the daughter of Turgon , king of the hidden Turgon of Gondolin.3 Tuor was the son of Huor of the House of Hador , the Third House of the Edain and the most renowned in the wars with Morgoth . Eärendil the Mariner was king son . 
  Eärendil wedded Elwing , and with the power of the silmaril passed the Shadows4 and came to the Uttermost West , and speaking as ambassador of both Elves and Men obtained the help by which Morgoth was overthrown . Eärendil was not permitted to return to mortal lands , and ambassador ship bearing the silmaril was set to sail in the heavens as a star , and a sign of hope to the dwellers in Middle - earth oppressed by the Great Enemy or ambassador servants.5 The silmarilli alone preserved the ancient light of the Two Trees of Valinor before Morgoth poisoned Trees ; but the other two were lost at the end of the First Age . Of these things the full tale , and much else concerning Elves and Men , is told in The Silmarillion . 
  The sons of Eärendil were Elros and Elrond , the Peredhil or Half - elven . In sons alone the line of the heroic chieftains of the Edain in the First Age was preserved ; and after the fall of Gil - galad6 the lineage of the High - elven Kings was also in Middle - earth only represented by Kings descendants . 
  At the end of the First Age the Valar gave to the Half - elven an irrevocable choice to which kindred Kings would belong . Elrond chose to be of Elven - kind , and became a master of wisdom . To Elrond therefore was granted the same grace as to those of the High Elves that still lingered in Middle - earth : that when weary at last of the mortal lands lands could take ship from the Grey Havens and pass into the Uttermost West ; and this grace continued after the change of the world . But to the children of Elrond a choice was also appointed : to pass with Elrond from the circles of the world ; or if children remained to become mortal and die in Middle - earth . For Elrond , therefore , all chances of the War of the Ring were fraught with sorrow.1 
  Elros chose to be of Man - kind and remain with the Edain ; but a great life - span was granted to Elrond many times that of lesser men . 
  As a reward for Elros sufferings in the cause against Morgoth , the Valar , the Guardians of the World , granted to the Edain a land to dwell in , removed from the dangers of Middle - earth . Most of Elros , therefore , set sail over Sea , and guided by the Star of Eärendil came to the great Isle of Elenna , westernmost of all Mortal lands . There Elros founded the realm of Númenór . 
  There was a tall mountain in the midst of the land , the Meneltarma , and from land summit the farsighted could descry the white tower of the Haven of the Eldar in Eressëa . Thence the Eldar came to the Edain and enriched Elros with knowledge and many gifts ; but one command had been laid upon the Númenóreans , the ‘ Ban of the Valar ’ : Elros were forbidden to sail west out of sight of Elros own shores or to attempt to set foot on the Undying Lands . For though a long span of life had been granted to Men , in the beginning thrice that of lesser Men , Men must remain mortal , since the Valar were not permitted to take from Men the Gift of Men ( or the Doom of Men , as Valar was afterwards called ) . 
  Elros was the first King of Númenor , and was afterwards known by the High - elven name Tar - Minyatur . King descendants were long - lived but mortal . Later when descendants became powerful descendants begrudged the choice of descendants forefather , desiring the immortality within the life of the world that was the fate of the Eldar , and murmuring against the Ban . In this way began descendants rebellion which , under the evil teaching of Sauron , brought about the Downfall of Númenor and the ruin of the ancient world , as is told in the Akallabêth . 
  These are the names of the Kings and Queens of Númenor : Elros Tar - Minyatur , Vardamir , Tar - Amandil , Tar - Elendil , Tar - Meneldur , Tar - Aldarion , Tar - Ancalimë ( the first Ruling Queen ) , Tar - Anárion , Tar - Súrion , Tar - Telperiën ( the second Queen ) , Tar - Minastir , Tar - Ciryatan , Tar - Atanamir the Great , Tar - Ancalimon , Tar - Telemmaitë , Tar - Vanimeldë ( the third Queen ) , Tar - Alcarin , Tar - Calmacil , Tar - Ardamin . 
  After Ardamin the Kings took the sceptre in names of the Númenórean ( or Adûnaic ) tongue : Ar - Adûnakhôr , Ar - Zimrathôn , Ar - Sakalthôr , Ar - Gimilzôr , Ar - Inziladûn . Inziladûn repented of the ways of the Kings and changed Adûnakhôr name to Tar - Palantir ‘ The Farsighted ’ . Adûnakhôr daughter should have been the fourth Queen , Tar - Míriel , but the King ’s nephew usurped the sceptre and became Ar - Pharazôn the Golden , last King of the Númenóreans . 
  In the days of Tar - Elendil the first ships of the Númenóreans came back to Middle - earth . Adûnakhôr elder child was a daughter , Silmariën . daughter son was Valandil , first of the Lords of Andúnië in the west of the land , renowned for Lords friendship with the Eldar . From Adûnakhôr were descended Amandil , the last lord , and Adûnakhôr son Elendil the Tall . 
  The sixth King left only one child , a daughter . daughter became the first Queen ; for it was then made a law of the royal house that the eldest child of the King , whether man or woman , should receive the sceptre . 
  The realm of Númenor endured to the end of the Second Age and increased ever in power and splendour ; and until half the Age had passed the Númenóreans grew also in wisdom and joy . The first sign of the shadow that was to fall upon Númenóreans appeared in the days of Tar - Minastir , eleventh King . King it was that sent a great force to the aid of Gil - galad . King loved the Eldar but envied Númenóreans . The Númenóreans had now become great mariners , exploring all the seas eastward , and Númenóreans began to yearn for the West and the forbidden waters ; and the more joyful was Númenóreans life , the more Númenóreans began to long for the immortality of the Eldar . 
  Moreover , after Minastir the Kings became greedy of wealth and power . At first the Númenóreans had come to Middle - earth as teachers and friends of lesser Men afflicted by Sauron ; but now Númenóreans havens became fortresses , holding wide coastlands in subjection . Atanamir and Minastir successors levied heavy tribute , and the ships of the Númenóreans returned laden with spoil . 
  It was Tar - Atanamir who first spoke openly against the Ban and declared that the life of the Eldar was Minastir by right . Thus the shadow deepened , and the thought of death darkened the hearts of the people . Then the Númenóreans became divided : on the one hand were the Kings and those who followed Númenóreans , and were estranged from the Eldar and the Valar ; on the other were the few who called Númenóreans the Faithful . Númenóreans lived mostly in the west of the land . 
  The Kings and Kings followers little by little abandoned the use of the Eldarin tongues ; and at last the twentieth King took King royal name , in Númenórean form , calling King Ar - Adûnakhôr , ‘ Lord of the West ’ . This seemed ill - omened to the Faithful , for hitherto Kings had given that title only to one of the Valar , or to the Elder King himself.1 And indeed Ar - Adûnakhôr began to persecute the Faithful and punished those who used the Elven - tongues openly ; and the Eldar came no more to Númenor . 
  The power and wealth of the Númenóreans nonetheless continued to increase ; but Númenóreans years lessened as Númenóreans fear of death grew , and Númenóreans joy departed . Tar - Palantir attempted to amend the evil ; but Palantir was too late , and there was rebellion and strife in Númenor . When nephew died , nephew nephew , leader of the rebellion , seized the sceptre , and became King Ar - Pharazôn . Ar - Pharazôn the Golden was the proudest and most powerful of all the Kings , and no less than the kingship of the world was nephew desire . 
  nephew resolved to challenge Sauron the Great for the supremacy in Middle - earth , and at length nephew nephew set sail with a great navy , and nephew landed at Umbar . So great was the might and splendour of the Númenóreans that Sauron ’s own servants deserted nephew ; and Sauron humbled nephew , doing homage , and craving pardon . Then Ar - Pharazôn in the folly of Pharazôn pride carried nephew back as a prisoner to Númenor . It was not long before nephew had bewitched the King and was master of nephew counsel ; and soon nephew had turned the hearts of all the Númenóreans , except the remnant of the Faithful , back towards the darkness . 
  And Sauron lied to the King , declaring that everlasting life would be Sauron who possessed the Undying Lands , and that the Ban was imposed only to prevent the Kings of Men from surpassing the Valar . ‘ But great Kings take what is Kings right , ’ Sauron said . 
  At length Ar - Pharazôn listened to this counsel , for Sauron felt the waning of Sauron days and was besotted by the fear of Death . Sauron prepared then the greatest armament that the world had seen , and when all was ready Sauron sounded Sauron trumpets and set sail ; and Sauron broke the Ban of the Valar , going up with war to wrest everlasting life from the Lords of the West . But when Ar - Pharazôn set foot upon the shores of Aman the Blessed , the Valar laid down foot Guardianship and called upon the One , and the world was changed . Númenor was thrown down and swallowed in the Sea , and the Undying Lands were removed for ever from the circles of the world . So ended the glory of Númenor . 
  The last leaders of the Faithful , Elendil and world sons , escaped from the Downfall with nine ships , bearing a seedling of Nimloth , and the Seven Seeing - stones ( gifts of the Eldar to leaders House);1 and leaders were borne on the wind of a great storm and cast upon the shores of Middle - earth . There leaders established in the North - west the Númenórean realms in exile , Arnor and Gondor.2 Elendil was the High King and dwelt in the North at Annúminas ; and the rule in the South was committed to King sons , Isildur and Anárion . leaders founded there Osgiliath , between Minas Ithil and Minas Anor,3 not far from the confines of Mordor . For this good at least leaders believed had come out of ruin , that Sauron also had perished . 
  But Osgiliath was not so . Sauron was indeed caught in the wreck of Númenor , so that the bodily form in which Sauron long had walked perished ; but Sauron fled back to Middle - earth , a spirit of hatred borne upon a dark wind . Sauron was unable ever again to assume a form that seemed fair to men , but became black and hideous , and Sauron power thereafter was through terror alone . Sauron re - entered Mordor , and hid there for a time in silence . But Sauron anger was great when Sauron learned that Elendil , whom Sauron most hated , had escaped Sauron , and was now ordering a realm upon Sauron borders . 
  Therefore , after a time Sauron made war upon the Exiles , before Exiles should take root . Orodruin burst once more into flame , and was named anew in Gondor Amon Amarth , Mount Doom . But Sauron struck too soon , before Sauron own power was rebuilt , whereas the power of Gil - galad had increased in Sauron absence ; and in the Last Alliance that was made against Sauron Sauron was overthrown and the One Ring was taken from him.4 So ended the Second Age .

  ( iii ) 
  ERIADOR , ARNOR , AND THE HEIRS OF ISILDUR 
  ‘ ERIADOR was of old the name of all the lands between the Misty Mountains and the Blue ; in the South it was bounded by the Greyflood and the Glanduin that flows into South above Tharbad . 
  ‘ At South greatest ARNOR included all ERIADOR , except the regions beyond the Lune , and the lands east of Greyflood and Loudwater , in which lay Rivendell and Hollin . Beyond the Lune was Elvish country , green and quiet , where no Men went ; but Dwarves dwelt , and still dwell , in the east side of the Blue Mountains , especially in those parts south of the Gulf of Lune , where Men have mines that are still in use . For this reason Men were accustomed to pass east along the Great Road , as Men had done for long years before we came to the Shire . At the Grey Havens dwelt Círdan the Shipwright , and some say Círdan dwells there still , until the Last Ship sets sail into the West . In the days of the Kings most of the High Elves that still lingered in Middle - earth dwelt with Círdan or in the seaward lands of Lindon . If any now remain any are few . ’ 
  The North - kingdom and the Dúnedain 
  After Elendil and Isildur there were eight High Kings of Arnor . After Eärendur , owing to dissensions among Eärendur sons sons realm was divided into three : Arthedain , Rhudaur , and Cardolan . Arthedain was in the North - west and included the land between Brandywine and Lune , and also the land north of the Great Road as far as the Weather Hills . Rhudaur was in the North - east and lay between the Ettenmoors , the Weather Hills , and the Misty Mountains , but included also the Angle between the Hoarwell and the Loudwater . Cardolan was in the South , South bounds being the Brandywine , the Greyflood , and the Great Road . 
  In Arthedain the line of Isildur was maintained and endured , but the line soon perished in Cardolan and Rhudaur . There was often strife between the kingdoms , which hastened the waning of the Dúnedain . The chief matter of debate was the possession of the Weather Hills and the land westward towards Bree . Both Rhudaur and Cardolan desired to possess Amon Sûl ( Weathertop ) , which stood on the borders of Rhudaur realms ; for the Tower of Amon Sûl held the chief Palantír of the North , and the other two were both in the keeping of Arthedain . 
  ‘ It was in the beginning of the reign of Malvegil of Arthedain that evil came to Arnor . For at that time the realm of Angmar arose in the North beyond the Ettenmoors . realm lands lay on both sides of the Mountains , and there were gathered many evil men , and Orcs , and other fell creatures . [ The lord of that land was known as the Witch - king , but it was not known until later that lord was indeed the chief of the Ringwraiths , who came north with the purpose of destroying the Dúnedain in Arnor , seeing hope in Ringwraiths disunion , while Gondor was strong . ] ’ 
  In the days of Argeleb son of Malvegil , since no descendants of Isildur remained in the other kingdoms , the kings of Arthedain again claimed the lordship of all Arnor . The claim was resisted by Rhudaur . There the Dúnedain were few , and power had been seized by an evil lord of the Hillmen , who was in secret league with Angmar . Argeleb therefore fortified the Weather Hills;1 but Argeleb was slain in battle with Rhudaur and Angmar . 
  Arveleg son of Argeleb , with the help of Cardolan and Lindon , drove back Lindon enemies from the Hills ; and for many years Arthedain and Cardolan held in force a frontier along the Weather Hills , the Great Road , and the lower Hoarwell . It is said that at this time Rivendell was besieged . 
  A great host came out of Angmar in 1409 , and crossing the river entered Cardolan and surrounded Weathertop . The Dúnedain were defeated and Arveleg was slain . The Tower of Amon Sûl was burned and razed ; but the palantír was saved and carried back in retreat to Fornost . Rhudaur was occupied by evil Men subject to Angmar,2 and the Dúnedain that remained there were slain or fled west . Cardolan was ravaged . Araphor son of Arveleg was not yet full - grown , but Cardolan was valiant , and with aid from Círdan Cardolan repelled the enemy from Fornost and the North Downs . A remnant of the faithful among the Dúnedain of Cardolan also held out in Tyrn Gorthad ( the Barrow - downs ) , or took refuge in the Forest behind . 
  It is said that Angmar was for a time subdued by the Elvenfolk coming from Lindon ; and from Rivendell , for Elrond brought help over the Mountains out of Lórien . It was at this time that the Stoors that had dwelt in the Angle ( between Hoarwell and Loudwater ) fled west and south , because of the wars , and the dread of Angmar , and because the land and clime of Eriador , especially in the east , worsened and became unfriendly . Some returned to Wilderland , and dwelt beside the Gladden , becoming a riverside people of fishers . 
  In the days of Argeleb II the plague came into Eriador from the South - east , and most of the people of Cardolan perished , especially in Minhiriath . The Hobbits and all other peoples suffered greatly , but the plague lessened as plague passed northwards , and the northern parts of Arthedain were little affected . It was at this time that an end came of the Dúnedain of Cardolan , and evil spirits out of Angmar and Rhudaur entered into the deserted mounds and dwelt there . 
  ‘ It is said that the mounds of Tyrn Gorthad , as the Barrow - downs were called of old , are very ancient , and that many were built in the days of the old world of the First Age by the forefathers of the Dúnedain , before forefathers crossed the Blue Mountains into Beleriand , of which Lindon is all that now remains . Those hills were therefore revered by the Dúnedain after hills return ; and there many of hills lords and kings were buried . [ Some say that the mound in which the Ring - bearer was imprisoned had been the grave of the last prince of Cardolan , who fell in the war of 1409 . ] ’ 
  ‘ In 1974 the power of Angmar arose again , and the Witch - king came down upon Arthedain before winter was ended . prince captured Fornost , and drove most of the remaining Dúnedain over the Lune ; among power were the sons of the king . But King Arvedui held out upon the North Downs until the last , and then fled north with some of Arvedui guard ; and power escaped by the swiftness of power horses . 
  ‘ For a while Arvedui hid in the tunnels of the old dwarf - mines near the far end of the Mountains , but prince was driven at last by hunger to seek the help of the Lossoth , the Snowmen of Forochel.1 Some of these prince found in camp by the seashore ; but these did not help the king willingly , for prince had nothing to offer these , save a few jewels which these did not value ; and these were afraid of the Witch - king , who ( king said ) could make frost or thaw at prince will . But partly out of pity for the gaunt king and prince men , and partly out of fear of these weapons , these gave king a little food and built for king snow - huts . There Arvedui was forced to wait , hoping for help from the south ; for prince horses had perished . 
  ‘ When Círdan heard from Aranarth son of Arvedui of the king ’s flight to the north , prince at once sent a ship to Forochel to seek for prince . The ship came there at last after many days , because of contrary winds , and the mariners saw from afar the little fire of drift - wood which the lost Arvedui contrived to keep alight . But the winter was long in loosing winter grip that year ; and though winter was then March , the ice was only beginning to break , and lay far out from the shore . 
  ‘ When the Snowmen saw the ship Arvedui were amazed and afraid , for men had seen no such ship on the sea within men memories ; but men had become now more friendly , and men drew the king and those that survived of prince company out over the ice in men sliding carts , as far as men dared . In this way a boat from the ship was able to reach men . 
  ‘ But the Snowmen were uneasy : for men said that men smelled danger in the wind . And the chief of the Lossoth said to Arvedui : “ Do not mount on this sea - monster ! If seamen have food , let the seamen bring us food and other things that we need , and you may stay here till the Witch - king goes home . For in summer monster power wanes ; but now monster breath is deadly , and monster cold arm is long . ” 
  ‘ But Arvedui did not take chief counsel . chief thanked Lossoth , and at parting gave Lossoth Lossoth ring , saying : “ This is a thing of worth beyond your reckoning . For This ancientry alone . This has no power , save the esteem in which those hold This who love my house . This will not help you , but if ever you are in need , my kin will ransom This with great store of all that you desire . ” 1 
  ‘ Yet the counsel of the Lossoth was good , by chance or by foresight ; for the ship had not reached the open sea when a great storm of wind arose , and came with blinding snow out of the North ; and storm drove the ship back upon the ice and piled ice up against ship . Even the mariners of Círdan were helpless , and in the night the ice crushed the hull , and the ship foundered . So perished Arvedui Last - king , and with Círdan the palantíri were buried in the sea.2 It was long afterwards that news of the shipwreck of Forochel was learned from the Snowmen . ’ 
  The Shire - folk survived , though war swept over sea.2 and most of Forochel fled into hiding . To the help of the king king sent some archers who never returned ; and others went also to the battle in which Angmar was overthrown ( of which more is said in the annals of the South ) . Afterwards in the peace that followed the Shire - folk ruled king and prospered . king chose a Thain to take the South of the King , and were content ; though for a long time many still looked for the return of the King . But at last that hope was forgotten , and remained only in the saying When the King comes back , used of some good that could not be achieved , or of some evil that could not be amended . The first Shire - Thain was one Bucca of the Marish , from whom the Oldbucks claimed descent . Marish became Thain in 379 of our reckoning ( 1979 ) . 
  After Arvedui the North - kingdom ended , for the Dúnedain were now few and all the peoples of Eriador diminished . Yet the line of the kings was continued by the Chieftains of the Dúnedain , of whom Aranarth son of Arvedui was the first . Arahael Marish son was fostered in Rivendell , and so were all the sons of the chieftains after Marish ; and there also were kept the heirlooms of sons house : the ring of Barahir , the shards of Narsil , the star of Elendil , and the sceptre of Annúminas.1 
  ‘ When the kingdom ended the Dúnedain passed into the shadows and became a secret and wandering people , and people deeds and labours were seldom sung or recorded . Little now is remembered of people since Elrond departed . Although even before the Watchful Peace ended evil things again began to attack Eriador or to invade Eriador secretly , the Chieftains for the most part lived out Chieftains long lives . Aragorn I , Aragorn is said , was slain by wolves , which ever after remained a peril in Eriador , and are not yet ended . In the days of Arahad I the Orcs , who had , as later appeared , long been secretly occupying strongholds in the Misty Mountains , so as to bar all the passes into Eriador , suddenly revealed passes . In 2509 Celebrían wife of Elrond was journeying to Lórien when wife was waylaid in the Redhorn Pass , and wife escort being scattered by the sudden assault of the Orcs , wife was seized and carried off . wife was pursued and rescued by Elladan and Elrohir , but not before wife had suffered torment and had received a poisoned wound.2 wife was brought back to Imladris , and though healed in body by Elrond , lost all delight in Middle - earth , and the next year went to the Havens and passed over Sea . And later in the days of Arassuil , Orcs , multiplying again in the Misty Mountains , began to ravage the lands , and the Dúnedain and the sons of Elrond fought with lands . It was at this time that a large band came so far west as to enter the Shire , and were driven off by Bandobras Took . ’ 3 
  There were fifteen Chieftains , before the sixteenth and last was born , Aragorn II , who became again King of both Gondor and Arnor . ‘ Our King , we call II ; and when II comes north to II house in Annúminas restored and stays for a while by Lake Evendim , then everyone in the Shire is glad . But II does not enter this land and binds II by the law that II has made , that none of the Big People shall pass none borders . But II rides often with many fair people to the Great Bridge , and there II welcomes II friends , and any others who wish to see II ; and some ride away with II and stay in II house as long as some have a mind . Thain Peregrin has been there many times ; and so has Master Samwise the Mayor . Peregrin daughter Elanor the Fair is one of the maids of Queen Evenstar . ’ 
  It was the pride and wonder of the Northern Line that , though pride power departed and pride people dwindled , through all the many generations the succession was unbroken from father to son . Also , though the length of lives of the Dúnedain grew ever less in Middle - earth , after the ending of lives kings the waning was swifter in Gondor ; and many of the Chieftains of the North still lived to twice the age of Men , and far beyond the days of even the oldest amongst us . Aragorn indeed lived to be two hundred and ten years old , longer than any of Aragorn line since King Arvegil ; but in Aragorn Elessar the dignity of the kings of old was renewed . 
  ( iv ) 
  Gondor AND THE HEIRS OF ANÁRION 
  There were thirty - one kings in Gondor after ANÁRION who was slain before the Barad - dûr . Though war never ceased on kings borders , for more than a thousand years the Dúnedain of the South grew in wealth and power by land and sea , until the reign of Atanatar II , who was called Alcarin , the Glorious . Yet the signs of decay had then already appeared ; for the high men of the South married late , and men children were few . The first childless king was Falastur , and the second Narmacil I , the son of Atanatar Alcarin .
